title: CAMBODIA RENEWS TROOPISSUE PLEA
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 31The Government disclosed today that it had renewed an earlier appeal to the Soviet Union and Britain, cochairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1954, to send the International Control Commission back to investigate its charge that North Vietnam and the Viet cong were stepping up their military activities against Cam bodia.

title: Books of The Times
description: ON May 17, 1968, nine men and women entered the offices of Local Board No. 33 in Catonsville, Md., expro priated 378 individual draft files, carried those files in two wire baskets to the parking lot and burned them with a crude form of napalmtwo parts gasoline, one part soap flakesmixed according to a recipe discovered in the Green Berets' Special Fortes Handbook. The Catons ville Nine then waited 15 minutes for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to arrive and arrest them. On Oct. 5, 1968, they stood trial in a Baltimore Federal court, and on Oct. 9 they were convicted of de stroying United States property, destroy ing Selective Service records and interfer ing with the Selective Service Act of 1967. They were, they are, all Christians, in cluding thre priests and an exnun, and they were bearing witness. To what? To the fact that people who use napalm on pieces of paperor death certificates, as one of the Nine called the draft files go to jail; and people who use napalm on people do not go to jail.

title: CHRISTIAN VIEWS OF ISRAEL STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The American Jewish Commit tee said today that Roman Catholic and Protestant opinion, as reflected in major periodicals published throughout the coun try, has recently shown increas ing understanding of Israel's security needs and increasing support of Israel's sovreignty.

title: Catholic Schools Urged to Stress Distinctiveness
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 31 The new trend for Roman Catholic schools will be toward a kind of institution that will complement the public schools but not imitate them, the pres ident of the National Catholic Educational Association said today.

title: Advertising: Auto Racing Aids Marketing
description: Agencies seem to be able to think up imaginative and creative titles for their imagi native and creative people, but isn't vice president for racing a little bit much? Not if it's auto racing and not if the agency is in Indianapolis.

title: Census Opens Today With Goal of Full Count
description: Dick Gregory tells a story of a young censustaker who tries unsuccessfully to get into a building in a black community. Undaunted, she looks at the size of the building and estimates about 12 occupants.

title: Sam Thong, Key Laotian Town, Reported Retaken From Enemy
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 31 in an unexpected show of strength, Laotian troops have driven North Vietnamese sol diers from several hilltop posi tions overlooking Sam Thong and reentered the mountain valley town, 80 miles northeast of here, it was reported today.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS PICK SLATE TODAY
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., March 31Most of the 345 members of the Democratic State Com mittee and 1,000 more politi cians crowded into Grossinger's resort hotel today and seemed to divide quickly into two groups  those for Arthur J. Goldberg and those against.

title: Embattled Knicks and Bullets Are Starting All Over Again
description: BALTIMORE, March 31  It's a new series now. We're both starting from scratch, commented Gus Johnson in the steamy, noisy, happy Baltimore Bullets' dressing room tonight after his club had evened its National Bas ketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff set at two games apiece with a 10292 victory over the New York Knicks.

title: A Decade Ago, Bill Blass Wouldn't Admit He Was a Designer
description: LA GRENOUILLE was a patchwork quilt of carefully cultivated coun try flowers, gleaming silver, starched napery and beautiful people as Bill Blass walked through the door. His pereniallytanned face broke into a genial smile; his clear blue eyes crinkled with recognition. The waves and hellos and cheektouching  the rituals of success in the right industry, at the right time, with the right peoplebegan.

title: PLAN WITHDRAWN FOR PLANT ON L.I.
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 31 A plan to construct a $150 million oil  desulphurization plant on the shore of the Long Island Sound was scuttled to day in the wake of mounting local protest against the dan ger of the pollution the plant might cause.

title: Mutual Fund Chief Sees Change
description: John C. Bogle, a leading mutualfund executive and chairman of the industry's principal trade association, charged yesterday emphasis on a one number approach to measuring performance had proved unfortunate. One result has been that a trend toward broader gauges of success has already begun, he added.

title: Train to Be Discontinued
description: CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) The Milwaukee Road said to day that it intends to discon tinue its Pioneer Limited, which for decades afforded luxury overnight service between Chi cago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Minneapolis.

title: PAKISTANI IS FIRM ON CIVILIAN RULE
description: RAWALPINDI Pakistan, March 31President Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan, in an unusually candid news confer ence, said today that he would tolerate no resistance to his restoration of civilian rule, even if this meant using the army to deal with the resisters.

title: Seminary to Hold Annual Luncheon
description: At the annual luncheon of the National Benefactors So ciety tomorrow at the Pierre, the Jewish Theological Semi nary of America will honor five women for leadership in religious and civic causes.

title: Jewish Forward Names Aide
description: Paul F. Rubinstein, assistant general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward for the last five years, has been elected general manager of the Yiddishlan guage newspaper. Mr. Rubin stein, whose new position was announced by the board of di rectors of the Forward Associa tion, has been with the paper since 1954.

title: 6MONTH TERM SET IN VIETNAM DEATH
description: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 31A military court sentenced First Lieut. James B. Duffy to six months in confine ment today in what the court decided was the involuntary manslaughter of an unarmed Vietnamese prisoner.

title: American Head Hunters
description: Millions of Americans spent last weekend warming up for their 1969 Federal income tax that is due April 15 and also pondering the newly arrived 1970 Bureau of the Census form, returnable today. The former counts your money; the latter counts you.

title: AnsweringSerice Union To Vote on Contract Offer
description: A strike by the city's tele phone answeringservice opera tors appeared yesterday to have been avoided by a lastminute offer from the employers that grants most of the demands of the operators' union.

title: Moscow Assails Peking Again on Border Activity
description: MOSCOW, March 31The Soviet Defense Ministry news paper today accused Com naunist China of an openly provocative increase of its military preparedness in areas bordering the Soviet Union and Mongolia.

title: Joseph Henry Neebe, 82, Advertising Agency Aide
description: Joseph Henry Neebe, a for mer advertising executive who was active in the theater, died March 24 at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert S. Bunge, in New Canaan, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived at 251 East 51st Street.

title: Sports Car Club Will Distribute Road Racing Annual This Month
description: THE Sports Car Club of America will begin distrib uting this month the 1970 edition of The Road Racing Annual, a 36page reference work containing race results, schedules and a variety of other racing information. The Annual is edited by the able Venlo Wolfsohn of Washing ton, who is well known for his ex pertise in racing statistics. This is the eighth year Wolfsohn and the S.C.C.A. have cooperated in producing the booklet. The 1970 edition will be spon sored by Sears, Roebuck and Co., which is getting into motor racing this year through several approaches. The sponsorship enables the club to send copies to its membership and to the racing community. The club and Sears also will offer bulk supplies at less than cost.

title: U.S. and Cambodia Agree On Return of Hijacked Ship
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The State Department said today that agreement in principle had been reached with the Cambodian Government for the release of the United States munitions ship Columbia Eagle.

title: Art: The Omega Series
description: HOW do you like your Mor ris Louis? Dry, as in the unfurled paintings of 1960? Rich and fullbodied, like the bronze veil series of 1958? Or with a light, evanescent bouquet, as in the 1960 floral naintines?

title: JOHN GRAHAM PLAYS NEW CHAMBER MUSIC
description: John Graham is really too good a Violist to be as self effacing as he was in his con cert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. By putting two mod ern chambermusic works at the heart of his program, he took so much attention away from himself and the viola that at least one listener began to wonder just whose concert it was.

title: City Police Get $38,324 Fund To Develop Heroin Sniffer
description: WASHINGTON, March 31At torney General John N. Mitchell announced today a $38,324 grant to the New York Police Depart ment to help finance develop ment of a scientific sniffer to detect large quantities of heroin.

title: SOVIET PARENTS BID SON END FAST AT U.N.
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (Reu ters)The parents of Yakov Kazakov appealed to him today to end a hunger strike he began seven days ago on their behalf outside United Nations head quarters.

title: Ann C. Kennedy Is Married Here
description: Miss Ann Cecily Kennedy and Allen G. BedynekStumm were married here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by Msgr. Andrew F. Quinn, Epis copal Vicar of the Borough of Richmond, who also cele brated the nuptial mass.

title: Democrats Pick Engineer To Oppose Reid for Congress,
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 31 The Westchester Democratic Executive Committee last night designated G. Russell James, a chemical engineer from Ar monk, to run for the House of Representatives from the 26th District against the Republican incumbent. Ogden R. Reid.

title: DR. EDWARD S. O'KEEFE
description: BOSTON, March 31Dr. Ed ward Scott O'Keefe, a pedia trician, died Sunday night at Massachusetts General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: PRICES DIP AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices continued to ease in slow trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Court's Ruling on Trial Disruptions
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court opinion by Justice Huge L. Black in the case of William Allen, who was convicted in Illinois for armed robbery after being expelled from the courtroom following several outbursts:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Twist, Same Crime
description: The bizarre touch added to the style of airliner hijackingthe brandishing of samurai swords by the Japanese students demanding to be taken to North Koreamust not deflect attention from the enormity of this crime. The lives of 138 persons were endan gered by the antics of this selfstyled Red Army, which boasted of bombs as well as swords.

title: HelpWanted Advertising Holds Ground After Dror
description: Help  wanted advertising, which declined sharply from October through January, lev eled off in February, the Na tional Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. The index on classified advertising for help, stood at 203 per cent of the 195759 average in Feb ruary, unchanged from January, but 26 points below February of 1969.

title: CYRUS M'CORMICK, 79, OF REAPER COMPANY
description: HARTEORD, March 31  Cyrus McCormick, former vice president and director of the International Harvester Com pany and grandson of the in ventor, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in a hos pital here. He was 79 years old and had lived here for about 15 years. He retired in 1931.

title: 34,000 Tax Refunds Sent A Month Early by City
description: The city mailed 34,000 tax refund checks yesterday, the earliest this had ever been done, according to Finance Ad ministrator Fioravante G. Per rotta.

title: Suffolk Democrats Name U.S. and State Candidates
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., March 31  The Suffolk County Demo cratic Committee recessed its nominating convention early this morning after designating Harvey W. Sherman, a lawyer from Babylon, to oppose Rep resentative James Grover Jr., a Republican, in the Second Con gressional District. Representative Otis G. Pike was desig nated for renomination in the First District.

title: Rangers Start Road Back to East Playoff Berth Tonight in Game With Leafs
description: BRANTFORD, Ontario, March 31As the Ranger bus sped through beautiful downtown Brantford today, en route to the Civic Center, Walt Tkaczuk asked slyly, Hey, coach, can I skate tonight?

title: NIGH COURT BACKS GAGGING TO CURB TRIAL DISORDERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Supreme Court said today that trial judges could have dis ruptive defendants bound and gagged, jailed for contempt of court or expelled from court if such measures were necessary to preserve order.

title: PRINTER MEETINGS HEED AT THE TIMES
description: The typographical union ap plied economic pressures on The New York Times yester day by holding meetings of printers on each shift and in terrupting production in the newspaper's composing room.

title: Houghton to Make 1970 Debut At Yonkers Raceway on Friday
STATE SENATE ACTS TO SPUR BUILDING
description: ALBANY, March 31 The Senate passed a bill today de signed to spur the state's slug gish homebuilding industry by creating a state mortgage agen cy with an authorization to sell $750million in taxexempt bonds.

title: Forecast for Today: Maybe More of Same
description: A man in New Rochelle, N. Y., looked out of his bedroom window yesterday morning and said:

title: Ford Subsidiary in Britain Follows Price Rises There
description: LONDON, Wednesday, April 1 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company, Ltd., today became the third major British auto manufacturer to announce price increases this year because of higher production costs.

title: U.S. Jet Downs Hanoi MIG In Battle Over the North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1A United States Navy F4 Phantom jet fighterintercepter shot down a North Vietnamese MIG21 jet fighter over North Vietnam last Saturday, spokesmen for the United States military com mand reported yesterday.

title: Bank Purchase Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The Federal Reserve Board ap proved unanimously today the acquisition by Charter New York Corporation, a large bank hold ing company, of the Ogdensburg Trust Company, the only bank with headquarters in Ogdens burg, N. Y. The chief subsidiary of Charter New York is the Irvine Trust Company.

title: Missile Site Contract
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Army awarded a $137million contract today for construction of the first Safe guard antimissile site in the Grand Forks, N. D., area. The contract went to a joint ven ture concern headed by the Morrison  Knudsen Company. Boise, Idaho. A second site is to be built near Malmsstrorn Air Force Base in Montana contracts for building this base have not yet been awarded.

title: Engineering Study Of Bergen Transit Is Vetoed by Cahill
description: TRENTON, March 31 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill, exercis ing a Governor's veto power of New Jersey Turnpike Author ity minutes for the first time, has blocked an engineering study of a combined superhigh way, and rapidtransit line in nortthwestern Bergen County.

title: The Dance: Feld Rejoins His Troupe
M.T.A. Narrows Its Decision On Wall Street PeopleMovers
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority has narrowed its choice of peoplemovers to ease congestion in the down town financial area from 115 kinds of hardware to about seven, according to Dr. Wil liam J. Ronan, chairman of the agency.

title: Departure of British Celebrated by Libyans
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 31  Libya was gaily decorated today to celebrate the com pletion of British troop evac uation from the country. The day was proclaimed a nation al holiday, and raliles were organized in every town and village.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP AS VOLUME EASES
description: The stock market chugged along in low gear yesterday and finished with price declines leading advances by a narrow margin.

title: Tatham Division Picked By Deltona Corporation
description: The Deltona Corporation, the Florida builders, have tapped Tatham & Weihs as its agency.

title: An Action Scene
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, April I thought they were filming an action scene, 12yearold Yoshitaka Uga. said.

title: National City's Chairman Sees Continuing FallinInterest Rates
description: The chairman of the First National City Bank predicted yesterday that the whole pat term of interest ratesinclud ing the prime interest rate on bank loans to businesswould contine to decline in the months ahead.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1970

title: Midtown Hotel Raid Nets 60 Pounds of Pure Heroin
description: More than 60 pounds of pure heroin, reportedly one of the largest hauls of narcotics made recently, were seized yesterday by the police in a raid in a Times Square hotel. Two men were taken into custody.

title: Podgorny Leaves Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 31 (Reuters)President Nikolai Y. Podgorny of the Soviet Union left here today after a sixday state visit and talks with the Shah Mohammed Reza Pahievi, and Iranian Government minis ters. The talks centered on plans for increasing trade, eco nomic and technical coopera tion.

title: Racing at Narragansett Off
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., March 31 (AP)A spring snowstorm re sulted in cancellation of racing today at Narragansett Park. Of ficials at the track said racing would resume tomorrow.

title: Venezuela Signs for $100Million Loan
description: Agreement for a $100mil lion loan to Venezuela by a 16bank syndicate was com pleted yesterday at the main offices of the Chase Manhat tan Bank, which headed the lending group.

title: A Black Radical Is Ordered To Appear on Gun Charge
description: DETROIT, March 31 (UPI) Robert F. Williams, the former black revolutionary who re turned to the United States to face kidnapping charges, was ordered today to appear for a Federal court hearing on a charge of transporting a gun from Canada into the United States while under criminal indictment.

title: El Paso Gas Co. Orders 2 Tankers at $100Million
description: An $100million order for two tankers to carry liquefied naturalgas, said to be the larg est of their type in the world, was placed with a French ship yard yesterday by the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

title: Guatemala Terrorists Kidnap West German Envoy on Street
description: GUATEMALA, March 31 Count Karl von Spreti, the West German Ambassador to Guate mala, was kidnapped by terror ists shortly after noon today.

title: UTILITY OFFERING IS WELL RECEIVED
Papal Trip to Sardinia Is Set, First in 17 Centuries
description: ROME, March 31The Vati can announced today that Pope Paul VI would make a oneday visit to Cagliari, the capital of Sardinia, on April 24. He will be the first Pontiff to go to the economically backward island in more than 17 centuries.

title: ASSOCIATED CHAIN POSTS PROFIT DIP
Claire Ruestow Will Be Bride Of George J. Telecki on May 2
description: Miss Claire Ruestow, a greatgreatgranddaughter of President Ulysses S. Grant, and George J. Telecki, plan to be married on May 2 at the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N. Y.

title: Polio Victim, 22, Is Denied License to Teach in City's Schools
description: Judy Heumann, a 22yearold honor graduate of Long Island University who has never been able to walk because of polio, has charged that the Board of Examiner's refusal to license her to teach in city schools discriminates against the phys ically handicapped.

title: G.O.P. Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)  Richard W. Gabbett, director of communications for the Republican National Com mittee, resigned today to be come a Washington consultant in political comumnications and government relations.

title: A Worldly Christian
description: IN September, 1937, a 21 year old graduate of Tem ple University showed up at the Episcopal Theological School in Cambridge, Mass., with one small suitcase. He was there to see whether he liked seminary life, and it took two weeks for him to decide to send for the rest

title: POSTMEN RESTIVE OVER WAGE TALKS
description: The possibility of a recur rence of the postal strike was raised yesterday by union lead ers of 20,000 letter carriers in New York City and on Long Island.

title: MAILMEN OFFERED 12% RISE IN WAGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Government has made an unconditional offer of a 12 per cent pay increase to the postal workers, half of it retro active to Oct. 1 and half to be effective next July 1.

title: Theater: Borstal Boy
description: A STAGE, a few lights and an actor, Niall Toibin. Mr. Toibin looks at the audi ence and for a shocked in stant, Brendan Behan, Dub lin's own darling, roaring boy is among us again. The resemblence is uncanny. The moment passes, but its spe cial magic endows the Abbey Theater's adaptation of Bor stal Boy, which opened last night at the Lyceum Theater, with a strange authenticity.

title: DECISION DUE TODAY ON M'LAIN'S STATUS
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said last night he had reached a decision in the case of Denny McLain, the suspend ed Detroit pitcher, and would announce it today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Madame Lhevinne Going Strong at 90
description: It was Rosina Lhevinne's 90th birthday party, but it looked like a scene from Queen Victoria's court. The world's most famous piano teacher sat in her famous greenupholstered throne last night in a reception area at the Juilliard School, receiving homage from a starry assem blage.

title: Bullets Quell Late Knick Rallies and Win, 10292, Squaring Playoffs at 22
description: BALTIMORE, March 31In another rousing game, in which that famous term momentum swung back and forth like a runaway pendu??, the Balti more Bullets de?? the New York Knicks tonight, 10292, and evened their fourofseven playoffs series at two games apiece.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Vietnam: Moral Issue

title: Miss Casals Upsets Mrs. Jones, 62, 62, and Gains So. African Semifinals
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 (UPI)Little Rosemay Casals of San Fran cisco upset Mrs. Ann Jones of England, 62, 62, today and gained the semifinals of the $49,000 South African open tennis championships.

title: There's More Than Alcindor To Bucks' Rise as Contenders
description: The Milwaukee Bucks are not volunteering to do what the University of California at Los Angeles did this season. They will try to win their cham pionship with Lew Alcindor, not without him.

title: Rise Reported in U.S. Youths Jailed in Foreign Drug Cases
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The State Department said today there had been a 300 per cent increase in the last year in the number of young Americans jailed in for eign countries for narcotics vio lations.

title: Lehn & Fink Leaving D. D. B. for SSC&B
description: Beacon Wax, Glisade Fabric Finish, Glis Spray Starch and Down  the  Drain are leaving the house of Doyle Dane Bern bach to join Jato and a whole bunch of Lysol products at SSC&B.

title: San Diego Enrolls Kretzer
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 31 (UPI)The San Diego Rockets of the National Basketball As sociation today signed their sixthround draft choice, Mike kretzer, a forward from East Tennessee state.

title: Justices Rule Guilt in Juvenile Cases Must Be Beyond Reasonable Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Supreme Court ruled to day that juvenile courts may not convict children unless they are found guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, as in adult trials.

title: Athenagoras in Vienna
description: VIENNA, March 31 The Ecumenical Patriarch of Con stantinople, Athenagoras I, ar rived here today for a medical checkup at the clinic of Prof. Karl Fellinger, a specialist in internal medicine. The Patri arch is 84 years old.

title: Ice Delays Fall Starts Of Seaway's Season
description: MASSENA, N.Y., March 31 (AP)The severe winter has blocked plans to open the St. Lawrence Seaway to gen eral navigation tomorrow morning. Ice remains in the river between Montreal and Massena.

title: TUGMEN TO VOTE A NEW OFFER
description: Tugboat workers who went out on strike Feb. 1 will vote this morning on a new manage ment offer.

title: New Quakes Kill 100 More in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 31 A new series of more than 300 earth tremors was recorded in the last 24 hours in the Anatolia region of Turkey, raising sharply today the offi cial figures for dead and in jured in the earthquake dis aster that began Saturday night.

title: Wheelson 150,000 G.M. Trucks Called Unsafe in Suit by Nader
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Ralph Nader and other safety crusaders filed suit here today in an effort to establish that the wheels on 150,000 General Motors pickup trucks were in herently unsafe.

title: Saigon's Raid in Cambodia Stirs U.S. Aides' Concern
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1The South Vietnamese Army's penetration of Cambodian territory last week has caused considerable concern among United States diplomats here.

title: Hydrofoil to Be Scrapped
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 31 (UPI)The $800,000 hydrofoil Sun Arrow left for Italy today on the deck of the freighter Callao. It will be sold for scrap in a Messina shipyard. The hydrofoil first suffered about 50 per cent damage two weeks ago when it ran aground on a reef off Puerto Rico. A 150 ton crane used to hoist the hydrofoil onto the deck of the Callao then fell on it, complet ing the damage.

title: What Role for Banks?
description: This is a time of troubles in Wall Street. The scattered failures in the brokerage corn munity, the Populist drive in Congress to restrict the banks in their future diversification, and perhaps most importantly the collapse of the homebuilding mar ket due to the shortage of mort gage money all bespeak a malaise to which the country's political leadership is now starting to respond. Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, certainly speaks only for his own special constituency when he suggests that now is the time to burn the banks.

title: Plays and Stars Nominated for Tonvs
description: Borstal Boy, Child's Play, Indians and Last of the Red Hot Lovers have been nominated in the best play category for the 1970 Antoinette Perry Awards. Applause, Coco and Purlie have won nomina tions for best musical.

title: TRUCKING TALKS ARE BROKEN OFF
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The nation's trucking industry and the International Brother hood of Teamsters recessed their negotiations early this evening, letting the clock run down on their threeyear na tional contract.

title: FUND LACK CITED IN SPACE PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration budget will have to start growing again if plans for a manned reusable space shuttle are to be realized. Dr. Wernher von Braun, the space agency's top planning of ficer, said today.

title: Comden and Green Talk All About the New Bacall Hit
description: The critics adored Bacall, praised the rest of the cast, found the music at least serv iceable, and cheered the book of Broadway's new hit musi cal, Applause, which opened Monday night at the Palace.

title: New Tremors in Italy
description: POZZUOLI, Italy, March 31 (Reuters)  Four minor earth tremors were detected at this ancient Roman port over the weekend, bringing the total in recent weeks to 12, scientists said today. The latest tremors were not felt by residents.

title: Specialists Ask Early CheckUp On Infants' Hearing Problems
description: Auditory specialists said yes terday that too many children with hearing difficulties were not identified in the first months of life, when treatment of the problem is best able to prevent impairment of language development.

title: REV.DR.KITAGAWA OF WORLD COUNCIL
description: GENEVA, March 31  The Rev. Dr. Daisuke Kitagawa, an American Episcopal clergyman attached to the Geneva head quarters of the World Council of Churches, died of a heart attack on Friday at the age of 59.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, March 31, 1970 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Undersea Study Delayed
description: BEEHIVE COVE, St. John's, Virgin Island, March 31The start of a sevenmonth under water research program has been delayed 48 hours, from tomorrow until Friday, because some equipment for the labora tory on the sea floor has not arrived. The project is called Tektite 2.

title: In Memoriam
description: DAVISMarilyn Elaine. Time cannot leal the wound of your passing or dim the brightness of your memory.

title: PERFECT FILM SEES 35MILLLION '69 LOSS
description: Sheldon Feinberg, president since last September of the Perfect Film and Chemical Cor poration, informed the New York Stock Exchange yester day that the concern had an es timated loss of $35million in 1969.

title: Films Are Backdrop For Robust Dances Of Yvonne Rainer
description: The dance world of the cho reographer Yvonne Rainer is bounded by the physical prop erties of objects and people. They run,roll,ljump, fall, tumble and occasionally colapse. Last night at the Whitney Museum of American Art she present ed Continuous ProjectAltered Daily, a piece of amorphic va riety that draws and feeds upon itself.

title: SONIC JET PROJECT SHIFTED BY VOLPE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)William M. Magruder of the Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion was named today to be director of development of the supersonic transport plane in a shift of the, program from the Federal Aviation Administration to the Transportation Secre tary's office.

title: State's New Welfare Rates Called Praiseworthy, but Too Small
description: Jack R. Goldberg, the city's Social Services Commissioner, said yesterday that the new welfare grants enacted by the state were a step in the right direction but would still fall short of enabling relief recipi ents to catch up with the rising costs of living here.

title: Abortion Reform Now
description: The good faith of the Republican leadership in the State Legislature is at test in the battle over abortion reform, an idea whose time not only has come but is long overdue. The manner in which a strong reform bill was maneuvered into defeat in the Assembly this week after its surprise passage in the Senate raises questions about the sincerity of the G.O.P. high command in Albany.

title: $3.4Billion Surplus Arms Given to Allies in 19 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The State Department disclosed today that used military equip ment valued originally at $3.4 billion had been given to al lied governments over the last 19 years.

title: Mrs. Kinsey at 73: Some Topics Taboo
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind.  it's cold bright and snowy in Bloomington, and the blue jays, screaming in the sunlight, wheel through the blue sky. The tree branches are lumpy with tight buds. The crocuses are purple and yellow blossoms against the snow. According to Mrs. Alfred C. Kinsey, It's getting to be that time of year again.

title: MRS. DEANE EDWARDS OF RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: ROCHESTER, March 31Mrs. Margaret Dulles Edwards, a former director of religious edu cation at the Riverside Church, and a sister of the late Secre tary of State John Foster Dulles, died Sunday in Strong Me morial Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in Holly Lane. Rve. N. Y.

title: RICHARD MARSHALL OF PITTSBURGH COKE
description: PITTSBURGH, March 31 Richard Mather Marshall, for mer board chairman of the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old. He retired in 1961.

title: Life Is Not So Simple Now in Cambodian Capital
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 31All is simple, why complicate things?

title: LONG BRANCH TIES TO MAFIA RELATED
description: TRENTON, March 31The State Commission of Investiga tion, opening public hearings into alleged corruption in the shore community of Long Branch, heard testimony today about Mafia penetration of the courts, the police and the city administration there.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 1, 1970

title: RENT CONTROL LAW EXTENDED 3 YEARS BY COUNCIL'S VOTE
description: The city's controversial 27 yearold rentcontrol law was extended for three years yester day by the City Council.

title: 20 British Soldiers Hurt in New Clash In Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, April 1 (Reuters) A fresh clash between British troops and hostile Catholic republicans early today flared into the city's worst rioting this year. More than 20 sol diers were injured.

title: 63 Million Families to Mail Data for Decennial Survey
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Sometime tomorrow, like people in 63 million other American families, a Wash ington resident will fill out a questionnaire.

title: Indian Communist Leader Escapes Sniper at Depot
description: NEW DELHI, March 31  A Left Communist leader, Jyoti Basu, narrowly escaped today when a sniper fired at him in a crowd at Patna Railroad Station in Bihar State. The bullet killed the man standing beside Mr. Basu.

title: MAN SOUGHT HERE SEIZED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, March 31A Brook lyn man who allegedly shot and killed his commonlaw wife Sunday and then set a fire that cost five other lives was ar rested yesterday when he was spotted driving through Rox bury.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS BACK CARSWELL
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Two influential Republican Senators, George D. Aiken of Vermont and John J. Williams of Delaware, announced today that they would support the Supreme Court nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell.

title: MISS VERRETT JOINS AIDA AS AMNERIS
description: Of all the Metropolitan Opera's standard repertory productions, none is richer in the simple minded pleasures than its Aida, with its Theda Bara staging and Catfish Row ballets. Last night's performance, the season's ninth, introduced two new members to the familiar cast, and they subordinated their talents to the sublime ab surdity of the show, which can stand, teeteringly, as a monu ment to the state of opera in 1970.

title: KARL BERGER & CO. GIVE JAZZ CONCERT
description: Pools of calm serenity alter nated with agitated flurries of sound last night in a jazz con cert by Karl Berger and Com pany in the. Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York Uni versity. Mr. Berger, a vibra harpist. Mr. Berger, a vibraharp ist, led a group made up of Carlos Ward, alto saxophone and flute, Dave Holland, bass, and J. C. Moses, drums.

title: POLICEMAN LINKED TO ARGENTINE PLOT
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 31 Argentine authorities disclosed last night that a deputy inspec tor of Argentina's federal police had led the attempt to kidnap a Soviet diplomat Sunday.

title: Pilots' Move to Milwaukee Is Cleared by Court Decision
description: SEATTLE, March 31 (UPI) A Federal bankruptcy court referee granted owners of the financiallyplagued Seattle Pi lots permission tonight to sell their oneyearold American League baseball franchise to Milwaukee interests.

title: ISRAELI JETS RESUME RAIDS ON NILE DELTA
description: JERUSALEM, March 31 Israeli jets returned to the Nile Delta today with two at tacks against SAM2 antiaircraft sites near Mansura. Targets along the Suez Canal also were hit, officials here reported.

title: 50,000 Downtown Employes To Stagger Work Hours
description: About 50,000 employes of 45 private and public concerns in Manhattan's downtown fina cial district will break out of the traditional 9to5 officehour pattern today in a cooperative effort to ease the strains of peakhour commuting.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER TO RETURN TO LISBON
description: Mario Soares, a Portuguese opposition leader jailed repeat edly for his views, is going home after breathing the free air of the United States and finding it good.

title: Nixon Announcement Expected On Further Troop Withdrawals
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Pentagon officials said today that they expected President Nixon to announce further troop withdrawals from South Vietnam sometime in April, de spite reports that some top military men were urging a delay in the next phase of the withdrawals.

title: Panel Upholds 3Pilot Rule On U.A.L. Boeing 737 Jets
description: Manning United Air Lines Boeing 737 jets with three pilots instead of two consti tutes a meaningful addition to safety, an arbitration panel ruled yesterday.

title: DOLLY MADISON TO SELL DIVISION
description: Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., has agreed in principle to sell its ice cream operations and furniture manufacturing divi sion to two companies in trans actions valued at more than $21million.

title: Cambodians Welco me but Censor Foreign Newsmen
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 31Leaders of the new Cam bodian regime, unlike the de posed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, have wel comed foreign correspondents.

title: Jargon Collector Finds Capital a Rich Source
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)Robert A. Podesta, an Assistant Secretary of Com merce who collects Washing ton jargon, has cited these examples in a speech:

title: Washington: For The Record
description: March 31, 1970

title: Metals Concern Indicted Here for Violation of Trade Sanctions Against White Rebel Regime in Rhodesia
description: A New York importexport concern was indicated by a Federal grand jury here yes terday on charges of conspir ing to violate regulations im posing economic sanctions on Rhodesia.

title: Sesame Street Writes New Chapters in Success
description: Sesame Street, public tele vision's highly acclaimed chil dren's program, is on its way to becoming an electronic insti tution. These recent develop ments emphasize its spreading influence:

title: Justice Black Rejects Delay In Florida School Integration
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Justice Hugo L. Black turned down today a bid to delay full integration of schools in Manatee County, Fla., by next Monday.

title: Air Force Raises Negro To Brigadier General
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird helped yes terday to pin a brigadier general's star on Daniel Chap pie James, who thus became the highestranking Negro in the Air Force.

title: ALLISON OF TWINS IS PUT ON WAIVERS
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 (AP)  The Minnesota Twins placed Bob Allison, an out fielder, on waivers and sent 11 players to their minor league camp today as they trimmed the squad to within one of the 25player limit.

title: FIRST WOMAN DEAN IS NAMED AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, March 31 For the first time in the 269 year history of Yale University, a woman has been named dean of one of the school's 12 resi dential colleges.

title: YANKS' 8RUN 9TH BEATS TWINS, 92
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 John Ellis continued to tear up the Grapefruit League today, and made it almost certain he would be in the Yankees' start ing lineup on opening day next Tuesday.

title: Heinrich Bruning, Chancellor Of Germany Before Hitler, Dies
description: NORWICH, Vt., March 31 (AP)HeinrichBriining, Chan cellor of Germany in the last months before Hitler took pow er, died yesterday in this com munity where he had spent his last years. He was 84 years old.

title: Mrs. Fischer, William Wrigley Marry on Coast
description: William Wrigley, president tf the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Com pany, the chewing gum con cern, and Mrs. Joan Fischer of New York were married last Thursday in Avalon, Calif. Judge Herbert Camer on performed the ceremony at the old Wrigley home on the hill overlooking Avalon Bay on Santa Catalina Island.

title: DONALD M. GOODYEAR
description: NORWALK, Conn., March 31 Donald M. Goodyear, mort gage secretary of the Guardian Life Insurance Company in New York, died in Norwalk Hospital last night of a heart attack. Mr. Goodyear, who lived at 91 East Rocks Road, was 60 years old.

title: SEMINARY ELECTS AN EPISCOPALIAN
description: The Right Rev. J. Brooke Mosley, deputy for overseas re lations of the Episcopal Chruch, was chosen yesterday to be the 12th president of Union Theological Seminary.

title: Leaking Gulf Well Smothered by Mud As Jury Starts Study
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (UPI)The well that spilled thousands of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico was smothered by tons of mud to day shortly before a Federal grand jury began investigation of offshore drilling violations.

title: N.Y.U. Medical Chief Named
description: Dr. Clark T. Randt has been appointed chairman of the new ly established department of neurology at New York Univer sity's School of Medicine.

title: Western Union and Utility Blocked on Rate Increases
description: ALBANY, March 31 (AP) The Public Service Commission today blockedat least tempo rarily  rate increases planned by Western Union and the Cen tral Hudson Gas & Electric Cor poration.

title: Schayes Will Coach Buffalo N.B.A. Team
description: BUFFALO, March 31 (UPI) Dolph Schayes signed a mul tiyear contract today to coach Buffalo's expansion entry in the National Basket ball Association.

title: Market Place:
description: PERHAPS a word should be said in behalf of the mu tual fund industry, which rightly or wrongly believes it is fighting for its life in Washington today.

title: Girl Jockey Takes Mud Bath, but It's Not for Beauty
description: Robyn Smith frowned when a freshly painted sign that said Girl Jockey was removed from the door of her dressing room yester day at Aqueduct.

title: PIRATES TRIUMPH OVER METS, 12 TO 3
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 What do the New York Mets need to win the pennant again?

title: Big Four to Draft Report On Their Mideast Efforts
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union agreed today to have their deputies draft a report on the results of nearly a year of Big Four meetings in search of peace between Israel and the Arabs.

title: Gulf Reports Oil Discover Off the Coast of Nigeria
description: The Gulf Oil Company re ported yesterday an impor tant wildcat discovery in Ni geria. The company said the offshore Nigerian well is north of previously discovered off shore fields and will substan tially increase the company's producing capacity.

title: Builders Seek Air Space Over Entrance to Tunnel
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority is talking with developers about erecting a large office building over the Manhattan entrance to the BrooklynBattery Tunnel.

title: LINDSAY TO SPEAK AT PEACE RALLY
description: Mayor Lindsay will speak at a Vietnam peace rally April 15 in Bryant Park, the Vietnam Moratorium and Peace Parade Committees announced yester day. Mr. Lindsay's office said the Mayor had accepted the in vitation of the organizers.

title: Poor Nations Given Assurance on Trade
description: GENEVA, March 31  The United States sought to assure the developing countries today of the genuineness of its offer to permit broad categories of their products to enter the American market free of tariffs.

title: Athens Newspaper Officials Before a Military Tribunal
description: ATHENS, March 31Yiannis Kapsis, editor of the newspa per Ethnos, its three publishers and its managing editor ap peared before a military tri bunal today to answer charges that an interview they had pub lished on the Cyprus situation had caused anxiety to the average Greek and constituted antinational propaganda.

title: ALBANY INCREASES AID FOR EDUCATION
description: ALBANY, March 31 The Legislature today passed the educationaid formula for the coming school year with a $388million increase that, in effect, repealed many of the economies approved a year ago at Governor Rockefeller's re quest.

title: BOMB PLANT FOUND BY CHICAGO POLICE
description: CHICAGO, March 31 AP) The police have uncovered what they described as a bomb factory in a North Side apart ment building, they reported finding 59 sticks of dynamite, an explosive liquid, weapons and ammunition.

title: Foreman Stops Brassel
description: HOUSTON, March 31 (AP) The former Olympic heavy weight champion, George Fore man of Houston, took only 2 minutes 42 seconds of the first round tonight to knock out Rufus Brassel of Miami Beach. It was Foreman's 18th victory against no defeats. Brassel now has an 183 wonlost record.

title: NORTH STARS TOP KINGS, GAIN 4TH
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 31 (AP) Billy Collins broke in for his 27th and 28th goals and set up a third tonight as the Minnesota North Stars stuck Los Angeles with a rec ordtying 52 National Hockey League loss and moved into fourth place in the West Di vision.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: E. 5TH ST. VICTIM CALLED BOMBER
description: The police said yesterday that they had identified Ishmael Brown, the City College student killed last Saturday in an ex plosion in an East Fifth Street apartment, as the man who planted a bomb in the Electric Circus, an East Village disco theque.

title: U.S. Aide Favored For Ginsberg's Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Jule M. Sugarman, who di rected Head Start, one of the more successful Federal anti poverty programs, is expected to be named head of the New York City Human Resources Administration later this year, city officials disclosed today.

title: Gilbert Accepts Caps' Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)  The Washington Caps signed James Gilbert, a 7footer from Adams State, to a one year contract today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 31If you don't hit on this ball club, said Richie Hebner, you feel very em barrassed. Not one to be discomforted, even by the besthitting team in baseball, the Pirates, the then 21yearold third baseman responded emphatically to the company he was keeping. He batted .301, the only rookie regular in either league to go over the magic .300 mark.

title: Southern Yemen Executes 9 As Plotters Against State
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, March 31Nine men have been executed by firing squads in Southern Yemen during the last two weeks after having been convicted of subversion and conspirancy against the state.

title: Major Moviemakers Agree to a FairHiring Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Seventytwo movie and tele vision production companies agreed today to an equalem ployment plan that includes hiring, training and upgrading of minorities and sets racial quotas.

title: Bridge:
description: THE Spring National Cham pionships of the American Bridge Association begin to day in Cincinnati at the SheratonGibson Hotel with strong representation from the New York metropolitan area.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
Foreign Affairs: Europe Is as Russia Does
description: BRUSSELS  United States policy favors supranationalism among its friends and national ism among its enemies and in this respect its diplomacy bears broad resemblance to that of the Soviet Union. By one means or another, since World War II, we have tried to sponsor re gional groups in Western Eu rope and Latin America. How ever, this has been patently a coin with two sides.

title: Dentzer, Economic Aide, Named State Banking Superintendent
description: ALBANY, March 31Gover nor Rockefeller's office said to day that William T. Dentzer Jr., executive secretary of the State Council of Economic Ad visers, has been named acting Superintendent of Banks.

title: Hijacked Jet Still in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednes day, April 1  A Japanese air liner was still on the ground at Kimpo Airport here last night after authorities gave up on a fivehour attempt to convince a group of hijackers that they had landed in North Korea, not South Korea.

title: Liberal Plan Approved
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 31 The General Assembly ap proved today a bill that would make Maryland's abortion law the most liberal in the nation.

title: FISCHER ADJOURNS HIS 2DROUND GAME
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31Bobby Fischer, eighttime United States chess champion, adjourned his sec ondround game today with Tigran Petrosian, former world champion, of the Soviet Union. Fischer was a pawn ahead.

title: Topics: In Search of Sixth Avenue
description: At four o'clock on a Friday afternoon not so long ago a visitor hurried into the lobby of an office building on the Avenue of the Americas. His appointment was with a man reported to know all about West Road, enlarged in 1810 to a hundredfoot thoroughfare. Its name was subsequently changed to Sixth Avenue, thus becoming the first boulevard and first numbered street in New York. In 1945, by official edict, it became the Avenue of the Americasthe most con fusing and appealing street name between Fifth and Sev enth Avenues.

title: Loretto Mead Will Be a July Bride
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 31  Miss Loretto O'Brien Mead and Robert J. Bradley, who has served as a first lieutenant in the Connecticut National Guard, have made plans to be married here in July.

title: ALLAN M'DOUGALL
description: EASTHAMPTON, L. I., March 31Allan MacDougall, former vice president and sales mana ger of the International Divi sion of National Distillers Prod ucts Company of New York, died after a heart attack at his home here today. He was 76 years old.

title: Rep. John Dowdy of Texas Is Indicted on Charges That He Took $25,000 in an Alleged Bribe Conspiracy
description: BALTIMORE, March 31A Federal grand jury investigating reported conflicts of interest by members of Congress indicted Representative John Dowdy, a veteran Texas Democrat, today on charges that he accepted $25,000 in an alleged bribery conspiracy with Washington area home remodelers.

title: Bradshaw and Phipps Dealing Without Aid of 10PerCenters
description: Terry Bradshaw and Mike Phipps, the two college ath letes who will command the largest contracts from pro football this year, have sig nificantly eschewed the help of the hustling agents, the 10percenters who now abound in professional sports. Perhaps an age of reason is coming to pro football, which started the move toward big contracts with the famous Sonny WerblinJoe Namath $400,000 pact of five years ago.

title: The Army's Indiscretion
description: Recent disclosures in The Washington Monthly that the Army is operating an extensive political intel ligence network raise the specter of secret military power undermining civilian rule. The American Civil Liberties Union has challenged in court what appears to be an unauthorized system of surveillance under control of the Defense Department. The A.C.L.U. charges that by maintaining dossiers on political dis senters, a special intelligence branch with some 300 offices throughout the country potentially violates the rights of free speech, association and privacy.

title: MARCOS DISCOUNTS U.S. FUNDING DISPUTE
description: MANILA, March 31 President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called the issue of American funding of the Philippine contingent to Vietnam an internal quarrel be tween the two political parties in the United States who were dragging in the Philippines.

title: 134 Wall Street Lawyers Criticize Behavior of Judge Hoffman
description: A group of 134 young lawyers from Wall Street firms have signed a petition asking for an investigation and possible censure and removal of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoff man, who conducted the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial.

title: Tunney's Daughter Ordered Held at Hearing on Death
description: LONDON, March 31A Ches ham magistrate today ordered Mrs. Joan Wilkinson, daughter of Gene Tunney, former world heavyweight boxing champion, to be held in custody on a charge of murdering here 31 yearold husband, Lynn Carter Wilkinson Jr. The next pretrial hearing will be on April 8.

title: COPPER FUTURES RIDE A SEESAW
description: Copper futures drew a flurry of interest during the trading session yesterday on a report of labor difficulties at the Rhokana Corporation's mines in Zambia.

title: Move Hailed in Britain
description: LONDON, March 31The in dictment of the Muller com pany was welcomed here as further evidence of American determination to support diplo matic efforts against the Rho desian rebels.

title: Late Snowfall Pleases Ski Operators
description: AT a time of year when rec reational skiing, usually prepares for its annual fade out, snow running centers throughout the East are still presenting a midwinter pic ture.

title: Imports of Gold Decline To a SevenMonth Low
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (Reuters)United States gold imports in February reached their lowest level in seven months, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Mansfield Urges Nixon Not to Aid the Cambodians
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Senator Mike Mansfield of Mon tana, urged President Nixon to day not to extend military aid to Cambodia and thus become more deeply engaged in South east Asia.

title: EXPLORER I DIES; 12 YEARS IN ORBIT
description: Explorer 1, the first Ameri can earth satellite, the first to record the earthgirdling radia tion belts and the oldest man made object in space, plunged back into the earth's atmos phere yesterday after 12 years in orbit.

title: SwingWing Jet Undergoes Tests for Wing Strength
No Comment by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change declined to comment yesterday on published reports that Baerwald & DeBoer, a small member firm, had entered liquidation. The reports said liquidation had been necessi tated by an inability to meet the exchange's minimum capital re quirements because of certain litigation that had encumbered the firm's funds.

title: Premier's Brother Slain
description: PNOMPENH, March 31A brother of Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol, the Cambodian Premier, was stabbed to death last Saturday at his home in Chup, near the troubled city of Kompong Chain, by a gang of Vietnamese rubber plantation workers.

title: W. W. Lewis 3d, Ellen Anschuetz Wed in Lebanon
description: Miss Ellen Anschuetz and Welbourne Walker Lewis 3d of Boston were married on Monday in the American Com munity Church of Beirut, Leb anon, by the Rev. Romaine Swedenbourg, a Methodist who is pastor of the inter denominational community church.

title: N.B.C. Ordered to Give Private Fliers a Forum
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Government told the National Broadcasting Com pany that it had violated the fairness doctrine with news re ports critical of the nation's private pilots. It asked the net work to take appropriate steps to achieve fairness.

title: Executive Changes
description: Richard P. Gifford has been elected a vice presi dent of the General Electric Company, in the company's communication systems division.

title: Miss Darcy Somber Is Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Somber have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Darcy Somber, to Richard Katz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Katz. Bott families reside in Bayside, Queens.

title: REORGANIZATION HITS CHAMPAGNE
description: PARIS, March 31  Those magic vineyards in an irregular triangel of northeastern France where dreams of affluence are bottled under old family names like Mot et Chandon, Mumm and Taittinger are going through their biggest financial reorganization in centuries as part of the drive toward French industrial concentration.

title: Who Fired Accidental Shot in Newark City Hall?
description: NEWARK, March 31A shot heard round City Hall was be ing investigated by the police today on the possibility that it had come from a weapon ac cidently dropped by Anthony Imperiale, a Councilman and candidate for Mayor.

title: Smith Out of Caribe Tennis; Ayala, 37, Topples Barth
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 31 (Reuters)  Gerald Battrick, Britain's secondranked player, defeated Joaquin Loyo Mayo of Mexico, 63, 61, in the second round of the Caribe Hil ton international tennis tourna ment today.

title: Trust Suit Names Utility
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Justice Department today filed a civil antitrust suit charging the Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha with monopolizing the sale of nat ural gas to industrial customers in Minnesota and Michigan. The department said it also had filed a proposed consent decree settle the complaint.

title: ExI.R.S. Aide Held In 1967 Kidnapping Of Youth on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP)The county grand jury indicted a former Internal Revenue Service agent today for the 1967 kidnapping of Kenneth Young, son of a Bev erly Hills financier.

title: Phelps Dodge Raises Copper Price 7%
description: The Phelps Dodge Corpora tion, the nation's second largest producer of domestic copper, raised the price of the metal by 7 per cent yesterday. The quotation for copper mined in the United States was in creased, effective today, to 60 cents a pound from 56 cents.

title: High Court Ruling on Behavior Is Seen Speeding Panther Case
description: Assistant District Attorney Jo seph A. Phillips said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court decision on how judges may treat unruly defendants would no doubt expedite pre trial hearings of 13 Black Panthers.

title: BEAM PRESSES DRIVE ON BUILDING
description: Hammering away on a favor ite theme, the city's need for a construction czar to speed public building projects, City Controller Abraham D. Beame accused the Lindsay administra tion yesterday of having a bleak record in building schools and hospitals.

title: WITNESSES ACCUSE SENATOR ADAMS
description: Two witnesses at the trial of State Senator William E. Adams testified here yesterday that Senator Adams had asked them to give false testimony to a Federal grand jury.

title: COUPLE IS FOUND SLAIN IN JERSEY
description: OLDWICK, N. J., March 31 (AP)A man and his wife were found shot to death in their home in this welltodo Hun terdon County conummity to day in what the state police described as an apparent mur dersuicide.

title: Sheila Moran Florida Bride
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., March 31Miss Sheila Kath leen Moran, daughter of Rear Adm. Edmond J. Moran, U.S.N.R., retired, and Mrs. Moran of Darien, Conn., and Gulf Stream, Fla., and John Edward Wells, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Wells of Lee, Mass., were married this afternoon by the Rev. John A. Skehan of St. Vincent Fer rer Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Norfolk Plans Controversial School Integration Based on Coleman Report
description: NORFOLK, Va.This port city of 315,000 peoplewhich closed six of its schools rather than desegregate them a decade agois planning a citywide venture in racial integration that is said to be the first in the country based on the findings of the Coleman Report.

title: Cutting into the Bone
description: President Nixon's Vietnamization program is ap proaching a critical test of credibility this month as the third phase of announced American troop with drawals from Southeast Asia nears completion.

title: Fashion Show on April 15 to Aid St. Luke's Hospital
description: Rummage and a $15 ticket will admit members of the Auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospi tal and their guests to a luncheon and fashion show April 15 at the Plaza.

title: New Vote Due Next Week
description: ALBANY, March 31Re fusing to accept defeat, spon sors of the bill that would lib eralize the state's abortion law, which failed in the Assembly yesterday, are keeping the bill alive and hope for another vote next week.

title: UNION HEAD URGES END OF AIR TIEUP; RESPONSE IN DOUBT
description: F. Lee Bailey, executive di rector of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organiza tion, announced yesterday that he was urging the controllers to end their sevenday work stoppage against the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Premier Assails Hanol
description: VIENTIANE, March 31 Prince Souvanna Phouma, Pre mier of Laos, said in an inter view today that the Communist regime in Hanoi was seeking to reconstitute Indochina un der its oun authority.

title: Morgenthau Assails Governor on Crime
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, for Imer United States Attorney now seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, yes terday attacked Governor Rock efeller and the state's Water front Commissionerand came under fire himself for his tactics.

title: Knicks Face Bullets at Garden In 5th Game of Series Tonight
Slump in Italy's Movie Industry Is Not MakeBelieve
description: ROME, April 1The hap piest rumor making the rounds of Italy's depressed movie industry is that Amer ican producers have agreed to finance the making of 20 films here this year.

title: Dance: '51 Street Games
description: THE inclusion of modern dance works in the companies is no longer a novelty, in this country at least, and the American Ballet Company headed by Eliot Feld, is no exception.

title: Lacey Says Ties Of Gross to Union Are Under Inquiry
description: TRENTON, April 1  Fred erick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said tonight that Nelson G. Gross, the Republican State Chairman and the party's lead ing contender foh its senatorial nomination, was being inves tigated for an alleged involve ment with a labor union that is said to be dominated by the Mafia.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements man be tele phoned to OXford 5SS11 until 11 P.M. in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:39 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark (201) MArket 3.3900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) IVanhos 36660: Commack (516) 5??5400; Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: BIG STEEL MAKERS MATCH PRICE RISE
description: Price increases of about 4.5 per cent on most steelbar products, were assured of in dustry acceptance yesterday when the two largest steel com panies in the nation and a third major concern announced that they would match the action of the Republic Steel Corporation.

title: Bronx to Discuss Future of Its Show
description: THE Bronx County Kennel Club show, forced out doors last Saturday when the Kingsbridge Armory became unavailable on short notice because of National Guard occupancy, will be reviewed by the members at a meeting next Wednesday. The future of the 48yearold fixture also will be dis cussed.

title: Songmy Captain Accused Of Responsibility in Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Capt. Ernest L. Medina was ac cused by the Army today of being responsible for the mur der of Vietnamese civilians al legedly killed by members of his infantry company in the vil lage of Songmy two years ago.

title: Sunbury Paper Sold
description: SUNBURY, Pa., April 1 (AP) The Sunbury Daily Item has been purchased by a wholly owned Pennsylvania subsidiary of Ottaway NewspapersRadio, Inc., of Campbell Hall, N. Y. An nouncement of the sale, effec tive April 15, was made today by Harry H. Haddon, president and publihser of The Daily Item, and James H. Ottaway Sr., chairman of the board of Otta way Newspapers.

title: Judge Orders Hickel to Delay Permit for Alaska Pipeline, Road
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A Federal judge granted a tempo rary restraining order today prohibiting Secretary of the In terior Walter J. Hickel from Issuing permits for the construc tion of an Alaska oil pipeline and a parallel road for much of its length.

title: Soviet Airline to Serve Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet airline Aeroflot will link Vientiane with Hanoi and Mos cow under a new agreement with the Laotian Government, it was announced here today. Under the previous aviation agreement between the two countries, Soviet aircraft were only allowed to enter Laotian airspace in an emergency.

title: Evers Asks Whites To Aid the Growth Of South's Industry
description: Charles Evers, Mayor of Fayette, Miss., charged here last night that white business men had not done enough to locate industrial plants in the South and thereby provide more fobs for Negroes.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK GOLDBERG BUT HE WAIVES SELECTION; PLANS A RACE BY PETITION;
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Thurs day, April 2Arthur J. Gold berg won the Democratic State Committee's designation for Governor last night and then threw the committee meeting into chaos by announcing that he would waive the designa tion to prove he was not the creature of the bosses.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES to Angeles 113, New York 101.

title: Researchers Cast Doubt on Finding That Water Can Be Converted to a Dense, VaselineLike Form
description: One of the most extraordi nary scientific findings of re cent yearsthat water can be made to assume a dense, Vase linelike formhas been called into question by two groups of researchers, working inde pendently.

title: Teachers Defy Court Order
description: WOBURN, Mass., April 1 (UPI)Teachers defied a court order against striking the city's public schools today, and war rants were issued for seven members of the Woburn Teach ers Association. The walkout closed 14 of the city's 15 schools. The teachers voted 218 to 112 to strike last night when their contract expired. They are seeking a $7,300 to $11,700 pay scale, while the city offered $7,100 to 10,900.

title: In The Nation: The TicketBalancing Problem
description: Arthur Goldberg no doubt ex pressed what a good many people think should be the case when he told the New York Democratic convention yester day that the party should re pudiate the concept that eth nic considerations should play a determining part in electing candidates to public office. But, in fact, they often do play such a part, and many times they should.

title: U.S. Court of Appeals Here Will Take Up the Question of Long Delays in Trials
description: The United States Court of Appeals decided unanimously yesterday to take up the ques tion of long delays in the trial of criminal cases here and else where in the state at a hearing this spring on Foley Square.

title: Lennon Exhibitor Draws Picasso Into His Defense
description: LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) A court was asked today to de cide whether a drawing by Beatie John Lennon depicting a sex act was more obscene than a similar work by Pablo Pi casso.

title: MRS. BAYH'S PARENTS ARE SHOT TO DEATH
description: ENID, Okla., April 1 (AP) The father and stepmother of Mrs. Birch Bayh, wife of In diana's Democratic Senator, were found shot to death today in their home in what the au thorities described as an appar ent murder and suicide.

title: Music: Thomas and Boston Symphony
description: BECAUSE of the continued illness of William Stein berg, the 26yearold Michael Tilson Thomas continues to flourish on the podium of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Last night he conducted the players at Philharmonic Hall in a program that consisted of J. C. Bach's Symphony for Double Orchestra in E flat, Stravinsky's Symphony in Three Movements and Tchai kovskv's Symphony No. 1.

title: CENSUS QUERIES KEEP AIDES BUSY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 One Philadelphia man said he did not work but his wife did. He asked: Who is the head of the household? The Census Bureau said: Your wife is. He insisted that he was, since he wears the pants in the family.

title: 4 MEN AND HOSTAGE QUIT RIVIERA HOTEL
description: VILLEFRANCHE  Sur  Mer, France, Thursday, April 2 (Reu ters)  Four gunmen walked out of a luxury hotel in this Mediterranean resort early to day with a male hostage and drove off in a car without in terference by the police they had held off for nearly 24 hours.

title: Humble Oil Lets Contract For Arctic Tanker Design
description: The Humble Oil and Refining Company awarded a contract yesterday to the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Com pany to develop the design for icebreaking tankers for pos sible use in transporting crude oil through the Northwest Pas sage over the top of the North American ontinent.

title: TIMES JOB ACTIONS ACCOMPANY TALKS
description: Negotiations between the ty pographical union and the city's major newspapers centered on noneconomic issues yesterday, as the printers continued to de lay composingroom operations at The New York Times by holding a series of chapel, or union, meetings.

title: Westinghouse Sets Sight on Seventies
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., April 1 (AP)The Westinghouse Elec tric Corporation will aim its corporate muscle at environ mental problems in the nine teenseventies, the chairman of the board of the Pittsburgh based concern said today.

title: RED WINGS DOWN BLACK HAWKS, 52
description: CHICAGO, April 1 (AP)The Detroit Red Wings clung to their onepoint hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League's East Division tonight by whipping the Chicago Black Hawks, 52.

title: His Bid Day Counts
description: I THOUGHT I had one of these jobs people talk about  a Federal bureauc racy where you don't do any thing, said John C. Culli nane yesterday. His tone said that he was joking, and so did the circumstances: Mr. Cullinane is New York's re gional director of the Bureau of the Census.

title: Xavier Rehires Krajack
description: CINCINNATI, April 1 (AP) George Krajack signed a new oneyear contract today to coach basketball at Xavier Uni versity.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BOWIE KUHN was at the White House on Tuesday to present a Mets ring and some autographed baseballs to President Nixon. After the little ceremony, according to Kuhn, the two men spoke privately and the President asked the commissioner what he had decided to do about Denny McLain. Nixon, according to Kuhn, pronounced the decisions to continue the Detroit pitcher's suspension until July 1 a fair one and then expressed his interest in the general problem of the athlete's image, his obligation to be a model for young people and the great service he can perform by properly conducting his affairs.

title: Marine Will Get New Trial In '68 Okinawa Rape Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Navy announced today a new trial for a former Marine lance corporal serving an eight year sentence in the rape of a woman at Camp Hauge, Okin nawa, in 1968.

title: LOUIS FALCO STAGES 2 DANCES AT N.Y.U.
description: I always derive an enormous professional satisfaction from watching Louis Falco dance. Even though I don't understand why he choreographs only to his talent and not beyond, I would defend to the death his right to do it. Last night at New York University's School of Continuing Education he pre sented two works from reper tory and an open discussion period afterward.

title: Economy Healthy, Nixon Aide Finds
description: The economy is in good shape, Herbert Stein, a mem ber of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, confidently stated here yes terday. He painted this pic ture:

title: Deanne Gillette, Thomas Violich To Wed in May
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1  Miss Deanne Gillette and Thomas John Violich plan to be married late next month in the chapel of Yosemite National Park. A reception will take place at the park's Ahwahnee Hotel.

title: Executive Changes
description: Charles E. Arnett and Kenneth Fulton have been elected as vice presidents of the General Foods Corporation.

title: Action Is Approved
description: The executive board of a ManhattanBronx local repre senting 8,000 letter carriers unanimously voted yesterday to give iits president, Gustave J. Johnson, the power to take whatever action is deemed necessary if an agreement on a postal pact was not forth coming.

title: METS TURN BACK CARDINALS, 3 TO 2
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1Jim McAndrew, who is striv ing to become the New York Mets' fourth starter, and Mike Jorgensen, who is just striving to remain with the club, both made successful bids in their own behalf tonight whiel the world champions were edging the St. Louis Cardinals, 32.

title: TRADE UNIT WARNS CITY LAGS ON BILLS
description: The Subcontractors Trade As sociation warned its members yesterday against doing con struction for the city's Housing and Development Administra tion, charging that the agency was not paying its bills.

title: Henry, Miss Potter Take Diving Titles In A.A.U. Tourney
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 (AP)Two Texans took today's opening events in the Amateur Athletic Union's na tional indoor diving champion ships, which are being held out doors.

title: HARPSICHORDIST, 24, PLAYS DEBUT RECITAL
description: Robert Smith, a 24yearold Bayonne  born harpsichordist, made his solo debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He was at his best in dancelike music.

title: Farm Workers Union Signs First TableGrape Contract With Two California Growers
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 The United Farmworkers Or ganizing Committee signed to day with two growers in the Coachella Valley the nation's first labor contract covering tablegrape pickers.

title: HOME LOAN BANKS SET NEW POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will soon make a set of policy decisions and announce ments designed to induce sav ings and loan associations to use savings inflows this year for expansion of mortgage lending rather than for repay ment of advances from the Home Loan Banks.

title: In Memoriam
description: KRAMMary Levy. In loving memory of our dearly beloved mother. April 2, 1934. Bertha, Dorothy, Alfred and Irving

title: Vandals Wreck Pressroom
description: CHARLO AMALIE, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, April 1 (UPI)  Management of The Home Journal, one of two daily newspapers on St. Thomas, sought an emergency publishing site today after vandals wrecked the pressroom equipment over the Easter holidays. The news paper is published by the island's Democratic leader, Sen ator Earle B. Ottley. Roy Gott lieb, a Journal spokesman, said an effort would be made to get out two editions a week until the pressroom was restored.

title: Herman Ehrenreich, Critic Of The Jewish Daily Forward
description: Herman Ehrenreich, drama critic of The Jewish Daily For ward, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 162 West 54th Street.

title: Woman ShipSpotter on S.I. Is a Link to Maritime Past
description: Mrs. Laura K. Hassell watches the ships go by and gets paid for it.

title: College Association Aide
description: BOSTON, April 1 (AP)The vice president of Simmons Col lege, Frank E. Trednick Jr., has been named director of the New England Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, the as sociation announced today.

title: In Korea, It's Not a Meal Unless There's Kimchi on the Table
description: SCEOUL, South KoreaIn one notable respect, Mrs. Sang Kook Choo of Seoul is much like her neighbors. When November rolls around, it is time to make winter kimchi, that spiced, if not to say heady, Korean pickle that is the delight and essential addition to every native table three meals a daymorn ing, noon and night. It is as common place in Korean homesif not more so as soy sauce throughout the Orient or salt and pepper in the Western home.

title: Neighborhoods: Pelham Parkway Is an Urban Shtetl in the Bronx
description: It's our Florida here, said Mrs. Ethel Rudin. We sit here every day in the sun.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Sirhan Back in Cell
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 1 (Reuters)Sirhan B. Sirhan, convicted assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was re turned to his death row cell today after two days in the prison hospital. Associate Ward en James Park said that he had caught a cold and been treated with antihistamines, which made him feel groggy.

title: Test of the War's Legality Voted By Legislature in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, April 1The Mas sachusetts legislature gave final approval and sent to the Gov ernor today a bill intended to force a court test of the con stitutionality of the war in Vietnam.

title: L.S.U. Confirms Expulsion Of Maravich and Hester
description: BATON ROUGE, April 1 (AP) A Louisiana State University spokesman confirmed today that Pete Maravich and Danny Hester, basketball players, had been dropped as students be cause of prolonged absence.

title: Jewelry Designed to Reflect the 70's
description: IN 2,000 years, when the archeologists dig up our artifacts, will they judge our civilization by our jewelry as they have that of the Egyp tians and the Greeks? Jean Dinh Van thinks they might Jewelry is the mirror of life, he says. And, as a jew elry designer, Mr. Dinh Van thinks that what we wear on our arms and fingers or around our necks should mirror to day's life, not that of the Ren aissance or the Victorians. Judg ed by his current collec tion at Cartier, Mr. Dinh Van has succeeded in being com pletely contemporary. It has pleasant, cleancut lines and another quality rarely found in real jewelrya sophis ticated sense of humor.

title: LONG WAIT ENDS WITH PHONE CALL
description: LAKELAND, Fla., April 1 At five minutes before noon, the telephone rang in the kit chen of Denny McLain's house. It was an assistant to the Com missioner of Baseball  a man, McLain said who holds my life in his hands.

title: Laotians Strengthen Hold on Sam Thong; Shell and Bomb Foe
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 Laotian forces were reported to have strengthened their hold on Sam Thong today as North Vietnamese troops pulled back from the mountain valley town they captured two weeks ago but lost to counterattacking Laotian troops yesterday.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest re port on changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors, officers of shares listed on the exchange. The report includes the following:

title: Nixon Signs Bill Banning RadioTV Cigarette Ads
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) President Nixon signed to night a bill that will ban ciga rette commercials from radio and television starting Jan. 2.

title: Cancer Cost $5Million Here
description: The American Cancer Society spent more than $5.2million last year in New York City in its attack on cancer, former Federal Judge Paul W. Wil liams, chairman of the board of the society's New York City Division, reported yesterday on the opening of the 1970 Cancer Crusade. He said $3.5million had been spent at 14 medical and scientific institutions here for research and more than $1.5million had gone for pati ent care, education and com munity service.

title: Chesapeake & Ohio Earnings Down in the Quarter
description: Consolidated earnings of the Chesapeake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio railroads fell in the first quarter this year to $3.55mil lion, or 41 cents a common share, from last year's restated $4million, or 45 cents a share.

title: Action Is Seen on Funds Reform
description: A member of the House Commerce subcommittee, which is considering mutual fund reform legislation, pre dicted yesterday that the panel would move Tuesday to break the Iogjam that so far has prevented House ac tion on the controversial measures.

title: 2 WITNESSES LINK ADAMS TO $5,000
description: Two prosecution witnesses testified under crossexamina tion yesterday that their com pany provided $5,000 for State Senator William A. Adams after the Senator's campaign coordi nator solicited the cash con tribution.

title: TEAMSTERS BEGIN WIDE STOPPAGES
