description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Thousands of truck drivers around the country walked off their jobs this morning after national contract between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking in dustry expired at midnight.

title: Market Place:
description: The Scovill Manufacturing Company's annual report leads off briskly to say that earnings and sales in 1969 were exactly on targeta 10 per cent increase in per share earnings to $3.91 a share and a 12 per cent in crease in sales to $444.5mil lion.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4??7 Game Series)

title: Rangers Defeat Leafs, 21, on Goal by Ratelle and Keep Cup Hopes Alive
description: TORONTO, April 1The Rang ers set the stage for their week end series with the Detroit Red Wings tonight, preserving their hopes for a sip of Stanley Cup champagne with a 21 victory over the Maple Leafs.

title: Nelson Proposes a Fee On Disposable Packages
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Senator Gaylord Nelson, Dem ocrat of Wisconsin, proposed legislation today to require in dustry to pay a fee for product packaging materials that are not easily disposable: bottles, boxes, wrappings.

title: Chess:
Opposition in Newark
description: NEWARK, April 1 (UPI)  The board of the Greater New ark Urban Coalition announced today that it opposed the ele vation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court. The board consists of antipov erty aides, community leaders and elected city officials.

title: Outlays on Billboards Climbed 4.5% in 1969
description: Advertisers spent over $232.8million for billboard advertising last year and that is an increase of 4.5 per cent over 1968. The top 100 users of the outdoor medium were more enthusiastic, though, and increased their usage 14.4 per cent.

title: Chou to Visit North Korea
description: TOKYO, Thursday, April 2 (AP)Premier Chou Enlai of Communist China will visit North Korea early this month, it was announced today by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

title: City College to Add Course In Jewish Studies Next Fall
description: City College will offer a pro gram of study leading to a bachelor's degree in Jewish studies, Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, acting president of the school, announced yesterday.

title: HUNTER STUDENTS BLOCK ELEVATORS
description: Militant students declared last night that they had closed Hunter College after blocking elevators in the 15story build ing that houses the branch of the City University at Park Avenue and 68th Street.

title: Wall St. Staggers Working Schedules To Ease Rush Hour
description: Some 50,000 workers in the Wall Street area went on stag gered work schedules yester day, the first day of a six month experiment to ease rush hour congestion in Lower Manhattan. Most of the work ers came and left 30 to 45 minutes early, but some came and left 30 minutes late.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you buy a defective prod uct on credit from a dealer who turns out to be un scrupulous, the chances are very strong that you won't get anywhere by refusing to continue payments.

title: 61 KILLED IN CRASH OF MOROCCAN PLANE
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, April 1 (Reuters)  Sixtyone persons were killed today in the crash and explosion of a Royal Air Maroc jetliner after the pilot apparently made a last minute maneuver to avoid a village. Six of the 21 sur vivors were reported to be in critical condition tonight.

title: MRS. JOHN ROSS HAAS
description: Mrs. Agnes H. Haas, wife of John Ross Haas, a partner in the Haas Securities Corporation, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She lived at 433 East 51st Street.

title: G.O.P IN VIRGINIA DIVIDED ON BYRD
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Does the Republican party want Harry F. Byrd Jr. or not?

title: DR. F. R. MACAULAY, ECONOMIC COUNSEL
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 1 Dr. Frederick Robertson Ma caulay, an economist and au thor, who had advised banks, securities companies and in vestment trusts, died Friday at his home, 11 Clover Drive. He was 87 years old.

title: RHODESIANS TERM CURBS LOSS FOR U.S.
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 1  United States prohibition of chrome imports from Rho desia is making American in dustry increasingly dependent on Soviet ore, in the view of economists here.

title: Auto Production Drops
description: DETROIT, April 1 (UPI)  The earlyyear lag in new car sales was reflected in the first quarter production figures re leased today by three of the four major auto companies down almost 434,000 from the comparable period a year ago.

title: 16 Restored Film Prints to Be Shown in Series Here
description: Sixteen films produced since 1927 that have been rescued from detorioration by 20th CenturyFox, the Museum of Modern Art and the American Film Institute will be shown at the New Yorker Theater, 88th Street and Broadway, today through Anril 29.

title: Bucks Topple 76ers, 118111, For a 31 Edge in Playoffs
MORGAN BANK PLANS WORLD STOCK NOTES
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York an nounced plans yesterday to introduce a system of inter national depositary receipts to facilitate trading in inter national markets.

title: FM Radio Grows Up to Have Its Own Convention
description: FM radio is big business, and tomorrow in Chicago the Na tional Association of FM Broad casters will begin a threeday convention to signalize its in creased importance.

title: Fire in Village Flat Kills Retired Food Importer, 72
description: Herbert B. Moeller, the retired president of the Atalan ta Trading Corporation, a food importing company at 17 Varick Street, was found dead in his bed early yesterday after firemen extinguished a blaze in his sixthfloor apartment in the Hotel One Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village.

title: Arts Council Outlines Plans for Grants
description: Obviously stunned by the size of its windfall, the New York State Council on the Arts outlined plans yesterday for distribution of more than $20million it received last week from the State Legisla ture. The sum amounted to nearly $18million more than last year's appropriation.

title: Pontiff Is Cautioned on Celibacy Stand
description: ROME, April 1A group of 32 theologians in Rome has warned Pope Paul VI that Papai insistence on priestly celibacy is out of proportion to the issue's importance and risks schism within the Roman Cath olic Church.

title: Stokes, ExStar of Royals, Has Heart Attack in Ohio
description: CINCINNATI, April 1 (AP) Maurice Stokes, a former Na tional Basketball Association star with the Cincinnati Royals, suffered a heart attack Monday night and is under intensive care at Good Samaritan Hos pital.

title: Embassy in Soviet Asserts It Is Still Loyal to Sihanouk
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (Reuters) The Cambodian Embassy has issued a note to other embassies in Moscow that will remain under the direction of the de posed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and not the new Government in Pnom penh.

title: LONDON RUN DROPPED BY HARKNESS BALLET
description: LONDON, April 1  The Harkness Ballet of New York has canceled its scheduled visit to London next month because it is short of money.

title: Liberals Report Pledges By 4 Democrats to Run
description: The four top Democratic aspirants for Governor were re ported last night to have com mitted themselves to run on the Liberal party ticket this fall if given a Liberal nomination even against the winner of a Democratic primary.

title: Bridge:
description: IDENTIFYING the strongest married partnership in New York bridge circles would be a hazardous ven turethere are several candi dates for the title. But if the measuring stick is play in recent major tournaments, the award must go to Michael and Gail Moss, who in the last two months have had successes as far afield as Dallas and Mexico City.

title: Sons of Eli Are Trailing Daughters in Grades
description: NEW HAVEN, April 1 (AP) Yale women are outdis tancing Yale men In academic achievement in this first year of coeducation here.

title: Lebanon Apologizes to U.S. For Attacks Upon Property
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 The Lebanese Government apol ogized today for weekend at tacks on American property in Lebanon.

title: License Miss Heumann
description: In the age of the dropout, the handicapped student who overcomes obstacles to get an education and a job is a thoughtprovoking example in the classroom and in life. The blind student who takes mental notes and the paraplegic who wheels himself through school show a determination that exceeds the courage of more acclaimed heroathletes in our society.

title: Carolyn Stires To Be a Bride
description: ALNA, Me., April 1Miss Carolyn Brooks Stires, a granddaughter of the late Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, who was the Episcopal Bish op of Long Island, will be married June 20 to Thomas Porter Aldrich.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON LONDON BOARD
Sholty Unable to Drive Here; Flight From Florida Canceled
Bomb Threat in Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 1 (UPI)  A bomb threat forced the evacuation today of the Fed eral Building where former President Lyndon B. Johnson maintains his office. Mr. John son was not in the building. He was at his ranch recuperating from a recent heart ailment. No bomb was found.

title: Victoria Schmidlann Bride in Florida
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 Miss Victoria Olson Schmid lapp was married this after noon to Gray Frederickson, a movie producer, by the Rev. Dr. Hunsdon Cary Jr. in BethesdabytheSea Episco pal Church.

title: Ocean Resources Given Priority In Research Planning by Hickel
description: BEEHIVE COVE, St. Johns, Virgin Islands, April 1  Secre tary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the Nixon Administration intended to give a high priority to re search efforts aimed at under standing and exploiting the na tion's ocean resources.

title: DENVER MINTENDS SALE OF SILVER
description: After a day's delay in an nouncing the latest awards at its weekly silver auction, the Government yesterday an nounced that henceforth it will sell no more silver from the, Denver mint. The regular auc tion of 1,500,000 ounces week ly, plus a carryover of unsold silver, will continue, but de livery will be at the Assay Of fice in New York.

title: Order in the Courts
description: The conduct and language of the petitioners... he unending villification heaped upon the Court, the almost uninterrupted flow of vile, demeaning, vicious, base and threatening language shouted by the peti tioners...must be unparalleled in court history.

title: City Hospitals to Bar The Sale of Cigarettes
description: Cigarette sales will be banned in the city's 18 pub lic hospitals under an order issuued yesterday by Hospi tals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio.

title: Text of the President's Letter to Senator Saxbe Defending His Nomination of Carswell to High Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Following is the text of the letter from President Nixon to Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, on the nomination of Judge G. Har rold Carswell to the Supreme Court:

title: FRANCE PROPOSES INDOCHINA PARLEY
description: PARIS, April 1The French Government called tonight for a general conference on Indo china to make the area as a whole a zone of neutrality and peace.

title: A GERMAN COMPANY ACQUIRES INTEREST
description: Farbenfabriken Bayer, A.G., of West Germany, announced yesterday it had acquired a major interest in the Helena Chemical Company from the Diamond Shamrock Corpora tion for an undisclosed sum.

title: Japanese to Dance Sunday
description: Three ballet dancers from Japan will make their American debut at Kaufmann Concert Hall on Sunday at 8:30 P.M. The program, featuring Yoko Morishita, Yukiko Mushanokoji and Yuriko Kawaguchi of To kyo's Asami Maki Ballet, will be choreographed by Igor Schwezoff of New York. The Lepercq Foundation, in associa tion with the Consulate General of Japan, is presenting the group.

title: Skirts: An Answer to Fashion Question
description: WOMEN who aren't committed to the long look but are openminded enough to wonder how it feels to wear it have an easy out. Designers have come up with a rela tively painless transition from fashions that practically bare all to styles that leave almost everything to the imagi nation: They're making a big do about the separate skirt.

title: Strike at Dictaphone
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1 (AP)Employes of Dictaphone Corporation went on strike to day after their contract expired and bargaining broke down in the early morning hours.

title: ENEMY IN VIETNAM OPENS WIDE DRIVE, ENDING LONG LULL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1After six months of relative quiet, the Vietnam war flared up again today with a coordinated series of enemy shelling and ground attacks against American and South Vietnamese targets throughout the country.

title: British Troops Fire Tear Gas In Fight With Belfast Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, April 2 (Reuters) British troops fired tear gas to break up a fierce street battle with hostile Roman Catholics here early today.

title: STENNIS REBUFFED IN SCHOOL AID VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Senate passed a $24.6billion education bill today after re jecting a renewed Southern challenge to school desegrega tion policies dealing primarily with the South.

title: Dissident's Mother Barred From Leaving Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1Vera Mihajlov, mother of Mihajlo Mihajlov, the dissi dent writer who was recently released from prison, was de tained by the police today and deprived of her passport as she was about to leave by air for the United States.

title: Abilene Boom Is Evidence Americans Still Like Ike
description: ABILENE, Kan., April 1 The charisma is still there, even in death.

title: CANADIENS SCORE OVER BRUINS, 63
description: MONTREAL, April 1 (UPI) Jean Beliveau scored two goals and assisted on another tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 63 victory over the Boston Bruins before a record Forum crowd of 18,848. The victory consolidated Montreal's hold on third place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Mrs. Grant Will Receive League for Israel Award
description: Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, Commissioner of Consumer Af fairs, will receive the 1970 Freedom Cup Award of the Women's League for Israel at the organization's 42d anni versary luncheon on April 9 at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Royals Conquer Yanks, 4 to 3, On Unearned Run in 6th Inning
Pennsylvania Gas Tax Up
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 1 (AP)A onecent state gasoline tax increase, from 7 to 8 cents a gallon, took effect today in Pennsylvania.

title: SCANDALS IN PAST ROCKED BASEBALL
description: In 1924, just five years after the Black Sox scandal, a young New York Giant outfielder, Jimmy O'Connell, was thrown out of baseball for life for al legedly attempting to bribe a Philadelphia player to throw a game.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SHOW PRICE RISES
description: The credit markets moved nearly unanimously yesterday toward higher prices and lower interest rates, broaden ing a trend that had concen trated largely in corporate bonds earlier in the week.

title: Australian Veteran Identified as Seller Of $280,000 Stamp
description: An Australian veteran of the Galipoli campaign of World War I was disclosed yesterday as the former owner of the British Guiana 1cent magenta stamp that sold here for $280, 000 at an auction on March 24.

title: Kuhn to Lift McLain's Suspension on July 1
description: Dennis McLain, who pitched 55 victories for the Detroit Tigers the last two seasons and who was suspended from base ball six weeks ago because he was involved in a bookmaking operation in 1967, has been suspended for three, more months, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

title: Cultural Week Will Mark Spanish Institute's Move
description: Leaders in the business and cultural worlds of Spain and the United States will take part in a week of activities begin ning April 26 to mark the move of the Spanish Institute into its new home at 684 Park Avenue, between 68th and 69th Streets.

title: Laborite Accused of Spying Resigns From the Commons
description: LONDON, April 1 (AP) William James Owen, a 68 yearold Labor party member awaiting trial on a spy charge, resigned from the House of Commons today.

title: Pope Paul to Honor 2 Woman Saints
description: ROME, April 1Pope Paul VI will name two woman saints to the honorific rank of Doctor of the Church, a title held by only 30 others, all men, the Vatican announced today.

title: A Correction
description: Two photographs by Jon Brenneis of infants' hearing tests, which ran in Wednes day's issues of The New York Times, should have been cred ited to Hospital Practice, the magazine that supplied the pic tures.

title: CLEANUP SPEEDED ON DERELICT CARS
description: A new system of sticking shiny numbered patches on derelict cars to indicate targets for towaway contractors, has speeded the city's street clean up campaign, Sanitation Com missioner Griswold L. Moeller said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT I am is what I feel now. What else, how else. But Webb all this is yours. Museums, whores, all the beauty he thought was me, all the beauty he thought. And I was young. I could kill the dragon, release the golden dream, find the cup, the maiden, the castle, the home, the father, the seek ing. Ruins, ruins we all fall down. The voice and the youth belong to Cecil Braithwaite, a black man, sometime janitor, graduate of law school, deserter of the wife who sustained him dur ing his academic endeavors. Webb is a middleaged white man, an ex hausted writer, a kind of ambula tory culture bag, seeking in Amenca and Europe the son he sired on a black woman and has never seen, gambling that coin cidence will somehow supply him with the one person capable of forgiving him. Webb finds Braithwaite in a New York museum and takes him to Spain. In Spain, and in France, and in Italy, and in Africa, Braithwaite discovers that he must go home again.

title: A.P. and Newsweek Support Caldwell Subpoena Challenge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (AP)  The Associated Press and Newsweek magazine filed memorandums today in support of the motion by Earl Caldwell and The New York Times for an order quashing subpoenas served on Mr. Caldwell, a Times reporter, in connection with a Federal grand jury in vestigation of the Black Pan ther movement.

title: City Manager Resigns
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., April 1 (AP)City Manager Richard Bowen has resigned, effective today, giving no reason other than his personal and profes sional interests. He said the in terests of the city would be better served by this action.

title: Theater: A Sam Shepard Double Bill
Coast Beaches Lose Sand
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)South ern California beaches are los ing sand at the rate of a million cubic yards a year because of erosion and because inland dams are blocking deposit of new sands, Bernard W. Pap kins, a geologist, says.

title: Indians on Alcatraz Weigh Interior Department Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI)Indians who have oc cupied Alcatraz since Nov. 20 considered today an Interion Department proposal to turn the island into a park with Indian qualities.

title: The Community Mandate
description: The city's first community school boards elections have ended with a distinctly moderate to conservative trend. The choice of candidates reflecting such views rather than the often more audible radical voices is probably a more accurate reflection of majority sentiment, particularly after the bitter experience of school strife in the last two years.

title: Intrepid Anglers of All Ages Brave Chill Waters of Croton River as New York State Trout Season Opens
description: BREWSTER, N. Y., April 1 Undaunted by the previ ous day's unseasonable snow, which still lay six inches deep in places, hundreds of anglers were at their usual beats this morning on the Croton River watershed for the opening day of the trout season.

title: Lagos Eases Flight Ban
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 1 (UPI) The Government said today it had lifted the ban on most night flights to Nigeria and re opened two international sea ports in waraffected areas. Port Harcourt and Port Cala bar, closed during the Nigerian Biafran civil war, have been reopened to ease congestion at Lagos airport, a Government announcement said.

title: 1,000 Acres of SmogAfflicted Pines to Be Cut
description: LAKE ARROWHEAD, Calif., April 1A thousand acres of towering ponderosa pines in the San Bernardino Mountains, fatally afflicted by smog from nearby metropolitan Los An geles, were turned over by the United tSates Forest Service to day to a lumber company for commercial logging.

title: REBEL CHIEF DEAD, SUDANESE ASSERT
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April (AP)The Sudanese Premier announced today that a rebel leader, Imam elHadi Ahmed el Mandi, had been killed while try ing to cross into Ethiopia after his rebellion had been crushed.

title: Platform Unit Urges Asia Withdrawal
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 1 Embattled New York Demo crats, badly divided on a state ticket, received for considera tion today a state platform that includes proposals for re structuring the state govern ment.

title: Peck & Peck Chooses NonFamily President
description: John I. Gotlinger, previous ly vice president and chief executive officer of Peck & Peck, New York, has become the first nonfamily presi dent of the 82year old chain of 72 women's specialty stores. He succeeds Wilbur F. Burt Jr., who continues as chairman.

title: NEW POSTAL BID TO GO TO MEANY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  A new and more generous Gov ernment proposal to the seven national unions of postal work ers will be put before George Meany tomorrow for his ad vice on whether the postal unions should accept it. Mr. Meany is president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Or ganizations.

title: 1st Printers' Chaper Was at English Abbey
description: The term, chapel, as used in the printing trade, refers to printers' shop organizations, which may call meetings to discuss such subjects as work ing conditions, relations with employers and other trade un ion matters.

title: MERGERS HELD FIRM IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Despite the market decline, merger activity in the first quarter of this year was un changed, from the like period in 1969.

title: Fire Destroys the Black Studies Center at Cornell
description: ITHACA, April 1  A fire destroyed the threestory black studies center on the Cornell University campus today.

title: Soviet Army Units in U.A.R. Becoming More Conspicuous
description: CAIRO, April 1  The build up of Soviet military units in the United Arab Republic has reached the point where they are being observed more fre quently these days on the high ways and, occasionally, in the cities.

title: Kidnapped Envoy In Guatemala Writes He Is Feeling Well
description: GUATEMALA, April 1The West German Ambassador, Karl von Spreti, kidnapped by leftist guerrillas Tuesday after noon, disclosed in a hand written note this morning that he was in good health.

title: Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, Soviet War Hero, Dead at 75
description: Marshal Semyon K. Timo shenko, the Soviet war hero, died of cancer Tuesday in Mos cow, according to Tass, the So viet press agency. He was 75 years old.

title: Lady SpencerChurchill Is 75
description: LONDON, April 1 (UPI) Lady SpencerChurchill, widow of Sir Winston, marked her 75th birthday today at her home overlooking Hyde Park.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Sees Hoax in Plan for Black Workers in Building Trade Here
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday condemned as a hoax and a subterfuge a recently announced plan by leaders of the building industry to train minoritygroup mem bers as skilled construction workers.

title: Mining Venture Planned
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corpora tion, the Coolbaugh Mining Cor poration and Mine Finders, Inc., a recently formed Colorado concern, staffed mainly by geologists, announced yesterday that they had formed a joint venture for the exploration and development of a broad spectrum of mineral deposits and recoverable metals.

title: VINCENT T. NOLA
description: Vincent T. Nola, a recording engineer and owner of the Nola Penthouse Sound Studios at 111 West 57th Street, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 8629 Midland Parkway, Jamai ca Estates, Queens.

title: Mortgage Scene Brighter, U.S. Housing Official Says
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP) The housing mortgage pic ture is not so bad as a few weeks ago, Woodward King man, Deputy Assistant Secre tary of the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment, said today.

title: GEORGE SCHWARZ
description: George Schwarz, a real estate and insurance broker of 703 Seneca Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, for more than 50 years, died Monday of a heart attack.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, April 1, 1970

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 2, 1970

title: New York City Weather in March
Six Greeks Are Jailed in Press Trial
description: ATHENS, Thursday, April 2 An Athens military tribunal early today gave stiff prison sentences and fines to five newspaper executives and a former cabinet minister held responsible for publication of an interview calling for the restoration of democracy in Greece.

title: Luis Rafael Reyna Corvalan Weds Princess Maria Beatrice
description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, April 1 (AP)Princess Maria Beatrice of Savoy daughter of former King Humbert II of Italy, was married in a civil ceremony today to Luis Rafael Reyna Corvaln, a wealthy Argentine diplomat.

title: HOUSING CRISIS SEEN EASED BY MOBILES
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)  The Nixon Administration told Congress today that the easiest way for nearly half of all American families to meet their housing needs was to buy a mobile home.

title: AMEX POSTS GAIN AS VOLUME RISES
description: Most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yes terday on moderate volume.

title: 41% Pay Rise for Tugmen Ends 60Day Strike Here
description: The longest tugboat strike in the port's history ended yesterday when union members accepted a contract that will increase their wages by more than 41 per cent over three years. Fringe benefits will in crease the employers' overall costs during the threeyear contract to 53.5 per cent for half of the workers and 58.5 per cent for the others.

title: Bethana R. Adams Planning Nuptials
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., April 1Mr. and Mrs. Earle Chetwood Adams of Hastings  on  Hudson and York, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bethana Rob erts Adams, to Curtis Emer son Youngdahl Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Youngdahl of Summit, N. J.

title: The Text of Commissioner Kuhn's Statement in McLain Case
description: On Feb. 19, 1970, I sus pended Denny McLain from all organized baseball activi ties pending the completion of further investigation and my review of facts obtained therefrom. I base the initial suspension substantially upon certain admissions made can didly to me by McLain. These admissions related to his in volvement in purported book making activities in 1967 and his associations at that time.

title: Construction Strike Called
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 1 (AP)Five construction work ers unions went on strike to day, the second big construction strike here in a year. The five locals, representing 4,000 men, have been negotiating as a team.

title: Market Summary
description: Wednesday, April 1, 1970

title: Rotterdam Orchestra Due
description: The Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra will make its United States debut tonight with a con cert in Red Bank, N. J., and will play tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall, when Jean Fournet will conduct. The en semble will give 26 concerts in a tour that will take it as far west as Oshkosh, Wis., and will end on May 2 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Blacks at Fieldston

title: Monkey Trial Teacher Still Fights
description: NASHVILLE, April 1 (AP) John T. Scopes, the substi tute teacher who lost his fight for academic freedom in Tennessee's 1925 monkey trial, renewed the crusade in a classroom here today.

title: Silurians Elect Officers
description: The Society of Silurians, an organization of newsmen, today elected William R. Hart, a pub licrelations executive, as its president. Other officers named in balloting at the Overseas Press Club were Kalman Sei gel, first vice president; Oliver Pilat, second vice president; Charles B. Crisman, treasurer; Jesse G. Bell, associate treas urer; Charles Speaks, secretary; and Victor House, counsel.

title: AIRLINES SEEKING MORE FLIGHT CUTS
description: The nation's airlines peti tioned the Government late yes terday for authority to restrict their flights further until the mass sick call of Federal air traffic controllers is ended.

title: RALPH ASTROVE, 74, OF PLUMBING FIRM
description: Ralph Astrove, who retired two years ago as president of the Astrove Plumbing and Heat ing Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nurs ing Home, 175 East 96th Street. He was 74 years old and lived at 2601 Henry Hudson Parkway West. Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: ALEX MATTISON, 77, EXPERSONNEL AIDE
description: Alex C. Mattison, a retired employment agency executive and earlier an advertising man with The New York Times, died Tuesday at University Hos pital. He was 77 years old and lived at 280 Lansdowne Ave nue. Carle Place. L.I.

title: Alfred Drake to Head Players
description: Alfred Drake has been elected president of the Players. He suc ceeds Dennis King, who re signed recently for health rea sons. Mr. Drake, the seventh president of the club, whose membership is drawn from the theater and related arts, has had a long career as actor and singer.

title: FISCHER WINS AGAIN AT BELGRADE CHESS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Apri 1Bobby Fischer, the eight time United States chess cham pion, triumphed over Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, in their secondround adjourned game today in the match be tween the Soviet Union and top players from other coun tries.

title: Yonkers Drivers
description: Last night's races not included.

title: Business Records
description: EASTERN DISTRICT BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Observer: The Fool Problem
description: WASHINGTON, April 1It is not easy for a young man to become a fool these days. In fact, it has become so difficult that it's a wonder there are so many of them still in business. Everything conspires against it.

title: Giggly Young Cambodians Begin Drills
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1Grinning and giggling self consciously in ill  matched, storebought khakis and occa sional floppy bush hats, eager secondaryschool and university students of Cambodia are as sembling on their campuses for volunteer military training.

title: BIG BOARD STOCKS UP WITH VOLUME
description: The stock market picked up some speed and strength yes terday with prices at the close of trading near the highest levels of the day.

title: MONTAGE IS LED BY HAGOOD HARDY
description: A group called The Montage, which has come to Shepheard's in the Drake Hotel under the leadership of Hagood Hardy, a Canadian jazz vibraharpist and pianist who has served with George Shearing and Herbie Mann, seems at first glance to be patterned on Sergio Mendes and Brasil '66. Two girls, a blonde and a brunette, sing duets and solos and vocalize in scat phrases in front of an in strumental group made up of Mr. Hardy, a bassist and a drummer.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: NIXON AIDE URGES END TO TRADE BARS
description: Carl J. Gilbert, President Nix on's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, asserted yesterday that name calling offered no solution to United States trade disputes with Ja pan and the European Common Market.

title: Con Ed Seeks to Build 2 Islands For Nuclear Power Plants Here
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany said yesterday that it was seeking to build nuclear power plants on manmade islands off Coney Island and in the Lower Bay.

title: Police Study Shows Criminal Repeaters On Increase Here
description: Arrests for serious crimes are increasing here among per sons with previous arrests, the Police Department announced yesterday.

title: Cybernetics Elects 2
description: The Cybernetics International Corporation, a computer soft ware company, announced yes terday the election of E. W. Housh as president and Lewis W. Kresch as chairman of the executive committee.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Exclusive Dancer Takes Prioress at Aqueduct
description: Exclusive Dancer made her way into the winner's circle for the first time this season when she won the $27,700 Pri oress at Aqueduct yesterday be fore a crowd of 28,229. The homebred filly owned by the Happy Valley Farm scored after engaging in a thrilling contest with the favored Restless Life and Petunia in the stretch drive of the sixfurlong event for 3 yearold fillies.

title: Auto Makers Score Japan
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Automobile Manufacturers Association today released the text of a letter to Secretary of State William P. Rogers bit terly complaining about the Japanese brush off of automo bile trade and investment.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Geneva a Bit Raffled By April Foolish Press
description: GENEVA, April 1The staid people of Geneva learned from their newspa pers today that a Swiss bank had decided to identify the holders of secret numbered accounts.

title: U.S. Halts Poverty Funds To Suffolk Legal Aid Group
description: The Suffolk County Legal Aid Society announced yester day that the United States Office of Economic Opportunity had cut off the society's Fed eral funds.

title: Strange Animal Seen on Sea Floor
description: A special deepsea camera has recorded, reportedly for the first time, a strange ten tacled animal rising from the ocean floor on a pencilthick stem.

title: Wrong Target in Peru
description: After a period of uncertain backing and filling, Peru's military Government has definitely resumed the path of radical revolution rather than orderly reform. This will have unfortunate effects beyond Peru's bor ders, but it is bad news especially for those very elements in Peruvian societythe wretched campesi nos of the countryside, the unemployed of the cities that the military revolution was designed to help.

title: SYLVAN D. FREEMAN
description: Sylvan D. Freeman, senior partner in the law firm of Dreyer and Trub, died of a heart attack yesterday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 60 years old and lived at 12 Hemlock Drive, Great Neck. L. L.

title: Earthquake Toll in Turkey Put at 1,084 and Still Rising
description: GEDIZ, Turkey, April 1 (Reu ters)Relief supplies continue to pour into earthquakeravaged areas of Western Turkey to night.

title: INSPECTORS UNION TO FIGHT NEW DUTY
description: The Lindsay administration was warned yesterday that the 1,200 members of the Building Inspectors union would refuse to be sworn in as special patrol men to issue and serve sum monses for building violations.

title: Narcotics Addict Held in Fire Death of Bronx Woman
description: A 21yearold narcotics ad dict was held without bail in Criminal Court yesterday on charges of arson and homicide, accused of having caused the death of a woman when he set fire to her apartment.

title: Israeli Planes Attack
description: TEL AVIV, April 1 (AP) Israeli planes struck along the Suez Canal today, hitting at Egyptian military targets, the Israeli command said.

title: Rent Control Time Bomb
description: Few of the City Councilmen who have voted to extend the old rent control law for three years can have any serious thought that the law will stand unchanged for that period. There is no question that the city's desperate housing shortage makes total repeal of this carryover from World War II unthink able. There is also no question that longterm reten tion in its present form would be disastrous.

title: GIANTS' M'COVEY GETS MEDICAL CLEARANCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 UPI)Willie McCovey, the Na tional League's most valuable player, got a clean bill of health on two fronts today and will rejoin the San Francisco Giants in Phoenix on Friday.

title: Millions Mail In Census Forms; Mayor Asks for Cooperation
description: Countless residents of the metropolitan area trooped to the mailboxes yesterday to de posit the long tan envelopes that will enable them to be counted by the Government.

title: Clouds Appear in Labor Picture
description: When labor specialists last fall ran their fingers down the list of contract negotiations that were scheduled for this year, they sighed and almost unanimously agreed that it would be a troublesome year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Mary P. Collins Plans to Wed
description: JAMAICA PLAIN, Mass., April 1Miss Mary Patricia Collins and Roger Howard Potter, plan to be married here on Aug. 16 in St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church.

title: McMillan Ousts Gonzales in FiveSet Battle and Enters South African Final
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 1 (Reuters)Frew McMillan of South Africa scored one of the best singles triumphs of his career when he ousted Pancho Gonzales, the 42year old American, in the South Af rican open tennis championship today.

title: REALTY TRUST SET FOR CHASE BANK
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, acting to plug the gap in mort gage money, became the first major New York bank to an nounce a plan to sponsor a sizable, closedend, realestate investment trust.

title: Post 87 Lacrosse Victor On Late Goal by Gutierrez
description: FREEPORT, L.I., April 1A goal by Alex Gutierrez with a little more than five minutes remaining gave C. W. Post Col lege an 87 lacrosse victory over Plymouth State College of New Hampshire today.

title: PLAN TO INCREASE THE VOTE OFFERED
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A program designed to increase citizen participation in the elec toral process, with a goal of a hundred million voters in the Presidential election of 1976, was outlined today by the American Jewish Committee.

title: F.T.C. Charges Jewelry Chain Violates TruthinLending Act
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The Zale Corporation, the country's largest jewelry re tailer, was charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with violating the truthinlanding act.

title: INQUIRY ON MAFIA TOLD OF BAD LOAN
description: TRENTON, April 1  The State Commission of Investi gation heard several witnesses testify today that alleged Mafia figures had gained control of a man's oceanfront mansion in Long Branch and then had proceeded, in an apparent conspiracy that involved arson and municipal corruption, to erect a luxury apartment house on the property.

title: Cambodia Hints at Shift Toward Joint Troop Use
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1A Government spokesman, asked today if concerted actions between Cambodia and Am erican or South Vietnamese troops were being carried out or envisaged, said that the answer was negative as far as South Vietnam was concerned but that he preferred not to comment on the United States ??

title: TORTURE INQUIRY IN ISRAEL SOUGHT
description: LONDON, April 1Amnesty International, a respected priv ate organization, has called for an inquiry into allegations that Israel tortures Arab prisoners.

title: 15 Japanese Hijackers Reject Compromise in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, April 2A group of about 15 hijackers hold ing about 100 people hostage aboard a Japanese Air Lines Boeing 727 today rejected a fresh compromise offer to allow them to fly to North Korea. A deadlock was reported as the Japanese Am bassador to South Korea, Masahide Kanayama, con tinued negotiations by radio with the students who had seized the jet three days earlier on a domestic flight over Japan. Toshikazu Ma eda, counselor at the Japa nese Embassy, said at a news conference that the Ambas sador had appealed to the students: Let the passengers off and we will fix the plane to fly to Pyongyang at noon. But the hijackersmembers of an extremist leftwing faction known as the Red Armyreplied: We cannot rely on your words. Japan and Korea tricked us by saying that this was Pyongyang, so we cannot trust you unless you explain why you did this.

title: NEW TOOL URGED IN MONEY POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A member of the Federal Reserve Board proposed today a sweep ing change In the way the na tion conducts its monetary policy.

title: Wedding of Janie Lee Is Canceled
description: The wedding of Miss Janie Curry Lee of Dallas and Angier St. George Biddle Duke of the Biddle and Baker banking families and the Duke tobacco family, has been canceled.

title: Last of Jubilee Concerts Given By Yale Ensemble at Tully Hall
description: The Yale University School of Music last night gave the third of its three concerts in Alice Tully Hall commemorat ing the 75th year that it has offered degrees in music. Di vided into two parts, the pro gram first offered chamber works performed by members of the faculty and then the Yale Wind Ensemble, led by Keith Wilson, took over.

title: EUGENE A. TERRAY
description: BRIARCLIFF, N. Y., April 1 Eugene A. Terray, vice presi dent in special projects of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., White Plains, died today of a heart ailment at his home, 234 Pine Road. He was 58 years old.

title: Americans Abroad Get Plea To Fill Out the Census Forms
description: LONDON, April 1United States consulates are appeal ing to the thousands of Ameri cans living abroad to complete the special overseas forms for the 1970 census.

title: Aerial History Unit to Meet
description: The American Aviation His torical Society will hold a meet ing for Eastern area members on April 11 at 8 P.M. at the Eastern Air Lines Reservations Center in Iselin, N. J. The theme of the gathering will be early New Jersey aviation.

title: Advertising: Woman's Day Dishes Up Crow
description: Talk about rubbing it in! Did you see that Woman's Day fullpage ad opposite this column Monday? That was the one in which Faw cett's flagship publication kicked the four other major women's magazines when they were down.

title: N.F.L. Playoff Is Set Up
description: The Eastern and Western Di vision champions of the Ameri can Football Conference and the Eastern and Central Divi sion champions of the National Football Conference will be the host teams for the 1970 Na tional Football League division al playoff games. Pete Rozelle, pro football commissioner, said yesterday the schedule was adopted unanimously by the N.F.L. members clubs at the recent pro football meetings in Honolulu.

title: FREDERICK PEAKE; LED ARAB LEGION
description: LONDON, April 1Lieut. Col. Frederick Gerald Peake, founder of the Arab Legion in Transjordan, died Monday at Kelso, Scotland. He was 84 years old.

title: Balaguer Challenges Dominican Opposition to Select Single Candidate to Oppose Him for the Presidency
description: SANTO DOMINGO, April 1 President Joaquin Balaguer challenged the seven opposition parties today to agree on one candidate to face him in the presidential election of May 16. The opposition parties have demanded his resignation:

title: Siberia's Oil Bonanza
description: The economics and politics of the world oil industry are in for a radical reshaping now that Soviet geolo gists have found enormous oil and gas deposits in western Siberia. Moscow intends to market these riches at home and abroad with all possible speed.

title: 34,000 Tax Refunds Sent A Month Early by City
description: The city mailed 34,000 tax refund checks Tuesday, the earliest this had ever been done, according to Finance Ad ministrator Fioravante G. Per rotta.

title: Fiedler Goes on Trial In '67 Marijuana Case
description: BUFFALO, April 1Dr. Les lie A. Fiedler, the author and literary critic who is a profes sor of English at the State Uni versity here, went on trial in City Court today on a charge that he and his wife maintained their home as premises for the use of marijuana.

title: Woolworth Sales Up 28.7% In 4 Weeks Ended March 28
description: F. W. Woolworth Company announced yesterday that its sales for the four weeks ended March 28 rose 28.7 per cent to $186,053,530 from $144,565,534 the year before. The company operated 3,740 stores at the end of the period compared to 3,680 the year before.

title: Trailblazers Sign Gilmore
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 1 (UPI)  The new Portland Trailblazers of the National Basketball Association signed today their No. 2 choice in the N.B.A. draft, Walt Gilmore of Fort Valley State, Ga. Gilmore, a 6foot6inch forward who weighs 235 pounds, averaged 23.2 points a game last season, sinking 62.2 per cent of his floor shots.

title: Lindsay's Aide on Health And Estimate Board Quits
description: The departure of Werner H. Kramarsky as a special assist ant to Mayor Lindsay, long ru mored because of his differ ences with Deputy Mayor Rich ard R. Aurelio, was confirmed yesterday in letters made pub lic by the Mayor's office.

title: BROWN IS ORDERED TO TRIAL APRIL 20
description: H. Rap Brown, the missing black power leader, has been ordered to appear on April 20 in Ellicott City, Md., to stand trial in the old Greekrevival courthouse of Howard County on charges of arson and riot.

title: Robbers Get $23,400 in Coins
description: Three bandits robbed a mes senger for a Manhattan coin dealer of $23,400 in nickels and quarters yesterday. Ac cording to the police of the As toria, Queens, station, the mes senger, Aaron Mitchell, 52 years old of Jackson Heights, had just picked up 25 bags of coins from Kennedy and La Guardia airports for a dealer, Daniel Messer, of 39 W. 55th Street.

title: Pension Checks Bigger
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Bigger Social Security checks were on their way to 25.5 mil lion Americans today, reflecting the 15 per cent increase in ben efits approved by Congress in December. The increase is retro active to Jan. 1. The regular checks due to reach all benefi ciaries by Friday will carry the enlarged monthly payment for March. Special checks will go out in the week of April 20 containing the increases for January and February.

title: NIXON SEES PERIL TO HIS AUTHORITY IN CARSWELL FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 President Nixon contends that the appointive powers of the President are being threatened by Senators seeking to defeat the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Su preme Court.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April I (UPI) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Vietnam:

title: Catherine Johnson Wed To Richard A. Meffert
description: RYE, N.Y., April 1Miss Catherine Schofield Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Johnson, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Richard Anton Mef fert, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Forster Meffert of Weston and Branford, Conn.

title: Enemy Fire Kills U.S. General, The Fifth to Die in Vietnam War
description: April 1 (AP)Brig. Gen. Wil liam R. Bond, commander of the United States 199th Light Infantry Brigade, was killed by enemy smallarms fire today. He was the fifth American gen eral killed in action in the Viet nam war the four others died in aircraft crashes.

title: Inventories Gained During February; Key Ratio Steady
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Manufacturers' inventories continued to rise at a sub stantial rate in February, al though the key ratio of in ventories to shipments did not increase any further, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Police Officer of 22 Years On Trial Today in Bribe
description: A police lieutenant with 47 departmental awards for out standing work lost a legal move yesterday to prevent his trial by the department for allegedly accepting a $75 bribe.

title: Airport Called Too Quiet
description: LONDON (UPI)Thousands of Londoners have complained about Heathrow Airport noise, but Stewart Urquart complained in a letter to the British Air ports Auhority that he had spent many fruitless hours at the airport trying to record loud airplane sounds for a record.

title: Mrs. Sherman Wakefield Dies; A Granddaughter of Ingersoll
description: Mrs. Eva Ingersoll Brown Wakefield, granddaughter of Robert G. Ingersoll, and an authority on the orator and ag nostic's life and works, died yesterday, after a long illness, at the Carolton Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. She was 78 years old and lived at 144 East 24th Street. She was the wife of Sherman Day Wake field, a retired encyclopedia editor.

title: IMPROVEMENT DUE ON PENN CENTRAL
description: Plans for emergency im provements on the Penn Cen tral's Westchester commuter lines  including the purchase of 50 new cars and the reno vation and painting of almost all passenger stations  were announced yesterday by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: New President Named By Johnson & Higgins
description: Johnson & Higgins, the in ternational insurance broker age and employe benefit plan company, has announced that Richard I. Purnell has been elected president, effective May 6. Mr. Purnell is cur rently president of the com pany's Pennsylvania subsidi ary. Edwin L. Knetzger Jr., who is now a vice president of the parent concern, will replace Mr. Purnell as presi dent of Johnson & Higgins, Pennsylvania.

title: RABBIS SEEK HELP IN ANTIDRUG DRIVE
description: The Rabbinical Council of America, the nation's largest Orthodox rabbinic organizaton, yesterday called upon Protes tant and Roman Catholic lead ers to join it in a campaign to help stamp out drug abuse.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: SovietBorn Jew, 23, Ends Hunger Strike Outside U.N
description: A young Sovietborn Jew ended a nineday hunger strike yesterday expressing confidence that his fast outside the Unit ed Nations had drawn atten tion to the tragedy of the Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: No Rubber Stamp for Carswell
description: President Nixon distorts both history and the facts in arguing that the Senate's job in considering the confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell for the Supreme Court, is to advise and consent, and not to substitute its judgment for that of the President.

title: LAKES FISH SEARCHED FOR POISON MERCURY
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) Officials of the United States and Canada are searching Great Lakes fish for poisonous mer cury.

title: Japan to Buy 34 Phantoms
description: TOKYO, April 2, (Renters) The Japanese Defense Agency has signed contracts with 11 Japanese companies to buy 34 Phantom jet fighter planes from the United States, the agency said today.

title: For White House Press, Currier & Ives With Muzak
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  It looks like the sort of place Pres ident Nixon would like to walk through, part fancy hotel lobby, part English taproom.

title: GUATEMALA REBUFFS LEFTISTS ON ENVOY
description: GUATEMALA, April 2 (Reu ters)Guatemala refused today to accept conditions of leftist guerrillas for freeing the West German Ambassador, Count Karl von Spreti.

title: Mrs. King Tops Miss Casals To Gain South African Final
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 2 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., smashed her way into the wom en's singles final today in the $47,000 South African open championships.

title: Condition of Track Is No Worry To Insko, Driver of Good Chase
description: YONKERS, April 2Today's downpour virtually inundated Yonkers Raceway, and the forecast for tomorrow indicated a 20 per cent chance of preci pitation. A week ago, such a prediction might have caused Del Insko to shudder, because it was over a sloppy track at Yonkers Raceway the previous week that Good Chase of New Zealand, driven by Insko, was upset by Adaptor of Australia.

title: Democratic State Committee Makes Final Choices
Building Contracts Strong
description: Contracts for new construc tion continued strong in Febru ary, according to the latest fig ures compiled, indicating that Nixon Administration measures to slow down the economy are not yet taking hold in an im portant sector.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, April 2, 1970

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: NO PROGRESS SEEN IN RAILROAD TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)  Labor Secretary George P. Shultz reported today no prog ress in efforts to avert a rail road walkout and he urged Congress to impose a settlement before the April 11 strike deadline.

title: Fireman Held as Arsonist
description: DANBURY, Conn., April 2 (AP)Richard I. Mtirphy, a 27yearold volunteer fireman here, was arrested this after noon on 17 counts of arson and other offenses in connec tion with a rash of fires here over the alst several months.

title: U.S. Withdraws Charges Against Air TieUp Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 The Government agreed today to the dismissal of contempt ofcourt complaints against three Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization offi cers after they pledged to make strong new appeals to bring sick controllers back to work.

title: Police Officer's Trial Delayed
description: The disciplinary trial of a po lice lieutenant accused of ac cepting bribes was adjourned yesterday at Police Headquar ters until Monday. If the Po lice Department rules against the defendantLieut. James H. Hardinghe could lose his pen sion rights. The 46yearold po lice officer had been in com mand of the 88th Precinct de tective squad in Brooklyn.

title: Looking Over the Talent at Grossinger's
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 2Politics and overcrowding made strangers roommates at Grossinger's, the sprawling resort hotel in the Catskills that was the scene of the meeting of the State Demo cratic Committee.

title: SNOW ADVANCES FUTURES PRICES
description: Another spring snowstorm swirled through the Midwest yesterday. However, the two big trading centers in Chicago, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Ex change, said trading would be conducted as usual. Apparently transportation facilities were not so badly delayed as during the recent previous storm.

title: 7 POSTAL UNIONS WIN 14% PAY RISE TIED TO REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The Administration and seven na tional postal unions reached agreement today on a twostep, 14 per cent pay increase for postal workers, 6 per cent of which the Administration wants to extend to all other Federal employes, civilian and military.

title: Haunted Boat of Another Era Will Steam Along the East Coast
description: THERE'S a steamboat round the bend in Edmond St. Martin Hanrahan's dreams. It has been there since the 32 yearold bachelor fell in love with the 150foot Parthenia on sight at City Island three years ago, despite her having been con verted to diesel power, taking on water through a gaping hole in her hull and being haunted. Nevertheless, Hanrahan has purchased the yacht from Gerald W. Ford and plans to put the steam back into her.

title: Advertising: Magazine RateCutting Stir
description: There is considerable talk these days among agency media men about the willing ness of some major maga zines to ignore their pub lished rates and sell space for less. Some media men think this is bad, but all don't.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Attributes of Judges

title: PRICES OF BONDS IN A MIXED TREND
description: Corporate bond prices con tinued to advance yesterday as the market neared the end of its third consecutive week of heavy financing activity.

title: Manhattan School Bill Signed
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day signed into law a bill es tablishing six new school dis tricts in Manhattan and desig nating May 28 for the election of the community school boards. Because of litigation elections for the school boards were not held in Manhattan on March 9 when elections took place for the boards in the other boroughs.

title: Fulbright, Fearing a Disaster, Urges Nixon to End War This Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Sen ator J. W. Fulbright said today that President Nixon's policy for Vietnam was not working, predicted that it would lead to a major disaster if it continued, and urged the President to reach a political settlement in Viet nam and in Laos and Cambo dia, the former French Indo china, this year.

title: S.E.C. Allows Stock Surcharge For 90 Days, Starting Monday
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission expressed concern yesterday over Wall Street's financial plight and gave interim approval to a request by the New York Stock Exchange to impose a $15 sur charge on most stock trans actions.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Cohoe Salmon
description: CONCORD. N. H.Ever since the spectacularly success ful introduction of cohoe salmon into Lake Michigan in the last decade, fish and game departments all over the country have had visions of the same thing in their own back yards.

title: 12 S.D. S. Militants Indicted in Chicago; Hoffman Gets Case
description: CHICAGO, April 2  A Fed eral grand jury indicted 12 lead ers of the Weathermen today on charges of conspiracy and violation of the Federal anti riot act.

title: Cambodia Frees 486, Called Last of Sihanouk's Political Prisoners
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 2The new leadership of Cambodia released today 486 persons described as all the remaining political prison ers jailed by the ousted Chief of State, Prince Norodom Si hanouk. In a ceremony, outside the National Assembly, the prisonersincluding old men, women and children born in jailwere pronounced patriots whose revolt against abuses, corruption and the absence of all social justice was fully justified. They were given mimeographed documents bearing their thumbprints and attesting their release. Prisoners from the provinces were given the equivalent of $i or $2 for bus fare home. The prisoners applauded the announcement loudly and joined in a Gov ernment  sponsored cheer: Long live Lon Nol! Long live Sirik Matak! Long live Cheng Heng! The three leaders are the Premier, First Deputy Premier and Pro visional Chief of State, who deposed Prince Sihanouk. They did not attend the cere mony. The Government, rep resented by Trinh Hoanh, secretary general of the National Committee of Salvation  the movement that overthrew the Prince two weeks agoand deputies and ministers used the occasion to impress on the freed prisoners and the several thou sand spectators that the new leaders were restoring rights that Prince Sihanouk, intoxi cated with personal power, had unjustly abrogated.

title: RABBI TELUSHKIN, 88, ORTHODOX SCHOLAR
description: Rabbi Nissen Telnshkin, an Orthodox scholar, died Satur day in his home at 942 East 10th Street, Brooklyn. He was 88 years old.

title: Scientists Tracking Elk Wearing Electronic Collar
description: JACKSON, Wyo., April 2 (AP)Space scientists are keeping a closce watch on the elk Monique in their second at tempt to track migration ha bits of the 7,000head elk herd near Jackson.

title: Market Place:
description: IT'S no joke in the executive suite. Before the annual meeting of Hercules, Inc., there was considerable fear that protesters might turn up and use some of the explo sives manufacturer's blasting powder to reduce the meeting to smithereens.

title: NEW SUSPECTS HELD IN HARLEM MURDER
description: Two new suspects in the 1968 robberymurder of a Harlem bartender  a crime for which two other men were paroled Monday after spending two years in jail awaiting trial were arraigned and held with out bail yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Salute to American Achievement
description: AN ode to the accomplish ments of American engi neering, entitled It Couldn't Be Done: A Salute to Ameri can Achievement, was de signed as a tribute to the imaginative minds that built the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, the Holland Tunnel in New York, the Alaska Skyway and the Hoover Dam, among many other ventures.

title: TIGHT CREDIT GRIP RELAXING SLOWLY
description: Bit by bit, the Federal Re serve System is relaxing the tight grip of its policy of credit restraint, banking figures pub lished yesterday showed.

title: Burt Avedon Is Fiance Of Luciana Pignatelli
description: Princess Luciana Pigna telli, European fashion co ordinator for Eve of Roma, and Burt Simm Avedon, presi dent of the Bostonbased cosmetics concern, plan to be married.

title: HAYASAKI SETS PACE IN TITLE GYMNASTICS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 2 (UPI) Yoshi Hayasaki of the Uni versity of Washington surged into the lead in three events today in the opening competi tion of the National Collegiate gymnastics championships at Temple University.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 3, 1970

title: Music: Abduction Back
description: MOZART'S Abduction From the Seraglio not the Entfhrung aus dem Serail, for the work is being sung in Englishre ceived its first performance last night at the New York State Theater. It was the New York City Opera pro duction that had been done last fall with the same cast.

title: Appeal in Soviet Asks for Gradual Democratization
description: MOSCOW, April 2  An appeal fol gradual democratiza tion of Soviet society, pur portedly written by three schol ars, has been made available here by reliable Soviet sources.

title: Company Fined in Pollution
description: The Colonial Sand and Stone Company was fined $2,500 yes terday after pleading guilty in Federal Court to five counts of any 11count indictment for polluting the Hudson and East Rivers.

title: Aquanauts Ready to Start 7Month Undersea Study
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., April 2  Frigate birds and brown pelicans circled watch fully over Beehive Cove, a se cluded inlet. The water was warm, tranquil and turquoise, with an occasional ripple of navy blueideal for the mis sion at hand.

title: Johnson Nephew Charged
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 2 (UPI)  A nephew of former President Lyndon B. Johnson faces five charges resulting from a traffic accident in northwest Oklahoma City, the police said today. Samuel Sum mers Johnson, 27 years old, was charged with failure to yield the right of way, destroy ing city property, driving with out a state driver's license, driving under the influence of intoxicants and public drunken ness. He was jailed Tuesday night and later released on bond.

title: Youngstown Sheet Says President Retired Early
description: The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, the nation's eighth largest steel producer, announced yesterday that its 57yearold president and chief executive officer, Robert E. Wil liams, had requested and been granted early retirement.

title: Washington: President Nixon's Gamble
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Something very odd seems to have happened to President Nixon's staff work or his judgment, or both. For he is constantly surprising everybody or being surprised himself in the Supreme Court fight these days, and finding himself in precisely the kind of political battles he was previously de termined to avoid.

title: Gov. Rhodes Says His Attorney Will File Libel Suit Against Life Magazine
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 2 (AP)Gov. James A. Rhodes, said today that he would file a libel suit against Life maga zine because of an article about him last May that he said was designed to eliminate me from the race for the U.S. Senate.

title: Rockland Phone Service Cut
description: BARDONIA, N.Y., April 2A construction crane severed the telephone toll cable to New City here on Route 304 at 81 o'clock this morning and all toll telephone service in the area was off until 10:20 A.M. Local dial calls were not affected.

title: City Designates Affiliate Artist For Dance Plan
description: The city named its own ambassador at large for dance yesterday. She is Carole Johnson, a dancer, who will be Affiliate Artist of the De partment of Cultural Affairs.

title: Official Testifies Cash Given Adams Was Not Reported
description: A state election official testi fied yesterday that State Sena tor William E. Adams had not reported a cash contribution of $5,000 that two company ex ecutives said they made to the Senator's 1968 election cam paign.

title: Qatar Now Dawlat Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar, April 2 (UPI) Qatar proclaimed a new provi sional constitution today and declared itself the independent sovereign state of Dawlat Gatar.

title: DR. RUDOLF F. N ACER OF SWISS AMERICAN
description: Dr. Rudolf F. Hager, presi dent of Swiss American Corpo ration, securities analysts, 100 Wall Street, died here Monday. He was 58 years old and lived at Old Bedford Road, Green wich, Conn.

title: French Revising Airport Plans
description: ROISSY  EN  FRANCE, France, April 2The building of Europe's largest airport has produced surprises rang ing from the threat of im mense traffic jams to an un expected boon for the pheas ants that survive here on the outskirts of Paris.

title: FANS BRAVE SNOW FOR BREWER SEATS
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2 (AP) Six inches of snow whitened Milwaukee County Stadium this morning, but baseball fans wad ed through the slush to buy season tickets for the Brewers' games.

title: Authors League Deplores News Media Subpoenas
description: The Authors League of America announced yesterday that it deplores the recent wave of subpoenas compelling news media writers to produce notes and records of interviews and to testify about private conversations.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS CONTINUE SLOWLY
description: Newspaper labor negotiations proceeded at a slow pace yes terday with no announcement of major progress.

title: COURT BARS SITIN AT Y IN HARLEM
description: State Supreme Court Justice Edward T. McCaffrey has granted a preliminary injunc tion to the Harlem Y.W.C.A., barring a sitin on the organiza iton's premises.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Defiant Greek Editor
description: ATHENS, April 2Ioannis Kapsis will be unable to address the Overseas Press Club in New York tomorrow on PresentDay Working Conditions for Greek Jour nalists, as he had been in vited to do.

title: AURELIO DAUGHTER DIES AFTER A FALL
description: Jodi Aurelio, the 18yearold daughter of the Deputy Mayor, died last night of a blood clot caused by a fall from a horse.

title: Savings Bond Redemptions Outpaced Sales for March
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (Reu ters)  The Treasury Depart ment said today that redemp tions of Treasury Savings Bonds and notes outweighed sales for the 16th consecutive month in March. Total isssues came to $458million compared to Feb ruary's $414million, with re demptions at $549million against $487million in Febru ary.

title: 7 Dominican Parties to Boycott Vote
description: SANTO DOMINGO, April 2 The Dominican Republic's seven nonCommunist opposition par ties declared jointly today that they would abstain from general elections May 16 in protest against President Joaquin Bala guer's refusal to resign.

title: Miss Tingle Takes Feature at FogEnshrouded Aqueduct
description: C'mon Somebody was the cry at Aqueduct through most of the racing program yesterday. The fog that enshrouded the the race course made it almost impossible at times to follow the progress of the thorough breds on the sloppy track, but the actionhungry fans did not let that interfere with their im pulse for exhortation.

title: WagePrice Treadmill
description: The Nixon Administration's failure to move long ago tb check the wageprice spiral is exacting a heavy price in the battle to shore up the value of the dollar.

title: Yanks Again Will Admit City's Youngsters Free
description: The New York Yankees and Con Edison will continue to play Take Me Out to the Ball Game this season for youngsters from disadvan taged areas.

title: TENANTS POLLED ON RENT INCREASE
description: A confidential poll taken last fall for the Lindsay adminis tration by Louis Harris and Associates found that 37 per cent of a sample of ten ants in rentcontrolled apart ments thought rent increases would be fair to cover rises in landlords' maintenance ex penses.

title: JERSEY APPROVES HIGHER BUS FARES
description: NEWARK, April 2The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners approved today an interim fare increase by Public Service Coordinated Transport that will affect about 800,000 passengers with in the state.

title: Crippled Veterans Find Hospitals Crowded and Attitudes at Home Ambiguous
description: The only time the American people ever see a Vietnam casualty is when he's got blood running out of him on the Cronkite program. After that, he's forgotten.

title: State Electoral Chaos
description: In the end, the prize proved no prize at all. After all the armtwisting by county leaders, the bitter demonstrations by blacks, the shouting and turmoil on the convention floor, the State Democratic Com mittee's nomination for Governor lost any luster it previously might seem to have had.

title: Unueilings
description: SALHOLZHelena. Unveiling April 51:30, Knollwood Park Cemetery, Cooper and Cypress Ave., Brooklyn. Section L. Sons: Joshua Salholz and Simon Sethlz, M.D. Friends and relatives are invlited to come.

title: Hijackers Delay on Offer
description: SEOUL, April 2The offer by Mr. Yamamura to become a hostage to North Korea was not immediately accepted by the hijackers because they were not sure he was the Japanese Vice Minister of Transportation.

title: Troops Again Fire Tear Gas to Quell Ulster Outbreak
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, April 3 (Reuters)  British troops fired tear gas last night to break up a riot by several hundred Roman Catholic youths.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK SORENSEN TO RUN FOR U.S. SENATOR
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 2  The Democratic State Com mittee completed a tumultuous twoday meeting today by des ignating two candidates who made their reputations with the Kennedy familyTheodore C. Sorensen for United States Senator and Adam Walinsky for Attorney General.

title: HENRY CAPTURES ONEMETER DIVE
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 2 (UPI)Jim Henry, a student at the University of Indiana, competing as an inde pendent, won the onemeter springboard event today for his second straight victory in the National Amateur Athletic Un ion diving championships.

title: City of Golden Calf Being Unearthed
description: Excavations at the north ernmost tip of Israel have begun to yield evidence of the ruins of the city of Dan, where the Bible says the secessionist King Jeroboam worshipped the Golden Calf about 900 years before Christ.

title: French Police Hunt Gunmen After They Release Hostage
description: AIXENPROVENCE, France, April 2 (Reuters)The police searched today for four gunmen after they released a hostage taken from a Riviera hotel.

title: Fox Merger Talk Ended by Heller
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, whose man agement has been reported over the last IS months to be both seeking and rebuffing merger proposals, had onagain offagain talks with another company this week.

title: Hijackers of Jet Release Passengers in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, April 3More than 100 pas sengerssome near collapse were released today after 78 hours in a Japanese jet liner hi jacked by Japanese students armed with swords.

title: Sam Kaplan, Zenith President And General Manager, Is Dead
description: CHICAGO, April 2Sam Kaplan, president of Zenith Radio Corporation, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Oak Park. He was 62 years old.

title: Blast in Mine Kills Company Official On Inspection Tour
description: DOLA, W. Va., April 2An explosion of methane gas roared through the Compass No. 2 mine of the Clinchfield Coal Company this afternoon. One man was reported killed.

title: FISCHER STILL LEADS IN BELGRADE CHESS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 Bobby Fischer, eight times the United States champion, drew his thirdround game to day with a former world cham pion, Tigran Petrosian.

title: NIXON SCHOOL STAND ASSAILED BY MUSKIE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 2 (AP)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, disagreed here today with President Nixon on the ques tion of what is expected of the nation's schools.

title: Sanitation Police Will Resume Ticketing for Illegal Dumping
description: The Sanitation Department began a crackdown yesterday on the illegal dumping of con struction and household rub bish on city streets.

title: Melbourne Skipper Retires
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 2 (UPI)Capt. John P. Stevenson, commander of the Australian aircraft carrier, Melbourne, which cut a United States de stroyer in half last year, has retired from the Navy

title: I.B.M. GEAR SOUGHT BY UNITED AIR LINES
description: United Air Lines, which last January canceled a $56million contract it had given the Sperry Rand Corporation in 1965 for a Univac electronic data sys tem, disclosed yesterday it now is negotiating with the Inter national Business Machines Cor poration for computers and other electronic equipment.

title: La MamaCanada in Play
description: The La MamaCanada Rep ertory Company, a new troupe of 25 student actors who were trained at McMaster Univer sity under the direction of Martin Brenzell, will appear here tomorrow and Sunday at the Drama Workshop of Co lumbia University, Broadway and 120th Street. The group will perform in Torn Eyen's The White Whore and the Bit Players. Ellen Stewart is pre senting the company in asso ciation with Columbia Uni versity.

title: NewCar Sales Fell 11% During March; Installment Credit Was Up in February
description: Newcar sales in the final third of March were down sharply from yearbefore levels, it was reported yesterday. Meanwhile, more production layoffs were announced by the General Motors Corporation.

title: VIETNAMESE COOL TO FRENCH PLAN
description: PARIS, April 2North Viet nam, the Vietcong and the Sai gon delegation to the peace talks took a reserved attitude today toward a French sugges tion for a general conference on peace and neutrality in Indo china.

title: Enemy Attacks Ebb in Vietnam After 61 Americans Are Killed in 2Day Surge
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2 (AP)A wave of heavy en emy attacks that struck across South Vietnam for two days ebbed tonight, and the United States command said the worst of the fighting appeared to be over.

title: Wings Subdue Leafs, 42, and Take 3d Place From Idle Canadiens
description: DETROIT, April 2 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings moved into third place tonight, a point in front of the idle Montreal Cana diens, in the nipandtuck East ern Division battle in the Na tional Hockey League by down ing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 42. The victory gave the Wings a threepoint edge over the New York Rangers, who also did not play tonight.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been hilted in Vietnam:

title: Cambodia Gets Asian Loan
description: MANILA, April 2 (UPI)The Asian Development Bank ap proved its first loan to Cam bodia today: $1.7million for improving the electric power supply system in Pnompenh..

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Sentence for Flag Burning
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., (UPI) A teenage Arlington high school girl was sentenced to six months in jail today for burning an American flag. East Cambridge District Court Judge M. Edward Viola imposed the sentence on Martha A. Meyers, 17 years, after the girl pleaded guilty to the incident.

title: A.C.L.U. CONDEMNS ATTACK ON GROSS
description: TRENTON, April 2  The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey today accused Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for the state, of conducting a campaign of guilt by investigation against Nelson G. Gross, the Republi can state chairman and the leading contender for the party's United States Senate nomination.

title: Stage: Pinter's Small Talk of Reality
description: PRESUMABLY, and I put it at least diffidently, Harold Pinter is, apart from the dubi ously linguistic case of Sam uel Beckett, the most im portant Englishspeaking play wright of our time. It is per haps therefore a little surpris ing to see his new bill, al ready given by the Royal Shakespeare Company in Lon don, in that amiable basement of the Lincoln Center Reper tory Company, which it calls the Forum Theater.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AS much an exercise in fumbling un certainty as the children's game of blind man's buff is the groping of every selfappointed baseball expert in the land when confronted by the task of sorting out the ball clubs into an order of finish for each pennant race. There are bound to be embarrassing cases of mis taken identity.

title: Miss Nancy H. Stewart Is Engaged
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 2Dr. and Mrs. Charles F. Stewart of Bronxville and North Goshen, Vt., have an nounced the engagement of Dr. Stewart's daughter, Miss Nancy Hanford Stewart, to Specialist 5 Gerald George Nadig, U. S. A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Nadig of Southold, L. I.

title: White House Asks Rise of $65Million For Veterans' Care
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 President Nixon asked Congress today for a $65million increase in the Veterans Administra tion's budget for health care to expand medical programs for the increasing number of Vietnam veterans.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS NIXON ON RIGHTS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 2 Mayor Lindsay said today that recent legislative proposals by the Nixon Administration con stitute the most significant threat to freedom from our own Government in a generation.

title: ACTION ON IMPORTS OF MEATS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)  Federal farm officials an nounced today that they saw no need for starting a pro cedure that could lead first to invoking and then to suspend ing 1970 meat import quotas in an effort to hold the line on consumer meat prices.

title: Books of The Times
description: THIS is a lowpressure, atmospheric sort of story, a book to be consumed at ease and in small bites. But there's a scene about threefourths of the way through that is curiously powerful and illustrates how Joanna Ostrow's first novel affects the reader.

title: Disruption at Hunter Is Ended After 200 Policemen Are Called
description: A student protest that had crippled operations at Hunter College since Wednesday after noon appeared to have ended last night after the college administration summoned the Police.

title: Greensboro Golf Postponed
description: GREENSBORO, N. C. April 2 (AP)A heavy rain, accompa nied by gusty winds, forced the postponement today of the first round of the $180,000 Great er Greensboro open golf tour nament. Play was rescheduled for one round tomorrow and Saturday with the final two rounds on Sunday.

title: Mrs. Zabriskie Wed To Arthur Cohen
description: Mrs. Virginia Marshall Zabriskie, founder of the Zabriskie Gallery, and Arthur W. Cohen were married here yesterday at the bridegroom's home. Rabbi Joseph Gelber man performed the ceremony.

title: George Backer Heads Fund To Foster Worthy Plays
description: George Backer has been elected president of the Theater Development Fund, Inc., a non profit organization founded in 1967 to stimulate interest in the theater. The fund buys tickets to stage productions it con siders worthy of support, and distributes them to young people at reduced prices.
