title: Excerpts From Address by Lindsay
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 3 Following are excerpts from the text of an address by Mayor Lindsay at the Berkeley campus of the University of California.

title: Miss Wallach, John McKeon Plan to Marry
description: WARRENTON, Va., April 2 Miss Madeleine Feroline Perkins Wallach, a great granddaughter of Richard Wallach, who was Mayor of Washington during the Civil War, has made plans to be married this summer to John Bernard McKeon, grandson of the late Robert L. Hoguet of New York, former president and board chairman of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

title: SUNS TURN BACK LAKERS, 112 TO 98
description: PHOENIX, April 2 (AP)The Phoenix Suns rallied late in the third quarter to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 11298, tonight and took a 21 lead in the National Basketball Association Western Division playoffs.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
Agreement Bridges the Continent
description: Carson/Roberts in Los Angeles and Dodge & Delano in New York have agreed to a countryspanning working relationship. Who knows, if all works well, it could lead more.

title: Many Democrats Assail State Nominating System
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 2 The confusion and disarray and the charges of bossism and racism that marked the Democratic State Committee's meeting here during the last few days have brought wide spread demands for the elimina tion of such meetings from the nominating process.

title: YANKS TOP EXPOS WITH 5 IN 6TH, 97
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 2 (AP) Bobby Murcer's first home run of the spring capped a five run, sixthinning rally that gave the New York Yankees a 97 exhibition victory tonight over the Montreal Expos.

title: Bogs Keeps European Title By Stopping McAteer in 11
description: AARHUS, Denmark, April 2 (UPI) Tom Bogs, Denmark's unbeaten European middle weight champion, successfully defended his title tonight by sstopping Les McAteer, a Britis challenger, in 1 minute 23 seconds of the 11th round of their scheduled 15round bout.

title: Hungarian Fund To Give Awards To 5 at Dinner
description: The American Hungarian Studies Foundation's annual George Washington Awards dinner dance will be held April 15 at the Plaza.

title: Wood, Skater, Turns Pro
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2 (API) Tim Wood, a twotime world amateur figure skating cham pion announced today he had signed a threeyear professional contract with an ice show.

title: Phil Ochs Fans Are Won Over by Rock
description: Enough time had passed since his two tumultuous con certs at Carnegie Hall last Friday night to give Phil Ochs a chance to reflect on the ex perience. The concerts, which threatened to be the most disastrous of his nineyear career, have turned into a major breakthrough for the politically oriented folk singer.

title: Katherine Anne Porter Is 79 and Sovereign
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md. Katherine Anne Porter has reached that peak in a writer's life when occasional writings are collected and enduring wisdom cherished.

title: Jersey Acts on Auto Bills
description: TRENTON, April 2 (AP) The Assembly acted today on a package of bills designed to stiffen existing laws on motor vehicle violations.

title: Syria Reports Victory
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2  The Syrians reported today that they had shot down seven Israeli jets, including three Phantoms, as the Israeli Air Force and artillery struck at Syrian territory for seven and a half hours along a sixtymile front. Broadcasts by the Da mascus radio said two Mig21's had been lost.

title: R.O.T.C. Protest at Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 2 (AP) Demonstrators attacked R.O.T.C. headquarters at Stan ford University for the second straight night today, breaking a dozen windows before law officers dispersed them. About 80 policemen and sheriff's dep uties quickly broke up the demonstration of 150 persons. The police arrested four per sons. Two were identified as nonstudents.

title: Screen: History as Myth
Reagan Greets Lindsay As Occupant of State
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 2 (UPI)Mayor Lindsay said here today that he had re ceived a warm note from Gov. Ronald Reagan when he arrived at his hotel to speak at the University of California.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS A 1.1% DROP
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Freight traffic on United States railroads and Intercity Truck Tonnage in the latest week ended March 28 were both be low the volume in the corre sponding week of last year.

title: Rockefeller Fund Elects 2
description: Cyrus Vance, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and Clif ton R. Wharton Jr., president of Michigan State University, have been elected to the board of trustes of the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday. They replace Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secrtary Gen eral for Special Political Af fairs at the United Nations, and Lord Franks, provost of Worcester College, Oxford, England.

title: Postal Accord
description: The agreement coupling future postal wage increases to postal reform is a distinct contribution to the national welfare. The pact should remove all threat of another major disruption of the mails and also insure swift Congressional approval of the Nixon Adminis tration's plans for a more efficient postal service.

title: LOEW'S NET SETS SIXMONTH MARK
description: Revenues and earnings of Loew's Theatres, Inc., for the six months ended Feb. 28 were the highest in the company's history, reflecting increased profits of the hotel, theatre and tobacco operations, the con cern's report disclosed yester day. Secondquarter earnings, on slightly lower gross revenues than the year before, also set a record.

title: Sympathy for Air TieUp Ebbing
description: Aviation leaders are a lot more outraged by the current airtraffic disruption than they were when F. Lee Bailey's con trollers engaged in two previ ous slowdowns. In the past, despite the loss of dollars, in dustry officials quietly felt a good deal of sympathy for what the controllers were doing. This was particularly true during the summer travel rush two years ago when the con trollers' super strict adherence to trafic rules, plus bad weather, caused hor rendous delays. They sympa thized because years of experi ence had shown that it took a crisis (a slowdown orworse a catastrophic midaircolli sion) to produce any noticeable improvement in an airtraffic system that was blatantly over strained.

title: Rain, Snow and Wind Batter The Eastern Half of the Nation
description: Drenching rains, heavy snow and tornadoforce winds bat tered the eastern half of the nation yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDADY, APRIL 3, 1970

title: EARLY STOCK RISE FADES STEADILY
description: The stock market lapsed back into an indecisive pattern yes terday as Wednesday's modest rally failed to attract new buy ing interest.

title: COLETTE BOKY SINGS JULIETTE AT THE MET
description: Colette Boky was the Juliette in last night's presentation of Romo et Juliette at the Met ropolitan Opera. It was a role she had sung once before with the company here, as a replace ment for Mirella Freni, and on this occasion she gave an as sured performance. She looked young, pretty and winsome, was suitably spirited in the first act and softly appealing in the love scenes.

title: Four Teachers Jailed
description: BOSTON, April 2 (AP)Four Woburn teachers who took part in a teachers strike in defiance of a court order were held in contempt of court today and sent to Suffolk County Jail without right of bail. Judge Robert Sullivan in Superior Court told the teachers they would be released if they re turn to contract negotiations.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange mostly declined yes terday in slow trading.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: APRIL 2, 1970

title: The Indochinese Puzzle: U.S. Holding to Its Policies
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Two weeks after the overthrow of Prince Sihanouk in Cambodia, this capital does not know whether that country is drifting toward civil war or coming under solidified and friendlier rule.

title: Ski Conditions
description: The following reports were provided by the operators of the ski areas now open. Mes sages were filed at times indi cated in parentheses:

title: Name Change Planned
description: The St. Joseph Lead Com pany said yesterday that share holders would vote at the annual meeting on May 11 on a proposal to change the name to the St. Joe Minerals Corpo ration.

title: Knicks, Paced by Reed, Rout Bullets, 10180, and Gain 32 Edge in Series
description: With a superb 36point, 36 rebound performance by Willis Reed, whose aching knee re sponded to a second cortisone shot on Wednesday, the New York Knickerbockers crushed the Baltimore Bullets, 10180, last night at Madison Square Garden to the accompaniment of nonstop shouting by another capacity crowd of 19,500.

title: Nixons to See Graduation
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) President and Mrs. Nixon plan to attend the graduation of their daughter Julie from Smith College at Northampton. Mass., on May 29 the White House said today. But the President declined to make the commencement address. It was ?ertain whether the Nixons would attend the commence ment a week later at A? ? when Julie's husband. ???

title: Syracuse U. to Give Award To Drew Middleton of Times
description: SYRACUSE. April 2 (AP) The Syracuse University School of Journalism yesterday named Drew Middleton, the European affairs correspondent of The New York Times, as this year's recipient of the school's dis tinguished service award.

title: Students Elect Radical at Texas U.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 2A 25yearold bearded, radical activist from Brentwood, L.I., was elected today as presi dent of the students associa tion of the University of Texas.

title: ORDER IN FINANCE URGED BY BANKER
description: A. W. Clausen, the president of the Bank of America, warn ing that the lack of liquidity a worldwide shortage of money would be a chronic condition in the years ahead, outlined a sevenpoint program yesterday to restore order to the financial system.

title: Philadelphia Defendant Is Gagged
description: PHILADELPHIA. April 2 (UNI) Just 24 hours after the United States Supreme Court ruled that a defendant may be gagged in court if he failed to behave himself, Judge Leo Weinrott ordered George Kenney gagged yes terday after the defendant had told the judge to go to hell.

title: BAYH SAYS NIXON ERRS ON HIS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Senator Birch Bayh said today that President Nixon was wrong in charging that Senate opponents of G. Harrold Cars well's nomination to the Su preme Court were overstepping their Droner constitutional role.

title: Effort to Terrorize Press Laid to Athens
description: ATHENS, April 2A former Foreign Minister of Greece, Evangelos AveroffTossizza, ac cused the militarybacked re gime today of trying to ter rorize the Greek press through harsh courtmartial sentences on journalists.

title: FAITH IN THE LAW SUBJECT OF STUDY
description: The Ford Foundation has appropriated $1million for grants to study what it feels is a growing lack of faith in this country's judicial process.

title: Seoul Restaurant With a Dazzling View
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe place to be seen in Seoul these daysprovided you have enough won (there are approximately 300 won to a dollar)  is in the Galaxy Room of the glittering, new and still uncompleted Chosun Hotel here.

title: Jurists Protest Trial Bar
description: GENEVA, April 2The Inter national Commission of Jurists said today that the Greek au thorities had once more pub licly demonstrated their indif ference to the rule of law by barring foreign observers from a military court now trying 34 persons on charges of subver sion.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert W. Hasbrouck Jr., Joseph A. Payne and Robert N. Davies have been named as vice presi dents of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Philippine Senators Agree On Inquiry Into U.S. Funds
description: MANILA, Friday, April 3A committee of the Philippine Senate investigating the use of United States funds for a Philippine group in South Viet nam has agreed to begin with an inquiry into possible secret agreements between the Philip pines and United States.

title: Jets Sign Sauer to 2Year Pact For Salary of $40,000 a Season
description: GEORGE SAUER, the star pass receiver of the New York Jets and one of the best in the game, signed a twoyear contract yesterday. In keeping with club policy no salary was divulged, but Sauer's annual base pay was assumed to be about $40,000, befitting a twotime allleague performer who caught 45 passes last season. Sauer caught 66 the year before and led the league with 75 in 1967. His lower production reflected a more balanced Jet attack rather than any deficiencies on the part of the 26yearold blond.

title: Mets Sink Pirates, 20, in Florida Finale as Seaver Fans Nine in 7 Innings
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2The New York Mets closed out the Florida phase of spring training tonight when Tom Seaver and Ron Taylor shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 20.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales for the latest week ended March 28 were an esti mated $709million, an increase of 11 per cent above the $638 million sales for the correspond ing week of last year.

title: D. D. RODERICK JR., EL PASO PUBLISHER
description: EL PASO, April 2 (AP)  Dorrance D. Roderick Jr., news paper executive and cattleman, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 45 years old.

title: Liberal Party Group Demands an Open Primary and End to Rose Manipulations
description: Key members of a new group within the Liberal party yesterday attacked the leader ship of the party's vice chair man, Alex Rose, and called for open primaries to choose party candidates for Senator and Governor.

title: A Surprise From HalstonLow Prices
description: AFTER the pink, purple and green wigs, and the prices, the most astonishing thing about the first show ing of the Halston International collec tion yesterday was the miniskirts. There were at least two of them, plus a long shirt worn as a dress, and they set the audience buzzing.

title: lona Paper Purchased
description: BRISTOL, Va., April 2 (AP) James P. Lawrence and asso ciated newspaper companies in Bristol and Florence, Ala., an nounced today the purchase of The Oskaloosa (Iowa) Daily Herald. The Herald is pub lished six afternoons a week and has a circulation of ap proximately 8,500.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA FIGHT WITH TANKS AND JETS 8 HOURS
description: JERUSALEM, April 2Israel today initiated the heaviest air and ground battle with Syria since the sixday war of 1967, apparently losing her first Phantom jet fighter over enemy territory in the process.

title: Theater Directory Published
description: The American Educational Theater Association has pub lished the 1970 Summer The ater Directory, which lists 365 summer theaters  amateur, semiprofessional, educational and professional. This year's edition includes information about whom to write to for jobs.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: U.S. MOVES TO AID MIDWEST SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Government moved today to resolve a financial problem in two Middle Western school districts that have declared that the children of Federal em ployes must pay tuition to at tend public school classes.

title: SCOTTOS CALLED TO HEARING TODAY
description: Anthony M. Scotto, the Brooklyn dock union leader, was ordered yesterday to ap pear today before the Water front Commission, which is looking into alleged conflicts of interest in a licensing case.

title: HEALTHCARE IS SUED ON DENTAL SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The Government filed an antitrust suit today to require the Healthcare Corporation of Boston to divest itself of four dental supply companies in New York.

title: Murrow Papers Donated For New Center at Tufts
description: MEDFORD, Mass., April 2 (AP)The papers and personal library of Edward R. Morrow have been given by his widow, Janet, to a center bearing his name at Tuft University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy.

title: ALLAN STEVENSON, A BIBLIOGRAPHER, 66
description: CHICAGO, April 2  Allan Stevenson, a bibliographer, died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home at 1018 North State Street. He was 66 years old.

title: LOS ANGELES GETS LEADFREE CAR GAS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2 Texaco, Inc., announced today that some of its stations in the Los Angeles basin were offer ing a new leadfree gasoline, the first introduced for sale on the West Coast.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Associated Dry Goods Elects
description: Edward M. Condon, regional executive vice president of the Associated Dry Goods Corpora tion, has been elected to the company's board of directors. He continues as president of the H. & S. Pogue Company di vision.

title: Hersholt Award for Jesse!
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 2 (AP) The Jean Hersholt humani tarian award will be presented to comedian George Jessel next Tuesday during the Academy, Award ceremonies. Gregory Peck, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and, Sciences, said today Mr. Jes sel would be cited for his con sistent devotion to the cause of easing the burdens of loneliness and pain of American service men in combat areas and hos pitals throughout the world.

title: West Germany Narrows February Payments Deficit
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, April 2 (Reuters)West Germany's basic balance of payments showed a deficit of $100million in February, com pared to a deficit of $790mil lion the previous month, the Central Bank announced today.

title: War Foes to Fight Counterinsurgency On U.S. Campuses
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Antiwar protesters announced today the beginning of a na tional drive to force Govern mentsponsored projects involv ing counterinsurgency off the campuses and eventually out of existence.

title: Franco Article Rules Out Liberal Reforms in Spain
description: MADRID, April 2General issimo Francisco Franco and his principal aide, Vice President Luis Carrero Bianco, warned their countrymen today that efforts to introduce liberal Democracy into Spain would be tantamount to offering a drink to a reformed alcoholic.

title: WOMAN INDICTED IN FIRE FATAL TO 11
description: A 77yearold woman was in dicted yesterday on charges of manslaughter and negligent, homicide in the deaths of 11 children in a fire last Dec. 18 that destroyed the 80yearold wood frame building she owned in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Asian Textile Stand Angers U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  United States officials today expressed their anger and frus tration after a year of negotia tions with Japan and other Asian countries over the prob lem of textile imnorts.

title: U.S. Doubles Narcotics Corps Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 The State Department an nounced today a doubling of the corps of narcotics control officers assigned to United States embassies and missions overseas.

title: Soviet Bloc Chiefs Gather In Budapest for Major Fete
description: BUDAPEST, April 2Hun gary is preparing to hold a big celebration Saturday, the 25th anniversary of her liber ation by the Red army.

title: MILWAUKEE ROAD SEEKS A MERGER
description: Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad decided late yesterday what their financiallyailing system needs is to become part of the highly profitable Union Pacific Railroad and, if not that system, then part of the equally profitable Southern Pacific Company.

title: U.S. DOUBTS RUSSIANS PILOT U.A.R. PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the Ad ministration had no evidence whatsoever that Soviet pilots had been flying Egyptian air craft in combat against Israel.

title: GLORIA CONTRERAS GIVES NEW DANCES
description: Gloria Contreras is a thor oughly professional choreog rapher and ballet dancer whose concertslike the one by her company at Kaufmann Concert Hall last nightnever fail to please or impress in their craftsmanship.

title: JAMES A. SCHAUMBURG
description: James A. Schaumburg, who retired as vice presidentsecuri ties of the Hamburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn, in 1965, died Sunday in Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and lived at 49 Sum mer Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Reed's Big Effort Heals Pride Wounded by Two Poor Games
description: I don't think you could say anyone on our ball club played well, said Gene Shue, the Baltimore coach. I'm thinking hard, but I can't come up with anyone who was close to his potential.

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONRichard. Happy birthday In heaven, father. Children Jewel, Geraldine and Parnell.

title: Bridge:
description: IT is often vital to be able to judge whether another player's bidding is based on highcard strength or distri butional power. Subtle clues that may provide the answer to such questions can easily be missed by experts.

title: Homemade Bomb Found in Vestibule Of Bank in Bronx
description: A homemade pipe bomb was found early yesterday in the vestibule of a Chase Manhattan Bank in the South Bronx.

title: Black Panther Trial in Jersey Is Quiet and Orderly Process
description: JERSEY CITY, April 2The trial of three members of the Black Panther party on charges of machinegunning a police pre cinct house moved into its sec ond month this morning in an atmosphere of quiet propriety that has pleased the officers of the court and disappointed hangerson who seek excite ment in courthouses.

title: Chase Assailed on World Issues
description: Stockholders of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, meet ing yesterday afternoon under extraordinary security arrange ments, peppered David Rocke feller with an assortment of questions and protests that turned the annual meeting into a noisythough orderly forum dealing largely with international affairs.

title: ARNOLD NEMIROFF
description: Arnold Nemiroff of Sherman Oaks, Calif., director of busi ness affairs for network pro graming for Universal Stu dios, died of a heart attack Wednesday in North Holly wood. He was 43 years old.

title: Abortion Referral Unit Sues
description: BOSTON, April 2 (UPI)The Branch Referral Service and Travel Agency, Inc., of New York, filed suit in Federal Court here today against the State of Massachusetts chal lenging the constitutionality of an 1847 law forbidding the publication of information con cerning abortions. The agency provides advice and informa tion on legal hospital abortions in foreign countries where the practice is available.

title: HARRY L. POWELL SR., YACHT ENTHUSIAST
description: Harry L. Powell Sr., for 50 years a marine insurance brok er and for 30 years a principal in the firm of Barry & Powell, 90 John Street, died Tuesday in BeekmanDowntown Hospi tal. He was 71 years old and lived at 87 Hawthorne Place, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Benjamin F. Leaman to Marry Mrs. Monique Pflieger Blake
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pierrepont Isham Prentice of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have made known the en gagement of Mrs. Prentice's daughter, Mrs. Monique Pflieger Blake of New York and St. Maarten, Netherlands Antilles, to Benjamin F. Lea man of Birchrunville, Pa., where the wedding will take place on May 9.

title: Negro Named Cougar Aide
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 2 (UPI)Washington State Uni versity hired its first black foot ball coach today. His is Roose velt Ellerbe Jr., currently on the football staff at Sacramento City College, Calif. Head coach Jim Sweeney said Ellerbe would join the Cougar staff on Mon day and be assigned to coach ing linebackers.

title: Impressionists Retain Special Status
description: NOWADAYS, the paintings of the impressionists are universally adored. Contro versies may still divide the art world into factions. Difficult new ideas may still separate artists from the public. Criti cal disputation may have de veloped into a minor indus try. But none of this touches the special status that im pressionist painting currently enjoys. Here is a style that brings pleasure to the Philis tine public and the connois seur in equal measure.

title: 76ers, Near Elimination, Face Loss of Cunningham to A.B.A.
description: MADISON, Wis., April 2 Two youngsters standing outside International Airport in Philadelphia today spotted Billy Cunningham as he pre pared to leave with the 76ers for the fifth game of the National Basketball Associa tion Eastern Division semi final against the Milwaukee Bucks, which will be played here tomorrow night.

title: Sid Barry, Retired Head Of Electronics Concern
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 2 Sid Barry, who retired in 1968 as chairman of the board of the Filtron Company in Flushing, Queens, an elec tronics concern, died yesterday at his home, 34 Shore Drive. He was 62 years old.

title: Britain Bolsters Financial Stand With Large Increase in Reserves
description: LONDON, April 2Britain continued to bolster her finan cial position in March with a large increase in gold and for eignexchange reserves, a small er net repayment to the Inter national Monetary Fund and substantial repayments of shortterm loans from foreign central banks.

title: Exchange Punishes A Former Partner In Coggeshall Firm
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had disciplined a former partner of a member firm for violations of Federal margin re quirements in an account car ried by the firm for a Swiss bank.

title: Abercrombie Clears Attic for a Cause
description: MRS. NATALIE CHILVERS, a blueeyed blonde in a flowered straw hat and dark mink coat, couldn't resist the bargain. The $250 price tag on the motorbike had been slashed to $50. She bought it.

title: Tugboat Operations Here Normal Again After Strike
description: Tugboat operations in the Port of New York returned to normal yesterday following re sumption of work after the union accepted a new contract offer from management.

title: A Test of Legality Of War Advances
description: BOSTON, April 2  Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed today a bill challenging the le gality of the war in Vietnam.

title: Synagogue to Hold Its Annual Art Sale
description: The Park Avenue Syna gogue, at 50 East 87th Street, will hold its 11th annual art show and sale for four days starting Sunday. The syna gogue's Mr. and Mrs. Club, of which Richard Osserman is president, is sponsor of the event.

title: Foundation Plans Statue Of F. D. Roosevelt Here
description: The Four Freedoms Foun dation announced plans last night for a fullsize statue of Franklin D. Roose velt, possibly on the site now occupied by a statue of Wil liam Tecumseh Sherman at the Fifth Avenue and 59th Street entrance to Central Park.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Brooklyn Priest Stabbed And Robbed in Rectory
description: The assistant pastor of the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Williams burg section of Brooklyn was slashed several times with a knife and robbed early yester day after parking his car in the garage adjoining the church's rectory at 138 Mon trose Avenue.

title: Strike Ends at U. of Michigan; Pact Calls for 10% Blacks in '73
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 2 A strike of classes at the University of Michigan ended today following agreement last night between black students and the Board of Regents over proposals for increased minor ity admissions.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 Game Series)

title: Miss Barinaga Registers Triple in Title Badminton
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2 (AP)  Tina Barinaga scored a triple in the finals of the 17th annual North American badminton championships last night by winning the women's singles and teaming to capture the women's doubles and mixed doubles titles.

title: Katharine T. Newlin Is Betrothed
description: TYRONE, Pa., April 2 The engagement of Miss Katharine Theda Newlin to William Frazier Lapham, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Fra zier Lapham of San Bernar dino, Calif., has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Wigton Newlin.

title: End Paper.
description: This is not a book of advocacy but of exposition. Although it is the conviction of the author, a science writer of long standing, that the pill works and is safe, it is a conclusion he reaches from the evidence. He is meticulous in taking up the objections to the pill and breaks down the statistics concerning its use, success and side effects so that they are under standable to the layman.

title: Alcan to Decide This Year On Building European Plant
description: MONTREAL, April 2 (UPI) Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., said to day that it would decide later this year whether or not to build a huge alumina plant somewhere in the European area.

title: Bunny, New Krasna Comedy, Is Due on Broadway in the Fall
description: Norman Krasna, who has shuttled between the theater and the screen, will be rep resented on Broadway in the fall by a new comedy, Bunny. Leland Hayward is producing it.

title: MRS. HAROLD L. LEVIN
description: NUTLEY, N. J., April 2 Mrs. Mildred Marcus Levin, honorary vice president of the National Council of Jewish Women, and wife of Harold L. Levin, president of the Indus trial Emulsoons Company, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson. She was 66 years old and lived at 193 Rutgers Place.

title: March in Capital Tomorrow to Back Vietnam War
description: WASHINGTON, April 2A march on Washington is sched uled for Saturday to support victory over the Communists in Vietnam.

title: AnnAudley Richard to Marry
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 2 Mr. and Mrs. Trumbull Richard of La Jolla, formerly of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss AnnAudley Richard, to Lieut. Roy L. Ste phens, U.S.A.F. The prospec tive bridegroom is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Leonard A. Stephens of Albany, Ga.

title: Tanks at Ecuador University
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 2 (UPI)  The Government sent 10 tanks into the city to quell stu dent disorders at Central Uni versity of Ecuador in which six persons have been injured. The disorders stemmed from the closing of the country's largest allwomen's college after the students rebelled against Gov ernment educational policies.

title: Fire in New Mexico City
description: LAS VEGAS, N. M., April 2 (UPI)Fire touched off by ex ploding fuel tanks in a commer cial gasoline warehouse swept through a fourblock downtown section today, leaving 25 per sons homeless and forcing evacuation of an elementary school.

title: 2 Old Works Bow on Philharmonic Bill
description: The prospect of a first per formance invariably offers the openminded listener a carrot of anticipation, even if the per formance itself too often proves to be a stick.

title: Tentative Wage Accord Reported in Truck Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The trucking industry and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters reached tentative agreement tonight on a new contract that would give most of the nation's 450,000 truck' drivers a 27 per cent wage increase over the next three year.

title: Knicks' Playoff Tickets on Sale Today
description: Tickets for the next batch of Knick playoff games at the Garden go on sale this morn ing at 10 o'clock, and the ar rangements are confusing.

title: April 23 Supper Dance Is Planned By London Philharmonic Society
description: The London Philharmonic Orchestra Society U.S.A. will hold a supper dance at the Roof of the St. RegisShera ton on April 23 after the or chestra's opening concert of its first American tour. Ber nard Haitink will conduct and Claudio Arrau will be the piano soloist.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Alliance Comes of Age
description: BRUSSELS  NATO, which observes its 21st birthday Sat urday, has given the difficult gift of peace to an entire gen eration which has shown no adequate appreciation of either the source or value of this present.

title: CAR MAKERS END LAGGING QUARTER
description: DETROIT, April 3 (AP)The nation's automobile industry closed out its worst first quar ter since 1962 this week, and both General Motors and Ford cut back on their production schedules for April to keep newcar inventories in line with sales.

title: CARSWELL BACKER ATTACKS LIBERALS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The Senate minority whip, Robert P. Griffin, charged to day that much of the opposi tion to the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court was an ef fort by liberals to prevent President Nixon from carrying out his campaign pledge to place conservatives on the Court.

title: Text of Nixon Message Proposing Postal Reform and Rate Increases
description: WASHINGTON April 3  Following is the text of a message on a pay increase for postal and other Federal employes sent to Congress today by President Nixon:

title: TruetoLife Dolls That Start With Lump of Gray Clay
description: THE children who cluster around the Unicorn Shop on East 11th Street are fasci nated by the figures in the window. Their maker calls them dolls. But dolls to the local children mean idealized cherubs with frozen faces and simpering smiles. The little people who cavort on wires in the shop window look realHey, there's my brother, a Negro child points out.

title: WILLIAM C. CLOW 2D, HELPED GREEK GIRLS
description: William E. Clow 2d, operator of a weaving business in Greece that enables poor village girls to earn their dowries, died in his sleep Thursday in his home at 30 Suton Place. He was 40 years old.

title: Kroger Company Reports 8.7% Rise In Quarter Profit
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest grocery chain, after the leader, the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Com pany, and Safeway Stores, re alized an increase of 8.7 per cent in earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended March 21 on a sales gain of 7.9 per cent, its report disclosed yesterday.

title: American Exchange Stocks Drop in Quiet Trading
description: The American Stock Ex change ended the week in a bearish manner yesterday as prices mostly declined in quiet trading.

title: Benvenuti to Risk Crown Against Bethea on May 23
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, April (AP)The world middleweight champion, Nino Benvenuti of Italy, will defend his title against Tom Bethea of New York, the only man ever to stop Benvenuti, it was an nounced tonight. The fight, scheduled for 15 rounds, is set for May 23 at Umago, Yugo slavia.

title: A Nixon Aide Challenges Another's Budget View
description: Two of President Nixon's top economic advisers have dis agreed sharply over the sig nificance of allowing the Fed eral budget to slip into a small deficit  should this occur as a result of unexpected increases in Federal spending.

title: Retail Innovations Aid Shopping Centers
description: The nation's retail shop ping centers, despite the tight and scarce money situa tion that has reduced the in cidence of new centers, con tinue to reflect dynamism in the form of new ideas to energize existing centers and to develop new types of centers.

title: Van Ness Signs Falcon Pact
description: ATLANTA, April 3 (AP) Bruce Van Ness of Rutgers signed a National Football League contract today with the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Judge Puts a Limit on Disclosure Subpoenaed Writer Must Make
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3A Federal district judge ruled to day that a New York Times reporter must appear before grand jury, as directed, but would not have to disclose con fidential information to the jury unless there is a compel ling and overriding national in terest that cannot be served by alternative means.

title: High Waters Cancel Racing
description: WHEELING, W. Va., April 3 (UPI)The waters of the rising Ohio River covered the parking lot at Wheeling Downs Race Track today, forcing cancella tion of tonight's scheduled har ness races. The track is situ ated on Wheeling Island.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS TUMBLE SHARPLY
description: Computer stocks and other glamour issues tumbled sharply on the New York Stock Ex change yesterday while the bluechip sector of the market held fairly steady.

title: Chronicler of Berlin's Disintegration
description: SOLDIERS strutted, fat con sumers glutted. Junkers jeered and tycoons profi teered. Bureaucrats bustled, pimps hustled, and on the Kurfurstendamm, whores pa raded their wares.

title: W. STANFIELD COOPER
description: W. Stanfield Cooper, who re tired as copy chief of the in dustrial and professional de partment of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertis ing agency, in 1964, died Thurs day in East Long Island Hos pital, Greenport. He was 71 years old and lived in Southold, L. I.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Brandt
description: BONN, April 3Following, in translation from the Ger man, are excerpts from an interview conducted with Chancellor Willy Brandt yes terday by David Binder, Bonn correspondent of The New York Times:

title: 4 Airmen Not P.O.W.'s, North. Vietnamese Say
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3 The mother of one United States airman and the wives of three others shot down in the Vietnam war were told to day at the North Vietnamese Embassy that none of the men had ever been prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: So. Illinois Bows at Soccer
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, April 3 (UPI)Southern Illinois battled its way into the final of the international university soccer tournament today but lost the championship match to Uni versity College of Dublin, the host school, 10.

title: Nationalist China's Deputy Premier to See Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The State Department announced today that Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo of National ist China, the son of President Chiang Kaishek, would visit Washington on April 20. He is expected to meet with Presi dent Nixon, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

title: 2 SCOTTOS SILENT AT PIERS HEARING
description: Anthony M. Scotto, president of the Brooklyn longshoremen's local invoked the Fifth and 14th amendments 29 times yesterday in refusing to answer questions at a hearing conducted by the Waterfront Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Primary Ballots

title: Showing Children How College Leads to Good Jobs
description: THEY came from an area of the South Bronx where pov erty prevails: 30 seventh graders from Intermediate School 139. Some had parents who talked to them of col lege, but until recently, the youngsters had not shown much interest.

title: Appeal of Fingerprinting Law Is Filed
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)  A Wall Street lawyer ap pealed to the Supreme Court today to strike down, as an un constitutional invasion of pri vacy, a 1969 New York law that requires the fingerprinting of the thousands of employes in stock exchanges and mem ber brokerage firms in New York City.

title: CURB ON OIL SPILLS IS SIGNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 President Nixon signed today the Water Quality Improve ment Act of 1970, which sharply increases penalties for oil spills and extends the lia bility for the cost of cleaning them up.

title: DUKE POWER POSTS RISE IN '69 INCOME
description: The Duke Power Company re ported yesterday 1969 operating revenues of $342,242,000, a gain of 9.6 per cent over the $312, 246.000 renorted a year earlier.

title: KNICKS GO BACK TO WORK IN GYM
description: William (Red) Holzman, the coach and general manager of the New York Knickerbockers, likes to say, at appropriate times, now I'm wearing my coaching hat or now I'm wearing my general manager hat. Yesterday, he donned his kindly old boss hat and gave his players a whole day off.

title: Mrs. Muller, Urban Expert, Is Wed Here
description: Dr. Charlotte F. Muller, pro fessor of urban studies at the Center for Social Research of the City University of New York, was married here yes terday to Carl Schoenberg of Teaneck, N. J., director of publications for the Child Welfare League of America, Inc. The ceremony was per formed by Criminal Court Judge Milton Shalleck at the home of the bride.

title: Astros Subdue Yanks, 95, As Bouton Stars on Mound
description: HOUSTON, April 3Jim Bou ton pitched seven innings against his former Yankee teammates tonight as the Hous ton Astros beat New York, 95, in the Astrodome.

title: ExPresident of Subsidiary Sues Visual Electronics
description: The Visual Electronics Cor poration said yesterday that a complaint had been filed against it in the United States District Court in Massachusetts by George D. Mason, who recently resigned as president of a subsidiary, Educational Elec tronics. The complaint makes five claims under Section 10B of the Securities Act of 1934 and a charge of breach of con tract.

title: Brandt, in Nixon Talks, to Stress U.S.Market Ties
description: BONN, April 3Chancellor Willy Brandt has declared that his top priority in his talks with President Nixon next week would be the future relations of the United States with the European Economic Commu nity.

title: Lebanon 21 Soccer Victor
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 3 (UPI)Lebanon beat Malaysia, 142, today in the Asian soccer tournament, after leading, 21, at halftime.

title: LIBERALS CONFER ON STATE TICKET
description: The Liberal party is expected to designate two of its most prominent members today as its statewide candidatesthe Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington for Governor and Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello for United States Senator.

title: Rev. Francis C. Keyes, 57, Of the Paulist Missioners
description: The Rev. Francis C. Keyes, since 1959 with the Paulist missioners of the New York Preaching Apostolate based at the Paulist Mother Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 West 59th Street, died Wednesday at the Paulist Fathers' residence there. His age was 57.

title: Article 2  No Title
Hayasaki Captures Title In AllAround Gymnastics
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) Yoshi Hayasaki, a University of Washington student from Osaka, Japan, took first place in the allaround competition tonight in the 1970 National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championships.

title: MRS.ZARRYVIEILLEVILLE
description: Mrs. Jacqueline GarryVieille ville, a commissionaire or resi dent buying agent in Paris for several major American con cerns, died there Tuesday, ac cording to word received here yesterday.

title: Antiques: Rediscovery of Tapestries
description: TAPESTRIES still provide surprising discoveries in this country because the great quantities collected be fore Depression are largely ignored today.

title: San Diego Signs Perry
description: SAN DIEGO, April 3 (AP) The San Diego Rockets of the National Basketball Association signed Curtis Perry of South west Missouri today.

title: THREAT TO NIXON LAID TO PANTHER
description: The Secret Service is in vestigating an alleged threat on the life of President Nixon by one of the 13 Black Panthers awaiting trial here on bombing conspiracy charges, but the inquiry will probably not re sult in the filing of charges, a Justice Department source said yesterday.

title: Faith in the Law
description: The directors of the studies the Ford Foundation has underwritten into the causes for the ebbing respect many Americans show for the judicial process need not look far to discover reasons for this dangerous trend. The assignment of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman to preside over the Chicago trial of twelve leaders of the Weathermen and the stalled investiga tion into alleged police persecution of the Black Panthers are immediate cases in point.

title: N.H.L. East Race
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Jewish Fund Plans Dinner Tomorrow
description: The Brooklyn division of the Jewish National Fund will honor Mr. and Mrs. Marshall D. Butler of Kings Point, L. I., at its 21st annual dinner to morrow evening at El Patio in Atlantic Beach, L. I.

title: Retrogression in Belgrade
description: Early last month, just before he was scheduled to fly to the United States, Yugoslavia's most famous political heretic, Milovan Djilas, was suddenly deprived of his passport. This repressive move came as a par ticular shock because it contrasted so sharply with the generally liberal attitude the Belgrade regime has followed with regard to foreign travel by its citizens.

title: LAVER CAPTURES SO. AFRICAN TITLE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 3 (UPI)Rod Laver overcame a series of lapses in the first set today and went on to crush Frew McMillan, 46. 62. 61. 62. and capture the men's singles crown in the South African open tennis championships.

title: Police Relax Patrol at Hunter After Demonstrations Subside
description: While 25 policemen guarded Hunter College from the outside yesterday, students inside the 16story building chanted slo gans, went to classes, or danced and sang in the main lobby.

title: INSURANCE FIGHT WAGED IN ALBANY
description: HARTFORD, April 3A ma jor battle to prevent the sale of lowercost auto insurance in New York on the payroll deduction plan is now being waged in Albany, the Travelers Corporation said at its annual meeting here today.

title: Stage: Dark of the Moon
description: DARK OF THE MOON, the drama  fantasy of mountain witchcraft that started a long Broadway run back in 1945, still wears well. It does so, in its re vival at the new downtown MercerShaw Arena Theater, even with an omnipresent cluster of male and female witches, who wear nothing at all, and a hero who sym bolically pitches in and peels down. For once, nude stream lining actually enhances a text and performance.

title: ALFRED SCHILLER
description: Alfred Schiller, sales con troller of DuroLite Lamps, Inc., Fair Lawn, N. J., died Thursday in Holy Name Hospital, Tea neck, N. J. He was 68 years old and lived at 83 East Long Drive, Teaneck.

title: A JUDGE IS FACING VOLOSHEN INQUIRY
description: Supreme Court Justice Mitch ell D. Schweitzer has been sub poenaed by the Joint Legisla tive Committee on Crime for questioning about his relations with Nathan Voloshen, an in dicted lobbyist who allegedly used the name of House Speak er John W. McCormack to ob tain favors for which he was paid by businessmen and oth ers.

title: F.B.I. SPURS HUNT FOR WEATHERMEN
description: CHICAGO, April 3The Fed eral Bureau of Investigation has begun a nationwide hunt for the 12 Weathermen indicted in Chicago on charges of conspir acy and violation of the Fed eral antiriot act.

title: JAZZ RECITAL GIVEN BY FREDDIE HUBBARD
description: Freddie Hubbard's Sextet, which played last night at Car negie Recital Hall as part of the Jazz: The Personal Dimension series, is one of the most pol ished exemplars of a style that is a heritage of the bebop era of 25 years ago.

title: U.S. Foreign Travel Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Americans are traveling abroad at a far greater rate this year than in 1969, the State Department reports. In March there was a 50 per cent increase in passport applica tions over March, 1969, the de partment reported, with appli cations totaling 255,704.

title: Screen: Search for Girls:Robert Walker Stars in 'Man From O.R.G.Y.'
description: O.R.G.Y. stands for Organization for the Rational Guidance of Youth, but otherwise it need, not concern you. It exists only so its director (Robert Walker) can give up his research into the erotic responses of working girls in order to track down three beautiful prostitutes who are to share a $15-million inheritance. Each heiress can be identified only by the image of a grinning gopher branded on her bottom, and to pursue his quest, Robert Walker must uncover a lot of girls. And that is what "The Man From O. R. G. Y.", which opened yesterday at the Forum, is all about. A certain charming innocence pertains to all the low-level vulgarity, as it does to the plump, often pretty girls themselves with their piled-up hairdo's, their freighted eyelids, and their brave little attempts to say their lines.Maybe in two cases out of every three they are fun to look at, and collectively they suggest a soft solidity to shore against the flimsiness of the film's sets, which, like wallpaper without walls, shake and rustle at each passing step.Because "The Man From O.R.G.Y." is a dirty movie that means to be a spoof of dirty movies, it also features a lot of comedy, none of which is funny, but much of which is energetic enough somehow to engage the attention if not the interest. To an extent, this is remarkable, because the film seems determined to repeat each of its comic ideas, no matter how awful, at least three times.It more or less has to just to fit in the acts. Not only has it a black-white male comedy team (White and Rossi; White's black), but also a female impersonator (his name is Lynn Carter, and he does Hermione Gingold, Phyllis Diller, Marlene Dietrich, and of course, Bette Davis), a real-female comedienne (Louisa Moritz), and a large cast of minor characters every one of whom has a routine. By the time each man has shown his stuff and each girl has had a chance to strip a little, "The Man From O.R.G.Y." resembles not so much a movie as a last bastion of individualist free enterprise against the encroaching coltivism of our society.

title: Yoke Lee and Bruce Reynolds, Graduate Students, to Marry
description: HAMDEN, Conn., April 3 Miss Yoke San Lee, and Bruce Lloyd Reynolds, gradu ate students at the University of Michigan, will be married next month in Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School.

title: Team Is Confident After Successful Spring Training
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3After six weeks of spring training, the New York Mets headed north to day to defend the champion ship that one year ago ap peared as remote to them as the moon.

title: ADAMS'S DEFENSE ON PERJURY OPENS
description: State Senator William E. Ad ams opened his defense yester day by presenting his grand jury testimony that he had re turned a $5,000 cash contribu tion from a Medicaid billcol lecting company.

title: HUGHES WINDS UP AIR WEST DETAILS
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., April 3 (UPI)The Hughes Tool Com pany announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for the purchase of Air West, Inc., the nation's largest re gional air carrier; for approxi mately $90million.

title: Numismatists to Meet
description: The American Numismatic Society willl meet next Satur day at the society's museum on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets. Leslie A. Elam, secretary, said that Mrs. Elvira E. ClainStefanelli, assistant curator of the Smithsonian Institution, would deliver the Moritz Wormser lecture, speak ing on Medals as an American Art Form. The meeting, start ing at 3 P.M., will be open to the public.

title: U.S. Still Maintains Contact With Japanese on Textiles
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The State Department said today that contact with Japan over a negotiated settlement of the textile import problem has not been broken off.

title: Leader of Air Controllers Urges Men to Return, but Is Pessimistic
description: WASHINGTON, April 3F. Lee Bailey read in public today a courtordered statement urg ing sick air traffic controllers to go back to workbut then predicted that none would re turn because they had not been promised amnesty or mediation of their grievances.

title: Defendant Is Ungagged
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (UPI)George Kenny, gagged Wednesday when he repeatedly told a judge to go to hell, promised to behave yesterday and sat silently with his hands folded at his trial on murder charges. Judge Leo Weinrott acted Wednesday just 24 hours after the Supreme Court ruled that a defendant may be gagged in court if he failed to behave himself.

title: TEXAS AGGIES TIE WORLD 880 MARK
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 3 (AP) Texas A. & M.'s explosive Cur tis Mills, the world retord holder in the 440, sizzled the Texas Relays new Tartan sur face with a tremendous anchor leg tonight as the Aggies tied the 880yard world elay record in 1:22.1. The standard was established by San Jose State in 1967.

title: Town Meeting: Flavor Gone, but Spirit Lingers
description: BELMONT, Mass.On the morning of March 9, Edwin N. Griswold, Solicitor Gen eral of the United States, took his traditional seat at the end of a long mahogany table before the Supreme Court's bench.

title: 6 Manhattan School Districts Charted
description: A new plan for the creation of six community school dis tricts in Manhattan, including one for East Harlem and an other for the Lower East Side, was proposed yesterday by the city Board of Education.

title: Kyoto: The Florence of Japan
description: KYOTO, Japan, March 23 There are two sides to everything, especially Kyoto. A couple of years ago Kyoto's city fathers decided to count its temples but gave up when they got as far as 2,300.

title: Bridge:
description: THE merits of leading top ofnothing from a worth less threecard suit are often debated. Some experts lead the bottom card in this situa tion, some the middle card, and some vary their tactics, leaving partner and oppon ents with some guessing to do.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1970

title: Hijackers Free 103, Fly to North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Satur day, April 4The case of the hijacked Japanese jetliner reached a dramatic climax yes terday when the nine hijackers exchanged 99 passengers and four stewardesses for a new hostage and flew to North Korea.

title: R. H. SIKES IS NEXT, TRAILING BY SHOT
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 3 On a cool, clear afternoon contrasted to the rain that caused yesterday's postpone ment, voluminous yells greeted Arnold Palmer today as he tied for the lead in the opening round of the $180,000 Greater Greensboro Open. Just before dusk, Palmer strode to the 18th green of the Sedgefield Country Club, tapped in a 30inch putt for a 64 and drew even with Tommy Aaron, who had fin ished five hours earlier.

title: Prison Guards Held Captive
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. April 3 (AP)Seven prisoners armed with guns and homemade bombs held three Nevada State Prison guards captive for about two hours today while demand ing fredom. The hostages were freed uninjured. The inmates were subdued and placed in solitary confinement.

title: Abortion Laws Seen Fading
description: PITTSBURGH, April 3 (UPI) Senator Robert W. Pack wood, Republican of Oregon, predicted last night that most states would abolish laws against abortion within the next one to three years. It's none of the state's business if a woman wants to abort an unwanted pregnancy, the Sen ator told a teachin on en vironmental problems spon sored by three local univer sities.

title: Young G.O.P. Aide Convicted by U.S. In Draft Fraud Case
description: CHICAGO, April 3Victor S. Kamber, 27yearold head of the national Young Republican organization's leadership train ing school, was found guilty by a Federal District Court jury here today of submitting a fraudulent and forged letter to his Chicago draft board in 1968.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in a continuance of slow trad ing.

title: Satellites to Check ATests
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 3 (AP)The Air Force an nounced today that it would launch two nuclear detection satellites next Wednesday to help watch for violations of the treaty prohibiting nuclear tests. Almost 691,000 miles above the earth, the satellites will join 10 earlier ones in a net work monitoring for clandes tine nuclear tests in the atmos phere, under water or in space.

title: TWO MORE BOMBS DISCOVERED HERE
description: Two homemade pipe bombs were found by the police early yesterday morning, one at an East Harlem bank and the other in a busy street in the South Bronx, just four blocks from where a similar device was found at another bank Thurs day morning.

title: French Reserves Rose $3.63Million in March
description: PARIS, April 3 (Reuters) France's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 20 million francs ($3.63million) in March to total 22 billion francs ($4billion), the Finance Minis try announced here today.

title: Postal Leaders Divided on Nixon Pay Proposal
description: Reaction to the postal settle ment reached Thursday ranged from outright rejection to guard ed approval and ambivalence yesterday by mailworkers lo cals here and throughout the country.

title: Cambodia's Deputy Chief
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 3The First Dep uty Premier of Cambodia, Prince Sisowath Sirik Matak, remembers with a little smile the advice his father often gave him.

title: Mortgage Group Appoints
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) Richard C. Dyas, an official of the United States Steel Cor poration, today was named executive vice president of the Government National Mortgage Association, a Federal agency established to provide financial support to the home loan mar ket. Mr. Dyas, 64, of Alexan dria, Va., leaves a post as as sistant to the administrative vice president and treasurer of the steel company.

title: $100Million Realty Trust Registered by Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Co., the San Franciscobased onebank hold ing company, announced yes terday its entrance into the real estate investment trust field as it registered a $100million of fering of Wells Fargo Mortgage Investors.

title: TV USE PROPOSED IN PANTHER TRIAL
description: If 13 Black Panthers facing trial here persist in unruly be havior and have to be sent from the courtroom again, Dis trict Attorney Frank S. Hogan proposed yesterday that they be kept in touch with their pre trial hearings by means of closedcircuit television. Mr. Hogan filed a motion yesterday asking Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh to approve the plan, which would also per mit use of closedcircuit TV for the actual trial.

title: High Court Turns Down Florida Integration Delay
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The Supreme Court turned down unanimously today an ef fort to delay full integration of the schools in Manatee County, Fla., by Monday.

title: Timoshenko, War Hero, Is Buried in Kremlin Wall
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (UPI) The ashes of Marshal Semyon K. Timoshenko were placed in a Kremlin Wall tomb near the grave of Stalin today in a fulldress military funeral honoring him as a hero of two wars.

title: Johnson Rolls to 339Pin Lead In $100,000 Pro Bowling Event
NATIONAL AIRLINES SETTLES A CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The International Associa tion of Machinists and strike bound National Airlines agreed today on a threeyear contract that would raise the pay of some 1,000 mechanics by a re ported $1.51 an hour.

title: Six More Deaths Reported Related to Heroin Addiction
description: The Medical Examiner's of fice reported yesterday six addict deaths from acute reac tions to heroin or from compli cations related to addiction from Tuesday to early yester day morning.

title: Richey Gains Net Semifinal
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 3 (AP)Cliff Richey of San An gelo, Tex., and Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., advanced today to the semifinals of the Caribe Hilton International ten nis tournament. Richey defeat ed Zeljko Franulovic of Yugo slavia, 62, 64, and McManus beat Nikola Spear of Yugo slavia, 64, 60.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Containers for Air Passengers Urged
description: BONN, April 3To cope with the growing crush of travelers and luggage at ma jor airports, the Fried. Krupp Company has come up with a new idea: putting a number of passengers and their suit cases in containers.

title: Market Place
description: MAJOR banks continue to draw barbed comments from customers who are dis appointed with bank invest ment management results.

title: 3 IN S.D.S. PUNISHED BY PRINCETON PANEL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 Three Princeton University sen iors who belong to the radical Students for a Democratic So ciety were suspended today for disrupting a speech by Secre tary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel on March 5.

title: MONEY TRADERS THRIVE IN VIENNA
description: VIENNA, April 3  The Czechoslovak koruna, or crown, has strengthened recently in the Vienna market for Eastern European currencies.

title: Bazaar to Aid the Aged
description: A twoday boutique bazaar will be held by the Plaza League of the Hebrew Home for the Aged on Monday and Tuesday at the Croydon Ho tel. Proceeds will aid the vol untary nonprofit agency in Riverdale, the Bronx. Mrs. Evelyn Sank is in charge of arrangements.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN MODERN fiction surely the novel of estrangement and the novel of anguish are no rarities. Camus's stranger and Joyce's Stephen Dedalus and the protagon ists in the work of Graham Green and Frangois Mauriac suggest themselves as prototypes. Man today may not be more alienated than in certain times in the past, but he is a thousand times more conscious of it. The possibilities are for him greater than they were for the third son of the manor lord or the freeman in Athens. And the sense of guilt has driven saints in all ages into the desert and men to selfsacri ficing heroism.

title: Topics: A Unilateral Step Toward Disarmament
description: It has been the policy of the United States to seek relaxa tion of international tension by means of agreements on the limitation of atomic arms. We want to avoid atomic conflict and it is almost generally ac cepted that such conflict can be more easily avoided if limita tions are set to the arms race. Negotiations with Russia are under way and the few quiet words one hears seem to give reason for cautious optimism.

title: ROBERT A. KOLLER
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., April 3 Robert A. Koller of 812 Sher brooke Drive, chief horticultur ist of the Union County Park Commission for 19 years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a brief illness. His age was 47.

title: New Gulf States Subsidiary
description: The Gulf States Utilities Com pany of Beaumont, Tex., an nounced yestreday the forma tion of a subsidiary, the Vari bus. Corporation. It will run en terprises outside the parent company's main business of providing electric power in southeast Texas and southcen tral Louisiana. The subsidiary's first venture will involve com puter software.

title: These Days, Even the Wine Experts in Bordeaux Find They Need a Scorecard
description: BORDEAUX, France  The neophyte confronted by a choice among hundreds of wines, most of which he has never heard of, may take comfort: The Bordeaux wine trade is more confused than he is.

title: AMBITIOUS GOAL IS SET BY PHILIPS
description: BONN, April 3  Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken, N. V., Eindhoven, one of Europe's largest industrial empires, has announced an ambitious goal: by 1991 the Dutch concern aspires to a consolidated annual turnover of 100billion guilders, or about $27.5billion.

title: Jersey Governor to Ask Environmental Agency
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., April 3 Gov. William T. Cahill an nounced today that he would move on Monday to establish a Department of Environmen tal Protection to assure the restoration, protection and enhancement of this state's physical environment.

title: Car Crash Kills Woman
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 3 (UPI)One woman was killed and another was injured early today when the car in which they were riding hit a snow bank, flew 45 feet through the air and struck a tree while still eight fret off the ground. The police said Mrs. Madelin Clump of Hartsdale died in the crash. Mrs. Marilyn Mum, also of Hartsdale, believed to have been the driver, was reported in serious condition at Grass lands Hospital, Valhalla.

title: Another Cosmos Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (AP)The Soviet Union launched Cosmos 329 today. It is an unmanned spacecraft designed for some type of space research.

title: Producers Raise Primary Copper To 60c a Pound
description: The Inspiration Consolidat ed Copper Company announced yesterday that it would raise the price of primary copper by 4 cents a pound to 60 cents, effective Monday.

title: The Convention's Shambles
description: About the only thing that delegates to the State Democratic Convention seem to have been able to agree onthey failed even to adopt a platformis that the convention itself has lost most of its value. Its proceedings were such a shambles that its endorse ments were meaninglessperhaps even a liability.

title: Florida State Golfers Lead By 15 Shots at Cape Coral
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla., April 3 (AP)Mark Alwin of Florida State carded a 69 today and led the Seminoles to a com fortable thirdround lead in the seventh annual intercollegiate golf classic.

title: Article 1  No Title
Lacey Signs 5Year Pact At $1.1Million With Royals
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., april 5 (AP)Sam Lacey, a 6foot10 inch center who starred for three years at New Mexico State, signed a $1.1million fiveyear contract today with the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Associ tion.

title: Frazier Breaks Ankle During Las Vegas Act
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 3, (AP)Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight boxing cham pion, fractured his right ankle, during a dance turn in his night club act at Las Vegas, it was revealed today.

title: Miss Joan Kelly Planning Bridal
description: Mrs. Lester J. Kelly of New York has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Sharon Kelly, to William Martin Kirschner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kirschner of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding is planned for August in New York.

title: CONCERN HERE FINED IN SANCTIONS CASE
description: A New York importexport concern has pleaded guilty in Federal court here to charges of conspiring to violate regu lations imposing economic sanc tions on Rhodesia and was fined $10,000.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE GAIN
description: A Government report touched off a flurry of activity and higher prices in soybean futures yesterday. Traders reacted to Government figures that indi cated soybean oil stocks had declined faster than expected.

title: DR. S. R. SAPHIRE, YESHIVA TEACHER
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 3 Dr. Shelley R. Saphire, a for mer professor at Yeshiva Uni versity in New York and the first dean of Yeshiva College, died in Kaiser Hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: A Negro Community in Alabama Cherishes Memory of Dr. King
description: GEE'S BEND, Ala., April 3 When the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. challenged the white supremacy tradi tions of Selma, Ala., five years ago, his marches and mass meetings were regular ly swelled by scores of sup porters from this tiny, pover tystricken, allNegro com munity.

title: Teamster Chiefs Silent on Whether Pact Will Be Sent to Membership
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The leaders of Chicago's 50,000 truck drivers rejected today the tentative national agreement reached yesterday between the trucking industry and the In ternational Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: South Korea Says Vessels Sank Spy Ship From North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Satur day, April 4 (Reuters)South Korean naval vessels sank a North Korean spy vessel with its 15 persons aboard off the west coast early today, it was announced.

title: Uncle Sam: Model Employer
description: Two hundred million Americans got their first indi cation yesterday of some of the painful facts of life that go with the duty of making their national Gov ernment a model employer.

title: Party in Prague Ousts Hajek
description: PRAGUE, April 3 (Reuters) Jiri Hajek, Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister at the time of the Soviet bloc invasion of August, 1968, has been expelled from the Communist Party. He resigned from office in Sep tember, 1968.

title: DIARAC IS PASSED IN CLOSING STRIDE
description: YONKERS, April 3That there is no such thing as a sure thing in harness racing is an adage as old as the sport itself. Bettors who backed, Good Chase in the $25,000 Red Sails Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight were reminded of this when the 35 choice, victimized by an accident, did not even finish.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Subpoena Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 Following are excerpts from an opinion issued today by Federal Judge Alfonso J. Zir poli on a motion by Earl well and The New York Times to quash a subpoena seeking testimony on interviews with Black Panther party members:

title: Gutenberg Bible Bought for Resale at $2.5Million
description: A Bible printed by Johann Gutenberg has just been pur chased by Hans P. Kraus, a prominent New York rare book dealer, and is on the market for $2.5million to $2.75million. Mr. Kraus pur chased the twovolume Bible from Arthur A. Houghton Jr., a noted collector and founder and benefactor of the Hough ton Library at Harvard Uni versity. He said it had taken two months to consummate the transaction, but he de clined to divulge the purchase price. The. Bible, one of the 13 Gutenberg Bibles in the United States, came to this country from England in 1951 as a newly rediscovered prize that had been lost sight of since 1824. Known as the Shuckburgh copy, the Bible was found by Charles Scribner's Sons. A few years later it was purchased for about $150,000 by Mr. Hough ton, who also gave Scribner's as part payment one volume of another twovolume Guten berg Bible that he had in his collection. Single leaves of some damaged Bibles were selling in 1951 for about $600. These days, they bring as much as 52,500. Fortysix copies of the Bible, perfect and imperfect, are known to have survived from a printing of approximately 200, issued between 1450 and 1455. The first book to be printed from movable type, the Gutenberg Bible is, as Mr. Kraus said yes terday:

title: ANNA LOUISE STRONG GIVEN LAST HONORS
description: PEKING, April 2 (Agencel FrancePresse)The ashes of, Anna Louise Strong, the Amer ican journalist and supporter of Communist China, were paid last respects in a funeral chapel here today.

title: Memorial Services
description: PERLSFredericks. The New York Insti?? for Gestail therapy anno??es, a pucblic memorial service on Sunday. April 5, at 2 P.M., at Public School 75, West End Ave. and 95th St. Address by Paul Good man.

title: Music Festival on Monday Will Benefit a Playground
description: A festival of jazz, rock and Latin music to raise funds for a playground on East Third Street between Avenue C and D will be held on Monday eve ning at Slug's, 242 East Third Street.

title: Friends to Cite Eliot Feld
description: The Friends of the Brook lyn Academy of Music will honor Eliot Feld and his American Ballet Company with a champagne reception tonight at the academy after the company's 8:30 perform ance of Harbinger, Mead owlark and Mr. Feld's new work, Early Songs. Admis sion to both the performance and reception is $7.50 a per son. Mrs. Leo Slutsky heads the ticket committee.

title: Charge of Israeli Torture Splits Amnesty's British, U.S. Units
description: LONDON, April 3The Brit ish and United States sections of Amnesty International split today in their reactions to a controversial report from the Londonbased organization al leging that Israel tortured Arab prisoners. Israel has criticized the report.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Minuteman 3 Tested
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 3 (AP)The Air Force success fully launched today a multi warhead Minuteman 3 missile on a 5,000mile test flight. The missile, which has a triple war head capability, darted out of an underground launching tube and drilled its paynad section toward an ocean target near Ascension Island in the South Atlantic.

title: Royal Family Sees Orchard
description: HOBART, Tasmania, April (Reuters)The royal family yesterday visited the country side fo rthe first time on their Australian tour. Queen Eliza beth, Prince Philip, Prince Char les and Princess Anne visited an apple orchard in the Hobart Hills near here.

title: PROCACCINO CALLS GOLDBERG A LOSER
description: Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that the statewide ticket endorsed by the Democratic State Com mittee this week was doomed to defeat and that he would not support it in the general election.

title: Unbeaten Hofstra Routs M.I.T. in Lacrosse, 11 to 4
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 3 Steve Dauses scored two goals and had seven assists today to lead Hofstra to an 114 victory over Massachusetts Institute of Technology in lacrosse.

title: Jodie Aurelio Rites Today
description: A funeral service will be held at 5:30 P.M. today at the Com munity Church of New York at 40 East 35th Street for Jodie Aurelio. Miss Aurelio the 18 yearold daughter of Deputy Mayor Richard Aurelio died at Mount Sinai Hospital Thursday night after suffering a cardiac arrest caused by a blood clot. She had broken a hip in a horseback riding accident last week.

title: MILWAUKEE'S PACE SET BY ALCINDOR
description: MADISON, Wis., April 3 The Milwaukee Bucks, a team that went from rags to riches on the shirt tail of Lew Alcin dor in its two seasons in the National Basketball Associa tion, gained the Eastern Divi sion final playoffs tonight by defeating the Philadelphia 76 ers, 115106, at the University of Wisconsin ifeld house.

title: Featherstone Ashes in Lagos
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 3 (AP) A small crowd watched the arrival here today of the ashes of a black American civil rights leader, Ralph Featherstone, killed when a bomb exploded in his oar near Bel Air, Md., March 9. Mr. Featherstone's widow, Charlotte, and close relations brought the ashes, to be buried here Tuesday. Mr. Featherston had reportedly expresse da de sire to be bureid in Nigeria.

title: Woman of Influence in City Hall
description: In a cluttered basement office at City Hall, a shrewd and witty woman has rather suddenly taken on quite a role with the second Lind say administration.

title: Foe Said to Have Left Cambodian Base
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 According to authoritative re ports reaching here, the prin cipal Communist political and military headquarters for South Vietnam was hurriedly moved late last month from Cambodia to South Vietnamese territory.

title: An Automobile Exhaust Suppressant Is Patented
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 As a result of research done by his company under a Navy contract, a New York inventor has discovered what he regards as a breakthrough in automobile exhaust and smoke purifica Marks, president tion. Alvin M. of the Marks Polartzed Cor poration, Whitestone, Queens, was granted Patent 3,503,704 this week on his method and apparatus for suppressing fumes with charged water droplets.

title: Mr. Heykal Sees the Light
description: The Middle East relates to the essential higher strategy of any major international power and, there fore, neither of the two international sides involved in the Middle Eastthe Soviet Union and the United Statescan afford to cede the region to the other nor retreat from it...On the local level, the crisis has reached the point where neither of the two sides, the Arabs and the Israelis, can impose the peace that suits it.

title: DR. N. A. IPPOLITO
description: Dr. Nicholas A. Ippolito, a dentist with offices at 1 Han son Place, Brooklyn, who had served as chief of the ortho dontia clinic at Brooklyn Hos pital, died March 19 in Me morial Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 93 Wil low Street, Floral Park, L.I.

title: Combat G.I.'s Tell of Using Marijuana
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3Nearly one out of five frontline soldiers surveyed in an elite American combat unit in South Vietnam said re cently that they smoked mari juana at least once a day, according to an Army physi cian's study.

title: U.S. Investigation Said to Clear Gross
description: TRENTON, April 3A United States Justice Department of ficial reported today that an inquiry into the relationship of Nelson G. Gross, the New Jersey Republican State Chair man, with a labor union linked to the Mafia had ended with Mr. Gross's apparently com plete exoneration.

title: Thorough Inspection Is Called Way to Cut Some Auto Mishaps
description: More thorough, inspection of motor vehicles by automobile mechanics was urged this week as a means to reduce accidents caused by mechanical failure.

title: Bay State Honors Dr. King
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has pro claimed tomorrow a special day of commemoration in memory of the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April, 4, 1968.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Juvenile Justice
description: The Supreme Court ruling on evidence in criminal cases involving accused youth will have at least two important effects: It will almost certainly make it necessary for the SenateHouse conference on the harsh District of Columbia crime bill to discard some of its tough provisions directed against juveniles. Simi larly, the decision will enable family and juvenile courts across the country to apply a clearer standard of justice for youthful offenders.

title: In Memoriam
description: GROSSPhyllis D. In memoriam beloved wife and mother, we both miss you and will never forget you. JONNY and MARTY KOCHLouise M. April 17, 1917. In treas ured memory.

title: NEWSDAY FIRE CUTS EDITION TO 16 PAGES
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 3  Newsday was forced to publish a limited 16page edi tion this morning because of fire in its paper warehouse be hind its main plant.

title: Ycaza, Hurt in Hialeah Spill, Sues Track for $2.5Million
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)Man uel Ycaza filed suit today seek ing in excess of $2.5million in alleged damages from Hialeah Racing Course as a result of an injury the jockey received dur ing a race on Jan. 30.

title: EXWEAPONS MAKER GETS A 5YEAR TERM
description: ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP)  The former president of a rock et launcher manufacturing com pany was sentenced today to five years in prison and fined $10,000 for illegally exporting launchers to a foreign arms concern. His executive secre tary was given a fiveyear pri son sentence on the same charge.

title: Silent Screen, Derby Favorite, Heads Today's Field in Gotham
SAMUEL KREUTZER, A LAWYER 35 YEARS
description: Samuel Kreutzer, a partner an the law firm of Lovett, Kreut zer, Vittoria & Lovett, 350 Fifth Avenue, and a lawyer for 35 years, specializing in cor porate, finance and estate law, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 11 Bayberry Ridge, Roslyn, L. I.

title: Miss Krautter Wed in Illinois
description: Miss Elisabeth Ward Kraut ter and Alexander Ferguson Treadwell, staff members of Sports Illustrated in New York, were married March 21 in the All Saints Chapel of Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka, Ill., by the Rev. Dr. William S. Lea.

title: DALLAS BANK'S NET UP IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The First National Bank in Dallas has announced a sig nificant improvement in first quarter earnings, reflecting, it said, an easing of money market interest rates.

title: Allison, Placed on Waivers By Twins, Goes Unclaimed
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 3 (AP) Bob Allison went through waivers unclaimed by any American League team, and Calvin Griffith, president of the Minnesota Twins, said today a decision would be made Mon day on whether to retain the 36yearold outfielder.

title: A Quarrel in a Far Away Country...
description: LONDON, April 3A Soviet delegation will arrive in London in a few days for political talks on world and bilateral issues. It is the first such AngloRus sian meeting since August, 1968 and thereby hangs a moral tale.

title: LESS ZEAL FOUND FOR PEACE CORPS
