description: WASHINGTON, April 3  A survey taken for the Peace Corps reports that the corps' reputation is waning among volunteers.

title: WITH EDITORS JAILED, GREEK PAPER CLOSES
description: ATHENS, April 3Ethnos, the only Greek newspaper openly hostile to the military backed regime, indefinitely suspended publication today, after the jailing of its principal editors and publishers.

title: SOLARWIND IS GIVEN BY JOFFREY BALLET
description: Solarwind is a ballot of little distinction but much activitity and last night City Center Joffrey Ballet presented Dermot Burke and Dana Sapiro in the piece for the first time.

title: Blankshine Dances In Varied Program By Morelli Ballet
description: What was billed as a Ballet Soire by the Morelli Ballet at the Fashion Institute of Technology last night turned out to be pretty ecumenical fare including Robert Blank shine, Starr Danias, modern dance, actors dancing, dancers trying to act and a young lady in the audience who called out, damned male chauvinist at the end of a series of succes sive amorous jazz duets be tween Matt Mattox and four women.

title: WALKER GETS 39 TO PACE VICTORS
description: CHICAGO, April 3 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls, sparked by a 39 point performance from Chet Walker, scored 74 points in the last half tonight to defeat the Atlanta Hawks, 131120, for their first victory in their four ofseven game playoff series.

title: Robyn E. Goldsmith To Wed in December
description: YONKERS, April 3  Mr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Gold smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robyn Ellen Goldsmith, to Andrew Schaeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Schaef fer of Wheaton, Md.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Johnny Jadick, 61, Is Dead; Former Boxing Champion
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) Johnny Jadick, former junior welterweight boxing champion, died last night at his home. He was 61 year old.

title: Court Orders the Arrests Of SitIns at Y in Harlem
description: Supreme Court Justice Fred erick Backer yesterday ordered the arrest of a group of blacks and Puerto Ricans who took over the operation of the Har lem Y.W.C.A. on March 3.

title: NEW ISSUES SHOW A STRONGER TREND
description: The newissue market staged a mild rebound this week from the depressed levels that have prevailed most of this year.

title: FORMER KLAN CHIEF BEGINS PRISON TERM
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 3 (UPI) The former imperial wizard of the militant White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan was taken to a Federal prison yesterday to begin a 10year sentence for conspiracy in the 1964 slayings of three young civil rights workers.

title: Lobbyist Indicted on 21 Counts of Fraud by Mail and Wire
description: Nathan M. Voloshen, a lobby ist accused of posing as a mem ber of the staff of Speaker of the House John W. McCormick, was indicted here yesterday on charges of defrauding a Cali fornia prison inmate of $16,000 in exchange for a promise to get him out of jail.

title: Urtain Stops Weiland to Take European Heavyweight Crown
description: MADRID, April 3 The name is Urtain, and it rhymes with poor wine. But this has been a vintage year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: MET FIGARO SUNG BY JINTINO DIAZ
description: Le Nozze di Figaro had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last Monday, and, singers' schedules being what they are, the first repetition of Mozart's opera last night had two major cast changes. Evelyn Lear sang the role of Cherubino here for the first time, and, as usual, put her own imprint on it. She was less cute than most Cherubinos, managing to seem more boyish stubborn and a bit truculent in an adolescent way. And she gave point to the meaning of the words in her arias, which she sang well.

title: PRESIDENT URGES 10C LETTER RATE TO MEET PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  President Nixon urged Con gress today to raise the cost of mailing a firstclass letter to 10 cents, to adopt other postal in creases and to speed up the col lection of estate and gift taxes to finance pay increases for Federal employes.

title: 3D COLORADO TERM SOUGHT BY GOV. LOVE
description: DENVER, April 3Gov. John A. Love announced today that he would seek a third four year term as Governor of Colo rado, and he is expected to have solid Republican party support. Meanwhile, the Dem ocrats have been squabbling among themselves.

title: Schools Closed in York, Pa.
description: YORK, Pa., April 3 (AP) School officials closed all pub lic schools today following three stabbings at William Penn Senior High School. The police said that three youths had been stabbed and that two were hospitalized.

title: Music: Rotterdam in First Visit Here
description: THE Rotterdam Philhar monic Orchestra made its first New York appear ance last night in Carnegie Hall, and one thing about it immediately was different. While the orchestra was tuning up, the oboist strolled through the ranks like a pied piper, sounding his A.

title: McDermott Distribution Set
description: The board of J. Ray McDer mott & Co., Inc., announced yesterday the distribution to shareholders of 5,899,879 shares, or about 95 per cent of the shares of Transocean Oil, Inc. Each McDermott stockholder will receive .8784 share of Transocean Oil.

title: TWO N.Y.U. WOMEN SWEEP IN FENCING
description: Two New York University fencers, Sally Pechinsky and Ruth White, captured all their openinground bouts yesterday in the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association champion ships at N.Y.U.'s School of Ed ucation gym.

title: 2 U.S. COURTS BAR G.I.'S TEST ON WAR
description: BOSTON, April 3 (UPI)Two Federal courts rejected today the first attempt by a Massa chusetts serviceman to bring suit under a new law challeng ing the President's authority to commit troops to combat zones such as Vietnam.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Unexplained Poses Some Questions
description: THE multiplicity of chal lenging scientific and bi ological mysteries was unsatisfactorily reviewed last night on The Unexplained, a special on the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Portland Clarifies Name
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 3 (UPI)It's supposed to be Trail Blazers instead of Trail blazers as the nickname for Portland's new National Bas ketball Association team, Harry Glickman, the executive vice president of the club, said today.

title: Dance: Feld's New Work
description: YES, Romanticism is back. Last night as I walked up the aisle at the Brooklyn Academy of Music after see ing Eliot Feld's new ballet, Early Songs, my friend and colleague Walter Sorell re minded me that he had told me this a year ago. He is so right. Mr. Feld and Jerome Robbins are busy giving bal letic Romanticism a new va lidity. And if this is a style and we should not neglect Balanchine's Lieberslieder Walzer of some years back then Early Songs is one of the liveliest examples of it.

title: RESHEVSKY SCORES IN BELGRADE CHESS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3  The United States chess champion, Sammy Resh evsky, today defeated Vasily Smyslov, a former world cham pion, in their thirdround ad journed game in the match be tween Soviet masters and the best chess players from the rest of the world.

title: Chinese Star Leads on 68
description: LINKOU, Taiwan, April 3 (AP)  Chang ChungFa, a Chinese pro playing on his home course, posted a four underpar 68 and took a one stroke lead today after one round of the China open golf tournament.

title: Jacobi Hospital Psychiatrists Defy City Policy on Admissions
description: Psychiatrists at Jacobi Hos pital, declaring they have been forced to give inadequate, in humane and illegal treatment to the mentally ill, yesterday established new procedures in defiance of city policy.

title: Technicians' Union and N.B.C. Reach Accord, Averting Strike
description: A fivecity strike scheduled by the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Tech nicians against the National Broadcasting Company was av erted yesterday afternoon 90 minutes before it was to have begun.

title: BIG BOARD TO END SMALLORDER BAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change ordered its membership yesterday to suspend certain discriminatory practices against small investors as part of an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to implement a $15 surcharge on most transactions.

title: International Action Sought to Curb Art Smuggling
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 The growing illicit traffic in art and antiquities  which draws on the cultural treasures of Latin America, Asia and Eu rope and which often results in the mutilation of historical treasureshas become the tar get of a series of worldwide control efforts.

title: Kidnappers Raise Price in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, April 3The leftist guerrillas who kidnapped Ambassador Karl van Spreti of West Germany increased their price today for his release. The new demand was $700,000 and liberty for 25 political prisoners.

title: Art: The Lyricism of Arthur G. Dove
description: ONE of the larger ironies of the current art scene is to be found in the uneven pace at which the history of modern art in America is studied, documented and ex hibited.

title: Ralph C. Engelstnan Dies at 71; An Authority on Life Insurance
description: Ralph G. Engelsman, a leader in lifeinsurance sales for many years, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Gulf Oil Appointment
description: Eugene Hosford has been named as an executive vice president of the Gulf Oil Com pany United States. He had been coordinator for explora tion and production for the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Expo Sidewalk Moves Again
description: OSAKA, Japan, April 4 (UPI) The moving sidewalk at Expo '70 began moving again today after a shutdown of eight days following an accident that in jured 42 persons after a woman fell. Offiicals said 28 hostesses and 28 guards had been added to the regular staff that patrols the sidewalk.

title: Marie Forsman Becomes Bride Of F. E. Heine
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 3Miss Marie Linda Fors man, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Forsman, and Frederick Ernest Heine of Plainfield, N. J., were mar ried today in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. James J. Halligan per formed the ceremony.

title: Fighting Rages as G.I.'s Pursue Foe Near Border
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (AP)  The United States infantrymen pursuing an enemy battalion toward the Cambodian border encountered heavy resistance today, and contact continued into the night, field reports said.

title: De Lima Victor Over Benton
description: A crowd of 3,605 sat through a 10round middleweight fight in The Felt Forum last night in almost complete silence. Juarez de Lima of Sao Paolo, Brazil, won the dull bout, scoring a unanimous decision over the 36yearold George Benton of Philadelphia.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS MAKE LITTLE GAIN
description: Leaders of the 10 unions negotiating contracts with the city's four major newspapers reviewed the status of their talks yesterday and reported very little progress in eco nomic areas.

title: Rangers Drill Hour For Key Struggle With Wings Tonight
description: BRANTFORD, Ontario, April 3  That form of torture known as the National Hockey League's pennant race enters its final weekend today with not one of the first five places in the East Division decided.

title: Paolo Buzzallino, Chef, Dies; Owner of Rose Restaurant
description: Paolo (Gigi) Buzzallino, pro prietor and chef of the Rose Restaurant, 41 West 52d Street, which is patronized by tele vision and news magazine men, died Thursday at Parkway Hos pital Forest Hills, Queens. He was 82 years old and lived at 8720 63d Avenue. Elmhurst.

title: Bombers Will Renew Old Acquaintances in Houston Games
description: HOUSTON, April 3  The Yankees couldn't believe it. It has been only three years since they last played in Houston, but look at all the changes.

title: Executive Changes
description: Dean R. McKay, vice president, has been named to the management committee and Wallace C. Doud and Ralph A. Pfeiffer Jr. have been elected as vice presidents of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Nile Span Collapse Kills 6
description: CAIRO, April 3 (UPI)Part of a Nile bridge 24 miles south of Cairo collapsed today under a passenger train, police sources said. Two of the coaches fell into the river, they said, killing six persons and injuring 47.

title: CAMBODIA PLANS A REPUBLIC SOON, ONE LEADER SAYS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 3The new leaders of Cam bodia plan to proclaim a re public soon, probably this month, one of them said to day.

title: Patrolmen Vote for Poll on Taking Job Action
description: The 28.000 members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso ciation will be asked Tuesday whether they want to begin a job action against the city that would result in an 80 per cent reduction in the number of policemen patrolling the streets.

title: DAHOMEY ELECTIONS ANNULLED BY REGIME
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, April 3 (Agence FrancePresse) The uncompleted presidential and legislative elections that were suspended here last Saturday following a series of violent incidents have been annulled, it was officially announced to night.

title: Western Turkey Is Struck By Earth Tremors Again
description: GEDIZ, Turkey, April 3 (UPI) Western Turkey suffered its sixth straight day of earth tremors today and rescue offi cials in this devastated town evacuated the last building un touched by previous quakes.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 Game Series)

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 3, 1970

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: South Vietnam Students Plan to Boycott Classes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)Some 60, 000 students from four South Vietnamese universities will boycott lectures indefinitely to protest the detention of 41 students, without trial, a spokesman said today.

title: 3 Children Killed in Tenement Fire
description: Three children ranging in age from 2 to 7 died yesterday de spite the efforts of firemen to revive them after they were found in a burning tenement in the Bronx.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WHEN Walt Frazier is tired or uninspired or playing off the beat, the Knicks do not look like the world's greatest basketball team, in fact they do not look very good at all. Willis Reed may be the only in dispensable Knick, but Frazier is the ignition key to the smoothrunning mechanism at its best. The team has built its entire game on running, on a swift, steady, merciless pressure that forces the opposition to take bad shots, to miss them, to throw away the ball and fumble it, to be out of position when Knicks drive, shoot, rebound.

title: Miss Redmond Enshrined
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (UPI) Carol Redmond, a 21yearold swimmer who retired with two championships at the age of 19, was elected today to the Helms Hall of Fame in synchronized swimming.

title: International Auto Show to Open at Coliseum
description: Scrubbed and glistening like children off to their first day at schoolmore than 600 cars were trundled into the Coliseum yesterday as the International Automobile Show was set to open a nine day stand.

title: No man can live with the terrible knowledge that he is not needed
description: NOW that we have, in effect, seized upon unemployment as a weapon of choice in the battle against inflation, we face the prospect of a 1970 unemployment rate of 5 per cent (4 million persons) or more. And as the unemployment rate goes up, economists and public policy makers debate the question: How much unemployment can the country stand?

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Defeats St. Francis Nine, 7 to 6
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 4 Coach John Orsino's surprising Fairleigh Dickinson baseball teams scored its second straight Metropolitan conference vic tory today by defeating St. Francis of Brooklyn, 76.

title: JAPAN'S POLICE USE LOCKABLE TICKETS
description: WASHINGTONGlobal war fare between parking violators and the police is escalating on all fronts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: WAR PROTESTERS SCORE THAI LINK
description: WASHINGTON April 4 The Student Mobilization Commit tee to End the War in Vietnam says it expects hundreds of thousands of high school and college students to stay away front classees on April 15 and to demonstrate against United States involvement in South east Asia.

title: 2 GROUPS DENOUNCE WEATHERMAN TRIAL
description: Two civil liberties groups issued statements Friday de ploring the conspiracy indict ments and choice of a judge in the forth coming trial of 12 members of the Weatherman faction of Students for a Demo cratic Society.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GREENJack M. The family of the late Jack M. Green wish to thank their many friends and relatives for their kind expres sions of sympathy.

title: L.I.U. TURNS BACK OSWEGO STATE, 60
description: A lefthander, Bob Files, struck out 15 batters to lead Long Island University to its second consecutive shutout over Oswego State, 60, yester day on the winner's field in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Old and new, fathers and sons, lies and truth, men and women, and the bridges between
description: By P. M. Pasinetti. 336 pp. New York: Random House. $6.95.

title: An Eisenhower Pitch Wilt Get Season Going
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The White House has come up with a pinchthrower to open the baseball season Mon day in place of President Nix on. It is his 22yearold son inlaw, David Eisenhnwrr.

title: ROUSE IS STOPPED BY FOSTER IN 4TH
description: MISSOULA, Mont., April 4 (AP)  Bob Foster, the light heavyweight champion, demol ished game Roger Rouse with a vicious right hand tonight, knocking the challenger down four times en route to a suc cessful defense of his title.

title: Sweden Jails U.S. Deserter
description: STOCKHOLM, April 4 (AP) An American deserted, Billy Wayne Staton, has been sen tenced to three years and six months in prison and subse quent expulsion for life on charges of illegally importing and distributing LSD tablets.

title: Hopes on Safety Unfulfilled
description: A few years ago the public outcry over safety was as loud as today's auto pollution debate.

title: John Todd Simonds Marries Juliet Hillman of Middlebury
description: PITTSBURGH, April 4 Miss Juliet Lea Hillman, daughter of Henry Lea Hill man, president of the Pitts burgh Coke and Chemical Company, and Mrs. Hillman, was married here today to John Todd Simonds, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Orms bee Simonds of Ben Avon Heights. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. John Baiz of the Calvary Epis copal Church.

title: Turkish Village Leveled By Eight New Tremors
description: GEDIZ, Turkey, April 4 (Reu ters)Fifteen houses in the village of Karamanca, the only ones left intact after a violent earthquake rocked an area of western Turkey around Gediz last weekend, collapsed when eight more tremors struck the area last night and today.

title: Television
description: INSTRUCTIONAL tele vision, potentially the most constructive use of the electronic medium, has been a distinct disappoint ment  although not an out right failure  for rather simple and obvious reasons: Its use has not been under the control of the teacher; a battery of transmitters, either over the air or on closed circuit, is needed to cover a fraction of a school's cur riculum; it is practically im possible to devise a schedule suiting the convenience of many schools simultaneously, and a taped or filmed pro gram may move too fast for maximum absorption of content.

title: MRS. COURT TAKES SO. AFRICA FINAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 4Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia, overcoming a rash of doublefaults, defeat ed Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., 62, 16, 63, in the final of the South African open tennis champion ship today.

title: Laws Tighten Vise on Drunk Driver
description: Stricter laws and strictor enforcement are zeroing in on the most dangerous killer at large in the United States todaythe driver who has been drinking.

title: 8 Die in Egypt Train Wreck
description: CAIRO, April 4 (AP)Eight persons died and 47 were in jured in a train accident in upper Egypt on Friday, the In terior Ministry announced today.

title: Lindsay in Reaganland
description: Mayor Lindsay's speech at the University of Cali fornia was significant because of what he said and where he said it. He did not bring home a degree from Berkeley; Governor Reagan and his Regents deliberately denied Mr. Lindsay the traditional honor accorded a Charter Day speaker.

title: TEMPLE VARSITY 4 OUTROWS FORDHAM
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 Temple's varsity oarsmen over took the Fordham four with cox swain after the first 100 meters today and went on to easily defeat the Rams by four lengths over the windswept Schuylkill River course here finishing in 6 minutes and 31 second. Temple's varsity light registered a 3length victory over La Salle in 5:37.3 over the 2,000meter olympic distance.

title: Nonviolence Making Quiet Gains in U.S. Despite Disorders
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., April 3 Two years after the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., nonviolence as a tech nique for social change, al though widely rejected, is making quiet gains across the nation.

title: EMERGENCY 999 WORKS IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, April 4  A dis traught farmer named Barry Hopwood told a telephone op erator that he had returned from milking his cows to find that his wife had been shot by an intruder.

title: Florida State Golf Squad And Clark of Purdue Win
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla., April 4 Florida State, the favorite, won the seventh annual intercolle giate golf classic here today, leading Florida, the defending champions, by 14 strokes.

title: N.Y.R.A. WEIGHING EXACTA WAGERING
description: The New York Racing As sociation confirmed yesterday it was seriously considering the possibility of introducing the exacta as a form of wager ing at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: WEATHER DELAYS DEBUT OF N.Y.U
description: With all three games last week washed out by snow and heavy rain, New York Univer sity's baseball team will try this week to open its, 103d season.

title: 3 Americans Among Dead In Moroccan Plane Crash
description: At least three Americans were among the 61 persons killed Wednesday in the crash and explosion of a Royal Air Maroc jetliner at Casablanca, Morocco, it was learned yester day. Roger Gilbert of Green wich, Conn., said the deaths of his brotherinlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Roberts of Greenwich, and another sis ter, Miss Lois Gilbert of New York, had been confirmed.

title: Q:
description: Education

title: The golden dream became a nightmare of deadly fool's gold
description: Real life often hands the historian a bonanza of a story which for drama and timing no fictioneer would ever dare to emulate. Such a tale was the news of the gold discovery in Californianot a rumor, not just another cockandbull yarn  but how the official facts were brought to Washington and the civilized world.

title: City and Store Closer to Accord
description: NEGOTIATIONS between the city and Alexan der's department store over a zoning change for a proposed West Side branch outlet have narrowed to a single pointwhen $175,000 of the store's money will be spent on improvements to a subway station.

title: If Gasoline Engine Goes, What Next?
description: For the first time in more than half a century, the gaso linefueled piston engines faces a serious threat to its existence. A measure to ban all gasolinepowered cars from the roads of California by 1975 passea the Senate there, then died in the As sembly. Similar auto pollu tion legislation has been pro posed in Congress. To en courage the development of alternate sources of power, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed a fiveyear program costing $45million.

title: Letters
description: Friedenberg

title: Ruth Ann Lawrence Engaged To Wed Thomas L. du Pont
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 4 Miss Ruth Anne Lawrence and Thomas Lewars du Pont, who expect to be graduated next month from Rollins Col lege, are planing a fall wed ding.

title: Benvenuti Arrives in Trieste
description: TRIESTE, Italy, April 4 (UPI) Nino Benvenuti, the world middleweight champion, arrived in Trieste today to begin train ing for a title fight against Tom Bethea of New York. Bethea, who scored a victory over Ben venuti in a nontitle bout in Australia last month, will meet the champion in Umag, Yugo slavia, on May 23.

title: PALMER, WITH 131, LEADS BY STROKE AT GREENSBORO
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4 Arnold Palmer remained in the lead, Gary Player carded a 63 and Jim Wiechers won $11, 000 for a holeinone today. All this was witnessed by a golf gallery of 28,000 persons, one of the largest to attend a tour event this year.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: PRIVATE apartment con struction in Manhattan will sink this year to the lowest level in a decade and a half, and next year there will be even fewer un subsidized apartments built in the borough.

title: Garden and Home
description: THE fixit, buildit, plantit, pruneit sea son is on. Homeowners, once snug in wintertime leisure, are stirring. They are coming out of their garages, tool sheds and work rooms to start the annual springtime race, a race that pits a long list of chores against a warming sun that too soon tones up the beaches for suntanners and greens up the hills for camp ers and hikers. Last weekend's unannounced blizzard didn't help by setting the clock back a touch. It put just enough white slush on the ground to delay repairs to the lawn, general clean up and early planting. Until the ground dries out for rake, spade and hoe work, there are inside tasks to get on with. Paneling, painting, build ing and home improvement projects are pro grammed by families who have watchful eyes on eroding dollars. Suburbanites find these choices wiser than new mortgages. They are learning to make do with the house they've got with an im provement here and an expansion there.

title: Unveilings
description: SIODMAKErlch. Unveiling In loving mem ory of Erich will Take place Sunday, April 12th, at 1 P.M. Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield, L.I. Block 306, Lot 27.

title: STUDENT LEADERS SPLIT ON POLICY
description: The citywide high school student government council has repudiated the committee that drew up its proposed bill of rights calling for a substantial student voice in school affairs.

title: Subjective S! Objective No!
description: In a memorable address to his faculty colleagues at Harvard last spring (reprinted in part in the Winter issue of The Public Interest) the economic historian Alexander Gerschenkron likened the events there to those unfolded in the Hans Christian Andersen tale The Most Unbelievable Thing.

title: An Educated Norse Shrikes Back at the Awful Diesel Smell
description: A research chemist in Cam bridge, Mass., has been hard at work for two years liter ally sniffing out ways to re duce the unpleasant, pungent odor of diesel exhausts.

title: Puma
Julie Eisenhower People They Weren't
description: RANDOM HOUSE is publishing a col lection of manifestoes by teenage revolutionaries titled Growing Up Radical that includes, among other things, an essay by a 13yearold boy who states, The United States enslaves, op presses, silences, and murders, and then adds, If we dare to question, or worse, to protest, our leaders are squashed. ...

title: Karmann Ghia
We give 'em what they can't get at home
description: If you are not with it now, you will be after you read Carnival. You will learn what a mark is, what is meant by ragbags, gil lies, and fortymilers, and what Pagan the stripper means when she says: We give 'em what they can't get at home.

title: AIDE AT WOODSTOCK REGAINS POLICE JOB
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 4 (AP)Joseph P. Kimble, secu rity chief at the Woodstock (N.Y.) music festival last year, has been reinstated as Beverly Hills police chief.

title: Flashy World of Fashion Goes Conservative on Cars
description: Seventh Avenue doesn't think much of Detroit. In a design sense that is.

title: BMW
Slowing Down of Slowdown Seen
description: A suggestion that the eco nomic slowdown is beginning to bottom out was ad vanced last week by the country's purchasing agents.

title: Farm Policy Helps Make the Rural Rich Richer
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Young Fred Salyer swung his little red and white mono plane through a bright Cali fornia sky, looking down on the flat expanse of the San Joaquiin Valley. His father had faced bankruptcy there in the early thirties. Now the land supports a thriving farm, with operations so ex tensive that only in an air plane can they all be checked in one day.

title: LACROSSE TAKEN BY JOHNS HOPKINS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 Johns Hopkins remained unde feated in lacrosse by trouncing Princeton, 137, today before more than 2,000 windchilled fans.

title: Oh, baby
description: Grownup babies will be coming out to play this summer wearing little knitted cottons with designs usually reserved for rompers. Ducks, flags and paper dolls are scattered all over clothes that are cut with a littlebaby look.

title: Ecology Post Is Filled
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 4 (AP)Dr. Andrew P. Nelson, now an assistant biology pro fessor at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N. H., has been named director of the new Vermont Environmental Studies Institute in Ripton, effective June 1.

title: Espalier a Tree or Shrub to Trim a Wall
description: THE oldfashioned art of growing espaliered plants is coming back into favor. Only recently, seems, this type of pruning was frowned upon, for it was too time consuming. However, the gardener with time on his hands often wants to pro duce something out of the ordinary to show off a blank space on a wall or fence.

title: Corvette
COLLEGES WIDEN BOARDS' MAKEUP
description: Significant and widespread increases in the number of Ne groes, women and persons un der 40 among college and uni versity trustees were reported yesterday to have been made across the country since mid 1968.

title: Paperbacks
description: FICTION

title: Insurers Opposing NoFault Policy
description: A pending measure before the New York State Legisla ture for nofault auto in surance, which its supporters say will sharply reduce costly litigation and thus cut pre miums by as much as 56 per cent, has produced predict able reactions throughout the nation.

title: New Device Helps Delicate Docking of Big Tankers
description: Bridges on supertankers all over the world are beginning to sport a special kind of black box to help them dock without damage. They show the man on the navigating platform how far off the bow of the huge vessel is moving until it is docked or anchored.

title: Greek Paper Thanks Readers in Farewell
description: ATHENS, April 4  The Athens newspaper Ethnos, in its last edition today, thanked its readers for their loyalty and told them that it could not continue publication with its principal editors and pub lishers in jail.

title: Shops Selling Erotica Increase In France as Curbs Are Eased
description: PARIS, April 4Gentle vio lin music filled the spotless showroom where Georges Gril lon's customers pored over his wares.

title: Washington: The Struggle for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 4This is spring training time for the 1970 Congressional elections, and the Republicans are acting like the Mets. This time, they have a President, a bankroll and Spiro Agnew, and the Dem ocrats are tired, divided and broke.

title: 50,000 IN CAPITAL SUPPORT THE WAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 About 50,000 people marched up Pennsylvania Avenue to a rally at the Washington Monu ment today to advocate vic tory in Vietnam.

title: W. AND. M. TAKES TWO RELAY RACES
description: WASHINGTON, April 4At an indoor meet in New York earlier this year, he was intro duced as Michael Howell, the Southeastern Conference cham pion. At the American Uni versity Relays today, the an nouncer called him Howard Michael.

title: AL HATTAB IS FIRST IN GULFSTREANI RACE
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 4 (AP)  Al Hattab ended his Florida drought today by gal loping past the field in the final turn and scoring a fourlength victory in the $20,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap at Gulf stream.

title: Wendy Chalif Is Bride of J. M. Eld
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., April 4  Miss Wendy Hull Chalif, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Louis Chalif of Chatham, was married here this afternoon to Jonathan Moulton Eld, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wendell Eld of Far Hills.

title: Observer: Lord Sean's Wives and Fellow Husbands
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 4  Those who fear that the country will fetch up on the wilder shores of sin because of the storms of heathenism now buf feting America's children might have been moved to think again had they seen the University of Colorado's confrontation the other day with Lord Sean and Lady Samantha.

title: In Brief: Theater
description: A Theater Divided, Martin Gottfried's distinguished book of criticism, appeared two years ago. Now, to the benefit of ad mirers who may not have fol lowed his regular writing as drama critic for Women's Wear Daily, he has gathered into another book 100 or more of his compact columns that ap peared between 1963 and the middle of last year. This is no routine reprinting. The columns are arrauged by ?? ?? chronologically (The Unappre ciated, The Overrated, musi cals, acting companies, the thea ter of race, the work of Albee, Pinter, Brecht); careful editing has brought everything up to date. The result is a combina tion of recent theater history and forceful, individual com ment on it. And these are not just New York opening nights; they extend across the nation Hartford, Atlanta, Minneapolis, Dallas, Los Angeles. They re view the seven years just past, but they also look to the pres ent and the future. In a way this book is a kind of valedic tory to the theater that has been most familiar up to now, from Peg o' My Heart to Tiny Alice.

title: A B C's of Planting Trees and Shrubs
description: IT IS virtually impossible to lift a tree or shrub out of the ground, move it, and replant it without damaging its root system. Se vere damage to the root sys tem will so impair the plant's ability to absorb water from the soil that it can cause it serious or fatal injury. A few simple procedures, how ever, will help to minimize transplanting injury and in sure the plant a quick re covery in its new location.

title: Agreement Signed
description: The Stone Container Cor poration of Chicago has en tered into an agreement with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., to develop and mar ket an automated system for packaging frozen meat. The Chicagobased company said that the nucleus of the sys tem was the continuous trans seal machine developed by Stone Container.

title: Romansky Aims at Record In Asbury Park Walk Today
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J.  Dave Romansky of Pennsville, N. J., the holder of the Asbury Park boardwalk 10mile walking rec ord of 1 hour, 12 minutes 56.5 seconds, aims to break that mark today in the Capt. Ronald Zinn Memorial Race.

title: Women's Rights Study Begun at Universities
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) A Government agency has said that it was investi gating alleged sex discrimina tion at several universities, including Harvard.

title: The Casts
description: TWO TIMES ONE, The Last Straw by Charles Dizenzo and Duet for Solo Voice by David Scott Milton. Directed by Gregory C. Meland and Martin Fried, respectively; setting and cos tumes by Kert Lundell; lighting be Roger Morgan; special sound by James Reichert; production stage manager, George Blanchard. Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Hand man, director. At St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street.

title: Aronow to Race Just for Fun in 1970
description: Don Aronow of Coral Gables, Fla., the world and United States offshore powerboat rac ing champion, has confirmed his intention not to campaign seriously in 1970, saying that he will race just for fun.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The most complete book on bead design ever published revives the Victorian art of beadcraft. Here is a comprehensive course for beginner and ex perienced craftsman with all the basic techniques for work ing with beads, wire and threads, and more advanced techniques. Not only includes 100 projects for different flowers, but also for trees, fruits, jewelry, boutique items, and a holiday workshop. With 400 large photographs, draw ings and diagrams.

title: Busy City Streets
description: Motor vehicles in the Unit ed States move just over a billion miles a year, accord ing to the latest compilation by the Federal Highway Ad ministrationand just over half of this is on city streets.

title: FRIDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: New York (Felt Forum) Juarez de Lima, 161 pounds, Brazil, outpointed George Ben ton, 160, Philadelphia, 10 rounds.

title: Motorists Joining the Consumer Revolt
description: Criticism of new cars, sales practices, warranty repairs and service are a big part of the rising consumer de mands for better quality in products and workmanship.

title: Smith Takes Fourth Crown In Veterans' Squash Tennis
description: Dave Smith of New York won his fourth national vet eran's squash tennis champion ship yesterday by defeating Ellsworth Carrington of Short Hills, N. J., 915, 1512, 1813, 1512, at the Yale Club.

title: Cubic Inches as an Index of Power
description: For some years now, be cause of increased concern for safety, it has been con sidered bad form for auto advertising to mention horse power. But as long as cars are produced for sale, the manufacturers consider it necessary to impress you with a figure of some kind.

title: Warranties Protect Motorists, Except Dragsters, Even if They Do Maintenance Work Themselves
description: The chances are that you can't recall the crucial terms of your car's warranty. Even more important, you prob ably don't know what is re quired to keep the warranty in effect.

title: TROOPS BREAK UP CROWD IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 4 (AP)  British troops used tear gas tonight to break up a crowd of Protestants that tried to invade a Roman Catho lic district of Belfast.

title: Princeton's Lightweights Set Back Columbia Crew
description: Princeton's 150pound crew, leading from start to finish, defeated Columbia by four lengths yesterday on the Har lem River. It was the first of ficial spring race for both crews.

title: VIETNAMESE SHOW FEAR IN CAMBODIA
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 4South Vietnam, torn by war, looks like a haven to most Vietnamese living in Cambodia.

title: Spaghetti alla Yankee
description: Although its spirit is Italian (it contains garlic, spaghetti, and tomatoes), this casserole is as American as fried chicken. It is a bit tedious to prepare, but the game is worth the candle. The dish is essentially spa ghetti with chicken, but it con tains such good things as mushrooms, sausage, ground meat and cheese, all of them bound together with a tomato and cream sauce. A bonus is that the casserole may be made a few hours in advance and popped into the oven half an hour before dinner. The spaghetti will absorb much of the liquid in this case, and it must be thinned again with stock before baking.

title: Chiefs Already Flexing Muscles For Their Warfare Next Fall
description: ALTHOUGH the opening of the season is five months away, the Kansas City Chiefs last week began to get ready. Coach Hank Stram began a conditioning program for 25 holdovers and 13 rookies at the champions' headquarters on the southeast edge of the city with four inches of snow on the ground. The program ended yesterday but Stram will call in all his rookies the end of the month for a day or two and then for a full week in June. Training camp opens July 1 at Liberty, Mo., for rookies and July 15 for the seasoned players.

title: Houk Tackles Pleasant Task in Picking Yanks' OpeningDay Batting Order
description: HOUSTON, April 4Spring training doesn't mean a thing. Everybody knows that. What ever the Yankees did in Florida will mean nothing when they open the season on Tuesday in Yankee Stadium. Everybody knows that.

title: Underground Papers Are Thriving on Campuses and in Cities Across Nation
description: RICHMOND  For the last three months, Hilton Lee Brooks, a bearded youth with flowing brown hair, has been pushing copies of his under ground paper in front of people walking on Broad Street, the main shopping center of this former, capital of the Con federacy.

title: Music
description: THE Beethoven bicentennial has brought out several good books, with the promise of more to come. One of the best studies so far is Martin Cooper's BeethovenThe Last Decade, a serious, analytic study of Beethoven and his music in the last ten years of his life.

title: SAMUEL E. SWIGGETT
description: ROSLYN ESTATES, L. I., April, 4Samuel E. Swiggett, former Mayor, Attorney and Trustee of the Village of Ros lyn Estates, and a retired New York lawyer, died last night at the Community Hospital, Glen Cove. He was 82 years old and lived at 6 The Birches.

title: News of the Rialto
description: GATHER round, theater buffs, for the story of the near demise and ultimate rise of the musical, Purlie, which, all indications are, will be vic torious. It is a tale of woe to gray a man's hair over night, and let's not overlook the more morbid thoughts that crossed his fevered brain. The man is Philip Rose, producer of Ossie Davis's play, Purlie Victorious, who was later moved to make a musical of it with himself as a coadapter as well as director and producer.

title: Movies
description: THE fact that Anne of the Thou sand Days was nominated for 10 Oscars, including best picture, and Hello, Dolly! tied Midnight Cowboy with seven nominations, in cluding best picture, may have more to do with beef Stroganoff and imported champagne (Anne) and threeinch thick prime ribs (Dolly) than with anything in the nature of academies.

title: Malcolm C. Stewart, 57, Vice Chairman of Gillette
description: BOSTON, April 4Malcolm C. Stewart, vice chairman of the board and a director of the Gillette Company, died in a hos pital here yesterday at the age of 57. He was a resident of Beverly Farms.

title: Disk Brakes Stay Cool
description: During the early years of motoring, automotive en gineers concentrated on mak ing cars go. Today the em phasis is on getting them to stop effectively.

title: JERSEY RAIL BRIDGE IS STRUCK BY BARGE
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., April 4 (AP)Repairmen worked on a Raritan River railroad bridge here today after it was struck yesterday by a barge for the second time in two months.

title: $100,000 BOWLING TAKEN BY JOHNSON
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 4Don Johnson, a 29yearold solemn faced youth from Akron by way of Kokomo, Ind., endcd four years of frustration today by winning the sixth annul $100,000 Firestone Professional Bowlers Association Tourna ment of Champions with a game of 299 in bowling's post dramatic finale at the Riviera Lanes.

title: BROOKLYN TECH VICTOR IN RELAYS
description: NANUET, N. Y., April 4 When the Nanuet Relays were organized three years ago, the purpose of the early season schoolboy meet was to ad vance track in Rockland Coun ty, according to Dave Harison, the local high school coach and meet director.

title: Brighter Radar Screen Finds Favor at Airports
description: A small radar screen instant ly readable even in day light is finding favor in air control towers at airports all over the country.

title: Gadget Drummers Turn to Practicality
description: A review of the year' out put of auto gadgets shows clearly that the market is cooling, although ever so slowly. The cooling probably has more to do with the lack of avaialale cash and the decline in auto purchases than it does with any return to sanity in the gadget fac tory. But the rational look of the counters is welcome in any case.

title: 8 MARKS BROKEN IN KENTUCKY MEET
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 4 (AP)Eight meet records were set today in the final day of the University of Kentucky Re lays; as 82 colleges, clubs and high schools competed in the 32 events.

title: Yale Defeats Four Boston U. crews
description: DERBY, Conn., April 4 Tony Johnson's debut as Yale's rowing coach was a complete success today as each of his four eight  oar heavyweight crews won in a sweep over Boston University on the fast and windy Housatonic River.

title: Trout Season Start Draws Small Turnout in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 4 (AP) New Jersey's trout season opened today and the turnout of fishermen was reported as the smallest in many years.

title: Argo Port Is Victor by a Neck In $25,000, BlanketFinish Trot
description: YONKERS, April 4  Argo Port, although forced to take the long way round, captured the $25,000 Star's Pride Trot before 27,534 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: On Youth, Truth and the itch to Get Switched On
description: DEFENDING the indefensible strikes me as a strange occu pation for a critic, even if he be a television critic like Jack Gould, who has been inured by a quar ter of a century's trash to a level of programing that would be unacceptable in any other medium. Astonishment, therefore, was my initial reaction last week when I saw Gould rushing to the defense of a wretched little program entitled The SwitchedOn Symphony. Why anyone should want to plead on behalf of this patently dishonest pro tram with its preposterous thesis, that there is a close relationship between today's rock music and the classics, escapes me completely. Yet as I watched Gould employ all the devices and colors of an opportunistic rhetoric, as I saw him consistently distort or evade the issues, while making unwar ranted and derogatory assumptions about me simply because I severely crit icized this program, my astonishment turtgd to disgust at ??s perversion of the critic's function.

title: With Sales Slump, Dealers Stress Used Cars
description: Because of tight money policies, inflationary pres sures and the lack of real novelty in the. 1970 models newcar dealers are devoting an increasing effort this year to the sale of used cars to make up for the sluggish sales of the new ones.

title: Tax Form: Problems
description: It was bound to happen. The new tax returndesigned to make the annual tax chore simplerhas, at least at the outset, caused some problems.

title: Sterling Boston U. Captain
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP)Steve Ster ling, a junior, was elected captain of the Boston Univer sity hockey team tonight at the awards dinner. Mike Hyndman and Larry Davenport were co recipients of the mostvaluable player award.

title: 2 Arabs in Athens Appeal
description: ATHENS, April 4 (Reuters) Two arab commandos sentenced last month for attacking an Israeli airliner at Athens air port today appealed to the Greek Supreme Court for a re trail. Mahmoud Mohammad, 26 years old, and Maher Hussein Suleiman, 20, received 17 years and five months and 14 years and three months imprison ment respectively.

title: Spirit of 1976 May Mix Fusillade on Pollution With Colonial Hoopla
description: IT reads like a combination of a Holly wood script and a Madison Avenue story board, and it promises to be a colorful and patriotic ceremony which it should be, since it will be the first official announcement of how the United States of America will cele brate in 1976 the 200th anniversary of its Revolution and founding. The cere mony will take place at one of the White houses, permanent or temporary, on July 4, when President Nixon will announce just how this nation will observe its 200th birthday.

title: Expo Sidewalk Moves Again
description: OSAKA, Japan, April 4 (UPI) The moving sidewalk at Expo '70 began moving again Friday after a shutdown of eight days following an accident that in jured 42 persons after a woman fell. Offiicals said 28 hostesses and 23 guards had been added to the regular staff that patrols the sidewalk.

title: Zanda
Caroline W. Metcalf Married To Peter M. Saylor, Architect
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 Miss Caroline Walker Met calf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Rich Metcalf of Prince ton and York, Me., was mar ried this afternoon to Peter Martin Saylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Theodore Saylor of Ardmore, Pa. The ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel was per formed by the Right Rev. Dudley Scott Start, retired Episcopal Bishop of Roches ter, assisted by the Rev. John M. Mulligan.

title: Fore Failure Costs $6,500
description: DETROIT, April 4 (AP)A Detroit golfer who failed to yell fore when he teed off from the 15th hole has been ordered to pay $6,500 in dam ages to another golfer who was struck behind the left ear. Leon Heller, 56 years old, hooked his tee shot to the left one day in August, 1967, and struck Joseph Stack. Mr. Heller told a Wayne County Circuit Court jury that he did not yell fore because he was a con sistent slicer, sending his drives off to the right.

title: Dog Show Entries Continue to Boom
description: PARTICIPATION in dog shows, which as a luxury activity in a period of eco nomic uncertainty should by all logic be expected to slacken, has been under going what looks like a boom, instead, during the waning indoor season. Alan P. Winks of Media. Pa., 41 yearold London born president of the Foley Dog Show Organiza tion, professional show superin tendents, offered three nota ble examples of recent growth.

title: No Peace for Pedestrians Along the Rue de la Pair
description: PARISThe last time I really saw Paris was on a dramatic day during the minirevolution of MayJune, 1968, when all of France was dry. No gasoline was available to feed the tanks of the city's 900,000 automobiles. They stayed Home and couldn't spoil the view.

title: Call him a sentimentalist
description: To damn him at once this early spring morning, call novelist (This Is Goggle) Bentz Plagemann a square. He tries to pay his bills, he is in terested in his church. Also call him a sentimentalist, for he likes his wife, his son and the neighbors' children. Final ly, fool that he is, he is rea sonably content with middle class virtues and middleclass life. In these, days of power black, white or Agneweven the title of his new book of casual essays, This Happy Place, and its subtitle, Liv ing the Good Life in America, defines him as an anachronism.

title: Toll Roads Worth Price for Safety
description: Drivers are in some ways safer on the nation's toll roads than they are on free ones.

title: Jeep Wagoneer
Elizabeth Heep Plans Nuptials
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 4 Heinrich Heep, president of Krupp International, Inc., and Mrs. Heep of Montclair and Madrid, Me., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eliza beth Bernardine Heep, to Brent Bernikow, a student at the State University Down state Medical Center in Brooklyn. He is the son of Irwin Bernikow, a pharma cist, and Mrs. Bernikow of Plainview, L. I.

title: 2,000 March Past Two Auto Sites Here to Protest Motor Pollution
description: About 2,000 people, most of them young marched from the General Motors Building at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street to the Central Park Mall yesterday for a rally protesting air pollution caused by automobile.

title: No century gap here
description: Collectors, especially if their treas ures range from the antique to the modem, often face a rather knotty problem when it comes to composing their eclectic collections into a harmonious whole. The owner of this Beekman Place apartment in Manhattan has not only an imposing selection of fine French furniture, Savonnerie and needlepoint carpets, but also a museumworthy group of modern paintings and sculpture. In this case, the collector's personal taste was so strongly expressed in the 18thcentury furnishings and 20th century art that old and new made a compatible blend and accented each other's virtues. Walls were painted to set off the art, and flowers are used generously as a denominator.

title: Life at U.N. Outpost in Cyprus Dull Despite Spectacular View
description: OUTPOST HILLTOP, Cyprus, East of the rockstrewn hill top, and about 400 yards away, looms a higher peak surmount ed by a flagpole flying a blue Greek flag. To the west, about the same distance, towers an other hill, topped by a red Turkish flag.

title: RHODESIAN HEAD ASSAILED ON SONG
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 4When Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia rose last night to speak to a crowd of white farmers at an election rally, a voice from the audience) rang out, What about a song?

title: Ethyl's Removal Means Less Mileage and dower, Higher CostsAnd. Gleaner Air
description: DETROITEthyl was won derful, peppy and exciting, but her escapades were just too much for the boys from Detroit, and they've dropped her.

title: KatesKristal Wedding
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 4 In the Jewish Community Center of Teaneck tonight Miss Carolyn Ruth Kristal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. John Kristal, was married to Dr. Charles Howard Kates, son of Mrs. Joseph Y. Kates and the late Mr. Kates. Both families are of Hackensack. Rabbis Judah Washer and Jacob Kleinhan officiated.

title: Dance
description: FIRST just a postscript about the City Center Joffrey Ballet, which ends its spring sea son at the New City Cen ter tonight. This year the com pany has played longer in New York than ever before, a 12week stint split into two 6week legs. It must surely have been the successful sea son in its history. The audience is really building, and now the size is not so different, I am informed, from that which New York City Ballet used to attract when it too was the City Center.

title: Tapeworm Infection in Humans Linked to Cattle Raised in U.S.
description: Some Americans are getting tapeworm infections from eat ing infected beef raised in this country, three United States Public Health Service doctors have reported.

title: 151 Gay Trip First In Grand National
description: AINTREE, England, April 4 Pat Taaffe, a 40yearold Irish jockey who was assigned the mount only two weeks ago, rode Englishowned Gay Trip, a 151 shot, to a 20length vic tory today in the 126th running of the Grand National Steeple chase over the Aintree course.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One of the sorrows of my fictionreading life is that Ed mund Crispin ceased recounting the immensely witty and lit erate adventures of Oxford don Grevase Fen in 1953 after but eight novels and a collection of short stories. And so if I in dicate that I had been searching with some degree of diligence but no success for a copy of the only Crispin book still lack ing from my library, THE CASE OF THE GILDED FLY, you will appreciate my pleasure on find ing it reissued by London and Maxwell (Elmsford, N.Y. 10523, $4.95). This is the first case for Professor Fen, who describes himself modestly as the only literary critic turned detective in the whole of fiction. (For balance we also have a police man who fancies himself un excelled in literary criticism.) A famed London playwright comes to Oxford to try out his latest highly experimental dra ma in the college repertory theater. An actressa former mistress of the playwright, and unloved by allis done in un der circumstances consistent neither with accident, suicide or murder, and it's up to Fen to sort it out. And all the while Crispin is at his prime, lovingly assembling the words of the Queen's English in freshly ex presive ranks.

title: Indian Job Discrimination Laid to U.S. by 4 Tribes

title: Art
description: OSAKA, Japan THE function of a world's fair, accepted at its pro fessed idealistic level, is to open channels of com munication that lead to international understanding. We all know, however, that what this boils down to is a matter of international showing off. You don't have to be a cynic to recognize that each nation's pavilion is intended as a competitive idealized selfportrait, even when the job backfires.

title: Photography
description: THE photographer James Van DerZee started out making pictures by hand, like Giotto, Dali and the cavemen of Altamira, but after I found out there was such a thing as a camera and that you could put peo ple in position and just press the button and you had the picture, then I didn't do so much painting and drawing. We may be thankful for Van DerZee's discovery, for with out it we would never have had his visual record of black American life which formed such an important part of the Metropolitan Museum's exhi bition Harlem on My Mind last year, and has now been put into book form by Regi nald McGhee as The World of James Van DerZee (Grove Press, $15).

title: GUATEMALA SAYS A CAPTIVE IS DEAD

title: Designed for Use Rather Than Delectation
description: TWO exhibitions, unprecedented in America, of Tantric mystical draw ings and stone lingams from the Alexandra Marc collection of Indian art opened recently at the Jewish Mu seum and the uptown Richard Feigen Gallery. The drawings, of which there are 50 at the museum and about half that number at the Feigen, are small, mostly geometrical diagrams in ink and gouache, and the lingams, all at Feigen, are polished ovoid stones of various sizes. Most are from the l8th and 19th centuries, though their tradition is said to date back to the 5th century A.D. A visit to both shows, with the guidance of two very readable pamphlets one may acquire in the process, can be an absorbing, edifying and even a somewhat psychedelic experience.

title: 4 SEIZED IN HOTEL IN GAMBLING RAID
description: Four men were arrested in a suite at the Peter Cooper Hotel, 130 East 39th Street at 1:30 P.M. yesterday and charged with operating a sports and policynumber betting ring that, according to the police, took in nearly $5million in three months.

title: None for the Road
description: Newly released figures show that the Soviet Union is in even worse condition than the United States in respect to fatal traffic accidents. Until recently, data on traffic fatalitieslike those on crime and other negative subjectswere closely guarded state se crets in the U.S.S.R. But it has now been announced that motor vehicles killed 16,000 persons last year in the Russian Republic, an area that has only slightly more than half the total Soviet population. Allowing for population, therefore, it seems likely that about 30,000 persons died in Soviet traffic accidents last year. The Soviet Union has less than 10 per cent as many motor vehicles as this country. If cars and trucks here had been killing people at the same rate per million vehicles as in the Soviet Union, more than 300,000 Americansinstead of 56,400would have died on the road in 1969.

title: Mama Makes Wanton Soup
description: THE oval table in the top floor apartment of the new home of La Mama Experimental Theater Club, 74A East Fourth Street, was a cheerful clutter of coffee mugs, oranges, flowers and unopened mail from all over the world, and the room was a Babel of excited voices all talking theater in French, German, Yugoslavian, as well as British and Chinese accented English.

Before the celebra tion ends next Sunday, more than a million visitors are expected to sample offerings ranging from military pageants to band contests to the crowning of the CherryBlossom Princess. They are also expected to be the most cautious com plement of visitors in the city's his tory.

The giant project will eventu ally irrigate 250,000 acres and supply water for municipal, in dustrial and recreational uses. The contract went to William Clairmont, Inc., of Bismark, N. D., a the low bidder at $7,991,331.

title: There are parts of all our victimized selves in MacMannan
description: What Anthony C. West wants in As Towns With Fire is revelation. Life unzipped and laid bare. History and person al fate connected. Cosmic means and ends manifest in the fortune of one man, an Irish loverpoethusbandair man during the dreary 1930's and the terrifying 1940's. Even the title from Love's Labour's LostAnd when it hath the thing it hunteth most, 'tis won as towns with fire, so won, so lostsounds like a minis ter's exhortation. A powerful ambition possesses West, the kind of oldfashioned lust to write great fiction that one associates with bigsweep Slav ic literature. His novel runs the length of a Congressional report, and West has a glut ton's hunger for teleology. No boy would undertake As Towns With Fire. It's a man's work, all 518 heavy pages, and the goal is simply beyond West's capacity. He has ener gy, intelligence, imagination. Unfortunately, he doesn't have what his ambition requires: literary genius.

title: New York
description: ALBANYThe cathedrallike light of sunshine through the stainedglass windows of the cavernous Assembly chamber gave way to gloomy darkness as the debate dragged toward midnight and suspicions began to overwhelm reason.

title: Judge Roy Bean Lives On in Town He Named for Lily
description: LANGTRY, Tex.It is per haps typical of Texas temperament that the state could dedicate a park and an elaborate new visitor center in honor of a colorful scalawagand do it with a straight face. The Judge Roy Bean Law West of the Pecos Museum, a rus tic shack squatting incongru ously behind a shining, mod ern visitor center and infor mation bureau in this tiny outoftheway hamlet a mile off U.S. 90, is the original, un restored saloon that also served as a hoine and court room for this improbable frontier character. The unpainted and weath ered frame building is still known as The Jersey Lilly, a misspelled version of the popular name for Judge Bean's idol, Lily Langtry, the reigning international stage star of the period.

title: Sylvia D. Dillon, Robert Holly Jr. Wed in Suburbs

The political and military alliance came into be ing 21 years ago in Washing ton when the United States, Iceland, Canada, France, Brit ain, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Denmark, Italy, Norway and Portugal signed the North Atlantic Treaty. West Germany, Greece and Turkey joined later.

It is immensely readable, and the reader not only has the sense of Immersion in the sights, scents and sounds of India, he also meets representative people from high and low walks of life, and he is supplied with taped infor mation, as from one of those talking machines spectators may obtain at museums.

title: Journey to The Moon
description: You might think that the eightday, Apollo 11 moon mission, shrunk to the dimensions of a child's picture book, would lose proportionately in lustre and stature. No; except for occasional jaunty waves from the trio of astronauts the feat of July 16 to 24, 1969, presented here in a dozen doublepage paintings by a German artist, still has us awed, hushed and anxious until the final splash down. Erich Fuchs conveys the grand, dra matic moments: the launching against the prangedrenched sky of Cape Kennedy; acceleration up through lowering clouds as the things of earth recede; staging and linkup with the lunar module as the, cratered moon waits, like a giant blueandwhite whiffle ball; the landing of the geo metrically patterned Eagle; the moon walk of Armstrong and Aldrin while Collins circles in the command ship Columbia; the return to the carrier Hornet.

title: Bridge

title: Neither a saint nor a sinner
description: From Montgomery to Mem phis, two characteristics domi nated Martin Luther King Jr.'s 13year public life: In race relations, he was the major figure; and his career was pre occupied, inevitably, with vio lent crises. David L. Lewis's biography is a wellresearched, clearly written and well balanced account of these phe nomena. This is not a book that heaps praise or condem nation lavishly, which is a temptation when dealing with a figure like King. He is presented as neither a saint nor a sinner, but a sincere moral activist who won some and lost some, and who would have preferredbut ultimately was unableto live to fight another day.

description: HONOLULU, April 3Lieut Gov. Thomas J. Gill, 47 years old, pointed from his office win dow in the state Capitol to the graceful upward sweep of land from sea to mountains, and to the housing projects encroach ing into the farmland.

title: Meanwhile, Folks, Back in Soap City...
description: JOAN BENNETT. Dana Andrews. Geraldine Fitzgerald. Lilia Skala. Henderson Forsythe. David Birney. Shepperd Strudwick. Jan Sterling. Laurence Luckinbill. Diana van der Vlis. Macdonald Carey. Troy Donahue. Marco St. John. Cathy Burns. Gale Sonder gaard. C. C. Courtney. Constance Ford. Mary Fickett. Patty McCormack. M'el Dowd. Bibi Osterwald.

title: Giants' Marichal Is Ill And May Miss Opener
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 4 (UPI)Juan Marichal is suf fering a severe ear infection and may not start Tuesday's season opener against Hous ton in Candlestick Park, Clyde King, the San Francisco man ager, said today.

title: Ecuador's Consul in Philadelphia Held on DrugSmuggling Counts
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI)  Ecuador's consul in Philadelphia, Alfredo J. Giler, was arrested today by agents of the United States Customs Bureau on charges of smug gling seven pounds of pure Cocaine.

title: Chrysler
Buick
BRITISH PAIR TAKES U.S. BADMINTON TITLE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4 (AP)Paul Whetnall of Swan ley, Kent, and Margaret Boxall of Gosport, both of England, upset the highly touted Japa nese mixeddoubles team of Ip pei Kojima and Miss Machiko Aizawa, 158, 152, today in the final of the 17th annual United States badminton champion shins.

title: Mary E. Drury Married to Joseph Charles Guilfoyle
description: The marriage of Miss Mary Ellen Drury to Joseph Charles Guilfoyle took place in Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Tomp kinsville, S. I., at noon yes terday. The Rev. Robert A. Reagan performed the cere mony at a nuptial mass.

title: Midget Racing Season to Open Today
description: MAKE way for the little guys, the midgets and sprints.

title: Homage to Spain
description: IF THE title had not been preempted long ago by George Orwell for spe cifically political pur poses, the newest album of songs by Victoria de los An geles might best be called Homage to Catalonia. The Orwell book paid respects to the region in northeast Spain where, in the civil war of the Thirties, an ancient, independent people briefly won and then lost their free dom, trapped in an ideo logical crossfire between Franco's Falangists and Stalinist partyliners.

title: In The Nation: Strong Move in Massachusetts
description: WASHINGTONThe impor tance of the Massachusetts Legislature's bold challenge to the war in Vietnam is not that the Supreme Court is likely to rule that this undeclared war is an unconstitutional exercise of Presidential power. It is rather that the Massachusetts bill is the longest official step yet taken in making war resist ance acceptable and legitimate. That means it is bound to be come even more effectively political.

title: Fleischmans Have Son
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 4A son was born March 3 at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset to Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Fleisch man. The child has been named Richard James.

title: Sunderiand is 10 Soccer Victor Over Manchester City
description: LONDON, April 4, (Reuters) Sunderland, fighting to avoid relegation from the English Soccer League First Division, kept its hopes alive today by toppling Manchester City, the league cupholder, 10.

title: OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: DEAR JANET ROSENBERG, DEAR MR. KOONING Tonight, Gramercy Arts Theater, 7:15. A comedy by Stanley Eveling.

title: A Head Start for Peas
description: PEAS have been raised since pre historic times, when they were used in dried form. The Chinese treated them as a green vege table in about the third century B.C. In other eras, it was proper to eat them by finger, by knife or to lick them from their shells after dipping the pods in a sauce.

title: Lesotho King in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, April 4 (AP)King Mo shoeshoe II, who has been un der house arrest in Lesotho since the aborted election there Jan. 31, arrived in Amsterdam today for a scheduled six month stay.

title: Rosi Fortner Captures Special Slalom at World Student Games in Finland
description: PYHATUNTURI, Finland, April 4 (UPI)Rosi Fortna of Warren, Vt., easily won the women's special slalom today to give the United States its first gold medal in the 1970 World student winter games.

title: Renault
Pioneers of the Industry
description: The 20 years between 1891 and 1910 were the spring time of the automobile indus try, here and abroad. It was the time of the improvement of the internalcombustion gas engine from a clumsy, heavy machine to something light that would fit on a car riage . . . and move it success fully.

title: YANKEES VICTORS OVER ASTROS, 63
Sloop Niagara Is Gift to Syndicate
description: The cruising sloop Niag ara, beaten United States challenger for the Canada's Cup on Lake Ontario last September, has been given as a gift to the syndicate headed by Robert McCul lough that is financing a new 12Meter yacht as a possible America's Cup de fender.

title: ABORTION CLINICS IN BRITAIN WARNED
description: LONDON, April 4 (AP)The Government has warned Brit ain's private abortion clinics, in which 20,686 women had legal abortions last year, to stop soliciting foreign patients.

title: Everything to be suffered and nothing to be done
description: The same man keeps turning up in these nine wellmade, ob servant, rather gloomy stories. To relate him to a tradition, we might call him Nick Carra way's neurotic nephew. He was born and grew up in the decent middle upper class Midwest, saw a bad but not disastrous time during the Depression, formed deep attachments to, and a kind of identification with, the femi nine members of his household, went to a good university and into the armed services, and came to New York at the end of the 1940's.

title: Aeroflot Flying to Malaysia
description: MOSCOW April 4 (AP) Aeroflot opened a new weekly air service to Malaysia this weekend with an IL62 flight from Moscow via Teheran, Karachi and Colombo to Kuala Lumpur. Tass noted Aeroflot now links the Soviet Union with 55 foreign countries.

title: For Routine Servicing Hints, Go by the Book
description: There is nothing about rou tine servicing of a car that is beyond the comprehension of a woman capable of figur ing out the cycle of a coin operated washer or dryer. It is only when a husband or other male member of the family tries to explain it that it gets complicated.

title: Bacall Takes Your Breath Away
description: BECAUSE Applause, which has been lovingly and honorably adapted from Joseph Mankiewicz's dandy old screenplay, All About Eve, is a musical about show business, it is able to indulge itself in one small, homey conceit. Whenever Lauren Bacall and her bigtime pals go downtown, whipping to the Village in a blast of blinking green and red lights, to join the kids who wait on tables while waiting their hearts out for one good break, the joint tends to jump. There is dancing on the checkered tablecloths, and rollerskating in the aisles.

title: Special Edition Is Best Lakeland Terrier Second Year in Row at Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 4When Ch. Special Edition, the Lake land terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr., was named best of breed at the International Kennel Club show today, it was the second years in a row that the red grizzle and tan had accomplished the feat.

title: Marcia C. McNeary Wed to W. P. Barber
description: Miss Marcia Catherine Mc Neary, daughter of John J. McNeary, a partner of Car lisle, DeCoppet & Co., stock brokers, and Mrs. McNeary of Brooklyn, was mar ried yesterday morning to William Patrick Barber, son of William Eugene Barber of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Barber.

title: Best Seller List
description: GENERAL

title: Foiling Thieves
description: For the sophisticated thief preying on car owners, such marketable extras as radios and tape players are favorite targets. A new tape player, however, is less vulnerable to theft.

title: Sunbeam
Grass Growing Procedures
description: THE urge for outdoor action is never stronger in a gardener's pulse than after a long, dreary winter. Chances are that the first wisp of green grass will send him charging outdoorsrake, mower and fertilizer bag in hand.

title: Pepsi Testing A New Bottle
description: The PepsiCola Company, a division of PeppsiCo, Inc., has introduced a new plastic bottle in an indepth mar keting test in Las Vegas, Nev. It is the product of a twoyear development and research program, according to James B. Somerall, presi dent and chief executive of ficer.

title: VIETCONG TROOPS SEEN IN CAMBODIA
description: BAVET, Cambodia, April 3 Three Americans checking re ports of Vietcong presence around: this Cambodian border town halted their car here this afternoon to wait while about a dozen menidentified by vil lagers as Vietcongcrossed the road in single file 200 yards ahead.

title: Coins
description: TEN clubs will participate in the 15th annual Met ropolitan New. York Nu mismatic Convention, which will be held at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street, May 14 through May 17. The show, one of the most at tractive on the spring calen dar in the East, is open to the public and there is no admission charge.

title: Royals Cancel Exhibition
description: KANSAS CITY, April 4 (AP) The Kansas City Royals to day canceled tomorrow's ex hibition baseball game with the St. Louis Cardinals. A light rain that fell last night further complicated, efforts to dry out the Municipal Stadium field after it was covered with a heavy snow in midweeek.

title: Wall St. Opens Doors, But No Crowd Seen
description: A timehonored Wall Street tradition will topple Thurs day when Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., the broker age house, becomes the first publicly owned member of the New York Stock Ex change, opening the way for the exchange community to tap the public's vast capital resources for the first time.

title: Chang Cards 71 for 139 At Taiwan
description: LINKOU, Taiwan, April 4 (AP)Chang ChungFa, the host pro, posted a oneunder par 71 today and increased his lead in the $12,000 China open golf tournament.

title: SEATO ENDS TALKS; CALLS FOR FIRMNESS
description: MANILA, April 4The mili tary conference of the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization said in a statement at the end of two days of talks yesterday that the organization's effectiveness should be increased in the face of increasing Communist sub version, insurgency and open aggression in the treaty area.

title: A Place of Honor In Osaka: At Nome With MoriSan
description: IRRAISHAIMASU! (Welcome!), and the bowing begins. Mr. Mori will bend deeply, slid ing his palms down from his knees. My house Is an ugly place, but we honored to have you please stay.

title: Duffy Quoted as Being BodyCount Conscious
description: I know I was always con scious of how many body counts my platoon had. I kept a record on the wall of my room and had a record paint ed on the side of my APC (armored personnel carrier). I was always proud of the fact that my platoon had more kills than any other platoon in the company and that our company led the battalion in kills. hese were the words of First Lieut. James B. Duffy at a pretrial investigation of his case, according to an article in the current issue of Scanlan's magazine.

title: Arbitration Group Will Honor Walter Hill at Pierre Dinner
description: The American Arbitration Association will present its annual Sylvan Gotshal World Trade Arbitration Medal to Walter Hill at a dinner April 13 at the Pierre. Mr. Hill is Secretary General of the In ternational Chamber of Com merce in Paris.

title: INDIANS SEND ALVIS, SNYDER TO BREWERS
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 4 (AP) The Cleveland Indians traded Max Alvis, third baseman, and Russ Snyder, outfielder, to the Milwaukee Brewers today for Roy Foster and Frank Coggins, rookies, and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Builders Join to House Quintuplets
description: LIBERTY CORNERS, N. J., April 4  Dozens of builders, who ordinarily employ the men Who put up houses, pitched in today with hammers, saws and their own muscle to make sure the Kienast quintuplets have a new roof over their heath when they leave the hospital in the next few weeks.

title: Seoul Presses Program For New Port at Inchon
description: INCHON, South Korea The South Korean Govern ment is pressing ahead with a vast construction program here to create a permanent deepwater port, thus over coming the formidable dock ing problems caused by a 38 foot tidal fluctuation.

title: Teamsters in a Few Cities Stay Out Despite a General Return
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Truck drivers in a few cities remained off their jobs today despite a general return to work by thousands of other teamsters after tentative agree ment on a threeyear contract.

title: FRIDAY NIGHT BASEBALL
description: AT LOS ANGELES

title: Scorecard on Labor Trouble
description: In last week's strike catalogue, these were some of the big numbers:

title: Liberals Name Chairman Gubernatorial Candidate
description: The Liberal party's State Committee designated the Rev Donald S. Harrington yesterday as its unopposed candidate for Governor, but many committee members predicted that the party would switch its endorse ment to Arthur J. Goldberg within the next five weeks.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: QUOTATION OF THE DAY: I'm young so I'm feeling fine.Capt. Shinji Ishida, 47yearold commander of the Japan Air Lines plane hi jacked to North Korea, when asked how he was feeling as the plane was returning to Tokyo. [1:5.]

title: Sports of The Times
description: ANY forecaster who would have pre dicted a year ago that the New York Mets would not only win the National League pennant but also would end up as champions of the world would have been cashiered out of the lodge. He would have been accused of losing his marbles and would promptly have been clamped into a straitjacket before being carted off to the nearest loony bin. Crazy, man, crazy.

title: RELOCATION HELD COSTLY TO POOR
description: The city's emergency pro cedures to relocate families from dangerous housing take an average of two and a half months and cost poor tenants hundreds of dollars, according to an unpublished section of the Rand Corporation's report on housing conditions here.

title: South Vietnamese War Veterans Charge Neglect
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4Pham Van Dan, 29 years old, has been out of the South Vietnamese. Infantry Rangers for nearly five years, but he still wears his uniform and his eyes reddened slightly the other day when he was asked why.

title: Studded Tire Study
description: Minnesota is about to spend $50,000 to find out whether studded tires really help prevent winter driving accidents.

title: New Highways in Sicily Open Up Island's Interior
description: PALERMO, Sicily  Si cilian tourism, after re couping its 1968 earth quake losses last year, appears to to be heading for a record in 1970. The key to this development is found in the emphasis placed on air sea communications not only with the mainland, but also with charter flight coun tries in the north.

title: U.S. NOT PUSHING NEW MINE LAW
