description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Interior Department has dis closed that for at least the next six months it will not be able to enforce fully the strict new Federal law designed to reduce death and injury in the nation's coal mines. The delay in en forcement has already stirred Congressional criticism and brought a lawsuit accusing the department of nonfeasance.

title: BearsVikings in Benefit
description: CHICAGO, April 4 (UPI) The National Football League champion Minnesota Vikings will play the Chicago Bears in Soldier Field Sept. 11 in the 25th Armed Forces benefit game, the Bears annnounced today.

title: Saab
Mass Evangelism Called of No Relevancy to Blacks
description: The mass evangelism prac ticed by the Rev. Billy Graham, and other preachers never had and never will have any rele vancy to the black community, the Rev. George M. Perry said yesterday.

title: POLITICIANS' ADS ABOUND ALREADY
description: Several Democratic candidates for statewide office have be gun expensive advertising cam paigns on television, radio and in newspapers, although it is 12 weeks before the state primary and eight months before the general elections.

title: Roberta Bryan, Franklin Harty Plan Nuptials
description: FAIRFIELD, N.J., April 4 Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Truman Colley have made known the engagement of Mrs. Colley's daughter, Miss Roberta Cam eron Bryan, to Franklin Cox Harty. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank John Harty.

title: SIX CHILDREN DIE IN LOCKPORT FIRE
description: LOCKPORT, N. Y., April 4 (UPI)Six young childrenall cousinsdied early today when fire swept through a twostory house in the southside area of this city in western New York.

title: Lectures and Shows
description: THE 16th annual show of the Camellia Society of Potomac Valley will be staged April 11 and 12 at the Administration Build ing of the U.S. National Ar boretum, 24th and R Street NE, Washington, D.C. Hours opening day will be from 2:30 to 6 P.M. and from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. the following day. The classes will include horticul tural specimens, singly or in groups, and several divisions devoted to floral arrange ments featuring camellias. There will be no admission charge.

title: Aging Bullfighter Eyes Spring Training
description: The winter ends Tuesday for Antonio Ordoez. He flies black to Spain, to the farm paths and gymnasiums and squash courts, to the isolation that will prepare him to stay alive.

title: Car Stolen? Your Policy Probably Doesn't Cover Personal Aggravation
description: There are few experiences that produce the sinking feel ing in the pit of the stomach that hits a driver when he discovers that his car has been stolen.

title: Management Books
description: A series of six volumes covering various facets of business management, orig inally published by the Man agement Development Insti tute, will be distributed by the McGrawHill Book Com pany in cooperation with the original publisher. The insti tute, a subsidiary of Infor mation Industries, Inc., Wayne, Pa., prepared the books as selfstudy texts to be used in conjunction with management seminars. The books are planned on a new approach geared to maxi mum visual information and a minimum of text.

title: 39 States Fail to Comply With Federal Welfare Requirements
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The welfare systems of 39 (states failed to meet Federal standards completely, the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare disclosed this week.

title: Hardy Nuts To Grow In the Northeast
description: NUTS are one of the most pop ular, nutritious and expensive foods around. They are also one of the most effortless to grow, even in cold New England gardens.

title: SEGUE SAYS NORTH TRIED TO LAND SPIES
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April The Defense Ministry an nounced today that a North Korean boat sunk by South Korean' naval craft early this morning was apparently at tempting to land agents on the west coast.

title: 4 Newspapers and Electricians Resolve NonEconomic Issues
description: Negotiators for the city's four major newspapers and the electrical workers settled non economic issues at a meeting yesterday with Theodore W. Kheel, who is serving as media tor in the newspaper dispute.

title: Recent Winners Find Masters Crown Is No Bonanza
description: AUGUSTA, Ga. April 4 (UPI) How much will the winner of this week's prestigious Masters golf tournament reap from his victory?

title: The Nation
description: The labor scene came apart in a big way last week, with more turbulence in more key sectors than the country had experienced in any single period since 1946. A few of the worst trouble spots had been smoothed out by week's end, but the price of peace was extremely highso high that it threatened to give extra bounce to the upsurge in living costs that caused most of the strikes in the first place.

title: Miss Redpath Wed in Jersey To Brooke Cobb
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 4Miss Virginia Atherton Redpath and Brooke Adams Cobb were married here this afternoon in St. Luke's Epis copal Church by the Rev. George M: Bean of Lynch burg, Va., former sector of St. Luke's. The Rev. John C. Owens assisted.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: McMillian & Co.

title: NASSAK DIAMOND SET FOR AUCTION
description: A magnificent diamond with a colorful past will be on view at the ParkeBernet Galleries beginning Saturday. Its auction on April 16 is expected to equal the proceeds of several fine sales; gallery experts envision a figure of around $500,000.

title: Soviet Map Shows Border Claim
description: An official Soviet map just received here shows graphic ally how the Russians claim territory On the Chinese border beyond the main channel of boundary rivers separating the two countries.

title: Podgorny, Ailing, Cancels Visit to Japan's Expo '70
description: MOSCOW, April 4President Nikolai V. Podgorny has can celed a visit to Japan scheduled for the first half of this month because he has a cold, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said tonight.

title: Randie Waldbaum to Wed Sept. 1
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., April 4  Miss Randie Waldbadm, whose father, Ira Waldbaum, is president of Waldbaum, Inc., the supermarket chain, plans to be married to Aaron Malinsky. The wedding will take place Sept. 1 at the Sephardic Temple in Cedar hurst.

title: U.S., Philippines Sign Trade Pact
description: MANILA, March 28 (UPI) The Philippines and the United States have signed an agreement for the sale of $10million worth of cotton and tobacco to the Philip pines.

title: MARTHA M'DOWELL
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 4 Miss Martha McDowell, the manager of the Sarah Lawrence College bookstore, died of a heart attack at Lawrence Hos pital yesterday. She was 59 years old.

title: Melinda M. Hall Bride Of John McC. Eaton
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., April 4  The Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here was the scene this afternoon of the wedding of Miss Me linda Morgan Hall and John McCurdy Eaton. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger.

title: North Sea Oil Wells
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 4 (UPI)The Phillips Petroleum Company reports discovery wells drilled so far in the Norwegian section of the North Sea indicate the presence of several petrole um fields in the area.

title: The Passing of the British Working Class
description: LONDON

title: Soviet Black Sea Resort of Sochi Is Preparing for the 1970 Season
description: SOCHI, U.S.S.R. March 25 On the dock at this resort which stretches along the Black Sea with its back to the snow peaked Caucasus, men and boys fished for herring that seemed to have gone elsewhere to eat.

title: 5 Children Killed by Mortar
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 4 (AP)Five children, ranging in age from 3 to 14 years, were killed today when a mortar round with which they were playing exploded in the back yard of a home south of here.

title: Stanford Crew Triumphs
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., April 4 (UPI)Stanford swept St. Mary's today in its first crew competitions of the year. The Stanford varsity shell covered the 1,800meter course in Redwood City Harbor in 6:14.5 to win by six lengths. St. Marv's was timed in 6:42.5.

title: Ellington Named Head Coach
description: PHILIPPI, W. Va., April 4 (UPI)AldersonBroaddus Col lege signed Jerald M. Ellington, assistant coach at CarsonNew man College, as its head bas ketball coach today.

title: Job Changes:
description: In a reorganization of top executives, Dean B. Seifried has been elected as president of Orange and Rockland Util ities, Inc., and also president of the Pike County Light and Power Company. He succeeds Richard D. Wilhite, who con tinues as a director. The elec tion is subject to Federal Power Commission approval.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  For years there have been hints from the Supreme Court that even the guardians of the First Amend ment are not immune to a natu ral law of dissentthat one's toleration of noisy protest tends to be in inverse ratio to one's distance from it.

title: Guide to London's Mazes
description: As a oneway city, London is virtually impenetrable to the stranger. Ways, mews, streets and places run hig gledypiggledy and squares go clockwise with no visible way out.

title: Advertising:
description: It would seem almost as if Robert F. DeLay was pre destined to become president of the Direct Mail Advertis ing Association. His father, for example, contributed the necessary background by first running a general mer chandise store, then becom ing a postmaster and then endowed the son with just the proper initials and sur name to suggest the mails.

title: They Drive Your Car For a Price
description: An executive of a large corporation telephoned the AAACon Auto Transport of fices recently to arrange to have his car driven to San Francisco.

title: The place is Italy, mainly Naples, drawn so perfectly that it seems to breathe
description: If ever a more serene age comes to our society, those who look back will probably find much of the favorite writing in the 1960's and 1970's ludi crous and grotesque. Just as the great failing of the late Victorians was sentimentality, ours is likely to be defined as a weakness for a kind of Grand Guignol melodrama. The ex act discussion of character and per sonality disappears, to be replaced by the figures of melodrama, literary de vices ridden by anger, lust, ambition, hatred, mockery, or absurdist aliena tion. Even sex, which was real to Joyce or D. H. Lawrence, is becoming so melodramatized in fiction that it no longer represents any recognizable human relationship. Good novels that simply deal with living are hard to write and hard to find.

title: Author's Query
description: I have written a book about the Garden of Allah, the hotel where the famed writers of the '30's and '40's lived during their assignments in Hollywood. I am in urgent need of and would be grateful for any photographs or snapshots taken in the Garden during this period.

title: Focus of Battle on Noise Is Quietly Shifting
description: A FEW years ago when East Side landlords were offering attractive concessions to lure people into their newly built high rise apartment, buildings, a common reason for rejection by a prospective tenant was that he could hear his neigh bor's plumbing, his snoring, his violin playing and even his confrontations with his wife.

title: Moger Monger Pays $45.80 As Suffolk Downs Opens
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP)Mo ger Monger won the $15,000 Homecoming Handicap today as Suffolk Downs opened its 90 day racing season.

title: Democrats Name McNair
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina has been ap pointed a vice chairman of the Democratic National Commit tee. Lawrence F. O'Brien, the National Chairman, said today that Mr. McNair, 46 years old, replaced former Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey.

title: Philatelic Museum Leaves Its Stamp on NonCollectors
description: WESTON, Mass.  The Cardinal Spellman Philatelic Museum here is vivid evidence that an imagina tively displayed stamp collection can be memorable even for noncollectors. It is like a miniature picture gallery in that it illustrates a nation's arts and literature, commemorates its scientific and industrial advances and honors its great historical figures and events.

title: Unveiling a 1970 model The Lunar Rover (Max. speed, 10 m.p.h.)
description: SOMETIME in late 1971, when it is early morning in the Marius Hills region near the moon's equator and the sun casts long shadows on the rough terrain, an American astronaut is scheduled to back out of his lunar module and down the LM's ladder. Midway, he will pause, as previous Apollo astro nauts havebut this time he will pull four Dshaped rings mounted on the LM's side. Much like a magician materializing live rabbits and long scarves from a top hat, the astronaut will perform an unusual trick of his own: From a 6by4foot stowage space, about the size of a baby's playpen, he will produce a four wheeled, electricpowered vehicle capable of carrying himself and a second astronaut, their packs, their equipment and their expected rock haul a distance of 75 miles around their base camp.

title: OIL LEASE CALLED EVERGLADES PERIL
description: MIAMI, Fla., April 4The University of Miami, which ad ministers millions of dollars for the study and protection of the Florida Everglades and sur rounding waters, has become embroiled in a controversy over its role in granting oil drilling rights on universityowned land in the heart of the Everglades.

title: First Aquanaut Team Enters Undersea Laboratory as 7Month Test Begins
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., April 4Four scientists and an engineer, the first aquanaut team of Tektite 2, swam down today to occupy an underwater laboratory here and begin an ambitious sevenmonth study of marine life.

title: Evans, 400Meter Olympian, Signs Pro Track Contract
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4 (AP) Lee Evans, the world 400 meter recordholder and Olym pic gold medal winner, has signed a professional track con tract, Al Schallau, the president Pf World Sports Promotions, Inc., announced today.

title: DI BIASI WINS TITLE IN PLATFORM DIVING
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 4 (UPI)Klaus DiBiasi of Italy, the 1968 Olympic cham pion, won the men's 10meter platform competition today at the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving champion ships.

title: Cougar
Paris Meeting Eases Strain In CanadianFrench Relations
description: PARIS April 4 Some of the strain has been taken out of relations between France and Canada by a fourhour meeting yesterday between the French Foreign Minister Maur ice Schumann, and the Cana dian Secretary for External Affairs, Mitchell Sharp.

title: Dr. King's Father Leads Silent Prayer at Rights Leader's Grave
description: ATLANTA, April 4 (AP)The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. led a silent prayer today at the grave of his son, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., on the second anniversary of the civil rights leader's assassination.

title: 1968 Backers of McCarthy, Dormant Elsewhere, Run Strong Drive in Senatorial Race in Connecticut
description: HARTFORDThe McCarthy movement of 1968 is flounder ing in most states, but it is alive and well in Connecticut.

title: Vacation Car Rentals Better Deal Than Ever
description: For the motoring public that uses rental cars, whether on business or vacation, the now look of the rental in dustry spells vastly increased service at interesting bargain prices.

title: STARS SCORE, 10, ELIMINATE FLYERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI)Barry Gibbs slammed in an 80foot shot in the third pe riod today that gave the Minne sota North Stars a 10 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

title: CITY PLANS CENTER FOR INFORMATION
description: Making the procedures of city government here more visible to the public will be one of the tasks facing Milton Mu sicus when he is sworn in to morrow as administrator of the Municipal Service Administra tion.

title: Tips on Averting Car Thefts
description: Women, more than men, are vulnerable to auto thefts as much through the things they forget to do as through any other single factor.

title: Mills Brothers Spark Texas A. and M. Quartets to Victories in Mile and 440
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 (AP) Texas A. and M.'s Mills broth ers, Curtis and Marvin, sparked the sprint teams to a Texas Re lays record today and the Aggies dosed the 43d annual meet with an impressive victory in the mile.

title: Hijacker Found Mentally Ill
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 (AP)Christian Belon, the 26 yearold Frenchman who hi jacked a Trans World Airlines jet to Beirut in January, is mentally irresponsible, a group of psychiatrists reported today i?? shrdlu

title: Tonys? Oscars? What About Toscars?
description: TONYS and Oscars are again being handed out, amid the usual pomp and circumstance. But, as always, many of the sea son's worthy theatrical deeds have gone unrewarded. Here with our annual consolation prizea Toscarto some un sung heroes of stage and screen whose recent achieve ments merit recognition.

title: House Needs A Spring Checkup
description: BECAUSE winter sub jects a house to its hardest wear and be cause prompt atten tion to minor repairs will often ward off expensive, largescale breakdowns later on, smart homeowners know that at this time of year it is important that the house be given a spring tuneup in other words, critical points should be checked to see what repairs, if any, are needed in the aftermath of winter's storms.

title: How to Exercise Your Auto Options
description: Bemused, over the mass proliferation of auto options, accessories and extras, a group of math students re cently figured out how many cars of one make and model could be produced so no two were identical.

title: HOSTETTER ENDING HIS S.L.A. CAREER
description: Donald S. Hostetter, who re tired seven years ago from the Federal Bureau of Investigation after nearly 30 years of hunt ing down bank robbers, kid nappers and other criminals, will resign Friday as chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

title: John Gates Weds Miss Stephenson
description: GREENVILLE, Del., April 4  Miss Susan White Steph enson and John Davis Gates were married here today at Meadowlark Hill, home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wil son Stephenson, parents of the bride. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gates of New York, is business editor of The Wil mington Morning News and Evening Journal. His father is vice president, develop ment, of Pan American World Airways, Inc. Mr. Stephenson is director of public relations for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.

title: Architecture
description: HOW do others see us? That question has been fascinating Americans since de Tocqueville and Mrs. Trollope assessed our democracy and manners. Tell us about our selves, even if it's terrible, we beg our visitors from over seas. And they do. Often with a clarity and objectivity that make lengthy foundation re search projects, Congression al hearings and special task force reports seem strained and murky.

title: Opel
3 Tracks in Florida May Lose Licenses Over Election Funds
description: MIAMI, April 4 (AP)State Attorney Richard Gerstein called today for revocation of horse racing permits for Trop ical Park, Hialeah and Gulf stream tracks for alleged viola tion by their owners of Florida election laws governing polit ical campaign contributions.

title: Roadside Play
description: Interstate highways are actually a boon to sports minded youths in crowded cities, according to the the Fed eral Highway Administration.

title: Miss Gainers Fiancee Of Burton Mark Gold
description: Providence, R. L. April 4 Mr. and Mrs. David H. Gaines have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nancy Ann Gaines, to Burton Mark Gold, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham T. Gold of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: In This Issue
description: GENERAL

title: Dallas Uses Computer as a Traffic Policeman
description: DALLAS  Brains, elec tronics and sensors imbedded in concrete are being applied to a prime problem in this growing Southern metropoli tan area. It is the same prob lem other cities have traffic.

title: New Publication Will Document Changes Catholic Church Faces
description: A documentary service start ed eight years ago in Rome to keep the Dutch press and cler gy abreast ofand often sev eral steps ahead ofdevelop ments during the early days of Vatican Council II, unveiled last week the first issue of its North American edition.

title: Young People Get a Voice
description: KING'S MOUNTAIN, N. C. (AP)  Twelve young men and women, from 15 to 23 years of, age, have been named by the city commissioners to sit with adults on city committees and governing boards. They will be active members, but will have no vote.

title: Move to Establish Fire Resistance Standards for Carpeting Opposed by Majority in Federal Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) A move to establish firere sistant standards for carpeting has encountered opposition from a majority of members of a government advisory com mittee.

title: Jaguar
MICHIGAN IS VICTOR IN TITLE GYMNASTICS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI)Michigan rode a ster ling horizontal bar routine by the final performer in the meet today to win the team title by onetenth of a point in the National Collegiate gymnastics championships.

title: It Happened in Monterey (Calif.) ...
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Jan Gard ner's delicate, beringed hand draws a wide arc in the air. It's 1830, she says. I see sun shine on the plaza, music, color, white surf on the beach, sea gulls flashing in the sun, boys in sombreros and girls in flounces rolling hoops and playing tag, proud mamas promenading, horses and carriages waiting at the curb. I see scenes of old Monterey. This vision of Mrs. Kenneth Gardner, a member of the Monterey Art and His tory Association, will come to life on April 25, the date of the Adobe House Tour, of which she is chairman. Since this is the year of Monterey's 200th an niversary the annual tour of early adobe homes, until now a rather sedate affair for garden club women and local historians, is about to turn into a swing ing historical happening.

title: Aluminum Prices: Kaiser Sees Gains
description: Even while prices were be ting raised last week for pri nary copper and important categories of steel products, the most striking develop ment in metal pricing might have been the mere words of the head of one of the big aluminum companies.

title: Florence Meyer Wed to Kent Brittan
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 4  Miss Florence Roome Meyer and Kent Lan don Brittan, both of whom served in the Peace Corps, were married here this after noon. She served in Majuro, Micronesia, and he was a volunteer in Lima, Peru.

title: Samuel Carmalt Weds Miss Platt, Debutante of '63
description: Miss Susan Platt, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Ruther ford Platt of New York and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., was married here yes terday afternoon to Samuel Woolsey Carmalt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wool sey Carmalt of Hastingson Hudson and Friendsville, N. Y.

title: U.S. Business:
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 4  Neighboring private power systems and the Ten nessee Valley Authority are strengthening their links to protect the reliability of service and for system econ omy.

title: 2 Ministers Are Named Vice Presidents of Iraq
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April (UPI)Iraq's President, Ahmed Hassan AlBakr, appointed two vice presidents, the Baghdad radio said yesterday.The radio, monitored here, said the Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Hardan Takriti, and the Interior Minister, Lieut. Gen. Saleh Mahdi Amash, had been named Vice Presidents.

title: Phasing Out Is Started at Floyd Bennett
description: The phasing out of Floyd Bennett Field as a military installation began yesterday as 1,500 Naval Air Reservists stood at attention in a han ger for the field's final for mal inspection.

title: GOB
Conservationists and City dwellers Set Up Roadblocks to the Interstate System
description: If you hate red lights and suffer from insomnia but have the stamina of Hercules and a est for endurance runs, go West, young manfrom Phil adelphia to North Platte, Neb.

title: YALE CAPTURES TRIANGULAR MEET
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Yale's track and field team set three meet records, took eight first places and scored in every event except the two Imile run today and captured triangular meet from Rutgers and St. John's. The Elis had 89 points to 58 for Rutgers and 45 for the Redmen.

title: International Rules to Govern New Brunswick Driving Show
description: WTHEN it was introduced to a largely befuddled pub lic in 1968, it was named the Johnson Park Driving Show. This year, it is the John son Park International Driv ing Show, the first such event in the United States under the newly adopted in ternational rules for driving competition.

title: Princeton varsity Crew Wins Logg Cup
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 The varsity and junior varsity crews from Princeton rowed away from Rutgers today in the opening regatta for both on the schedule of the Eastern Asso ciation of Rowing Colleges. The margins of victory were about four lengths in each case as the Tiger eights won their races right at the start of the 2,000meter course on Lake Car negie.

title: Bank Groups in Maine Seek Pollution Code
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 4 The executive committees of three statewide banking asso ciations have approved a Bankers Pollution Code, a voluntary proposal calling on banks to consider environ mental factors when deciding whether to lend money to in dustry.

title: All About Tasty Tomatoes
description: TOMATOES have come a long way since 1830, when they were thought to be poisonous in this country. That year, Robert Gib son Johnson dared to eat a tomato be fore a crowd of spectators at New Jersey's Salem Courthouse. Wagers were made that he would not live un til morning. Johnson, of course sur vived, but a popular magazine was ad vising its readers thirty years later that tomatoes should be cooked for at least three hours. Today, no one be lieves that the fruit is poisonous, but sometimes the commercial tomato, which is harvested green and packed in cellophaned boxes, tastes as if it were.

title: Israel Reports Some Shelling On Syria and Jordan Lines
description: TEL AVIV, April 4 (AP) The Israeli command reported sporadic firing today along Is rael's borders with Syria and Jordan. The exchange with Syria was in the Golan heights, where Syria and Israel Thurs day fought their biggest land and air battles since the 1967 Middle East war.

title: Stratford Season Opens With Staging Of a Dark Comedy
description: STRATFORDONAVON, Eng land, April 2  The Royal Shakespeare Company has done much of its best Stratford work by focusing on clusters of re lated plays, and appropriately its 10th anniversary season opens with the completion of such a series. This is John Bar ton's production of Measure for Measure, which concluded his cycle of the dark comedies.

title: Zambia Seeks to Attract A New Species of Tourist
description: LUSAKA, ZambiaAlthough this copper rich African nation between Tan zania and Rhodesia is potentially fertile soil for tourism, the number of holidayers visiting Zambia since is became independent of Britain in 1964 has fallen sharply. Valiant efforts by its tourist of ficials to attract more visitors have met with only limited success.

title: Ignition Reserve
description: If your car misfires when you accelerate and shows other signs of an illness, the problem could be lack of what engineers call ignition reserve.

title: A Father Stops Smoking
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., April 4 (AP)For two days, 14year old Sheree Bryan refused to eat as a means of forcing her father to quit smoking. After watching his daughter lose eight pounds, James Bryan, 47 years old, declared himself a former smoker.

title: Driver Education Using Specialists
description: When the Passaic, N. J., Board of Education voted for reasons of economy to drop a driver education course, the action was sup posed to save $8,000 an nually. But it ran counter to a trend across the nation to expand this type of course by merging training and teaching.

title: Counter And Amex Gain a Bit
description: Prices ended slightly higher in slow trading last week on the overthecounter market and on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Milwaukee Rated High
description: Lew Alcindor, Bob Dandridge and Greg Smith, the 1968 draft sleepers; Flynn Robinson's out side shooting and more and more Alcindor.

title: Plymouth
Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Remke and Weber Capture 6th Spot in A.B.C. Doubles
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 4 (UPI)  Jack Remke and Ron Weber of Cincinnati rolled a 1,289 today to earn sixth place in regular doubles in the Amer ican Bowling Congress tourna ment. Remke had a 601 and Weber a 688. Charles Gregory and Bob Bensch of Toledo. Ohio, hold the doubles lead at 1,354.

title: Alewife Warning Issued
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Interior Department warned this week that some areas of Lake Michigan might experience large dieoffs of ale wivesbut not as serious as in 1967, when millions of dead fish washed up on beaches. The alewife is a small fish that serves as food for larger fish and is caught commercially for fish meal and pet food:

title: N.Y.Y.C. to CoSponsor Ocean Races
description: A transAtlantic race to Spain in 1972 and another to England in 1975 were made public last week by the New York Yacht Club, which will have a hand in sponsoring both. The starting dates remain to be selected, but the event to Spain will begin from Bermuda after the NewportBermuda race and the one to England from Newport.

title: Kate, Vanessa and Irene, Too
description: THE Trojan Women contains three spien?? roles for actresses, And Mi chael Cacoyannis, director of Zorba the Greek is over joyed to report that he has engaged three splendid stars to fill the roles in his film version of the Euripides drama: Katharine Hepburn as Hecuba, Vanessa Redgrave as Andromache and Irene Papas as Helen of Troy.

title: COAST STAKE ENDS IN A DEAD HEAT
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 4 Quicken Tree and Fiddle Isle, two stout Americanbreds, raced to a thrilling deadheat triumph over an international field today in the $125,000. San Juan Capistrano invitation han dicap on the Santa Anita Park turf course.

title: Wigs Start Blaze
description: CLAREMONT, N. H., April 4 (UPI)A fire that devastated an entire downtown block was apparently started by wigs being dried at a beauty school, the authorities here reported. Six businesses were destroyed Wednesday, the blaze roared through the block which officials termed a total loss.

title: 7 HURT, 11 SEIZED IN PANTHER MARCH
description: A rally and march by several thousand supporters of the Black Panthers led yesterday to a series of traffic jams and scuffles with the police in Long Island City and Times Square.

title: Mrs. Mason Wed To R. D. Leonard
description: Mrs. Anna Barr Mason was married yesterdy to the Rev. Richard Davis Leonard, who is director of development at the Walden School and minister of the Flatbush Unitarian Univer salist Church in Brooklyn. The ceremony in the Chapel of Peace at the Community Church of New York was per formed by the Rev. Dr. Jack Mendelsohn of the First Uni tarian Church of Chicago.

title: Catherine Blaffer Bride of Lawyer
description: HOUSTON, April 4  Miss Catherine Hepburn Blaffer, granddaughter of the late Robert Lee Blaffer, a founder of the Humble Oil Company, and greatgrand daughter of the late W. T. Campbell, a founder of the Texas Company, was mar ried here at noon today to Nicholas Cowenhoven Tay lor, a lawyer with the New York firm of Shearman & Sterling.

title: Road Signs Still Confusing
description: The state's $14million pro gram to replace misleading and unsafe directional signs on New York City's highways appears to have lost its way.

title: Home Cooking Adds Spice To a Scottish Auto Tour
description: GLASGOWFor several weeks last summer, I traveled by car in the Scottish Highlands. The grass was greener than I had imagined, the people more pleasant than I had been told, the scenery simply devastat ing and, wonder of wonders, the weather was glorious.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Shopping for Credit Can Lower Cost of a New Car
description: Consumers buying new or used cars are finding that inflation has once again made it more costly to fi nance their purchases. But they can take consolation in the fact that car loans still are widely available, while other loan sources have dried up.

title: Census Shields Wife's Age
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 (UPI)When the United States Census Bureau says its infor mation is secret it means it. A census official here reported having received a telephone call this week from a man who asked if his census form could be returned. Asked why, he said his wife had filled out her portion of the form and mailed it without his seeing it. The census official told him he could not see the form since it was confidential. He remarked: Well, I just wanted to find out how old my wife really is.

title: Edith Smart, Student, Fiancee Of Eugene Maxwell Moore 3d
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 4 The engagement of Miss Edith Minturn Smart, a fresh man at Wells College, to Eugene Maxwell Moore 3d, who is a junior at Yale, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. S. Bruce Smart Jr., par ents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Moore.

title: DOMINICAN BISHOPS URGE PEACE TALKS
description: SANTO DOMINGO, April 4 The Dominican Republic's six Roman Catholic bishops ap pealed today for peace talks between President Joaquin Ba laguer and Opposition party leaders as three more persons died in acts of political vio lence.

title: PALESTINIAN TIES GROWING ABROAD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 The voyage last week of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, to Pe king and Hanoi is part of the commando movement's grow ing role in international of fairs.

title: Italian Communists Divided by Dispute Over BirdNetting
description: ROME, April 4 Italy's pow erful Communist party, which prefers public unity and issues of resounding importance, is openly split over the question of the netting of migratory birds.

title: Going to Watch a Race? Here's How
description: On a sunny summer after noon at Bridgehampton, the sports cars seem to rise out of the waters of Peconic Bay as they thread their way through the sand dunes of the famous Long Island race course.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: POLICE AND C.L U. GIVE PROTEST TIPS
description: Two views of a demonstra tionthe policeman's and the demonstrator's  can be pieced together from two recently issued pamphlets, one drawn uF by the New York City Police Department listing laws under which arrests may be made, the other, by the New York Civil Liberties Union, on how not to get arrested.

title: Y Symphonic Group Plans Spring Concert on April 19
description: The annual spring concert by the Symphonic Workshop of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association will be presented on April 19 at 3 P. M. at Kaufmann Con cert Hall, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street. Maurice Levine will conduct.

title: Jazz at Cocktail Time
description: Jazz for cocktails will be in augurated at the Grill Room of the Roosevelt Hotel on Mon day with music provided by the World's Greatest Jazz Band and the Bobby Hackett Quintet. Both groups play in the Grill later in the evening, Monday through Saturday. The cocktail jazz will begin at 5 P. M. and continue until 7:30, Monday through Saturday.

title: The Mini and the Maxi Tests of Ingenuity
CHASE BUILDS UP HEALTH SERVICES
description: Gordon Chase, the new chief of the city's Health Services Administration, is quietly re cruiting a cadre of youthful ex ecutives with impressive cre dentials.

title: What to Do When The Judge Is Put Up Against the Wall
description: IN 1944, the United States Govern ment tried 30 American Nazis and Fascists for undermining the mo rale of our armed forces then at war. Among the defendants were Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, Fritz Kuhn's succes sor as head of the GermanAmerican Bund; Elizabeth Dilling, who had attended Hitler's giant 1938 Nurem berg rally; George Sylvester Viereck, a German agent; William Dudley Pelley, head of the Silver Shirts move ment; Joseph E. McWilliams, head of the Christian Mobilizers; Lawrence Dennis, selfstyled Nazi, who insisted on defending himself, and others. They had published leaflets hailing Hitler as a savior, and denouncing President Roosevelt as a Jew and warmonger. This printed material was being disseminated among American troops by devious means.

title: Patriots Pick Site In Foxboro, Mass., For New Stadium
description: BOSTON, April 4The Bos ton Patriots selected Foxboro, Mass., today as the site of a new 57,000seat stadium, thus preserving the professional football team's home in New England.

title: Coal Mine Blast Kills 26 In Moravian Industrial Area
description: PRAGUE, April 4 (Reuters)  Twentysix miners were killed and three others were missing today after a gas ex plosion ripped through a coal mine in the Ostrava industrial area of Moravia early this morning.

title: Who's Who in Capital's Farm Power Infrastructure
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Farm legislation is shaped and funded in Congress by a small group of powerful men who show great dedication to the causes of the American com mercial farmer and display some fear that social programs may use up money that they feel is needed to maintain a healthy agriculture.

title: Baseball to Start Second Century
description: Professional baseball will open its sec ond century tomorrow and will movefor a few moments, at leastfrom the court room, tax office and grandjury chamber back onto the ball fields of America.

title: Recordings
description: WHEN Ornette Cole man arrived in New York ten years ago playing the unusual music that agitated the jazz world then to its greatest ver bal battles since the bebop vs moldy fygges forays in the forties, there was one thing about Coleman's quartet on which both the pro and con Colemanites could agree: He had a rare and exciting bas sist in Charlie Haden. Haden, who was 22 and quite un known in New York or, for that matter, anywhere except San Francisco, proved to be the balance wheel in Cole man's quartet, a bassist whose virtuosity was appar ent both in the skill with which he supported the com plexities of Coleman's music and in his own often dazzling solos.

title: Oldsmobile
You Can Fly to the Coast For $142 But It Costs $255 to LisbonWhy?
description: SAUL LESSER, a Manhattan lawyer, returned from a visit to his travel agent puzzled and irritated. In late June, he's flying from New York to Lisbon, and he wonders why he must pay $255 for a oneway ticket.

title: City Police Lab Makes Living Harder for CriminalsThrough Chemistry
description: The Police Department's crime laboratory, a busy place of whitesmocked chemists and sophisticated equipment that would make Sherlock Holmes quiver with soy, is working around the clock these days in a scientific war on criminals.

title: EXHIBITIONS
description: WITKIN GALLERYNew Realism: Four San Francisco Photographers, 237 E. 60th Stret. Tuesday through Saturday, 12:30 to 6; Thursday to 8; Sunday, 2 to 5. Through April 30.

title: California Places Second In Vacation Survey
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Running a close second Florida as the ideal vacation spot is California. Of 2,025 people interviewed by the Opinion Research Corporation, 30 per cent favor Florida and 29 per cent prefer Califor nia. In third place is Hawaii, the choice of 21 per cent.

title: Hijacked Airliner Returns To Tokyo With 4 Aboard
description: TOKYO, Sunday, April 5 Yodo, the Japan Air Line jet that was hijacked to North Ko ma, came home this morning. The Boeing 727 stopped at Gate at Haneda Airport here at 9:39 A.M., 121 hours, and 34 minutes after it had been hi jacked by nine leftist students on a routine flight from here to Fukuoka.

title: Atlantic Avenue Renewal Stirs Dispute in Brooklyn
description: An obscure bill for the re habilitation of Atlantic Avenue that went through the State Senate last week with barely a ripple had residents and legis lators from Brooklyn Heights and surrounding communities on the battlements yesterday.

title: Negro Business Aid Group Backs Carswell Nomination
description: WASHINGON, April 4An organization called N.E.G.R.O. has taken a fullpage advertise ment in tomorrow's edition of The New York Times to en dorse the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Su preme Court.

title: Alison Blair Taylor Is Bride Of Robert S. Fastov, Lawyer
description: DALLAS April 4  Miss Alison Blair Taylor, daugh ter of William Allen (Ted) Taylor, retired president of E. F. Hutton & Co., stock brokers, and Mrs. Baker Tay lor, was married this morn ing to Robert S. Fastov of Washington, a lawyer with the. Office of the Chief Coun sel of the Economic Devel opment Administration.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: April 10Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey T.S.D. rally: start at Bowlero, junction of Routes 3 and 46, Clifton, N. J. Registration: 7:30 P.M., first car off 8:01. Information: Betsy Am licke, phone (201)4713917.

title: Marilyn R. Torrisi Becomes Engaged
description: SCAARSDALE, N.Y., April Mr. and Mrs. John Vincent Torrisi have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Rose Torrisi to Barry Mark Krengel, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Krengel of New York. The wedding will take. place Aug. 1.

title: Greece: Studies in Courage
description: Greek democrats continue to fight back against the spreading tyranny of the ruling army junta with a stubborn courage that leaves free men everywhere heavily in their debt. Ten of 34 distinguished Athenians on trial for sedition by a military court have now repudiated earlier confessions, saying these were extracted by brutality and torture.

title: A Survival Kit for Crises on the Road
description: A good survival kit packed with a few inexpen sive items can help a motor ist out of a jam on a de serted stretch of road.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Easter business around the country was spotty but de partment stores managed to pull their sales up to a re spectable figure and went ahead of the 1969 week by 11 per cent. So far this year, the stores selling apparel and general merchandise are keeping their heads above water, but their gains are more modest than in 1969.

title: Trout for the Masses in New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New ZealandOn a crys talclear North Island crater lake not long ago, I watched a 6year old girl subdue a lordly fivepound rainbow trout with the help of her father. An Australian grandmother who had never fished before caught the daily limit of eight trout, with the help of a guide, and an American visitor, here for a fort night, netted a total of 100 fish averaging more than four pounds each.

title: Prabavathy Arthur, Engineer, Is Bride of Takayuki Kawaii
description: Miss Prabavathy Arthur, an electronics engineer with the Burroughs Corporation in Piscataway N. J., was married in the Riverside Church here yesterday to Takayuki Kawaii, who is treasurer of the N.S.K. Cor poration in Newark, a wholly owned subsidiary of Nippon Seiko, bearings manufactur ers in Tokyo.

title: D. F. Mackler Fiance Of Carol L. Groman
description: Deputy Inspector Louis Groman of the New York City Police Department and Mrs. Groman of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter Miss Carol Lynn Gro man, to Donald Franklin Mackler, a student at the Georgetown University Med ical Sohool. He is the son of Dr. Harry Mackler, a den tal surgeon, and Mrs. Mack ler of Westbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for Dec. 24.

title: Young People Gaining Increasing Role as Government Advisers as Officials Seek to Blunt Protests
description: Young people in their teens and early twenties are gaining an increasing role as advisers close to the seats of govern mental power in cities and states across the nation.

title: 131 Shot Takes Gotham, With Delaware Chief 2d
description: With his jockey, Angel Cor dero, making expert use of the knowledge of the track that he had gained through two earlier victories on the program, the Happy Valley Farm's Native Royalty won the $58,100 Goth am at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THE widely accepted scenario for the nation's econ omy this year seems to be unfolding without much surprise at the start of the second quarter.

title: Mets' Cars Match Their Lofty Status
description: So you're wondering wheth er the New York Mets went from ninthplace cars to first place cars in one season? Whether it's true that singles hitters drive compacts while homerun hitters drive Cadil lacs? Whether the Mets are as amazing on wheels this year as they were on their feet last year?

title: Cathedral Carvings Gilded
description: YORK, England (AP) More than 100 15th century oak carv ings in the ceiling of York Min ister's central tower are being illuminated with gold bordering on a red background so as to be more clearly visible.

title: WESLEYAN EIGHT VICTOR IN BRONX
description: An eightoared varsity crew, which had to do its training on a snowbanked Connecticut River course because of unsea sonably cold weather, warmed to its task quickly yesterday to defeat three rivals on the Or chard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

title: Office Construction Is Transforming the West 30's
description: A longneglected part of midtown Manhattan that lies along the Hudson River between Chelsea and Hell's Kitchen, now dominated by freight yards, factories, garages and warehouses, shows signs of transition into a new center of commercial office construction.

title: Chess
description: BEGINNING with the forthcoming interzonal tournament in Spain this year, the veteran grandmas ter, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, New York, 59 and a seventime United States chess champion, will take a longshot try at the world title once again.

title: Federal Courts to Get Magistrates
description: United States Commissioner Earle N. Bishopp holds what is probably one of the least known posts in the Federal Government. Soon, he will not even hold that, because the 730 commissioners are to be re placed by equivalent magis trates in the Federal courts.

title: Air Force Denies Request For Isolation Pay in Maine
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Air Force has made it clear that there is no such thing as isolation pay for serving at a base in Maine.

title: Busing Is Opposed By 8to1 Margin, Gallup Poll Finds
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 By nearly 8 to 1, people ques tioned by the Gallup Poll said they would oppose the busing of Negro and white children to achieve racial balance in schools, the Gallup organization reported today.

title: A Fun Car's Road Is Paved With Sand, Snow ... or Water
description: THEY bounce, they jiggle, they shake. They come in all sizes. They're lots of fun and some even have redeeming social value.

title: Letters
description: LIFE. LIB AND THE PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS

title: Marcis Sets 2dDay Pace In Southeastern 500 Trials
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., April 4 (AP) Dave Marcis of West Salem, Wis., headed the second day qualifying today at Bristol In ternational Speedway for to morrow's Southeastern 500 stock car race. His time in a Dodge was 104.376 miles an hour.

title: Skiers Join Summer Trek Into Iceland's Interior
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  The Kerlin garfjokull ski center, where the snow never melts and where the long daylight makes it possible to ski most of the night, was discovered by Americans just last summer and they are expected to return there in greater num bers this July and August. This glacier area of Iceland's uninhabited central highlands is accessible only in midsummer because the road to it is blotted out by snow during the rest of the year.

title: Army Engineers Join in Battle Against Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  The issue of the environment apparently has caught up with the Army Corps of Engineers. And the corps seems to be mak ing a strong effort to catch up with the issue.

title: Strikers Raise Boss's Salary
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., April 3 (UPI)Striking employes of the Sprague Electric Company took up a collection this week for the company's president, Robert Sprague. They said they felt sorry for him because he took a cut in salary from $80, 000 to $70,000 in the last year. The employes collected $40.

title: PHOENIX HANDICAP GOES TO PADEROSO
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 4 (AP)Fred W. Hooper's Pader oso won the $24,050 Phoenix Handicap today as half a dozen Kentucky Derby eligibles stretched their legs in minor preps on Keeneland's opening day.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayGreater New York Bishon Frise Fanciers fun match, American Legion Hall, Marvin Avenue and Greenwich Street, Hempstead, L. I.; entries noon; judging 1:30.

title: National Survey Finds Alcoholism More Widespread Than Estimated
description: There may be as many as nine million adult Americans who are alcoholics, with many, millions more on the verge of having a serious drinking prob lem, according to a recent sur vey by researchers at George, Washington University.

title: For the Animal That Travels  A Motel at JFK
description: THE sign on the cage read: MAY BE TAKEN OUT. With that as surance, George F. Bauer, man ager of the Animalport at Ken nedy International Airport, opened the cage to let a halfgrown, 300pound lion, the pet of an Army unit in Germany, out for exercise.

title: Cadillac
Murphy Signs Multiyear Pact With N.B.A. San Diego Rockets
description: SAN DIEGO, April 4 (UPI) Calvin Murphy, three  time allAmerican guard, signed a contract today with the Na tional Basketball Association San Diego Rockets.

title: FEMINIST EFFORT GROWS IN CROTON
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N.Y., April 4The women's libera tion movement, born on the campuses and in the cities and nurtured on the energy of rad ical politics, has come to this village on the Hudson.

title: In This Issue
Motorists in Area Pay Millions Daily in Taxes
description: State and Federal highway user tax collections in the tri state area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut aver age nearly $5million a day almost $3million in New York, $1.4million in New Jersey and $597,000 in Con necticut.

title: RANGERS LOSE BUT CAN GAIN PLAYOFF BERTH TODAY
description: RANGERS LOSE BUT CAN GAIN PLAYOFF BERTH TODAY; SILENT SCREEN FINISHES THIRD TO NATIVE ROYALTY

title: Seaver Prepares to Strike
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: TACOMA'S MAYOR FACING A RECALL
description: TACOMA, Wash., April 4 This city of 160,000 is faced with the possibility that its Mayor and the eight other mem bers of the City Council will be subjects of a recall election this year.

title: Pauline Hammick Wed to Kristian Holst
description: Miss Pauline Rose Ham mick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Ham mick of Maidstone, England, and Kristian Abel Holst of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludvig Holst of San Francisco, were married here yesterday afternoon at Trin ity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Davis Given.

title: Three strangers and not afraid
description: The link between these three writ ers is tenuous but real. Both Peter Weiss and Eugene Ionesco are aliens thoroughly at home in exile, while Heinrich Boll has always been a stranger in his own country. All were born around the time of World War and came of agecreatively, at any rateduring the second installment of the apocalypse; and though each was to go his separate way, the youthful efforts collected in these volumes clearly owe a common in spiration to the end of the world, phase two.

title: Miffed Mets' Fan Flashes Sign Doubting Another Banner Year
description: The sign man of Shea Sta dium wants the sports world to know that he's no cheer leader. In fact, he doesn't think the New York Mets will re peat as world champions. Not only that, but he's a bit miffed at them.

title: Amateur Boxing Program To Benefit Scholarship Fund
description: An amateur boxing program of six bouts between teams rep resenting New York and Chi cago will be held April 15 at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

title: DR. ROBERT E. WALSH
description: Dr. Robert Emmet Walsh, a retired surgeon who was phy sician to the New York Yankees baseball team in the late nine teenthirties, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. His age was 85.

title: Anne Phillips Is Bride Here
description: Miss Anne Read Phillips was married here yesterday afternoon to Wallace. W. Clark, president of R. & W. Clark (Cowes) Ltd., boat builders of Cowes. Isle of Wight, England. The Rev. William G. Weinhauer per formed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: Living on Wheels
description: MORE than 10 million peo ple will spend their week ends, vacations and leisure time this year traveling throughout the nation in more than three million recreational vehicles of all shapes and sizes. They will include camping families, sports men and retired couples.

title: CITY'S LOBBYIST SETS FORTH AIMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  A Federal antipoverty official who has spent the last five years administering aid programs for Indians, migrant farm workers and residents of Puerto Rico, Guam and American Samoa took over this week as New York City's lobbyist in Wash ington.

title: Air America's Civilian Facade Gives It Latitude in East Asia
description: WASHINGTON, April 4As the Americansupported clan destine army went on the at tack in Laos again this week, pilots of a flamboyant airline called Air America took to the skies once again to move troops, provide supplies and evacuate wounded.

title: Mayor Urged to Push Bill on H.R.A.
description: A key city Councilman nudged the Lindsay administra tion yesterday to take some ac tion on the longdelayed plans for giving legislative sanction to the ninth and last super agencythe Human Resources Administration.

title: Hopes on Safety Unfulfilled
description: A few years ago the public outcry over safety was as loud as today's auto pollution debate.

title: PRISONER KILLING DIVIDES SOLDIERS
description: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, April 4  Interviews held here today with a number of com hut infantrymen completing duty in Vietnam provided no easy explanation why some Americans kill defenseless pris oners of war and others do not.

title: Capital Plans Floodlights On Government Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The General Services admin istrator, Robert L. Kunzig, has announced plans to floodlight Government buildings in Wash ington's Federal Triangle to make the city more beautiful and safer by night.

title: Herbalist Finishes First In $50,000 Arkansas Derby
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 4 (AP)  Greentree Stable's 3yearold Herbalist dazzled a record Oaklwn crowd of more than 23,000 today by winning the 34th running of the $50,000 added Arkansas Derby.

title: NERVIEST CLASH SINCE NOVEMBER REPORTED AT DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, April 5The allied com mands reported yesterday the heaviest fighting involving American troops along the de militarized zone in nearly five months and new clashes near the Cambodian border.

title: Buffalos Five Signs Case
description: BUFFALO, April 4 (AP)  Chip Case a guard at the Uni versity of Virginia, was the first college draftee to sign with Buffalo's new entry in the National Basketball Association. The signing of the Gfoot3inch Case, who lives in nearby Lock port, was announced today.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: AS a relatively new member of the Board of Governors of the Acad emy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, I was fascinated by John Simon's sometime witty attack on our alltooimperfect institution. His maledictions, however, were filled with such an intractable bias and seethrough ignorance that I feel impelled to reply.

title: Reader's Report
description: In thisneat little fable, Glen don Swarthout uncovers a neg lected stratum of the disad vantaged: the psychologically battered offspring of the neg lectful rich. The six boys who mount a children's crusade through the canyon country of Arizona all carry scars left by broken homes and absentee parents. (A teeth grinder. A head banger. Two actual bed wetters. A nailbiter and over eater. And a thumbsucker and baddreamer.)

title: NEWS TECHNIQUES STRESSED IN TRIAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 The arguments and affidavits presented in a court case here this week have focused unusual attention on the procedures used by newsmen in collecting information and their conten tions that such procedures re quire protection.

title: One man in his time plays many psychosocial parts
description: AT a recent faculty reception I happened to join a small group in which a young mother was talking about her identity crisis. She and her husband, she said, had decided not to have any more children and she was depressed at the thought of being past the childbearing stage. It was as she continued, she had been robbed of some part herself and now needed to find a new function to replace the old one.

title: Israeli General Resigns and Then Changes Mind
description: JERUSALEM, April 4The army announcement, issued on the eve of the sabbath, was unusually brief and enigmatic: Maj. Gen. Yisrael Tal has decided not to resign from reg ular military service.

title: CAMP IN MONTANA AIDS DEAF CHILDREN
description: BOZEMAN, Mont. (UPI)A unique camp, combining scenic beauty and oral and written instruction for deaf children, will open for the second time this summer at Hyalite Canyon south of here.

title: Departing Division Leaves Its Mark in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4The United States First Infantry Division dis played its colors in South Vietnam for the last time yes terday, but the division has left its mark on South Vietnamese soil for years to come.

title: R.O.T.C. Scholars Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Army, has chosen 1,242 high school seniors for four year scholarships in the Res erve Officers Training Corps. Such scholarships covering tui tion, textbooks and laboratory fees, are worth $10,000 or more in many cases, Army officials estimated. Youths who accept such scholarships must serve at least four years of active duty as commissioned officers after they are graduated from college.

title: Getting the Old Clinker Fixed
description: Motorists have long been plagued with the question of where to bring a car for competent and reasonable service.

title: Alexis de Tocqueville on revolution in France
description: By Alexis de Tocqueville. A New Translation by George Lawrence. Edited by J. P. Mayer and A. P. Kerr. Introduction by J. P. Mayer. 333 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collecting's most famous bit of paper, a crude and not  so beautiful adhesive, is changing ownership. Securely vaulted for 30 years by an anonymous Australian (ex cept for a few rare showings at exhibitions) the stamp, the British Guiana 1cent ma genta of 1856; was sold at auction on March 24 for $280,000. For its size (2.2 inches horizontally and 1.6 inches vertically) and weight (just a bit of paper and ink) it is more than likely the most valuable objet d'art in existence. Objet d'art? Hard ly. It just happens to be the only one of its kind in ex istence, one of a handful of unique postage stampsthe one facedifferent, oneofa kind postage stamps.

title: Bradley Five in Gator Bowl
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 4 (AP)Bradley University was named today to play in the Gator Bowl basketball tourna ment Dec. 28 and 29. St. Bona venture, Georgia Tech and Florida were announced pre viously.

title: Poll Brings Ray of Sunshine To Florida Tourist Trade
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The most desirable va cation region in the world, in the opinion of a group of Americans re cently surveyed, is Florida. And, according to the state's Department of Commerce, which hired the Opinion Re search Corporation of Prince ton, N. J., to ask the ques tions, even more people would be attracted to Florida if it were not for a fear of hurricanes.

title: James P. Lee Marries Flora S. Lin
description: Miss Flora S. Lin and James P. Lee were married here yesterday afternoon in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David D. Cockcroft.

title: A Wealth Of Choices On Wheels
description: A MAJOR revolution in American personal trans portation moves toward center stage this week at the Coliseum, where the glamorous and excit ing International Automobile Show is displaying the collective craftsmanship of the world of wheels.

title: Original Dachau Records Are Discovered in Poland
description: WARSAW, April 4 (UPI) The Polish Press Agency PAP today anounced the discovery of original files from the Nazi concentration camp at Dachau, obtained from the widow of Jozef Batory, an inmate.

title: Ford
Smallest Town in Nation Has Population Explosion
description: DELLVVIEW, N. C. April 4 (UPI)A population explosion threatens this town's claim as the smallest in the nation.

title: City Dweller's Car a Lovable Nuisance
description: What, you still have a car in the city? The wellmeaning friend who had driven in from the su burbs for dinner with us let her fork slip into the fondue. When are you going to get rid of it?

title: Susan S. Dale Will Be Married To Daniel Sullivan, a Student
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 4Miss Susan Sutphen Dale and Daniel Milton Sullivan will be married in the sum mer.

title: Drugs and Alcohol
description: The Highway Users Fed eration for Safety and Mobil ity has warned that many common drugs can be dan gerous to the driver, espe cially when combined with alcohol. These include medi cines used daily by millions of personsand the list is by no means limited to pre scrintion drugs.

title: Crack Ruler Rallies for HalfLength Victory in $27,900 Pimlico Handicap
description: BALTIMORE, April 4A. J. Somerville's Crack Ruler, last in the field of six during the early part of the race, stormed through the stretch today and won the $27,900 City of Balti more Handicap by onehalf length at Pimlico Race Course.

title: COLUMBIA SQUADS READY FOR ACTION
description: Six Columbia spring teams are scheduled to compete this week as the spring season gets into full swing.

title: Air Bag to Replace Clumsy Harnesses
description: DETROIT  If everything goes right, within a few years there are going to be strange doings inside the automobile when an accident occurs.

title: A Part of Spring
description: Once April arrives it is easier to believe in spring, no matter what may be the daytoday weather. Daylight again surpasses darkness. The sun is overhead. Not until another January will those long, deep nights and abbreviated days allow the cold to burrow down and settle in. Now it is the sun, not the cold, that strength ens.

title: Monteverdi
Tires Made With New Materials and Techniques Are Stronger, but Costlier
description: Those two whitewall rings on the tires of many 1970 cars may appear to be an esthetic innovation, but they actually symbolize the new fiberglass beltingthe big gest change in this country's basic tire construction since the advent of tubeless tires in Detroit some 20 years ago.

title: Peugeot
CAMBODIA OPENS DOOR TO U.S. AID
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 4The official Cambodia press agency has published a tran script of the news conference held Monday by Premier Lon Nol in which the Premier's words have been changed to raise the possibility that Cam bodia might call for United States troops to help her expel North Vietnamese and Viet cong troops from her territory.

title: BACALLAO, SQUIRES REACH SEMIFINALS
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April Dr. Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club, the defending champion, led the way into the semifinals of the national squash tennis championship to day while continuing a two year undefeated record.

title: W. R. Grace Tries a Different Tack
description: Question: The end of the 1960's saw Grace drop or reduce some of the in terests that were more or less trade marks of the company, such as shipping and Latin American activities. Why?

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of the British war poet Wilfred Owen (1893 1918), I would appreciate hear ing from anyone who has perti nent information.

title: Guard Unit to Enlist Women
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., April 4 (AP)The New Hampshire Air National Guard plans to en list its first women member since the unit was organized 23 years ago. Maj. Benjamin LaSalle, personnel officer for the unit at Pease Air Force Base here, says the National Guard Bureau has set a quota of 10 women recruits for the New Hampshire Air Guard unit.

title: Joseph Durso's
CHOU BEGINS VISIT TO NORTH KOREA
description: TOKYO, Sunday, April 5 (AP)  Premier Chou Enlai of Communist China arrived today in Pyongyang, capital of North Korea, for a friendship visit, the Pyongyang radio reported.

title: The Bust Book
description: The Bust Book is not about a portion of a lady's anatomy. As its subtitle indicates, it is a handbook of legal advice for young Movement people who get arrested. One of the four authors, Kathy Boudin, has al ready achieved a separate no toriety by being identified as one of two girls who survived an explosion which destroyed a Greenwich Village town house.

title: CUP SOCCER TOPS TODAY'S PROGRAM
description: The New JerseyPennsylvania final of the United States Chal lenge Cup, the eastern semi final of the Amateur Cup and four GermanAmerican Soccer League contests, give fans a wide choice today.

title: Personality:
description: This is the year that the Southern Pacific Company, according to its president, Ben Biaggini, is really going to begin getting the most from the 3,855,000 acres of land its owns in California, Nevada, Utah and 11 other states.

title: Seek to Oust Bullets
description: Hoping to wind up their first round series so that they can get a good breathing space be fore confronting Lew Alcindor and the Milwaukee Bucks in the next round, the New York Knickerbockers play the Bullets in Baltimore today in the sixth game of the National Basket ball Association's firstround playoffs. The Knicks have won three games, Baltimore two, in the fourofseven competition.

title: NEWSMAN IN SAIGON DISCHARGED BY ARMY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 (Reuters)The Civilian bureau chief of Pacific Stars and Stripes in Saigon said to day that he had been dis charged for having permitted a Army newsman to send a critical article on military cen sorship to The New York Times.

title: CLAY BOY TAKES HUNTS FEET CUP
description: RICHMOND, April 4 (AP) Clay Boy caught the favored Tahawus three strides from the finish today and won by a neck in the 38th running of the Deep Run Hunt Cup at the Virginia State Fairgrounds.

title: What Happens To Trade Stamps?
description: What happens to the bil lions of trading stamps re deemed for merchandise each year by more than 47 million stampsaving households in the country? Old stamps, like money, must be destroyed to keen from being recirculated.

title: SURPLUS IN STATE PUT AT $5MILLION
description: ALBANY, April 4Control ler Arthur Levitt released this week a financial report he had sent to Governor Rockefeller for the 196970 fiscal year, which ended March 31, that shows a surplus in state reve nues of $4.65million.

title: Better Service Is on the Way
description: The next time you have to wait to get your car serviced, take heart. You won't have to put up with delays much longer. There is really no such thing as an automobile mechanic shortage.

title: Mutual Fund Dealers, With Morale Below Sea Level, Attempting to Surface
description: Turning lemons into lem onade. This, in the words of a motivation consultant, is the essential challenge now facing the mutualfund in dustry.

title: Ashe to Play in Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 4Arthur Ashe, Charles Pasa rell and Zeljko Franulovic will head the field for the Bacardi Rum invitation tennis sched uled from Friday through Sun day at the Bermuda Tennis Stadium. A purse of $5,000 will be at stake in the round robin competition.

title: ...When by the Sea
description: WHEN warming rays of the sun displace winter's frost, the bare earth opens but the seaside gar dener in New England usually has to wait until midApril before these encouraging signs appear.

title: Subway Revenue Up 40% Over 1969
description: The city's subways have scored a financial success this year, according to the Metro politan Transportation Author ity. But consumer groups see things rather differently.

title: Pop: The Early Blues Sound Better Than Ever
description: I AM THE BLUES: Willie Dixon [Columbia CS 9987]. POP ORIGINS (Chess LP 1544). It's a lit tle hard to believe that at this late date it should be nec essary to reconfirm the con tinuing story of white exploi tation of black music. But for the many skeptics still around, two fascinating re leases will provide convincing evidence.

title: Nuclear Generator Planned
description: CHICAGO, April 4 (UPI) The Commonwealth Edison Company plans to build an other nuclear generating station in the near future. The com pany announced plans for the station in a registration state ment filed Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Corn mssion. Commonwealth cur rently has 15 generating sta tinns. One, situated near Morris, Ill., is a nuclear plant.

title: Foreign Affairs: To the Finland Station
description: CASTEAU, BelgiumFor the first time America is in the military front line around the world and not protected from the threat of assault by either allied or buffer states.

title: KEY LAOTIAN BASE IS IMPERILED ANEW
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 4 A North Vietnamese counter attack launched before dawn this morning is threatening the Laotian hold on Sam Thong, re taken Tuesday after having been under North Vietnamese control for two weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: The President's message on school desegregation has been subject to widely differing in terpretations. The reason for these differences, I believe, is that the message takes two major policy positions, which go in opposite directions.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThat war just will not go away.

title: Marcos Says Martial Law Will Be Imposed if Needed
description: MANILA, April 4President Ferdinand E. Marcos said this evening he would impose mar tial law if the Communists re sorted to massive sabotage and if local civilian Government collapsed.

title: REP. MORTON STIRS DISPUTE IN MADRID
description: MADRID, April 4The Span ish Foreign Ministry and Repre sentative Rogers C. B. Morton, the Republican national chair man, found themselves in sharp disagreement today over wheth er Mr. Morton had praised Spain as a bastion of freedom in the Mediterranean.

title: Reflection Can Save Your Life
description: The use of reflective ma terials is widely becoming recognized as a means of in creasing vehicular and pedes trian safety at night.

title: GRAPE STRIKE GETS BELL FROM BRITAIN
description: LONDON, April 4 Six months ago, the Rev. Francis B. Sayre, dean of Washington Cathedral, appealed for a church bell to use in the cam paign supporting the Califor nia grape pickers strike.

title: In Memoriam
description: ABRAHAMIsidore. In ever toying memor of our dearly beloved father.

title: Arms Panel Urges a Halt In Weapons Deployment
description: President Nixon was urged by an arms control group yes terday to propose to the Soviet Union a twoyear interim halt in deployment of strategic weapons while the two sides attempted to work out an agreement to stop the nuclear arms race.

title: Susan Mulford Becomes Bride Of John Gantly
description: RIVERTON, N. J., April 4 Miss Susan Parry Mulford, daughter of Dr. William Pink erton Mulford, a physician and Mrs. Mulford of Moores town, was married here this afternoon to John Gantly of New York, son of Patrick Gantly, a horticulturist, and Mrs. Gantly of Sands Point, L. I.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE home improvement industry has been growing at an unprec edented rate in recent years  and all indications are that this rate of growth will continue well into the seventies, if not longer. Census Bureau figures indicate that well over $8billion was spent in the improvement and maintenance of singlefamily dwell ings in 1968, and no one doubts that 196970 totals will be still higher.

title: Italian Avalanche Kills 3
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, April 3 (UPI)Three West German tourists were killed today by an avalanche at this winter resort. The death brought to 32 the number killed in avalanches in Italy this year.

title: PANEL CALLS MSG FIT FOR ADULT USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  A National Research Council panel has concluded that mon sodium glutamate, the popular food additive, is fit for human consumption but not necessar ily by infants.

title: Critic I Deductions, Decorative Effects
description: I HOLD, Andr Gide once wrote, that the best explanation of a work must be its sequel. Wheth er or not this rule invariably ob tains in the study of an artist's work, there are certainly some artists whose work seems to defy almost any other mode of analysis. Such oeuvres are so completely selfenclosed, so fixed in the orbit of their own internal logic, that the usual explanations seem almost supererogatory. All that matters is the sequential progression from work to work, from idea to idea. In the presence of work of this sort, the critic is tempt ed intowell, not silence exactly (never that!), but a form of apology and ad vocacy which lavishes all its intellec tual resources on expounding the artist's rationale, passing over the larg er questions of value and significance with silent contempt.

title: Theater: Specializing in Eccentric, Even Comic, Derangement
description: THE latest double bill of the American Place The ater specializes in gently ac centric comic, derangement. The Last Street, by Charles Dizenzo, has a young man answering an advertisement in a newspaper offering a happier life, and the second play, Duet for Solo Voice, by David Scott Milton, is a portrait of a hotel clerk firm ly convinced he is being per secuted by a sinister figure sent by an alliance between Moscow's Secret Police and the Mafia.

title: A:
description: Solution

title: Escalating for Peace
description: France's proposal for a new international conference to deal with the indivisible problems of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia offers the Nixon Administration another chanceperhaps a last chanceto move from confrontation to negotiation in Indochina before a wider war engulfs the entire area of the former French colonial empire.

title: Spotlight:
description: Up again, down again, Telex and Memorex again.

title: Nancy Hite Bride Of P. H. Vietmeyer
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Anril 4Miss Nancy Jean Hite, of Greenwich and New York, and Philip H. Vietmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Vietmeyer of Milwaukee, were married here this morn ing in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George A. Pera.

title: FRICTION MARRING U.S.CANADA AMITY
description: OTTAWA, April 4One year after Prime Minister Pierre El liott Trudeau was welcomed at the White House as President Nixon's first visiting head of state, friction mars the warm and understanding friendship bailed then by the two leaders.

title: RIGA JEW'S LETTERS CHARGE PERSECUTION
description: LONDON, April 4  Three letters written by a 33year old Soviet Jew describing how he was persecuted for his re ligious beliefs and dismissed from his job were made public here this week.

title: RICHARD A. ZACHARIAE
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 4 Richard A. Zachariae, Mayor of Surf City, N. J., from 1934 to 1964, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Zoning Struggle Stirs Town
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn. An extended but still unsuccessful campaign to bring zoning to this rap idly developing township in the hills of western Con necticut is raising some of the fundamental issues con cerning zoning's impact on town growth.

title: Science
description: Five months ago there was widespread speculation that Dr. James Shapiro and his fellow researchers at the Harvard Medical School had accom plished a feat of Nobel Prize calibre. Last month Dr. Sha piro was publicly and harshly attacked by a group of Ameri can scientists who linked him by inference with the Nazi and Stalinist enemies of science. The factors behind this drastic shift of public image grow out of serious tensions and fears in the world of American science.

title: Rites for Jodi Aurelio
description: Funeral services for Jodi Aurelio, daughter of Deputy Mayor and Mrs. Richard Aure lio, were held last night at the Community Church of New York where she was a member. The Rev. Dr. Donald Harring ton presided over the services. He read the poetry of Edna St. Vincent Millay, Wordsworth, Whitman, and Dylan Thomas, Among those attending the funeral were Senator Jacob K. Javits, Deputy Mayor Robert M. Morganthau, Deputy Mayor Timothy Costello, and Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: Ruth Cornwall Woodman Dies; Creator of Death Valley Days
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 4 (UPI)Mrs. Ruth Cornwall Woodman, who created the Death Valley Days radio series 40 years ago and wrote more than 700 of its scripts, died in a hospital here on Thursday after a brief illness. She was 75 years old.

title: ROBERT M. SHEDDEN
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 5 Robert M. Shedden, retired ex ecutive officer of Dillon, Read & Co., investment bankers, in New York, died yesterday at the Carolton Convalescent Hospital here. He was 75 years old and lived at 221 Tahmore Drive.

title: Nicholas O'D. Lederer, 58, Editor in Plainfield, Dies
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., April (AP)  Nicholas O'D. Lederer, managing editor of The Courier News of Plainfield, died early today after having been strick en at a company dinner. He was 58 years old.

title: Ox Ridge Wins in Polo
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 5The Ox Ridge A team defeated the North Salem A team, 129, in the first game of a polo double header at the Ox Ridge Arena today: Reid Graham scored seven goals for the winners. In the second game, Ox Ridge B downed North Salem B, 176.

title: Cambodian Rulers Rally the Young
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 5 Cambodia rallied her high school and college students today to the cause of loving their new leaders and hating the Vietnamese Communists. The young peo ple took to it with ferocious slogans, cruel posters, the singing of new patriotic songs; disorganized close order drill and embarrassed giggles. Even the teachers who gave the orders were often too busy squelching their amusement to get out the words that would make their classes execute a right face or stand at ease. The lan guage of the posters that be gan to spring up on trees and walls and across streets all over town was strong.

title: Pakistan Changes Under Yahya
