description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 1A few days ago, at a news conference here, a Paki stani reporter asked President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan to respond to the criticism that since he had already decided so much, there was virtually nothing for the National As sembly to decide when it meets in October to draft a constitution.

title: TORPID ACCOUNTS FACE CUSTODY FEE
description: In a significant break with Wall Stret tradition, Burnham & Co., the brokerage firm, has begun imposing a custody fee on dormant customer accounts in an effor tto offset rising costs.

title: Road to East Nigeria Bustling Again
description: BENIN, Nigeria, April 4 The postwar reconstruction of eastern Nigeria has brought new life to this ancient city in Midwestern State.

title: A New Revolution of Rising Expectations
description: LONDONAccording to the British Government, wage in creases in this country should be no more than 2.5 to 4.5 per cent in the year 1970. That is the officially declared norm. In fact, as opposed to theory, wages in Britain are now rising at a rate of about 12.5 per cent a year.

title: Cardinal's First 2 Years: Renewal Amid Problems
description: In his first two years as Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, Terence Cardi nal Cooke has won praise for moving forward toward church renewal in the spirit of the Second Vatican Coun cil, but in some respects, his critics say, he has proceeded with unnecessary caution.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Baltimore Bullets, N.B.A. Eastern Division playoff, at Madi son Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, 7:30 P.M. (RadioWHN, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Maritime Agency Appoints
description: The appointment of Aaron W. Reese as managing director has been announced by the Federal Maritime Commission. Before joining the regulatory agency.

title: Decline of the Bosses: Ticket Named by Democratic State Committee Is Anything but OldLine
description: A handful of important Dem ocrats met in a smokefilled room one night last week and picked their 1970 statewide ticket: Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor, because he looked like a winner; Representative Richard D. McCarthy of Buffalo for Senator, to get upstate and Irish votes; Mayor Alfred Del Bello of Yonkers for Lieutenan Governor, to get the Italian vote; William vanden Heuvel for Attor ney General, to appeal to youth and Arthur Levitt for Controller because the Democrats always run Arthur Levitt.

title: RUTGERS DEDICATES LOUNGE TO ROBESON
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. (UPI) Rutgers University paid trib ute to Paul Robeson, its best known black alumnus.

title: BALTIMORE TAKES SIXTH GAME, 9687
To Live or Not to Live With Campus Coercion
description: After last month's unrest at the State University of New York at Buffalo, a faculty fact finding committee said that police should be called only under the most extraordinary circumstances.

title: Nixon and Johnson Attend White House Services
Nixon Guides Republicans on Senate Races, Recruiting a Slate Aimed at Gaining Control of Chamber
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  President Nixon has assembled, with the aid of his political strategists, a slate of Republi can Senatorial candidates that is expected to make an ag gressive race against the Demo crats this fall.

title: GEN. J. HARRY LA BRUM
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP) Brig. Gen. J. Harry LaBrum, U.S.A., retired, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 72 years old.

title: Trampler, Francescatti and Tureck Heard in Weekend Concerts
description: A pleasing mix of works in various styles was presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. Berg's Four Pieces for Clarinet and Piano (1913), Schumann's Fan tasy Pieces (Op. 73) for the same combination and Berio's Sequenza VI for Solo Viola were set betwen Haydn's Trio in D major for Flute, Cello and Piano and Mozart's Quintet in G minor (K. 516).

title: Rice Boom in Asia Raises Doubts
description: LOS BANOS, the Philippines The new strains of rice, wheat and corn that are producing the socalled green revolution in Asia, holding out a promise of plenty for under fed millions, are beginning to stir objections.

title: Soviet's 10 Checkmate World in Belgrade Chess
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5The Soviet Union has won the match here that pitted its 10 top players against leading players from the rest of the world. The score, after comple tion today of the final ad journed games in the fourth round, was 20 to 19.

title: New Publisher Chosen For Harper's Bazaar
description: Having given a good num ber of his years to the young chicks at Mademoiselle, Gor don N. Morford, the pub lisher, is moving along to join the more mature gals at Harper's Bazaar. The title, however, remains the same.

title: Blast in Argentine Leads Police to Bomb Factory
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 5 (AP) The police reported today that an explosion had led to the discovery of a terrorist bomb factory five miles from downtown Buenos Aires and the arrest of 102 persons, in cluding two men wounded in the blast.

title: Sunday Drinking in Brisbane
description: BRISBANE, Australia, April 5 (Reuters)Hotel bars opened to Sunday drinkers here today for the first time in 100 years. Liberalized liquor laws intro duced by the Queensland state government allow city hotels to serve drinks for two hours on Sundays.

title: Best Wishes on His Retirement Follow Airline Pilot Across Sky
description: When an airline pilot is re tiring after more than three decades, he may find that he is better known to ground con trollers and dispatchers, than he thinks. This happened last month to Capt. Robert J. Car roll on his final flight from San Francisco to New York for American Airlines.

title: U. S. Consul in Brazil Shot Foiling Abduction Attempt
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5  Ctirtis C. Cutter, the United States consul in Porto Alegre, thwarted a kidnapping attempt late last night, struck one of the attackers with his car, ran over him and escaped in a burst of machinegun fire.

title: Cake Reciicies From the West
description: THE recipes for prune cake and apple cake givenbe low have been treasured in a handwritten collection be longing to a South Dakota family for several genera tions. The fruit and nut cake is a delectable confection of cherries, dates, pecans, Bra zils and Walnuts held to gether with a minimum of dough. It is quick to make and bake.

title: Fire Levels Block in Maine
description: KEZAR FALLS, Me., April 5 (AP)A windwhipped fire destroyed a business block in the heart of this western Maine village tonight but firefighters won control before the town']s bank and an adjacent woolen mill were ignited.

title: Bridge:
description: IT is unusual for the honors to be shared in a major tournament, and for two successive events to result in a tie is very rare indeed. This occurred in the Spring Nationkls of the American Bridge Association in Cin cinnati, which ended yester day.

title: MRS. GEORGE WATSON JR.
description: Mrs. Forsyth Patterson Wat son, widow of George E. Wat son Jr., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died at her home, 970 Park Avenue, Friday. She was 66 years old.

title: Irish Republican Army Warns of Ulster Reprisal
description: BELFAST, Northern, Ire land, April 5 (AP)The out lawed Irish Republican Army threatened today to shoot a British soldier if a civilian was killed by security forces in Northern Ireland.

title: ISRAELIS EXPECT U.S. BID TO EGYPT
description: JERUSALEM, April 5Is raeli officials believe that the United States may seek more direct ties with the United Arab Republic in the visit to the Middle, East next week of Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Sec retary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

title: Pompidou Asks French To Celebrate Roquefort
description: PARIS, April 5President Pompidou advised French farmers today to advertise their products better.

title: AUSSIES' CUP SQUAD SWEEPS FILIPINOS
description: MANILA, April 5 (AP)Aus tralia completed a 50 rout of the Philippines today in the Eastern Zone of the Davis Cup elimination series as John Al exander and Ray Ruffels easily won the final singles matches.

title: Explorations Spotlights Use of Technology in A
description: WASHINGTON, April 5A random, unprogramed no tion flashed through my mind at Explorations, the new arttechnology show at the Smithsonian Institution's Na tional Collection of Fine Arts. It was this: that 50 years from now some of today's zappy, technologically ori ented art may seem as hack neyed as Rosa Bonheur's 19thcentury salon piece, The HorseFam.

title: JACOB H. MOGELEVER, EXTREASURY AIDE
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 5 Jacob H. Mogelever, a former newspaper editor who retired in February as promotion man ager of the Savings Bond Divi sion of the Treasury Depart ment, died here last night. His age was 69 years old and lived here.

title: The Status of Major Legislation Offered in Congress
description: JAN. 19, 1970, TO APRIL 4, 1970

title: NEW BONDS MEET HOPEFUL MARKET
description: The corporate bond market, encouraged by its ability to work its way through three con secutive weeks of exceptionally heavy financing activity, is op timistic it can handle a fourth.

title: ATHENS COURT LETS 6 DENY CONFESSIONS
description: ATHENS, April 5The spe cial military tribunal in Athens, which is trying 34 Greek intel lectuals on charges of sedition and of setting off bombs, tacit ly accepted pleas today by six of the defendants that their confessions to the police be dis regarded as untruthful.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Font's Decision

title: Nixon Aides Assist Unusual Library
description: MONTAUK, L.I., April 5  Members of the Nixon Admin istration displayed support this weekend for an unusual library project that was rebuffed by the Johnson Administration.

title: CATHOLIC DOGMAS CHALLENGED ANEW
description: ROME, April 5The dictates of human conscience are better guides to proper behavior than are the possibly mistaken dec larations of a pope, a Roman Catholic theologian told a con ference of 200 Italian moral theologians, who applauded his statement.

title: JACK ZANGER DIES; SPORTS WRITER, 43
description: Jack Zanger, a freelance sports writer and author, died at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx yesterday following sur gery for a brain tumor. Mr. Zanger, who was 43 years old, lived at 470 West End Avenue.

title: Twin Gains Cheer Producers of Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, April 5Steel producers reported firm domes tic demand last week and a sur prising turn in foreign trade.

title: Brothers Collide and Die
description: MOUNTAUBAN, France (AP) Two brothers, Daniel and JeanClaude Giannico were killed here when their motor biikes collided headon at a blind intersection, which the brohers were approaching op posite directions.

title: FRANCIS J. WIER
description: Francis J. Wier, a retired assistant general counsel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Thursday in Columbus Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 44 Gramercy Park.

title: Miss Joanne Gaffney Is Married To R. S. Bennett, Medical Student
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 15Miss Joanne Gaffney, a 1969 graduate of the Cornell University School of Nursing and a former student at Marymount College here, was married at noon today to Robert Sanford Bennet, who is in his final year at the Cornell Medical College.

title: AIRPORT TRAFFIC IS SMOOTHER HERE DESPITE STOPPAGE
description: A moderately heavy volume of postholiday air traffic moved through the nation's skies yesterday with few long delays as 1,000 or more air traf fic controllers continued their 13day sick work stoppage against the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: OUTPUT MAY RISE FOR GREMLIN CAR
description: But American Motors Sees Risk in Big Tooling Cost American Motors Corpora tion officials are weighing the possibility of increasing produc tion of the company's new small car, the Gremlin. But the costs of overcoming assembly line problems and the hazards from competition make a giant buildup of the model's output risky, company officials at the New York Auto Show said in a series of interviews.

title: METS' RALLY TOPS TWINS, 42, IN 9TH
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 5 (AP)  The world champion New York Mets scored two un earned runs in the ninth inning on a throwing error by Leo Cardenas, shortstop, to defeat the Minnesota Twins, 42, to day.

title: How Senate May Vote
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The following table shows how Senators are expected to vote tomorrow on the motion to recommit the Supreme Court nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Senators listed for or against the motion have either announced their intention publicly or have indicated their position in interviews. Senators have been placed in the lean ing categories on the basis of interviews with Congressional sources. Four Senators are ex pected to be absent.

title: Underseas Bahamas Mine Stirs Conservation Fears
description: A mining company has begun to strip away the sea bottom in the Bahamas to extract a commercially valu able mineral in what could be by far the largest under water mining operation in the world.

title: TransAtlantic Ship Fares Will Rise Next Year
description: The transAtlantic passenger steamship lines have decided to increase minimum fares next year by amounts ranging from $9 to $18.

title: ASHE WINS FINAL IN CARIBE TENNIS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 5 (AP)  Arthur Ashe of Rich mond, won the Caribe Hilton international tennis tourna ment for the third time today by defeating Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., 64, 63, 16, 63, in the final.

title: Advertising: Agency Talent vs. Urban Ills
description: Ellsworth L. (Tim) Timber man, the 42yearold execu tive, who had so much to do with the successful turn around of Kenyon & Eck hardt, will be leaving the agency business to pit his youthful energies against the problem of urban blight. Maybe there is hope.

title: Church's Plumbing Stolen
description: A Baptist church in Brooklyn was stripped of its plumbing and a set of antique chandeliers over the weekend by thieves who apparently hoped to sell the brass fixtures. The theft was discovered yesterday af ternoon by the Rev. Robert G. Green of the Noah's Ark Bap tist Church at 771 Sackman Street, near New Lots Avenue in the Canarsie section.

title: HUDSON, HALLARD SPARK CLINCHING
description: ATLANTA, April 5 (UPI) The Atlanta Hawks choked off a lastperiod rally by Chicago today to defeat the Bulls, 113 107, and advance to the Na tional Basketball Association's Western Division finals. Atlan ta took the semifinal series, 41.

title: Wisdom on Cambodia
description: The Administration's decision to stay out of Cam bodian politics serves the best interests of Cambodia, Vietnam and, not least, the United States.

title: LOLICH OF DETROIT OPPOSES BOSNIAN
description: President Nixon, Seattle, Denny McLain and Curt Flood, will be among the missing when the baseball season opens today and tomorrow before crowds expected to total 330,000.

title: Nixon Asking Soap Industry To Stop Using Phosphates
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The White House said today the Administration was trying to persuade the soap industry to find a substitute for phos phates because they were pol luting the nation's streams and lakes.

title: NEW TALKS URGED IN TEXTILE BATTLE
description: Hopes that there still might be time and willingness to break th ebitter deadlock that has developed between Wash ington and Tokyo over textile imports was expressed by Jap anese sources here last week.

title: Rangers in Playoff; Knicks Series Tied
description: The Rangers squeezed into the Stanley Cup hockey play offs last night, but the Knick erbockers were balked in their efforts to clinch the Eastern semifinal playoff in the Nation al Basketball Association.

title: G.O.P. Expected to Name Rockefeller and Goodell at Meeting Beginning Today
description: ROCHESTER, April 5New York Republicans began gathering here today for a two day meeting that is expected to designate Governor Rocke feller and Senator Charles E. Goodell to head the party's 1970 state ticket.

title: Republic Seen by Saturday
description: PNOMPENH, April 5 (AP) A Government source said to day it was expected that the new Cambodian regime would form a republic by Saturday.

title: Chess:
Tank Flaw Plagues Apollo 13 as Countdown Begins,
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 5 Preparations were under way here tonight for the nation's third manned flight to the moonApollo 13and there were already signs that the sixday count down that began tonight would be a hectic time of grappling with technical gremlins.

title: DALLAS TRIUMPHS IN SOCCER OPENER
description: The North American Soccer League opened its 1970 season at St. Louis yesterday where the local Stars suffered a 40 defeat at the hands of the visit ing Dallas Tornado. Mike Ren shaw scored twice for Dallas while Bill Moffet and Louis Juresy scored one apiece at Francis Field before 6.100.

title: KIRK TAKES OVER A SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: BRADENTON, Fla., April 5 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida ordered pupils in Mana tee County today to ignore an integration, plan approved lase week by the Supreme Court and personally assumed control of the county's school system.

title: Judge in Kopechne Case
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, Judge Wilfred J. Paquet of the Massachusetts Superior Court sentenced two convicted bookies to 10 years in jail. Two weeks later he ordered them released and explained that he had decided the sen tences were too sever. I am big enough to admit I made a mistake, he said. The District Attorney in the case sought to nullify Judge Paquet's action, and the issue was finally re solved in the Supreme Judic ial Court of Massachusetts. A Boston lawyer named Ed ward B. Hanify, arguing in behalf of Judge Paquet, said that the judge's honor and integrity have won the res pect of his colleagues on the bench, members of the bar and the general community. Judge Paquet was upheld.

title: Swede Sets Lift Record
description: SUNDBYBERG, Sweden, April 5 (AP)Hans Bettembourg, a Swedish light heavyweight weight lifter, bettered his own world record press today with a lift of 381.3 pounds.

title: G. J. Holding Corp. Elects Chairman and Top Officer
description: Dan Rodgers, formerly presi dent of Revlon, Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive officer of G. J. Holding Corporation, which ac quired Georg Jensen, Inc., in October 1968.

title: Mrs. Charles Iselin, Turf Figure And Social Leader, Dies at 102
description: Mrs. Hope Goddard Iselin, a prominent sportswoman and long a social leader here, died yesterday in Aiken, S. C., where she had a winter home. Mrs. Iselin was 102 years old and lived in Upper Brookville, L. I. She was the widow of Charles Oliver Iselin, banker and yachtsman, who three times defended the America's Cup.

title: Gagarin Museum Opened MOSCOW, April 5 (Reuters)
description: Gagarin Museum Opened MOSCOW, April 5 (Reuters)  A museum commemorating. Yuri A. Gagarin, the world's first man in space, was opened today, near Smolensk, in his home town, which has been re named in his honor. The astim naut, who was killed in an air crash two years ago, orbited the earth in the first manned space flight on April 12, 1961.

title: Counterfeit Bills Seized
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Counterfeit money with a to tal face value of $18.2million was seized by Secret Service agents last year, as compared to $16.6million in 1968, the Treasury Department reported today. The department said $15.7million worth of the bills were seized last year before they could be put into circula tion; the remaining $2.5million was recovered after it had been passed to the public, compared to $3.2million in 1968.

title: Film on Red Army Portrays World War II Leaders
description: MOSCOW, April 5  Gray haired and speaking with slow, Geoigian accent, Stalin calmly refuses to give the Nazis a field marshal in ex change for his captured son.

title: JURY WILL STUDY R.O.T.C. PROTESTS
description: ST. LOUIS, April 5A Fed eral grand jury will begin here Tuesday an investigation that could have farreaching effects on campus demonstrators everywhere.

title: Penn Station Is Geared to Commuter
description: As regiments of commuters trooped past and loudspeak ers droned timetables in the background, Mrs. Theodore Malino set up camp on the concourse of Pennslyvania Station with four romping children, five heavy red suit cases, three stuffed shopping bags and a big basket of coloring books.

title: 60% of Students in State Enroll in Private Colleges
description: Nearly three out of five of the students attending four  year colleges and universities in New York State this year are going to private institutions, accord ing to the Commission on Inde pendent Colleges and Universi ties.

title: Federal Judges Urge Reforms To Reinvigorate World Court
description: A group of Federal judges in meetings this weekend at New York University expressed dis may at the plight of the In ternational Court of Justice, which does not have a single case on its docket.

title: Gas Reserves Drop Two Years in Row
description: The proven gas reserves of the United States dropped in 1969, marking the second con secutive year of decline, the American Gas Association an nounced today.

title: Marchi to Offer Substitute For OffTrack Betting Bill
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he was preparing a substitute bill for legislation that has been intro duced in Albany seeking the legalization of offtrack bet ting on horse races.

title: In Pineapple Country the Bid Topics Are Rain and the Lack of It
description: LANAI CITY, HawaiiThe clouds churned ominous ly on the crest of the hill, but Swede said No, the rain won't come. They were riding the Trade Winds and had been wrung out on the much higher mountains in Maui, across the channel.

title: Freed Japanese Tell of Hijack Ordeal
description: TOKYO, April 5As in dividuals they were very pleas ant and polite companions, Shinjiro Yamamura, the Japan ese Deputy Minister of Transpor tation said of the nine young hijackers he accompanied to North Korea aboard the hi jacked Japanese airliner.

title: Labor Organizers Invade South via Madison Avenue
description: ATLANTA, April 5At the sound of a drum a radio announcer proclaims: Atten tion all Georgia Shoe Company employes! Martial music, force ful and patriotic, swells in the background as the voice con tinues:

title: Perot Again Tries to Visit Hanoi to Aid P.O.W.'s
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5  H. Ross Perot, the Texas mil lionaire, returned to Vientiane today in a Boeing 707 jetliner, full of journalists, to continue his campaign to induce the North Vietnamese to improve the treatment of United States prisoners of war.

title: 1969 WORLD TRADE SWELLED BY 14.1%
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Despite a rising volume of complaints about barriers to trade, the total of world trade rose massively again last year, the International Monetary Fund has reported.

title: Despite the Problems, Children's Camps Look Forward to a Busy Summer
description: THE days of simple woods manshipp and marshmal lows around the camp fire are all but over. In their stead, increasingly more sophisticated fare is being offered by children's camps to compete with the lures of family travels, Euro pean tours, beefedup sum mer schools and dozens of activities designed to fill the vacation months.

title: Catledge, Retiring, Backs Objective News Coverage
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 3 The American news media are in the grip of a credibility crisis, according to Turner Catledge, who served for nearly two decades as the chief news executive of The New York Times.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 6, 1970

title: Theater: Thinker's Plays
description: BRAVO! Most playwrights write more than they think. The British playwright Stanley Eveling, a newcomer here, thinks more than he writes. Although he is ex traordinarily funny, you take away from the theater the memory of his wit and sen sibility rather than recollec tions of his jokes. Unlike so many witty writers, he dares with the stuff of the theater. Sometimes the dares are as obvious as tightrope walking, occasionally they involve more arcane theatrical acro batics. Mr. Eveling is good.

title: Part of Cliffs of Dover Falls
description: DOVER, England, April 5 (AP)Part of the white cliffs of Dover collapsed into the sea today. The fallen chalk ex tended several hundred feet, and the sea turned white over a large area. The police closed the popular clifftop path be tween Dover and Deal.

title: Providence Tops St. John's
description: St. John's University bowed to Providence 31, yesterday in a nonleague baseball game at St. John's field in Hillcrest, Queens.

title: MARTIN HOXTER
description: Martin Hoxter, a director of the Reichs Kredit Gesellschaft in Berlin from 1927 to 1933 and managing director of Ellern's Bank in Haifa, Palestine, from 1934 to 1947, when he retired, died Saturday at his home, 1803 Riverside Drive. He was 91 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, April 5On any given night a guy can get that hot and it don't matter who is out there, Wilt Chamberlain or anybody, and you go out there and you tell yourself, Now don't get excited; you know a guy gets a hot hand thinks he has to do it all.

title: Lanterns That Are Sculptures Light
description: ISAMU NOGUCHI, the sculptor who, on the side, has designed playgrounds, stage sets, costumes, gardens, furniture and fountainsthe ones for Expo '70 have won more acclaim from critics than anything else at the fair in Osakahas a special feel ing toward his lanterns. (Most people call them lamps, but he prefers lanterns.) Because they are made of white paper, come in a multitude of designs, can be hung or placed on floor or table and are inexpensive prices start at $5they can be bought by almost anyone. And with their simple, pure shapesthey are really sculp turei in lightthey can fit into almost any decor. The thought that many people can have them is what appeals most to Mr. Noguchi. With $85 as the top price, there is not much profit for the man who designed them, but this does bother him.

title: Joan Bradley, Actress, Is Married
description: Miss Joan L. Golub, an actress known as Joan Bradley, was married last evening to Patrick J. Des mond, an actor. State Su preme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson performed the Ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Golub.

title: For Women Seminarians, Good Works, Not a Pulpit, Is the Goal
description: THEY cringe at the thought of having the title Reverend tacked before their names. They wear miniskirts, march in protest parades, and work in the ghettos. If somebody says God is Dead to them, they're apt to argue for hours.

title: 17 Ships Ordered by Group
description: The WorldWide Group, shipowning and shipmanage ment combine in Hong Kong, has ordered 17 new tankers and orebulk carriers to be built in shipyards in Japan and the United Kingdom. The vessels, totaling 1,643,000 deadweight tons, are scheduled for delivery between 1971 and 1973.

title: CHOU IS WELCOMED BY NORTH KOREANS
description: HONG KONG, April 5Pre mier Chou Enlai of Communist China was welcomed at Pyong yang airport today by the North Korean Premier, Kim Il Sung, and President Choi Yong Kun.

title: Bell Aerospace of Canada Plans AirCushion Vehicle
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 4 (AP)The Bell Aero space Division of Textron, Inc., is planning to manufacture a twinengined, selfpropelled air cushion vehicle in Canada.

title: Grocer Escapes Trap
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., April (UPI)Two men robbed supermarket today, then locked an owner in a freezer locker and burned the store down. The owner, Ronald Hinton, 41 years old, kept an ax in the locker and was able to hack his way free before the flames en gulfed the market.

title: Miracle Rice Improves Life of a Filipino Family
description: BARRIO PANSOL PILA, PhilippinesLucio Matienzo, a rice farmer with less than five acres of wet paddy fields, has six children and is able to send all of them to school.

title: Liberals and Conservatives Gain In Rolls as Major Parties Lose
description: New York State's Liberal and Conservative parties have scored gains in enrolling voters while the Democratic and Re publican parties have slipped back in statewide tallies made public by Secretary of State John F. Lomenzo.

title: David Eisenhower Wary Of Commencement Talk
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)David Eisenhower, President Nixon's soninlaw, said today he was seriously considering not attending his own graduation ceremonies at Amherst College to avoid embarrassment to his family.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: WILKIE BUSBY, 72, OF LAW FIRM HERE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 Wilkie Bushby, a partner In the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, and its prede cessors, since 1928, died Fri day here. He was 72 years old and lived in Deer Park, Conn.

title: New York and Philadelpha Triumph In Lacrosse Games
description: The New York and Phila delphia Lacrosse Clubs toppled foes from Baltimore yesterday.

title: Charity Takes to the Rails
description: HARTFORD, April 5What do you do if your charity isn't as glamorous, chic and social as others? In this 335 yearold city, intersected by the Connecticut River, you take over the 19thcentury Union railroad station, redec orate it with a Victorian atmosphere and get some instant glamour of your own.

title: Boeing Cuts Back
description: SEATTLE, April 5 (AP)The Boeing Company said this weekend that its work force in the Seattle area declined by 4,000 in March.

title: SAIGON'S INFANTRY REPORTED TO RAID FOE IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 6South Viet namese troops penetrated neer ly 10 miles into Cambodia yes terday, reliable military sources said today.

title: State to Train 150 Clerks For Jobs Held by Police
description: ALBANY, April 5A 26week training program has been developed by the State Labor Department's Division of Em ployment to free more New York City policemen, for laiv enforcement duties.

title: Lumber Price Rises Called Inevitable
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 5 Lumber prices, depressed for almost a year, have started to firm and probably will be steeply higher by the end of this year.

title: Building of Public Schools Declines in Cost in State
description: ALBANY, April 5 (AP)  The New York State Depart ment of Education reports that the cost of building pubile schools in New York dropped slightly for the six months from September, 1969, to March, 1970.

title: COLONEL DEFENDS RECALL OF EDITOR
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 6 (Reu ters)  Col. William V. Koch, the editor in chief of the author ized American Army newspaper, Stars and Stripes, the Pacific edition, said here today the newspaper's Saigon bureau chief would be reassigned to Tokyo later this week as a routine change.

title: NETS DOWN PACERS AS DOVE SCORES 32
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) The New York Nets beat the Indiana Pacers, 10499, today. It marked the fourth loss in the last five games for the Pacers, who already have clinched the American Basket ball Association's Eastern Division title.

title: Arctic Pipeline Test Promises Wide Boon
description: INUVIK, Northwest Terri tories, Canada, March 29 An experiment that could bear on the cost of home heat, industrial fuel and gas oline for millions of Ameri cans is being conducted two miles outside this Western Arctic town at the top of the North American continent, where the sea will be frozen until June.

title: Vice Chairman of Board At General Motors Retires
description: General Motors Corporation has announced that George Russell, vice charman and chairman of its finance com mittee, has retired after more than 42 years with the auto mobile maker.

title: NEW YORK CRUSHES RED WINGS, 9 TO 5
description: With one of their most im portant and strongest victories in their lossstrewn 44year ca reer, the Rangers wedged their way last night into the Stanley Cup playoffs on the final day of the tightest race in National Hockey League history.

title: SUDAN REBELS DENY UPRISING IS CRUSHED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 5 Supporters of Imam elHadi Ahmed elMandi, the religious leader of a Moslem sect in the Sudan who was killed last week after his uprising against the Government was crushed, said that the outbreak was larger than the Government had ad mitted and that fighting was continuing.

title: Spoken French of Quebec Not Bad, a Parisian Holds
description: MONTREAL (AP)The French spoken in Quebec is not bad just because it is differ ent from that spoken in France, according to Yves Rey Herme, director of the summer school of tht Allianct Franaise in Paris.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: LAWRENCE VICTOR AT KUALA LAMPUR
description: KUALA LUMPUR, April 5 (AP)  Graeme Lawrence of New Zealand, maneuvering through 25 minutes of driving rain, won his second straight Selangor Grand Prix auto race today.

title: Angie Brooks Out of Hospital
description: JERUSALEM, April 5 (AP)  Miss Angie Brooks of Liberia, president of the United Nations General Assembly, was dis charged today from Hadassah Hospital here where she spent five days being treat for ton silitis. She came to Israel March 26 for an official visit.

title: How Liberal a Party?
description: The lack of debate, the refusal even to allow, candi dates seeking endorsement to speak, the secret deci sions carefully worked out by private conference among the very fewall this combined at the Liberal party's nominating convention over the weekend to turn its proceedings into a mockery of democracy.

title: TAIWAN IS PLANNING FARM POLICY SHIFT
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 5A new agricultural policy, stress ing capital investments in farm machinery rather than the tra ditional reliance on human la bor to meet the problems posed by an industrializing economy, was approved by the Kuomin tang, Nationalist China's ruling party, at its annual session here last week.

title: An Unqualified Judge
description: Neither the frantic appeal by the President nor the dogged loyalty of some. Republican Senators has changed the persuasive evidence that Judge G. Harrold Carswell lacks tilequalifications to sit on the Supreme Court. The tactics employed by his supporters in his defense have only underscored the indefensibility of the appointment. Even the hastily solicited signatures of Federal judges in the South seem like a desperate maneuver to offset the refusal by seven out of eight een judges on Judge Carswell's own court to endorse him.

title: Nan Marcus Bride Of Michael Blecker
description: LEONIA, N. J., April 5  Miss Nan Barbara Marcus, daughter of Percy Marcus of Englewood Cliffs and the late Mrs. Rose Fox Marcus, was married here this noon to Michael Jay Blecker, son of Mrs. Benjamin Blecker of Bayonne and the late Mr. Blecker. Rabbi Zelick Block performed the ceremony at Congregation Sons of Israel.

title: BACALLAO TRIUMPHS IN SQUASH TENNIS
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 5 Dr. Pedro A. Bacallao of the Princeton Club retained the United States national squash tennis championship today by rallying to win at the Bronx ville Field Club after losing the first two games.

title: Harlem Pastor Goes Into Street To Ask Drive Against Narcotics
description: The Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, preached his sermon yesterday through a bullhorn while standing on the trunk of a white. Mustang park ed in front of the Teen City pizza parlor at 162 West 116th Street.

title: MRS. JESSE I. STRAUS, WIDOW OF ENVOY, 94
description: Mrs. Irma Nathan Straus, whose husband, Jesse I. Straus, was Ambassador to France from 1933 to 1936, died at her Park Avenue home yesterday. She was 94 years old.

title: Off Broadway Revival Set For Odets' Awake and Sing
description: Clifford Odets's Awake and Sing, which was first pro duced on Broadway in 1935, will be revivied off Broadway at the end of May at the Twin Arts Theater on West 38th Street between 8th and 9th Avenues. Previews will begin May 11.

title: SCHERMAN LEADS UNUSUAL WORKS
description: Thomas Scherman's Little Orchestra was littler than usual for its concert last night in Alice Tully Hall. The reasons were entirely musical ones, for Mr. Scherman, with his cus tomary enterprise, had un earthed four unusual works all requiring reduced orchestral forces.

title: Slot Machine Unprofitable
description: SEVENOAKS, England (UPI) John Barrluck, a pub owner, says he is returning his slot machine to its manufacturer because it keeps paying out jackpots to one of his cus tomers, a retired police sergeant.

title: Article 3  No Title
Endless Chain on City Pay
description: The vote that 28,000 patrolmen start taking tomor row on whether to authorize illegal job action against the city represents an ominous new phase in a scandalous miscarriage of municipal collective bargaining.

title: Romansky Wins Walk
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J. April 5 (AP)Dave Romansky of Penns ville, N. J., won the Capt. Ronald Zinn Memorial 10mile walk to day on the boardwalk. His time of 1 hour 10 minutes 54.2 sec onds bettered his own mark of 2:05:00 for the event. Ron Daniel of the New York Ath letic Club was second. His teammate, Ron Kulik, was third.

title: Kidnapped German Envoy Found Slain in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, April. 5The body of the West German Ambassador, Count Karl von Spreti, was found by villagers in an abandoned but on a dusty mountain road near the small town of San Raimundo this evening.

title: Green With Envy Is Hunter Victor At North Salem
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., April 5  Jessica Fleischmann's Green With Envy captured both classes over fences to win the regular working hunt er championship  his second title in two weeks  at the North Salem Lions horse show today.

title: Gary Player's 65 for 271 Wins by Two Strokes
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5 Gary Player of South Africa, who has been winning golf tournaments in the United States since 1958, passed Ar nold Palmer and three others in the fourth round today and won the Greater Greensboro open by two strokes.

title: Penn Takes Sailing Regatta
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 5 Penn won six of nine races to day and captured team honors in a Middle Atlantic Intercolle giate Sailing Association regat ta on the Hudson River.

title: GAELIC FOOTBALL
description: Down (0 goals, 9 points) 9, Louth (07) 7. Kildare (28) 14, Wexford (04) 4.

title: U.S. Says Unemployment Here Rose in 1969 as It Fell in 19 Other Big Cities.
description: The average number or un employed workers here in creased by 0.5 per cent in 1969 after a period of which the average number of the jobless had been declining, according to a Bureau of Labor Statistics study.

title: Arson Hits San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (UPI)One of the longest strings of arson fires in the pity's history42 in the last 11 days  kept firemen and arson squad investigators busy today. Four manimade blazes occurred during the night, ac cording to Robert Gerhon, arson investigator.

title: Donnie Allison Wins at Bristol, Beating His Brother by 3 Laps
Artificial Leg Holds Drugs
description: ST. LOUIS (AP)The police examined the artificial leg of and said they found in it syringe, a needl eand a pack age of powder believed to be narcotics. Mr. O'Gorman was booked on suspicion of nar cotics wialation. The police kept the leg and issued him a crutch.

title: TV: Sensitive Look at Generation Gap
description: ADELICATE and moving exposition of the gener ation gap within the context of religious values was writ ten by Robert Crean, the playwright, and presented yesterday afternoon by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and the National Broadcasting Company. With out raising his voice, Mr. Crean achieved the major ac complishment of suggesting how ideals do pass from parents to children, although each generation must try to realize them in its own way. There was a haunting beauty to his suggestion that so much misunderstanding may stem from confusing enduring goals with changing methods.

title: AntiCarswell Vote Today Likely to Fail
description: WASHINGTON, April 5A move to sidetrack the nomina tion of Judge G. Harrold Cars well to the Supreme Court is expected to fail tomorrow in the Senate.

title: Ulbricht Returns to Germany
description: BERLIN, April 5 (Reuters) Walter Ulbricht, head of the East German Communist party, and Premier Willi Stoph re turned here from Budapest to day, the A.D.N., East German press agency, reported. They had attended celebrations mark ing the 25th anniversary of the liheration of Hungary in World! War II.

title: TALKS CONTINUE ON PRINTER PACT
description: Negotiations on new con tracts between union employes and the city's four major news papers continued yesterday without any announced prog ress.

title: Law Enforcement Officers Less Upset at Court Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Big city law enforcement officers are becoming less disturbed by the Supreme Court's rein on their conduct toward suspects, despite new evidence that crime has been steadily out stripping their capacity to con trol it.

title: PLANNERS ADVISE SUBSTANTIAL AID TO BETTER QUEENS
description: Faced with steady growth in population and industry, the borough of Queens will require substantial public investment and careful rezoning to main tain its present residential qual ity, according to the City Plan ning Commission.

title: ROY O. EASTMAN
description: Roy O. Eastman, who retired 10 years ago as head of the Eastman Research Organiza tion, publishers' consultants here, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla: He was 87 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Heads of 3 Major Religious Organizations Urge Congress to Pass Welfare Reform Bill
description: The executive heads of three major religious organizations joined in commending yester day the welfare reform bill now before Congress and urged both houses to pass it.

title: Pole Takes Saber Event, But Soviet Wins Tourney
description: WARSAW, April 5 (AP) Jerzy Pawlowski of Poland, an Olympic gold medalist, won an international saber match to day, defeating Victor Sidiak of the Soviet Union, the world champion.

title: Without Prince, Sihanoukville's Fate Is Uncertain
description: SIHANOUKVILLE, Cambodia, April 2The future of this small seaport, which Prince Norodom Silhanouk named af ter himself and tried to make into a Rivieralike resort, is not a cheerful one.

title: NEW ROLE URGED FOR BLACK CHURCH
description: DETROIT, April 5Delegates to the first convention of the Black Christian Nationalist movement here vowed today to work to align the traditionally strong Negro church with the growing nationalist feeling of black Americans and to make the curch a primary revolu tionary force for the liberation of black people.

title: Personal Finance: Clear Auto Titles Urged for State
description: Car drivers in New York State might focus their head lights on a couple of bills now pending in Albany that could save them moneyand quite a few headaches.

title: Turkish Leader Promises To Rebuild City Hit by Quake
description: GEDIZ, Turkey, April 5 (Reu ters)A weeping President Cevdet Sunay today promised to rebuild this western Turkish town in which 1,087 persons were killed by an earthquake last weekend.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1970

title: Chang Wins Formosa Golf
description: LINKOU, Formosa, April 5 (AP)Chang ChungFa of For mosa soared to a 4overpar 76 today but still won the China open golf tournament with 215 for 54 holes.

title: MET RAISES PRICES FOR COMING SEASON
description: The Metropolitan Opera an nounced yesterday it has raised admission prices for next sea son because of higher costs re sulting in part from a contract settlement reached in December with the company's personnel. The last such general increase was four years ago.

title: BRITISH RUGBY RESULTS; (Reuters)
description: Doncaster 7, Featherstone Rovers 19. Halifax 5, Leeds 7. Horton 8, Batley 8.

title: BRUINS PLACE 2D WITH 31 VICTORY
description: BOSTON, April 5 (UPI) Thirdperiod goals by Derek Sanderson and Ken Hodge, scored only 68 seconds apart, gave the Boston Bruins a 31 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

title: Arbor Day in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 5 (UPI)President Chung Hee Park and Government officials planted some 9,000 saplings on a hill near Seoul today to mark the nation's 25th annual Arbor Day.

title: Ecuadorian Consul Held On Drug Smuggling Charge
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (UPI)  The Ecuadorian consul in Philadelphia was held on charges of smuggling narcotics today after his embassy refused to post his bail.

title: WIFE SUES IN DEATH OF CAPETOWN IMAM
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 5The widow of the Moslem community leader in Capetown who died while being detained by the police last year is claiming $31,000 in damages from the Ministers of Police and Justide.

title: Chaparrals Defeat Stars On Combs Shots, 131127
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5 (UPI) Glenn Combs hit four free throws and a field goal late in the fourth period to give the Dallas Chaparrals a 131127 victory over the Los Angeles Stars in the American Basket ball Association today.

title: Sprung Displays Champion's Finesse In Banjo Concert
description: Fresh from his triumph at last month's Old Time Fiddlers Convention at Union Grove, N. C., where he was pro claimed World's Champion Banjo Player, Roger Sprung gave a lively and informal con cert yesterday afternoon at the McBurney Young Men's Chris tian Association, 215 West 23d Street.

title: 101 Victory Caps Yanks' Best Spring
Manila Police Break Up March on U.S: Embassy
description: MANILA, April 5  Riot squads using tear gas and rifle butts dispersed about a thous aind demonstrators today as they reached within 80 yards of the United States Embassy here after an afternoon student labor rally downtown.

title: Gilda CruzRomo Top Winner In Metropolitan Opera Audition
description: Gilda CruzRomo, a soprano from Fort Worth, Tex., won the top cash award of $2,500 last night in the finals of the Metro politan Opera National Coun cil's 1969 regional, audition at the Metropolitan Opera House. Rudolf Bing the Metropolitan's general manager, made the award onstage at the conclu sion of a long evening of singing and cheering, and im mediately offered Miss Cruz Romo a Met contract.

title: Israel Rejects Bid By Zionist Leader For Nasser Parley
description: JERUSALEM, April 5The Israeli Government tonight re jected a bid by Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, to ac cept what he said was an ap parent invitation to confer with President Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Socialist Labor Convention Chooses Statewide Slate
description: The Socialist Labor party, a Marxist party founded in 1890, yesterday nominated Stephen Emery, of Jamaica, Queens, a subway dispatcher, for Gover nor, and John Emanuel, a Man hattan fur worxer, for United States Senator.

title: Teaching Times Announced
description: SASKATOON, Saskatchewan (Canadian Press)The staffs of Saskatchewan's high schools spent 76 per cent of their time teaching in 1969, com pared to 88 per cent in Regina high schools.

title: Books of The Times
description: HIGH up on a remaining wall of that bombedout house on 11th Street in Manhattan, one can make out the remains of what must once have been a comfortable den. Where the third floor used to be suspended grotesquely above rubble reminiscent of Berlin after World War II, there is a fireplace flanked by bookshelves built into the wall. On the Shelves rest the charred but still intact remains of a hundred or so volumes.

title: HAWKS WIN, 102, AND FINISH FIRST
Joan S. Elbaum Is Bride Here
description: In the Park Avenue Syna gogue yesterday, Miss Joan S. Elbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Elbaum of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Harold Lewis Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Gordon of New York and Mahopac, N. Y. Rabbi Judah Nadich per formed the ceremony.

title: The Pearl Happy to Let Mate Carry Load in Bullets Victory
description: BALTIMORE, April 5For change, Earl Monroe was not at the front of the Baltimore Bullets offense today as they evened their National Basket ball Association playoff series against the New York Knicks with a 9687 victory.

title: Quintuplets' New Home Is All but Completed
description: LIBERTY CORNERS, N. J., April 5 (UPI) With a little help, the William Kienast family nearly finished their barnraising todaybuild ing a larger home.

title: INCENDIARY DEVICE IS FOUND AT Y.W.C.A.
description: A small incendiary device was found yesterday in the West Side Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association at 840 Eighth Avenue, at 50th Street, a residence club for 250 women.

title: The Saga of Yodo
description: Aerial hijackers have written many strange chap ters in aviation's history, but no past incident quite. Matches the exotic saga of Japan Air Lines' Yodo. Almost every element of the classic act of air piracy was given a new twist in this case. This time the hijackers were an organized political group of youths swinging swords; when Yodo landed at Seoul, an effort was made to convince the hijackers they were really in Pyongyang, and finally Japanese Deputy Transport Minister Yamamura courageously offered himself as a hostage to secure release of the passengers.

title: Mideast Lobbies Active in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Days before the official an nouncement, one of the first copies of the Nixon Administra tion's statement turning down Israel's request for more jet fighters was delivered to Max M. Fisher, the Detroit indus trialist.

title: Building Work Resuming On DieselPowered Tankers
description: Work on building four 34, 000 tankers at Pascagoula, Miss., is to be resumed follow ing agreement on a change of power plants between the In Ingalls East division of Litton Industries, the builder of the ships, and the Uower System division of Colt Industries.

title: Reockets Rally to Win, 11298, As Haywood, Wright Excel
description: DENVER, April 5 (AP) Spencer Haywood and Lonnie Wright sparked a secondhalf rally today, leading the Denver Rockets to their 15th consecu tive American Basketball Asso ciation victory at home as they beat the Kentucky Colonels, 11298.

title: East German Guards Haft Man Trying to Flee to West
description: BERLIN, April 5 (Reuters) West Berlin policemen reported that East German border guards today foiled an attempt by a man to escape over the border wall into West Berlin.

title: Dr. Joseph C. Morris, 67, Dies; Physicist and ExTulane Officer
description: Dr. Joseph Chandler Morris, former vice president of Tulane University, died Saturday night at the Biltmore Hotel, where he was attending a meeting of the Council of Library Re sources. He was 67 years old.

title: ORTHODOX CHURCH IN DISPUTE ON L.I.
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., April 5A small Russian Orthodox Church tucked away in the woods near Hempstead Harbor was the scene this morning of services by two groups battling for possession of the building.

title: 27 Ill After Party; Doctor Says LSD Was Put in Snack
description: LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) Twentyseven persons were treated at a hospital today after eating potato chips apparently laced with a hallucinogenic drug at a swinging singles party, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Vermont Legislature Passes Environmental Control Bills
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 5 The Vermont legislature moved toward final adjournment yes terday by passing several en vironmental control and gov ernment reorganization bills proposed by Gov. Deane C. Davis.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
Ronson Had 3Month Loss; Full Year's Earnings Fell
description: The Ronson Corporation had loss of about $1.77million in last year's fourth quarter, fig ures issued yesterday by the company indicate. Ronson said the quarter showed a loss' of 46 cents a share as a result of special charges of $3million. On the basis of 3.86 million shares outstanding, this would amount to $1.77million. Sales rose in the quarter to $27.13 million from $24.89million. Earnings of the cigarette lighter manufacturer in all 1969 fell sharply to $803,000 from 1968's $3.44million. Sales last year slippeed to $94.48million from $98.6million.

title: STEEL REPAIRS SET ON WEST SIDE ROAD
description: About $1million will be spent to repair and reinforce the de teriorated structural steel of the elevated portion of the West Side Highway over the Penn Central's freight yards between 59th and 72d Streets, according to Constantine SidamonEris toff, the city's Transportation Administrator and Arterial Highway Coordinator.

title: Big Brothers Honor Founder
description: CINCINNATI, April 5  Irvin F. Westheimer, founder of the Big Brothers Association of America, was honored here last night at the annual dinner meeting of the local Big Brothers Association. Mr. West heimer, who is 90 years old, was given a plaque in honor of his service in the organiza tion.

title: Une de Mai Wins Trot Before 90,000 in Italy
description: NAPLES, Italy, April 5 (UPI)  Une de Mai set a course record today and then won the 21st Agnano Trot ting Classic before an enthu siastic crowd of 90,000.

title: London: Of Man, Rats and the Absurd
description: LONDONOn March 2, the switchboard of the British Broadcasting Corporation ex perienced a sudden surge of worried, indignant and just plain inquisitive telephone calls from TV viewers. They were jolted by an episode in a new drama series featuring a species of superintelligentrats, originally bred to destroy their fel lows, which had developed a crav ing for human flesh. The series is called Doomwatch.

title: LOS ANGELES CUTS ITS DEFICIT TO 32
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 5 (UPI)Jerry West and Wilt Chamberlain each scored 36 points as the Los Angeles Lak ers trounced the Phoenix Suns, 138121, and cut the Suns lead to 32 in the National Basket ball Association's Western Di vision playoffs tonight. The next game is at Phoenix Tues day night.

title: LAKELAND NAMED BEST AT CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, April 5Ch. Spe cial Edition, a red grizzle and tan Lakeland terrier, gained the bestinshow award tonight at the 30th International Kennel Club show in the Amphitheatre.

title: TEXAS, PENN STATE HEAD TV FOOTBALL
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) Texas, the national champion, and secondranked Penn State, the only major teams with per fect records last year, will ap pear twice each on a 35game 1970 college football telecast schedule announced today by the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Bulls Sign No. 6 Draft Pick
description: CHICAGO, April 6 (AP)The Chicago Bulls today signed Lon nie Kluttz of North Carolina A. & T., their No. 6 choice in the National Basketball Associ ation draft.

title: 100 Cornell Negro Students Loot New Campus Store as Payment for the Burning of Black Studies Center
description: TIEACA, N. Y., April 6 About 100 black students made a brief invasion of the new Cornell University Campus Store today, carrying off cloth ing, rock records and books as payment for the black stu dies center that burned down during the Easter recess last week.

title: Nassau Democrats Meet to Pick Federal and State Candidates
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 6  The Nassau Democratic County convention met at the Garden City Hotel tonight to nominate candidates for Conpress and the Legislature.

title: NETS PICK SEAVER TO FACE PIRATES
description: The New York Metsthe only team in major league base ball that has never won an opening gamewill open their title defense this afternoon in Pittsburgh against the Pirates.

title: ARTHUR J. BLANK
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 6Arthur J. Blank, a lawyer, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 991 Plymouth Street, Pelham Manor. N.Y.

title: The Screen: Marguerite Duras's Destroy, She Said
description: I'M not sure that I can rea sonably explain the pleas ure I take in Marguerite Duras's Destroy, She Said, much of which I find un endurable, but an explana tion on some level is worth trying.

title: Colts Promote McCafferty to Head Football Coach as the Successor to Shula
description: BALTIMORE, April 6 (UPI) Don McCafferty, a softspoken and popular assistant coach, was named head coach of the Baltimore Colts today by Car roll Rosenbloom, the club owner.

title: Widening Support for the Arts Seen
description: A note of guarded opti mism for the future of the arts in the United States was sounded here yesterday by the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and by two Congressmen.

title: Pattern of Prices
Government Briefs Minority Businesses
description: Several hundred represen tatives of ethnicminority business enterprises were giv en an opportunity yesterday to question Government offi cials about the problems of obtaining Federal contracts for goods and services.

title: Korvette Planning a Store At Mall in Levittown, L.I.
description: The Korvette division of Spartans Industries, Inc., will open its sixth Long Island de partment store in Nassau Mail, a new regional shopping center to be built in Levittown. The new 170,000squarefoot store will be Korvette's first Long Island unit in a regional shop ping center and its first in an allweather, enclosed mall.

title: Event to Aid Asthma Unit
description: The Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hos pital at Denver will benefit from a luncheon In the Trianon Ballroom at the New York Hilton on Saturday. Four hundred guests are expected to attend the 14th annual event sponsored by the beneficiary's Riverdale Chapter, of which Mrs. Mort Mandel is president.

title: Long Russian Space Flights
description: BUDAPEST, April 6 (AP)Maj. Gen. Georgy T. Beregovoy of the Soviet air force told newsmen here today that the Russians were preparing spacemen for flights that would last up to several months, which meant some extremely tricky health problems, including loss of body fluid, muscle inertia and food intake.

title: Catledge Is Honored At Awards Dinner Of Silurian Society
description: The Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran newspapermen, honored Turner Catledge of The New York Times at its annual awards dinner in the Americana Hotel last night. Mr. Catledge, who served for nearly two decades as the chief news executive of the newspaper, is retiring on April 30.

title: Israelis Welcomes Protester
description: TEL AVIV, April 6 (AP)More than 200 Israeli students turned out at Iydda airport today to welcome Yasha Kazakov, the Moscowborn Israeli who held a hunger strike outside United Nations headquarters in New York to dramatize his demand that the Soviet Government allow his family to emigrate to Israel.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS A FAMILY CEILING FOR WELFARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Supreme Court ruled today, to 3, that it is not unconstitu tional for states to set limits on the amount of welfare bene fits that any family may, col lect.

title: Atlantic Avenue Development
description: There is a fairsized communications gap between New York and Albany, and it isn't going to be helped by the bill that would create an Atlantic Avenue De velopment Authority. This legislative sleeper, which breezed through the Senate and is due for considera tion by the Assembly tomorrow, came as an unwel come surprise to city officials, planners and local communities.

title: Selina S. Croll Future Bride Of A. C. Bellas
description: The engagement of Miss Selina (Tina) Schroeder Croll to Albert Constantine Bellas has been announced by her parents, Joseph D. Croll and Mrs. William C. Breed Jr., both of New York. Mr. Bellas is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine M. Bellas of Steubenville, Ohio, where his father is president of the Bellas Company, wine im porters. Mr. Croll is a limited partner of Asiel & Co., stock brokers here.

title: Expos Option Hahn
description: CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP) The Montreal Expos announced today they have optioned Don Hahn, an outfielder, to Buffalo of the International League to get down to the 25 player limit.

title: Illinois to Get Antiwar Bill
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 6 (UPI)Legislation authorizing Illinois servicemen to refuse duty in the Vietnam war will be introduced next week in th General Assembly. The bill, patterned after a ??milar one passed in Massachusetts last week, will be introduced in thel House by Representative Robert E. Mann. Democratic og Chi cago.

title: ATTACKS ON PRESS IN AMERICAS DECRIED
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 6 (AP)  Editors and publishers belonging to the InterAmerican Press Association were told today that freedom of press in the Western Hemisphere is at the lowest ebb since World War II.

title: Autopsy on Black Panther
description: CINCINNATI, April 6 (UPI) Homicide detective were await ing today an autopsy report to learn the cause of death of a reputed Black Panther member whose bound and gagged body was found in the attic of a con demned house. The authorities said Turner Williams Jr., 36 years old, had been stabbed 16 times and marks on his neck. indicated he had been strangled.

title: Businessmen Support Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Committee for Economic De velopment expressed strong support today for the Nixon Administration's welfare re form plan, on which a House vote is expected this week.

title: Group to Install Officers
description: The newly elected officers of the Jewish State Employes As sociation of New York will be installed April 29 at the State Office Building. 80 Centre Street. The officers include Sylvia Miller, president, and Irving Gelb, Benjamin Kramer, Gladys Stricoff and Mollie Goldstein, vice presidents.

title: CREDIT MARKETS BEGIN TO FALTER
description: The bond market started to falter yesterday. Prices de clined and new issues of corpo rate and tax  exempt bonds failed to attract investors.

title: U. of Pennsylvania to Back G.M. ConsumerAid Action
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6 Tht investment committee of the University of Pennsylvania unanimously voted today to support the consumeroriented proposals of the Washington based project for Corporate Re sponsibility.

title: Negro Explorer Of Pole Honored In City Ceremony
description: One of the first men to walk on the moon paid tribute yes terday to Matthew A. Henson, the Negro exptore, ?? in Admiral Robert E. Peary's ex pedition, was one of the first men to set foot on the North Pole on April 6, 1909.

title: RETIRED POLICEMEN RETURNING TO DUTY
description: Sixtythree retired members of the police force, ranging from sergeant to inspector, re turned to duty yesterday to take advantage of an opportu nity to earn higher pensions.

title: French Press Move for Broad Indochina Parley
description: PARIS, April 6French dip lomats have been active in number of capitals to advance the proposal by France last Wednesday for general peace negotiations involving all the countries concerned with Indo china.

title: After Lean Years, French Bull G.E. Reports a Profit
description: PARIS, April 6With its newly specialized product line and an intensified cost account ing program, Machines Bull, the French Company, has reported a profit for the first time since the stunning G.E. takeover in mid1964.

title: Pollution Curbs Fishing in Ontario
description: TORONTO, April 6 (Cana dian Press)  The Ontario government today ordered the suspension of all com mercial and sports fishing in the Detroit River, Lake St. Clair, St. Clair River and the

title: Air Controllers on the Job Feel Loyalty to Two Sides
description: The current sick walkout by members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organi zation has placed a strain on fellow PATCO workers who have stayed on the job, in the opinion of two New York area controllers. But it is a strain on loyalties rather than job pres sure.

title: Kopechne Jury, Enjoined to Secrecy, Opens Inquiry
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., April 6 A grand jury of 10 men and 10 women, sternly enjoined to secrecy, opened today an inves tigation of the death of Mary Jo Kopechne. The jury began call ing witnesses this afternoon.

title: Aim Is to Avert Strike
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 The Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare voted unani mously today to impose a new contract on 48,000 railroad shoperaft workers, rather than run the risk of a national rail shutdown next weekend.

title: LTV Aerospace Contract
description: DALLAS, April 6 (UPI)The TV Aerospace Corporation said today its Service Technology subsidiary had received a three year $3million subcontract from the Jet Propulsion Labora tory to provide engineering sup port services to the laboratory's deep space instrumentation facility in Goldstone, Calif.

title: Civil Service Pact Approved
description: ALBANY, April 6 (AP)The Civil Service Employes Associ ation, which represents the bulk of state workers, an nounced today overwhelming approval by its members of twoyear contract that will in crease individual salaries by at elast $1,275.

title: Benefit Lunch Set For Daycroft School
description: The eighth annual fashion show and luncheon to bene fit the scholarship fund of the Daycroft School in Greenwich, Conn., will be held at the Pierre at 12:30 P.M. on Thursday. Mrs. Ar thur B. Colwin and Mrs. Louis Wheeler are cochair men for the event, which will include a showing of Adele Simpson's spring and summer collections. Tickets at $12.50 each may be ob tained from Mrs. Alfred A. Meyer, 301 East 78th Street, or at the door of the hotel's Grand Ballroom at luncheon time.

title: Problems Accompany the Gains of Canadian Arctic's Eskimos and Indians
description: TUKTOYAKTUK, Northwest TerritoriesWilly Felix, who is 19 years old, is a blocker in the Tuk Fur Garment factory.

title: Airco in Expansion Move
description: The Air Reduction Company, which in February announced its intent to sell its Airco chem icals and plastics division, said yesterday it plans to build a $2million plant to double its annual production of vinyl ethylene emulsions. Airco pres ident, George S. Dillon, said the latest announcement under scores the company's policy to maintain the division as an et fective and ongoing business until it is sold.

title: Bridal Planned By Sheri Perl
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., April 6Herman Perl, board chair man of Intercontinental Real ty, Ltd., and Mrs. Perl have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheri Peri, to Leonard J. Gannet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Gannet. Both families are of Short Hills. The wedding is planned for Aug. 29.

title: UNICEF Receives $7Million
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6A check for $7,626,000 for UNICEF, the United Na tion's Children's Fund, was ac cepted at ceremonies here to day by Secretary General Thant. Th sum included contributions from doortodoor collections by American schoolchildren at Halloween, income from the sale of greeting cards and gifts to help Nigerian war victims.

title: Limiting the Subpoena
description: Our liberty, said Thomas Jefferson, depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost.

title: JACK KRONER, 44, LAW PROFESSOR
description: Jack L. Kroner, a professor of labor law at New York Uni versity, died Sunday, apparent ly of a heart attack, at his home, 110 Bleeker Street. He was 44 years old.

title: In The Nation: Crime and the Courts
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Ford Foundation recently made grants totaling $1 million for studies of the public's confi dence in the American judicial process. Such confidence, Mc George Bundy, the foundation's president, described as essen tial to the maintenance of both liberty and order in a demo cratic society.

title: WARRANT ISSUED FOR RUDD ARREST
description: A bench warrant was issued here yesterday for the arrest of Mark Rudd, a leader of the Weatherman faction of Stu dents for a Democratic. Society, when he failed to show up for a Criminal Court trialbut his $2,500 bail was freed for return to his father.

title: Columbia Pictures Elects
description: Howard H. Buhse, chairman of the executive committee of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, has been elected a direc tor of Columbia Pictures Indus tries, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Abraham Schnei der, chairman. He fills the va cancy on the board left recently by the late Ben Regan, who also was a partner of Hornblower.

title: Russell Casts a Vote
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, returned to the Capitol today for the first time since entering Walter, Reed Army Hospital for em physema treatment on March 4. The dean of the Senate came to cast a vote against recommit ting the Supreme Court nomi nation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Senate Judi ciary Committee.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Visit City
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will fly to New York Sunday to at tend the evening opening of a new American Wing exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She will return to Wash ington after the ceremonies opening 23 galleries that in clude a concentration of 19th century furniture, similar to furnishings in the White House.

title: Market Place
description: IT was blue Monday with a vengeance for the little guy on ?? Street yester day. The ?? transaction charge went into effect  amid mountains of confusion. And, meanwhile, Burnham & Co. announced that it would begin charging customers $50 every six months they didn't do enough business to gen erate that much in fees for Burnham.

title: Archives Charged With Suppressing Assassination Data
description: CHICAGO, April 6 (AP)A suit charging the National Ar chives in Washington with sup pressing documents concerning an alleged plot to assassinate President Kennedy in Chicago was filed today in Federal Dis trict Court.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CONCORD, N. H.  A cen tury ago when the New Hampshire Fish and Game Commission was formed, its first major assignment was to bring the Atlantic salmon back to the Connecticut River.

title: CHANGES PLANNED ON ATLANTIC AVE
description: Responding to sharp criticism from political and community opponents, State Senator Wal daba H. Stewart proposed yes terday a series of amendments to his Atlantic Avenue Develop ment Authority bill, limiting the scope of the controversial renewal project in central and downtown Brooklyn.

title: Bridge
description: A NEW YORK contingent of 100 players came home empty handed from the American Bridge Associa tion's Spring National Cham pionships in Cincinnati. The association, a primarily Negro body, ended its tournament Sunday at the SheratonGib son Hotel, and almost all the major titles went to Ohio players.

title: Weak Glamour Stocks
description: Just as Wall Street began be lieving that the bear market had finally ended, a wave of selling shifted into the socalled glamour stocks, those issues that somehow had been able to maintain super priceearnings ratios in the face of adversity elsewhere in the market.

title: 11 Hemingway StoriesCub to Giant
description: When Ernest Hemingway began his apprenticeship on The Kansas City Star on Oct. 1, 1917, the 18yearold cub reporter was handed a style sheet with four basic rules: Use short sentences. Use short first paragraphs. Use vigorous English. Be positive, not negative.

title: BANKS EARNINGS GAIN IN QUARTER
description: Earnings reports from the nation's largest banks started to come in yesterday, showing higher net incomes for the first quarter, but markedly lower profit margins because of soar ling interest payments.

title: Correspondence Unit Added
description: The National Institute for Better Reading, Inc., Bellmore, L. I., a seller and distributor of homestudy, office and schoolroom training and teach ing systems, announced yester day the formation of a corre spondence school division to be called the National Institute of Home Study.

title: Defiant Israel Tennis Body Decides to Play Rhodesia
description: TEL AVIV, April 6 (UPI)  The Israeli Lawn Tennis Associ ation decided today to go against the Gvernment and meet Rhodesia in the Davis Cup next month. But where the series would be played was uncertain.

title: Heart Group Plans A Dance in Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 6The Morris County Heart Association will celebrate its 20th anniversary with a dinner dance at the Gover nor Morris Hotel here on Saturday. Representative and Mrs. Peter H. B. Frelinghuy sen are honorary chairman for the invitational event. Mrs. E. Bruce Hallett is chairman.

title: Pompidou Opposes Ad And L'Express Is Late
description: PARIS, April 6The dis tribution of the weekly mag azine L'Express was delayed today by official objections to a page of advertising that made President Pompidou ap pear to be endorsing an out board motor.

title: Gail Warren Thayer Betrothed To Michael John Candela Jr.
description: RYE, N.Y., April 6Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Thayer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail War ren Thayer, to Michael John Candela Jr., son of Mrs. Joseph Nickerson of West wood, Mass., and the late Mr. Candela.

title: $6.9MILLION CACHE OF HEROIN IS SEIZED
description: A 24pound cache of pure heroin, which police estimated would have brought a total of $6.9million in street sales, was seized yesterday in a Bronx apartment whose occupant was accused of being a courier.

title: Vietcong Seize 2 Japanese Newsmen in Cambodia
description: CHIPHOU, Cambodia, April 6  Two Japanese television newsmen were captured by the Vietcong well inside Cambodia today during the Government sponsored tour to show to for eign correspondends the extent of Vietnamese Communist penetration into this country.

title: Kind Words for Agnew Surprise N.A.B.
description: CHICAGO, April 6Sched led and unscheduled happen ings enlivened the first session of the National Association of Broadcasters convention here today.

title: Cabinet Veto of a GoldmannNasser Meeting Decried in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, April 6The Israeli Government came under sharp internal attack today for rejecting a reported proposal for a meeting between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress.

title: MARCH PRICES UP AT WHOLESALE
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) Wholesale prices increased twotenths of 1 per cent in March, or twice the amount in dicated by preliminary figures released two weeks ago. De spite the higherthanexpected increase, it was still the smallest gain since September.

title: Unblocking the Airways
description: The principal effect of the twoweekold disruption of air traffic by sick air controllers has been to make clear the insubstantiality of many of their grievances. The recent postal stoppage was just as illegal as the controllers' stayaway from their Federal jobs, but the mailmen did make the country aware of how shabbily the Administration and Congress had treated them on wages.

title: Advertising: More objections to Rate Cuts
description: The publisher of Good Housekeeping, who has had a thing or two to say recent ly about advertising rate cutting, has gone further in to the subject as a result of last Friday's column.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Cambodian Leaders. Struggle to Dig Themselves
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 6Prince Norodom Sihanouk is a difficult act to follow, but the leaders who deposed him as Chief of State are still holding the stage three weeks later.

title: RCA Repair Service Picks Carl Ally, Inc.
description: The newly formed RCA operation, which is expected to become a nationwide TV repair service, may not have a name yet, but it's got an ad agencyCarl Ally, Inc.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: MISS FORTNA WINS 2D SLALOM CROWN
description: ROVANIEMI, Finland, April 6 (A.P)Rosea Fortna of War ren, Vt., won her second event at the World University Games today by capturing the wom en's giant slalom at Phyaetun turi.

title: DOMINICAN SCHOOLS SHUT BY PRESIDENT
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domin lican Republic, April 6Presi dent Joaquin Balaguer today closed all urban public schools for two months to reduce stu dent agitation against his plans to run for reelection.

title: Upstate Banks Plan Merger
description: Two upstate savings banks, with combined assets of about $87million, are planning to merge, the New York State Banking Department disclosed yesterday. The move, reflecting a general trend toward consoli dation of small savings banks, would unite the $16million St. Lawrence County Savings Bank, Ogdensburg, and the $71milion Watertown Savings Bank. The combined concern would be called the Upstate Bank for Savings.

title: Thant Goes to Asia Today
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aprli 6  Secretary General Thant will leave tomorrow on a nineday visit to the Philippines and Japan. He will receive an honorary degree from the University of the Philippines and will attend Expo '70 in Osaka, Japan, on United Nations Day.

title: BREWERS WIN DAY AS BEER RUNS 2D
description: MILWAUKEE, April 6Brew ery signs still outnumber Brew ers' signs in this beer producing city, but Schlitz and Miller High Life had to take second place to Dave Bristol and Lew Krausse today in satisfying the appetites of baseball thirsty fans.

title: New Enemy Assaults Reported But Allies Initiate Most Combat
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6Four enemy ground as saults were reported by allied spokesmen in the last 36 hours. In addition, 41 enemy shelling attacks were reported for the 24hour period ending at 8 A.M.

title: Tananbaum Left $5Million
description: Martin Tananbaum, for 14 years president of Yonkers Raceway, left an estate esti mated at $5million, according to an application for probate of his will filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Tanan baum lived in Great Neck, L. I., and maintained a suite at the Beekman Hotel, where he died last March 24 at the age of 54. The bulk of the estate was left in trust to two daughters, Mrs. Peter Brock, 20, and Barbara E. Tananbaum, 19, both of Great Neck.

title: Poetry Festival Sunday
description: The Eastern Center of the Poetry Society of London, in association with World Poets Resources, will sponsor a festi val from 2 P.M. to 5 P.M. Sun day at the Downtown Commu nity School, 235 East 11th, Street. Participants will include young poets from this country, England and Canada. The festi val is intended as the first of an annual series.

title: BONN REDUCES TIES WITH GUATEMALA
description: BONN, April 6  The West German Government, shocked and infuriated by the murder of Count Karl von Spreti, its am bassador in Guatemala, moved swiftly today to reduce to bare minimum its diplomatic relations with Guatemala.

title: Providence & Worcester Would Quit Penn Central
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 6 (AP)  The Providence & Worcester Railroad announced today it wants to separate it self from the Penn Central and become an independent short line railroad.
