title: No Decision on F5's, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  State department officials say that no decision has been made on supplying eight more F5 jet aircraft to Libya. They were contracted for last June.

title: BALLET ORCHESTRA AUTHORIZES STRIKE
description: The New York City Ballet orchestra has authorized its negotiating committee, dead locked in labor talks with the ballet management since No vember, to call a strike if became necessary, the musi cians' attorney said yesterday.

title: Thursday Night Fights
description: TokyoKoichi Wajima, 153 pounds, Japan, outpointed George Carter, 153, Chicago, 10 rounds.

title: CALM AND BALANCE NARK MOORE DANCE
description: Jack Moore is a choreog rapher who combines mystica calm with muscular balance and last night at the Manhat tan School of Music he pre sented the New York premiere of his threepart dance Rocks, a piece for six girls and three Men, which he originally showed three years ago at Ben nington College.

title: Uncertainty in Church
description: Few thinkers have had as much influence on the religious life of recent years as Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the German Prot estant theologian. Executed by the Nazis for participating in a plot to kill Hitler, Bonhoeffer died before he could put his ideas into systematic form. In his letters from prison and other writings, however, he ar gued that in a modern scientific, culture men were becoming increas ingly capable of solving their problems without reference to traditional religious belief and that what was needed was a radically secular brand of Christianity.

title: British Football Results
description: Football ASSOC. Cup Playoff

title: FRYMAN OF PHILS BEATS PIRATES, 20
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP) Woody Fryman held the Pittsburgh Pirates without a hit for 71/3 innings and fin ished with a fourhitter today as Philadelphia Phillies tri umphed, 20, on Deron John son's tworun homer.

title: CURBS DEFENDED ON BANK HOLDINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 A key staff member of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, while expressing ob jections to some aspects of pending legislation on one bank holding companies, said today that there was a no alter native to enactment of legal re srictions on holding company acquisitions.

title: 89 CIVILIANS SLAIN IN CAMBODIA FIGHT
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 10  At least 89 Vietnamese civilians, including many wom en and children, were killed late last night during what Cambodian military sources de scribed as a Vietnamese Com munist attack on the border vil lage of Prasot.

title: Antiques: The Art of Ancient Italy
description: THE ART OF ANCIENT ITALY, an exhibition of sculpture, frescoes and decorative objects dating as early as the eighth century B.C., is currently being shown at the Andre Emme rich Gallery where contem porary art is usually fea tured.

title: Process Art and the New Disorder
description: AT first glance the cav ornous thirdfloor gallery of the Whitney Museum looks as if Uris Brothers had moved in with a load of raw mat terials for a construction project. Along the room's castwest axis is strewn a vast load of humble but far from modest components huge concrete blocks, steel pipes, 12foot timbers flung down like matchsticks, to cover a 96foot by 16foot tract of floor.

title: Sisco, in Cairo, Declares U.S. Goal Is a Just Peace
description: CAIRO, April 10Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco arrived in Cairo tonight for talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser and other Egyp tians on the complex aspects of a peaceful settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: 5 Convicted War Protesters Refuse to Surrender to Start Terms
description: BALTIMORE, April 10Five war protesters who were con victed of destroying Selective Service records have refused to surrender to the authorities to begin serving their Federal prison sentences.

title: George Washington High Melee Results in Arrests of 13 Students
description: Thirteen students and a par ent were arrested and seven policemen were slightly injured yesterday in a new outbreak of fighting at George Washing ton High School, which has been wracked by disturbances for more than a month.

title: NINE SLATED TO GO IN $57,800 STAKES
description: The Excelsior Handicap, for older horses at a mile and an eighth, will occupy the main spot in the Aqueduct card today. A field of nine has been named for the event, which will have its 62d running. With nine competing, the Excelsior will have a gross value of $57, 800, the winner getting $37, 570.

title: April 15 Is Time of Woe for Tax Men, Too
description: The woman leaned across the table and talked intense ly to Herman. Glass, an ac countant with the Internal Revenue Service here.

title: BRADSHAW, PIANIST, MAKES TULLY DEBUT
description: David Bradshaw, the pianist who made his New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall last night, showed considerable boldness and imagination in perparing a program that fol lowed none of the conventional pattern. It ran as follows: Rachmaninoff's Variations on a Theme of Corelli, Haydn's Sonata No. 60 in C, Balakirev's transcription of Glinka's The Lark, Debussy's L'Isle joye use, Kabalevsky's Sonata No. 3 in F, Schumann's Wald scenen and Godowsky's Symphonic Metamorphosis on Strauss's Wein, Weib, and Gesang.

title: Eino Hiilivirta Fiance Of Miss Oppenheimer
description: Miss Katherine Toni Op penheimer and Eino Ilmari Hiilivirta, a chemical engineer of St. John, Virgin Islands, plan to be married April 25 in Paris. The future bride is a daughter of Mrs. J. Robert Oppenheimer of Princeton, N. J., and St. John, widow of Dr. Oppenheimer, the physi cist, who helped develop the atomic bomb.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Cleveland at New York (2 P.M.) Chance (00) vs. Bahnsen (00).

title: Vote on Abortion
description: ALBANY, April 10Follow ing is the rollcall vote by which the Senate passed the abortion reform bill today.

title: 2,200 at Cornell Meet With Trustees
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 10 In a sharp departure from convention, the board of trustees of Cornell University met today in open forum with 2,200 students and teachers concerned with cam pus racial developments.

title: Firemen Get Into Act As Show Must Go On
description: WIMBOURNE, English (UPI) The cast for the children's pantomime was all assembled for the rehearsalexcept for Mrs. Ruth Parker, cast as the back end of the horse.

title: PEMBERTON QUITS AS A.C.L.U.'S HEAD
description: John de J. Pemberton Jr. an nounced yesterday that he was resigning as executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, the country's leading organization in its field.

title: Consequences of the Carswell Affair
description: LONDONRobert H. Jack son, who lived through the great Roosevelt struggle over the Supreme Court and later became a justice himself, re garded the Court's survival as something of a phenomenon. The Court had been in contro versy again and again in our history, he said. Popular Presi dents attacked it, the public repudiated certain decisions. Yet the institution lived.

title: Sato Warns Japan on GreatPowerism
description: TOKYO, April 10  Premier Eisaku Sato warned the Japa nese people today against greatpowerism. While prais ing the quantitative economic successes of the last decade, he said the nineteenseventies should be devoted to building up social capital and in solving the problems of modern soci ety  high prices, pollution, dehumanization and the gener ation gap.

title: Impasse Snarls Air Traffic for 3d Straight Weekend
description: With air travel curtailed over much of the nation for the third consecutive weekend, there was no sign of a break yesterday in the 17day deadlock between the Federal Aviation Adminis tration and the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organ ization.

title: CASPER AND LUNN TIE FOR 3D PLACE
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 There was one mystery at the Masters golf tournament today, When all the scores were post ed everyone knew that Bert Yancey and Gene Littler shared the 36hole lead over the Au gusta National Golf club course at 139.

title: Truman Portrait Shown At Smithsonian Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The National Portrait Gallery unveiled last night a portrait, painted from life, of Harry S. Truman. The portrait was shown at a reception attended by many members of Mr. Tru man's Cabinet and one of his admirers, former President Lyn don B. Johnson.

title: No Southerner for the Court?
description: President Nixon's angry statement following rejec tion by the Senate of Judge G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court is reminiscentin tone if not in contentof the diatribe Mr. Nixon deliv ered following his defeat in the California guberna torial election of 1962. The kindest interpretation that can be put on his reaction to the Carswell vote is that, once again, he has lost his cool.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 11, 1970

title: House Tours Here to Benefit 2 Schools and a College Club
description: Three house tours here, to day, tomorrow and Tuesday, will raise money for two schools and the Mount Hol yoke Club of New York.

title: Full Professor at 27
description: Wilfred Schmidt, a mathe matics professor at the Univer sity at Berkeley, has been ap pointed to a full professorship at Columbia University. The 27 yearold mathematician, who will be the youngest full pro fessor in the history of the uni versity will begin his teaching duties next fall.

title: Hostetter Still at S.L.A.
description: The retirement of Donald S. Hostetter as chairman of the State Liquor Authority, sched uled to become effective yes terday, has been delayed by the illness of his successor, Thoma F. Ring, Mr. Hostetter said this week. Mr. Ring is ex pected to report within two or three weeks, Mr. Hostetter said.

title: Smith Party Sweeps Rhodesian Election
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 10  The Rhodesian Front party, led by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, was overwhelm ingly returned to power today in elections for a new repub lican parliament.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION EDGES UP IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, April 10 (AP) The tempo of United States auto production picked up a bit this week but output for the year to date still was more than 500,000 cars behind last year's pace.

title: ONE OF HARLEM 6 GUILTY IN RETRIAL
description: Robert Rice, the first of the socalled Harlem Six defend ants to be retried for the 1964 slaying of a Hungarian shop keeper and the knifing of her husband, has again been con victed of firstdegree murder.

title: COLUMBIA GROUP SCORES VIOLENCE
description: Many of Columbia Univer sity's leading scholars and teachers have formed an or ganization of tenured faculty members to fight campus vio lence, which they attribute to the actions of a minuscule group of extremists.

title: Italian Cabinet Wins Vote of Confidence In Senate, 167117
description: ROME, April 10  Premier Mariano Rumor's twoweekold Cabinet won its first vote of confidence in the Italian Sen ate today.

title: Deaths
Dotson in AllStar Game
description: Jim McMillian and Heyward Dotson of Columbia University were among five basketball players who agreed yesterday to play in the Association of Black Athletes college senior allstar game on May 1 in the St. John's University gymnasi um.

title: Books of The Times
description: AS a citizen of the world, Pablo Casals occupies a peace uniquely his own. Even his native Spain that drove him into exile and that he has not seen in more than 30 years is happy to claim him as her own. Venerable age (he is 93) and great musicianship are only part of the story. And this autobiography makes clear how small a part it is. For Casals is incom parably the man of principle, the incarnation of antifascism, the living exile, the conscience of us all. For a musi cian, this auto biography is a remarkable docu ment. It would be for an ordinary citizen, but it is doubly so for a man whose life was music and who had every opportunity for a carefree and comfortable existence. His political commitments and unbending determination to live up to them are blazing light in a stormdarkened world.

title: FINAL APPROVAL OF ABORTION BILL VOTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 10The State Senate, after more than two hours of quiet but emotional debate, voted 31 to 26 today to accept an Assembly bill that strikes the state's 140yearold abortion law from the books.

title: Flasg Destroyer Reinstated
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 10 (UPI)A 16yearold boy, expelled from school because he destroyed an American flag during a speech class, wa or dered reinstated yesterday. Dis trict Judge John Gallagher told the FountainFort Carson High School it would have to re admit Rod Taylor. He was ex pelled on Feb. 10.

title: U.S. UNITS TO REVIEW MEATTUMOR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department has decided to review its long standing regulations allowing beef processors to carve out cancer eye and similar tu mors from cattle and sell the rest of the meat to consumers.

title: Apollo 13
description: For engineers and scientists, the Apollo 13 flight to the moon promises to be the most challenging and, if fully successful, the most productive of all lunar trips so far. Pinpoint navigation will be required for safe landing in the Fra Mauro hills whose rolling ter rain poses many more perils than did the relatively level areas on which Apollo 11 and Apollo 12 landed.

title: New Computer Device
description: A device that will allow the connection of computers with any type of peripheral device was introduced yesterday by the Data Products Group of E. G. & G., Inc. The device, called the 832 Data Interface, uses in terchangeable circuit cards to permit computer control of printers, cathode ray display units and even satellite com puters.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
N.B.A. Playoffs
description: WESTERN DIVISION

title: Upstate Utility Sets Record Expansion
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., April 10Orange and Rock land Utilities, Inc., and its sub sidiaries plan to spend a record total of $135.4million on ex pansion over the next five years, Charles H. Tenney 2d, chairman, told some 225 stock holders at today's annual meeting at the company's head quarters. He indicated that $35million would be spent this year and $100million over the next four years.

title: SNOW SPORTING TOPS FLORIDA FIELD TODAY
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 10 (AP)  Clement L. Hirsch's Snow Sporting will find out tomorrow if grass racing in the United States is as easy as it has been for him on the dirt.

title: Lunar Landing Site a CraterPocked Upland Region
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 When the Apollo 13 astronauts touch down on the moon Wednesday they are expected to land in a gently rolling, craterpocked upland region where the surface has been largely intact for four billion years.

title: Cancer Unit to Gain. At a Dance on L.I.
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 10The Smithtown Unit of the American Cancer Society will welcome 450 guests to morrow to its Jewel Ball, at the SmithHaven Mall on Jericho Turnpike, an event planned for only 400 guests. Tickets to the ball $25 each.

title: The Cast
description: MISSISSIPPI MERMAID, directed by Francois Truffaut; screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Truffaut, based on the novel, Waltz Into Dark ness. by Cornell Woolrich; director of Photography, Deny Clerval; music by Antoine Duhamel; A production of Los Films du Carrosse, Les Productions Artistes Associes and Produzioni Asso ciate Delphos; released by United Artists Corporation. At the 72d Street Playhouse, East of Second Avenue. Run ning time: 123 minutes. (The Motion Picture Association of America's Pro duction Code and Rating Administration classifies this film: GPall ages ad mitted, parental guidance suggested.)

title: Judgment Reserved
description: The brief grand jury investigation into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne has ended with no indictments and no diminution of the mystery surrounding the plunge from a narrow bridge on Chappaquiddick Island last summer of a car driven by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Reserve Bankers Elect
description: Emmett G. Solomon, chairman of the board of the Crocker Citizens National Bank, San Francisco, has been elected pres ident of the Association of Re serve City Bankers. Mr. Solo man, formerly vice president of the association, succeeds R. E. McNeill, chairman of the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Barbara L. McKenna To Marry on July 18
description: PITTSBURGH, April 10 Miss Barbara Louise McKenna and Bruce Wiegand plan to be married July 18 in the Heinz Chapel. Their engage ment has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Mc Kenna, parents of the bride tobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Louis Wiegand Jr.

title: CAPT. MEDINA FACES A HEARING TUESDAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)The Army today ordered hearings to determine if Capt. Ernest L. Medina will be court martialed on charges in con nection with the alleged mas sacre at Songmy, South Viet nam.

title: Judge in School Dispute
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 10  While a student at the University of Florida in the late nineteenthirties, Isaac Benjamin Krentzman Jr. be gan a lasting friendship with a young man named George A. Smathers.

title: Laos Makes Public the Text Of Reply to the Pathet Lac
description: VIENIANE, Laos, April 10 The Laotian Government made public today the text of a letter delivered to the local Pathet Lao representative yesterday in which the Government proposed a ceasefire and the immediate supervised withdrawal of all foreign military forces from Laos.

title: Article 2  No Title
Interior Aide Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Fred J. Russell, 53 years old was sworn in Thursday as Under Secretary of the Interior. He succeeds Russell E. Train, who was appointed chairman of the new President's Council on Environmental Quality last January. Mr. Russell, a fomrer industrialist and real estate de veloper, has been deputy direc tor of the Office of Emergency Preparedness since February, 1969.

title: Apollo 13 Shot Set Today; Substitute Pilot Approved
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10Apollo 13 was cleared to day for launching here tomor row afternoon with a substitute pilot in the spacecraft's center seat for the nation's third manned mission to the moon.

title: The Cast
description: HOW TO SUCCEED WITH SEX, written and directed by Bert I. Gordon; photography by Michel Cetti; music by Forest Hamilton and Sean Bonniwell; produced by Jerome F. Katzman; released by Medford Film Corporation. At the Pacific East Theater, 59th Street between Second and Third Ave nues and the Penthouse Theater, Broadway and 47th Street. Running time: 77 minutes. (The Motion Picture Association of America's Production Code and Rating Administration classifies this film: Xno one under 17 admitted.)

title: BRAVES SCORE, 50, ON AARON'S HOMER
description: HOUSTON, April 10 (UPI) Henry Aaron hit the 13th grand slam home run of his career, most among active players, to give the Atlanta Braves a 50 victory tonight over Houston in the Astros' home opener.

title: DECLINE GOES ON IN AMEX TRADING
description: The downward trend con tinued unabated on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday as prices fell to a twoyear low in quiet trading.

title: Briton Asks Global Standards On Car Safety, Noise, Pollution
description: A leading British car manu facturer has issued a call for international standards gov erning automotive safety, noise and exhaust emissions.

title: Ox Ridge Triumphs by 154 In New England Polo Final
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 10 Reid Graham and Jim McManus scored five goals apiece tonight to lead the Ox Ridge Hunt Club polo team to a 151 victory over Shallow Brook of Somers, Conn., in the playoff for the 1969 Now England champion ship.

title: Yablonski Aide Files Charge On U.M.W. Pension Practice
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)A campaign aide of the murdered mine union candi date, Joseph A. Yablonski, filed an unfair labor practice charge today against the United Mine Workers for requiring retired miners to pay union dues to qualify for pensions.

title: Museum Says Ecologist Studied Effects of Mining on Sea Bottom
description: The American Museum of Natural History said this week that ecological studies had been undertaken in the Bahamas be fore a mining company, in which the museum had a fin ancial interest, began stripping away a commercially valuable mineral from the sea bottom there.

title: Leeds Faces Chelsea In Soccer Final Today
description: LONDON, April 10 (UPI) Three weeks ago the Leeds United soccer team would have been a firm favorite to beat Chelsea in tomorrow's Football Association Cup fin al. Now Leeds is no better than even money.

title: Invention Heps Pupils' Reading
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Peter C. Goldmark, pres ident of C.B.S. Laboratories, and three coinventors were granted a patent this week for a teaching machine that has enabled pu pils in a Brooklyn school to improve their reading skill. Called the AVS 10, the portable audiovisual device protected by Patent 3,504,445 is about the size of an overnight case and can be used on a desk top.

title: MARCHERS URGE U.S. ACT ON DRUGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Several hundred residents of the New York City metropoli tan area marched near the Capitol today to urge stronger efforts by the Federal govern ment to combat the narcotics traffic.

title: Unishops Sets Acquisition
description: A formal contract was signed yesterday by Unishops, Inc., for the acquisition of White's De partment Stores. Initially, 125, 000 shares of Unishops com mon will be issued to owners of White's and an additional amount not exceeding 85,000 shares will be issued over the next five years dependent on White's earnings.

title: AGNEW LINKS VOTE TO LIBERAL MEDIA
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Vice President Agnew charged today that the Senate had re jected the nomination of G. Harrold Carswell to the Su preme Court on the basis of subjective judgements after its members had been snowed by material in the liberal media and subjected to for midable, almost incredible pressures from organized labor and civil rights activists.

title: SCHOOLS' OFFICES VACATED BY KIRK
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 10Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. vacated the Manatee County school board offices tonight, but neither he nor his staff would say if he was giving up his defiance of court orders imposing racial in tegration in the county's schools.

title: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Brandt Exhorts the U.S. Not to Reduce Its Troop Strength in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Chancellor Willy, Brandt of West Germany sought to convince the Nixon Admin istration, Congress and the American public today that he security of Europe and the success of negotiations with the Soviet bloc depend ed on a continued American military presence on the Continent. The Chancellor, whose Government is nego tiating with the Soviet Union, East Germany and Poland for improved relations, delivered his massage during a whirl wind day. It included a two hour conference with Presi dent Nixon, a meeting with Secretary of State William P. Rogers, a session with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a speech at the National Press Club and the taperecording of two net work television programs. Mr. Brandt summed up his views in his address at a press club luncheon when he said that the efficiency of the Atlantic Alliance contin ues to depend essentially on maintaining the mililary presence of the United States on the European Continent. No European effort can be substitute for this, he said. There is still no security for Europe without the United States. I am sure that the in terpretation of America's own interests will arrive at the same conclusion.

title: SPEEDY ABORTIONS FAVORED IN STUDY
description: BOSTON, April 10Thera peutic abortions can be per formed simply, safely and in expensively without requiring overnight hospitalization of the woman, a California medical team has concluded after a six month study of the procedure.

title: INTEREST IS LOW IN NEW OFFERINGS
description: One of tne most eagerly awaited first public stock of ferings in years failed to kindle a spark in the new issue mar ket this week.

title: TV Review
description: THE charm and enduring makebelieve of Cinder ella was turned into a gro tesque fairy tale last night under the title of Hey. Cin derella, over the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Tall Tasks Confronting Knicks and Rangers Today
Catholic Bishops Assail Abortion Bill
description: Cardinal Cooke called pas sage of the abortion bill in Albany yeterday a threat to our state and our country and a direct attack on the sanctity of human life and the welfare of our society.

title: Market Summary
description: Friday, April 10, 1970

title: Shriver and Mandel Meet
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10 (UPI)R. Sargent Shriver met with his possible gubernatorial opponent, Gov. Marvin Mandel, today, but neither man shed any light on Mr. Shriver's po litical situation. Mr. Shriver, a former Ambassador to France, has indicated that he is inter ested in running in the Sep tember Democratic primary. Governor Mandel is also a Democrat.

title: Hunter High Students Are Given Equal Voice on Faculty Boards
description: The faculty members of Hunter College High School have voted to grant student de mands for equal representation with teachers on governing boards at the school.

title: For Youngsters who'd Rather Ski Than Swim, a Touring Camp in the Alps
description: FOR the past four years, summer travelers at Ken nedy Airport have been star tled to see dozens of teen agers trouping through the terminal carrying ski equip ment. High school students, they are members of Ski Tour r Camp, Inc., a group that skis through June and into August in the French, Swiss and Italian Alps when the rest of the world seems to he headind for the beach.

title: Resignation of a Spanish Aide Reported
description: MADRID, April 10The po litical difficulties faced by the Spanish Government increased today with the reported resig nation of the Public Works Minister, Federico Silva Muoz.

title: Minnesota Five Gets Coach
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 (UPI) An assistant coach, George Hanson, was named head bas ketball coach at the University of Minnesota today succeeding Bill Fitch, who resigned Iast month to join the new National Basketball Association fran ohise in Cleveland.

title: TwoWay Wireless System Developed for Use in Mines
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., April 10 (UPI)The Consolida tion Coal Company announced today that a twoway wireless underground communication system has been developed and proved in actual operation in the company's coal mine in West Virginia and Illinois.

title: MAJOR KENNELLY, REAL ESTATE MAN
description: MIAMI, April 10Maj. Wil liam Kennelly, a New York real estate executive and former president of the New York Ath letic Club, died of cancer at the Veterans Hospital here yester day. He was 84 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Article 6  No Title
Holmes Upsets Bacallao In Final of Squash Tennis
description: Starting with a 7point ad vantage, Joseph Holmes of New Canaan, Conn., the No. 3 seeded player in the Norman Torrence squash tennis handicap tourna ment, upset Pedro Bacallao, the defending champion, 158, 815, 1512, 1215, 1511 In the final at the Harvard Club yesterday.

title: GUATEMALANS GET SCHEEL'S PROTEST
description: GUATEMALA, April 10 (AP)  Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany de livered a protest today to the President of Guatemala for having failed to prevent the terrorist killing of Donn's m bassaclor, Count Karl von Spreti.

title: HAWAIIANS AVOID SCHOOL PROBLEM
description: HONOLULU, April 8While the stitching seems to be break ing in the patchwork of elemen tary and secondary school financing in state after state on the mainland, the problem does not exist here in Hawaii.

title: RENE MOSSU
description: GENEVA, April 10  Rene Mossu, Geneva correspondent for two Paris newspapers, Le Figaro and FranceSoir, since 1944, died in a hospital here last night. He was 68 years old.

title: Rail Walkout Continues
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 10 (AP)Wildcat strikers at the Louisville & Nashville Railroad facilities here continued their walkout today in defiance of a Federal court order. The walk out began Wednesday night as a protest by some 400 shoperaft workers against legislation, signed yesterday by President Nixon, prohibiting a rail strike.

title: Misery Loves Company: A Saying That Was All Too True Among Competitors in 2d Round of Augusta Golf
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 Bob Goalby and Roberto de. Vicenzo, who were involved in the memorable scorecard con troversy here two years ago, were among several noted golfers who failed to qualify today for the final 36 holes of the Masters golf tournament.

title: Pope Voices Sympathy
description: ROME, April 10Pope Paul VI sent Egyptians an expression of his most profound sympathy today for the death of so many innocent victims in the Israeli bombing at Bahr el Bakar in the Nile Delta Wednes day. The Egyptians said that 30 children had been killed in the raid.

title: Dance: Beautiful Intermezzo by Feld
description: THIS weekend Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company completes its second New York season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It per forms tonight and twice to morrow. You should go and see it. In the present day and age o feconomic pres sures, quite frankly, you may never have another chance. For that matter you may never deserve another chance.

title: American Eagle Heads List In Yacht Race to Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Appril 10 (UPI)  Twenty entries, including American Eagle, were set to start tomorrow in the Sol Al Sol Regatta from St. Peters burg, Fla., to Isla Mujeres, Mexico.

title: Subpoenas Are Served
description: BRADENTON, Fla April 10 (UPIGovernor Kirk allowed Federal marshals to serve sub poenas on nine of his aides to day and told the Supreme Court there was grave danger of loss of life among both Federal and state officials in the school confrontation.

title: Allied Relief Unit Enters Besieged Camp
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10 (AP)A South Vietnamese relief battalion fought its way into the Americanled camp at Dakseang today, easing a 10 day enemy siege. But to the north near the demilitarized zone, North Vietnamese at tacked another outpost led by American Green Berets.

title: '70 Crop Forecast For Winter Wheat Cut 7% From 1969
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)The Agriculture De partment forecast today a 1970 winter wheat crop of 1,065,000 000 bushels, down 7 per cent from last year's production of 1.147.646.000 bushels.

title: VIETNAM REDS DUE TO AID ON NEWSMEN
description: The TimeLife News Service said yesterday that representa tives of the North Vietnamese Government and of the Vietcong had agreed to make inquiries into the disappearance of a number of newsmen on assign ment in Laos and Cambodia.

title: FULBRIGHT PANEL VOTES TO REPEAL TONKIN MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to re peal the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, which was fre quently cited by President John son as Congressional authori zation for the United States military involvement in Viet nam.

title: Herrera Optioned by Expos
description: MONTREAL, April 10 (AP) The Montreal Expos optioned an outfielder, Jos Herrera, to Buffalo of the International league today to make room on the roster for Jack Hiatt, catch er purchased from the San Francisco Giants Monday.

title: CAMPUS DISORDER IS TARGET OF BILL
description: ALBANY, April 10  The Assembly, in a waspish session that haggled on late into the evening, today passed a bill requiring colleges that receive state funds to suspend students convicted of offenses commit ted on campus.

title: 16 High School Students Seized in Heroin Charges
description: Sixteen students from 15 to 119 years old attending James Madison High School in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn were arrested yesterday for al legedly either selling or possess ing heroin.

title: Scranton on A.&P. Board
description: William W. Scranon, former Governor of Pennsylvania, has been elected to the board of directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc. He fills a vacancy left by the resignation of Gwilyn A. Price, who served on the baord since the food chain became publicly held in 1958.

title: A Women's Liberation Approach to Solving Career Problems
description: EIGHT women sat upright and fiercely attentive in the living room of midtown Manhattan apartment one evening last week. They were sustained by coffee and mutual need.

title: Hopes of Labor Party Stirred By Gain in London Council Vote
description: LONDON, April 10Labor party gains in voting for the Greater London Council raised the Government's hopes today and increased the possibility of an early general election.

title: Screen: A New Truffaut:'Mississippi Mermaid' Uncoils Complexly
description: FRANCOIS TRUFFAUT's "The Mississippi Mermaid" has the form of a preposterous romantic melodrama, but it is so full of lovely, complex thingsof unannounced emotions, of ideas, of the memories of other movies (Truffaut's, as well as of those of two of his father-figures, Renoir and Hitchcock)that it defies easy definition and blithely triumphs over what initially appears to be structural schizophrenia. It is the creation of a superior moviemaker who works eccentrically in the classical tradition.For approximately half of its running time, "The Mississippi Mermaid" proceeds as a conventional mystery: Louis Mah (Jean-Paul Belmondo), a tobacco planter on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean, has sent away for a mail-order bride. When Julie (Catherine Deneuve) arrives, it's quite apparent that she is not the girl with whom he has been corresponding. However, she is so beautiful, so sweetly enigmatic, so (he says) worthy of adoration, he dismisses his doubts until he comes home one evening to find Julie gone, along with most of his cash resources, amounting to something like 27-million francs.Several months later, while recuperating from an illness in the south of France, Louis finds Julie hustling in an Antibes discothque. When he finally confronts her, she admits everything and, in several minutes of detailed exposition that seems to destroy the movie we've been watching, she simply explains away the plot of murder, blackmail, deception and double cross.One mystery film ends and another begins. At least, it seems that way until you realize that Truffaut, as fond as he is of the mechanics of surface intrigue, is more profoundly fascinated by explorations of loneliness and love, which comprise, of course, a different kind of mystery.This, actually, is what "The Mississippi Mermaid" is all about, right from the movie's opening credits that are presented against the background of a newspaper's "personal" ads. On the soundtrack voices are heard, first one, then another, and then a kind of chorus of controlled desperation ("Young girl, serious, pretty. . . ." "Bachelor, 35, interested in music. . . ."). Everyone is searching for love.In "The Mississippi Mermaid," as in all of Truffaut's films, love leads only to an uncertain future that, at best, may contain some joy along with the inevitable misery. Truffaut's special talent, however, is for communicating a sense of the value of that joy.As he did in "The Bride Wore Black," Truffaut here has taken as his source material a rather shabbily written mystery romance by Cornell Woolrich (the sort of book in which a lady's mouth might be described as looking like crushed rose petals), published in this country as "Waltz Into Darkness" and in France as "La Sirne du Mississippi." He has followed the broad outlines of the original quite closely, while updating the period and shifting the locale. However, because Truffaut is a more gifted filmmaker than Woolrich was a novelist, the film successfully neutralizes elements that in Woolrich are dramatic absurdities."The Mississippi Mermaid" is the sort of melodrama in which a young man and his wife, fleeing from the police, will get into an argument over the way he drives. "Richard," she says, cheerfully recalling an earlier lover to annoy her husband, "always swore at other drivers. Those who passed him were S.O.B.'s. Those who didn't were morons." He makes her get out and walk.The film is filled with visual references: to Renoir (to whom it is dedicated), to Nick Ray ("Johnny Guitar"), to his own "Shoot the Piano Player," and to Balzac, the author read most by Truffaut heros. It is also played with marvelous style by Belmondo, Miss Deneuve and by Michel Bouquet ("La Femme Infidele") who, as the detective originally hired by Belmondo to find his wife, is the figure of absurd, unflappable self-assurance that has stalked through Truffaut's last three films, once as a heroine ("The Bride Wore Black"), and here as a villain."The Mississippi Mermaid" is a difficult, abrasive movie with lots of faults that, to me, are ultimately academic. I like it very much, but I suspect that United Artists, the distributor, does not. They opened it yesterday at the 72d Street Playhouse with all the care and fanfare that might be accorded the closing of a supermarket.

title: MUSEUM STARTS FESTIVITIES HERE
description: The staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art informally started the museum's centennial birthday celebration yesterday afternoon, undeterred by the absence of a malfunctioning 25 feettall birthday cake especially constructed for the occasion and for a candlelighting cere mony on its pinnacle.

title: Apollo 13's Goals Include Drilling 3 Holes in Moon
description: HOUSTON, April 10  The scientific experiments to be carried out by the Apollo 13 astronauts and by means of the instruments they leave on the moon may prove to be the most revealing in man's early explo ration of that body.

title: Vermont Gov. Davis To Get Opposition By Lieut. Goy. Hayes
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 10 Lieut., Gov. Thomas L. Hayes, conceding that he would be a distinct underdog, announced today he would challenge Gov. Deane C. Davis in the Republi can primary this year.

title: Heroin Smuggler Sentenced
description: An Argentinian artist, seized at Kennedy International Air port while smuggling heroin valued at $50,000 wholesale, was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison by Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia. The artist, Arsenio A. ArayaMur chio, 31 years old, of Salta, Argentina, was arrested in De cember when Customs authori ties found 12 pounds of uncut heroin hidden in the false bot toms of two wine jugs.

title: SANTA CLARA SETS U.S. MEDLEY MARK
description: CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) John Kinsella, a Hinsdale (Ill.) High School senior, posted his second freestyle victory in con secutive nights tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's na tional indoor swimming cham pionship.

title: UNITED FUND GROUPS WARNED ON SUPPORT
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 10 United Fund and Community Chest organizations were told today that they would lose the support of big business unless they redirected their efforts to ward the human issues behind national protests.

title: State Also Indicts Bombing Suspect In U.S. Case Here
description: Samuel Joseph Melville, al ready under a Federal indict ment alleging that he conspired to bomb Government property here, was indicted by a New York County grand jury yester day that accused him of having a role in the bombings of six buildings in the summer and fall of 1969.

title: Carolina Voting Bill Fails
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 10 (AP)The House rejected yes terday a proposed amendment to the state constitution to lower the minimum voting age to 18 in South Carolina.

title: Beggar on Horseback Set
description: Beggar on Horseback, the George S. Kaufman and Marc Connelly satire, will serve as the fourth and final play of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center's 196970 subscription season. It will open May 14 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater under the direction of John Hirsch. The cast includes Leon ard Frey, Biff McGuire, Cherry Davis, Susan Watson, Robert Symonds, Tresa Hughes and Robert Pahlen.

title: MRS. KING GAINS NATAL NET FINAL
description: DURBAN, South Africa, April 10 (Reuters)The former Wimbledon champions, Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., qualified to day to meet in the women's singles final of the Natal open tennis championships.

title: SHIP GROUP LOSES CONTAINER APPEAL
description: The New York Shipping As sociation lost an appeal yester day from a Federal District Court ruling that ordered it and the International Longshore men's Association to stop in ducing others in the Port of New York not to do business with an independent container cargo consolidator.

title: Coburn Corp. Plans to Report A Loss for Year Ended Feb. 28
description: The Coburn Corporation of America, a diversified Long Is landbased finance company, that has been experiencing fi nancial problems, said yester day that it expects to report a loss of $5million to $6million for its fiscal year ended Feb. 28.

title: Shelepin, Of f the Sick List, Appears at Moscow Fete
description: MOSCOW, April 10  The Soviet Union marked Astro nautics Day today with a Krem lin meeting extolling Soviet space exploits, but the atten tion of Western diplomats was focused on a Politburo mem ber, Aleksandr N. Shelepin, who made his first public ap pearance in more than a month.

title: Amy M. Furth To Be a Bride
description: LAFAYETTE, Calif., April 10Miss Amy Melville Furth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gor don Furth, plans to be mar ried in May to Frank Forres ter Church 4th, son of Sena tor and Mrs. Church of Boise, Idaho, and Bethesda. Md.

title: March Retail Sales Are Estimated Off
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Government unofficially estimated today that retail sales last month were $29.877 billion seasonally adjusted, down slightly from $29.942 billion in February.

title: Experts Reject Plan of ExNixon Doctor for Tests of Children to Find Potential Criminality
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Three professional organiza lions denounced today a pro posal, which has won President Nixon's personal interest, to predict potential criminality by giving psychological tests to every 6, 7, and 8 year old child.

title: Placid New Hebrides Feels Political Strain
description: VILA, New Hebrides, March 26  Growing political consciousness has become a strange new force in the nor mally placid life of these coconutgrowing and cattle raising islands governed jointly by Britain and France.

title: New Libyan Regime's Goals Still Unclear
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 5  More than a half a year after a handful of angry young of ficers overthrew the Libyan monarchy, their proudest ac complishment remains the rath er quick agreement by the United States and Britain to withdraw from their military bases.

title: F.D.A. Will Review A List of Additives Approved in Foods
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Food and Drug Adminis tration has taken a step to ward reevaluating a large number of food additives au thorized as usable between 1938 and 1958.

title: TIMES PUBLISHER GIVES A WARNING
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, pub lisher of The New York Times, warned yesterday that the pos sibility of a shutdown of the newspaper was rapidly ap proaching because of a labor crisis.

title: Arculeo Seeks Nomination By. G.O.P. in Congress Race
description: Angelo J. Arculeo, represent ative of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn in the City Council, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican in the 16th Congressional Dis trict.

title: Cobina Wright, Society Hostess And Hollywood Columnist, Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 10 (AP) Cobina Wright, former so ciety hostess of prominence, who later turned to journalism and wrote of both the Holly wood scene and of cultural happenings, died yesterday, after having suffered a stroke on Easter Sunday. Her age was never made public.

title: Show of Art Will Benefit Asia Society
description: Masterpieces of Asian art have been borrowed from American collections for a show to open with a preview next Tuesday evening at the gallery of the Asia Society at 112 East 64th Street.

title: THREE PANTHERS FILE PLEAS OF NOT GUILTY
description: NEW HAVEN, April 10 Three Black Panthers pleaded not guilty today to kidnapping and murdering Alex Rackley, a Panther who was suspected of being an informer for the po lice.

title: Few Filipinos Get Electricity
description: MANILA (UPI)Only 20 per cent of the houses in the Philip pines have electric power, al though there are more than 200 licensed power companies, ac cording to the Philippine Elec tric Plant Owners Association.

title: EARNINGS OF I.B.M. RESUME ADVANCE
Hanoi Aide Warns France on Backing Cambodia Leaders
description: PARIS, April 10Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Vetnamese Politburo left here today for Moscow and Hanoi after a twomonth stay. As he left, he warned France against supporting the new leadership in Cambodia.

title: Giacomin Is Goalie in Battle to Pare Bruins' 20 Lead
description: Donnie Marshall, one of the Rangers' senior citizens, came tripping down the stairs into the locker room after the team's workout yesterday, sat down across from Ed Giacomin and told the goalie:

title: WILLIAM T. SMITH
description: William T. Smith, a vice pre sident of Dominick & Dominick, Inc., an investment banking, and brokerage firm, died Thurs day at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 200 East 64th Street.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS VOLUME CLIMBS
description: I.B.M. was the star of a drab stock market yesterday, while American Telephone showed weakness in the final session before terms of its huge financ ing are set.

title: Senator Russell Plans Rest
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, was dis charged from Walter Reed Army Hospital today and left immediately for 10 days of rest. He entered the hospital March 4 for treatment of an infected respiratory tract.

title: The President and His Action in the Latest Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The available clues suggest that President Nixon thought himself caught in another of his selfconscious crises when the Senate rejected the nomination of Judge G. Har rold Carswell to the Supreme Court.

title: Sale of Hoe Unit Approved
description: Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday approved the sale of R. Hoe & Co.'s press division to Wood Industries, Inc. R. Hoe has been in Chan ter 10 reorganization proceed ings since last July.

title: CARSWELL CRITICS CALL NIXON WRONG IN SENATE ATTACK
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Leaders of the bipartisan opposition in the Senate that defeated Judge G. Harrold Cars well urged President Nixon to day to reconsider his decision not to nominate a Southerner to the Supreme Court.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Unemployment Rate Rose Last Month to 4.4%
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The nation's unemployment rate rose further in March, to 4.4 per cent of the labor force from 4.2 per cent in February, the Labor Department reported today. At 3,733,000, the number of people out of work last month was a little below the February level. But normally there is a big drop in March; thus, on a season ally adjusted basis, the unem ployment rate rose again.

title: MISS LAMHUT STARS IN EXTENDED VOICES
description: A new dance work by Phyllis Lamhut, Extended Voices, or the choreographer a come dienne, was presented last night at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse.

title: National Stores Unit Elects
description: Clarence N. Jacobson has been elected to the presidency of the J. Baker division of Na tional Stores, Inc. He will be succeeded as executive vice president by Robert M. Becker, former vice president of the di vision. The division operates 87 leased selfselection and semi selfselection shoe departments in discount stores in the east ern half of the United States.

title: JACOBSON APPEAL IS AT CROSSROAD
description: Howard (Buddy) Jacobson's attorney said yesterday he felt the controversial trainer should abandon the court appeal of his 45day suspension by the New York State Racing Com mission.

title: PENTANGLE QUINTET GIVES FOLK RECITAL
description: The stylistic essence of me dieval folk song was mixed with jazz and brushed with a touch of the bluees last night at Carnegie Hall by the British group called Pentangle. The un usual quintet, made up of acoustic guitar, electric guitar, string bass, drums and female voice (with the instrumental ists occasionally adding their voices, too) created a blend of sound and rhythm that was such a skillful amalgam that it never seemed to narrow down to any of its root sources.

title: Openings of the Week
description: THE DRUNKARDTomorrow, 13th Street Theater, 7. A musical version of the melodrama by W. H. S. Smith, adapted by Bro Herrod with music by Barry Mani low.

title: Peter Carey Fiance Of Deborah Mehlman
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 11 Mr. and Mrs. Roy Mehlman have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Deborah Joan Mehlman, to Peter Carey Krauskopf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Kraus kopf of Malverne.

title: Mine Owners Say Law Imperils Coal Production
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Spokesmen for the coal mining industry complained today that new Federal regulations to protect the health and safety of mine workers were paralyz ing production, forcing hun dreds of small mines to close and hastening the likelihood of disruptions in coalfueled elec trical service to millions of consumers.

title: SmallBusiness Measure
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) A bill based on a Presidential task force recommendation to improve prospects for small businesses has been introduced by Senator Thomas J. McIn tyre, Democrat of New Hamp shire.

title: Britain Eases Wage and Price Curbs After 5Year Effort to Check Increases
description: LONDON, April 11As the United States searches for ways to combat wage and price inflation, Britain is dismantling tackle the same problem for the last five years.

title: Judge Bids Defiant Kirk Pay $10,000aDay Fine
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 11Fed eral District Judge Ben Krentz man ordered Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. today to stop disobey ing his school desegregation or ders or pay a fine of $10,000 a day.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Daymare
description: A PICTURE of a pretty girl in a bikini standing be side a glassyeyed, 54pound 8ounce king mackerel was recently mailed to me by Lefty Kreh, manager of the annual Metropolitan Miami fishing tournament.

title: Con Ed's Charles Luce
description: AT 12:30 P.M., Wednesday, Sept. 3,1969, Bill Wall, vice president for public affairs at the Con solidated Edison Company, walked into the office of his boss, Charles F. Luce, Con Edison's chairman and chief executive officer, to report a power failure. A feeder cable at the utility's East 14th Street substation was on the blink. In a spasm of chain reactions to the temporary voltage loss, the stock ticker at the New York Stock Exchange was knocked out of service. Trading on the Ex change came to a halt. (The Stock Exchange was to remain inoperable on that Wednesday for a frantic half hour until the downed ticker righted itself.)

title: Holly Richards Wed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 11 Miss Holly Richards, daughter of Harper Richards, the archi tect and the late Mrs. Louise Beville Richards was married here this afternoon to Ste phen Calhoun Day, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Albert Day of Colorado Springs, Colo.

title: 3 WILL BE HONORED BY BOXING WRITERS
description: Joe Frazier, the world heavy weight boxing champion; Yan cey Durham, Frazier's manager, and Murray Goodman, boxing publicist and former sports writer, will be the honored guests at the Boxing Writers Association's annual dinner.

title: JAMES C. SHEERS, 45, FILM PRODUCER, DIES
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., April 11James C. Sheers, a pro ducer and writer of television documentaries, died at the Gen eral Hospital here Thursday night of injuries from a fall at a friend's home here last Satur day. He was 45 years old, and lived at 337 Old Long Ridge Road in Stanford.

title: RAGS WINS AGAIN IN HUNTER CLASS
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 11Ed Wiley's Rags, who has dominated the division all win ter, scored 10 points and won the junior working hunter championship today at the New Canaan Mounted Troop horse show.

title: U.S. Transport Plane Crashes
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 11 (UPI)  A United States Air. Force C130 transport plane manned by a civilian Air America crew crashed and burned yesterday in mountains southwest of the clandestine army base at Long Cheng, kill ing all six crewmen aboard.

title: JAPANESE STARTLES MASTERS' PARTNER
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 Who is Takaaki Kono, the tiny Japanese only six shots from the Masters golf lead?

title: U. S. Craft Named to Defend the Onion Patch Trophy in Distance Racing
description: Cartha, Equation and Bay Bra, all sloops and all built of aluminum, will form the United States team that will defend the Onion Patch Trophy in a series of four cruisingyacht races ending with the Newport Bermuda event next June. The announcement was made by H. Irving Pratt, the selection committee chairman, who said also that the alternate would be Robin, a fiberglass vawl.

title: New Refuse Device
description: A new refuse compacting system designed to replace incinerators in apartment houses and commercial in stallations in New York and other cities will be manufac tured and marketed by a new company to be formed by the Electronic Assistance Corpo ration and International Pat ents and Development Cor poration. Electronic Assist ance and International Pat ents will each own 50 per cent of the stock of the new company.

title: Cars Are Ordered By Penn Central
description: The Penn Central Transpor tation Company last week or dered 15 new highspeed diesel freight locomotives and 137 new highcapacity box cars. This equipment will cost $13.7million. To supple ment these purchases, the carrier is going to rebuild and modernize 60 diesels at a cost of $5million.

title: Virginia, the Land of Boxwood
description: GARDENERS with a yen for boxwood can see a lot of it in Virginia. The best area for these handsome shrubs, cli matically speaking, is the Chesapeake Bay region and the foothills of the Blue Ridge in Virginia and North Caro lina.

title: Mihajlov's Memoir Is Postponed Here Under Court Terms
description: The prison memoirs of Mi hajlo Mihajlov, the controver sial Yugoslav writer, will not be issued for at least four years in accordance with the condi tions of his release, the 35year old author's American publisher announced yesterday.

title: Hospital Aide Is Named
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP) David L. Everhart, administra tive vice president of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, was named this week as execu tive director of the New England Medical Center Hospitals, effec tive July 1.

title: Dance
description: DANCE is an art that does not have much in the way of a litera ture, I myself collect dance booksfor personal re ference more than bibliophilia even though some element of that also intrudesand by now I have most of the com Trion or garden variety of books written on the subject. I have never counted them but I imagine that there can not be more than 1,000, and perhaps even slightly less. And most of these books are ephemeral fan material, inter minable albums of photo graphs, and volume after vo lume telling the stories of ballets only interesting for their choreography.

title: Policy Overhaul Expected
description: BRUSSELS, April 10 (Reu ters)The North Atlantic al liance is expected to make a thorough overhaul of its de fense policy later this year. In formed sources said here.

title: Julie Eisenhower Calls Feminists Too Strident
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)Mrs. David Eisenhower, INGTON, families are the most important thing life, says leaders of the women's liberation movement are alienating a lot of women and most of the men.

title: Bucknell Quintet to Play In Tournament at Albright
description: Bucknell University's basket ball team will participate in the. Albright invitation tournament on Dec. 29 and 30.

title: Truman Greets Guests 25 Years After He Took Over Presidency
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 11Harry S Truman sat in the front parlor of his white Vic torian mansion on North Dela ware Street today and extended his hand, his wit and his thanks to a dozen distinguished visit ors from out of the past.

title: The World
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A young Russian driving his Volga through the twisting streets of Cairo's Garden City district stopped at an intersection and in Arabic asked a policeman for directions to an address where a cocktail party was un derway.

title: YALE EIGHT WINS HOUSATONIC RACE
description: DERBY, Conn., April 11 The Yale varsity crew beat Northeastern and Rutgers to day on the chilly Housatonic River. Afterward the Eli oars men celebrated by throwing their coxswain and captain, Roger Little, off the dock into the water.

title: Calif. Utility Signs Letter of Intent
description: The Southern California Edison Company has signed a letter of intent with the English Electric Corporation for a large turbine generator to be installed in the San Onofre nuclear generating station on the Pacific Ocean south of San Clemente. The utility also signed an option for a second unit, each of which is rated at 1.1 million kilowatts.

title: Bank Plans Building
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 4 (AP)The Bank of Cali fornia has announced plans for an 18story building cov ering a city block in down town San Diego. Construc tion is expected to start May 1 with the multimilliondollar building to be open by Oc tober, 1971.

title: ANGELS WIN BY 63 AND STAY UNBEATEN
description: KANSAS CITY; April 11 (UPI)Alex Johr?son accounted for all of California's runs with a pair of threerun homers to night as the unbeaten Angels won their fourth in a row by downing the Kansas City Royals, 63.

title: LIME TRIUMPHS BY NOSE ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 11 (UPI)  The partnership of Mary Jones, the Florsheim heiress, and her trainer, Charles Whittingham, scored a double victory today as their colts, Lime and Whittingham, won $44,200 divisions of the Will Rogers Stakes for 3yearolds on the Hollywood Park turf course.

title: 8:56.5 Schoolboy Two Miles
description: LOCKPORT Ill., April 11 (AP)Dave Merrick, a junior at LincolnWay High School, ran the fastest high school two miles of the year today when he covered the distance in 18 minutes 56.5 seconds.

title: 4 Stakes Listed on Turf
description: Four of Delaware Park's ma jor stakes events will he con tested on the turf course this season. Included is the $25,000 added Brandywine Turf Handi cap, opening day feature on Memorial Day, May 30.

title: No, Joan's Not Jealous
description: WHEN you walk into Joan Sutherland's brownstone apartment in the heart of Greenwich Village, you can't help but see red. First there is the great diva herself, floating across the foyer a wildly printed red and purple gown. She leads you a Victorian living room. Red velvet draperies ... red velvet sofa ... red fresh flowers. You settle down, then turn face a huge pouf of red hair, and a mouth of red lipstick that has gone slightly askew beneath the right lower lip.

title: Temper, temper, temper, temper, TEMPER!
description: THE yelling, fighting, wild anger of a child is an alarming sight. Parents be come frightened. They ask, What did we do to provoke this? And they worry that their child might be seriously disturbed.

title: M. L. Trayser, A Broker, Weds Susan Bradley
description: ANDOVER, Mass., April 11 Miss Susan Elizabeth Brad ley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Withrow Bradley, was married here this after noon to Malcolm Lewis Tray ser of New York, son of Mrs. Lewis William Trayser of Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Trayser. The Rev. J. Everett Bodge of the South Congre gational Church here, per formed the ceremony in the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Andover Academy.

title: Investors Mark Time On Counter, Amex
description: Investors continued to mark time on the sidelines last week as prices and volume declined in the over thecounter market and on the American Stock Ex change.

title: ECOLOGICAL ETHIC URGED ON NATION
description: The president of the Rocke feller Foundation proposed yes terday that America formulate a new environmental ethic that would deemphasize such cherished industrial principles as economic growth based on constantly increasing produc tion and consumption of goods.

title: John O'Hara Dead; Novelist Dissected SmallTown Mores
description: John O'Hara, the prolific American novelist who took the public poses and the private hells of the smalltown rich as his theme, died of a heart at tack yesterday morning in his sleep at his country home in Princeton, N. J. He was 65 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
Swigert, Under Pressure, Proved He Fitted in Well
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 11Jack Swigert has probably undergone more stress in the last three days than he'll see throughout the flight.

title: Cooke Announces WealthSharing Church Plan
description: A system for church financ ing that commits the richer parishes in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to share their wealth with needy and less affluent congregations was announced this week by Cardinal Cooke.

title: Hawks Down Wings, 42, and Capture 30 Lead in East Division Semifinals
description: DETROIT, April 11 (UPI) Bobby Hull shot the Chicago Black Hawks into a command ing 30 lead over the Red Wings in the East Division semifinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs to night with two goals and two assists in a 42 victory.

title: 2 SCHOOL RECORDS SET ON NEW TRACK
description: The new $150,000 Elastaturf track at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island was put to its first serious test yesterday and it came away with rave notices from coaches, athletes and of ficials.

title: Palmer Is Still King With Fans, Even Though He Is Tottering
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 Suddenly, beyond the grassy rim of a slope on the second fairway, his head appeared, and then his torso. Soon he was completely visible, his face swinging from side to side in that familiar march that has appeared on tele vision sets on an almost weekly basis for more than decade.

title: Davis Leading Hitter
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI) Willie Davis was the Los Angeles Dod gers' leading hitter in 1969. He ranked seventh in the National League with a .315 average.

title: On Moving Day, Complaints Flower
description: DIANE and Garrett Fried man were up early on moving day to get themselves, their 3yearold daughter and some remain ing unpacked items ready for an 8 A.M. date with the movers.

title: Lack of Funds Threatens the U.N. DrugMonitoring Program That Arose From the Thalidomide Case
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10An experiment in in ternational monitoring of drugs to prevent future thalidomide tragedies is jeopardized by lack of funds, according to the World Health Organization.

title: Advertising:
description: The public service adver tising campaign aimed at curbing drug abuse that is now being created at Comp ton Advertising, Inc., might well turn out to be the big gest in the history of the Ad vertising Council. The agency reports fantastic interest in side and outside of its of fices. The council says it is already receiving requests from interested media even though the campaign has not passed the storyboard stage or received final approval from Washington.

title: Gettysburg Picks Captains
description: Two men who represented Gettysburg College in the Na tional Collegiate wrestling cham pionships last month have been named cocaptains of the Bullet grapplers for the 197071 sea son. Elected by their teammates were Ron Emenheiser, 190 pounder from York, and Don Cramer, 167pound product of Belmar, N. J.

title: B. E. Goldman to Wed Jane Morton
description: Miss Jane Virginia Morton, a copywriter with the Cam bridge University Press, and Bruce E. Goldman, a copy writer at Young & Rubicam, Inc., plan to be married.

title: Linda Winsor, a Museum Aide, Engaged to Bolan H. Boatner Jr.
description: ARDMORE, Pa., April 11 The engagement of Miss Linda Holmberg Winsor to Bolan Herbert Boatner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Boatner of Sewickley, has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Curtin Winsor. A wedding here in July is planned.

title: THOMAS M. FERRARA
description: Thomas M. Ferrara, founder and chairman of the Shenan doah Valley Produce Company, poultry producers, with plants in Harrisonburg, Va., and sales offide here, died Friday of a heart ailment in New York, Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 3205 164th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Florida Would Terminate Alimony for Able Women
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 11 (UPI)  With Florida's only woman Senator in the fore front, the state Senate has passed a bill that would relieve divorced husbands of able fe males of having to pay perma nent alimony.

title: Decline of The New
description: Irving Howe has a mind so fine that no ideology can violate it. He has no desire to make reality squeal in the grip of a system, no itch to scratch his way through a literary work to the furthest reaches of anal ysis; he has none of the vanity that holds up literature as a reflection of some philosophy in which the crit ic has found himself. He is more con cerned with fixing the just attitude toward what is there than with trans forming it into something else.

title: Transportation Meeting Set
description: CarnegieMellon University, in Pittsburgh, will hold a con ference on advanced urban transportation systems from May 25 to 27. The meeting, ar ranged in cooperation with the United States Department of Transportation, will take place ion the school's campus.

title: Months of Brutality Prior to Songmy Laid to G.I's
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A magazine account of the events at Songmy reports that the American unit involved had begun to mistreat its prison ers and to be less discriminat ing about who was or was not a Vietcong months before the alleged massacre.

title: NETS TO END SEASON WITH 2 HOME GAMES
description: The New York Nets, face the Miiami Floridians this afternoon and the Kentuscky Colonels Wednesday night on their home court at Island Garden, West Hempstead, L. I., in closing their regular American Basketball As sociation season.

title: ST. JOHN'S SCORES OVER L.I.U., 4 TO 2
description: Before Charlie Cappello of Long Island University could warm up to the chilly 35de gree temperature yesterday the St. John's batters struck him for three runs and went on to defeat the Blackbirds, 42, in a Met Conference game on the Redmen's diamond.

title: Gentry Gains Victory
Brooklyn Judge Routs Muggers, Shooting 2 Attacking Neighbor
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice told yesterday how he saved an elderly neighbor from two muggers after being alerted by his pet dog's persistent bark ing.

title: 20 Hits and 8 Walks Mark 230 Victory by Seton Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 11Seton Hall University cap italized on 20 hits, eight walks, a hit batsman and six Fairleigh Dickinson errors today for a 230 Metropolitan Conference baseball victory. It was the third straight triumph for the Pirates, whose wonlost mark is 42.

title: Vietnamese Flee Cambodia
description: ANTHANH, South Vietnam, April 11Cambodian soldiers came to our house and told us to leave, Nguyen Van So, a Vietnamese who was born in Cambodia, said in explaining why he fled his homeland 10 days ago and resettled with his wife and nine children in this South Vietnamese border vil lage.

title: Point of View
description: ALL cities have a multitude of agen cies to deal with the auto, the taxi, the bus and the truck. But what our cities need most des perately is officials whose chief con cern is the pedestrian.

title: Witty Gritty Alex Rose Is Influential Lindsay Adviser
description: As F.D.R. needed a Sidney Hillman, Lindsay needs an Alex Rose, one of the Mayor's top aides commented recently. There's something nittygritty about Rose that you don't get from the [Herbert] Brownells.

title: The Quest For Rananim
description: When D. H. Lawrence's letters are at last published in full, they will surely be recognized as a continued effort of sympathy and creative en ergy surpassed only by his 10 novels. Among other English writers only the letters of Keats, his fellow consump tive, have comparable brilliance and intensity. This collection of his 346 letters to S. S. Koteliansky is there fore, above all, distinctive for bring ing to us 220 letters previously unpublished. Furthermore, we are indebted to George J. Zytaruk for making an island of order in the chaotic dissemination of Lawrence's letters, which have been parceled out in some 30 separate publications, with more to come.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to Oxford 53311 until 11 P.M. In suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark (201) Market 33900; White Plains (914) White Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) Ivanhos 36660; Commack (516) 5435400; Stamford (203) 3487761.

title: The Care and Feeding
description: THE two most widely cultivated boxwood are English box and common box. English box, Buxus sempervirens suf fruticosa, is a dwarf shrub, often less than 3 feet tall at maturity. Common box (B.s. arborescens) is larger, usually attaining the height of a small tree. Both have dense foliage and full, round ed shapes.

title: Art in London
description: THE IDEAS of great Eng lish arists  Rossetti, Nicholson, Moore, to name a fewhave often had a greater impact than their taste or sense of style. This may once again prove true with Joe Tilson. Tilson's Pagesa series of reliefs now on exhibition at the Marlborough New London Gallery  state the dilemma of the current generation with piercing clarity and place the evolution of art in the 60's into better perspec tive; but as aesthetic compo sitions they leave a less en during impression.

title: Nixon and the Southern Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  To nearly every disinterested observer in this suddenly troubled capital, there was little doubt that the explosive events of the past few days have brought the President, his party, and his relations with Congress and the country to new point.

title: Thursday Ladies Day At Garden State Track
description: Garden State Park has an nounced that the six Thurs days during the spring meet ing will again be designated as Ladies Day.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: Educating Athletes

title: PENALTY MARK SET
description: In the most penalty  filled game in the history of the Stan ley Cup playoffs, the Rangers last night vindicated themselves and their goalie with a 43 vic tory over the Boston Bruins.

title: Outstanding Young Farmers Are Cited by U.S. Jaycees
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., April 11 (AP)America's four outstand ing young farmers were named here this week by representa tives of the United States Jay cees.

title: The Middle American Who Edits Ideas For Nixon
description: HE believes that the Federal Government must wage war against pollution. He would require trade unions to take in more blacks as members. He is not offend ed by the notion of minimum family. assistance. But for all that, John Ehr lichman, the President's chief adviser on domestic policy, is a Republican and a conservativenot so much be cause he prefers private to public action to solve social problems but because he is conservative in an emo tional, deeply personal sense.

title: MARQUEZ AND AYALA BOX HERE TOMORROW
description: Angel (Enri) Marquez, 29 yearold boxer from Cordoba, Argentina, will make his Ameri can debut in a lightheavy weight fight with Ray Ayala of New York and Puerto Rico, in the eightround cofeature to morrow at Audubon Ballroom, 166th Street and Broadway.

title: Brazil Soccer Star Sidelined
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 (UPI)Tostao, one of the stars of Brazil's World Cup soccer team, hasn't recovered from eye surgery and may be lost for next month's competition in Mexico City, a team spokesman said today.

title: POLL FINDS DROP IN WAR SUPPORT
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 11 Public confidence in President Nixon's Vetnam policies has de clined steadily since January, according to the latest Gallup, Poll.

title: The Conscience Of Impressionism
description: AMONG the painters who made up the original Impressionist group, the oldest was Camill Pissarro. He was born in 1830 and died in 1903. John Re wald has called him the dean of the Impressionist paint ers, and he certainly occu pies a special position in the history of the movement. Yet his authority was not based on a gift for daring innova tions. He was anything but the typical firebrand of the avant garde. Indeed, despite his seniority, Pissarro was mo::ie often a follower than a leader. He looked first to the examples of Corot and Cour bet. Then to Monet. Then to SeuratSeurat, who was 29 years his junior!

title: John Denver Spins Folk Spell in Bow At the Bitter End
description: John Denver is a polished folk singer making his first solo New York appearance through April 20 at the Bitter Edn, 147 Bleeker Street.

title: Princess Roycraft and Weekend Fun Take Divisions of Flirtation Stakes
description: BALTIMORE, April 11Prin cess Roycraft, an invader from New York, and homebased Weekend Fun shared honors today at Pimlico Race Course as 21 3yearold fillies turned out for the renewal of the Flirtation Stakes.

title: Beamon at Clinic Wednesday
description: Bob Beamon, the Olympic champion and world record holder in the long jump, will speak on his specialty at 8 P.M. Wednesday at a free clinic con ducted by the Metropolitan Track and Field Coaches As sociation. The clinic will he held at Archbishop Molloy High School. Queens Boulevard and Van Week Expresswav, Briar wood, Queens.

title: Letters: About Cassadaga's Spiritualists
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Trial
description: Trial is deliberately a nov el of social problems and only incidentally a novel of charac ter. It concern an honest cop with difficult sexual relation ships; it concerns society's treatment of criminals and derelicts; it concerns the mores of politics; it concerns, finally and doggedly, the question of capital punishment.

title: In The Nation: Mr. Nixon's Bay of Pigs
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A few hours after President Nixon made his remarkable accusation that Judges Haynsworth and Carswell had been rejected by the Senate because of anti Southern prejudice, the follow ing question was put to an audience of about 500 students, faculty and townspeople at Campbell College in Harnett County, N. C.:

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has signed a lease for 107.000 square feet of office floor space  about two and half acres  in White Plains.

title: Miss Suzanne Snowden Is Married
description: Miss Suzanne Stewart Snow den, personal secretary to Mrs. John V. Lindsay, was married here yesterday after noon to Charles Edwin Mitch ell Rentschler, an associate with McKinsey & Co., man agement consultants.

description: BERLIN, West Germany Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest commer cial bank, celebrated this week the centenary of its founding with the subdued pride that befits staid bankers.

title: Snake's Infrared Detector Studied for Science Clues
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 11 (AP) The snake's infrared detector, capable of accurately measur ing heat to within .001 degrees Centigrade over a wide range, is being studied by scientists at the University of Colorado.
