description: It was an impressive gathering, an elegant class in corporate finance and security analysis at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Sociologists Differ on the Effects Of the Liberalized Abortion Law
description: Making abortion legal in New York solves a legal problem but raises substantial othe questions: will it improve the lot of women, the sanctity of marriage, the morality of citizens?

title: Circuit Thrives in Colorado, Says Bennett College Rider
description: HORSE shows in Colorado are not all hootn'holler cowboys and western riding.

title: Ban Sought on Troops for Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Senators Frank Church and John Sherman Cooper an nounced today that they would offer legislation to prohibit the introduction of American com bat forces into Cambodia.

title: Lawyer to Wed Judith P. Grape, Magazine Aide
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 11 The engagement of Miss Judith Pierrepont Grape to Charles E. Barnett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Barnett of Detroit, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dudley H. Grape.

title: Regina C. Ryan, Publishing Aide, Wed to Author
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 11The marriage of Miss Regina Claire Ryan to Paul E. Deutschman of New York took place here this after noon. Judge George D. Burch ell of the Westchester County Court performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. X. Ryan, par ents of the bride.

title: Teri Freedman to Be Married on Aug. 2
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., April 11  Miss Teri L. Freedman, executive secre tary of the Advertising Club of Greater Boston, and P. Richard Weidner Jr., who is with the Boston office of N. W. Ayer & Son, Inc., the ad vertising agency, plan to be married here on Aug. 2.

title: Kerr on Borstal Boy
description: BORSTAL BOY, orig inally produced at Ireland's Abbey The ater and now brought here with several fine members of the original com pany, is a detailing of the late Brendan Behan's experi ences in reform school after he'd been deposited there at the age of 16 for carrying I.R.A. explosives in England. It is simply but handsomely staged  four trenchcoated figures carrying dangerous suitcases emerge like sea gods from a blue mistand in Niall Toibin and Frank Grimes it has two Behans, one mid dleaged and mussed, one young enough to seem to be wearing his father's much too large trousers, both excellent.

title: Religion
description: For the last 134 years Man hattan's Union Theological Seminary hus been sending out socially conscious graduates including war critic William Sloane Coffin Jr. and Chicago Seven defendant David Delling er  to do battle at the front lines of protest and social change.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: April 19Porsche Club of America, New York Metropolitan Region gymkhana at Mitchel Field, Hempstead, L. I. Registra tion: 10 A.M., first car off 11. C.L.I.S.C.C. event. Information: Jay Beckerman, phone (212) 7378584.

title: Mail Order Catalogue of the Hip Becomes a National Best Seller
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.Atter more than a year of popularity among the underground co gnoscenti, the Whole Earth Catalogue, a sort of Montgom ery Ward of the hip move ment, has become a best seller from coast to coast.

title: A.B.A. PANEL EYES DEFENSE CONDUCT
description: CHICAGO, April 11  An American Bar Association committee recommended to day that disciplinary action including possible disbarment be taken against defense lawyers who permit conduct purposefully calculated to annoy or irritate.

title: Marc E. Leland to Wed Gustava de Rothschild
description: Miss Gustava E. de Roths child, daughter of Baron and Baroness Elie de Rothschild of Paris, and Marc E. Leland, general counsel of the Peace Corps, plan to be married on July 7. The wedding will take place at Royaumont, Val D'Oise, the de Rothschilds' country estate outside Paris.

title: OTHER EVENTS
description: Today

title: Events Are Burgeoning for Rally Fans
description: NOW that the antifreeze has been drained out or their systems, the sports car club ralliers are beginning to take to the checkpointed roads again. The weekend calendars are blossoming with varied events all over the Metropolitan New York area and most or the Rather ings are designed to guide new I corners into thet proper ways of the auto rally sport. One group that was not in complete hi bernation is that which does the plotting for the North east All Night Rally Cham pionship Series. These enthu siasts burned plenty of mid night oil in putting together a program of seven races for the 1970 season. Last year they ran five successful ral lies that drew over 2,000 en trants from seven Northeast states.

title: NEW TAXI AGENCY PROPOSED IN CITY
description: A proposal to create a seven member commission to set the rules and rates for the city's taxicabsincluding livery serv ices and socalled gypsy scabs  is on Mayor Lindsay's desk.

title: ATROCITY REPORT SPURS NEW STUDY
description: WASHLNGTON, April 11  The latest report of an atrocity by United States troops in Viet nam has produced another in vestigation, according to the Defense Department, but it may be a long time before it yields results.

title: RISE IS PREDICTED IN WELFARE COSTS
description: George K. Wyman, New York State's Commissioner of Social Services, has predicted that ris ing unemployment will increase relief costs throughout the United States this year.

title: Lynch and Fagan Pace Yale To 111 Victory in Lacrosse
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11  Dan Lynch scored four goals and Two Fagan added three more today as Vale's lacrosse team whipped Dartmouth, 111.

title: After Test, the Pentagon Bars Lake Port Shipping
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Defense Department has concluded it cannot economic ally operate chartered vessels to deliver military cargo from Great Lakes ports to Europe.

title: NATO Stirred by Hint of U.S. Cutback
description: BRUSSELS, April 6The pos sibility of United States troop withdrawals from Europe has been disconcerting the North Atlantic Council, the highest authority in the alliance.

title: A 68 IN 3D ROUND
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 Just as he did a year ago, Billy Casper led the Masters golf field today after 54 holes by a onestroke margin on a total of 208.

title: Dale Rose Raczkowski Is Wed To Ens. John C. Baker of Navy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 11Miss Dale Rose Raczkowski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Racz kowski, was married in the Kirkpatrick Chapel of Rut gers University here today to Ens. John Cooper Baker, U.S.N.R.

title: Marietta Varsity Eight Beats Purdue by Four Lengths
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, April 11 (AP)  Marietta won three of four crew races against Purdue on the Marietta fiver today.

description: WASHINGTON.

description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)  Gov. Francis W. Sargent has vetoed a bill that would have permitted charitable groups, veterans organizations and church societies to play beano.

title: Pa. Reports New Plants Are Rising
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 11  New plant openings in Pennsylvania in 1969 showed a gain over the 1968 level, according to William T. Schmidt, State Secretary of Commerce.

title: Lovell Returns to Moon That Beckoned to Him
description: AFTER Jim Lovell came back all abubble from his (and man's) first voyage around the moon 15 months ago, he sat down and wrote the following vivid descrip tion of how it had been:

title: Brandeis Gets $1.9Million
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 11 (AP)  The National Science Foundation has awarded a $1.9 million grant to Brandeis Uni versity's physics and chemistry departments, the college an nounced Tuesday.

title: Okay, Fellows, Now Look Superstitious
description: I FIRST acquired my specialized enthusiasm way back in July of 1946, during the first broadcast (by radio, no TV then) of an atomic bomb explosion. I was stretched out on the sands of Fire Island on the At lantic Ocean while out on the Pacific a staggering col lection of experts were preparing to blow up Bikini. Yes, children, Bikini was an island then and only later became ... well, it's a tiny island, that's why. Now shut up and listen.

title: The Jackals At J. F. K.
description: SPRAWLED around the perimeter of John F. Kennedy Interna tional Airport is a cluster of drab cargo sheds that house a hoard so rich it would have made the an cient traders of Damascus drool in their shaggy beards. Here is the crossroads of the modern caravans of the airthe largest aircargo ter minal in the world. Day and night, the huge planes disgorge their wealth. Fortunes in cash. Jewels. Costly imported watches. Furs. Wearing apparel of all descriptions. Wigs worth hundreds of dollars apiece. Precious metals the average man has heard of. Goldfish and fresh fruit from Florida. Even monkeys. It is all gathered here under the grimy sheds that line a macadam road rimming the outskirts of Ken nedya massive and often chaotic clutter of unimaginable treasure.

title: ExJohnson Aides Assert Nixon Acts Illegally on Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Two former Commissioners of Internal Revenue said today that President Nixon had acted illegally in authorizing a mem ber of his staff. Clark R. Mol lenhoff to look at any tax returns he believes he needs to see.

title: 2 PARTY AIDES GET KEY SOVIET POSTS
description: MOSCOW, April 11  Two veteran regional Communist party officials have received key government jobs as part of an apparent effort to strengthen the administration of the Soviet economy.

title: Saigon General Says Foe May Attack Camp Again
description: TANCANH, South Vietnam, April 11 (AP)The North Viet namese still have 1.500 soldiers around the shellbattered Spe cial Forces camp at Dakseang, and a South Vietnamese gen eral warned today that new at tacks might conic in a week.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE interesting thing about the symposium on Five Plays I'd Like to See Revived is the dichotomy between the choices of the actors and of the scholarcritics. The actors picked for questioning may be prominent in a purely theatrical sense but theatri cal prominence apparently confers neither brains nor professional responsibility nor literary sense.

title: In Brief: Violence
description: Poverty is on the way out among publishers, that isand mayhem and riots are in. As always in periods of boom, when everybody attempts to jump on the bandwagon, the product ranges all the way from the superb to the medi ocre. The books here under re view are a fairly representative sample.

title: FISH STILL UNTESTED FOR MERCURY PERIL
description: LANSING, Mich., April 11 Michigan state officials have disclosed that not a single Great Lakes fish has yet to be tested for the mercury contamination that caused a Canadian crack down in Detroit area interna tional waters.

title: Losing Battles
description: By Eudora Welty. 436 pp. New York: Random House. $7.95.

title: STARVATION TOLL IN BIAFRA REVISED
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 A maximum of 50,000 people died of stazvaticn in the former territory of Biafra after the end of the Nigerian civil war last January, experienced pro fessional observers believe.

title: Bridge
description: A PLAYER could go through a lifetime of bridge without hold ing a tencard suit. (The chance of picking up such a hand is about one in 600,000, and few enthusiasts play even half a million deals from first to last.) When the fates do deal such a hand, the bidding is often a tactical matter, for the player with the ten card suit has to convince both his opponents and his partner that he should be permitted to play the hand, which may not be easy. And the play of such hands tends to be dull, for the degree of variation possible in the dummyplay and defense is very limited.

title: Health
description: Mr. L is a rabbi in his mid 40's who for years had been plagued by a stubborn re current mental disorder known as manic depressive psychosis.

title: GermanU.S. Trade
description: COLOGNE, Germany, April 4 (AP)West German ex ports to the United States rose to $215.1million in Jan uary front $155million in the 1969 month, the German American Chamber of Com merce reports. United States exports to Germany rose to $251.3million from $181.2 million.

title: Brown's Oarsmen Sweep 4 Races From Boston U.
description: PROVIDENCE, R J., April 11  Brown University crews opened their 1970 season by sweeping four races from Bos ton University on the Seekonk River today.

title: Patent System to Mark 180th Birthday
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 was 180 years old yesterday. On April 10, 1790, President George Washington signed the bill that for the first time in history recognized the intrinsic right of an in ventor to profit from his invention.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon joined an lite circle last week when he dissipated some his Presidential powers against what he saw as unseemly politi cal activities by the Supreme Court. Jefferson, Jackson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt had done the same, only to have the Court survive with more power than before.

title: LEUKEMIA LINKED TO CATS IN STUDY
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11A Iteam of researchers has found statistical evidence that they say shows, for the first time, a clear relationship between sick cats and some cases of leukemia in children.

title: Field Of Travel
description: AS high as the cost of asoline in the United tates is, American vis ?? abroad are met with even higher prices: 40 to 84 cents a gallon for reg ular gasoline and 47 to 90 cents for the premium va riety. The average price per gallon throughout Europe is 60 and 69 cents, respec tively.

title: CubsExpo Game Postponed
description: MONTREAL, April 11 (UPI) The scheduled baseball game between the Chicago Cubs and Montreal Expos today was postponed because of cold weather. The temperature two hours before the scheduled start of the game was 35 degrees.

title: Coeds to Join Penn Band
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11  Coeds will join the formerly all male cheerleaders and marching band at the Univer sity of Pennsylvania next fall.

title: Spain Lists Cave Paintings As a National Monument
description: MADRID, April 11 (Reuters) The Spanish Government has classified as a national monu ment a network of caves con taining prehistoric paintings of high quality.

title: College to Give Contrast
description: The third annual American Theater Festival of C. W. Post College of Long Island Uni versity will be held April 15 through April 19. The Con trast, the comedy by Royall Tyler, written in 1787, will be presented for eight perform ances during the fiveday festi val, which also will offer a series of exhibitions and per formances. Stuart Vaughn will direct.

title: New Snow Machine Seen as a Boon to Ski Centers
description: Something new in snow making that is expected to make a great impact on the ski industry will be demon strated this week at Jay Peak in North Troy, Vt.

title: Elizabeth Sexton Becomes a Bride
description: WARWICK, N. Y., April 11In the St. Francis Chapel at Mount Alverno Convent here this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Sexton, a junior at the College of New Ro chelle, was married to James Edward Cooper Jr., who is director of real estate for the Sterling Forest Corporation. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by, the Rev. Valentine Long.

title: Belgium Lays Claim to Flower Power
description: BRUSSELS  At 3 P.M. on Friday, Aug. 28, most of the 6,000 men, women and children in Lochristi, about an hour's drive from Brus sels, will stop whatever they are doing and stream out to the begonia fields that stretch for miles on either side of the village, Their task: to cut a million begonia flowers of eight different colors and three different sizes and bring them home by nightfall.

title: John Hancock Honors Writers
description: Five winner in the annual John Hancock awards con test for excellence in busi ness and financial writing last year were announced in Boston yesterday by Gerhard D. Bleicken, chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company. The awards will he made af cere monies this Fall.

title: New York, N.Y.
description: In 1941, two labor leaders David Duhinskv of the Inter national Ladies Garment Work ers Union and Alex Rose of the United Hatters, Cap and Milli nery Workersdropped out of the American Labor party with an attack on Communist infiltra tion of the eightyearold party.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Guilt and Songmy

title: In for Pneumonia, Man Is Billed for Childbirth
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 11 (AP)Ted Kazzmaroski, 37 years old, entered a local hospital recently for treat ment of pneumonia but, ac cording to his bill, suffered complications.

title: Karen Ann Oser Is Wed to Officer
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 11 Miss Karen Ann Oser and Lieut. John Ollie Edmunds Jr., senior medical officer at the Naval Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, New York, were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Name of Jesus.

title: Home Improvement
description: UNTIL recently, when a homeowner stopped in at his local paint or hardware store to buy some calking com pound there was little or no doubt as to what kind of material he would get  the only kind being widely sold and used was the oilbase calking that has been around for many years. The con sumer did have a choice of color (it comes in white, gray or black) and sometimes a choice of grade (many com panies make more than one quality), but that was all.

title: Bills Sign 3 Free Agents
description: BUFFALO, April 11 (AP) The Buffalo Bills announced the signing today of three free agents: Jim Gill, a 295pound tackle from McNeese State in Louisiana; a wide receiver, Torn McKernan of Omaha, and a lineman, Bill Crone of Loyola of Los Angeles.

title: Churches Warned of Thieves
description: LONDON (AP)To thwart thieves in England's 10,000 parish churches, the Council for the Care of Churches recom mended searching and locking the building at night, removing all ladders to safeguard any lead or copper in the roof, and placing a few simple spikes or coils of barbed wire at stra tegic positions.

title: Solzhenitsyn Can Still Write He Just Can't Publish
description: SAVING cotranslated Alexander Solzhenitsyn's novel Cancer Ward and play The Love Girl and the Innocent, I was particularly interested, when visiting Moscow re cently, in finding out how he lives. I wanted to speak to him, or, if not to him, at least to his friends, colleagues and sympathizers. But I did not know whether, with my special interest in Soviet affairs, I would even be allowed to move about the city in peace, let alone gossip with rebellious intel lectuals.

title: Ivory Coast Plans Nationwide School TV System
description: PARIS, April 3Two govern ments and three international organizations have joined forces to set up in the Ivory Coast Africa's first nationwide classroom television system.

title: The Transformation of Political Culture in Cuba
description: A second generation of books on the Cuban Revolution, now in its second decade, is beginning to take shape. These new books are far more detailed and analytical than those that came before, many of which suffered from excesses of special pleading, sometimes hysteri cal, in what were frequently first person accounts by recently exiled Cuban politicians or uncritical en dorsements by leftwing tourists adding only heat to the confused and passionate debate of the early 1960's.

title: WALKER NOTCHES HIS FIRST VICTORY
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (UPI)  Luke Walker and Chuck Hartenstein blanked Philadelphia on four hits today and the Pittsburgh Pirates ended the Phillies' threegame winning streak with a 40 vic tory.

title: An Early Warning System For Happenings in Nature
description: THE Case of the Giant Rat of Sumatra and the Repulsive Story of the Red Leech will never, unfor tunately, be known to sci ence. Their details, which might prove highly interest ing to zoologists, lie buried with Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John H. Watson, who judged the world unready for revela tions so disturbing. Secretive ness of this sort is much frowned upon by scientists.

title: ONE FOR ALL WINS STAKES IN FLORIDA
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 11 It had been a lean winter for Horatio Luro, one of the na tion's most accomplished and more dapper trainers. The senor, winner of two Kentucky Derbies and several dozen other stakes, had won only two allowance races in Florida this year and had one chance re maining to salvage the season.

title: Were You a Symbol N This Month?
description: FOR the average custom er, the points of fric tion between himself and Con Edison are most often the deposit and the bill. Unlike the New York Tele phone Company, which by comparison is generous about waiving an initial deposit, Con Edison re quires a minimum deposit on all new residential gas and electric accounts, except for selected homeown ers, religious organizations, business executives, em ployes with at least three years on one job, govern ment employes with one year on the job and wel fare clients (the Welfare Department makes good on its clients' bills).

title: Washington: Bring Us Together or Tear Us Apart?
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 President Nixon has put the worst possible interpretation on the Senate's vote against Judge Carswell, and the only way to make things more difficult and dangerous now is to put the worst possible interpretation on the President's remarks.

title: Gaynors Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Miles Gaynor of Scarsdale, N.Y., on Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. The child has been named Jill Elizabeth. Mrs. Gaynor is the former Miss Betty Ann Goldstein, daughter of Na than W. Goldstein, circula tion director of The New York Times, and Mrs. Gold stein.

title: Out West, the Census Taker Has to Hoof It
description: SUPAI, Ariz., April 8 There was still an allim portant hour of sunlight left as Robert Siyuja walked past the spring green cottonwoods down the village trail in three inches of sandy, red dust.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There aren't many publishing statistics in mystery fiction to rival those of John Creasey, but the late Erle Stanley Gard ner's are just about as incredi ble. According to Alice Payne Hackett's 70 Years of Best Sellers, 151 mystery titles have sold more than one million copies, and of these more than half were by Gard ner. Almost obscured in this mountain of paper is the fact that he started as a shortstory writer for the pulps, beginning in 1921, and during his most active year (1933) his byline appeared at least 60 times. That same year, his first novel  The Case of the Velvet Claws  was published, to be followed by nearly 140 more.

title: Turkey's Ancient Ruins Vie With Modern Resorts In Attracting Tourists
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyAlthough the tour ism bonanza anticipated for Turkey at the beginning of the 1960's did not materialize, more travelers than ever before came here last year, and the coun try's tourist industry is optimisically hailing 1970 as the Golden Year of Tourism.

title: The Search for The Perfect Inn
description: IHAVE never understood the fascina tion that surfers have with the per fect wave. Now it's here and now it's gone, on its way to or from Hawaii or whichever way those wet, elusive things go.

title: Jane Oatis Murphy Married To Gaetan Maurice Herbosch
description: Miss Jane Oatis Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. P. Murphy of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Gaetan Maurice Herbosch, son of Mrs. Mau rice Herbosch of Antwerp, Belgium and the late Mr. Herbosh.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Americans With Titles? Why Not a Briton Asks
description: MAURICE EDELMAN has been in the House of Commons for 25 years, but while other Members of Parliament aim phrases at one another, he puts most of his into works of fiction. Having examined the delicate skein the British Establishment in 10 novels, he is now visiting this country to see how Americans reward their upper classes.

title: Buchenwald Date Marked
description: BUCHENWALD, East Ger many, April 11 (Reuters) Former inmates of the Nazi concentration camp of Buchen wald gathered here today to mark the 25th anniversary of its liberation.

title: RALLY BY ORIOLES BEATS TIGERS, 53
description: BALTIMORE, April 11 (AP) Brooks Robinson's basesloaded double highlighted a fourrun eighth inning today that gave the Baltimore Orioles their fifth straight victory, a 53 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Soviet Photographs Spell U.S. Profits
description: Cameras whirred and snapped, recording every fa cet of a recent Soviet pho tographic exhibition here all 1,500 works.

title: Mrs. King Gets Post
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)Mrs. Coretta King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has accepted appointment to Boston University's Board of Fellows.

title: The Glories of Ceylon  Then and Now
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon  This pearshaped island off the southeast coast of India is only 270 miles long and 140 wide, but it encompasses a variety of landscape that few other coun tries can equal and it is encircled by nearly 1,000 miles of beaches. The visitor can choose to vacation in the warm west and south, the jungle areas of the south east and north or the central hill country, where temperatures range from 50 to 70 degrees.

title: Satellite Collects Data On Atmosphere and Elk
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)  America's newest weather satellite, Nimbus 4, has taken the temperature of an elk in Wyoming and has measured, for the first time, the temperature of a puzzling layer of the earth's upper atmosphere.

title: Goldberg Envisions Role of Governor as That of an Ombudsman
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, Demo cratic organization designed for Governor, said in an Interview last week that Governor Rocke feller has been a good gov ernor but not activist enough.

title: Reusable Space Rocket Forecast
description: TULLAHOMA, Tenn., April 11 (AP)  Airlinetype rockets may be heading into space later this decade, a space official said today.

title: Asian Development Bank Closes Meeting in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 11The 34nation Asian De velopment Bank closed the third annual meeting of its board of governors today. Tak eshi Watanahe, president of the bank, described the meeting as very successful.

title: RULES ON HOUSING SCORED AS CHAOTIC
description: An unpublished study by the Rand Corporation has described as chaotic the city's attempts to force landlords to maintain housing as prescribed by law, and it places much of the blame on the leniency of the criminal courts.

title: April 23 Luncheon to Benefit Girls Club
description: The Girls Club of New York will benefit from a luncheon and fashion festival to be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on April 23. Mrs. Theodore P. Donahue and Mrs. Paul H. Hornbeck are cochairmen for the event.

title: CASPER'S RIYALS NOT INTIMIDATED
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 Judging by the reactions of his closest rivals, Bill Casper does not intimidate his challengers for the Masters golf champion ship.

title: Hannah Darrin Will Be Bride
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., April 11Miss Hannah Lee Darrin, daughter of Ralph M. Darrin Jr. of Old Greenwich and Schenectady, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Darrin, plans to be married on Aug. 22 to James Falconer Sanford in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside.

title: The Littlest Evergreens
description: DWARF evergreens are natural dwarfs caused by some quirk of mixed genes in plant cells of otherwise normal woody plants. Sometimes a seedling is dwarf while other plants in the seedling row are normal, vigorousgrowing plants.

title: ABORTION IS LEGAL IN MANY COUNTRIES
description: A number of foreign coun tries permit abortions for one or more reasons, according to the Association for the Study of Abortion.

title: St. Barts: Pure French, Even Sans Gendarmes
description: GUSTAVIA, St. Barthelemy, F.W.I. We were three passengers pre paring to leave Juliana Airport on St. Maarten for the island of St. Barthelemy. We also represented a fair percentage of the twoor three dozen tourists  half of them French who visit St. Barthelemy each week during the high season.

title: Trinity Eight Easy Victor Over Amherst, C.W. Post
description: HARTFORD, Conn., April 11 Trinity College led from start to finish today and won the seventh annual MasonDixon Cup regatta on the Connecticut River by defeating Amherst and C. W. Post.

title: Foreign Affairs: If Roosevelt Had Lived?
description: THE HAGUE  On April 13, 1945, I was in Moscow when the news was received that late the previous day President Franklin Roosevelt had died.

description: Following are highlights of the Apollo 13 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern Standard.

title: A Doctor's Tonic For Oakland Birds
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Per haps the most remark able thing about the ducks and other wild birds on Lake Merritt is that they choose to come here at all. This lake, the nation's oldest wildlife refuge, is sit uated in the most unlikely of placesright in the middle of beautiful downtown Oakland. Oakland, that is, not Bur bank.

title: BIG RISE FORESEEN IN U.S. ATOM ARMS
description: LONDON, April 11The In stitute for Strategic Studies said today that the United States, on current planning, could have 11,000 nuclear warheads in its strategic force by 1975.

title: CORNELL CAPTURES LIGHTWEIGHT RACES
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 11 Cornell's lightweight oarsmen opened their season today by sweeping both races from Penn sylvania and regaining the Matthews Cup. The Quakers took the cup for the first time last year.

title: NETs' RALLY FAILS, PIPERS WIN, 124113
description: PITTSBURGH, April 11 (AP) John Brisker, a rookie scored 29 points and Warren Davis added 28 tonight in leading the Pittsburgh Pipers to a 124113 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball As sociation game.

title: Roosevelt's Doctor Says Last Illness Did Not Prevent President From Performing Duties
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 President Franklin D. Roose velt was in total command of his faculties during his last illness, despite rumors to the contrary, according to a medi cal report to be published to morrow on the 25th anniver sary of his death.

title: In Memoriam
description: DELSONLizzle, 29 years missing and lov ing my adored mother, Rose West.

title: The Breaks of the Game Could Last a Lifetime
description: LONDON, April 11 (AP) Roger Brookshaw, an ama teur soccer player who was sent off the field for kick ing an opponent and breaking his leg, will spend the nex 37 years paying for it.

title: Shirley and Eleanor Griggs to Be Brides
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 11Miss Shirley Hopkins Griggs plans to be married to Bruce Edmund Bradley in August. Her sister, Miss Eleanor Southworth Griggs, plans to be married in Sep tember to Robert Emery Diemar Jr.

title: Miss Dianne E. Mullane Bridge Of James A. Magee, a Lawyer
description: Miss Dianne E. Mullane and James Allan Magee, 1966 graduates of the University of Michigan Law School, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Cath olic Church of St. Thomas More by the Rev. William Lewis.

title: SECRECY IS IMPOSED ON MYLAI HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) A Conareasional Investigation of the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai will begin Wednesday under strict secrecy.

title: Just 25 Years Ago Today in Warm Springs ...
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga.Twenty five years ago today, as Franklin Delano Roosevelt was sitting for a portrait in the living room of the Little White House, he put a trembling hand to his forehead and slumped forward, uncon scious. Two hours later he was dead of a massive brain hemorrhage without having regained consciousness.

title: Scotch Whisky
description: Its Past and Present. By David Daiches. Illustrated. 168 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $9.95.On his celebrated and pioneering safari to the Hebrides, Dr. Johnson condescended to drink a glass of whisky, telling Boswell that he want ed to know what it is that makes a Scotchman happy. This celebrated if ambiguous compliment to the Gae lic water of life reminds us of how comparatively recent is the fame and fortune of whisky.

title: SOLUTIONS
description: (Mary) CABLE: (The) AVENUE OF THE PRESI DENTS Then came Bull Run. When the troops moved out over.

title: Rockefeller, Signing Abortion Bill, Credits Women's Groups
description: ALBANY, April 11  Gover nor Rockefeller signed into law today the new abortion reform bill, adding New York to a growing list of states increas ing a woman's control over the medical termination of her pregnancy.

title: Paul Worthen Higgins Marries Christina Slats, a Bacteriologist
description: Miss Christina Thomson Slats, a bacteriologist at Rock efeller University, was mar ried here yesterday to Paul Higgins, whose father, Capt. John Worthen Higgins Jr., U.S.N., retired is commission er of the Flordia Keys Aque duct System.

title: Bergen Celebrates A Birthday
description: OSLO  The news from Norway this year centers on the fact that the West Coast city of Bergen is 900 years old. This is longevity, even for Scandinavia (Copenhagen is 100 years younger, Stockholm nearly 200), and the 127,000 inhabitants of that friendly city of music, fish and fjords are using that as an excuse for a celebration this summer.

title: House Swap Nets Landmark
description: ONE way to acquire an authentic early Amer ican house on Long Island is to swap it for a split level in Princeton, N. J. In any case it worked for Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kap lan two years ago.

title: East GermanSomali Ties
description: BERLIN, April 11 (AP)East Germany and Somalia have agreed to establish diplomatic relations, the East German press agency announced today.

title: MOSCOW IS GIVEN SPRING CLEANING
description: MOSCOW, April 11 Thou sands of Muscovites gave up their day off today to prune bushes, repair streets and wash windows as part of a nation wide voluntary day of work.

title: Publishing In the Promised Land
description: Thirteen minutes after I ar rived in Los Angeles, I was picked up and shepherded to a luncheon meeting of the Book Publishers Association of Southern California. Over the next two and onehalf hours I was to be astonished by sev eral things: the teeming New York style rain, for which each publisher in the restaurant felt personally, jingoistically obliged to apologize and to assure me it was obviously the only rain I would ever experience in L. A. (It continued, I would like to add, for 11 days and 11 nights); the guest speaker who, I figured, in a town filled with currently idle movie stu dios, would certainly be no less than Burt Lancaster but, in fact, turned out to be a free lance promotional brochure maker who talked about gate folds.

title: Coins
description: THE United Nations will issue two types of med als to mark its 25th anniversary this year. There will be a limited num ber of solid sterling silver pieces released on April 25 to commemorate the opening of the United Nations Confer ence on International Organ ization, held in California in 1945. Others will be issued on June 26, the date of the signing of the U.N. charter in 1945 at Veterans Memor ial Hall in San Francisco.

title: Car in L.I.R.R. Tests Develops Gas Pains
description: The Budd Company's GT2 experimental gasturbine rail road car is recovering from an attack of acute asphyxi ation that will delay its cur rent testing program on the Long Island Rail Road for an estimated four weeks.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
NAVY BIDS PRINCETON END R.O.T.C. PROGRAM
description: The Navy has asked Prince ton University to eliminate its 25yearold Navy Reserve Offi cers Training Corps program, university officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Eskimos Sign Two Backs
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, April 11 (Canadian Press)Manuel Britto, an American halfback, and Bayne Morris, a Canadian halfback, signed today with the Edmonton Eskimos of the Western Football Conference.

title: Carnevale and Davies Inducted Into Basketball's Hall of Fame
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 11Ben Carnevale, who coached North Carolina and Navy into National Collegi ate Athletic Association bas ketball tournaments, and Bob Davies, the best player dur ing Seton Hall's heyday on the court, were inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame today.

title: Detained Zorba Composer Transferred to Sanitarium
description: ATHENS, April 11  Mikis Theodorakis, the imprisoned Greek composer, was reported by his father, George Theodora kis, today to have been trans ferred to Sotiria sanitarium near Athens after a relapse caused by tuberculosis.

title: ANTIWAR RALLIES SET FOR THIS WEEK
description: WASHINGTON. April 11  Widespread antiwar activities are scheduled for this coming week, culminating on Wednes day, with rallies, leaflet distri bution and demonstrations in more than 200 cities and towns across the nation.

title: STUDENTS STRESS DRUG EDUCATION
description: Students at Martin Van Bur en High School in Queens, a school without a tradition of student involvement in dealing with basic student problems, have drafted their own pro gram for dealing with narco tics addiction problem.

title: C.C.N.Y. Downs Wagner With 2 Runs in 9th, 1110
description: Stu Pepper, the relief pitcher, singled across two runs with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning to spark City Col lege to an 1110 victory over Wagner in a Metropolitan Base ball conference game yesterday at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx.

title: Blacks Seeking to Manage Building
description: BLACK real estate brok ers in Harlem are call ing upon the white owners of a new Harlem of fice building to appoint a black to manage the build ing. Black real estate agents are in charge of a few of the large apartment develop ments built in Harlem in re cent years, but a black agent for commercial prop erty in Harlem is rare, if not nonexistent.

title: Problem of Drug Use
description: That we are in a world pan demic of drug dependence, which has become the polite way to say drug addiction, is a fact that cannot he ignored and swept under the rug. Every one seems to be talking about doing something, but to date there has been more anguish than action.

title: Beef Plant Workers in Nebraska Await Call to Work After Violent Strike Ends
description: DAKOTA CITY, Neb., April 11Men and women here who picketed day and night for 227 days during a violent strike at one of the world's largest meat processing plants are awaiting a call back to work following a compromise settlement that was reached Thursday.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES BILL ON RESEARCH
description: ALBANY, April 11A bill that would establish a state board to regulate research and experimentation on human sub jects was passed today by the State Assembly.

title: Cambodian Civil Servants Enjoy Drills
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 11 Mildmannered civil serv ants, their secretaries and mes sengers in Government minis tries are showing a relish for military dress and drill under the encouragement of the new leadership of Cambodia.

title: Athens and Bonn at Odds Over Trial
description: ATHENS, April 11  The courtmartial of 34 opponents; of the Greek regime on sedition; charges has touched off a crisis in relations between Greece and, West Germany.

title: G.O.P. BROCHURE ON BLACKS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The National Republican Con gressional Committee has, stirred a mild controversy by publishing a roster of Negroes, who the committee said hold key positions in the Nixon Ad ministration.

title: Trevino and Hinson to Play In Rich New Orleans Golf
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 11 (AP)Winners of most of the major golf tournaments this year will he on hand Thursday to try for the $25,000 first prize money in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tourna ment.

title: Living With History In Spacious Fincastle
description: FINCASTLE, Va.  Botetourt County, here in southwest Vir ginia, is celebrating the 200th anniversary of its founding this year. Two centuries ago, the county stretched to the Mississippi River, and the settlement of Fincastle, the pres ent county seat, was an early gateway to the Kentuck and beyond.

title: Will Success Spoil The Insentive Folk Artists of San Blas?
description: PANAMA CITY, Panama  In the archipelago of San Blas, 360 co conutpalmed coral blips off the Caribbean coast of Panama, Cuna tribesman, dressed drably as coolie, commutes to the mainland daily by dugout canoe, tends his vegetable patch in the jungle, markets the coco nuts and does a little fishing.

title: Moratorium on MIRV and ABM
description: The Senate's call for an immediate SovietAmerican moratorium on nuclear weapons deployment provides President Nixon with an opportunity really to negoti ate from strength in the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) when they resume Thursday in Vienna. The bipartisan 726 vote for the revised Brooke reso lution amounts to an offer by the upper house to share the responsibilityand the risksinvolved in making this proposal to Moscow.

title: Observer: Let's Let Baby Choose His Own
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The present issue of Look ex plains how prospective parents can choose their baby's sex. The instructions, detailed be tween pages 88 and 98 of that magazine, should not be be yond the grasp of anyone accustomed to performing a moderately complex industrial process.

title: How the G.I.'s in Vietnam Don't Learn About the War
description: SAIGON. APRIVATE first class whose company was ambushed and mauled by the enemy will know intimately the anthill behind which he hid trying to save his hide, but his mother in Des Moines, Iowa, will probably know more about the whole fight than he does.

title: EDWARD R. ROSENBAUM
description: Edward R. Rosenbaum, board chairman of the Dialight Corporation of New York, an electronics company, died at Doctors Hospital Friday of cancer. He was 74 years old, and lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: Kerr on the Pinter Plays
description: ALMOST the eeriest thing that happened at the opening performance of Harold Pinter's two new plays, Silence and Land scape, at the Forum here was the sound of one manone man onlyapplauding as the lights went up to start the evening. The man con tinued to applaud though no one joined him. By the time he had subsided, the mood of the playsfaraway, echo chambered, discontinuous, gray on whitehad been es tablished as if by prearranged collusion.

title: Mexico's Olmecs Pose A Riddle: Priests, Gods or Ball Players?
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico  A new road off Mexican Highway 186 leads to the site of La Venta, a center of Olmec civilization that was perhaps the oldest city in the Americas. It is believed to date from about 1200 B.C., preceding the betterknown Mayan civilization by a thousand years.

title: Tennessee Tree Planting
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Tennessee's state tree, a tulip poplar, is to be planted on the Capitol grounds next week with appropriate ceremonies. Repre sentative Richard H. Fulton, Democrat of Tennessee, said state dignitaries, including Gov. Buford Ellington, have been in vited to the event Tuesday morning, April 14.

description: ON a nondescript avenue just south of Astoria in Long Island City stands a sturdy if rundown group of fourstory apartment houses, home for 106 families.

description: FINANCIAL markets maintained a re markably stable course during the last two weeks in the face of some potentially unsettling developments on the economic, national and international fronts.

title: NIXON SAID TO CUT HIGH COURT LIST TO THREE JUDGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 11A high Administration official said today that President Nixon had narrowed his search for a new Supreme Court Justice to three Federal judgesHarry A. Blackmun of Minnesota, Edward T. Gignoux of Maine and Alfred T. Goodwin of Ore gon.

title: MAYOR TO ORDER MINORITY HIRING
POPE ADMONISHES ITALIAN BISHOPS
description: ROME, April 11Pope Paul VI firmly told his Italian bishops today not to yield to attacks on their authority and advised them to deal severely with priests and laymen who dissented from orthodox Catho lic teaching in a mistaken ef fort to invent and create a new church.

title: Riders Are Pleased by a CenturyOld, FamilyRun Jersey Bus Line
description: CLIFTON, N. J., April 11 At a time when militancy and discohtent are becoming nor mal states among commuters generally, it is still possible to find a transportation line making more patrons happy than not.

description: BOSTON, April 11Stiffer competition from foreign shoe imports is being blamed for declining output in the New England shoe and slipper industry.

title: Merman: A Kid Who Wins All the Marbles
description: IN THE END the only rea son they'll have for closing Hello, Dolly! is to get ready to open the revival the following Monday. Hello, Dolly! does now loom as a permanent nation al institution, one that in vites anybody who is any body to drop in and play it sometime. It may become, for all star performers who can wear red on red, a kind of test match, a rite of ini tiation, an ordeal by fire and an election by accolade: Eith er you do it right or you don't get into heaven, or Sar di's, or sixth grade.

title: Body of Envoy Slain in Guatemala Flown to Germany
description: BONN, April 11 (AP) The body of Count Karl von Spreti, the murdered West German Ambassador to Gua temala, arrived here today aboard a West German Air Force plane and was hon ored with a military cere mony.

title: State Department Voids Visa of Wife Of Belgian Marxist
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The State Department has de nied permission for Gisela Man del, wife of the Belgian Marxist economist, Ernest Mandel, to enter the United States at the invitation of the Columbia Uni versity Student Mobilization Committee.

description: TENNIS continued on its merry carousel last week, extending an uneasy arm to ward a ring of gold and the answer to its numerous ad ministrative problems.

title: M. J. Brienze to Wed Tiffany Pratt
description: WESTON, Conn., April 11 Miss Tiffany Phelps Pratt and Michael Joseph Brienze plan to be married next Sat urday in Westport. Miss Pratt is a credit analyst with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, where her fianc is a financial an alyst with Time Inc.

title: GAY MISSILE WINS KEENELAND DASH
description: LEXINGTON, April 11 (AP) Michael G. Phipps's Gay Missile scored an easy victory in the $32,025 Ashland Stakes at Keeneland, but the victory was overshadowed by Hard Work's pounce into the Kentucky Derby limelight.

title: STUDY SAYS SOVIET BOLSTERS BORDER
description: LONDON, April 11 An authoritative estimate indicated today that the Soviet Union has substantially increased its troop strength near the Chinese border but is still outweighed by Chinese manpower in the area.

title: Music
description: SURPRISINGLY little scholarly work has been done on American instrumentalists of the 19th century, and even less on Negro instrumentalists. Standard reference books on American music, while pay ing great attention to Negro music (spirituals, ragtime, jazz), have next to nothing to say about the black mu sicians of the period. Even W. S. B. Mathew's enormous book on American musicians, which came out in the 1880's and lists every Amer ican performer of importance, keeps away from the Negro. One might understand 19th century lack of references to Negro performers, but it is surprising that more atten tion has not been paid to them today  today, when many Negro musicians are international headliners, and when the Negro is experi encing a great sense of pride in his accomplishments.

title: Paul Woody Weds Jane Marie Werner
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 11Miss Jane Marie Werner and Paul Richard Woody, a thirdyear medical student at Temple University, were mar ried at the Hitchcock Pres byterian Chapel here this af ternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Dev. Dr. James Seth Stewart.

title: SISCO OPENS TALKS WITH U.A.R. LEADERS
description: CAIRO, April 11 (Reuters) Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco declined com ment today after a meeting with Foreign Minister Mah mould Riad of the United Arab Republic. The meeting, the first in a series with Egyptian leaders was depicted by a For sign Ministry source as an ex change of conflicting views.

title: Sarah McK. Willard, Teacher, Fiancee of Charles Devens Jr.
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., April 11 Mr. and Mrs. Louis Willard Jr. have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah McKnight Wil lard, to Charles Devens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Devens of Milton, Mass.

title: Anne Elizabeth Clarke Is Wed To Peter Brown, an Architect
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 11 Miss Anne Elizabeth Clarke and Peter Harrison Brown of New York, were married here today at the home of Mr. and Miss Anne Elizabeth Clarke Mrs. Edward Perry Clarke, the bride's father and step mother. The Rev. Donald Poole of the Rye Presbyterian Church performed the cere mony.

title: David Miller Gaffney Marries Miss Nancy Chandler Buddy
description: Miss Nancy Chandler Bud dy and David Miller Gaffney were married at St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul Thompson.

title: Plymouth Plans a Monumental Beanfeast
description: PLYMOUTH, EnglandOn Sept. 6, 1620350 years agoa sobersided company of 102 men, women and children, many of them seeking freedom of religious conscience, stepped afloat from the granite quays of this ancient Devon seaport. The Pilgrims who embarked for the New World that day would startled to see what a monumental beanfeast the anniversary of their sailing is going to be.

title: Old lronsides in Good Shape
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)The Navy has not let Old Iron sides decay at her berth but spends a quarter of a million dollars annually to keep the historic ship in shape, Rear, Adm. J. C. Wylie said this week. The commandant of the First Naval District called a news conference Thursday on the main deck of the U.S.S. Consti tution to lay to rest some un fortunate rumors, he said.

title: POLICEMAN GIVEN CASH, WOMAN SAYS
description: A prosecution witness  an admitted numbers runnertes tified yesterday at the depart mental trial of a police lieuten ant that she had seen the offi cer being handed money last July by her policygambling boss.

title: Political Terrorism Hysteria On the Left
description: THE life of the political terrorist is overwhelmed by loneliness, not merely because he can no longer trust completely friend or comrade, but because he cuts himself off from all movements and com munities in which choices can be weighed. Staking everything on the act, he blocks off all that comes be fore it and all that comes after. Deciding whom to smite, he replaces God. Choosing whom to punish, he replaces the justice (be it good or bad) of society. And since the con flicts of social classes must be bent to his will, he replaces history, too. The terrorist carries a moral burden only saints or fanatics would under takeworst of all, fanatics mistaking themselves for saints.

title: Undefeated Navy Crushes Princeton in Lacrosse, 9 to 3, for Fourth Victory
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 11 Navy's unbeaten lacrosse team scored five goals in the second period today and routed Prince ton, 93. The victory was the fourth for the middies.

title: A Novel Week For Choruses
description: THE standard choral works stay with us, more or less. But in an unusual combination of events, New York will be hearing three brand new, full  scale compositions for chorus and orchestra next Friday and Sunday.

title: Mutual Fund Industry Suffers as Its NewShare Sales Decline
description: The mutual fund industry, where portfolo values have eroded for more than a year now because of declining securities prices, is beginning to suffer on another front.

title: ACADEMY STUDIES END TO POLLUTION
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 11Dramatic confronta tions over threats to the en vironment may draw attention tothe dangers of pollution, but they do not solve problems, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democat of Washington, said here today.

title: Edith Sands Blake Married To Peter Stickney Anderson
description: Miss Edith Sands Blake and Peter Stickney Anderson were married here yesterday afternoon in St. James Epis copal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph Warren.

title: Toronto Faces Problem: To Drive or Not to Drive
description: TORONTO, April 11 (Reuters) By 1980, Toronto could have North America's most complex transportation network with skycars, Hovercraft and mov ing sidewalks linked with sub way and fast commuter sur face lines. Or, according to urban planners here, it could become a tightly packed auto mobile park, too impoverished even to improve its bus service.

title: To Know the Allagash Start as a Boy of 12 And Wait 80 Years
description: ALLAGASH, Me.A visiting canoe ist asked Fred Hafford, a local resident and former lumberjack, how to get to know the Allagash Wilderness Waterway. Hafford, who at 74 has the vitality of men half his age, replied, By starting when you're 12 and waiting for 70 to 80 years.

title: Rindt Posts Fastest Time In Trials for Clark Race
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Ger many, April 11 (UPI)Jochen Rindt of Austria emerged to day as the fastest driver from the twoday practice for to morrow's Jim Clark Memorial Formula Two auto race.

title: Whites Said to outpace Nonwhites in Reading Deficiency Here
description: A private analysis of the Board of Education's current citywide reading test scores has concluded that predomi nantly white areas seem to be going downhill faster than pre dominantly nonwhite areas.

title: Drexel Crew Captures Grimaldi Cup
description: PELHAM, N. Y., April 11 Drexel Tech of Philadelphia, breaking away to a halflength lead at the start, rowed to a solid victory in the annual Gri maldi Cup regatta over the 2,000meter Orchard Beach La goon course today.

title: The Responsive Roosevelt
description: A quarter of a century ago today Franklin D. Roose velt died, and with his death the Age of Roosevelt ended for America and the world.

title: For Public Spaces, Rather Than Private Places
description: FOR sheer visual ele gance, it would be dif ficult to improve upon the recent sculpture of Anthony Padovano now on view in a striking show at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 41 East 57th Street. The ex hibition consists of four mod estlyscaled pieces in welded steel whose highly polished and chromed surfaces per form an important function in Padovano's radically sim plified formal vocabulary, as well as a series of smaller castmetal sculptures which represent a newer experimen tal mode for the artist.

title: TWINS TURN BACK ATHLETICS, 8 TO 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 11 (UPI)Jim Kaat gave up seven hits and drove in two runs as the Minnesota Twins walloped the Oakland Athletics, 82, in their home opener to day before 21,653.

title: News of the Rialto
description: SINCE, sooner or later, Broadway manages to catch up with events, world and local, it probably will come as no surprise that a space musi cal is on the launching pad. It's called, rather poetically, Via Galactica, which, for the benefit of the theater party ladies who will be asked to sell it, may be read as Road to the Stars.

title: PARIS FIXES NO BLAME IN FATAL SNOWSLIDE
description: PARIS, April 11A Govern has found that nobody was re ment commission of inquiry sponsible for the death of 39 young vacationers in an ava anche at Vald'Isre Feb. 10. At the same time, however, it re ported a series of anomalies in the award of building per mits in the mountains as a re sult of the ski boom.

title: Otto F. Langmann, Artist And Architect, Dies at 85
description: Otto F. Langmann, an archi tect and artist, died at his home, at 129 East 82d Street, Thursday. He was 85 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Ultimate in Brotherhood

title: 4POWER BALANCE FORESEEN IN ASIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11A new array of major powers is emerging in East Asia and will reduce the chances of big power confrontation there, a prominent political scientist has forecast here.

title: Sills a Leading Judge
description: A. Nelson Sills, track super intendent at Dclwarc Park, is one of the nation's field trial judges. Sills also is the owner of a former national retriever champion.

title: Merchants And Masterpieces
description: At the formal dedication of the Metropolitan Museum in its perma nent quarters in Central Park in March, 1880, Joseph C. Choate, one of the trustees and a distinguished lawyer, stated in the principal ad dress of the day that the authors of the enterprise believed that the dif fusion of a knowledge of art in its higher forms of beauty would tend directly to humanize, to educate and refine a practical and laborious people.

title: Photography
description: NO microcosm better exemplifies Marshall McLuhan's concept of the global vil lage than the world of art in our time. Assimiliationism is rampant in every creative medium, and experimenta tion so prevalent that the avant and derrieregardes seem to have reversed roles, with the more tradition ori ented now in a definite, if de fiant, minority. The arts have so overlapped that it is fast becoming impossible to tell precisely to which media (save for the catchall mixed) individual works belong without consulting wall labels, those esthetic equivalents of scorecards; and, with curators hot on the heels of each new break through, even those are not always useful.

title: The Heron
description: Quite soon in The Heron you will recall the brilliant opening scenes in Across the River and Into the Trees. In Hemingway's novel the boats moved slowly in the Venetian lagoon, the beatup colonel took aim at the ducks and hunting became an occasion for personal fulfillment. As the middleaged protagonist in Giorgio Bassani's new novel sits along one of the branches of the Po not far from Venice, the duckblind becomes a sym bol of his personal futility. Observing two artists at work in the same landscape, one creating from the outside in and the other from the inside out, you rediscover the infinite human possibilities that only the novelist can convey.

title: Mary Morse Bride Of M. W. Calhoun
description: WILTON, Conn., April 11 Miss Mary Hadley Morse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Boyd Morse, was married here this afternoon to Michael Woodbridge Cal houn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Calhoun of New Canaan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Chester M. Miller of the Wil ton Congregational Church at the home of the bride's par ents.

title: From Sultan or Store, Tiara Can Be Woman's Crowning Glory
description: MISS AMERICA is always given one. The first time she wears it she usually cries.

title: Pop
description: STEVIE WONDER, little no more, the mighty mite of Motown grown to six footrallI'ma man maturity. We sit in his hotel room at the Waldorf, a room surprisingly modest in size for a soul singer of his magni tude, and rap about the re markable path he has traveled since the good old days when as a precocious 12yearold, he recorded his first hit, Finger Tips.

title: Another Carthage invasion: Tourists
description: CARTHAGE, Tunisia  in tne near ly 3,000 years since the arrival of the Phoenicians from the east ern end of the Mediterranean, Carthage has been the cynosure of a succession of civilizations  European, Asian, African. Now the tourists are flocking in.

title: U.S. to Tighten Surveillance of Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Nixon Administration, alarmed by what it regards as a rising tide of radical extrem ism, is planning to step up sur veillance of militant leftwing groups and individuals.

title: Spotlight:
description: Despite all the current un certainty about the stock market and where it may be heading, people have been putting in some good words about the noload mutual funds.

title: Ellen Hinch Affianced
description: FREEPORT, L.I., April 11 Mrs. Wiliam R. Hinch has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellen Marie Hinch, to William H. Cutrone, son of Mrs. William J. Cutrone, and the late Mr. Cutrone. Miss Hinch is a daughter also of the late Mr. Hinch.

title: Business Index Off in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 344.4 from 356.8 a week earlier. A year ago it was 336.9.

title: Cambodians Stage Nationalistic Rally With Martial Tone
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 11The new leaders of Cam bodia staged their first mass rally today in an atmosphere of intense nationalism and mar tial resolution. The accent was on youth, and the tone was military.

title: Malaysian Forces in Sarawak Fighting Guerrillas
description: KUCHING, Malaysia, March 2SThe famed white rajahs are gone from Sarawak, where the English Brooke family once held supreme power. This state on Borneo's northwest coast joined the federation of Ma laysia in 1963.

title: In Retailing, Shrinkage Is Outdistancing Profits
description: Inventory shrinkage, the combination of human dis honesty and human error, has risen to a new high among the nation's stores. Its rate of increase in the re cently completed retailing fiscal year in February has averaged more than double the increase in sales.

title: Police in Jerusalem Clash With Leftist Protesters
description: JERUSALEM, April 11 (AP) The police clashed today with about 150 young Israeli leftists demonstrating outside the residence of Premier Golda Meir. Several of the demon strators were reported injured. Eight arrests were made.

title: Untitled Subjects
description: Poems by Richard Howard. 88 pp. New York. Atheneum. Paper, $3.95

title: Plea Bargaining Is Upheld on Appeal
description: The common practice of plea bargaining  arranging guilty pleas to lesser offenses than the crimes originally charged in return for lighter penalties was upheld last week in a Fed eral Court of Appeals decision here.

title: Laura Lowy and Richard Adler, Seniors at Berkeley, Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Lowy of New York have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Renee Lowy to Richard Alex ander Adler, son of Mrs. Ira Guilden of New York and Sidney Adler of Los Angeles.

title: Miss Helen May Becomes Bride Of John Page Jr.
description: LANCASTER, Pa., April 11 The Franklin and Marshall College Chapel here was the scene of the wedding of Miss Helen Hartman May, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Skyles May, and John Nor cross Page Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Page of Mont clair, N. J.

title: Rumanian Ends Prague Visit
description: PRAGUE, April 11 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Comeliu Manescu of Rumania left here by air today for Bucharest at the end of a threeday official visit to Czechoslovakia.

title: Carnation Ball to Provide Asthma Research Fund
description: Flower Power will be the theme of the Carnation Ball at the WaldorfAstoria on April 29 to raise money for the Children's Asthma Re search Institute and Hospi tal in Denver.

title: REED TALFIES 24
description: The full menace of Lew Al cindor did not materialize at Madison Square Garden yester day, even though he scored 35 points, and the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 110102, in the opening game of their four ofseven game National Basket ball Association playoff series.

title: Exclusive: All About Kate
description: KATHARINE WILD FLOWER, the star of Duckie!, a superhit Broadway musical comedy based on the life and times of Renee (Duckie) L'Or ange, worldfamous pastry maker and feminist, is a truly remarkable woman.

title: Recordings
description: IN 1924, when Leos Jan acek's Jenufa was given its American premiere by the Metropolitan Opera, it was denounced by Ernest Newman, the distinguished English critic who was then a guest writer with The New York Evening Post. Of the characters he said: A more complete collection of unde sirables and incredibles has never previously appeared in opera. (One wonders what he found to like about those in Rigoletto.) The music, Newman added, is obviously the work of a man who ... is only a cut above the am ateur.

title: Jane Louis Wed To Harvey Gorrin
description: Miss Jane Ellen Louis and Harvey David Gorrin were married here yesterday by Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz in the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Mrs. Lovell Is Consulted
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 11 (AP)Even the wife of one astronaut was consulted over whether Apollo 13 should be launched today. The NASA ad ministrator, Dr. Thomas O. Paine, said he had a frank talk with Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., the spacecraft commander. I asked him how Marilyn felt about this. Dr. Paine said, re, ferring to Captain Lovell's wife. Jim said that Marilyn was very, enthusiastic about the mission.

title: IMISHEL PIASTRO, VIOLINIST, IS DEAD
description: Mishel Piastro, violinist and conductor, died Friday of can cer at his home, 405 East 54th Street. He was 77 years old.

title: Travelers Facing Stricter Searches By Customs Men
description: The usually friendly customs inspector is going to be a little less amicable in his relations with the traveling public this summer.

title: Tunic time
description: The long tunic holds its own in the spring and summer fashion scene, and the longer the better. It is a shirt, a smock, a cardigan. In soft fabrics, the tunic looks great pulled down over pants or worn with a skirt. Pull ing it all together is the wide laced belt, the wrapped sash and the scarf.

title: FORD ENVOYS DUE IN MOSCOW TODAY
description: DETROIT, April 11Henry 2d and two top Ford Motor Company aides are scheduled to arrive in Moscow tomorrow at the invitation of the Soviet Government.

title: New Pro Wrestling Era: It's for Real
description: Will the public pay $4 to see 10 wrestling matches, real matches between former intercollegiate and Olympic competitors turned profes sional?

title: 1,000 Attend Temple EmanuEl Services to Mark the Congregation's 125th Anniversary
description: Temple EmanuEl, the larg est Jewish Reform congrega tion in the world, celebrated its 125th anniversary today as more than 1,000 worshipers filled the edifice at 65th Street and Fifth Avenue for a special, service.

title: What's New in Art
description: TODAY

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am a mathematician not a businessman. Nevertheless, I believe that ltzhak Sharav's conclusions on building up keep costs [March 29 Real Estate section] will not stand up to critical evaluation.

title: A Kooky Time for Coco
description: TERRENCE McNALLY, author of the longrun ning Off Broadway comedy, Next, is set to make his scrcenwriting debutand he's going a bit Off Hollywood to do it. The name of the film is Noon, and it will be based on his contribution to the 1968 Off Broadway triple bill, Morn ing, Noon and Night.

title: Thomas Marshall Jr., 59, Dead; Director of Society for Testing
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 Thomas A. Marshall Jr., man aging director of the American Society for Testing and Materi als, died Thursday of cancer in Hahnemann Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Radnor.

title: Nilo Bay, $4.40, Recovers For Suffolk Downs Victory
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)  Nilo Bay overcame early inter ference today and won the $15,000 Varsity Drag Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

title: No Damage in Alaska Quake
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, April 11 (UPI)No damage was reported from an earthquake that jarred Yakutat, about 200 miles north of here, last night.

title: Sandra W. Cuneo Bride in Capital Of David dePury
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Miss Sandra Watson Cuneo and David dePury were married here this afternoon at the Episcopal Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul. The Rev. Craig Eder performed the ceremony.

title: Art
description: OSAKA, Japan. WITH its diversified audience re sponding to the spectacle in diversified ways, any world's fair exists at many levels. But none until Osaka's Expo '70 has includ ed a large segment of a national popu lation comparable to Japan's country people, people who not long ago would have been called peasants. Westerners are hardly aware of them, but they are the foundation of a pyramid whose tip does not count for much when you try to see Expo as anything more than carnival.

title: Hartke Says He Will Seek A Third Term in the Senate
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 11 (AP)Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, announced today that he would seek a third term and said the 1970 campaign would he a test of one man's record, his own.

title: HARVARD DIVIDES 2 WITH COLUMBIA
description: Doug Watt drove In a pair of runs to lead Columbia to a 21 victory over Harvard in the first game of an Eastern League doubleheader at Baker Field yesterday.

title: Columbia Crew Scores a Victory Over M. I.
description: Columbia University's varsity heavyweight crew returned to the Harlem yesterday after a successful tworegatta stand in Florida and defeated a Massa chusetts Institute of Technology eight by a length under sunny skies.

title: Skimming, a Bay In New Zealand On a Cream Roar
description: KERIKERI, New ZealandAlthough 31 years have passed since a fail ing dairy industry in the Bay of Is lands, in nothern New Zealand, shipped out its last can of milk by launch, the motor craft that still plies those scenic waters with mail, supplies and tourists is known to this day as the cream boat.

title: Personality:
description: Can a former captain of the Columbia College basket ball team make it as the new president of the Allied Stores Corporation?

title: Meeting Miss Welty
description: By the information counter in the Jackson, Miss, airport waits a tall, plain, grayhaired lady with bright blue eyes and a droll, shy smile for an arriving visitor she's never seen before. When told earlier that he would land at noon and get a taxi to her house, she had refused to bear of it: It's just a few minutes away, it's the easiest thing in the world to meet you. Now, no air port is just a few minutes away, but the first thing you learn about Eudora Welty is that one of the most admired of living writers hasn't learned to be a grande dame.

title: SYNANON TO CEASE OPERATIONS HERE
description: The Synanon Foundation has sold its fourstory brownstone at 35 Riverside Drive and plans to cease all operations here within 60 days unless it re ceives $500,000 in contributions and a building large enough to house 100 people.

title: Lockheed's Illness Is Contagious
description: BURBANK, Calif.The financial plight of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, is symptomatic of a far more pervasive malaise spreading in the aerospace in dustry.

title: Frazier Sticks to Defense, Holds Robinson to 4 Baskets in 16 Shots
description: The Knicks got the jump on the Milwaukee Bucks yesterday in part because of the slightly uncharacteristic play of Walt Frazier.

title: What's New
description: WILKINSON Sword Tools, manufactured in England, have in troduced a small solid stainless steel digging fork, called the border fork. It has a fourtined head that is eight and threequarter inches long; overall weight is three pounds. The tubular steel shaft is sleeved in tough plastic and strong polypropy lene hand grips provide added comfort. $44.95. (Wilk inson Sword, Inc. 1121 Bristol Road, Mountainside, N. J. 07092.)

title: Assist Costs Trucker $140
description: DOTHAN, Ala., April 11 (AP) A truck driver's efforts to assist two female motorists ap parently stranded cost him about $140 in cash, the sheriff's deputies said this week. W. R. Huff of Forest Park, Ga., told the police that he pulled his trailer truck to the side of the road north of here to assist the young women, whose sports car had apparently stalled. Mr. Huff said that when he lifted the hood of the car, one of the women stuck a gun in his back and demanded his money, took the cash and fled.

title: Chelsea and Leeds In 22 Soccer Tie
description: LONDON, April 11  Leeds United and Chelsea battled to the edge of exhaustion in an epie English Football Associa tion Cup final here today before a crowd of 100,000, but the teams remained deadlocked at 22 after overtime to force a replay. The replay is scheduled at Manchester's Old Trafford Stadium, April 29.

title: Law
description: You still get frisked before you enter John Murtagh's court room; you still see a band of husky guards once you get in side. You still sit on hard wood en benches, breathe stale air, and wonder if the 13 black men and women sitting at the table in front of you did all the things the District Attorney says they did.

title: U.S. RIGHTS PANEL CRITICIZES NIXON ON SCHOOL POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The President's recent policy statement on school desegrega tion is inadequate, overcau tious and may even signal a major retreat, the Commission on Civil Rights declared today.

title: Moscow Reports Launching
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (Reuters) The Moscow radio reported tonight the launching of Apollo 13 just a little more than 10 minutes after blastoff. A brief item carried near the end of the 10 P.M. (Moscow time) half hour news bulletin reported the event without comment.

title: Rain Puts Off 5 Openers In Japanese Pro Baseball
description: TOKYO, April 11 (AP)The 1970 Japanese professional baseball season opened today with only one game played at Fukuoka in southern Japan. The five other scheduled games were rained out.

title: 7 TRADE CHARGES IN NEWARK RACE
description: NEWARK, April 11Charges of racism and ethnic hypoc risy and demands for financial disclosures of campaign costs and net worth dominated the local political scene this week as the Newark mayoral election campaign approached its final month.

title: Hofstra's Lacrosse Team Will Play Army on Saturday
description: The Hofstra Lacrosse team will play host to squads from three service academies on con secutive Saturday nights. Next Saturday, Army will play at Hofstra's Astroturf field at 8 o'clock, and the Air Force will visit April 25 and Navy on May 2.

title: U.S. AND MADRID RESUMING TALKS
description: MADRID, April 11  Foreign Minister Gregorio Lpez Bravo left this morning for Washing ton to take up what is expected to be a critical phase of the long and fitful SpanishAmeri can negotiations on bases.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: ANDRETTI TO PUT NEW CAR TO TEST
description: TRENTON, April 11 (AP) Mario Andretti will drive a car he calls a whole new concept in auto racing in the ninth an nual Trenton 200 at Trenton Speedway April 26, it was an nounced today.

title: For Young Readers
description: These two traditional stories from Africa are outstanding. Both authors or tellersprovide excellent il lustrations for just the right touch of authenticity and excitement.

title: Shoemaker's Old Injury Forces Canceling of Rides
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 11 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker, the world's leading active jockey with 5,918 winners, was forced to take himself off his mounts at Hollywood Park today be cause of the recurrence of an old back injury.

title: I'm Alive, If Not Well
description: TRANSFORMING a nov el of ideas into a tele vision play of action is at best a delicate and difficult operation. And when National Educational Television asked me a year ago to perform it on my own book, They, I was prepared to snip, inject, remove, am putate, drain and transfuse wherever necessary, anesthe tizing myself rather than the patient when the pain began. What  cut that brilliant scene, that moving dialogue, that lovely appendix?

title: British Guiana lc Owner Identified
description: AMONG other happy ex periences that Poss Small recalls from his growing  up years in Rockhampton, Queensland, Australia, was the creation of a stamp collection. It was a lad's collection, but while he was soldiering in World War I his parents gave most of it away to visiting friends items they admired were giv en to them.

title: Party Reelects Strauss
description: MUNICH, April 11 (Reuters)  The former West German Finance Minister, Franz Josef Strauss, was reelected chair man of the Christian Social Union party today. The union is the Bavarian wing of the opposition Christian Democrats.

title: Tangier Relaxes And Cools OffPartly
description: TANGIER, Morocco Back in the 1930's and 40's, when Tangier was an International Zone and a smuggler's haven, it was a pretty rough place and you ran a fair risk of getting your throat slit if you walked around the native quarter alone at night. But now that Tangier is once again part of the Kingdom of Morocco, all the rough stuff has cooled and the city is a respectable place with just enough of the offbeat to keep it inter esting.

title: Q:
description: Questions of literary interest should be addressed: Queries Editor, The New York Times Book Review, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036, and accompanied by a stamped, selfaddressed envelope. The editor will publish those of greatest interest. Others are answered by letter.

title: Larchmont Dinghy Racing Led by MonteSavo, Isdale
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 11Bizzy MonteSano of the home club, sailing Cool Ghoul in the Interclub Class, and George M. (Dooie) Isdale Jr. of American Y.C., Rye N. Y., at the tiller of Woe Begone in the Dyer division, took his leads today in the opening of the Larchmont Yacht Club's spring invitation regatta of frostbite dinghies.

title: The Luxury of Luxembourg
description: LUXEMBOURG  This ministate is a good place in which to make the sudden transition from the United States to Europe. The cur rency is easy to translate into dollars, English is widely un derstood and her capital is small enough for most of it to be seen on foot.

title: Mideast Studies in Philadelphia Expand
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11  Tiny Dropsie University, a com munity of scholars, will an nounce at a 60th anniversary diner Tuesday the creation of a Center for the Study of Communication of Man's Hu manity.

title: Parks Department Opens Its 503 Tennis Courts
description: With the blessings of Mayor Lindsay, whose service is improving, and Commission August Fleckscher, whose game is rated just fair, the Parks Department opened its 503 tennis courts for the outdoor season yesterday.

title: R. I. Fries Weds Sylvia Doughty
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 In the Foundry Methodist Church here this afternoon, Miss Sylvia Doughty was married to Russell Inslee Fries by the Rev. Edward W. Bau man.

title: Two Explosions Rip Office Of Ulster Unionist Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 11 (UPI)Two explosions tore through an office and gar age today belonging to a former Unionist Cabinet Minister who is running for the Northern Ire land Parliament.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reporta obtained from more than 125 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Presbyterian Hospital Aided by Mellon Fund
