description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has given $1mil lion to the Presbyterian Hos pital for the construction phases of its development program, it was announced yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the pro gram, and Charles S. Hamil ton Jr., president of the foundation.

title: Seeing Swaziland & Co.
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Southern Africa is not just South Africa. There are three fascinating backwaters that can be visited quickly and economically from a Johannes burg base: Swaziland, Lesotho and Bots wana. All three are within about an hour's flight from Johannesburg's Jan Smuts International Airport at a cost of under $60 for the round trip.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS ORDERED TO WORK
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Leaders of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organ ization were ordered today to direct their members to go back to work or produce medical certificates of illness.

title: The Caribbean Fantasy
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V.I.I found that if I looked to the southwest and fixed an un focused gaze on the horizon, the effect was calming In the fading light between giant shadows of stacked clouds, the sea had turned a deep silver. Above the skyline, the air had faded to pink, and higher up the first stars were winking into view. Taking care not to look away, I reached for my glass of taxfree gin and began to review our plight.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: TRAVEL

title: Daley of The Times Will Be Toastmaster
description: Arthur Daley, Pulitzer Prize winning sport colum nist for The New York Times, will serve as toastmaster for the 36th annual Block F Din ner at the Hotel StatlerHil ton on May 16.

title: Stamps
description: DESIGNS of the two ad ditional United Na tions stamps valid for use only at its Ge neva, Switzerland, headquar ters, and of a pair of stamps with the theme Fight Can cer, have been released by Robert W. Maxwell, Chief, United Nations Postal Admin istration.

title: 2 CUP CONTESTS IN SOCCER TODAY
description: The New York Ukrainians soccer team will meet Taunton of Massachusetts at Schutzen park in North Bergen, N. J., and Elizabeth, winner of the New JerseyPennsylvania final, will take on Danubia of Cleveland at Farchers Grove in Union, N. J., today in the Eastern semi finals of the United States Chal lenge Cup. Both games will get under way at 2 P.M. The win ners of today's games will meet next Sunday for the Eastern championship.

title: Article 1  No Title
Track Rehearing Put Off
description: EL PASO, Tex., April 11 (UPI) The New Mexico Racing Com mission postponed today a de cision on a motion for rehear ing an application for operation of the Ruidoso, N. M., race track by a firm linked with Emprise Corp. of Buffalo, al legedly tied with the Mafia.

title: Science
description: HOUSTON  Among the as sorted posters, irreverent and sometimes bawdy, for sale along Broadway is an outsized re production of an apocryphal front page of The New York Daily News. It shows an astro naut in his allenveloping space suit standing bravely on the desolate lunar surface. The headline, in giant letters, says: So What.

title: NEW RELIEF HEAD VIEWS ROLE HERE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Jule M. Sugarman, who will take over the administration of New York City's programs for the poor in July, is already be ginning to wonder how the not sopoor manage to exist in the city.

title: Library Design Wins Award
description: THE design above by the Manhattan architect John M. Johansen for the Robert Hutch ings Goddard Library at Clark University, Worcester, Mass., was one of six award winners in the 1970 Library Buildings Award Program sponsored by the American Institute of Architects, the American Library Association and the National Book Committee. The jury was critical of most entries, however, saying that most designs interpreted the library as windowless or nearly so, and artificially lighted factories of learning without any feeling for people. Awards of merit also went to the Henry B. Dupont Li brary, Pomfret School, Pomfret, Conn., designed by Cambridge Seven Associates; the Adlai E. Stevenson College Library, University of Cali fornia at Santa Cruz, designed by Joseph Eshe rick and Associates; the Anna E. Waden branch library, San Francisco, designed by John S. Bolles Associates and the Madden Hills branch library, Dayton, Ohio, designed by Richard Levin Asso ciates. The Bancroft School Library in Andover, Mass., received an honor award. The architect wasa William D. Warner.

title: Lens Concern, 10 Years Later, Praises Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 11Hardly had the ink dried on the presidential title when Robert O. Barber was faced with his first major problemUnivis, Inc., of Day ton, Ohio, a large lens manu facturer, had decided it was in need of a new headquar ters plant.

title: Central Connecticut Blanks C. W. Post Nine in Twin Bill
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., April 11Rick Young and Rick Fu sari limited C. W. Post to only seven hits today in pitching Central Connecticut State to a pair of 40 baseball victories.

title: Job Changes:
description: Fred E. Tucker has been elected vice presidentenvi ronmental control for the National Steel Corporation.

title: Africa Is a Second Home For Italian Oil Company
description: Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, (E.N.I.), the Italian national oil company, continues to make the African Continent a home away from home by going into partnership deals with host countries.

title: Ships Become Scrap on S. I.'s Dark Side
description: Like the moon, Staten Is land has two sides  a bright one, facing east and overlooking New York Har bor, and a dark one, facing west and overlooking Arthur Kill and the industrial waste lands of New Jersey.

title: Chess
description: IN each of the epic battles retrieved from limbo, below, there is remarkable ferocity in the middle game with the foes imaginatively trading cruel blows during the com bative melee. Winner and loser share honors and the issue is not resolved until the final move.

title: Administration Unit Elects
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP)Walter W. Mode of Bos ton has been named president elect of the American Society for Public Administration. He is a regional commissioner for the Social Security Administration. He will assume the presidency of the society in 1971.

title: Chaparrals Sign Hamilton
description: DALLAS, April 11 (AP)The Hamilton, North Texas State guard, signed a oneyear con tract today with the Dallas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association.

title: Missile Company Proposes To Build Stadium for Boston
description: BOSTON, April 11 (UPI)  The Hicks Company, a manufacturer of missile hardware, has offered to build a 55,000seat sports stadium for Boston and foot all the bills. The $25million com plex, to he built in the Hyde Park section, would be avail able for football and baseball, with a separate 25,000seat arena for hockey and basket ball.

title: Tribe Hurlers Fan 10
description: The Yankees gaped when Dean Chance warmed up today by throwing long fly balls into the outfield. But they didn't do much with his more conven tional throws later, nor did they score off two relief pitchers, as they dropped a 30 decision to the Cleveland Indians.

title: Printers and Papers Push Talks; Union Continues Pressure Tactic
description: Negotiators for the typo graphical union and the city's four major daily newspapers concentrated their discussions on economic issues yesterday as they continued negotiations on a new contract in an effort to avert a shutdown of the papers.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Retail figures are suffer ing  but more from the ab normalities of the calendar than from a softening of con sumer demand. A minus el ement has crept into the picture, and this is apparent in retail sales figures for New York as well as the country as a whole.

title: THANT, IN MANILA, HAILS AGRICULTURE,
description: MANILA, April 11U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that for the first time Asia was on the threshhold of an agricultural breakthrough and that, through further regional arrangements, it should be able to ensure the future progress for its people.

title: OHIO PUPPY IS BEST IN COLLIE SPECIALTY
description: WORCHESTER, Mass., April 11Lee Aire's A Real Hap pening, an 8, monthold sable andwhite puppy owned and handled by Billie Gordon of Strongville, Ohio, led the 141 entries today in the Collie Club of America's annual sweep stakes show held at the Wor cester Memorial Auitorium.

title: Television
description: WITH the summer repeats begin ning before the snow is off the ground, the talk shows are about all that is left on the home screen to provide some element of the unexpected. If a viewer is willing to hunt around the dial and cope with odd hours he can usually find some talk show host and his guests busily analyz ing everything imaginable, ranging from important Issues to their private lives and much trivia.

title: Susan Mary Wellacott Wed in Suburbs
description: NEW CANAAN. Conn., April 11Miss Susan Mary Wellacott and Thomas Avery Coyne were married here this afternoon at St. Mark's Epis copal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Ven erable Grant A. Morrill, rec tor.

title: Education
description: In 1958, under the shock of the first Soviet Sputnik, Con gress heeded an appeal from the Eisenhower Administration and passed the National De fense Education Act. The act aimed largely at the improve ment of education in those areas  science, mathematics and foreign languages and re gional studiesto which the politicians attributed much of the Russians' success in space.

title: Miss MacMurray Wed to Lawyer
description: CAMP HILL, Pa., April 11 Miss Marcia Ann Mac Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John MacMurray, was married here this afternoon to Stefano Starace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adriano Sta race of Rome. The ceremony was performed in the Trini ty Lutheran Church here by the Rev. Matthew L. Winter.

title: Architecture
description: No, friends, the pic tures you see on this page are not what you think they are. This is not a repeat of the recent saga of Irving Gill's doomed Dodge House in Los Angeles. It is a far more complex and curious story, and it could have been writ ten by Lewis Carroll or Ed ward Lear. Actually, it was written by tight money and the Vermont State Legisla ture.

title: In Argentina: Superlatives
description: BUENOS AIRES  The visitor is apt to equate this city of sevenmil lion portenos with the size of its steaks. Both are somewhat awesome.

title: Rhodesia Faces Vexing Problems
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 11  The 1970 election in Rho desia, which will probably be remembered as the one in which Prime Minister Ian D. Smith sang a song about baboons to African hecklers, may seem to guarantee the preservation of the status quo.

title: Basement special
description: The basement of a demolished mansion in East Hampton cap hued the imagination of designer Benjamin Baldwin, who pro ceeded to turn the old cellar into a garden. He tore out the concrete floor and, using topsoil, redwood decking and bricks, turned the excavation with its existing partitions into cubicles (at left) of varying sizes at varying levels for sunning, swimming, reading and gardening. To accompany this garden, he de signed a simple woodframed house in collaboration with Earl Pope. They chose woodframed glass doors and windows, be cause they were in keeping with a wood house. Neutral colors, simple shapes, slate floors and vertical blinds keep the look of the interior in harmony with the look of the exterior.

title: Stock Transaction Cost RisesFew Traders Care
description: The cost of buying and selling stocks went up $15 transaction last week, and the investing public respond ed with what appeared to be monumental indifference.

title: BUSINESS RENT TAX URGED BY LINDSAY
description: Another tax increasere structuring the tax on commer cial rents to increase city reve nue by $40millionwas sug gested yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: THIRD SWIM CROWN CAPTURED BY HALL
description: CINCINNATI, April 11Gary Hall, an Indiana University freshman, became the first triple winner in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swim ming championships tonight by winning the 200yard butterfly event.

title: Detroit Family Profits by Its Plays
description: Meet a conglomerate fam ilythe closely knit Neder landers of Detroit.

title: ALUMNI OF C.C.N.Y. PRESS FOR CHANGE
description: One year after student dis ruptions and violence disrupted City College, a committee of prominent alumni has concluded that a process for institutional change has to be built into the college's administration sys tem.

title: Bruins' Bad Man Gunned Down Early
description: When Derek Sanderson of the Boston Bruins skated onto the ice last night, he looked up into the stands and saw a number of signs hanging from the highest balcony.

title: A.B.A. AND N.B.A. NEARING MERGER
description: The American Basketball As sociation has agreed to pay $11million in indemnities, move its Washington franchise and return Rick Barry to the San Francisco Warriors as part of a deal to merge with the Na tional Basketball Association.

title: Susan Gibby Bride Of Peter G. Gillim
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., April 11  Miss Susan Savin Gibby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Budd Gibby of Hill side, and Pocono Lake Pre serve, Pa., and Peter Gates Gillim of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gates Gillim of Tarrytown, N.Y., were married here this aft ernoon at the Westminster Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Robert W. Scott.

title: M'GOHEY RETIRES; 20 YEARS A JUDGE
description: Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey announced his re tirement last week after 20 years on the bench in the United States Court House on Foley Square.

title: Nixon Consulted Conservatives on Senate Attack
description: The only men he took with him on the Presidential yacht Sequoia on Wednesday night, after the vote, were John N. Mitchell, the Attorney General who was his campaign manager in 1968 and H. R. Haldeman, his chief of staff who was cam paign manager in the unsuccess ful Nixon gubernatorial effort in California in 1962.

title: RALPH A. OSTBERG
description: SHARON, Conn., April 11 Ralph A. Ostberg, a former vice president of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation in New York, died at his home here yesterday of congestive heart failure.

title: Boy Scouts' Project in 1971 To Center on Conservation
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Boy Scouts of America will begin Project SOARSave Our American Resourcesin 1971 as a major conservation service to help fight environ mental pollution.

title: A PRIVATE ISLAND SOUGHT BY HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, April 7Polit ical leaders here are trying to force the sale of a privately owned island to the state, even though the owners want to maintain it as a sanctuary of Hawaiian life in the 19th century.

title: Dr. Charles C. Wilson, 74, Yale Education Professor
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11Dr. Charles C. Wilson, a professor emeritus of education and pub lic health at Yale University, died at YaleNew Haven Hos pital Thursday. He was 74 years old.

title: Miss Emerson Fiancee of Banker
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., April 11Mr. and Mrs. George D. Emerson have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Andrea Emerson of New York, to John L. Put nam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Putnam of Forest Hills, Queens, and East Hampton, L. I. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Why I.T.&T. Got Into the Travel Business
description: ACOUPLE of weeks back, thee Division Division of Busi ness Management of New York University sponsored an executive man agement program in travel and tourism, for which the university persuaded 50 New York businesses to put up $225 each to send one execu tive each to a threeday program.

title: Iona Downs Hofstra, 32, On Schweizer's Hit in 6th
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 11  Joe Mazzella scat tered six hits and struck out six batters today as Iona posted a 32 victory over Hofstra in a Metropolitan Conference game at Haag Field.

title: Substitute Swigert, 38, Has Girl in Every (Air) Port
description: JACK SWIGERT, the come lately crewman aboard Apollo 13, is a man who car ries several reputations with him wherever he goes swinger, student, sportsman and systematizer.

title: Jefferson Enjoys Sweet Revenge
description: JEFFERSON, Tex.  This oncerol licking Texas steamboat town, whose demise as a major port was hastened by the advance of the railroad, is enjoying a sweet re venge today. In its comeback as a ris ing tourist center, it offers as one of its sightseeing lures the ornate private railroad car of Jay Gould, the financier who once predicted the end of Jeffer son, Texas.

title: Johns Hopkins Wins, 1110, In Lacrosse at Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, April 11Johns Hopkins University defeated the Mount Washington Lacrosse Club. 1110, today.

title: Harry S. Gutshall Weds Lee Boyd
description: MENDHAM, N. J., April 11 Miss Lee Allan Boyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Boyd of Green Village, was married here this afternoon to Harry Seeley Gutshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph William Gutshall of Chatham. The Rev. Karl G. Kumm, an Episcopal minister, per formed the ceremony at the Roxiticus Golf Club.

title: Famechon Beats Taylor In Nontitle 10Rounder
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 11 (UPI) Johnny Famechon of Aus tralia, the world feather weight champion, won a unanimous decision tonight over Arnold Taylor of South Africa in a 10round non title bout. Famechon weighed 127 pounds to Taylor's 125.

title: Montgomery Paper Sued By Alabama State Senator
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 11 (UPI)State Senator W. G. McCarley of Prattville filed a $750,000 damage suit against the Montgomery Advertiser yes terday.

title: Hydrologist, $17.40, Captures Excelsior by Nose at Aqueduct
description: Hydrologist of the Meadow Stable was first across the line in the $57,800 Excelsior Handi cap yesterday at Aqueduct. The 1mile event attracted a field of nine older horses and was witnessed by a crowd of 50,099 fans.

title: Anniversaries
description: BUBESTER, Max and Ann A. loving and grateful family rejoices on your 63th Wed ding Anniversary, April 12, 1970.

title: Verdun: Oh, What a Lovely Battlefield
description: VERDUN, FranceWe had come to Verdun quite by accident; it was the most convenient place to stop for the night on the drive from Heidelberg to Paris. The border crossing had been uneventful, except that, as soon as we entered France, the German auto bahn became a pitted twolane road. It struck us that this was the route that in vading German armies had taken in three wars over the last 100 years. Perhaps the French had not improved the road on purpose.

title: The House on Bitterness Street
description: This episodic novel describes the adventures of Maria Isa bel Brook during one of the great social upheavals of the present century, the Mexican Revolution of 1910. Marisa, as she is called, has plenty of ad ventures and almost all of them are unrelievedly grim.

title: American Eagle Sets Sail in Race to Mexico
description: Ted Turner's American Eagle, the winner of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference is taking on about 20 other yachts in the second annual Regata del Sol al Sol (race from the sun to the sun) that departed from St. Petersburg, Fla., yes terday and will finish at the Mexican resort island of Isla Mujeres off the Yucatan Penin sula.

title: POPULATION HUGE IN EAST PAKISTAN
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 1East Pakistan is a special crisis on a crisis subcontinent. It's got 72 million people jam med into a space just a little hit larger than Arkansas, which has only two million. That's twice the density of Japan and Holland.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BRONX

title: Rhode Island K. C. Show Today Attracts Field of 1,036 Dogs
description: IN 1889, the Rhode Island A Kennel Club, which had been organized three years before, chartered a steamboat to transport exhibitors, dogs and spectators to Newport for the club's first allbreed event. Three more shows were held at Freebody Park. Today, the hardy old organi nation has an en try of 1,036 dogs for its show at Rhodes Ballroom, Rhodes  on  the Pawtuxet, Cranston. Floyd Webster, who has been an enthusiast for three decades, heads the club. He's a Kerry blue fancier. Dalmatians and basenjis are in great favor with Rhode Island's top echelon. Robert Gustafson, the delegate to the American Kennel Club, and Mrs. Regina Soloway and Mrs. Charlotte Soloway, members of the board, are ardent coach dog en thusiasts. Raymond Masse, the club's vice president; Eleu terio Fonseca, its treasurer, and Mrs. Shirley Crossley, the secretary, are breeders of the barkless dog. Mabel Wall, the show chairman, favors Boston terriers. Mrs. Marjorie Brandt, a hoard member, has done much winning with her bas sets.

title: April Green
description: It doesn't take much warmth to inspire the first green along the country road and in the margin be tween the rural vegetable garden plot and the side lawn. As soon as the frost has got out of the topsoil, celandine is green at the roadside, doubly green because it has so little competition. A member of the poppy family, it will achieve small yellow flowers in May, but now it is simply green, foliage that doesn't need any blossom to find a welcome.

title: A. Susan Hill Married To John S. McLaughlin
description: St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church here was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Miss A. Susan Hill and John Shirley Mc Laughlin. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Harold S. Engel. He was assisted by Msgr. Philip J. Murphy, exec utive head of the Catholic Youth Organization.

title: The Future of the Court
description: The Supreme Court at once symbolizes and imple ments America's capacity to balance stability with progress, tradition with selfrenewal. Through the nearly 200 years of the American experiment, it has kept a written Constitution from becoming a dead document.

title: VIRGINIA ADOPTS ABORTION REFORM
description: RICHMOND, April 11 Ef fective June 26, Virginia will hay e a new and Liberalized abortion law, approved by this year's session of the state's Legislature and signed this week by Gov. Lynwood Holton.

title: Letters
description: IT HAPPENED AT BERKELEY

title: Movies
description: THEY say you're supposed to work out all your neuroses in your first marriage, so that you'll be marvelous in your second marriage, she says, smiling sweetly across the dining room table at her husband.

title: AQUEDUCT FLIES CASH TO YONKERS
description: YONKERS, April 11Yonkers Raceway, where the nightly handle averages $2million, un expectedly ran out of money today and the management at the Westchester County harness racing plant was confronted with the problem of finding enough to be used for operat ing purposes tonight.

title: Mrs. King Turns Back Mrs. Court in Net Final
description: Durban, South Africa, April 11 (Reuters)Mrs. Biliie Jean King heat Mrs. Margaret Court, the Australian cham pion, to win the women's singles title today in the Natal open tennis tourna ment.

title: Like Father, Like Son Holds True on the Road
description: A study of driving records of undergraduates at a large state university has found some vali dity in the old adage Like father, like son.

title: Business of Psychology Picks Up
description: If briefing sessionstwo day briefing sessions at thatare some kind of a measure of the current state of an art, it just may he that behavioral science is blos soming on the United States business scene.

title: Calculator Depends on Class to Beat the Races Some of the Time, Anyway
description: It has been a big week for indigent horseplayers in search of a system.

title: Low Prices Stir French Winegrowers
description: VENDRES, France, April 3 We had some demonstrations a month ago, the Mayor said, but they were quite peaceful. Oh, a few telephone poles.... I'm scared blue, though, that we'll come to the catastrophe of 1907.

title: Rumania Cuts The Red Tape
description: BUCHAREST, RumaniaCatering to hardcurrency tourists has been a serious business in Rumania for several seasons now, and the authorities have long dropped most unnecessary red tape and policestate attitudes toward the capitalist tourist. Americans were welcome guests even before President Nixon's visit to Bucharest last year.

title: Deductions Await Alert Taxpayers
description: If you've put off your in come tax ordeal until now just three days before the deadlinedon't feel too bad about it. You're hardly alone.

title: BENEFITS
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Joys and Sorrows
description: Pablo Casals is a saint, of course, and is now partly lost to us, hidden behind a haze of incense. Many years ago our leading cultural hagiograph ers recorded the canonization, and it is only through a tour de force of irreverence that one can think of the 93yearold cellist as a person. And yet, Casals is a man and resists quite stoutly, for a saint, the burial that sainthood entails.

title: Brandeis Gets $1.9Million
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 11 (AP)  The National Science Foundation has awarded a $1.9 million grant to Brandeis Uni versity's physics and chemistry departments, the college an nounced Tuesday.

title: Back to the rolling pin
description: There are drop cookies, pressed cookies, bar cookies and, with a little extra effort, rolled cookies. We give recipes for three kinds of rolled cookies on this page. The waferthin, gingerspicy Moravian cookies will keep for weeks in a tin with a tight cover. The currant cookies and the dateandnut whirls are the hearty afterschoolwithaglassofmilk variety that will please father and children alike.

title: Prober of a Town's Soul
description: To seriousminded critics  few of whom John O'Hara would have counted among his friendsthe verdict was in long ago: He would never fulfill the high promise of his first novel, Appointment in Samarra. What had seemed at first to be a penetrating eye and an un canny way with fictional dia logue that would carry him to any fictional heights he chose to scale, gradually turned out to be a habit, an easy trick that no one could quite imitate, but which O'Hara himself did not choose to de velop profoundly.

title: They're Off 'n Crawling In the Bayou Country
description: BREAUX BRIDGE, La.The second preliminary race neared its climax. All around us, the soft patois of the onlookers, an earthy blend of French and English, grew more excited. Look at that, would you, people? They're neck 'n neck. The darkhaired little man with the microphone gestured excitedly to the crowd. It's Number 17, Robespierre, and Number 14, ChouChou, leading the field. Man, this is one grand race, I gar ontee!

title: Wood, World Champion, Will Skate in Benefit
description: The world figure skating champion, Tim Wood, wilt star in the FunoramaonIce Show Saturday and next Sun day at the South Mountain Arena, West Orange, N. J.

title: ASTRONAUTS OFF ON 3D MOON TRIP; LAND WEDNESDAY
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 11Three American astro nauts, including a latehour substitute, were launched to day on man's third lunar land ing mission.

title: Government Work to End May 9 for U.S. Taxpayers
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) The average American tax payer will stop working for the government and start working for himself May 9.

title: Groppi to Leave Slum Parish; Hopes to Remain With Blacks
description: MILWAUKEE, April 11The Rev. James E. Groppi is being reassigned from the slum parish that has been the center of his civil rights activities for the last seven years.

title: Raise, as a Youngster, Cared Little for Flying
description: WHEN Fred Haise was a V boy growing up in Biloxi, Miss., he built model air planes as a hobby. But that was as far as his interest in aviation went.

title: NATO COMMITMENT CLARIFIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. April 11  The White House said today that the Nixon Administration had no present plans to with draw any troops from Western Europe even after the expira tion of its standing comit ment to maintain the current level of forces through June 30, 1971.

title: TOLEDO CLERICS EASING TENSIONS
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 11A halfdozen white and Negro clergy leaders played a medi ating role this week in opening communication lines between the city administration and a newly formed chapter of the Black Panthers.

title: The Harding Era
description: The Harding Era is another of the growing number of books that have resulted from the recent opening of the im portant collection of Harding papers at the Ohio Historical Society. Andrew Sinclair's The Available Man (1965) was a brief, interpretive overview of Harding's life, lucid and witty, but given to sweeping generali zations unsupported by much detail. Francis Russell's The Shadow of Blooming Grove (1968) supplied a mass of de tail, but put too much stress on the lurid and banal side of the man.

title: Marriages
description: HOROWITZOSINOFFMr. and Mrs. Gerald K. Osinoft of Lido Beach, N.Y., happily announce the marriage of their daughter Wendy Lynn io Mr. Irving Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Horowitz of West Orange, N.J. The marriage will take place today, Sunday, April 12, 1970 at the Se phardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: FLORIDA TRACKS FACE COURT TEST
description: MIAMI, April 11 (AP)  A suit calling for revocation of corporate charters held by Hia leah and Tropical Park race tracks was filed yesterday soon after Hialeah's owner, Eugene Mori, surrendered to face charges of making illegal po litical contributions.

title: Advertising: Public Route for Interpublic
description: If you needed any proof that the Interpublic Group of Companies is back on its feet, here it is. The giant communications company an nounced it was preparing to take the first step toward going public.

title: Mayor League Baseball
description: Monday, April 13, 1970

title: Flaws in Abortion Reform Found in an 8State Study
description: Serious shortcomings are be coming apparent in many of the liberalized state abortion laws, despite a clear nation wide trend toward abortion re form.

title: Transit Unit Will Hold Auction of Lost Items
description: If you wear a size 8 shoe and want to dance the way Shirley Temple once did, there's a pair of shiny black tap shoes waiting for you at the Transit Authority's public auction tomorrow.

title: Death Toll Now 9 in Crash Of Jet at Base in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 12 (AP)The death toll in Fri day's accident at Udony Air Base involving a crippled RF4 jet that plunged into a bar racks and a radio station has reached nine, a United States Embassy spokesman announced today.

title: Crocheting for Fun Is Turned to Profit
description: WITH so many women crocheting this spring, it was inevitable that some would decide to profit by it. Mrs. Lawrence Yaeger and Mrs. Howard Herbert, 30yearold housewives from Jamaica.

title: PENGUINS DEFEAT SEALS FOR SWEEP
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 12 (UPI)  Michel Briere rammed in a rebound after eight minutes in suddendeath overtime to night to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 32 victory over the Oakland Seals and a sweep of their Stanley Cup playoff series in the National Hockey League's West Division.

title: ELLEN KLEIN MIXES DANCE AND THEATER
description: Mondo Freako is a dance theater event that resulted Saturday evening from a spacedout sensibility col liding with country and West ern music at the Gate Theater.

title: WINGS LOSE, 4 TO 2, 4TH TIME IN ROW
description: DETROIT, April 12 (AP) The Chicago Black Hawks elim inated the Detroit Red Wings from the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs today with their fourth straight 42 victory over the Wings for a fourgame sweep.

title: U.N. Unit Adjourns in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 12 (Reuters)  A United Nations special committee investigating Israel's treatment of Arabs in occupied territories ended its meetings here tonight. The threeman committee which heard about 30 witnesses here, will leave tomorrow for Am man, Jordan.

title: Personal Finance
description: Now that spring is here, only an ogre or a taxman would solemnly ponder taxes and weddings, except possibly an expenseweary parent.

title: Walsh Urges Dual Rating
description: NASHVILLE, April 12Law rence E. Walsh, the chairman of the Federal Judiciary Com mittee of the American Bar Association, has suggested that the committee explore the possibility of using two stand ards when it evaluates nomi nees to the Supreme Court.

title: Highlights of Flight Plan of Apollo 13 Moon Voyage
description: Following are highlights of the Apollo 13 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern Standard.

title: Pacers Set Scoring Mark. Trounce Pipers by 177135
description: INDIANAPOLIS. April 11 (AP)The Indiana Pacers put on an awesome scoring show and blasted the Pittsburgh Pipers, 177135, today to set an American Basketball As sociation scoring record.

title: Major Bills in Congress
BAYLOR AND WEST STAR FOR VICTORS
description: ATLANTA, April 12 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers, after trailing most of the game, ral lied in the closing two minutes for a 119115 victory over the Atlanta Hawks today in the opening game of their playoff series for the Western Division championship of the National Basketball Association.

title: Hemisphere's First Albanian Catholic Church Opens in the Bronx
description: The only Albanian Roman Catholic Church in the Western Hemisphere opened yesterday in a rundown section of the Bronx.

title: Maddox Threatens to Seize City After Crime Fighter Is Fired On
description: ATLANTA, April 12 (UPI) Gov. Lester G. Maddox moved more state troopers into Lu dowici today and threatened to declare martial law in the south Georgia city after night riders had fired into the home of a crimefighting minister.

title: Surprising Indecision
description: Much has happened since the United States con tracted to sell eight F5 jet fighter planes to the friend ly and moderate government of King Idris in Libya a year ago. The King has been deposed by military officers who have cancelled American base rights in that country, allied themselves closely with the United Arab Republic and made Libya one of the most vocif erous champions of military confrontation with Israel.

title: Waterfront Thefts and Pilferage Foster Inflation
description: Inflation is being aggravated by theft and pilferage on the nation's docks.

title: U.S. ASKS EUROPE TO ASSIST DOLLAR
description: BASEL, Switzerland, April 12The United States is inten sifying its monetary diploma cy, trying to enlist further Eu ropean cooperation to keep the dollar out of trouble this year.

title: U.S. to Seek Review
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A Justice Department spokesman said tonight that the depart ment would file a petition with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit tomorrow asking the court to order civil rights officials from the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare to review the Manatee County integration plan.

title: NETS WIN, 113111, FROM FLORIDIANS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 12The New York Nets stormed from behind in the sec ond half to turn back the Miami Floridians, 113111, in an American Basketball Asso ciation game at Island Garden today. The Nets finished their seasons' work with the Florid ians leading 8 games to 3.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Funds for Education

title: Some Riders Find 747 Is Great But Others Vow, Never Again
description: After nearly three months in service, the Boeing 747 jumbo jet seems to be estab lishing some jumbosized im perssions, both good and bad, among air travelers.

title: This Singer Likes Acting Two Roles
description: SOMETIMES she says, This is Mildred Miller day. Then v again she might say, This is to be a Poszvar day. It all depends upon whether Mildred Miller, a slender (size 12) greeneyed mezzosoprano is attending to her career as an opera singer and recitalist or to activities involved with the University of Pitts burgh. For the last three years her husband, Dr. Wes ley Wentz Poszvar, has been chancellor of the university.

title: 28 Firemen Hurt In 7Hour Blaze On Union Square
description: Twentyeight firemen were injured in a fire that raged for seven hours yesterday and badly damaged two Union Square buildings. In one build ing, heat and water damaged the files of a law firm repre senting Black Panthers and other militant groups.

title: 25th Anniversary of Buchenwald Liberation Marked by 100 Survivors Here
description: It was 25 years ago to the day and I remember I seized the loudspeaker and began shouting: You are free.

title: General Turns Colombian Presidential Campaign Into a Class Struggle With Undertones of Violence
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 12 Colombia today ended a pres idential campaign that had be come a class struggle without benefit of Karl Marx.

title: R & R in Honolulu a SixDay Moment of Peace for Soldiers and Their Wives
description: HONOLULU, April 8They drift along on Kalakaua Ave nue in Waikiki on Saturday night, wandering with the crowd and watching the hours slip through their fingers.

title: British Budget Day Approaches
description: LONDON, April 12 The British budget is no longer one of the great events of western civilization, an American economist said recently. But it's still interesting, and it has its own mystique.

title: Miss Rybicki Will Be Bride
description: CAZENOVIA, N.Y., April 12 Miss Kathleen Ann Rybicki and James Byrne Robinson, who served with the Peace Corps in Africa, plan to be married here May 30.

title: JOE HEVING, 65, GIANTS' PITCHER
description: COVINGTON, Ky., April 12 (AP)Joe Heving, who pitched for four major league teams during his 16 seasons in base ball, died yesterday at St. Eliza beth Hospital here. He was 65 years old. He leaves his wife, Mary; two daughters and a son.

title: SPACE ANNIVERSARY OBSERVED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) Today was National Astronauts Day in the Soviet Union, but Russians found little to cele brate as Apollo 13 headed to ward the moon.

title: 500 SALUTE YESHIVA, WHILE 150 PROTEST
description: While 500 people celebrated the 85th anniversary of the founding of Yeshiva University in the school's main center on the Washington Heights campus yesterday, 150 Yeshiva students picketed outside to protest the alleged secularization of the institution.

title: Goodell Reiterates War Stand and Vows to Speak Own Mind in Campaign
description: Senator Charles H. Goodell, taking pointed issue with Presi dent Nixon and Governor Rockefeller, his running mate in this year's state election, says he will not be bound by any Republican consensus in the campaign.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, APRIL 13, 1970

title: 42 States Ease Laws on Transplants
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Within a period of only two years, 42 of the 50 states have passed new laws reducing sharply the legal barriers to donation and transplantation of human organs.

title: GARY PLAYERS BID FAILS AT 18TH HOLE
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12A pair of golfing pals, Billy Casper and Gene Littler, will play off for the Masters title tomorrow. The Californians, who learned the game as jun iors in the San Diego area, finished with 72hole totals of 279.

title: F.D.R. Era Is Remembered At Memorial on the Hudson
description: HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 12Twentyfive years after the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt the demand for research material from schol ars across the world is greater than ever at the li brary established at his home high on the Hudson River bluffs here.

title: KNICKS AND BUCKS RESUME TONIGHT
description: Buoyed by two consecutive top  notch performances in games that called for nothing less, the New York Knicks will attempt to sustain their mo mentum and maintain the homecourt advantage as they face the Milwaukee Bucks to night at Madison Square Garden.

title: TV: N.Y.U. School of Arts Turns to Lewis Carroll
description: ADVENTURES in television are not exactly numerous. Late yesterday afternoon there was offered something of a small feast in the off beat, not all readily compre hensible and subject as usual to the demand that the view er divine what the producer had in mind.

title: Lois M. George, Paul Kaufman, Physician, Wed
description: ARLINGTON, Va., April 12 Miss Lois Margaret George was married here this after noon to Dr. Paul Leon Kauf man, a staff associate at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md. The ceremony was performed at the home of a friend, Dr. David P. Byar, by Judge Francis E. Thomas Jr.

title: MRS. SAPERSTEIN, 63, A BAND SAXOPHONIST
description: Mrs. Miriam Stiglitz Saper stein, who toured the United States and Europe as a saxo phonist in allgirl bands, in cluding Ina Ray Hutton's dur ing the nineteenthirties and forties, died of cancer Friday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 63 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: Australian Collision Kills 15
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, April 12 (AP)A train and a bus crammed with picknickers col lided today at a crossing 30 miles northwest of here. Fif teen persons were reported killed and 30 were reported in jured.

title: A Nice Mean Streak
description: IN a moment of apparent weakness last fall, Derek Michael Sanderson told a re porter, I don't think I'm really a bad guy on the ice at all.

title: Met Stars Help Richard Tucker Mark 25 Years
Fordham Sailors Win
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 12 Fordham won the Army invi tation sailing regatta today on Othe Hudson River. The Ranis Iscored 94 points in the 11race twoday event. Union was sec ond with 81 points.

title: EXPOS' STONEMAN TAMES CUBS, 20
CITY ACTS TO LURE BUSINESS TO SLUMS
description: Mayor Lindsay has directed city agencies that need more of fice or storage space to lease it, whenever possible, in a de pressed area to encourage the neighborhood's economic de velopment.

title: Family of Six, Like Many, Digs Deeper to Handle College Costs
description: TULSA, Okla., April 7In the Depression days of the nineteen thirties, Joseph Petta worked his way through college by teaching arts and crafts after school to earn his $400 tuition.

title: REPORT ON SST SAID TO BE KEPT SECRET
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wiscon sin, accused the White House today of suppressing an Admin istrationrequested report that concludes that the supersonic transport, in Mr. Reuss's words, is economically wasteful and environmentally harmful.

title: Goldberg's Untested Ability as a Campaigner Called Key to His Success in Primary and General Elections
description: What kind of a candidate do you think Goldberg will be?

title: A.B.A. Owner Denies A Merger Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Earl Foreman, owner of the Washington Capitols of the American Basketball Associa tion, said tonight that the an nouncement yesterday of merger agreement between the committees of his league and the National Basketball Association was premature.

title: Icelandic to Fly Jets, Still at Bargain Fares
description: Icelandic Airlines is sur rendering its role as last of the allprop transAtlantic airlines, but without aban doning its claim to distinc tion as the bargain basement of the North Atlantic.

title: BAR OFFERS PLAN TO AID CONSUMER
description: WASHINGTON, April 12An American Bar Association com mittee has devised what it calls an efficient and expeditious alternative to consumer class action law suits against manu facturers and merchants for fraudulent, deceptive or unfair trade practices.

title: Israelis Decline Rare Papyri; Call $1Million Price Too Costly
description: JERUSALEM, April 12  The Israeli Cabinet decided today that a rare collection of Egyp tian papyrus documents offered for sale in Jerusalem was au thentic, generally in excellent condition but too highly priced.

title: SIEGE IS REPORTED ON 2D U.S. OUTPOST IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12  North Vietnamese troops were reported to have opened a heavy attack today on a second United States Special Forces camp.

title: Will Apollo 13 Upstage Moscow's Lenin Centennial?
description: Soviet sources have begun dropping annoyed hints that they consider the Apollo 13 flight as primarily an act of political and psychological war fare against the Soviet Union. These cold war goals, they maintain, explain Washington's decision to go ahead with the flight on schedule, despite the lasthour switch of command pilots.

title: Bridge:
description: A TEAM led by Stephen Dunko of New York won a decisive victory in the finals of the Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout champion ship played here Saturday. This event, which has been in progress for six months, is limited to players with less than 100 Master points and is therefore dominated by those with limited ex perience but much enthu siasm.

title: Phone Tax Protest Planned
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 12 (UPI)A group of housewives announced today a mass non payment of telephone taxes. Mrs. Susan Webster, one of the organizers, said the 10 per cent Federal excise tax on interstate telephone calls supports the Vitnam war. She said the wom en would pay their bills without the tax and give the rest to a local educational institution.

title: Alcan Expands in Australia
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., an nounced over the weekend that it had signed an agreement to double the capacity of its smelter in Australia to supply a 10year sales contract with Kobe Steel, Ltd., in Japan. The contract calls for Alcan to supply 50,000 tons of primary aluminum ingot per year for 110 years.

title: Project Read Engages Small Children
description: WHAT rhymes with bat? Wiiihe kindergarten teach er asked.

title: Vienna to Quietly Commemorate Russian Ouster of Nazis in 1945
description: VIENNA, April 12Twenty five years ago this week Soviet troops drove out the Nazi de fenders of Vienna, and this city is ready to observe the anni versary with as little fanfare as is possible without irritating Moscow.

title: ExHead of Bronx Zoo Named Aquarium Chief
description: Dr. James A. Oliver, a for mer director of the Bronx Zoo and of the American Mu seum of Natural History, has been appointed director of the New York Aquarium, to succeed Dr. Ross F. Ni grelli on June 1.

title: Brandt Is Back in Bonn; Pleased With U.S. Talks
description: BONN, April 12 AP)Chan cellor Willy Brandt returned from Washington today pleased with President Nixon's endorse ment of Bonn's eastern policy and American agreement that the Atlatic Alliance mut remain strong.

title: OTTO PROUNIS DIES; A RESTAURATEUR, 76
description: Otto D. Prounis, who had been coowner of the former Versailles Restaurant, a night club, died Friday of a heart attack in Syosset (L.I.) Hospi tal. He was 76 years old and lived at 126 Southwood Circle, Syosset.

title: Child to Mrs. O'Donnell
description: A daughter was born March 18 to Mr. and Mrs. James E. O'Donnell Jr. of New York at the New York Hospital. Mrs. O'Donnell is the former Miss M. Sieglinda GarfieldSnyder of Albany and Boston.

title: Cornell Sets Up Volunteer Fire Patrol
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 12 The administration of Cornell University organized a fire Watch today, asking students and faculty members to volun teer for patrols guarding the campus against arson attacks.

title: Berliners Shocked by Leftist Project to Emancipate Schoolchildren Sexually
description: BERLIN, April 12  It was disclosed last week that West Berlin schoolchildren ranging in age from 8 to 14 were en couraged by scientists of the city's Free University to un dress and enact scenes of sex ual intercourse.

title: STATE U. AIDES ASK STRICTER POLICIES
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., April 12More than 200 conserva tive faculty members from the State University centers at Buffalo, Binghamton and New Paltz have formed a committee to press for tougher adminis trative policies in dealing with campus militants.

title: Institution's WellWishers Are Led by Mrs. Nixon
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon made a flying visit to New York last night to help the Metropolitan Museum of Art celebrate its 100th birthday.

title: Beach Items to Bear Marlboro's Message
description: The prospect of losing air time to broadcast messages for Marlboro cigarettes has caused the crowd at Philip Morris, U. S. A. to devise an ingenious scheme: Make the public pay to advertise the brand. Impossible, you say. Harken.

title: A CHANGE OF PACE IN GARDEN HOCKEY
description: There weren't any Lions at Madison Square Coliseum last night, but there were 12 tigers and it was almost time for their feeding.

title: Mets Topple Cards, 64, as Seaver Bats In 3 Runs and Gains First Victory
EXF.A.A. Aide Elected By Flight Safety Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 The Flight Safety Foundation has elected David D. Thomas, who retired in February as deputy administrator of the Federal Aviation Administra tion, to be its president. He succeeds Murray Sargent Jr., who will continue as secre tary and counsel of the non profit organization.

title: O'Hara Rites to Be Held On Thursday at Princeton
description: The funeral of John O'Hara will be held at noon Thursday at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N. J. Dr. Ernest Gordon, the chaplain of the university, will conduct the service.

title: WALKOUT AT POST IS SET TOMORROW
description: Negotiators for the News paper Guild broke off negotia tions with The New York Post last night and called a strike for 6 A. M. tomorrow.

title: The Votes of the Week in Congress
description: Compiled by Congressional Quarterly

title: PIRATES TOP PHILS IN TENTH, 3 TO 1
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (UPI)Bill Mazeroski, who singled home a run in the eight, hit a tworun homer n the 10th inning today, to give the Pitts burgh Pirates a 31 victory over the Philadelphia piffles.

title: JOURNALIST SAYS HE WAS TORTURED
description: PARIS, April 12  A Greek horn French journalist, who was sentenced today in Athens to 18 years in a sedition trial, has smuggled a letter out re counting a series of tortures after which, he said, I admit ted everything they asked.

title: Rebel, American Yacht, Paces Tasman SingleHanded Race
description: NEW PLYMOUTH, New Zea land, April 12 (Reuters)Rebel, a 35foot American trimaran, forged ahead of four other yachts today in the Trans Tasman singlehanded race to Port Cartwright in Queensland.

title: Quakes Injure 18 on Luzon
description: MANILA, April 12 (UPI)  Four earthquakes shook the main Philippine Island of Luzon today, rocking tall buildings in Manila. At least 18 persons were reported injured, but dam age appeared to be light.

title: City Opera Presents Bright Ismailova
description: Shostakovich's Katherina Is mailova was given one of the New York City Opera's beauti fully puttogether performances last night at the New York Theater. It was last performed by the company in 1966.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: AUDIENCE PROTESTS HOLLANDER'S SONGS
description: Lou Hollander, a folk singer whose specialty is antiprotest songs, was subjected to some personal protest last night at the Rosebud Coffeehouse of the Universalist Church, 4 West 76th Street.

title: BROOKLYN BISHOP IS HOST TO JEWS
description: The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, was the host yesterday at an interfaith reception for nearly 1,000 members of the Jewish community of Kings and Queens Counties.

title: CITY URGES TAX PLAN TO AID CONSTRUCTION
description: A substantial tax incentive plan to encourage the private construction of new apartment buildings here was described yesterday by Albert A. Walsh, the city's Housing and Develop ment administrator.

title: Employment Here Down 24,000 in February
description: A decline of 24,000 jobs in February compared with Jan uary in the New YorkNorth eastern New Jersey area  running counter to the typical February rise in employment was reported yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Sta tistics.

title: Long Branch Police Chief Quits After State Hearings
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., April 12Chief of Police Joseph Purcell of Long Branch, named in a recent State Investigation Commission hearings as being on friendly terms with sus pected criminals, resigned last night.

title: Turner's American Eagle Leader in 500Mile Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 12 (AP)American Eagle, Ted Turner's 12meter sloop out of Atlanta, apparently was lead ing the 14boat fleet sailing to ward the Isla de Mujeres in the 500mile St. Petersburg to Mex ico yacht race late today.

title: Holdup in St. Patrick's
description: A gunman robbed the book store in St. Patrick's Cathedral of about $10 yesterday after noon, the police said. Hector Davila, a clerk in the bookstore at the rear of the cathedral told the police that a man entered the store at 4:20 P.M. and, pointing a small handgun, de manded the day's receipts. The robber said he was hungry and needed the money to buy food.

title: DODGERS WIN, 60, AFTER 5 DEFEATS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (UPI) Wes Parker singled in two men to lead a fourrun first inning that started the Los An geles Dodgers off to a 60 vic tory over the San Diego Pad res today. The triumph snapped a fivegame losing streak.

title: Trudeau Beset by Old Problems
description: OTTAWA, April 12  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has reached the midpoint of his term of office still shaping a Just Society that he has not yet unveiled to public view.

title: Hunter Waives Classes 2 Days, Urges Students to Debate Issues
description: Hunter College has suspended classes for today and tomorrow, but is urging students and fac ulty members to attend dis cussions on how to end the disturbances that have plagued the school for the last three weeks.

title: Venezuelan Refinery Will Desulphurize Oil
description: JUDIBANA, VenezuelaThose who breathe the New York air may do so a bit easier next winter because of a $120million petroleum desulphurization project nearing completion at the Amuay oil refinery of the Creole Petro leum Corporation.

title: Article 3  No Title
YUKON IS SEEKING MORE SELFRULE
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Terri tory, April 2The Yukon, the thinly populated, mineralrich and still largely unbroken terri tory a third larger than Califor nia, is engaged in a struggle with the national administra tion in Ottawa over territorial selfgovernment.

title: Cox Leads American Symphony With Stephen Bishop as Soloist
description: Under its founder, Leopold Stokowski, the American Sym phony can often sound like one of the country's topranking or chestras, and it seemed a cheer ing portent yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall to hear the 8 yearold ensemble maintaining that level of quality under its associate conductor, Ainslee Cox.

title: Angels' Rally Tops Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, April 12 (UPI)Roger Repoz and Jim Fregosi clouted homers in a fiverun sixth inning and the unbeaten California Angels scored their fifth victory today, downing the Kansas City Roy als, 75.

title: Guerrilla Attacks Rising in Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, April 12  An Arab resident of the Gaza Strip was shot and killed today by Israeli soldiers, adding to one of the highest death tolls in the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Senators Halt Red Sox, 65
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) Mike Epstein hit his third home run of the season and Frank Howard chipped in with two doubles today to power the Washington Senators to a 65 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Article 1  No Title
Oberlin Choir Shines as an Ensemble
description: When a choral director knows how to make singers take their music seriously and still aban don themselves to its sensuous pleasures, he has gone a consid erable distance toward mould ing a good ensemble.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF JOINS TAX RETURN FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 The Republican National Chair man and a Democratic Senator today stepped into the contro versy over the Nixon Adminis tration's policy of permitting Clark Mollenhoff, special coun sel to the President, to examine individual tax returns.

title: EAST GERMANS HOLD WAR GAMES IN SOUTH
description: BERLIN, April 12East Ger many disclosed today that it has conducted largescale de fense maneuvers in the south western part of the country, the area where Chancellor Willy Brandt met with Premiel Willi Stoph at Erfurt last month.

title: Descriptions of Site Differ
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, April 13Israeli spokesmen were un available early today for com ment, but it was apparent that the site shown to foreign cor respondents by Egyptian au thorities as the one hit in an Israeli raid last Wednesday was not the one that the Is raelis said they had hit.

title: Thant Says Geneva Accords Hold Key to Crisis in Asia
description: MANILA, April 12Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said today that any just and durable solution to the crisis in Southeast Asia can only be found within the Ge neva agreements of 1954 and 1962.

title: Ballet: A Troupe Visits
description: IT is perhaps curious that while we have no diffi culty in envisioning major American orchestras and even major theater com panies outside of New York, the idea of really important American dance companies that are not based in the cultural capital or golden ghetto, call it what you wish, seems strange.

title: GILBERT NETS PAIR IN OPENING PERIOD
description: For the 17.250 fans at Madi son Square Garden last night, that smashhit morality play, also known as the Stanley Cup playoffs between the Boston Bruins and the New York Rang ers, was won by the good guys, 42.

title: New Orleans Jazz Group Wins Cheers and Whistles at Concert
description: The Preservation Hall Jazz Band, a remarkable sextet made up of five New Orleans musicians in their sixties and seventies and the tubaplaying manager of Preservation Hall, Allan Jaffe, who is half the age of the youngest of his col leagues, yesterday afternoon kept an audience that filled Philharmonic Hall cheering and whistling all through the pro gram.

title: LEN LUSKIN
description: WOODMERE, L.I., April 12 Len Luskin, a partner in Talent Management International, with offices here and abroad, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 546 Longacre Avenue. His age was 45.

title: BERMUDA TENNIS CAPTURED BY ASHE
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 12Arthur Ashe of the United States won the Bacardi open invitational roundrobin tennis tournament today and the $2,250 first prize by defeating Yugo slavia's No. 1 player, Zeljko Franulovic, 86, 75.

title: LockedOut Drivers Threaten to Strike In Chicago Today
description: The Chicago area trucking industry continued its lockout of 35,000 drivers yesterday, the eve of a threatened allout strike by local teamsters de manding a wage settlement higher than that in a proposed national contract.

title: APOLLO 13 COASTS TOWARD THE MOON; AIM IS CORRECTED
description: HOUSTON, April 12  The Apollo 13 astronauts cruised quietly and smoothly toward the moon today, passing the halfway point in their outbound voyage before sharpening their aim with a short blast of the spaceship's rocket.

title: NO ARMS EVIDENT IN EGYPTIAN TOWN
description: Dispatch of The Times, London

title: MinorityGroup Leaders in Hartford See Tension Amid Calm
description: HARTFORD, April 12In the last month, policemen have shot four persons in the pre dominantly Negro and Puerto Rican northern section of Hartford. Two of the victims have died.

title: Athens Court Convicts 27; One Gets Life for Sedition
description: ATHENS, April 12The chief defendant in the Athens se dition trial was sentenced to life in prison today and 26 of the 33 other defendants were also found guilty.

title: AN APPETITE CURB IS FOUND IN RATS
description: A Rockefeller University re searcher has reported finding a neurochemical system in the rat brain that controls appetite in the animal.

title: Phyllis Teicher Married Here
description: Miss Phyllis Margaret Teicher, a graduate student in social work at Smith, and Alvin James Goldman, a third year law student at Colum bia, were married here last evening at Delmonico's Hotel. Rabbi David Golovensky and Cantor Lawrence Avery of BethEl Synagogue in New Rochelle, N. Y., and Rabbi Daniel Silver of Cleveland, performed the ceremony.

title: P.S.C. Head Warns Gas Supply Is Tight in New York State
description: The chairman of the state Public Service Commission de clared yesterday that the gas supply situation in New York is tight.

title: STUDY EXPLORES TRAINEES' NEEDS
description: The success or failure of em ploying the disadvantaged is often determined by the attitude of supervisors and fellow workers.

title: Rome: Annual Crisis Besets Spoleto
description: ROME  There are wise people in Roman cafes these days who sigh deeply, lower their eyelids to express stoic recognition of the inev itable, shake their heads, and admit that all good things come to an untimely end, the better the things the more untimely the end, and the Spoleto Festi val of Two Worlds (the name curi ously reminds Italians of Giu seppe Garibaldi known as the Knight of Two Worlds) might not open this year after all.

title: BIG CHANGE URGED IN STOCKFEE PAN
description: Pressures are mounting with in the membership of the New York Stock Exchange to bring about major changes in the new commissionrate structure pro posed Feb. 13 to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A 3Day Fast for Peace Begins
description: The first of this week's planned antiwar demonstra tions in the city began late yesterday afternoon in a pan eled auditorium on the upper West Side, where a group of New Yorkers gathered to be gin a threeday fast for peace.

title: Metropolitan Museum Plans Centennial Expansion
description: Plans for an expansion pro gram that would provide more than a third again as much space for the collec tions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been completed.

title: AlsoBans Turn Rooters at 19th Hole
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 On the color TV set in a cor ner of the greencarpeted men's locker room at the Augusta National Golf Club today, one of the commen tators stumbled through a sentence.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 13, 1970

title: A FILM EXPLAINS VIOLENCE IN U.S.
description: PARIS, April 12An unusual documentary film on the Unit ed States is currently trying to explain to French moviegoers why America got to her pre eminent position in world affairs.

title: OIL TALKS IN IRAN MAY WIDEN SCOPE
description: Dispatch of The Times, London

title: Books of The Times
description: EVER since he was a boy in Chicago in the nineteentwenties, and the pet of the boarders in his mother's work ingclass rooming house, Louis Studs Terkel has been listening in on people and transmitting their sound. For years he has jockeyed his own disk show, The Wax Museum, on Chicago's station WFMT. In 1967, he brought out Division Street: America, an impressionistic profile of mid America made up of interviews with some of Chicago's peo ple. Now he has carried his re cording equip ment out into America, tuned people into their memories of the twenties and thirties, and come back with Hard Times: An Oral History of the Great Depression. The book is solid talkthe talk of people who remember and those who have only heard; of those who suffered and those who didn't; of those who lost everything and those who had nothing to lose; and of those who were part of the problem, those who tried to solve it, and those who were caught in between.

title: A.A.U. Swim Titles Taken by Kinsella And Debbie Meyer
description: CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP) Debbie Meyer and John Kin sella, two California high school seniors, broke American records in the 1,650  yard free  style events at the final session of the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming cham pionships.

title: The Block, Seat of Old Baltimore's Libido, Awaits Bulldozers
description: BALTIMORE, April 12  This Is a place you can go after a large night. What else you got here? You get the Moose in town and the airconditioning goes out, you're dead. With these words, Max Cohen, the un official Mayor of The Block, once described the importance of Balti more's renowned amusement dis trict. For nearly a century, the Block has been the bastion of American bur lesque, its fleshly pleasures drawing the Moose, the Elks, the Lions and other species of the male animal to this otherwise tame old town.

title: BAR'S REVIEW UNIT COMES UNDER FIRE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  Joseph Califano, general counsel for the Democratic Na tional Committee, called today for reform of the American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary.

title: To Save a Tiger
description: The State Assembly this week is due to consider a bill to provide immediate, specific protection for fifteen species of wildlife by forbidding the sale of their furs or hides in New York, the market that offers the strongest incentives for poachers from the Ama zon to the Himalayas.

title: The Great Campus Fallacy
description: After the present rash of disruptive and destructive incidents on the university campuses have run their course, will there be the predictable postmortem ra tionalizations? It will be said once again, with a con descending indulgence which honest members of the student generation ought to resent, that because legiti mate grievances had existed, the lawlessness was a necessary prelude to reform.

title: RAY A. MARSHALL
description: WESTFIELD, N. Y., April 12 Ray A. Marshali, purchasing agent for Welch's Foods, Inc., and Mayor of Westfield in 196162, died yesterday of a coronary attack. He was 57 years old.

title: STRIKE THREATENED IN BUILDINGS IN CITY
description: Thomas Shortman, president of a huilding service employes union, warned yesterday that the 25.000 members of his local would strike 5,000 apart ment buildings on April 20 if a new contract agreement was not reached by then with the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, representing the owners.

title: Housing Bias in Suburbs Is Blamed for Labor Shortages There
description: The National Committee Against Discrimination in Hous ing said in a report last week that the exclusion of blacks and Puerto Ricans from hous ing in the suburbs has created labor shortages in new facto ries springing up around New York City.

title: Lawyer Resigns Drug Post; Denounces Narcotic Laws
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 The assistant district attorney for narcotics here has resigned and denounced the drug laws as asinine less than a month after he was heckled at the University of Pennsylvania when he tried to defend the narcotics laws.

title: To Dine Well in Hong Kong, It Helps If You Speak Chinese
description: HONG KONGThe next best thing to eating in Hong Kong's fine restaurants is to talk to someone who has. And the best way to dine there is to eat with the man who may be the town's ultimate authority on where to dine. He is a 35yearold, cherubfaced native of China named William Mark who earns his keep writing and editing international news for a local newspaper called Chun Po, or Truth Daily, but will act as a guide for visitors.

title: Michael Donaldson, 86, Dies; Won Medal of Honor in '18
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., April 12 (AP)Michael A. Donald son, who was awarded the Medal of Honor for rescuing six men from enemy fire in World War I, died at the Vet eran's Administration Hospital in Montrose today. He was 86 years old.

title: Cambodian Fighting Nears Capital of a Key Province
description: SVAYRIENG, Cambodia, April 12A surge of fighting moved to the eastern edge of this pro vincial capital today as Viet namese guerrillas approached the village of Prasot  down Route 1 in the direction of South Vietnamand a battery of Cambodian 105mm. howit zers began firing into the abandoned village from the Svayrieng soccer field.

title: Victor Trivas, Film Writer, 74; Nazis Burned His Best Work
description: Victor Trivas, a screenwriter and artist, died of a heart at tack at his home, 315 East 72d Street, yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Phone Call by Hoving in 1967 Led to Museum's Master Plan
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's elaborate master plan was initiated one late summer day in 1967 with a phone call from Thomas P. F. Hoving, the mu seum's new director, to Arthur Rosenblatt, director of design at the Parks Department and Mr. Hoving's former aide.

title: EGEBERG FAVORS AID FOR ABORTION
description: The chief medical officer of the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare said yester day that he would be in favor of using public funds for as sisting indigent patients in ob taining abortions in states where they are legal.

title: Students Occupy Fordham Building To Back Teacher
description: About 200 students occupied the administration building of Fordham University's Bronx campus last night to protest the denial of tenure to an Eng lish teacher and to press for changes in the school's policies.

title: At Warm Springs, Happy Days Are Gone
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12  A quartercentury ago today, Mrs. Ruth Stevens awoke long before dawn and began the long process of cooking an oldfashioned Southern dinner for the President of the United States.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series)

title: SCHMIDT, PIANIST, BOWS WITH GRACE
description: Thomas Schmidt, the pianist, presented himself last night in Carnegie Recital Hall for his New York solo debut. Although not a demon virtuoso at the keyboard, he commands an ef ficient technical facility. He maneuvered his way through a difficult program with ease and assurance.

title: Kirk Capitulates to Court On School Desegregation
description: BRADENTON, Fla., April 12 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., faced with the threat of fines of $10,000 a day for contempt of court, bowed tonight to the power of the Federal courts and said that he would return control of Manatee County schools to local officials.

title: C. EARL MORAN
description: WARREN, N.J., April 12  C. Earl Moran of Mountain Ave nue, who retired in 1958 as sec retarytreasurer of the Anacon da Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Scotch Plains. He was 78 ears old.

title: Elegy for a Country Church
description: LONDONOne of the great joys of England, and surprises, is the survival of rural villages unspoiled by the in dustrial revolution or the population curve or even the automobile. A few miles from a main road, among the farms, one comes upon a small street of stone houses and an old churcha village with a sense of historical identity, the sort of place whose eccentricities Miss Jane Marple would enjoy.

title: Astronaut's Car Is Damaged
description: HOUSTON, April 12 (AP)  With the family breadwinner halfway to the moon, the family of Fred W. Haise Jr., one of the Apollo 13 astronauts, had trou ble today getting into their own driveway. Bill Der Bing, a pro cotol officer who drove Mrs. Haise and her children to church and back, missed the driveway backing in, crumpling the car's tailpipe against the curb.

title: Levin Concern Is Ordered To Yield Stockholder List
description: NEWARK, April 12 (UPI)A Newark judge has ordered a New Yorkbased computerleas ing concern to turn over its stockholder records to a busi nessman who contends he was ousted illegally as the compa ny's president.

title: After Prison in Cambodia an Intellectual Needs to Talk
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 12Most men do not know, much less care, about the con ditions of prisons until they are inside them, and then it is too late, a 30yearold intellectual, Phouk Chhay, said last week.

title: TERMS DUE TODAY FOR A.T.&T. ISSUE
description: The directors of the Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph Company will meet this morning and set the final terms on the largest corporate financing ever undertaken in this country.

title: Argentine Base Raided
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 12 (AP)  Ten men raided a Coast Guard post 15 miles north of here today, manacled the four men on duty and fled with 30 uniforms and some weapons, the police reported.

title: BASESFULL WALK IN 9TH ENDS FINALE
description: The Yankees salvaged a split of their first doubleheader of thhe season yesterday, but riot ous disorders by thousands of spectators in the econd game marred a thrilling 54 victory over the Cleveland Indian.

title: Leonor March Is Bride Of Spanish Nobleman
description: MADRID, April 12  The marriage of Leonor March Cencillo and Francisco Chi cao de Guzman y Giron, per formed yesterday in Palma de allorca's cathedral by the island's Bishop, the Most Rev. Rafael Alvarez Lara, united two illustrious Spanish fam ilies.

title: Sisco Meets With Nasser; Said to Tell Peace Views
description: CAIRO, April 12 (Reuters) Joseph J. Sisco, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, conferred today with President Gamal Abdel Nasser at Mr. Nasser's home in Cairo.

title: James Farmer Says Nixon Is Not Biased on Minorities
description: James Farmer, Assistant Sec retary of Health, Education, and Welfare, defended the Nixon Administration yester day, against charges of bias and insensitivity to the prob lems of blacks and other minor

title: Mrs. Owen Johnson, Helped Found Berkshire Festival
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., April 12Mrs. Gertrude Bovee Johnson, widow of Owen John son, the author who wrote about life at the Lawrenceville School and Yale, died Friday of cancer at her home here. She was 81 years old.

title: Air Force Officer Acquitted On Opium Charge in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 (AP)Maj, Hugh A. Davis, 37 years old, an Air Force pilot assigned to a sup port squadron at Tansonnhut Air Base in Saigon, was found innocent today of smuggling opium from Thailand, but was convicted of illegal possession of United States currency.

title: Liberation Commemorated At BergenBelsen Camp
description: BERGEN, Germany, April 12 (AP)  BergenBelsen Nazi death camp victims, estimated to number more than 50,000, were honored today in a cere mony commemorating the 25th anniversary of the camp's liber ation by British troops.

title: Fat Saturday
description: THE weekend began with the distinct possibility that by Monday night the Mets could reclaim possession of New York. Lew Alcindor was getting bigger by the minute, his new era of basketball coming closer by the second. What better time to usher it in than against the Knicks on Saturday afternoon at Madison Square Garden in the city of his early fame? And that evening, the Rangers, already twice beaten, would meet the Boston Bruins, whose crude, clobbering hockey style turns off the purists but packs the arenas.

title: Mrs. King Gets Post
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)Mrs. Coretta King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has accepted appointment to Boston University's Board of Fellows.

title: STATE TO DEBATE BANKING REFORM
description: The first fundamental reform of the banking structure in New York State since the De pression is due to come up for debate in the State Legislature this week.

title: Leo Fuchs Brings New Touches To a Revue and in English Yet
description: It was Grossinger's on 57th Street Saturday night as Leo Fuchs, the popular veteran of New York's Yiddish thea tre, brought an English speaking entertainment, called A Time to Laugh, to Car negie Hall.

title: Ryan Wins 3Mile Run
description: Howie Ryan of the New York Athletic Club won the Metro politan Amateur Athletic Union sponsored threemile run yes terday at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island. Ryan was timed in 14 minutes 24 seconds as he led Charles Kaczorek of the St. John's Athletic Association by 70 yards. Joe Bessel of the N.Y.A.C. was third.

title: EDUCATOR LOSES IN CHICAGO SUBURB
description: EVANSTON, Ill., April 12 Supporters of Dr. Gregory C. Coffin, superintendent of Evanston's elementary schools, were defeated last night in a bitterly fought school board election that has polarized this affluent Chicago suburb.

title: The Museum's Birthday Cake
description: For its centennial celebration the Metropolitan Museum has come up with a giant birthday cake that can be sliced two ways. The skillful design for com pleting its physical plant, part of a carefully studied master plan for Its second century, is a rational, thoughtful and architecturally sensitive solution.

title: Mrs. John S. Reilly Dead at 76; Author Was a Charity Leader
description: Mrs. Estelle Mulqueen Reilly, an author and a leader in Roman Catholic charity work, died yes terday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 1 Lexington Avenue. Her hus band, John S. Reilly, is a retired food company executive.

title: Limit on Demurrage Is Fixed at 10 Days On Port Cargo Here
description: Free time on export cargo at the Port of New York and Philadelphia has been fixed by the Federal Maritime Commis sion at a maximum of 10 days, exclusive of Saturdays, Sun days and legal holidays.

title: More Air Traffic Controllers Reported on the Job
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The Government report ed a continuing improvement today in the situation caused by the sickout of the nation's air traffic controllers, ordered by a Federal judge to return to work or produce evidence that they were really ill.

title: Brewers Homers Conquer White Sox Twice, 52, 162
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (AP)  George Lauzerique, pitcher, drove in four runsthree of them on a homerto help the Milwaukee Brewers maul the Chicago White Sox 162 for a sweep of their doubleheader to day.

title: TALISMAN CAPTURES JUNIOR HUNTER TITLE
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 12 Talisman, Robin Bacon's smart stepping 6yearold chestnut gelding, won his fifth champion ship in six shows this season to day at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Ridden by Miss Bacon, who made her weekly trip from Cape Cod, Talisman scored 10 points to take the junior work ing hunter title at the final Ox Ridge indoor show of the year. The mount won blues in one class over fences and in the hack test.

title: Apollo Is 4,371st in Space
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 11 (AP) Apollo 13 has been designated the 4,371st object in space by the United States Air Force Aerospace Defense Com mand, which keeps track of the number from a command center in Cheyenne Mountain near here.

title: DANELY SLAUGHTER, CANCER SURGEON, 58
description: CHICAGO, April 12  Dr. Danely Philip Slaughter, a noted cancer surgeon, died yes terday in the University of Illi nois Hospital after surgery. He was 58 years old.

title: Henry Ford 2d in Russia
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (UPI) Henry Ford 2d arrived today on an official visit as a guest of the Soviet Government. The chairman of the Ford Motor Company was invited by the Soviet State Committee of Sci ence and Technology, the news agency Tass reported.

title: M. B. Masius Weds Kathryn Ann Kohn
description: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., April 12Miss Kathryn Ann Kohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Lyon Kohn, was married at the Tumble Brook Country Club here last even ing to Michael Benjamin Mas ius, a project director with the New. York City Housing Development Administration.

title: STARS BEAT BLUES, TIE PLAYOFFS, 22
