description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 12 (AP)Cesare Maniago, Min nesota goalie, foiled the high scoring St. Louis skaters and Bill Goldsworthy continued his torrid scoring pace as the North Stars defeated the St. Louis Blues, 40, today to even their West Division National Hockey League Stanley Cup series at two games apiece.

title: CURTIS J. HOOPER, 63, A TRAFFIC ENGINEER
description: MADISON, Conn., April 12 Curtis James Hooper, Deputy Director of Transportation of Connecticut and a leading traf fic engineer, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 12 Rolling Meadow Road. His age was 63.

title: Showdown on Rents
description: The unanimous decision of a state appellate court that the city's yearold Rent Stabilization Law is unconstitutional could prove of utmost benefit in com pelling the city to rationalize its present crazyquilt of rent control.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION Knicks vs. Milwaukee

title: Chess:
description: ARTHUR BISGUIER of Hartsdale, N. Y., and Larry Evans of Reno, both veteran grandmasters, shared top honors in the recent Na tional Open Chess Champion ship at Sparks, Nev. They scored 71 each. There were 112 players from every part of the country in the eight round Swiss system contest.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: ORIOLES BOW, 72, FOR FIRST DEFEAT
description: BALTIMORE, April 12 (UPI) Joe Niekro allowed six hits in 8 23 innings and got a two run triple during a fiverun fourthinning outburst today, to score his second straight victory as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 72.

title: Accidents, Alcoholism and Insecurity Blamed for French Underpopulation
description: PARIS, April 8Alcoholism, wild driving and housewives worries contribute to what the Government has now declared to be one of France's main problemsthe sparseness of the country's population.

title: STEEL SHIPMENTS FACE SOME DELAYS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 12 Most manufacturers were well stocked with steel inventory as they faced shipping delays last week.

title: EZRA HARARI, ACTIVE IN YIDDISH THEATER
description: Ezra Harari, a director of Yiddish theater, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after openheart surgery. He was 76 years old and lived at 285 Cen tral Park West.

title: 50% Rise Is Urged In Federal Spending On New Park Land
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Nixon Administration proposed today a 50 per cent increase in Federal spending for buying and developing new parks and recreation areas.

title: Quarter Gain Is 11%
INQUIRY BY HOUSE ON DOUGLAS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 A bipartisan group of Repre sentatives will press for a House investigation of Justice William O. Douglas's fitness to continue serving on the Su preme Court.

title: Advertising: J. W. T. Wins Eaton Account
description: Eaton Yale & Towne, Inc., a company with a century old heritage but a name that's only four, has just finished a twomonth search for an agency to do its corporate advertising. Having talked to more than a dozen agen cies in four cities, they've picked J. Walter Thompson.

title: Assembly Passes Bill Against Blockbusting That Would Permit the City to Curb Brokers
description: ALBANY, April 13The As sembly passed a toughened bill against blockbusting today that would place designated areas of racial tensions in New York City off limits to solicitations by realestate brokers.

title: Ombudsman for Consumers Urged in Scandinavia
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 9  Konsumentombudsman may be a bit long for a rally ing cry, but it is expected to he a household word in Sweden soon.

title: Ninth Botticelli Ball Will Benefit Orphans of Italy
description: The ninth annual Botti celli Ball will be held at the Plaza on April 27 to raise money for Orphans of Italy.

title: Casper's Deft Putting Defeats Littler by Five Strokes in Masters Playoff
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 Billy Casper's deft putting car ried him to a major golfing triumph in another playoff to day. Using only 12 strokes on the greens for the first nine holes of the Augusta National Golf Club to gain a fivestroke lead, Casper went on to defeat Gene Littler in the 18 extra hole session for the Masters crown, 69 to 74.

title: Four Lost in Ship Collision
description: DUNGENESS, England (UPI) The 400ton Spanish ship Sierra Bravia collided yesterday with the 8,200ton Liberian freighter Ruhr Ore. The Spanish vessel sank immediately. Au thorities said a seaman died and three others were missing and presumed drowned. Three of the nine survivors of the Spanish vessel were injured.

title: West Germans Honor Envoy Slain by Guatemalan Leftists
description: BONN, April 13 (AP)  The West German Government paid tribute today in the Bundestag to Count Krl von Spreti, its am bassador to Guatemala, who was murdered by leftist guer rillas in the Central American nation last week.

title: Cosmos 332 Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (AP) The Soviet Union has launched Cosmos 332 in its series of un manned satellites Tass reported today. The press agency said the new Sputnik, which was launched Saturday, was orbit ing the earth every 100 minutes at an angle of 74.5 degrees, with a high point of 488 miles and a low point of 469 miles.

title: Another Storm King?
description: What could be another Storm King situation threat ens the lower Berkshires. A power company combine called Northeast Utilities proposes to build the biggest pumpedstorage plant in the world, possibly two of them, in one of the most unspoiled areas of lower New England. Two sites have been chosen, one in south west Massachusetts, the other only ten miles away northwest Connecticut. The Massachusetts site in cludes Mount Washington, a mountaintop lake, a brook and a swamp that date back to glacial days. The Connecticut site takes in Canaan Mountain, another mountaintop pond and a valley with its brook and lowland.

title: Rise in Big Board's Fund From $7.5Million to $75Million Weighed
description: A highlevel committee studying the Special Trust Fund of the New York Stock Ex change is considering a recom mendation to increase the fund's assets as much as 10 fold, to $75million, to insure against customer losses in case of brokeragehouse insolvencies.

title: Alexander Fraser Jr. Fiance Of Miss Alexandra M. Harris
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., April 13  The engagement of Miss Alexandra Morrill Harris, a sophomore at Vassar College, to Alexander William Fraser Jr., a sophomore at New York University, has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Stewart Harris, parents of the future bride. Her financ is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fraser of Wilmington. Del.A June wedding is planned. Miss Harris attended the Wilmington Friends School. Her father, director of col lections at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, was formerly deputy director of the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum in Wil mington and director of the J. B. Speed Art Museum in Louisville.

title: JEROME S. STOLZOFF
description: Jermee S. Stolzoff, a senior vice president of the SSC&B advertising agency, 575 Lexing ton Avenue, died at Lenox Hill Hospital Saturday of complica lions following surgery. He was 46 years old and lived at 401 East 65th Street.

title: Rangers Return to Boston Battleground Tonight for Fifth Game of Playoffs
description: Amid fervent speculation over who is going to do what to whom (and how soon), the Rangers and Bruins will face each other tonight at Boston in the fifth game of their Stanley Cup series.

title: 3 FuelCell Units Supply Power for Spacecraft
description: HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) The Apollo 13 spacecraft gets its primary power from three, fuelcell power plants located in the service module that is attached to the coneshaped command module. Two of these fuel cells went out tonight.

title: 2 Great VoteGetters a Shy Taft and an Aggressive Rhodes, Prepare for Ohio Primary
description: NEWARK, OhioRepresenta tive Robert Taft Jr. spent an hour last week touring the Fiberglas plant in this ecntral Ohio city. He peered into the huge machines that spew out in sulating material like pink cot ton candy and learned how the manufacturing process works.

title: Conservation Groups Win Stay Of Start on Alaska Pipeline Road
description: WASHINGTON, April 13A Federal District Court judge en joined Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel today from issuing a rightofway permit for a road to parallel the pro, jected Alaska oil pipeline, until complaints of three conserva tion groups could be tried on their merits.

title: NATO May Invite Soviet Bloc to Parley
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Administration sources re ported today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was expected to issue a for mal invitation to the Warsaw Pact countries next month for a conference on mutual reduc tion of conventional military forces in Europe.

title: Wives of 2 Astronauts Told of Flight Trouble
description: HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) The wives of Capt. James L. Lovell Jr. and Fred W. Haise Jr., the Apollo 13 astro nauts, went home from Mis sion Control in a good mood after tonight's television show from space ended, unaware that trouble had developed in two of the spacecraft's three power cells.

title: Alcan Units to Raise Price
description: Alcan Aluminum, Ltd., an nounced yesterday in Montreal that its overseas subsidiaries would raise the price of alumi num ingot by half a cen pound, to the equivalent of 28 United States cents. This action fol lowed an increase of a cent a pound, to 29 cents last week, by all major American alumi num producers.

title: Market Place: A Critic Views Raider Tactics
description: IS the surprise takeover a legitimate tool of manage ment or a mischievous device leading to disruptive stock prices and losses for unso phisticated shareholders?

title: Union Rights Sought for State Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Legislation that would require state and local governments to recognize unions of their em ployes and bargain with them should be enacted in all parts of the country, a panel of labor and personnel experts said to day.

title: Beckett's Picture Of Life Is Turned Into Somber Dance
description: The parallel sensibilities of the dramatist Samuel Beckett and the choreographer Anna Sokolow were successfully joined last night at the Edison Theater in a production of Mr. Beckett's Act Without Words No. 1. Miss Sokolow, who for many years has detailed the entropic rundown of the human race in pure dance terms, di rected the playwright's pictorial vignettes of frustration with a sure hand.

title: Ford, in Soviet, May Get Proposal to Build Vehicles
description: MOSCOW, April 13Henry Ford 2d began talks today with high Soviet officials. A Ford, Motor Company spokesman said the talks were expected to result in an invitation to the company to establish op erations in the Soviet Union.

title: Russell Reponds to Pressure And Now It's All on the Bucks
description: Heroes were plentiful and spirit was running wild in the New York Knicks' dress ing room last night after their excrutiatingly exciting and highly important victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: The Long and Short of Augusta Victory
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 Suddenly voices were shout ing Fore! Fore! and Bill Casper's tee shot on the 555 yard, par5 second hole hooked into the tall pine trees. Rustling through the branches and brush, the ball rolled downhill and settled on a grassy basin. But the view to the fairway was blocked by a barricade of the towering pines perhaps 50 yards ahead.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WHEN the New York Mets made their last appearance at Shea Stadium they were engulfed by the eu phoria that comes from just having won the championship of the world. Out on the field the deliriously happy Met fans were ripping the joint apart, gouging out the turf with clawing fingers in a totally senseless display of misplaced enthusiasm.

title: DuPont Set Record for Sales in March
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 13E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.'s firstquarter sales rose by 7 per cent to $935 million, Charles M. McCoy, president, told some 1,500 stockholders at the 167th an nual meeting here today.

title: Panther Hearing Postponed by Fire Until Tomorrow
description: Pretrial hearings for 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places were ad journed yesterday to tomorrow because of a fire over the weekend in the building in which three defense lawyers have offices.

title: One Dead in Gan Battle At Ankara University
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 13 (UPI)One perpson was killed and scores injured to day during a gun battle be tween leftwings and right ring students at Ankara Uni versity, the police said.

title: Muskie Calls for Bill to Guard Against Failures by Brokerage Houses
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Senator Edmund S. Muskie ap pealed today for prompt action on his bill to create a system of Federal insurance against fi nancial losses to customers and others from the failure of brokerage firms.

title: Negroes Reject Gary Player's Golf Offer
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 Because of South Africa's racial separation policy, the United Negro College Fund has decided against accept ing Gary Player's offer to play exhibition matches with American Negro golfers for the benefit of the fund. The decision was announced to day by Vernon Jordan, ex ecutive director of the fund.

title: NEW CRIME CODE GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 13  An ex tensive revision of the state's Code of Criminal Procedure, containing hundreds of changes in nearly every facet of the criminal justice process, passed the Senate by a vote of 40 to 13 today and was sent to the Assembly.

title: Marshall Joins Staff Of Yale's Law School
description: NEW HAVEN, April 13 Burke Marshall, who headed the Justice Department's Civ il Rights Division in the tu multuous years from 1961 to 1965, has been appointed deputy dean of the Yale Uni versity Law School, a spokes man said today.

title: COURT ASKED TO BAR 2 HOSPITAL STRIKES
description: MADISON, Wis., April 13 Wisconsin Attorney General Robert Warren sought today Circuit Court injunction to halt work stoppages at two state mental hospitals.

title: MRS. WILLIAM M. LISTER
description: KEN?? WORTH, N. J., April 13Mrs. Adele Catlin Lister, wife of William M. Lister, a former mayor, died yesterday in Raritan Valley Hospital, Green Brook, after a brief ill ness. She was 77 years old and lived at 315 Math 21st Street here.

title: Jersey Turnpike Jam Feared
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 13 (UPI)The New Jer sey Turnpike Authority warned motorists today that repairs in the Newark Airport area and on the Newark Bay extension to the Holland Tunnel could re sult in traffic congestion. The authority said the extension would undergo repairs begin ning today and lasting through Aug. 14. The area between Newark Airport interchange 14 and the Lincoln Tunnel inter change exits 16 and 18 will be worked on starting today and extending through Friday.

title: NIXON AIDE SCORED BY SENATOR SMITH
description: WASHINGTON, April 13, AP Senator Margaret Chase Smith said today that Bryce Harlow, a Presidential Coun selor, had impugned the in tegrity and veracity of her office by false statements be fore and after last week's vote on the supreme court nomina tion of Harrold Carowell.

title: ANTIWAR SAILOR FACES NAVY TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  More than a year ago, a young sailor assigned to the Pentagon expressed his displeasure with military life, and the Navy in particular, by printing an anti war newsletter mocking the service.

title: Exercise Price on Warrants Put at $52
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company set an 8 per cent interest rate yesterday morning on its $1.57billion of debentures with warrantsthe largest financing package in American corporate history.

title: Pina Carmirelli Avoids Frills in Violin Debut
description: PINA CARMIRELLI, who made her local recital debut last night at Tully Hall, is obviously a violinist who takes her music seriously.

title: Orderly Students Protest at Fordham
description: More than 200 students con tinued to occupy the main ad ministration building of Ford ham University yesterday in an orderly demonstration resulting from the school's decision to deny tenure to a popular pro fessor of English.

title: At Mission Control, the Scene Is Quiet, Professional and Tense
description: HOUSTON, Tuseday, April 14The mission control room looked calm and professional, but tense. The voices were clipped and serious as mission, controllers on earth tried to, help three men in space cope with a grave emergency.

title: Art Museum, Huge Today, Began Small
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has come a long way since the day nearly a cen tury ago, when Henry James described it as the charming little academy in the Fifth Avenue.

title: Army Tops Fordham, 65, On Murray's Hit in Eighth
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 13  Jim Murray's basesloaded single with two out in the eighth carried Army to a 65 victory over Fordham today. The game was called after eight innings because of the cadets' curfew.

title: NEWSMEN'S RELEASE IS ASKED BY ROGERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Secretary of State William P. Rogers called today for the] prompt release of eight foreign newsmen believed to have been captured by Communist forces in Cambodia.

title: Bill for Retarded Passes
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Senate today passed 60 to 0 a $468million bill that would extend for three years and expand a program of Fed eral help in building facilities for the mentally retarded. The measure was sent to the House.

title: Las Vegas an Example of Cities' Air Pollution Lag
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.This des ert gambling and resort center derives its livelihood from its atypical features, but it typifies many of the nation's cities in its position on environmental problems. Most notably it exem plifies the wide gulf between President Nixon's sweeping pro posals for controlling air pollution, and condo tions as they ac tually exist. In his Feb. 10 environ mental message, the President said the program of designating 57 metropolitan air quality re gions for joint Federalstate control was moving too slowly and should be speeded up; that it should be supplemented by nationwide Federal limits on extremely hazardous indus trial fumes and on all emissions of major new industrial facili ties; and that Federal officials should have both interstate and intrastate enforcement powers backed by courtimposed fines to $10,000 a day.

title: PRICING BY A.T.&T. CHEERS BOND MEN
Mediators Seek to Avoid Post Strike
description: Mediators in the newspaper dispute made a new effort yes terday to head off a strike threatened for today at The New York Post by members of the Newspaper Guild.

title: Prices Show Fresh Decline in Slow Amex Trading
description: Prices eased for the eighth consecutive session in slow trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Monetary Changes Are Losing Support
description: GENEVA, April 13Mone tary authorities of the major Western nations are losing in terest in proposed changes de signed to provide for greater flexibility of currencies in ex change markets.

title: BrandtNixon Talks
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt's visit has helped to contain the widening policy gap that has been opening recently between Washington and Bonn, but it also has under lined dangers that lie ahead.

title: FEDERAL PRISONER MOVED TO TOMBS
description: Samuel J. Melville, who is under state and Federal indict ments charging him with bombing office buildings here last fall, was transferred to the Tombs on Saturday because he had tried to saw his way out of his cell at the Federal House of Detention, according to lawenforcement sources.

title: In The Nation: The Real Mess in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 13It is too bad that the Democratic and Republican national chair men have fired away at each other as to whether Clark Mol lenhoff, a White House assist ant, should have the right to inspect individual income tax returns. Since Democratic Chairman L. F. O'Brien raised the question and Republican Chairman Rogers Morton re sponded that the Democrats were unduly sensitive to in vestigation, it may indeed look as if Mr. O'Brien's party has something to hide.

title: High Police Official Slain in Montevideo; Terrorists Sought
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 13 (AP)The head of Uruguay's police intelligence branch was shot to death by machine gun ners here today, and the police authorities began searching for a leftwing terrorist group be lieved to have killed six other policemen since last July.

title: Books Reproduced on TV Cartridges
description: A system of reproducing the printed word by electronic means is being advanced by C.B.S. Laboratories in conjunc tion with major European elec tronic and publishing concerns.

title: In Delhi, It's Difficult to Find Bad Native Dish
description: NEW DELHIThere are scores of exciting dishes to be found in both Old and New Delhi and one of the greatest of the lot is tandoori chicken, which could be called the national dish of India. The name does not re late to a town or region or state as many people believe but rather to the word tan door, the Indian word for oven.

title: MSGR. FRANCIS SHEA OF NEW ROCHELLE, 75
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 13Msgr. Francis X. Shea, pas tor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament here, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a stroke. He was 75 years old and lived at the rectory.

title: Observer: The Ultimate Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Dear Mr. President,

title: 3 Miami Race Tracks Block License Revocation Move
description: MIAMI, April 13 (UPI)  Lawyers for Tropical Park to day blocked the State Racing Commission from holding li cense revocation hearings against Tropical park and two other horse racing tracks ac cused of making illegal political contributions in 1964.

title: PRICES ARE EASIER IN STOCK MARKET
description: The start of American Tele phone's massive new financing program dominated an other wise slow and sluggish stock market session yesterday.

title: Staponski Still Critical
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 13 (UPI)Virgil Stapon ski, 22yearold cocaptain of the Air Force Academy Football team, was reported in serious condition early today with a head injury suffered last week during spring practice contact drill. He underwent a fivehour operation at Penrose Hospital Friday.

title: EUGENE BIRD COLER, BANKER, DEAD AT 79
description: ROCKVILLE CENTER, L. I., April 13Eugene Bird Coler, a retired bank executive, died of cancer at his home here yester day. He was 79 years old and was the son of Bird S. Coler, former New York City Welfare Commissioner.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 13, 1970 THE PRESIDENT

title: EXCHANGE TO DEAL IN MONEY FUTURES
description: The Internationl Commercial Exchange, said to be the first market for currency contract futures, is scheduled to open on April 23 at 2 Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Murray Borowitz, exchange president.

title: HOFSTRA'S PAUSES LAUDED BY COACH
description: Hofstra University's lacrosse team has scored 93 goals in seven games and Steve Dauses has had a hand in 47.

title: Bridge:
description: MANY of the knockout and doubleknockout champi onships that began in the metropolitan area during the winter are being finished this month. The Westchester dou bleknockout event, for ex ample, ended Sunday when a foursome from Poughkeepsie, N. Y., captured the title.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: John M. Fisher has joined Curran, Anthony & Co., Inc., as chairman of the board. He suc ceeds Joseph C. Byrne, who will now devote all of his time to being chief executive of the company.

title: Nassau Democratic Convention Picks Lowenstein and DiPaola
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 13 Mayor Andrew J. DiPaola of Glen Cove was disegnated at the Nassau County Democratic Convention tonight as the party's candidate for County Executive and Representative Allard K. Lowenstein was designated for reelection in the Fifth Congressional District.

title: ROZELLE UPHOLDS BALTIMORE CLAIM
description: Joe Robbie, the managing general partner of the Miami Dolphins, violated the National Football League's rules against tampering when he hired the head coach, Don Shula, away from the Baltimore Colts last winter. The penalty will be the Dolphins' first draft choice next year and at will go to the Colts.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: U.S. T earn Off far Vienna; Caution on Arms Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The United States delegation left today for a crucial round of armslimitation talks with the Soviet Union amid continu ing complaints from Capitol Hill that the Administration was jeopardizing the negotiations by proceeding with the Safeguard missile defense system.

title: BREDINEV URGES FRESH SOLUTIONS TO ECONOMIC ILLS
description: MOSCOW, April 13Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, told the Soviet people today that new methods and new solutions were needed to solve the country's economic problems.

title: Samuels May Withdraw Support From Paterson Because Senator Endorsed Goldberg
description: Howard J. Samuels, one of four Democrats seeking the nomination for Governor, said yesterday he was considering withdrawing his support from Senator Basil A. Paterson of Harlem, the Democratic desig nee for Lieutenant Governor.

title: Athens Frees Ailing Theodorakis
description: ATHENS, April 13Mikis Theodorakis, Greece's leading contemporary composer and a political prisoner for 20 months, was unexpectedly set free today and was allowed to fly to Paris at once for treatment of tuberculosis.

title: Amaya Outpoints Jimenez
description: Amaya Outpoints Jimenez

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PANAMA, April 13 (UPI) Antonio Amaya, 135 pounds, of Panama, the ranking junior lightweight title contender, gained a unanimous 10round decision over Efren Jimenez, 136, of Mexico, last night.

title: Knicks Down Bucks, 112111, and Take 20 Lead in Eastern Final Playoffs
GUERIN OF HAWKS IS FINED $1,000
description: Commissioner Walter Ken nedy of the National Basketball Association fined Coach Richie Guerin of the Atlanta Hawks $1,000 yesterday for conduct, detrimental to professional bas ketball.

title: CITY MAY OBTAIN REVENUE SHARING
description: ALBANY, April 13Legis lative sources said today that New York City's quest for more money from the state might result in a fiscal pack age that would include keying urban aid to a specific pro portion of state incometax revenues.

title: 3Month Sales Dip
description: The economic slowdown, combined with inflationary pressures, reduced firstquarter earnings of the RCA Corpora tion 36 per cent to $27.4million from the record $42.5million in 1969's first quarter, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and presi dent, reported yesterday.

title: Card of Thanks
description: LEVINEHarry. The family of the late Harry Levine gratefully acknowledge the many kind and generous expressions of sympathy extended to them in their loss.

title: COLLEGE OARSMEN SEARCH FOR RIVALS
description: The Rutgers second freshman crew was scheduled to race Northeastern and Yale last Sat urday on the latter's course at Derby, Conn. But a budget shoitage forced Northeastern to cancel its trip and Yale had four oarsmen available rather than eight.

title: Israeli Jets Hit at Suez and Nile
description: JERUSALEM, April 13Is raeli bombers struck three times today at Egyptian sites described as military installa tions, hitting targets in two sectors of the Nile Delta and along the length of the Suez Canal.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Prices on the London stock market closed sharply higher yesterday amid general opti mism that the new national budget would be favorable to securities investment. The budget will be announced today.

title: Half of Los Angeles Teachers Strike for More Aid From State
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13  Teachers in the Los Angeles school system, the nation's sec ond largest, staged a crippling strike today aimed at wresting more aid for education from the State Legislature.

title: FIRE IN ROCKAWAY KILLS 4 IN FAMILY
description: A woman and her three chil dren were killed in a fire that swept through a twostory frame house on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens last night.

title: Excerpts From Talks Between Apollo and Houston
description: Following are excerpts from conversations between the Apollo 13 astronauts and Mission Control in Houston, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Books of The Times
description: AS Calvin Tomkins notes in the preface to this more or less authorized valentine, the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art is the greatest museum in the Western hemisphere and one of the half dozen greatest in the world, a cul tural attic full of 50 centuries of artifacts. Over 6 million citizens march annually down its corridors, all of them on the same Sunday afternoon that you or I decide to go. On the occasion of the Metropolitan's centennial cele bration, Mr. Tom kins takes us into the historical wings. There, mounted like moose heads, are the directors, col lectors, curators and trustees who made the museum what it is: Joseph Choate, General Cesnola, J. P. Mor gan, Francis Taylor, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Robert Lehman, Thomas P. F. (Pub licity Forever) Hoving, etc. Mr. Tomkins, a staff writer for The New Yorker, settles always for the seemliness of a court his torianeven when he must lash some nincompoop, he usually uses an ironic noodle to do sobut his stroll through anecdote is amiable and informative.

title: LEFTIST GOVERNOR WINS KYOTO RACE
description: KYOTO, Japan, April 13 The governing LiberalDemo cratic party suffered a humiliat ing defeat today in a key gubernatorial election in which the incumbent, Torazo Nina gawa, a Marxist, won in a land slide over Mamoru Shibata, a former Government official.

title: Let Jews Leave, Sorensen Appeals in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 13 Theo dore C. Sorensen, who is the choice of the New York Demo cratic state committee for the party's Senate nomination, told a Soviet audience today many things that New York voters might like to hear but that the Russians did not seem to ap preciate.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 14, 1970

title: For Museum Birthday, Good Cheer and Cake
description: In the manner of a rejuve nated dowager with unlim ited life expectancy, the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave itself a bangup 10th birthday party yesterday.

title: NEWAUTO SALES SHOW A DECLINE
description: DETROIT, April 13New car dealers reported today 198,084 sales of United States type cars in early April, down 14 per cent from 229,383 de liveries a year ago.

title: JAPAN AND COLOMBIA FINISH OFF CUP FOES
description: TOKYO, April 13 (AP)  The Japanese Davis Cup tennis team, having sewn up the right to face Australia in the Eastern Zone Section A final here, made it a 50 sweep over South Viet nam in their semifinal series today.

title: '69 Stock Buying Up 20% For Institutional Investors
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters)  Net purchases of common stock by four leading institutional investor groups rose 20 per cent last year, the Securities and Exchange Com mission estimated today.

title: Mansfield Files for Race
description: HELENA Mont., April 13 (AP) The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, paid the $425 fee today that puts him offi cially into contention for a fourth sixthyear term in the Senate. The state's senior Sena tor, who turned 67 last March 16, Is opposed in the Democratic primary by John Lawler. 31, a Havre rancher.

title: Nixon Signs Education Aid Bill With Reluctance
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  With considerable reluctance, President Nixon signed today the most expensive education legislation ever passed by Con gressa bill authorizing $26.4 billion over three years for ele mentary and secondary educa tion.

title: Hoad Victor in Tennis
description: MONTE CARLO, April 13 (AP)Lew Hoad, the Austra lian now living in Spain, de feated Bob Howe of Australia, 62, 86, in the forst round of the Monaco open tennis tourna ment today. Marty Mulligan of Italy eliminated JeanClaude Barclay of France, 62, 64.

title: Gateway Still Just an Idea
description: Almost a year after Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel announced the immediate start of planning on the Gate way National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor, the project remains little more than a sand castle.

title: Patterson and Hawks Named to Banking Board
description: ALBANY, April 13 (AP) Ellmore C. Patterson of Bed ford Village and Thomas H. Hawks of Rochester were named today by Governor Rockefeller to the State Bank ing Board for terms expiring March 1, 1973. They will suc ceed Gabriel Hauge of New York and Albert F. Martin of Schenectady.

title: Coeds Find Life at Yale Falls Short of Expectations
description: NEW HAVENOn a crisp clear day several weeks ago, about 40 coeds at Yale Uni versity barged into a quiet Alumni Day luncheon to com plain about their life on the predominantly male campus.

title: Heart Recipient Dies
description: RICHMOND, April 13 (AP) Willard M. Shepard, a former Navy pilot from Norfolk, died today at the Medical College, of Virginia following acute re jection of the heart he re ceived in a transplant operation here Feb. 10, college officials said.

title: Post for von Braun's Brother
description: BONN, April 13 (AP)Sigis mtnd von Braun, West Ger many's Ambassador to Paris and the brother or Wernher von Braun, the American rock et expert, will become a state secretary in the Foreign Minis try in Bonn, the ministry an nounced today. State secretary is West Germany's highest civil service rank.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: Wheat future price dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of the United States Department of Agriculture's increased esti mate of the winter wheat pro duction, made public on Friday.

title: Woody, Used to Punchers, Sees Chance for Upsetting Foreman
description: James J. Woody drummed his fingers on the tablecloth and said: I feel my calling card has come. I think I can pull this deal off.

title: Hall and Susie Atwood Expected To Head U.S. Swimming Team
description: CINCINNATI, April 13 (AP) Mark down Gary Hall and Susie Atwood as two of the eight choices for an American swim ming squad that will tour Eu rope this summer.

title: POWER FAILURE IMPERILS ASTRONAUTS; APOLLO WILL HEAD SACK TO THE EARTH
description: HOUSTON, Tuesday, April 14 The Apollo 13 astronauts, their lives threatened by a serious oxygen leak, were forced to evacuate their com mand ship late last night and use their intended moonland ing craft as a lifeboat for a fast return to the earth.

title: RHODESIA TO CUT BLACK EDUCATION
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 13The Rhodesian Government seems determined to press ahead with a plan to reduce spending on primary education for black Africans, a move that will probably force the closing of most Christian missionary schools.

title: Bringing the Bride Up to Date
description: THE girls swung down the aisle to music by Glenn Miller. It wasn't the Rolling Stones, but it wasn't Lohengrin either.

title: Carmichael, in Objective View, Sees Hitler as Greatest White
description: Stokely Carmichael said last night that, judging his genius objectively, Adolph Hitler was his nominee for the greatest white man. At the same time Mr. Carmichael asserted that, from a moral viewpoint, what Hitler did was wrong, was evil.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, April 13, 1970

title: Tombs' Guard Indicted
description: A 10count indictment was returned by a New York County grand jury yesterday against William Lindner, a 23yearold Correction Department officer charged with sellinig and pos sessing a dangerous drug. The suspect pleaded not guilty be fore Justice Gerald P. Culkin in the Criminal Division of the State Supreme Court. No date was set for trial. It was charged that Mr. Lindner had offered to sell a quantity of marijuana to a prisoner in the men's House of Detention in Manhattan.

title: Chiefs Report Record Sale
description: KANSAS CITY, April 13 (UPI)The Kansas City Chiefs, who once had a hard time fill ing old Municipal Stadium to half of its 49,002 capacity, an nounced today a professional sports seasonticket sales rec ord of 60,469 for the 1971 season. The Chiefs will move into their new 75,000seat sta dium at the Harry S. Truman sports complex after the 1970 season.

title: MISSISSIPPI UNIT DROPPED BY N.E.A.
description: ATLANTA, April 13  The National Education Association expelled its predominantly white Mississippi affiliate to day because, it said, the state group refused to merge with a black teachers organization.

title: Princeton Girls Share in Woes
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Yale's coeds are not alone in their complaints. The 167 women at Princeton University have been outnumbered by men 20 to 1, somewhat socially isolated and on the psycho logical defensive since they arrived last September as the first women undergraduates in the university's 223year history.

title: Composer, Rebel, Communist
description: HE is Greece's most roman tic revolutionary. Adored and despised, unpredictable and provocative, Mikis Theo dorakis, the composer re leased from prison in Greece yesterday, has become for many Greeks a popular cham pion, the idol of nonconform ist youth. His very musicloosely called bou zouki, a blend of Byzantine themes, the rough cafe tunes of the work men and the gen tler songs of the islands sings with the majesty of hu man perfectibility. And much of the work that has made him famous in this country, the songs from Zorba the Greek and the music for the Oscarwinning film Zadd to the illusion of the revolu tionary, not only because of their fiber but because they were smuggled out of Greece as one smuggles out any rev olutionary document.

title: Theater: The Drunkard
Screen: Man Who Lies Begins Run
MAURICE J. SHANNON
description: JERSEY CITY, April 13 Maurice J. (Red) Shannon, a former major league infielder, died yesterday at St. Francis Comunity Health Center here. He was 73 years old and lived at 46 Van Houten Avenue.

title: Fire in Nile Village Kills 22
description: CAIRO, April 13 (UPI)  A fire in the Nile delta village of Badr Halawa 90 miles north of Cairo destroyed 180 houses and killed 22 persons, the Mid dle East News Agency reported today. Fiftythree persons were reported injured.

title: Kennedy Hurt by Emphasis
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, waving his left hand to stress point, cut it on a glass ship model case in his office today, requiring three stitches. The point he was making: the Sen ate's role as the final judge of Supreme Court nominees.

title: CAMBODIA RUSHES TROOPS TO PROVINCE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 13 (UPI)The Cambodian Army rushed reinforcements toward the capital of Svayieng Prov ince, 70 miles southeast of Pnem penh, where reports said a major assault by Vietnamesel. Communists appeared inevita ble.

title: Legislature Votes That Credit Cards Must Be Requested
description: ALBANY, April 13The State Senate voted final leg islative approval today of a bill that would prohibit the mailing of credit cards to the public unless they were re quested specifically in writ ing.

title: LaRoche Persuades Its Stockholders of Its Progress
description: The setting was just per fect for a dignified meeting. The room in the Morgan Guaranty branch at 299 Park Avenue was small, intimate, its walls a warm yellow, its carpeting, a restful green. The 61 folding chairs never did fill up, but the half that did contained bodies that main tained the dignity of the set ting.

title: Kirk Orders Guard To Duty to Prevent Palm Beach Unrest
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 13 (AP)Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. ordered National Guard units to active duty tonight to deal with possible labor strife in Palm Beach County.

title: Air Traffic Protest Appears Near End
description: The 20dayold sickcall slow down of Federal air traffic controllers appeared to be col lapsing last night.

title: SCHOOL PLAN SET FOR MANHATTAN
description: The Board of Education yes terday adopted a school dis tricting plan for Manhattan the same plan it had tentatively proposed earlier this month.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Three Nations' Scholars End Meeting on Judaism in 1970
description: Scholars from this country, Canada and Israel ended threeday discussion yesterday of themes relating to contem porary Jewry.

title: Financing Agreement Set
description: An agreement in principle has been reached under which Electronic Memories and Mag netics Corporation is to provide additional capital for Sycor, Inc., it was announced yester day. The financing would be in the form of a private placement of convertible notes and war rants in which the initial com mitment would be $4million, convertible into one million shares of Sycor common stock. The new commitment replaces EMM's previously announced interim loan obligation of $1, 905,000.

title: Attles, Warrior Coach, Signs MultiYear Pact
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP)  The San Francisco Warriors rehired Coach Al Attles today, giving him what was termed a multi year contract.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev Talk on Economic Issues
description: LONDON, April 13 Fol lowing are excerpts from a televised speech tonight by the Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, as monitored and translated from the Russian by the Brit ish Broadcasting Corporation.

title: AGNEW URGES AID FOR BEST STUDENTS
description: DES MOINES, Iawo, April 13 Vice President Agnew said tonight that the best students in the United States constitued a natural aristocracy that, should be given special aca demic treatment.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN REPORTS INCREASE
description: Three of the nation's top dozen banking organizations re ported net income for the first quarter yesterday. The results were mixed: two companies were up, one was down; profit margins were under severe pressure at all three from ris ing interest rates, but a larger volume of business enabled two of the three to show an im proved rate of return on their stockholders' investment.

title: NEW PLAN IS GIVEN ON 3D AVE. HOUSING
description: The City Planning Commis sion formally revived a con troversial proposal yesterday to rezone parts of lower Third Avenue for luxury housing, but it added a requirement that developers either reserve 15 per cent of their new apart ments for lowincome families now living in the area or con tribute to a fund to build pub lic housing nearby.

title: Syracuse Dean Appointed
description: SYRACUSE, April 13John James Prucha has been ap pointed dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Syracuse Uni versity, effective Sept. 1, Chan cellor John E. Corbally Jr. announced today. He is now chairman of the college's geol ogy department. A student faculty committee recommended the appointment of the 45year old professor, wh owill succeed Dr. Frederic J. Kramer. The latter will resume the teaching of German.

title: Divorce Ages Found
description: LONDON (AP)The danger ous age for divorce in England and Wales is 2529 years for women and 3034 years for men, the Registrar General said in a summary.

title: Promenades Lose Namath
description: Joe Namath has had to post pone his scheduled appearance at the forthcoming New York Philharmonic Promenades be cause of changes in his film commitments. Instead, the foot ball star will appear next sea son in the work being written for him by Dick Schaap and composed by Dick Hyman, in a Philharmonic concert to be led by Andre Kostelanetz. His place in the Promenades will be taken by Cyril Ritchard, who will narrate Prokofiev's Peter and the Wolf on May 29, 30 and June 2.

title: Protest at Boston College
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 13 (AP)  Several thousands stu dents picketed Boston College and boycotted classes today to protest a proposed $500 tuition increase for next year's fresh men

title: Columbia Cites Casals for His Music and Morality
description: Pablo Casals was honored by Columbia University yesterday for the joy and peace his music and moral stands against injustice have given humanity.

title: Merriman Smith Is Dead at 57, an Apparent Suicide
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Metriman Smith, the chief White House correspondent for United Press International, was found dead this evening at his home. He apparently had shot himself in the head.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Choices for Court

title: 2 AIDES SAY G.M. CUTS POLLUTION
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13 Two eexcutives of the Gen eral Motors Corporation de fended the company's efforts in safety and pollution control at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today as a na tional campaign to make Gen eral Motors responsible be gan to gather momentum on college campuses.

title: Activity Reported for Port
OHIO GOVERNOR BANS FISHING IN LAKE ERIE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 Ohio's fishing industry tem porarily shut down today in response to Gov. James A. Rhodes's formal proclamation banning the commerical taking and selling of all fish from the Ohio waters of Lake Erie.

title: 91 and 182Day Bill Rates Off At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels and touched the lowest levels since March 23, the Government reported last this afternoon.

title: 9 Women Arrested In 5Hour Sitin At Grove Press
description: Nine members of the wom en's liberation movement were arrested yesterday after they invaded the offices of Grove Press, a pioneer publisher of erotic literature.

title: Black Titan Due Here
description: The Group of Ancient Drama will present Black Titan, based on Prometheus Bound, in the main auditorium of the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, on April 21, 22 and 23 at 8:15 P.M. Paul Nord has adapted the Aeschy lus drama, which is being staged by Aliki

title: LINDSAY PROPOSES REALTY TAX RISE AND HIGHER FEES
description: Mayor Lindsay proposed an unspecified increase in real property taxes and city fees last night in a televised Mes sage to the People on the fis cal plight of the city.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, April 14, 1970

title: A.B.A. Rockets Add Signing
description: DENVER, April 13 (AP)Bob St. Pierre of Hanover (Ind.) Col lege signed an Ameircan Basket ball Association Rockets today. St. Pierre was the Rockets' fourthround draft choice and the No. 3 selection of the De troit Pistons of the National Basketball Association.

title: ITALY ARRESTS ENVOY IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: ROME, April 13 (AP)  The Italian police said today that they had arrested the Pakis tani ambassador to Tunisia to day and that they suspected him of being the big gun in the illegal traffic in hashish in Italy. The police arrested a German movie actress and her Italian friend in the same case.

title: Fiedler Is Named Winner Of Guggenheim Fellowship
description: BUFFALO, April 13 (AP)  Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the liter ary critic who was convicted last week of a narcotics viola tion, was named today as a winner of a John Simon Gugg heim Mmorial Foundation Fel lowship.

title: Swigert Can Delay Tax Filing
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) John L. Swigert Jr. can relax the Internal Revenue Service says he has to more months in which to file his income tax re turn. The bachelor astronaut remembered yesterday that in the lastminute rush to get ready for his unexpected trip to the moon he had let the April 15 deadline for tax returns slip his mind. The ground communi cators told him about a tax reg ulation that provides an auto matic extension for anyone out of the country.

title: Alice J. Myers, Paul D. Guyer Plan to Marry
description: BALTIMORE, April 13 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dudley Myers have announced that their daughter, Miss Alice Jackson Myers, and Paul David Guyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Henry Guyer of Lynbrook, L. I., will be mar ried in June.

title: In Memoriam
description: BEAVERSCharles T. Attorney. Beloved bus band, left us April 14, 1969. Gone but not forgotten.

title: U.S TROOPS PUSH NEAR CAMBODIA
description: FIRE BASE ROHR, South Vietnam, April 12  American combat troops pushed within about 500 yards of the Cam bodian border today in this densely jungled northwestern corner of Tayninh Province.

title: QUAKES IN JERSEY LINKED TO FAULT
description: A series of minor earth quakes that gently nudged resi dents of Jefferson Township, N.J., last summer and fall has been attributed to movement along a fault under Lake Hopat cong, 35 miles northwest of New York City.

title: Container Terminal Planned in Jersey By a New Company
description: The formation of a new con tainer terminal organization with pier facilities on the Jer sey side of Upper New York Bay was announced here yes terday.

title: Museum's Ball Draws Arty Pickets Too
description: It was black tie inside and out at the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art last night. As the 3.000 formally clad guests prepared to ascend the gran ite stairway into the build ing for a Centennial Ball, a smaller group, many of them also in black tie, picketed along Fifth Avenue in what they termed a quiet, non action, dignified demonstra tion.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, April 13, 1970

title: Nostalgia Helps Guide Art Choice at Metropolitan's 19thCentury America
description: Anniversaries inevitably prompt nostalgia. This being the case, it was hardly ex pected that the Metropolitan Museum of Artnow in the midst of its massive centen nial celebrationswould re sist the temptation to suc cumb to this most soporific of all sentiments. In the event, alas, it hasn't.

title: Pulp Mill Planned In Saskatchewan; Cost Is 120Million
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, April 13 (Canadian Press)  Parsons & Whittemore, Inc., of New York and the Saskatchewan government today announced plans for a new $120million pulp mill and a $6.5million saw mill at two sites in the province's remote northwest.

title: 40 Blacks Damage Store In Ithaca College Protest
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 13 (UPI)  Forty black students rampaged through a bookstore on the Ithaca College campus here today, apparently to pro test a lack of increased funds for a program to aid disad vantaged ??

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS N.Y.U. NINE BY 74
description: It took three pitchers to get the job done, but St. John's finally moved one game above 500 yesterday by defeating New York University, 74, on the loser's diamond.

title: MRS. F. A. KORSMEYER
description: Mrs. L'avinia Bray Kors meyer, widow of the longtime editorial writer of The Wall Street Journal, died at Subur ban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., yesterday of a heart attack, after an operation. She was 90 years old. Her husband, Fred erich A. Korsmeyer, retired from The Journal in 1956, after working there for 45 years. He died in 1961.

title: Drive Against Vietnamese At High Pitch in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 13An officially inspired cam paign of hatred against Viet namese has reached fever pitch throughout Cambodia. It has re sulted in detentions, in disap pearances and, in at least one known case, in mass killings that witnesses attributed to Cambodian soldiers.

title: The Blair House in Washington Where Democrats Still Reign
description: WASHINGTONThe Demo crats may be in social limbo here now, but you'd never know it judging from the entertaining done by Mrs. William McCormick Blair Jr., whose husband worked for Adlai E. Stevenson, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. John son.

title: Censorship by Abduction
description: When the new Cambodian leaders sought to dem onstrate the extent of Communist Vietnamese penetration of their country last week by encouraging foreign newsmen to visit border areas, the Commu nists retaliated by seizing eight journalists, including two Americans.

title: Council Panel Votes to Expand Full Body's Seats From 37 to 48
description: A plan to create 11 new dis tricts to permit more represen tation for blacks and Puerto Ricans in the City Council was overwhelmingly approved by the Council's Committee on State Legislation yesterday.

title: Handley Page Apparently Faces Closure Despite Rescue Efforts
description: LONDON, April 13Hand ley Page, Ltd., Britain's oldest aircraft company, appears to be going out of business de spite the rescue attempts of various Americans, including Howard Hughes and Robert Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration.

title: SWISS PLAN TO SHOW AFROAMERICAN ART
description: An exhibition by AfroAmer ican artists will be held next year in the Rath Museum in Geneva, Henri Ghent, director of the Community Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum, an nounced yesterday.

title: U. S. Says Soviet Nuclear Sub Apparently Sank in the Atlantic
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Pentagon reported signs today that a Soviet nuclear submarine had sunk in rough waters of the Atlantic. The site was between 400 and 600 miles northwest of Spain.

title: CITY U. UNITS GET MORE AUTONOMY
description: The Board of Higher Edu cation amended its bylaws last night to permit the faculty and student body of each college in the City University system to share in establishing regula tions and rules of conduct.

title: Goldberg for 2Term Limit
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Arthur   J. Goldberg today advocated a twoterm limit for Governors of New York.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 1970

title: Scientist Says Timidness Limits Technical Progress in Medicine
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 Timidness of both manufactur ers and physicians due to legal and economic restraints is limit ing technical progress in medi cine Dr. Robert F. Rushmer, a leading biomedical engineering researcher, said today.

title: ROCK FESTIVAL SET UPSTATE FOR JUNE
description: Plans for a threeday, $1 million rock festival to be held in Northern New York State June 26 through 28 were an nounced here yesterday by a group of theatrical and rock promoters.

title: ROCKET ATTACKS KILL 2 IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tues day, April 14 (AP)Four enemy rockets plunged into the heart of Saigon just before last mid night, missing by just a few blocks the United States Em bassy and the official residence of President Nguyen Van Thieu. One of the 100pound rockets crashed through the roof of a theater where a play was under way.

title: CITY ENTERS TALKS ON LANDLORDS' PACT
description: Mayor Lindsay stepped into the negotiations between land lords and building service em ployes yesterday by assigning his Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, Benja min Altman, to sit in on the bargaining sessions.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an inadvertent transposition of figures, an article that appeared in The New York Times on March 21 erroneously reported the gross income of the Port of New York Authority for 1968 as $1082million. The correct amount was $102.8million. Net income, after debt service, was reported as $54million. The amount should have been re ported as $48.4million.

title: Bolivian Institute Attacked
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 13 (AP)Students today stormed the Bolivian Institute of Studies and Social Action, accusing it of carrying out espionage for Gulf Oil Corporation, the Cen tral Intelligence Agency and other United States organiza tions. The institute carries out studies for Bolivia's develop ment.

title: CHILD LABOR FAILS IN A COMEBACK BID
description: ALBANY, April 13In its rush to end its annual session this week, the Assembly nearly passed a bill last night that op ponents said would have rein stituted child labor in New York State.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Other Television News and Transportation News on Page 93.

title: 8 Die in Sinking off Sicily
description: MESSINA, Sicily, April 13 (AP)A 500ton Italian freight er, the Duizar, sank off Sicily today after her cargo shifted in the hold. Only one of the nine crewmen was saved.

title: Dartmouth Promotes Coach
description: HANOVER, N.H., April 13 (AP)Grant Standbrook, who compiled a 4817 wonlost rec ord as freshman hockey coach at Dartmouth College during the last three seasons, was named the school's varsity coach today. He succeeds Ab Oakes, who resigned.

title: Governor to Name 2 in G.O.P. to Port Authority
description: ALBANY, April 13  Gover nor Rockefeller plans to name two prominent Republicans within the next few days to fill vacancies on the Port of New York Authority's 12member board of commissioners.

title: European Lines' Overbooking Scored
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 13A Council of Europe re port made public here today criticized what it called the generalization and exaggeration of the practice of overbooking in European air transport.

title: U.S. Children Called Neglected
description: While we talk a great deal about being a childoriented society, we're markedly and dangerously neglectful of chil dren, according to Urie Bron fenbrenner, professor of psy chology and child development at Cornell University.

title: CHICAGO TEAMSTERS STRIKE OVER WAGES
description: Teamsters in Chicago began an allout strike yesterday against trucking companies to press their demands for a wage settlement 55 cents an hour migher than a tentative nation al agreement, The Associated Press reported.

title: Court Plan Begins Today
description: BRADENTON, Fla., April 13 The Manatee County school superintendent, Jack L. David son, was restored to office to day and predicted that a court ordered racial integration plan would be put into effect tomor row morning without any vio lence.

title: Koppers Obtains Contract
description: PITTSBURGH, April 13 (UPI) The Koppers Company ob tained a contract to bulid 24 electrostatic precipitators for four American Electric Power System generating plants. Such precipitators usually cost about $1million each.

title: Televised BoutofMonth Starts at Garden on May 11
description: Madison Square Garden will present a fightofthemonth program on network television starting May 11 with a middle weight match between Donato Paduano of Montreal and Mar cel Cerdan Jr. of France.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Discuss AntiSemitism With Soviet
description: An American Jewish leader appealed to the State Depart ment yesterday to raise the issue of antiSemitism in the Soviet Union with the Soviet Foreign Ministry.

title: Emergency in Space
description: With dramatic swiftness last night, a major emer gency befell the astronauts of Apollo 13. The electrical system difficulties and the loss of oxygen created the most serious situation ever experienced in any Ameri can space flight to date. The original plans for this expedition had to be abandoned and, instead, there was improvised an unprecedented set of measures aimed at saving the lives of the astronauts and re turning them safely to earth.

title: MARGARET BEALS IN DANCE PROGRAM
description: The Cubiculo presented An Evening With Margaret Beals last night, an attempt to inte grate, music, poetry and dance with a few musical interludes offered on their own.

title: TODAY'S CONTEST ALSO CALLED OFF
description: While the Mets finished mak ing plans to raise the world championship flag at Shea Sta dium today, the Minnesota Twins waved a flag of their own yesterdaya flag of sur render.

title: A.B.A. TO OPERATE MIAMI FRANCHISE
description: The Miami Floridians were taken over by the American Basketball Assocation yester day.

title: Veteran Modifies Allegation About 33 Killed in Vietnam
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 13 (AP)  A 22yearold Vietnam War veteran has issued a print ed statement modifying his story that 33 Vietnamese men, women and children were killed in a 1967 action in South Viet nam.

title: M'DONNELL & CO. CHARGED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission nailed the door shut on McDonnell & Co. yester day, exactly one month after the oldline brokerrage firm an nounced the gradual liquida tion of its business.

title: Miss Joanne Kerbs To Be a June Bride
description: RUMSON, N. J., April 13 Miss Joanne Elise Kerbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kerbs, plans to be married here June 13 to Kyle Christopher Mudd, whose father, Robert Clayton Mudd, is United States political counselor in Belgrade, Yugo slavia.

title: Academic Double Jeopardy
description: The campus disorder bill passed last Friday by a shameful vote of 95 to 43 in the New York State Assembly is a patently vindictive measure that rides roughshod over individual rights. It is a legislative absurdity that does no credit to those who created and passed the bill.

title: War Foe Bill in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 13 (AP) A bill similar to a Massachu setts law allowing servicemen to refuse to fight in Vietnam was introduced today in the New Jersey Legislature. The bill is sponsored by Assembly man George C. Richardson, Essex County Democrat. Mr. Richardson, a Negro, is the assistant Assembly minority leader and a candidate for Mayor of Newark.

title: J. Frank Johnson, ExHead Of City's Bridge Division
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., April 13 J. Frank Johnson, former di rector of the division of bridges of the New York City Depart ment of Public Works, died yes terday of heart disease at the Valley Nursing Home. He was 87 years old, and lived in Brooklin, Me.

title: Helena Rubinstein Plans Acquisition
description: Helena Rubinstein, Inc., man ufacturer of cosmetics and toiletries, announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire 80 per cent of the stock of Parfums Rochas, S.A., a leading French perfume house, and 100 per cent of other related companies of Rochas situated throughout the world, for more than $37million.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Tit Defense Department today listed the names of the follow ing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Franz Schoenberner, 77, Dies; Magazine Editor Fought Nazis
description: Franz Schoenberner, an au thor who was the last pre Nazi editor of Simplicissimus, the German satirical magazine, died Saturday at the Teaneck (N. J.) Nursing Home. He was 77 years old and lived until recently at 82 Irving Place.

title: A.B.A. Head Urges Prior Consultation On Court Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Bernard G. Segal, president of the American Bar Association, said today that the public in terest would be served if Presi dent Nixon would consult with, the association on potential nominees to the Supreme Court before nominating them.

title: MILLS ADVOCATES 2 IMPORT QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee introduced today an omnibus trade bill that would sharply limit imports of textiles and shoes under a new quota system.

title: Master Hand Is Winner at Aqueduct
description: John Galbreath, the Colum bus, Ohio, business executive with many and varied interests, took time out of a heavy sched ule yesterday to visit Aque duct. And he was glad that he did, too, for he saw his 4year old colt, Master Hand, win the feature race.

title: Housing Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) James Barry, 51 years old, former New Hampshire health and welfare commissioner, has been named New England re gional director for the Federal Housing and Urban Develop ment agency. Mr. Barry caused controversy when he ruled that mothers receiving aid to de pendent children had to register for work and when he accused the Federal Govxernment of promoting policies which he said fostered immorality and il legitimate births through aid to dependent children.

title: CORPORATE FUNDS FELL IN QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters)Net working capital of United States corporations fell $400million to $214.2bil lion in the final 1969 quarter, following a $1.7billion drop the previous quarter, the Secu rities and Exchange Commis sion reported today.

title: Tustice Department, Chiding Kirk for Disobeying Judge, Opposes Removal of Case to Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Justice department chided Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Flor ida today for disobeying a Fed eral district judge's order for the desegregation of the public schools in Manatee County.

title: Francine Onorati Is Engaged To W. E. Crawford, Yale '70
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 13Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Onorati have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Francine Paula Onorati, to William Edwin Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Crawford of Chicago and Pittsburgh.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CROCUSES, robins, cattail shoots moving up out of their slim green fuses, mounds of earth on the lawn brought up by worms on warm, wet evenings, are all signs that summer is near. Fishermen and those who attend to their desires are also awakening.

title: MANHATTAN OUT OF IONA RELAYS
description: Should college freshmen be allowed to compete in varsity track and field programs?

title: Land Exchange Authorized
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)] President Nixon signed a bill today authorizing the Public Health Service to exchange land in New Orleans with Tulane University. The bill would per mit the agency to give the uni versity land where an old hos pital is located in exchange for a new site near Tulane, where a new public health center is planned.

title: Yoder Rolls a Perfect Game And Leads A.B.C. Tourney
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 13 (AP)  Jake Yoder of Fort Wayne, Ind., rolled 12 straight striked for a perfect 300 game today and took the regular singles lead in the 67th Ameri Han Bowling Congress torna ment.

title: CRIMES IN FEBRUARY 4.8% OVER '69 LEVEL
description: Crimes reported to the police increased 4.8 per cent in Feb ruary as compared with the same month last year, the Po lice Department said yesterday.

title: Lasker Is Renominated To Head Exchange Board
description: Bernard J. Lasker was re nominated yesterday for an other oneyear term as chair man of the board of governors of the New York Stock Ex change. He is senior partner in Lasker, Stone & Stern. Ralph D. Denunzio of Kidder, Peabody & Co. was renominated for vice chairman.

title: Humphrey Backs Blackmun
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters)Former Vice Presi dent Hubert H. Humphrey gave his backing today to Judge Harry A. Blackmun, reported likely to be President Nixon's next nominee for the Supreme Court.

title: Hijacked Munitions Ship Arrives in the Philippines
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, April 13 (UPI)The United States munitions ship Columbia Eagle, hijacked March 16 and held in Cambodia until last Wednesday, arrived here today.

title: CURB ON RUTGERS PASSED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, April 13Goaded by simmering resentment over art openenrollment program primarily for blackstudents at Rutgers, the State University, the Republican majority in the State Senate gave final legis lative approval today to a measure giving the state tight euntrol over Rutgers's fiscal af fairs.

title: Seton Hall Tops Manhattan in Conference Test, 3 to 2
description: Jack Donovan, a Seton Hall righthander, won a pitching duel with Jimmy Murphy of Pirates defeated the Jaspers, 32, in a Metropolitan Confer ence contest in the rain at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: SENATE APPROVES TV CAMPAIGN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Over Republican opposition, the Senate approved today cam paign reform legislation de signed to limit and perhaps re duce the mounting spending on political broadcasts over tele vision and radio.

title: Season of Seeds and Tools Filling Hardware Stores
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  Mornin'.

title: Land Exchange Authorized
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) President Nixon signed a bill Monday authorizing the Public Health Service to exchange land in New Orleans with Tulane University. The bill would per mit the agency to give the uni versity land where an old hos pital is located in exchange for a new site near Tulane, where a new public health center is planned.

title: Hollywood Paper Sold
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 14 (AP) Sale of controlling interest in The CitizenNews and 16 associated Los Angeles area publications to an investment group headed by C. E. Williams was announced today. Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., chairman, and Mr. Williams, president of the Graphic Production Cor poration, announced sale of the daily newspaper.

title: High Court Nominee
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., April 14At 7:15 every week day morning, Judge Harry Andrew Blackmun leaves his big modern redwood and glass home on a hill over looking this quiet city and drives to his downtown of fice in a pale blue Volks wagen. He returns at 6:15 in the evening. The routine is varied somewhat on weekends. On Saturdays he goes to the office in the Rochester Towers apart ment house, across from the Olmsted County Court House at 8 A.M. and comes home at 3. He is at the office shortly after 8 A.M. on Sundays, put ting in some research before services at the First Metho dist Church of Rochester. He returns to the office after church and usually gets home about 1:30 in the afternoon.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev Speech on Arms Talks and Other Foreign Policy Issues
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on international af fairs by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, as distributed in Eng Iish here by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

title: Albany Votes Final Approval for Agency to Provide $750Million to Encourage Building of New Homes
description: ALBANY, April 14  Thel State Assembly voted final legislative approval today for the creation of a $750million state mortgage agence to re vive the sagging homebuilding industry.

title: Books of The Times
description: FIRST, let's get rid of the transsexual mash notes. According to Letty Cot tin Pogrebin (an unabashed man fan) most men are emotionally honest and uncomplicated ... professionally real istic and straightforward ... not devious or malicious in their personal relations... usually dependable confidants, lavish with praise, fairmind ed end seven anti a half times out of ten they have fascinating intel lects, interests or opinions. Accord ing to me, with out women the world wouldn't be worth living in; seven times out of ten, working wom en make better wives and mothers than the girl who settles for a tor nado in her kitch en; and ten times out of ten, work ing women are more interesting than any other anybody. So much for the castrating feminist and all those hairy oafs who, never having graduated from the Cub Scouts, want for companionship a combination of Den Motherhood and Tupperwariness.

title: A RICHER HEROIN BEING SOLD HERE
description: Heroin addicts in New York City are apparently getting more for their money. These days.

title: Quota Proposals Dismay Importers Here
description: Moves in Congress to limit imports of textiles and shoes were viewed yesterday as lead ing to wideranging reper cussions affecting both consum er interest and the nation's worldtrading txmition.

title: Keystone Aaron Gets No. 7 Post For Rich Sullivan Pacing Final
JOB SAFETY BILL SPLITS HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The House Education and Labo Committee divided on party lines today as the Democrats defeated, 20 to 14, a Republi canproposed substitute for an occupational safety bill.

title: TransAmerican Auto Racing To Begin on Coast on Weekend
description: WELL, we're ready now to go racing. After digging out from under mountains of computer printouts and other paperwork and enduring the vicissitudes of the truckers' strikes, the Sports Car Club of America and the Automo bile Competition Committee for the United States have come up with an eligibility  status report for the Trans  Ameri can champion ship, which be gins this weekend at Laguna Seca Raceway, Monterey, Calif. The two organizations announced yesterday the pro duction requirement for the Mark Donohue model of the Javelin had been met. They also granted recognition to five other sedans subject to verification of the final pro duction quantities. Those cars are the Chevrolet Camaro with a Z28 engine, the Ply mouth Barracuda, the Dodge Challenger TA, the Ford Mustang Boss 302 and the basic Pontiac Firebird.

title: Prudential Shifts Major Executives
description: The Prudential Insurance Com pany announced yesterday a major executive reorganiza tion.

title: Rescue Plans Worked Out for 3 Oceans
description: Before Apollo 13 even neared the lunar vicinity last night, defense officials responsible for recovering the astronauts after splashdown had worked out extensive plans for possible rescue operations in three oceansthe midPacific, the midAtlantic and the Indian.

title: Burger and Blackmun: Opinions Similar
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 President Nixon's third choice for Associate Justice of the Su preme Court was undoubtedly Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger's first choice. Judge Harry A. Blackmun, whose nomination to the Supreme Court was an nounced today, is an and close friend of the Chief Justice's and was known to have Mr. Burger's strong support for the position. The two men have so much in common by back ground and judicial philosophy that it seems logical that if the new nominee is confirmed by the Senate, they will often see things the same way on the Supreme Court.

title: Theater:
description: VODODEOHDO!! With many shrill giggles of seeming despair, that arche typal pastiche musical, The Boy Friend, returned to Broadway last night at the Ambassador Theater. With a gentility so strained that it is all but ruptured, this Sandy Wilson imitation of a 1920's musical comedy takes demureness to new depths and cuteness to fresh camps. Vododeohdo!!

title: Marquess of Milford Haven Dies; Queen's Cousin and Naval Hero
description: LONDON, April 14 (AP)Da vid Michael Mountbatten, Mar quess of Milford Haven, died today after collapsing at Lon don's Liverpool Street railway terminal. He was 50 years old.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: 5050 GOVERNING AT HUNTER SCORED
description: A group of faculty members at Hunter College issued a state ment yesterday opposing a pro posal for equal studentfaculty representation on governing bodies. The plan was approved Saturday by a committee nego tiating a new plan for govern ing the school.

title: Environmental Politics
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 14 (AP)Senator Gaylord Nelson, prime mover of the Earth Day teaching April 22, called today for a national political move ment to elect environment minded legislators to the House and Senate.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Threat of MIRV

title: Excerpts From Opinions of Judge Blackmun, Written While He Served on the U.S. Court of Appeals
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Following are excerpts from significant opinions of Judge Harry A. Blackmun, nomi nated today to the Supreme Court. The opinions were written during Judge Black mun's tenure in the United State Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, where he has served since 1959:

title: Elusive Budget Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Notes from the Poor Econo mist's Almanac:

title: Getting Message Across in Italian Modern Idiom
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S furni ture department has cer tainly made up for the time it took to make the plunge into Italian modern. And the wait gave Barbara D'Arcy, decorator of the store's mod ern rooms, a chance to learn how to translate the colorful, curvaceous and voluptuous style into set tings that look more American than European. Miss D'Arcy not only touches all bases of the modern Italian idiom in the eight rooms that go on view today on the store's fifth floor, but she in cludes in the settings many designs that are so new they are just now being introduced at the wholesale furniture showings in North Carolina, this week.

title: Young Presidents' Chief
description: M. A. Self, president of the Bee Chemical Company, Lans ing, Ill., has been elected presi dent of the Young Presidents' Organization, Inc.

title: State Appellate Division Gets Presiding Justice
description: ALBANY, April 14 (AP) Governor Rockefeller elevat ed Marcus G. Christ today from acting presiding justice to presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Judi cial Department.

title: JURY IS IN RECESS AT TRIAL OF JUDGE
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 14 After two days of deliberation, the jury in the trial of Union County District Court Judge Ralph DeVita on charges of bribery and obstructing justice failed to reach a verdict tonight.

title: DR. NORMAN HASKELL, RESEARCH SCIENTIST
description: HYANNIS, Mass., April 14 Dr. Norman A. Haskell, a former Air Force research scien tist, died at Cape Cod Hospital here Saturday after a long ill ness. He was 64 years old and lived in Cummaquid.

title: ABORTION GUIDELINES URGED IN MARYLAND
description: BALTIMORE, April 14 The Medical and Chirurgical Facul ty, Maryland's equivalent of a medical society, is preparing to establish guidelines that would restrict legal abortions to the first 20 weeks of a woman's pregnancy.

title: Bomb Plot Figure Pleads
description: Samuel J. Melville, the 34 yearold alleged leader of a conspiracy to bomb public buildings here last fall, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to a 19count indictment. His codefendants, John D. Hughey 3d, Jane L. Alpert and Jonathan B. Grell, pleaded not guilty last week. Two defense lawyers, William E. Crain and Frederick H. Cohn, unsuccessfully asked Judge Milton Pollack for a delay in the trial, scheduled for April 29, because their offices and case files were heavily damaged in a fire on Union Square on Sunday.

title: Happy April 15!
description: Together with the viewing of the first robin, the northward migration of the baseball clubs, and Cherry Blossom Week in Washington, there is an annual American spring rite known as income tax day. It is customary to celebrate the day with hearty jokes and pitiful moans.

title: John Paul Jones ReEnlists
description: PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii (AP)John Paul Jones reen listed in the United States Navy. Unlike the Revolution ary War naval hero, Mr. Jones, 22 years old, of Temperance, Mich., works with computers in the Fleet Control Center here.

title: MEDICARE FOR ALL IS ASKED BY JAVITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Senator Jacob K. Javits pro posed today a national health insurance program that would extend Medicare benefits to people of all ages by 1973.

title: Papers Offer 24.79% Increase But Printers Call It Insufficient
description: The Publishers Association of New York City improved their wage offer to the printers of the city's newspapers early to day, but the printers, represent ed by Typographical Union No. 6, said the offer was insuf ficient.

title: DR. GEORGE CROUCH, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
