description: PITTSBURGH, April 14  Dr. W. George Crouch, a Uni versity of Pittsburgh professor of English, died yesterday in Presbyterian  University Hos pital. He was 67 years old. He had been ill since December.

title: All Clear on the Runways
description: Judicial pressure, intelligently applied, has finally brought an end in most major cities to the illegal sick strike by a minority of Federal air controllers. Their miraculous return to health came after Federal district judges in New York and other centers ordered the absentees to go back to the radar screens or prove to a medical panel that they were really ill.

title: RETAIL CHAIN'S NET IS OFF IN QUARTER
It's Not Often One Has in His Kitchen a French Master Chef
description: THE Guide Michelin, su preme arbiter of French eating, describes a twostar meal as worth a detour and a threestar mealthe su preme levelas well worth the journey.

title: Brooklyn Museum To Benefit at Ball
description: The educational programs of the Brooklyn Museum will benefit from the Art Deco Ball, to be held in the audi torium court at the museum on Saturday. The event, sponsored by the museum's community committee, will include a campagne recep tion, a buffet suppper, danc ing and a preview of two installationsthe 20th cen tury period rooms and cos tume galleries and an inter national loan exhibition of the art and design of the 1920's and 1930's.

title: Henry St. Settlement to Build Arts Center
description: A $3million ArtsforLiv ing Center designed to serve a multiracial population in a poverty area will be built by the Henry Street Settlement oh the Lower East Side.

title: 5 FAVORITES OUSTED AT MONTE CARLO NET
description: MONTE CARLO, April 14 AP)  Five seeded players bowed out of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today.

title: Boy, 4, Finds Can of TNT
description: Boy, 4, Finds Can of TNT

title: BOSTON WINS, 83, WITH 3 HOME RUNS
description: BOSTON, April 14Baseball returned to the sensual and in timate confines of Fenway Park today and the Yankees were merely the other guys, the visi tors in gray.

title: Palme Sees French Leaders
description: PARIS, April 14 (UPI)  Premier Olof Palme of Sweden began his first official visit to France today with a call on Foreign Minister Maurice Sshu mann. He later lunched with President Pompidou and met with Premier Jacques Chaban Delmas.

title: Columbia in Court To Seek to Punish Six for Vandalism
description: Columbia University started legal action yesterday against six student demonstrators who allegedly committed acts of vandalism on the campus last week following a speech hailing the Black Panthers.

title: Paint May Heat Houses
description: LONDON (AP)Researchers say an electricityconducting paint developed for use on American space vehicles may revolutionize home heating. A wall at a London research cen ter covered with the paint has been giving off heat for most of a year.

title: Shoemaker to Pilot Silent Screen in Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday
description: Willie Shoemaker will fly here from California to ride Silent Screen in Saturday's Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, the colt's trainer disclosed yester day.

title: Ulster Chiefs Fight to Defeat Paisley
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 14Maj. James Chichest erClark, the Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, emerged from behind the shops on the main street of the small rural town to report that he had just made the rounds of the garage. He then proceeded to shake every and in sights.

title: Apollo Craft's Water Shortage Will Limit Astronauts' Use of Guidance System
description: HOUSTON, April 14So low is the Apollo 13 spacecraft on water to cool its electronic equipment that the three astro nauts will have to coast home without their inertial sense of direction.

title: ARMS TEAMS REACH VIENNA FOR PARLEY
description: VIENNA, April 14  United States and Soviet disarmament negotiators arrived here today for the second round of arms limitation talks.

title: U.S. Arrests Russian Skipper In Alaska Gulf for Spilling Oil
description: WASHINGTON, April 14A Coast Guard cutter sent a boarding party aboard a Soviet tanker in the Gulf of Alaska last night and arrested the ship's master on charges of spilling a milelong oil slick near Kodiak Island.

title: Bryan Downey, Who Claimed Boxina Title in 1921, Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (AP)  The death of Bryan Downey, a prizefighter who claimed the world middle weight championship after controversial match with Johnny Wilson in 1921 in Cleveland, was disclosed Tues day. He was 73 years old. Downey died March 28 in Veterans Hospital in West Los Angeles.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Fouryearold Ramon Rodrig res found a metal container on a roof near his home yesterday and took it home. Ramon's mother, Noemi, examined the container in their apartment at 846 Hewitt Avenue, near East 161st Street in the Bronx, and called the police. It contained one pound of TNT. The police evacuated the building until the bomb section removed the con tainer.

title: Protesters Leave Fordham Building After Court Order Is Signed
description: Under the threat of a court order, 350 students peacefully vacated the administration building of Fordham University last night, but they called a student strike for this morning.

title: BIRTH DEFECT CLUE SOUGHT IN FETUSES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 14  A geneticist said today that he and other doctors in Canada were seeking to detect from the tissue of naturally aborted fetuses the cause of some con genital abnormalities, or birth defects.

title: Flag Defiler Sentenced
description: CHRISTIANSBURG, Va., April 14 (AP)An 18yearold Vir ginia Tech freshman, arrested last month for wearing an American flag sewed to the seat of his pants was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $200 here today. Montgomery County Court Judge Kenneth L. Devore imposed the sentence on Christopher Tobiah Cole after finding him guilty of de filing the flag.

title: BILL AGAINST WAR PUSHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 14Liberal Democrats attempted today to give new life in the Legislature to the issue of the war in Vietnam.

title: Stage:
description: IN Terminal the Open Theater has created a country where the living are dead and the dead are cos metologized back into a natural state, which means, unlifelike  rouged, wigged, and the sneer caused by em balming wrenched and sewn into a permanent smile.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE NEAR FINISH LINE
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 14 (AP)American Eagle, Ted Turner's America's Cup boat out of Atlanta, set a struggling pace today in a near cairn and strong adverse currents in the 500mile St. PetersburgtoIsla de Mujeres yacht race.

title: War Foes Jeer New U. S. Envoy As He Enters Palace in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, April 14 (AP) The new United States Am bassador, Jerome H. Holland, said today that he was greeted by shouts of Nigger! Nigger! by Swedish antiwar demonstra tors as he entered the royal pal ace to present his credentials to King Gustaf VI Adolf.

title: PAYMENTS SURPLUS IN JAPAN IS RECORD
description: TOKYO, April 14 (Reuters) Japan today reported a record balanceofpayments surplus for the last year, with hopes of maintaining the trend for an other year.

title: Conversation With Apollo
description: Following are excerpts from conversations between the Apollo 13 astronauts and Mission Control in Houston, as recorded by The New York Times, during a rocket firing maneuver after the space craft rounded the moon:

title: STATE RIGHTS UNIT IS ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: Two employes who had just been dismissed from the State Division of Human Rights took over a public hearing yesterday and charged the agency itself with racism.

title: 3 Blasts Hit Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 14 (UPI)  Three windowshatter ing dynamite blasts hit a racial ly troubled high school, a church and a police academy building early today. There were no injuries and there was little structural damage.

title: Trenches Become Walks
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. (UPI) Trenches dug by Confederate soldiers during the Civil War are now campus walkways at Western Kentucky University here.

title: Wiodzimierz Moderow, 81, Of U.N. Office in Geneva
description: GENEVA, April 14Wlodzi niierz Moderow, first director general of the Geneva office of the United Nations, died today in Geneva Cantonal Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: SAVINGS DEPOSITS UP EXCEPT FOR THE CITY
description: The flow of funds into the nation's mutual savings banks improved during March, except in New York City, the National Associatidn of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: Cosmos 332 Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (AP) The Soviet Union has launched Cosmos 332 in its series of un manned satellites Tass reported Monday. The press agency said the new Sputnik, which was launched Saturday, was orbit ing the earth every 100 minutes at an angle of 74.5 degrees, with a high point of 488 miles and a low point of 469 miles.

title: 100 Cellists to Salute Casals Tonight
description: The man whose job it was to find 100 cellists willing to play without fee for tonight's concert saluting Pablo Casals at Philharmonic Hall found himself flooded with applica tions. I had to start turning people down about three weeks ago, said Arthur Aaron, personnel manager of the American Symphony Or chestra, which will perform in other portions of the pro gram honoring the 93year old cellist and teacher.

title: Citizens Broadcasting Committee, Gadfly Group, Reorganizes
description: The longexpected shakeup of the National Citizens Commit tee for Broadcasting took place yesterday at a meeting of the organization's board. Its results could signal a subtle change in direction for the group, which has served with Thomas P. F. Hoving as chairman, as a gad fly of commercial television.

title: Vietnam Protests Scheduled Today Outside Tax Offices
description: The Vietnam Moratorium movement will attempt today to stage its first major protests against the conflict in five months with demonstrations outside Internal Revenue Serv ice offices across the country.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS ALASKA LAND BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Senate Interior Committee virtually completed action to day on a bill that if approved by the Senate and House and signed by the president, would finally resolve the 86yearold issue of the claims of in digenous Alaskans.

title: To Marine Midland Board
description: James G. Baldwin, executive vice president and secretary, has been elected to the board of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York. He will assume the post of chairman of the executive com mittee on June 1.

title: Advertising:
description: Last week Craig W. Moo die Jr., the advertising chief of Armstrong Cork, took a shot at TV. This week James E. Duffy, the new president of the A.B.C. Television Net work, took a shot at Craig Moodie. Why not? It's a free country.

title: Music:
description: A FULLSIZED concerto for the English horn? That sonorous but lugubrious sounding instrument that normally sits in the rear of the orchestra, played by an anonymous specialist? Stan islaus Skrowaczewski, the conductor of the Minnesota Orchestra, has composed one, and the work had its New York unveiling last night in Carnegie Hall, played by Thomas Stacy, conducted by the composer with his or chestra.

title: Tornado Kills 17 Pakistanis
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 14 Seventeen persons were killed and 110 injured when a tornado lashed six villages some 25 miles from Dacca, cap ital of East Pakistan, last eve ning.

title: Space Center Relaxes as Decision on Apollo Is Made
description: HOUSTON, April 14  About midday today, a feel ing of relief filled the atmo sphere of the Manned Space craft Center.

title: House Votes to Bar Fund Use to Force Integration
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The House voted today to pro hibit the use of Federal funds in forcing school integration.

title: $10,000 Student Bail Fund Planned at Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., April 14The student government at the State University Center here has drawn up guidelines for a bail fund for resident stu dents arrested on campus start ing next year.

title: Experts Ponder Cause Of Spacecraft's Mishap
description: Excessive pressure of super cooled oxygen may have blown up a spherical oxygen tank and produced the emergency that enveloped the Apollo 13 moon flight Monday night.

title: Sisco Ends 4Day Mission to Cairo After a Cordial Welcome Despite Persistent Egyptian AntiU.S. Outcries
description: CAIRO, April 14Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco left Cairo this morning, ending a somewhat unorthodox fourday diplomatic mission to improve American  Egyptian communications at a crucial stage of the efforts for a po litical settlement of the Arab Israeli conflict.

title: Y. & R. Leader Looks At Ads of the Future
description: One of the country's best known ad makers says adver tising of the future will have to be more honest.

title: 4 Ejected at United Aircraft Meeting
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 14The annual stock holders' meeting of the United Aircraft Corporation here was marked by tight se curity surveillance in antici pation of trouble from war protestors and by stockhold ers' concern over the Apollo 13 astronauts.

title: 600 Social Workers Hold Protest for Pay Increase
description: About 600 members of a so cial workersunion pressed their demand for a pay increase yes terday by staging na noisy, threehour demonstration out side the offices of the Federa tion of Jewish Philanthropies, 130 East 59th Street.

title: Cerdan Arrives for Fight
description: Marcel Cerdan Jr., the French welterweight, arrived yesterday for his first fight in the United States. He meets Donato Padu ano, a Canadian, at MediKon Square Garden on May 11. The 26yearold son of the late mid dleweight champion was ac companied by his wife, Danielle, and manager, Philip Fillippi. He was met by his American man ager, George Cantor.

title: Clearwater Carrying Pollution Drive to Washington
description: The Hudson River sloop Clearwater sailed out into the rough waters of the At lantic Ocean yesterday to take its campaign against pollution to Washington for Earth Day Ceremonies next week.

title: Hot Dog Output Speeded
description: DETROIT (UPI)A sausage company here has a new frank furter machine capable of turn ing out 60.000 franks an hour.

title: Colorado U. Protest Ends
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 14 (AP)A 13hour occupation of the University of Colorado Re gents all ended early today after about 200 demonstrators were told by the authorities to accept a summons for trespass ing or he arrested by force, if necessary. The students filed out immediately.

title: Two Florida Senators Hurt
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 14 (UPI)The two topranking Re publicans in the Florida Senate, C. W. Young of St. Petersburg and Tom Slade of Jacksonville, were injured early today when their chartered plane crashed near the Tallahassee Municipal Airport. None of the injuries were considered critical. Mr. Slade's wife was treated at Tal lahassee Memorial Hospital for burns and shock.

title: Officer Seeks Albany Seat
description: SAIGON, April 14 (AP)  Navy Lieut. (jg) Rolland Kidder, 29 years old, of Jamestown, N. Y., says he wants to be a New York State Assemblyman and will run in the Democratic primary. Lieutenant Kidder, who is based at Binh Thuy, 80 miles southwest of Saigon, plans to return home in July after finishing three years in the Navy.

title: Nixon Hails Danish Leader
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) President Nixon today hailed Premier Hilmar Baunsgaard, who is here on a twoday visit, as a man who represents the progressive characteristics of Denmark. Mr. Nixon welcomed the Danish leader in the East Room of the White House.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON BASES IN SPAIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The United States is expected to emphasize scientific, educa tional and economic aid to Spain, instead of largescale military support as in the past, under a new agreement on mil itary bases reportedly ready for signing late next month.

title: LEAD IN FUELS SEEN AS KEY TO POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Engineers of the major automo bile manufacturers testified to day that leadfree gasoline was essential to their efforts at further reducing airpollution from cars.

title: Tandy Corp. Buys Allied Radio Assets
description: The Tandy Corporation has bought the business and certain assets of the Allied Radio Cor poration, a subsidiary of LTV Ling Altec, Inc., for about $30 million, it was announced yes terday.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at Boston  Burbach (00) vs. Lonborg (10).

title: RED WINGS LIKELY TO SIGN HARKNESS
description: Ned Harkness of Cornell, who coached three Eastern col lege teams to National Colle giate hockey championships, is expected to sign a contract as coach of the Detroit Red Wings today. The Canadian born Harkness, who is a citizen of the United States, went to De troit last night for final meet ings with Sid Abel, general manager and coach of the Na tional Hockey League club.

title: War Foe Bill in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 13 (AP) A bill similar to a Massachu setts law allowing servicemen to refuse to fight in Vietnam was introduced today in the New Jersey Legislature. The bill is sponsored by Assembly man George C. Richardson, Essex County Democrat. Mr. Richardson, a Negro, is the assistant Assembly minority leader and a candidate for Mayor of Newark.

title: BLUES TOP STARS, LEAD SERIES, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, April 14 (UPI) Terry Gray, Jim Roberts and Red Berenson scored St. Louis goals in the third period tonight that gave the Blues a 63 vic tory over the Minnesota North Stars and a 32 edge in games in their Stanley Cup quarter final series.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: (407 game series)

title: Some Rail Strikers Return
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 14 (UPI)Shoperaft workers here ended today their sixday wild cat strike against the Louisville & Nashville Railroad, but L.&N. workers at Corbin, in the heart of the eastern Kentucky coal fields, remained off the job. The strike was in protest of Congressional action to avert a nationwide rail strike.

title: Astronauts Face 2 Critical Problems: Keeping Spacecraft Cool and Its Air Clean
description: HOUSTON, April 14  In the cold void of space, a crucial problem for the Apollo 13 astronauts is that of keep ing cool.

title: Colleges and Individuals Here Seek to Bring Theodorakis to U.S.
description: The freeing of Mikis Theo dorakis by Greece's military, Government, has touched off al series of efforts by colleges and individuals here to bring the composer to the United States.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, April 15, 1970

title: PRICES UP SLIGHTLY ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices on the London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday, although profit tak ing caused scattered losses.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Somewhat On the Damp Side

title: PHANTOM OFFERED IN PLACE OF F111
description: The F111 attack plane suf fered a political setback last night with the announcement of a further delay in delivery of a 24plane fleet ordered by Australia.

title: Jenkins Presents Cautious British Budget, Cutting Taxes and Easing Credit Restrictions
description: LONDON, April 14In what he termed a cautious budget, Chancellor of the Exchequer Roy Jenkins cut taxes today by $528million a year and eased credit restraints.

title: Waste Them
description: The terrifying jungles of Vietnam shield from view many atrocities on both sides of the unseen battle lines. But certain disdainful phrases rise above the smoke of freefire zones to reveal the brutalizing meaning of the war.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 14, 1970

title: Terrorismand Repression
description: The danger in New Left bombing is not confined to the very great damage political fanatics can inflict on persons and property. The necessity for providing safeguards to the community against such terrorist acts often prompts governmental countermeasures that are themselves a threat to liberty.

title: Roundup: Cubs Give Selma Bum's Rush
description: You can take the burn out of the bleachers, but you can't take the bleachers out of the bum.

title: Concert by Brazilians
description: A concert of medieval and Renaissance music of France and Spain will be given by the Conjunto Brasileiro Roberto de Regina at Town Hall next Wednesday under the sponsor ship of the Center for Inter American Relations and the consul general of Brazil. The ensemble consists of eight sing ers, who double as instrumen talists, and a lutenist. The first half of the program will be de voted to chansons by Jannequin and the second half to music from Spain.

title: Market Place:
description: NOW that the New York Stock Exchange is mak ing progress in its efforts to make those small orders pay for themselves through high er commissions, it is time to ask whether enough is being done to reduce the cause of these lossesbackoffice in efficiency.

title: U.S. Backs Conservation Pact Involving Susquehanna River
description: TRENTON, April 14  The Nixon Administration's support of a proposed interstate com pact to coordinate the conser vation and development of the Susquehanna River was an nounced here today by Secre tary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel.

title: No Report on Space Debris
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 14 (UPI)The North American Air Defense Command said to day it had no way of knowing if any debris was in the vicinity of Apollo 13's course to the moon when the spaceship was crippled last night. The astro nauts reported a loud explosion shortly, before power from the service module was lost. Space agency officials have not ruled out the possibility the space craft was struck from the out side.

title: PRICES DROP AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in another poor performance yesterday as the list declined for the ninth con secutive session in steppedup trading.

title: Executive Heads Fund Drive
description: Frank R. Milliken, president of the Kennecott Copper Cor poration, has been named gen eral chairman for the 1970 appeal of the United Fund of Greater New York. He will di rect 150,000 volunteers in rais ing funds in the business, labor and governmental sectors for the 425 voluntary hospital, health and welfare agencies helped by the fund. The drive begins April 30.

title: Silent Nights for Hoboken
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., April 14 Garbage collections, which have begun here at midnight for many years, will not begin until 5 A.M. starting tomorrow. Pub lic Works Director Rafael Vitale said he had given in to com plaints from sleepless residents about noisy garbage trucks and collectors bouncing empty cans on the sidewalks. He said the new time for the sixday week garbage pickup will be given a trial several weeks.

title: NIXON AIDE CHECKS TAX RETURNS OF 9
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Randolph W. Thrower, the Commissioner of Internal Re venue, told Congress today that an aide of President Nixon had seen the tax returns of nine persons since last September, when he first started asking.

title: Two New Shows Confirm Henry Moore's Greatness
description: THE English sculptor Henry Moore is one of the few great living artistsalas, one of the very few. As is always the case with artists whose careers have been long, pro ductive, uneven and overpub licized, we have sometimes taken his greatness for granted. Indeed, there have been times when even Mr. Moore seemed to be taking it for granted.

title: I.O.S. SAYS ITS STOCK IS BEARRAID TARGET
description: GENEVA, April 14Top of ficials of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the mutualfund complex founded by Bernard Cornfeld, a former Philadel phia social worker, say they believe the company's enemies have mounted an oldfashioned bear raid against its stock.

title: Protest at Boston College
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 13 (AP)  Several thousands stu dents picketed Boston College and boycotted classes Monday to protest a proposed $500 tui tion increase for next year's frshrnen.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLDMAN  Dorothy. Two long years. I will never stop loving you.

title: Chemical Off Market
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it had discon tinued the production of caustic potash solution. A spokesman said the action was taken because of continued price at trition and declining profits over the last two years.

title: Lifeboat in Space
description: An emergency in a space craft on the voyage be tween earth and moon was bound to occur sometime. The enormous hazards of the long journey through the most hostile of environments, the ever present possibility of failure by one or more of the millions of components contained in an Apollo vehicle, the ubiquitous threat of human error, all these combine lunar flights to make them the most dangerous expe ditions human beings have ever undertaken. In retro spect, the remarkable fact is not that such ominous peril has arisen in the nowaborted trip of Apollo 13, but that the equally hazardous trips to the moon and back by Apollos 8, 10, 11 and 12 were accomplished in safety.

title: Private Export Picks Its First Executives
description: Nelson Schaenen, retired president of Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., has been elected chairman and John R. Burton, senior partner in the law company of Reid & Preist, president of the newly formed Private Export Funding Cor poration.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Defense Department to day announced the names of the following servicemen from the New York area killed in action in the Vietnam war:

title: Super Tennis Series' Urged As Part of Sweeping Reforms
description: If an open Davis Cup is not approved this year, the United States will push for a super tennis series between the chal lenge round champion and team of contract professionals, Alastair B. Martin said yester day.

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZES THANT ON BAHREIN
description: UNITED NATIONS N. Y., April 6The Soviet Union has complained that Secretary Gen eral Thant sent a mission to Bahrein, a Persian Gulf state, without consulting the Security Council.

title: MoonRock Project Lost; Equipment Will Burn Up
description: HOUSTON, April 14 (UPI) The change in Apollo 13 plans today cost scientists a long awaited chance to explore a hilly stretch of lunar terrain expected to yield the oldest rocks man had even seen  dating back five or 5.5 billion years.

title: NIXON IS BRIEFED ON APOLLO CRISIS
description: GREENBELT, Md., April 14 President Nixon, looking taut and tired, met with technical experts of the space agency here for 45 minutes this after noon and was briefed about the past and future problems of the Apollo 13 mission.

title: City Downs Hofstra, 53, On Camuto's 4Run Homer
description: Vinnie Camuto's grandslam home run in the first inning yesterday paced C.C.N.Y. to a 53 triumph over Hofstra in a Metropolitan Conference game at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx.

title: NIXON NOMINATES 9 FOR SCIENCE BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) President Nixon announced six new nominees today to the 24member National Science Board.

title: French Families in Cambodian War Zone Live on Edge of Fear
description: KREK, Cambodia, April 13 Two Frenchmen, both man agers of Frenchowned rub ber plantations here and both dressed in white shirts and white shorts, sat in big arm chairs listening to the mortar shells and the submachine guns a mile away. Their man ner was that of thoughtful men listening hard to music.

title: South Vietnamese Repulse Attack on Border Outpost
description: GODAUHA, South Vietnam, April 14 (Reuters)  South Vietnamese Government troops beat off a North Vietnamese attack from across the Cam bodian border today, killing 110 enemy soldiers and captur ing seven prisoners, their com mander reported.

title: Adm. Moorer Named To Head Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  President Nixon today named Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chief of Naval Operations, to succeed Gen. Earle G. Wheeler as chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest ranking military officer.

title: MRS. VINCENT CREED
description: Mrs. Barbara Creed, coordina tor of the Irish Linen Guild's promotion activities in the United States, died of pneu monia Monday in her home, 18 Lexington Avenue. She was 52 years old and the wife of Vin cent Creed.

title: TV: Apollo 13's Distress
description: THE American Broadcast ing Company News De partment took the measure of rival television networks in reporting late Monday night and early yesterday morning the trials of Apollo 13.

title: Judge Blackmun of Minnesota Is Named To Supreme Court Seat by the President
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  President Nixon today nomi nated Harry Andrew Blackmun of Minnesota to the Supreme Court.

title: Israeli Officials Declare Goldmann Misled Them
description: JERUSALEM, April 14Is raeli Government officials have asserted that Dr. Nahum Gold mann, president of the World Jewish Congress, misled them in his reported offer to meet with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Re public, raising false hopes here and abroad.

title: George H. Soule Jr. Dies at 82; ExEditor of The New Republic
description: SOUTH KENT, Conn., April 14George H. Soule Jr., a la bor economist and author, who was an editor of The New Re public from 1924 to 1947, died in a convalescent hospital in Warren this afternoon. He had been in failing health for the last year and a half. He was 82 years old and lived in South Kent.

title: Bridge:
description: THE number of ways in which a team contest can be organized is almost as great as the number of bid ding systems that have been devised in the history of the game.

title: Rates of Bond Interest Show Fairly Sharp Rise
description: Interest rates climbed fairly sharply yesterday as the capital markets shifted their gaze away from the Bell Sys tem's big new debenture offering and found other issues comparatively less attractive.

title: Agatha Kimmel to Be Bride of John W. Gates 3d
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 14Miss Agatha Gay Kimmell, whose ancestor, John Rolfe, married Poco hantas and whose grand father, the late Rear Adm. Husband E. Kimmel, U. S. N., was Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet when Pearl Harbor was attacked, plans to be married to John Wil liam Gates 3d, whose gland father, the late Norman Thomas, was a Socialist can didate for the President of the United States for six times.

title: NEWSMEN'S RELEASE IS ASKED BY ROGERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Secretary of State William P. Rogers called Monday for the prompt release of eight foreign newsmen believed to have been captured by Communist forces in Cambodia.

title: Soviet Exercises Seek to Prove Navy's Readiness
description: MOSCOW, April 14  West ern Naval experts said today that the largescale Soviet naval maneuvers scheduled to begin later this month appeared to have two purposes.

title: 2 Top Panthers Jailed for Contempt
description: NEW HAVEN, April 14  Two national Black Panther party leaders, David Hilliard and Emory Douglas, were jailed for six months for contempt after a courtroom scuffle with deputy sheriffs here today.

title: Revlon Promotes Executive
description: Theodore Boutin has been elected vice president, treasurer and a director of Revlon, Inc. Formerly vice presidentcorpo rate controller, Mr. Boutis joined the company in 1958 as assistant controller and in 1967 was promoted to controller. Before joining Revlon, he was with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co.

title: DR. HUGH M. WHITE
description: JERSEY CITY, April 14Dr. Hugh M. White, who practiced medicine in Jersey Ctiy for 53 years, died yesterday in a nurs ing home here. He was 89 years old and lived here at 271 Pali sade Avenue.

title: TIDDLEY, $4 WINS SPRINT IN FLORIDA
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 14 (AP)Heavily favored Tiddley finished with a rush today to win the eighth race at Gulf stream Park.

title: ALUMINUM PLANTS FOLLOW PRICE RISE
description: Two of the biggest United States aluminum companies raised their overseas prices for primary ingot yesterday by half a cent a pound to 28 cents.

title: CHICAGO BANK HIT FOR BACK TAXES
description: The First Chicago Corpora tion, parent company of the First National Bank of Chi cago, announced yesterday that it had been hit with a claim from the Internal Revenue Service for $16.7million in back taxes for the years 1965 and 1966.

title: Banana Machine Blows Up
description: LA SPEZIA, Italy (UPI)A bananaripening machine ex ploded in a warehouse here and destroyed $16,000 worth of ba nanas.

title: Criminal Law Revision Sent to Governor
description: ALBANY, April 14The as sembly gave final approval today to a voluminous bill re vising the Code of Criminal Procedure, which sets forth how the state's criminal justice Process is to be administered.

title: PARIS SEEKS LAW TO CURB VIOLENCE
description: PARIS, April 14The Gov ernment struck back on two fronts today against violence in the universities and elswhere.

title: Strike by State's Workers Is Spreading in Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis., April 14 A wildcat strike of state em ployes that began yesterday spread to a third state hospital today, and a union spokesman said guards at the state peni tentiary at Waupun would soot join the work stoppage.

title: ALBANY REPORTS TAX REFORM PACT
description: ALBANY, April 14The As sembly Ways and Means Com mittee said today that it had worked out an agreement with the Senate and he Governor on a tax reform that would ease the burden of some tax payers and increase it for others.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Black Candidates in Newark Widen Rift
description: The rift widened between black candidates for Mayor of Newark yesterday as supporters of one contestant accused an other of deception and im morality in seeking outside aid from Negro political leaders and theatrical personalities.

title: Brezhnev Says Soviet Aim Is Reasonable Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, April 14Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist party leader, said today that the Soviet Union would welcome a reasonable agree ment with the United States on limiting strategic arms when the second round of Soviet American talks begins in Vienna on Thursday.

title: Plight of 3 Crewmen Stirs World Interest and Prayer
description: Suddenly, in the moment it takes an oxygen tank to spring a leak, the flight of Apollo 13 was no longer something every body took for granted and was even slightly bored with.

title: Fighting in Yemen Is Reported Ended By Saudi Accord
description: SANA, Yemen, April 14  Fighting is reported to have ended in Yemen following the settlement of a dispute between this country and the neighbor ing kingdom of Saudi Arabia about royalist resistance to the republican Government here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Machines Lure Coins
description: LONDON (AP)  Britons pushed coins totaling more than $403.2million into vending machines last year. More than $240 million went for ciga rettes.

title: RISE OF 30% URGED IN CITY REALTY TAX
description: ALBANY, April 14  Mayor Lindsay arrived here tonight for talks with Republican legis lators on the city's financial problems facing the possibility that he might have to adopt a $440million package of real estate tax increases.

title: CREW OF CRIPPLED APOLLO 13 STARTS BACK AFTER ROUNDING MOON AND FIRING ROCKET; MEN APPEAR CALM DESPITE LOW RESERVES
description: HOUSTON, Wednesday, April 15With the lives of its three astronauts hanging in the bal ance, the crippled spaceship Apollo 13 swung around the moon last night and rocketed toward an emergency splash down in the Pacific Ocean Fri day.

title: ERROR BY M'GRAW LEADS TO DEFEAT
description: The New York Mets awakened memories of their furious summer of 1969 at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by raising their championship flag over Shea Stadium. But for the next three hours they awakened memories of dimmer days by losing their home opening game to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 64, in 10 innings.

title: Apollo Plutonium Capsule Expected to Fall in Ocean
description: HOUSTON, April 14  A graphite cylinder containing 8.36 pounds of radioactive plu tonium will fall into the earth's atmosphere Friday at the time Apollo 13 is scheduled to re turn to earth.

title: Foreign Affairs: Where War Is Indivisible
description: THE HAGUE  Soviet in fluence in the Arab world has gained impressively during the past three years and Western influence has commensurately diminished. Yet the latter has by no means vanished as in dicated by Joseph Sisco's cur rent diplomatic tour and the recent exploratory voyage of Joseph Luns, veteran Dutch Foreign Minister, widely known as a friend of the United States.

title: Tonight's the Deadline For Filing Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)The last income Lax returns should be going into the mail tomorrow, marking the end of the tax season for 77 million taxpayersa third of whom waited until the last five days to file.

title: New German Consul Is Here
description: Count Harald von Posadow skyWehner, the newly appoint ed West German consul in New York, arrived yesterday to as sume his post.

title: Island, Long a Naval Target, Is Taking Aim at the Navy
description: CULEBRA, P.R., April 14  For more than 60 years this tiny island 22 miles east of Puerto Rico has been bombarded by the United States Navy with hardly a grumble from its peaceable residents.

title: 2Level Parking Lot Collapses at Omaha Hospital
description: OMAHA, April 14The 408 car parking structure at Clark son Hospital was closed indefi nitely today following the col lapse of part of the twostory facility. There were no reported injuries.

title: Air Travel Returning to Normal As Controllers Go Back to Work
description: Air travel began returning to normal over much of the nation yesterday as hundreds of Fed eral air traffic controllers re ported to work for the first time in three weeks.

title: April 27 Benefit to Aid Boys' Club
description: A twopart benefit will be held on April 27 for the ben efit of Kips Bay Boys' Club. Proceeds will aid the club's program for boys at its new clubhouse at 1930 Randall Avenue in the southeast Bronx and at a summer camp in Carmel, N. Y.

title: Dr. Reuben Turner Headed Pediatrics at Bellevue
description: Dr. Reuben Turner, a pedia trician, died of a heart attack Saturday at the White Plains Center for Nursing Care. He was 66 years old and lived at 9 Ridgeland Road, Yonkers.

title: Sorensen Reports Gromyko Denies Rumors of Shifts
description: MOSCOW, April 14Theo dore C. Sorensen, the New York Democratic Committee's choice for the party's Senate nomina tion, said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had told him that no changes were imminent in the Soviet leadership.

title: Washington: Judge Blackmun and Justice Douglas
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Republicans have a new nominee for the Supreme Court of the United StatesJudge Harry A. Blackmunand a new villain on the Court itself Mr. Justice William O. Douglas.

title: Bruce Jay Friedman Novel Sold As Film Before It Is Published
description: Screen rights to The Dick, a novel by Bruce Jay Friedman which will be pub lished in August by Alfred A. Knopf, have been acquired by BrodskyGould Productions, headed by Jack Brodsky and Elliott Gould. They will film it next year in association with 20th CenturyFox. The purchase price, the author said, was $125,000 and a per centage of the film's profits. Mr. Gould will be starred and Mr. Brodsky will produce The Dick.

title: L.I. Library Gets Computer
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. (AP)The computer has come to the smalltown library. Here in Port Washington, cards are being punched out for all the library's borrowers and all the 76,000 volumes on the shelves.

title: Shoplifting Reward Set
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) In a move to stop shoplifters, Belgrade's largest department store  Beorgrad  has offered 30 per cent of the value of stolen goods recovered to any customers who points out thief.

title: First President Named In Rhodesian Republic
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 14 (Reuters)Clifford Dupont was appointed first President of the Rhodesian Republic today.

title: Bruins Beat Rangers and Take 32 Lead in East Playoff
description: BOSTON, April 14Not at all according to the script, which called for a protracted battle, the Bruins scored a solid 32 victory over the Rangers tonight to take the lead at 3 games to 2 in their Stanley Cup series.

title: PLATINUM PRICES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: The April platinum futures contract went off the New York Mercantile Exchange yes terday in a blaze of glory. With a total of 67 sales, prices of the contract closed at $172.50, compared with $170.10 the day before.

title: HENRY B. DU PONT INDUSTRIALIST, 71
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 (AP)Henry Belin du Pont, a former vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., and a greatgreatgrandson of the company's founder, Eleu thre Irne du Pont de Ne mours, died last night at his home in Greenville, a suburb. He was 71 years old and had suffered a stroke last October.

title: Population Rise Is Rescaled
description: BOLOGNA, Italy (UPI)City planners, who originally worked on the assumption the city's population would grow from 485,000 to 1.1 million have amended the plan, setting a ceiling of 600,000.

title: CANADA SEES RISE IN CAPITAL OUTLAY
description: OTTAWA, April 14The Government reported today that following two years of stagna tion an 11 per cent increase in capital spending by Canadian companies has been planned for 1970.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alfred A. Wolff, formerly vice president and secretary in charge of agency, credit and budget departments, the Home Insurance Company, has been named executive vice presidentoperations.

title: Griffith Gets L.P.G. Post
description: CINCINNATI, April 14 (UPI)  Ed Griffith Jr., a member of the Professional Golfers Asso ciation for 19 years and part of the staff for the men's tour the last two years, was named today tournament director of the Ladies Professional Golf As sociation.

title: COUNCIL REQUESTS FULL TAX PACKAGE
description: With a call for Mayor Lind say to disclose pronto the full dimensions of his newtax pack age, the City Council declined yesterday to act on the items that the Mayor has disclosed so far.

title: Memorial Services
description: WARNERAleen Tyler, of 711 N. E. Harbour Terrace, Boca Raton, Fla., and Sands Point, L. I., died in Boca Raton Dec. 5, 1969. Survived by husband, W. Winston Warner, brother, Robert B. Hoke. Memorial serv ices at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington, L. I., on Saturday, April 1B, 1970, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Aleen T. Warner Memorial Fund at Boca Raton Com munity Hospital, Boca Raton, Fla.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 15, 1970

title: Chicago Trucking Stalled By Strikes and Lockouts
description: A strike by teamsters and a lockout by truckers continued yesterday in Chicago while driver walkouts in other Middle Western areas increased layoffs of nonstriking erivers and em ployes in industries faced with parts shortages.

title: MANATEE SCHOOLS OPEN WITH CALM
description: BRADENTON, Fla., April 14 (UPI)The Manatee County school system began operation today under a courtordered desegregation plan delayed for eight days by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.

title: Mackell Quits Governor Race; Backs Goldberg for Nomination
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday for Governor.

title: Hudson Group Opposes Plan For Congers Can Factory
description: CONGERS, N. Y., April 14 The Hudson River Valley Commission has found after a 90day review that a proposed Reynolds Metals Company can factory would impair recre ational and natural resources in this area.

title: Columbia Law Professor to Be Named to P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, April 14Gov ernor Rockefeller plans to an nounce the appointment this week of William K. Jones, a 39yearold Columbia Univer sity law professor, to the state Public Service Commission.

title: Braniff Airliner Turns Back; Suspicious Man Is Seized
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 14 (AP)A Braniff airliner in flight to Mexico City turned back last night and officers overpowered a passenger quot ed as saying he carried some thing that can hurt us all.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Release of Kopechne Transcript
description: BOSTON, April 14A Fed eral judge ordered a temporary delay today in publication of the transcript of the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest, pending a decision on a suit brought by the inquest stenographers.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE DURING FEBRUARY
description: Business inventories in Feb ruary reversed the previous month's trend, rising $870mil lion over January, the Com merce Departent reported yes terday in Washington.

title: DOW LOSES 5.34, CLOSES AT 780.56
description: The stock market continued its losing ways yesterday with only a slight afternoon recov ery taking some of the sting out of an earlier broad de cline.

title: Lakers Down Hawks, 10594, for 20 Lead in N.B.A. Western Final Series
description: ATLANTA, April 14In the midcourt meeting of the cap tains before tonight's National Basketball Association playoff game, Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers grinned as he told Bill Bridges of the Atlanta Hawks: We brought enough tourniquets to stop the blood.

title: CAMBODIANS SEEKING U.S. AND PARIS BANKS
description: PARIS, April 14Cambodia's new regime has quietly invited American and French banks to establish facilities in Pnompenh, informed banking sources said today.

title: Cambodia Appeals To World for Arms
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 14Premier Lon Nol issued an urgent appeal tonight for arms from any country that wanted to provide them.

title: Championship Flag Stirs Fans, but Some Think It's Too Small
description: One of the least foreseen ceremonies of the 20th Century, the raising of a world cham pions flag by the New York Mets, took place at Shea Sta dium yesterday. The rain that began just before the festivities for the opening home game did nothing to dispel the joy of the occasion for the Mets and their supporters among a crowd of 41,679.

title: Agnew Cancels Apollo Visit
description: HOUSTON, April 14 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said to day Vice president Agnew had canceled plans in visit Mission Control during the flight of Apollo 13. Mr. Agnew chair man of the Presodent's Space Comneil had planned to fly here today to be at the Manned Spacercraft ?? for the memt ?? landing that had been been ?? ?? Wednesday.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: WAR PERIL IS FEARED IN POPULATION BOOM
description: RALEIGH, N. C. (AP)  A Duke University professor says that nations which control the stork must also guard them selves against nations that do not control their populations.

title: Canadian Press Elects Chief
description: TORONTO, April 14 (Canadi an Press)  Norman Smith, president and editor of The Ottawa Journal, was elected president of The Canadian Press today. He succeeded J. R. H. Sutherland of The New Glasgow News who served as president of the national news cooperative for the last two years.

title: Bill Henry, Los Angeles Times Columnist, Dies at 79
description: NORTHRIDGE, Calif., April 14 (UPI)Bill Henry, Washing ton political columnist for The Los Angeles Times for 30 years, and a television and radio com mentator for many years, died at a hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old and had suffered from heart trouble.

title: Medina Hearings Recessed; Captain Declines Comment
description: ATLANTA, April 14 (AP) Capt. Ernest L. Medina today attended the first formal hear ing on murder charges against him in connection with the alleged 1968 massacre at Songmy.

title: JOHN H. SHOTT
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., April 14 John H. Shott, retired alumni secretary at Bucknell Univer sity, died yesterday at Evangel ical Community Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived on College Hill.

title: A.B. A. Owners Agree to Pay $11Million Merger Indemnity
description: After two days of meetings, the owners of the 11 American Basketball Association clubs aave agreed unanimously to pay an indemnity of $11million to merge with the National Basketball Association, it was announced yesterday by the A. B. A. commissioner, Jack Delph.

title: Bucks Frown Upon a Defeatist Attitude
House Unit Backs Nixon Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 President Nixon's welfare re form program cleared another Congressional barrier today as the House Rules Committee voted to send the measure to the floor and prohibit any changes in it there.

title: JERSEY NEWSPAPER SUSPENDS PRINTING
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 14Morris County's Daily Rec ord suspended publication to day until the current strike of pressman, printers and mailers is settled.

title: Ashe at U.N., Urges World Tennis Union Expel South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 Arthur Ashe, the American Negro tennis star, called today for the expulsion of South Africa from the Inter national Lawn Tennis Federa tion because of the country's racial pnlicies.

title: Washington Editor Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)Ben W. Gilbert, an asso ciate editor of The Washington Post, announced today that he was resigning effective July 1. Mr. Gilbert, 52 years old, spent 28 years with The Post. He was city editor from 1945 to 1964.

title: U.S. TO EASE RULES ON METHADONE USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)The Nixon Administra tion indicated today that it would soon let doctors switch heroin addicts to regular doses of methadone, a cheap and rel atively harmless heroin substi tute.

title: Miss Anne P. Clark to Be Wed To C. C. Haffner 3d on June 19
description: GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., April 14  Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Anthony Clark have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Anne Peronneau Clark, to Charles C. Haffner 3d. Mr. Haffner is vice president and treasurer of the R. R. Don nelley & Sons Company, the Chicago printers founded by his greatgrandfather.

title: U.S. PROTESTS MOVE BY CANADA ON ARCTIC
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The United States formally pro tested to Canada today against a move to establish jurisdictior over international waters in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Percy Fears a Drive Is On to Put Rein on Dissent
description: Senator Charles H. Percy last night attacked those in politi cal life today whose public statements leave no doubt that they would support proposals to curb dissent and cautioned that the longrange con sequences of silencing the vocal minority could be tragically high.

title: In 3 Nations With Legal Abortion, Debate Goes On
description: Liberal abortion laws in Ja pan, Sweden and Britain are working well in the opinion of their supporters  and much too well in the opinion of their critics.

title: Undoing a Historic Mistake
description: On August 2, 1964, in the face of a deepening mili tary and political crisis in South Vietnam and on the eve of a bitterly contested Presidential campaign in the United States, the Johnson Administration an nounced that the United States destroyer Maddox had been the target of an unprovoked attack by PT boats while on routine patrol in international waters in the Gulf of Tonkin off North Vietnam. Two days later, the Pentagon reported a second attack.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The crippled Apollo 13 swung behind the moon last night and successfully fired its rocket to put it on a fast and more accu rate course toward an emergency splash down in the Pacific on Friday. The lives of the crew hung in the balance between their spacecraft's speed and their limited and dwindling supplies of oxygen, electricity and water. [Page 1, Columns 18.]

title: Past Problems in Space Troublesome but Minor
description: Despite one major setback on the ground and a few hair raising moments in the early days of space exploration, America's manned space pro gram has operated without serious inflight mishap for nearly nine years.

title: Two Breeds Barking for Recognition
description: THE two breeds with the best chances at this time to become accepted by the American Kennel Club into competition in the miscel laneous class at dog shows are the Bichon Frise and the Staffordshire bull terrier. What brought the subject up were talks with Martin Roth man of Massa pequa, L. I., presi dent of the Greater New York Bichon Frise Fan ciers, a club he organized in 1968, and John Brownell, a vice president of the American Kennel Club. There was no assurance when, or even if, action would be taken.

title: Bahamas Good Customer
description: NASSAU, The Bahamas (AP) The Bahama Islands imported a record total of $34million worth of goods from Britain during 1969, making them the most important British market in the Carribean, British Trade Commissioner John Towlson re ported.

title: Paley Orders San Franciso Hall ClearedNet Gains
description: Paley Orders San Franciso Hall ClearedNet Gains

title: Books of The Times
description: A YOUNG MAN, 26 years old, a few weeks away from escaping the draft, sud denly and arbitrarily loses his deferment and is inducted into the Army. When the bus bearing him to basic training breaks down, be is asked to hike down the road for help. Instead, he deserts, to run head long into an antimatter universe: of art,

title: Ivan Digging Up Rubles For World Cup Wagers
description: MOSCOW, April 15 (AP) A capitalistic vicebetting on soccer gameshas invaded the Soviet Union.

title: WILLIAM L. ONDERDONK
description: RUMSON, N. J., April 15 William L. Onderdonk, a former vice president of Appleton & Cox, Inc., marine underwriters in New York City, died Tuesday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. He was 75 years old and lived at 9 North Cherry Lane.

title: U. S. CURBS SALES OF A WEED KILLER
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Federal Government took steps today to halt the use of the controversial herbicide 2,4,5T as a weedkiller around, homes and ordered the suspen sion of its use as a defoliant in Vietnam.

title: The 325,000 Jaycees Call Her The First Lady of Young America
description: SHE is slender and blonde, married to a president, and lives in a mansion called the White House.

title: 100 Cellists Highlight a Salud Casals
Manning, Star Back At Ole Miss, Calls Plays at Shortstop
description: ARCHIE MANNING will probably start the 1970 football season as the favor ite to win the Heisman Trophy, the prize that goes to the outstanding college player. The Mississippi quar terback made a strong bid for that award as a junior last year and he Is expected to be just as im pressive in the coming cam paign. But pre sently, Manning is scrambling around picking up grounders at shortstop and hitting over .400 for the Mississippi base ball team. He anchors one of the best in fields in southern collegiate baseball circles and may help get Ole Miss into the college world series at Omaha, Neb., for the second year in a row.

title: Garbage Study Funds Cut
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that research funds to find new methods of dispos ing of municipal garbage have been cut by $6million by the Budget Bureau for next year. The decision, he said, was ir responsible because of the many problems cities face disposing of increasing amounts of municipal refuse.

title: Disaster Area Designated
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Small Business Adminis tration designated Chelmsford, Mass., as a disaster area today because of flood damage April 4.

title: Attempt at Rise Erased as Amex Falls 10th Time
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yes terday after selling pressure in the afternon erased most of the earlier Rains.

title: WOMEN DISRUPT MEETING OF C.B.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 Tranquility is not the order of the day, Dr. Frank Stantion, president, told the annual meet ing here today of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

title: Injured Soviet Seaman Says Shipmate Died in Accident
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 15 (AP)A crewman injured in an accident aboard a crippled Soviet trawler said today that another crewman had been killed in the same mishap.

title: Lenin Is Most Translated
description: PARIS (AP)  Lenin is the world's most frequently trans lated author, says the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Georges Simenon, a novelist born in Belgrade, was second, followed by Britain's Enid Bly ton and Shakespeare.

title: Shipyard's Plan for Hiring Minorities Called Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  The Labor Department said today that it had rejected as inadequate a minority hiring program worked out by the Maritime Administration with the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

title: Army Beats Princeton. 126, For Third Lacrosse Victory
description: PRINCETON. N.J., April 15 Pete Cramblet, an allAmer ica attackman, scored six goals today and led Army's lacrosse team to a 126 victory over Princeton. He also had two assists.

title: RECOVERY IS SEEN FOR U.S. ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 One of the top Nixon Admin istration economic officials said today that the worst part of the slowing of economic activity appears to be behind us and that economy is ap parently at the threshhold of moving upward once again.

title: MOODY'S RATING FEE ON TAXEXEMPTS SET
description: Moody's Investors Service, Inc., the oldest and largest securitiesrating agency, an nounced yesterday that it plan ned to charge for rating new taxexempt bond issues starting May 15.

title: An Experienced Audience Sees Play on Prison Life
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 A oneact drama about life in a prison played a oneday stand here todayin a prison.

title: City Granting Leases on Its Buildings' Air Rights
description: The city is pulling dollars out of the air under a new program with farreaching pos sibilitiesthe leasing and trans fer to private developers of air rights over cityowned build ings.

title: Professor C.C.N.Y. Ousted in '33 Wins His Pension
description: ALBANY. April 15  A 37 year quest by a professor who lost his job at City College in New York City for conducting a hunger strike against Fascism ended successfully here today as the Legislature ordered that he receive a pension.

title: Nets Sign Ard of Cincinnati To $400,000 4Year Contract
description: Jim Ard of the University of Cincinnati, one of the most sought after players by basketball's professional clubs this season, has signed a fouryear $400,000 contract to play with the New York Nets of the American Bas ketball Association.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1970

title: CORE Backs 2 State Candidates From Harlem
description: The Congress of Racial Equality and a coalition of black activists and organi zations announced yesterday their endorsement of black can didates for State Senate and Assembly seats from Harlem.

title: New Daily Paper in City Planned in 6 to 10 Weeks
description: A new daily newspaper with emphasis on coverage of local news will he published here starting in six to ten weeks, according to James A. Smith, publisher.

title: Lejeune Bowlers Advance To 2d and 3d in Tourney
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 15 (UPI)  Camp Lejeune (N. C.) bowlers moved into second and third places in classicdivision singles at the American Con cress tournament today.

title: Stage: Sympathy for Beaten Persians
description: The Persians, Aeschy ?? wrote about a con temporary event, the defeat of the Persians by the Greeks at Salamis in 472 B.C. He wrote from the point of view of the Persians, and although it is clear from history, and from the play, that the Persians were the aggressors, the play is sympathetic not to their cause, but to them as human beings.

title: PRISONER TORTURE IS LAID TO GREECE BY 15 COUNTRIES
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 15  Fifteen Western European Governments asserted jointly today that the Greek military junta engaged in torture and other ill treatment of its politi cal prisoners. The Governments also made public a 40,000word report detailing alleged mis deeds by the authorities in Athens.

title: 12 STATES DRAFT RAIL SAFETY CODE
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 Representatives of 12 states ended a twoday conference here today with proposals for uniform interstate safety regu lations for the railroad trans portation of cargo and passen gers.

title: JOHN EDGERLEY, 69, BANKING EXECUTIVE
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., April 15John Edgerley, who re tired as executive vice presi dent of the Bloomfield Savings Bank in 1966, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 144 Parkview Drive.

title: TEAMSTERS' STRIKES CAUSE NEW LAYOFFS
description: Teamster strikes in several cities forced more layoffs yes terday in industries suffering from a shortage of raw mater ials and parts. Many major man ufacturers feared thatmassive layoffs would occurr if the trucking dispute continued into next week, the Associated Press reported.

title: AUSTRALIAN SCORES 2 UPSETS IN TENNIS
description: MONTE CARLO, April 16 (AP)Barry PhillipsMoore, a lesser ranked Australian, elimi nated two seeded players today in the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament. Andres Gimeno of Spain was the Ione surviving contract professional.

title: NAVY COURT TOLD OF ANTIWAR PAPER
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Navy called its first eight witnesses today in the sedition courtmartial of Seaman Roger Lee Priest, who has published an antiwar newsletter critical of Government policy and high ranking military figures.

title: U.S. FREES RUSSIAN IN OIL SPILLAGE CASE
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 15 (UPI)United States author ities released today the master of a Soviet tanker that was found to have polluted the Gulf of Alaska.

title: Vietnamese Watch War Cross Over to Cambodia
description: KHANHBINH, South Viet nam, April 14  There is no mistaking the border here.

title: Senate Passes a Bill Creating a Powerful State Crime Agency
description: ALBANY, April 15A pro posed constitutional amend ment that would give the Gov ernor extensive power to super vise district attorneys and local police departments through a new state agency was approved today by the State Senate.

title: Nickerson Drops Race for Governor
description: Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson with drew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomina tion for Governor because contributions to his campaign stopped coming in the day that Arthur J. Goldberg be came a candidate.

title: Albany's Legislation by Fatigue
description: ALBANY, April 15Mem bers of the New York State Legislature are fond of calling themselves members of the greatest deliberate body in the world, but the picture emerg ing this week is of a process of legislation by exhaustion.

title: A. C. L. U. Challenges U.S. Over Mail Inspection
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a suit here challenging the constitutionality of proposed Federal regulations that would authorize customs officials to open mail from overseas without the recipient's permission, which is currently required.

title: Police Witnesses at Rallies, Delaying Panthers' Hearings
description: Pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places were ad journed to today because three police witnesses scheduled to appear were assigned to anti war demonstrations yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: INJURIES WEAKEN NEW YORK'S CLUB
description: The New York Rangers are back where they were on the final day of the regular Na tional Hockey League season facing elimination.

title: U.N. Economic Unit Bars East Germany at Session
description: GENEVA, April 15  The West refused today to permit East Germany to he officially invited to participate in the current session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 15  In creases in aboveground stocks of oil and a restudy of the pro ducing ability of Texas wells led the Texas Railroad Commis sion today to reduce the May allowable production rate from 68 to 64.5 per cent of the wells' ability to produce.

title: 14G.I.'S ARE KILLED BY A BOOBY TRAP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 16 (AP)The United States command re ported today that 25 Americans were killed and 54 wounded yesterday, one of the year's highest oneday casualty tolls Vietcong gunners also fired rockets into Saigon for the sec ond time in three nights.

title: STERLING FOOTE
description: Sterling De Groot Foote of 10 Mitchel Place, a retired insur ance broker, who was on the National Board of Review of Mtion Pictures, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Dublin, N. H., where he was on a visit. His age was 51.

title: Financial Data Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The nomination of Judge Harry A. Blackmun to the Supreme Court was greeted with cautious approval today in the Senate by both conservatives and lib erals, suggesting that the ap pointment should be approved with little or no opposition.

title: REALTY TRUST SET BY BANKAMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corporation announced plans yesterday to join the rapidly growing ranks of banking concerns that have formed real estate investment trusts.

title: ALBANY TAX PLAN VOULD GIVE CITY ITS OWN LOTTERY
description: ALBANY, April 15Gover nor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay are discussing a ten tative package of new taxes and revenue measures that would include offtrack betting and a revised numberslike lot tery.

title: Dinner Will Assist Lincoln House
description: GLEN COVE, L.I. April 15 The 53yearold Lincoln Settlement House will bene fit from the proceeds of the fourth annual dinner dance to be held at the Nassau Country Club here on Sat urday. Ben Ludlow and his orchestra will play for danc ing.

title: BARTOW L. HEMINWAY
description: WATERTOWN, Conn. April 15Bartow Lewis Heminway, president of the Heminway Cor poration of Waterbury, a print ing and Paper box manufactur ing company, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

title: Stephen Muskie Plans to Wed Miss Alexis Droggitis in June
description: BIDDEFORD, Me., April 15 Stephen Muskie, son of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, and Mrs. Muskie, and Miss Alexis Droggitis, a fellow student at the Uni versity of Maine, will be married on June 21. An out door ceremony is planned at the Muskie summer home in Kennebunk Beach.

title: 9 Defense Budgets Ranging From $59Billion to $88Billion Are Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Nine possible defense budgets ranging from $59billion to $88 hillion were offered today as potential altternatives to the $71.8billion defense budget re cently requested by the Nixon Administration.

title: Chess:
Father's Image Still Haunts Cerdan
description: In Ring No. 1 under the trapeze and tightropes of Madison Square Garden yes terday, a trainer put three bears through a rehearsal, while in Ring No. 3, Marcel Cerdan Jr. and his wife, Danielle, posed with the jugglers for the benefit of news photographers.

title: SAIGON UNITS RAZE BASE IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15  South Vietnamese troops, operating with a token force of Cambodians, destroyed a North Vietnamese base camp inside Cambodia yesterday in the first major combined oper ation reported in the war, informed sources said today.

title: Marie Carter To Be a Bride
description: Miss Marie Ophelia Carter, a senior of Spelman Col lege in Atlanta, and Ray mond Carl Henry, a senior at New York Medical College, plan to be married at the Community Church on May 30.

title: Newborn Child's Health Linked By Study to Weight of Mother,
description: Thin women should be urged to gain wieght before they be come pregnant in order to in crease their chances of having a healthy baby, an obstetrician recommended here yesterday. His recommendation was based on a study of 87,858 births.

title: Columbia Honors Cane, Lawyer and Poet, at 91
description: Columbia University marked the 91st birthday yesterday of Melville Cane, lawyer poet, by establishing the Cane Collection3,000 items documenting his twin careers over 70 years.

title: Robert Sparr's 'Once You Kiss a Stranger'
description: ACCORDING to the critic's sheet, the screenplay to Robert Sparr's "Once you Kiss a Stranger," playing with "Frankenstein Must Be Destroyed," was suggested by a novel by Patricia Highsmith. I assume the novel is "Strangers on a Train," for "Once You Kiss a Stranger" builds upon the same premise of murder by surrogate that Alfred Hitchcock used in his great 1951 film.But in place of the psychological complexities of Hitchcock's "Strangers," this movie substitutes a few sexual simplicities. And for the multiple personalities crises of Farley Granger and Robert Walker, it offers a one-dimensional parody of psychotic menace as bad-girl Carol Lynley preys upon good-guy Paul Burke.Burke plays a struggling professional golfer whose tournament nemesis (Philip Carey) is killed as an unrequested favor by Miss Lynley, an attractive young homicidal maniac, who in return wants him to eliminate her psychiatristso she can go to Europe rather than to the crazy house, where she belongs.Admirers of "Strangers on a Train" will recall that the killer thinks he has devised a perfect crime of motiveless murders, which the sharers must keep secret and for which he will plant false evidence (the famous cigarette lighterwhich reappears in "Once You Kiss a Stranger") only if his partner reneges.But Carol Lynley sets about things as if her real purpose were publicity, and the point of the plot (let alone whatever meaning it might have been given) is lost in her expertise with sneaky creepy TV cameras, edited tapes, and the fancier paraphernalia of blackmail.Committed to a spiritual desert between the golf course and the gossip column, "Once You Kiss a Stranger" wastes even its random cruelties in conspicuous display.Among the cast, Carol Lynley seems more interesting than her role. Martha Hyer (as Burke's estranged wife) seems even less interesting than her role, and Peter Lind Hayes (as an ancient tournament competitor) develops a horrendous characterization of country-club rusticity that, according to the film, is "known in golfing circles as 'the Old Pro.'"

title: MRS. R. BARRY KAMM
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., April 15Mrs. Tillie J. Kamm died today at her home. She was 54 years old, the wife of R. Barry Kamm of 449 Broadway here, public director of the city of Long Branch.

title: George Thomas, 70, Dies; Former Fashion Designer
description: George Thomas, a former fashion designer and, since 1960, business manager for David Barrett, the interior de signer, died yesterday at his home, 15 West 55th Street, after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: The stock market lumbered along in search of a gain yes terday but ended with another loss.

title: Credit Markets: Bond Prices Register a Decline
description: Bond prices continued to de cline pushed down by the weight of the supply of new issues currently being market ed.

title: 4,000 Workers on Census Are Still Needed in City
description: Census workers, particularly blacks and Puerto Ricans, are urgently needed in all parts of New York City, John C. Cul linane, regional director for the New York Area, Bureau of the Census, reported yesterday.

title: HAYMAKER HURT DURING 2D GAME
description: ATLANTA, April 15 (AP)  The Atlanta Hawks, facing a tough assignment, today re ceived news that made it even tougher.

title: Industry Gets Product Safety Tax Plan
description: A product safety tax sys tem, designed to compensate accident victims when product safety is a factor, was proposed yesterday to an audience of 100 businessmen by New York City's Commissioner of Con sumer Affairs, Mrs. Bess Myer son Grant.

title: SENATOR SUGGESTS ENVIRONMENT CODE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15  Senator Raylord Nelson, Dem ocrat of Wisconsin, today called for a wide range of na tional policies to curb envi ronmental pollution.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series)

title: O.A.S. Opens Study of Ways To End Political Kidnappings
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (Reuters)The Organization of American States began study today to seek ways of com bating the upsurge of kidnap pings and shootings of diplo mats and political figures in Latin America.

title: Shelepin in Ulyanovsk
description: MOSCOW, April 15. (UPI) Aleksander N. Shelepin, Soviet trade union leader led delega tion today to Lenin's birth place, Ulyanovsk, on the Volga to open a week of festivities observing the 100th birthday of the founder of the Soviet Union. Mr. Shelepin made his first public appearance after surgery in Moscow last week.

title: 3 and 6Month Profits Dip
Susan W. Lodge to Marry in July
description: BROOKLYN, Conn., April 15  Miss Susan Williams Lodge and Arthur John Peck Jr. plan to be married July 18.

title: Observer: Light Relief Breaks Out All Over
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  What a strange time. Nothing seems quite real, especially in Washington. These statesmen, are they really to be taken se riously?

title: Military Exercise Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) About 60,000 troops of all services will take part in a threeweek training exercise near Camp Lejeune, N. C., in late May and early June, the Pentagon announced today. The exercise, called Exotic Dancer III, will include airborne and amphibious operations.

title: Policeman in Coptor Spots 8 Hot Cars in 95 Minutes
description: KANSAS CITY (AP)Sgt. Stephen Neiburs riding as an observer in a police helicop ter, spotted eight stolen auto mobiles in an hour and 35 min utes.

title: Curb on All Pesticides Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Federal controls on all pesti cides were proposed today by Senator Gaylord Nelson, Demo crat of Wisconsin, as a means cif halting potential coviion mental damage.

title: Moon Rock a Las Vegas Hit
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov., April 15 (AP)A tiny fragment of moon rock outdrew the most lavish show here during a weeklong display on the Las Vegas Strip. Officials at the Stardust Hotel, where the glimmering piece of the moon brought back by the astronauts of Apollo 12 was displayed, said yesterday that 22,000 persons filed past it in six days last week. About 10,000 people see the most suc cessful strip show in one week.

title: Chiefs' SeasonTicket Sale Hits 70,000 Mark for 1971
description: KANSAS CITY, April 15 (AP) The Kansas City Chiefs an nounced today that 1971 sea Ison ticket sales had reached the 70,000 mark and that no additional orders could he con firmed for the first year in their new stadium.

title: Revenue Service Gives LastMinute Assistance
description: On the last day for filing 1969 Federal income tax re turns, more than 2.500 peo ple went to the Internal Rev enue Service offices at 120 Church Street to get assis tance in preparing their re turns.

title: Calm Director of Space Flights
description: HOUSTON, April 15When a ruptured oxygen tank stripped Apollo 13 of its pri mary power system, one man in particular was instrumen tal in engineering a quick response by the flight con trollers on the ground. He is Sigurd Arnold Sjoberg (pro nounced SHOWberg), a calm man who is direc for of light opera tions for the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Admin ministration. It is his responsibility to plan and analyze space missions, in cluding recovery operation, and to supervise ground sup port operations. He also co ordinates the various compo nents of Mission Control the communications net and the computer complex, for exampleand feeds informa tion to the flight controller who advises the crew.

title: UNIT PRICING HERE BLOCKED BY COURT
description: The city's plan to compel retail grocers to indicate the price per unit as well as the overall cost of virtually every item on their shelves was blocked yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice who indi cated that the city had exceeded its authority in setting the regu lation.

title: Some Art's Way Out  This Is Way Up
description: WASHINGTON  Vera Si mons's balloons are not the threeforaquarter type. Hers are on exhibit here in the Explorations show pro duced by Gyorgy Kepes, di rector of the. Center for Advanced Visual Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The exhibit, which continues through May 10 at the Smithsonian's Na tional Collection of Fine Arts, is sponsored by the Interna tional Art Program.

title: NETS TURN BACK COLONELS, 123112
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 15 (UPI)Eddie Johnson and Levern Tart ignited a 34 point thirdquarter scoring spree tonight that led the New York Nets to a 123112 victory over the Kentucky Colonels in the final American Basketball Association regularseason name for both teams.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock marked opened firm yesterday follow ing the announcement of the British budget on Tuesday, but profit taking brought prices lower at the close.

title: 6% U.S. PAY INCREASE SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) President Nixon signed today legislation granting a 6 per cent acrossthehoard increase to all civilian salaried employes of the Federal Government, in cluding postal workers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 16, 1970

title: CHICAGO 12 FUGITIVE SEIZED HERE BY F.B.I.
description: Linda Evans, one of the 12 members of the Weathermen wanted in Chicago on Federal antiriot charges, was arrested here yesterday morning by the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion.

title: Chemical Concern Off 8%
description: The Monsanto Company re ported yesterday that firstquar ter earnings declined by 8 per cent from a year earlier but that sales improved by 6 per cent.

title: Bridge:
description: ONE of the world's great est players, Jean Besse of Switzerland, paid a brief business visit to New York last weekenu and found time to play bridge in a private game at the home of Edgar Kaplan.

title: Charles McMurtry of A.P.; Covered War in Pacific
description: BURLINGAE, alif., April 15 (AP)Charles McMurtry, and Associated Press corre spondent, writer and editor for 35 years, died last night of cancer. He was 66 years old.

title: Harvard Junior Plans to Marry Miss Saltzman
description: Mrs. C. Myrick Saltzman of New York and East Hampton, L. I., and Charles Eskridge Saltzman of New York have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Cynthia Myrick Saltzman, to Warren Motley 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Motley of Acton, Mass.

title: 12 Countries Offer to Help In Recovery of Astronauts
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 President Nixon today re ceived offers of assistance in recovering the Apollo 13 astronauts from a dozen nations, ranging from the Soviet Union to the small African republic of Burundi. London, Paris, Moscow and Brasilia sent messages offering ships to help in rescue operations if necessary.

title: SALT II
