description: The sorry truth about the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) that resume today in Vienna is that hopes for halting the nuclear missile race ride for the moment with the Soviet delegation.

title: TRUSTEES SOUGHT FOR BOSTON & MAINE
description: Federal Judge Francis J. W. Ford in Boston invited the Boston & Maine Corporation and its creditors yesterday to nominate possible trustees for the bankrupt railroad.

title: MORTGAGE CEILING IN JERSEY RAISED
description: TRENTON, April 15Warn ing that the construction of housing in New Jersey has fallen drastically, the State Banking Commissioner an nounced today that he was increasing the state ceiling on interest rates on conventional home mortgage loans from 7 to 8 per cent.

title: FRANCE TO STRESS BIG GROWTH RATE
description: PARIS, April 5The French Cabinet decided today to press ahead in its planning targets over the next five years with relatively high rate of economic growth even though this might bring new troubles for the franc.

title: Eskin Group Makes Bid
description: The Chicano, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad, which in February lost a muchwanted suitor, found itself yesterday with what it considered an un wanted one.

title: Rocket Contract Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  A $5.18million contract has been awarded to Pratt Whitney Aircraft division, West Palm Beach, Fla., by the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration for 18 rocket engines of the type used for moon shots.

title: Advertising: New Sports Illustrated Page
description: It'll be interesting to see how I do in this job. I've certainly been prepared for it, said Dick Munro, since December publisher of Sports Illustrated.

title: Painter to Update Its World Sought by Florida Museum
description: MIAMI (AP)People at the Museum of Science here are the first to admit the world is in a mess.

title: BLUES WILL SEEK CLINCHER TONIGHT
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 15 (AP)The St. Louis Blues return to the Metropolitan Sports Center here tomorrow night with ideas of polishing off the Minnesota North Stars and winning their National Hockey League Stanley Cup, quarterfinal series.

title: LONBORG AND LYLE ALLOW BUT 6 HITS
description: BOSTON, April 15  If it were the middle of July, only the manager and a few dili gent observers might realize the Yankees are in a slump.

title: Maltese Strike Continues
description: VALLETTA, Malta, April 15 (Reuters)A stroke of Maltese Government employes entered its second day today as rela tives were forced to bury their own dead and water supplies dwindled on this Mediterranean island.

title: Taiwan Builds for Expo
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) Two wings have been added to the Palace Museum at a cost of $700,000 in anticipation of the million tourists expected to visit Taiwan en route to or from Expo '70 in Osaka, Japan.

title: HUGO A. LEANDER, 75, HEADED 3 CONCERNS
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 15  Hugo Austin Leander, a New York industrialist, died yester day at Stamford Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 5 Old Parish Road here.

title: Seattle Skipper's Dragon Takes Regatta in Bahamas
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 15 (AP)Bill Henry of Seattle, sailing Jinx won the Dragon Class sailing championship to day. Second was Mike Nunes of Kingston, in El Blanco. Third was Godfrey Kelly of the Ba hamas, in Guanahani.

title: Swing to Protectionism
description: Chairman Wilbur Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee has introduced an omnibus trade bill that includes mandatory quotas on textile and shoe imports, cutting them back to the level of 196768. While the bill is designed most specifically to hit Japan, which is refusing to accept voluntary quotas on textiles, it will hurt many other countries as well and probably provoke retaliation. The bill threatens reverse the long drive for freer trade in this country that began in the depths of the Depression and con tinued through the Kennedy Round of tariff reduction In the 1960's.

title: Legislators' Suit on Budget Rejected by Appeals Court
description: ALBANY, April 15  The Court of Appeals ruled today that three Democratic Assem blymen seeking to have the 1969 state budget declared un constitutional lacked standing as legislators and as taxpayers to challenge in the judicial branch the validity of appro priation bills submitted by the Governor.

title: CAMBODIA INFORMS ENVOYS OF APPEAL
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 15  Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur informed chiefs of dip lomatic missions today of the Cambodian Government's uni versal appeal for arms assist ance against Vietnamese Com munist invasion.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: SILVER FUTURES REGISTER A PROF
description: Silver futures on the New York Commodity Exchange dipped again yesterday after dropping the day before.

title: ANTIWAR PROTEST IS HELD MIDTOWN
description: The first major demonstration here against the war in Viet nam in five months drew a crowd estimated at 25,000 peo ple to Bryant Park yesterday afternoon, but their protest was nearly drowned out by slogans shouted by a variety of small radical groups.

title: Welfare Plan Survives a Test; House Approval Likely Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Nixon Administration's welfare reform bill narrowly survived preliminary test on the House floor today but is still expected to win final approval tomorrow.

title: WALLACE BROTHER ASSAILS NEWSMAN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 15Gerald O. Wallace, brother of former Gov. George C. Wal lace, charged yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had supplied information about his income tax returns to the syn didated newspaper columnist Jack Anderson.

title: 300 JERSEY YIPPIES CLASH WITH POLICE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 15Two Rutgers Univer sity students were arrested to day during a series of scattered confrontations between Yippies and the police.

title: Number of Crewmen of Lost Soviet Submarine Saved, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 A number of Soviet crewmen aboard a nuclear submarine believed to have been lost off Spain over the weekend have been rescued by Soviet sur face ships, a Pentagon source reported today. The source did not say how many were rescued or indeed, whether the entire had made it to safety. The submarine, No vember class designed to find and attack other subma rines and surface ships, nor mally carries a crew of 88. Pentagon sources speculate that the submarine suffered a ruptured hul when, while rid ing on the surface, it took on more water in high seas than it was able to pump out. When the submarine was first sighted last Friday by American reconnaissance planes, two Soviet surface ships were trying to take her under tow. The Pentagon re ported the apparent loss of the submarine on Monday after oil slicks had been ob served in the area.

title: Police Quell Radical Rampage on Columbia Campus
description: More than 200 policemen moved onto the Columbia University campus last night after about the same number of radical students and their supporters went on a window smashing, painthurling foray.

title: Harsh Realities in Greece
description: JeanJacques ServanSchreiber has brought off an admirable coup in persuading Premier Papadopoulos to free Mikis Theodorakis and to permit the ailing Greek composer to go to France far medical treatment.

title: Oil Output in Texas To Be Lower in May
description: Oil Output in Texas To Be Lower in May

title: Robert Riggs, Artist, Dies at 74; Lithographs in Many Museums
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 Robert Riggs, an artist whose lithographs of circuses and prizefights are in several art museums, died last night of heart ailment at his home, 51 West Walnut Lane. He was 74 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: JAMES HOWE, WROTE FOR A.P. 21 YEARS
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., April 15 (AP)James P. Howe, a re tired Associated Press foreign correspondent, died yesterday of a gunshot wound, authorities said. He was 91 years old.

title: MAYOR CRITICIZES AGNEW ON MEDIA
description: Mayor Lindsay took issue yesterday with Vice President Agnew's views if broadcast ing's role as a molder of public opinion. The Mayor urged radio and television to lead, to point the way, not wait to report that someone else has found it.

title: Next Year's Form 1040 May Bar Instructions on Backs of Pages
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Next year's basic Federal in come tax form, the Form 1040, may eliminate one of the fea tures that people have com plained about the most this year: The fact that the instruc tions for various parts of the return are on the backs of pages that have to be filed with the return.

title: California Children Refuse To Yield Their Frog Pond
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif. (AP)  The city, surrendering to a frog pond and children power, has scrapped plans for part of a stormdrain system.

title: Flight Director Is Making the Decisions
description: HOUSTON, April 15The Apollo 13 flight director's voice had a distinct edge to it.

title: Charity Bouts Here Aid Minority Groups
description: Politics and sports, kissing cousins in New York for a long time, blended last night at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club in the Grand Central Terminal Building.

title: Task Force Is Set To Help Investors If a Broker Fails
description: The major stock exchanges and the other selfregulatory bodies of the securities in dustry have created a task force to establish a new pro gram of protection for inves tors in case of brokeragehouse failures.

title: DOMINICANS DELAY RETURN OF BOSCH
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 15The Do minican Government today pre vented for at least a day the re turn of Juan D. Bosch, exiled rival of President Joaquin Ba laguer.

title: Printers and Newspapers Strive to Narrow Wage Issue Following a New Offer
description: Negotiators for the printers and the city's four major news papers centered their attention yesterday on the possibility of closing the gap on the critical wafle issue.

title: MOST IN POLL FAVOR LIMITING FREEDOMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 A majority of Americans ap pear ready to restrict basic freedoms guaranteed by the Bill of Rights, according to a poll by the Columbia Broadcasting System, the results of which were broadcast last night.

title: DIG HEROIN CACHE SEIZED IN CHELSEA
description: City narcotics detectives found 220 pounds of pure heroin in a Chelsea apartment yesterday in what was de scribed as one of the largest seizures of illegal drugs in the city's history.

title: British Columbia Legal Age Now 19, the First in Canada
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, April 15 (AP)British Colum bia became the first province in Canada to recognize teen age adults, as legislation low ering the legal age from 21 years to 19 went into effect today.

title: Article 4  No Title
Personal Finance: Bell Debentures
description: The debenture offering be ing made to shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has raised questions among investors. To help clarify them, Robert J. Cole of The New York Times has interviewed Wall Street financial leaders. Ex cerpts from these interviews follow:

title: RADICALS DISRUPT ANTIWAR RALLIES
description: Demonstrations were held across the country yesterday to protest the war in Vietnam and the taxes that help pay for it.

title: Article 1  No Title
Student From School for the Deaf Is Knicks' Loudest Cheerleader
description: Robert Klager smiled proudly yesterday as Nate Bowman, the New York Knicks' reserve center, pinned a button to his uniform shirt before the start of practice at the Lexington School for the Deaf. The blue and white button read, The Lexington Sticks Together  School Spirit.

title: Article 2  No Title
Nationalities Group Hails Mrs. Wallace On Work at Digest
description: Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, co chairman and cofounder of The Reader's Digest, became the first woman to receive the Golden Door Award of the American Council for Nationali ties Service at a dinner last night at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Dead Message Office
description: Sending a Western Union telegram ought to be a matter of a simple contract: payment of a fee by the sender for the service of having the message delivered promptly to the addressee by personal messenger. In actual fact, the company's normal practice nowadays is merely to telephone the addressee's home and dic tate the message to any available adult or child who may be or may not be equipped to scribble it on an old envelope.

title: PATHET LAO REJECTS SOUVANNA PROPOSAL
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 15 (AP)The Laotian Communists have rejected Premier Sou vanna Phourna's proposals to negotiate an end to the Laotian conflict, diplomatic sources here said today.

title: Ford Asks Douglas's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, touched off an angry floor debate tonight by suggesting that Justice William O. Douglas might have had tics with gambling and underworld figures.

title: MOBS IN JORDAN SACK U.S. OFFICES
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 15 Nearly 1,000 students, led by uniformed Palestinian com mandos, set fire today to the United States Information Cen ter here and another mob stormed into the United States Embassy compound.

title: Holy Land Outraces a Pair Of Kentucky Derby Hopefuls
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 15 (AP)  Three Kentucky Derby candidates went to the post in the eighth race at Gulfstream Park today.

title: BRANDT REPORTS U.S. BACKS BONN'S POLICY
description: BONN, April 15Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that he had the understanding, sup port and trust of the United States Government in his con tinuing efforts to improve re lations with the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Times Mirror to Get Control of Newsday
description: LOS ANGELES, April 15 The Times Mirror Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, announced today that it would purchase a controlling interest in Newsday, the pros perous Long Island paper pub lished in Garden City.

title: Barber Says Air Pollution Puts Wear on His Clippers
description: PONTIAC, Mich. (UPI)  A barber in this industrial city, the home of the Pontiac Motor Division of General Motors, has discovered a new problem cre ated by air pollution.

title: Market Place
description: CAN the most efficient brokerage houses afford to do business without the new transaction charge re cently put into effect?

title: Excerpts From Council of Europe's Report on Treatment of Prisoners in Greece
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 15Following, as made public today by the Council of Europe, are excerpts from a report by the European Commission on Human Rights on the situation under the military Government in Greece. The first section is testimony by Mrs. Anastasia Tsirlea, who was arrested in connection with pamphlets deemed suspicious. The sec ond section consists of com ment by the commission.

title: Nuclear Workers Strike At Two Oak Ridge Plants
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 15 About 4,400 workers went on strike today for higher wages at two of the three big nuclear plants in Oak Ridge, where to tal employment is more than 13.000.

title: Washington Higl Scene of Rampage; 6 Youths Arrested
description: Six youths were arrested yes terday following another dis ??bance at troubleplagued George Washington High School in which union officials said eight members of the teaching staff were injured.

title: Five More Cars Enter 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 15 (UPI)Five more cars were entered in the Indianapolis 500 mile race and eight to 10 more machines were expected to be named through the mail with postmarks before the deadline of midnight today. The entries raised the field seeking qualify ing berths to 70.

title: Imported Meat Checks Scored
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) 6Representative John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, said to day that Government inspection of imported meat falls a thou sand miles short of standards for domestic meat. Mr. Melcher added that less than 1 per cent of the 1.6 billion pounds of meat arriving in the United States each year is inspected.

title: A STRONAUTS FIRE ROCKE AND CORRECT AIM AS THEY PREPARE FOR SANDING TOMORROW
description: HOUSTON, Thursday, April 16The astronauts of Apollo 13, struggling homeward in their damaged spacecraft, fired a rocket late last night that put them on an exact course for the earth.

title: LTY DISPUTES CELLER ON DEBTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  Disputing contentions that its debts exceed its assets, the management of LingTemco Vought, Inc., told a House sub committee today, that it could retire its obligations at under 50 cents on the dollar and hoped to do so by selling off subsidiaries.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMHenry. In memory of our beloved father who passed away. April 16, 1945. LEAH and FRED.

title: Hunter Faculty Votes to Retain Governing Body
description: Fulltime faculty members at Hunter College voted yesterday not to dissolve the current gov erning body at the college and replace it with a college senate consisting of 50 per cent stu dent and 50 per cent faculty representatives.

title: AWARDS ARE MADE FOR DRIVING FEATS
description: YONKERS, April 15  Del Insko and George Sholty, two drivers who, if one stood upon the other's shoulder might match Lew Alcindor's height, were honored tonight at Yonkers Raceway, before the racing program.

title: Seder Menu: Traditional but Different
description: BAKING challah and onion bread is a Friday morn ing ritual for Mrs. Solomon Feffer, except during the eight days of Passover. Then, all forms of chametz, or leavened foods, are forbid den.

title: Stage: 2 Plays by Pinget
description: LE TRETEAU DE PARIS'S second program of French contemporary drama at the BarbizonPlaza Theater opened last night with Lettre Morte and Architruc by Robert Pinget.

title: In The Nation: What's a Strict Constructionist?
description: WASHINGTON, April 15In Judge Blackmun, it is said, President Nixon has found the strict constructionist of the Constitution for which he had been searching. The new nom inee looks like a man who can be confirmed, moreover, wheth er or not he is whatever a strict constructionist is.

title: State U. Aide Resigns
description: ALBANY, April 15 (UPI)  J. Lawrence Murray, vice chan cellor for administration of the State University of New York, resigned today to become ex ecutive director of the State Health and Mental Hygiene Facilities Improvement Corpo ration effective May I S. The position pays $34,000 a year.

title: Roundup: Braves' Bats Still Thunder
description: While Luman Harris's starting pitchers don't expect much rest in the immediate future, opposing pitchers wonder if they can expect any rest from Harris's hit ters.

title: Yale Lacrosse Team Beats Hofstra for 4th in Row, 63
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15  Tom Fagan and Jay Rauth scored two goals apiece today to lead Yale's lacrosse team to its fourth successive victory with a 63 decision over Hofstra.

title: KOPECHNE CASE DATA ARE DELAYED AGAIN
description: BOSTON, April 15 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit cleared the way today for making Mary Jo Kopechne in quest documents public, but another delay developed.

title: Soccer Star Out 3 Weeks
description: TURIN, Italy, April 15 (AP) Helmuth Haller, star German player on the juventus team in the Italian soccer league who was injured recently, had hisl dislocated shoulder placed in a cast today. Doctors said he would require no surgery and indicated he would he out of action for three weeks.

title: Migrant Food Plan Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Special food and food stamp programs for families of mi grant workers were advocated today by the director of Michi gan Stale University's Rural Manpower Center. Dr. Daniel Sturt, the director, testified be fore a Senate labor subcom mittee.

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: PARIS  Stanley Hayward, 164 pounds, Philadelphia, and Pascal Di Benedetto, 165, France, drew, 10 rounds.

title: Putting Life Back Into Hair
description: DISASTER, say the beauty experts, when they think of such things as air pollu tion, overheated rooms, late nights and overindulgence in the wrong foods. But, of course, the experts are on hand to combat these disas ters and if the war is never really won, at least the ene my's advance is halted. Two of the areas most susceptible to the elements are the hair and the skin. The everincreasing number of European specialists who are settling here have made these two fields their par ticular concern. The small salon of Georgette Briand is one of the newest and most specialized. Mrs. Briand's card says Etheirologie and translated into its simplest terms, it means treating and conditioning the hair.

title: Buenos Aires Grows Bigger
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 15 This city, which has drawn to itself more than a third of Ar gentina's population, is in dan ger of strangling for lack of housing.

title: In Vienna, SALT Means Tourists, Delegates, Secretaries and Security Men
description: VIENNA, April 15  The baroque doors of the Belve dere Palace creaked open this morning and a halfdoz en workmen trudged quickly inside. The workmen peered for a moment at the white stone cherubs flanking the marble steps and then, with solemn delicacy, taped the American and Russian flags on the stairway.

title: CASPER, TREVINO HEAD GOLF FIELD
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 15 (AP)  Lee Trevino and Billy Casper, the only two players to win two tournaments on the circuit this year, head an un expectedly strong field for the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament starting tomorrow.

title: FLIGHT RESTRICTIONS WILL BE LIFTED SOON
description: George M. Gary, regional di rector of the Federal Aviation Administration, said yesterday that emergency flight restric tions imposed at New York and Chicago because of the air traf fic control slowdown would be eliminated by Sunday, or sooner if possible.

title: Columbia Subdues N.Y.U. Nine, 40; St. John's Is Victor
description: Jim Romanosky hurled a fourhitter yesterday as Colum bia's baseball team defeated New York University, 40, at Baker Field. Romanosky, a sophomore righthander, pitched his second completegame vic tory of the season. He has 1.50 earnedrun average.

title: Foes of Direct Popular Vote for President Begin a Counterattack
description: WASHINGTON. April 13  Opponents of the proposal that the President he chosen by di rect popular vote opened counterattack today in an ef fort to block Senate approval of the plan.

title: Owners Discussing Deal
description: The fight between the Madi son Square Garden Corporation and Transnation Development Corporation for control of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., ap pears to he reaching a solution. Yesterday, Madison Square Garden indicated that it is not opposed to selling its 37.5 per cent holding in the racetrack to Transnation, holder of 26 per cent of the Roosevelt com mon stock.

title: Switzerland Gives Asylum To Sik, Former Czech Aide
description: GENEVA, April 15Switzer land granted political asylum today to Dr. Ota Sik former Deputy premier of Czechoslo vakia, who was the author of the economic reforms that were under way when Soviet troops occupied the country in Au gust, 1968.

title: Apollo 13 Rocket Caused a Moonquake
description: HOUSTON, April 15  When the 15ton rocket that gavel Apollo 13 its final push toward the moon last Saturday crashed into the moon last night, the Ocean of Storms trembled for three hours and 20 minutes.

title: The Privacy of Tax Returns
description: The millions of Americans whose income tax returns have been flooding into the Internal Revenue Service this week have been assured over the years that the Government will respect the confidentiality of those returns.

title: Hoses and Friction Tape Solve a Critical Problem
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  An improvised chemical air cleaning system seems to have solved Apollo 13's most critical supply problem for the flight back to earth.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THE wildlife swap begun a few years ago, in which West Virginia agreed to ac cept 25 New Hampshire fish ers in exchange for 25 tur keys, is nearly completed.

title: Current Problem Called Worse Than Anticipated
description: Thomas 3. Kelly, chief de signer of the lunar lander, heard about the trouble on the Apollo 13 mission through a call that awakened him early Tuesday morning at his home in Winchester, Mass.

title: Karl G. Linderoth, 42, Dies; Management Official Here
description: Karl G. Linderoth, a vice president of Bruce Payne & As sociates, Inc., New York man agement consultants, died in an automobile accident in Copen hagen Friday. He was 42 years old and lived at 200 Eleven O'Clock Road. Fairfield, Conn.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Control Pollution

title: Harlem Building Fight Ebbs
description: Seven months after the po lice cleared squatters from the site of the proposed state office building in Harlem, construction crews are about to begin laying concrete for the 22story structure's foun dation.

title: 6FootCube Glass Box Car Due Here
description: A car that looks like an aquarium on wheels is ex pected to be introduced next week in a department store here.

title: Suharto to Visit U.S. in May
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) President Nixon announced to day that, President Suharto of Indonesia will make a state vis it to Washington May 2627 ??

title: JAN. 15 VOTE BACKED EASIER RESERVE REIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided to aim for a resumption of modest growth in money and bank credit as early as its meeting of Jan. 15, it was dis closed today.

title: U.S. Seeks International Talks On Maritime Passage in Arctic
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The State Department called today for an international con ference to establish rules gov erning the passage of ships and the protection of natural resources in Arctic waters be yond national jurisdictions.

title: Hundreds of Bodies Of Vietnamese Seen In Cambodian River
description: NEAK LEUNG, Cambodia, April 15  The bodies of hun dreds of Vietnamese floated down the Mekong River in southeast Cambodia today, many with their hands tied behind them. They appeared to be victims of a mass killing.

title: MAZER CONDUCTS STRAUSS PROGRAM
description: In this dietconscious age the overly rich tone poems of Rich ard Strauss are less common concert fare than they used to be. But last night the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra went whole hog in its last appearance of the season in Carnegie Hall and served up an allStrauss program, including two tone poems. These were fortunately separated by the more spare Four. Last Songs.

title: Executive Changes
description: Dwight N. Wait has been named president, and Charles B. Under executive vice president of the fibers and fabrics division of the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Memorial Services
description: WAKEFIELDEva Ingersoll Brown. Service Sunday, Mar 10th, at Community Church, 40 E. 35th St., at 1:030 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to R. G. Inger soll Memorial Association, 144 E 24th St., NY 10010.

title: 68 MISSING IN ALPS AFTER AVALANCHE
description: SAINT  GERVAIS, France, Thursday, April 16Sixtyeight persons  nearly all of them children  were missing today after an avalanche engulfed three buildings of a tuberculosis sanitarium near this French Alpine center, the police said.

title: Senate Approves Ban on Mailing of Unsolicited Credit Cards
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Senate passed today a bill to outlaw the issuance of un solicited credit cards. In doing so, it brushed aside objections of the Nixon Administration and Federal banking authorities.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Vietnam:

title: BOYCOTT SNARES FORDHAN CLASSES
description: Students boycotted classes at Fordham University yesterday in a demonstration demanding, tneure for a popular professor and greater student participa tion in academic policies.

title: Frankenstein Makes His Return
Miss Bakker Is Eliminated In Carolina Tennis Opener
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 15 (AP)Laura DuPont of Char lotte upset Ada Bakker, the Dutch star, 75, 57, 62, in the opening round of the $18,000 Carolinas international tennis tournament today. Miss Du Pont ranks No. 1 in North

title: Apollo 13 Brings Delay In Nixon's Troop Talk
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Because of the Apollo 13 flight difficulties, Presi dent Nixon today put off un til the first of the week the report to the nation he had scheduled for tomorrow night on Vietnam and United States troop levels there.

title: Big 4 Meet on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aprl 15The delegates of the Big Fourthe United States, France, the Soviet Union and Britainmet today to consider the progress of their deputies in drafting a summary of their discussions on a peace settle ment between Israel and her Arab neigbors. Diplomats said the delegates had expressed satisfaction with the deputies' work and had instructed them to continue it.

title: Contempt Citation Appealed
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15An attorney for two national Black Panther party leadersDavid Hilliard and Emory Douglas appealed their contemptof court convictions today to the Connecticut Supreme Court. The two were sentenced to six months' imprisonment yester day after a scuffle with deputy, sheriffs in Superior Court here. They had been watching pre trial hearings for five other Panthers, who are accused of murder.

title: CARAMOOR FESTIVAL WILL OPEN JUNE 20
description: The 25th season of the Caramoor Festival at Katonah, N. Y., will open on June 20 with a performance of Mozart's Idomeneo. The opera will be staged by Tito Capobianco and conducted by Julius Rudel and will have a cast headed by George Shirley, Maralin Niska, John Stewart and Bianca Sauler. The work will be given in the Venetian Theater at Caramoor and will be repeated there on June 26.

title: DeVita Convicted of Obstructing Justice
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15 Ralph DeVita, a suspended Un ion County District Court judge, was found guilty here today of obstructing justice but not guil ty of bribery.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ONCE upon a time Redwood High School, in a suburb of San Francisco, had a rule for its athletes. This was the rule: Hair cannot fall below or over shirt collars and must not fall over ears. Sideburns must not longer than the midear level.

title: BROOKINGS LISTS BUDGET OPTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Brookings Institution, in the first project of its kind, pub lished today a detailed analysis of the national priorities choices and options disclosed in President Nixon's first budget.

title: Wedding Set By Miss Woltz
description: MOUNT AIRY, N. C., April 15Mr. and Mrs. William Kingsbury Woltz have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Winhourne Woltz, to John Clark Fennebresque, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Drouet Fennebresque of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: CHOMPION SECOND IN 7HORSE FIELD
description: Form, which had stood up almost perfectly in the earlier races on the card, was reversed in the feature at Aqueduct yes terday. Good Manners, racing in the silks of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rapisarda's AlJo Stable, won the mile event by a length and a half over C. V. Whitney's Chompion, with King of the Castle next in the field of seven. As the nexttolast outsider in the betting, Good Manners paid $23.80.

title: ExMarine Named Head Of Penn Central Police
description: A former Marine Corps captain will head Penn Cen tral's steppedup campaign to curb vandalism and crime on the railroad. Its new superin tendent of police is Donald M. Gibson of Levittown, Pa., who has served as inspector of railroad police at Pennsyl vania Station here.

title: Lights Out to Spare Birds
description: The floodlights illuminating the upper 30 floors of the Empire State Building will be turned off from dusk until mid night from now to May 31 so that migrating birds returning north this spring will not be come confused and fly into the structure. In the fall, the lights again will be turned off from Sept. 15 to Nov. 1 for the south bound migration. The procedure was begun in 1955 at the urg ing of the National Audubon Society.

title: New Publisher Chosen For Vogue Magazine
description: Richard A. Shortyway, for 20 years a Cond Nast man, has been named publisher of Vogue as S. I. Newhouse Jr. moves up to publishing direc tor.

title: Conservatives' Outnumber the Liberals, 3 to 2, in Gallup Poll on Attitudes
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 15 The American people by the ratio of 3to2 prefer to be la beled as conservatives rather than as liberals, according to the Gallop Poll.

title: GIJGGENHEIM FUND GIVES 286 GRANTS
description: Guggenheim fellowships to taling $2,605,000 have been awarded to 286 scholars, scien tists and artists.

title: 55 Members of House Sponsor Bill to Require Dating of Packaged Foods
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Fiftyfive members of the House joined today in sponsor ing a bill to require the open dating of packaged foods sold by supermarkets and other re tailers.

title: BANKER TERMS WAR A TRAGIC MISTAKE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)Louis B. Lundborg, the head of the world's largest private bank said today that the Vietnam war was a tragic mistake that had distorted the United States economy.

title: Cross Talk Afflicts A.T.&T.'s Annual Meeting
description: CLEVELAND, April 15  Guarded by several hundred helmeted police on foot and on horseback, the American Tele phone and Telegraph company held its 85th annual meeting in Public Auditorium here to day.

title: Nixon Asks Great Lakes Dumping Ban;
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  In a message to Congress today, President Nixon said that he would soon propose legislation to prohibit the Army Corps of Engineers and private industry from dumping polluted dredg ings into the Great Lakes.

title: WASHINGTON CHOIR SHOWS DEDICATION
description: The sheer fervor of 106 dedi cated human beings singing together can lead to an im pressive musical experience, and that's what happened al Carnegie Hall last night.

title: Article 3  No Title
Iroquois Are Seeking Return of Wampum Belts Held by State Museum
description: ALBANY, April 16 (AP) Leaders of the Iroquois Con federacy appealed to New York officials today to return to them religious and politi cal wampum belts in custody of the state under a 72year old agreement whose validity the Indians are challenging.

title: Home Loan Bank Sets 7% Rate For Savings Groups' Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today a new program of oneyear advances to savings and loan associations at a subsidized interest rate of 7 per cent, aimed at maintaining the volume of mortgage lending.

title: Ski Conditions
description: The following reports were provided by the operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in par entheses:

title: State and Local officials Back Nixon Revenue Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  In a rare display of unity, the nation's Governors, Mayors, state legislators and county of ficials announced today that they would push in Congress for approval this year of Pres ident Nixon's revenue sharing proposal.

title: MRS. KING ADVANCES IN MONACO TENNIS
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 16 (AP)  Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., became the only United States women's survivor as Rosemary Casals and Julie Heldman bowed today in the quarterfinals of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament.

title: NOWHERE TO LOOK FOR NETS BUT UP
description: Lou Carnesecca smiled as he looked up from his desk yes terday in the office of the New York Nets at Hempstead, L. I. Things were looking up for the American Basketball Associa tion. A call from the A.B.A. commissioner's office had brought the news that two and possibly three games of the league's championship series would be televised nationally by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: British Columbia Legal Age Now 19, the First in Canada
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, April 15 (AP)British Colum bia became the first province in Canada to recognize teen age adults, as legislation low ering the legal age from 21 years to 19 went into effect Wednesday.

title: Shifts at Chicago Bank
description: The formation of an executive department of the First National, Bank of Chicago was announced yesterday. It will be headed by Christopher W. Wilson, execu tive vice president, who also was elected general counsel for the bank. Also announced was the appointment of James P. Baxter, senior vice president, as head of the bank's trust department.

title: Time Inc. Reports a Recovery
description: Time Inc., the world's largest publishing company, reported yesterday that it had made a recovery in the first quarter of the year. Op erating earnings for the period were $1,083,000, equal to 15 cents a share, in con trast to an operating loss of $300,000 in the initial three months of 1969.

title: CAMPUS IN BROOKLYN IS DAMAGED BY FIRE
description: A threealarm fire ripped through the main campus build ing at Kingsborough Commu nity College late last nght, de stroying a major wng of the building, which houses the stu dent cafeteria and the director of students' offices.

title: Furniture Makers Go All Out for Modern
description: HIGH POINT, N. C.For the first time, modern furniture has moved into the forefront at the Southern Furniture Market, long the bastion of traditional. If manufacturers have guessed right, the trend toward Medi terranean styling, dominant for the last 10 years, may be on the wane.

title: Khmers vs. Vietnamese
description: Evidence of Governmentinspired mass murder of Vietnamese civilians living in Cambodia should pro voke second thoughts in Washington about the stabil ity as well as the morality of the regime that recently displaced Prince Sihanouk in Pnompenh.

title: Damage Estimated at $100,000 After Harvard Riot
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16  Tear gas still hung in the air near Harvard Yard late to day after a night of rioting led by the November Action Coalition, an offshoot of Stu dents for a Democratic Society.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 16, 1970

title: EDWARD J. HALL
description: JERSEY CITY, April 16Ed ward J. Hall, director of the New Jersey State, Employment Service, died Monday at Jersey City Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived here at 117 Kensington Avenue.

title: Harkness Takes Over As Red Wings' Coach
description: DETROIT, April 16 (AP) Ned Harkness, who coached Cornell University to two na tional championships, was named coach of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League today.

title: HOUSE TO PONDER MILDER FUND BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A Hbuse Committee subccirnmit tee, in a move that represented a tremendous victory for the antiregulation forces in the mu tual fund industry, decided to day to substitute legislation that the industry has little or no objection to for a stricter measure that passed the Senate.

title: TV: Working Washington Journalists
description: THE basic inadequacies of television network news coverage, which is essential ly a recital of bulletins with a smidgen of commentary, was illustrated afresh last night in perhaps the best program of its kind, Wash ington Week in Review. The program was seen over the facilities of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and Channel 13.

title: Washington: The Pitiless Political Winds
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The fierce winds and driving rains of early April have sud denly subsided here, and the capital of the United States is ablaze with flowering trees.

title: Books of The Times
description: GRANTED: There's enough to think and read about these days without adding small creatures who spend their days sleeping upside down in caves and their nights chasing moths. Even it's true that bats don't really stick in one's hair or suck Transylvanian blood or carry verminso what? They're still none too beautiful to look at, with their rub bery wings and gleaming little fangs. And besides, perhaps the scientific searchlight has exposed enough; maybe a few horrible little fantasies should be left intact.

title: Nixon Revises Postal Plan; Calls for an 8c Letter Rate
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Nixon unveiled today a broad compromise plan to reform the postal system, provide more pay and bargaining rights for postal workers and raise additional revenues to narrow the postal deficit.

title: U.S. PLANS SHARING OF AUTO RESEARCH
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 15The United States Govern ment and the major American automobile manufacturers plan to share with foreign manufac turers the fruits of their re search on automotive safety.

title: U.P.I. LETS CONTRACT TO EXTEND COMPUTER
description: United Press International awarded a $1million contract yesterday to Data Dimensions, Inc., for the development and implementation of a highly so phisticated automated system of gathering, editing and dis tributing news.

title: BEAN OIL FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS
description: With oil futures leading the way, activity in the soybean complex on the Chicago Board of Trade was hectic yesterday.

title: DOUGLAS INQUIRY PRESSED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A coalition of 52 Democrats and 52 Republicans called today for creation of a special House committee to consider possible impeachment of Justice Wil liam O. Douglas.

title: DAVID BERGER
description: David Berger, a vice presi dent of ABC Records, Inc., subsidiary of the American Broadcasting Company, died at his home in Forest Hills Wednesday. He was 54 years old.

title: Texts of Opening Statements at Talks in Vienna on Limiting Strategic Weapons
description: On behalf of the United States delegation, I want to thank you, Foreign Minister Waldheim, for your gracious words of welcome. May I also take this opportunity to convey my delegations' ap preciation to you and to the Austrian Government for the cooperation shown in provid ing the site and arrange ments for this second phase of the strategic arms limita tion talks.

title: Malik Says New Geneva Talks Could Bring Solution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet Union's chief delegate to the United Nations, said today that the situation in Southeast Asia is not a matter for the United Nations, but one for a new Geneva Conference.

title: Bankamerica Lists Gains in Quarter
description: The BankAmerica Corpora tion reported yesterday that firstquarter net income rose 15.6 per cent to $36.92million, or $1.07 a share, from $31.94 million, or 93 cents, in the 1969 period.

title: Israeli Jets Strike Along Canal
description: TEL AVIV, April 16 (Reuters) Israeli jets carried out a 70 minute raid tonight on Egyptian military targets along the Suez Canal front, a military spokes man reported. All planes re turned safely, the spokesman said.

title: TRUCK TONNAGE OFF 37.6% FROM '69 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 11, was reported considerably below the corresponding week of last year, following work stoppages throughout. Freight traffic on United States railroads in the same period registered in creased tonnage.

title: Beverly Griffith Is Dead at 82; Led Airline's Public Relations
description: Beverly Griffith, former di rector of public relations and assistant vice president of East ern Airlines, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 77 West 55th Street.

title: MR. RAYMOND MARTIN
description: WILTON, Conn., April 16 Mrs. Margaret L. Martin, the wife of Raymond Martin, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. She was 68 years old, and lived here for 35 years.

title: Ford Is Shown the Site Of Soviet Fiat Factory
description: MOSCOW, April 15 (AP)  Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, toured the construction site of an Ital iandesigned auto plant today 500 miles southeast of Moscow.

title: ORR KILLED US, FRANCIS LAMENTS
description: The sign hanging from the rafters said, We Will Bury You, but it was the Rangers, not the Boston Bruins, who got buried last night at the Gar den.

title: A BREZHNEV GAIN SEEN IN BUDAPEST
description: BUDAPEST, April 14Some Soviet and other East European sources believe that a struggle in the Moscow leadership cul minated early this month in a victory for the Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and possibly in plans to oust some of his associates from key posi tions.

title: MET'S HINDELL GIVES A BASSOON RECITAL
description: The bassoon is an admirably useful ensemble instrument that seems to go well with almost any combination of tone colors, but the mildness that can make it so agreeable in company keeps it from stirring up much interest in solo assignments. Thus, the bassoon recital given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Leonard Hindell, of the Metropolitan Opera Orches tra, was an uncommon event.

title: Rhodesian Head Sworn In
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 16 (AP)Clifford W. Dupont, a 64yearold native of Britain, was sworn in today as the first President of the Republic of Rhodesia. The ceremony, per formed by the Acting Chief Justice, Hector McDonald, was attended by Prime Minister Ian P. Smith, members of the Cab inet, heads of the armed forces and three black African chiefs.

title: Bridge:
description: THE New York interclub championship, contested each winter by representa tives of the leading social clubs here, resulted predict ably in a victory for the Re gency Whist Club. The win ning team included Constan tin Platsis, Thomas McCarthy, Fred Dossenbach and John Kachmar, with Wingate Bix by and Walter Hochschild alternating.

title: Apollo's Crew Cool, Calm and Efficient
description: HOUSTON, April 16  In spite of the stress of more than five days in space, most of it under emergency conditions, the Apollo 13 astronauts seem cool, calm and efficient as they approach the flight's last deci sive pointthe reentry tomor row.

title: FILION KEEPS LEAD FOR DRIVING TITLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 More than a few skeptics who had scoffed at the touring series from which a definitive world champion harness racing driver would emerge, found considerable merit in the idea tonight.

title: F.A.A. Doctors Studied Bailey To Guide Tactics in Air Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The Federal Aviation Adminis tration had its medical officers, including a staff psychiatrist, investigate the tactics and mo tives of F. Lee Bailey, the Boston lawyer who directed the air traffic controllers' three week sickout that ended this week.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, April 17, 1970

title: Cambodia Will Spur Private Enterprise
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 16  The Cambodian Minister of Public Works said here to day that his country would end state control over all sec tors of production and would encourage private enterprise.

title: A Radioactive Generator To Fall in Pacific Today
description: HOUSTON, April 16  SNAP 27, a nuclear generator with 8.6 pounds of radioactive plu tonium in it, will fall into the Pacific Ocean about 200 miles northeast of New Zealand about noon tomorrow, an Atomic Energy Commission official said today.

title: JOSEPH T. FOLEY
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., April 16 Joseph Thomas Foley, presi dent and owner of the Home Oil Company in Passaic, died yes terday in his home after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 12 Quaker Road.

title: English Speaking Union Plans Benefit Tuesday
description: The EnglishSpeaking Union, which has planned a theater party at the opening of the Royal Ballet at the Metro politan Opera House on Tuesday, will entertain the union's board of directors at a reception afterward in its offices at 16 East 69th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Mead ow, Queens, 2 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 2 P.M.) (Radio WJRZ, WNBCFM, 2 P.M.)

title: Pirates Win, 74, on 4 Met Errors; Red Sox Defeat Yankees, 85
description: The year after has not been brimming for the Mets so far. Nobody has hit a home run yet. No pitcher has completed a game. The gremlins of 1969 have been late arriving. And yesterday the Mets made four errors and lost their second straight game to the Pittsburgh Pirates. 74.

title: Soviet Astronauts Send Best Wishes to Apollo
description: MOSCOW April 16 (UPI) Soviet astronauts today sent the Apollo 13 crew their best wishes for a safe return to earth.

title: Music: Maazel Passes a Test of Stature
description: A SURPRISINGLY large number of musicians and critics are split about Lorin Maazel. Some consider him the most talented of the younger conductorsa man with an amazing memory, tremendous control, innate musicianship and a great deal of power. Others consider him a cold fish, an I.B.M. con ductor, a precisionist with out soul.

title: Sydney Judge Terms Brechinridge Filthy
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 16 (Reuters)  The novel Myra Breckinridge by Gore Vidal is filthy, bawdy, lewd and disgusting, a Syd ney judge said today in up holding a Customs Depart ment ban on the book.

title: HICKEL STOPS ROAD TO SAVE WILDLIFE
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 The United States Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel, said here today that he would withhold permission to con struct a section of Interstate 95 until steps were taken to preserve a wildlife refuge in the area.

title: Estimate Board Expands Brooklyn Housing Plans
description: The Board of Estimate ap proved major expansions of urban renewal housing plans in Brooklyn yesterday. It added 425 units in the Fulton Park project of the general Brooklyn Model Cities area and 1,362 in the Coney Island neighborhood development area.

title: Adm. Richard Cruzen, 72, Dies; Led Pioneering Polar Cruises
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 16 (AP)Retired Vice Adm. Richard L. Cruzen, who com manded pioneering cruises in both Arctic and Aantarctic wa ters during a 35year Navy career, died yesterday at the age of 72.

title: DR. GREGORY MABRY, CHURCH LEADER, 79
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., April 16 The Rev. Dr. Gregory Mabry, chaplain of the House of the Holy Nativity here, died yes terday at Bay Shore Hospital. Hp was 79 years old.

title: Federal Reserve Pushes Policy of Modest Growth
Rodley Joy Berger Planning Marriage
description: Mrs. Isadore Berger of For est Hills, Queens, has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rodley Joy Berger, to Ronald Mat thew Polon. He is the son of Matthew Polon, president of the R.K.O.Stanley Warner Theaters, and Mrs. Polon of Woodmere, L. I. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Sisco Drops Jordan Visit After AntiU.S. Riots
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)Joseph J. Sisco, Assist ant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Af fairs, has decided not to visit Jordan on his present tour of the area because of the vio lent antiAmerican demonstra tions yesterday in Amman, the State Department announced today.

title: Need of Standards Stressed
description: BONN, April 15 (UPI)  Adoption of international stand ards for clean air and water will force communities to re duce their pollution, Mr. Moy nihan said at a news confer ence here today.

title: Lack of Bacon Stops Ads
description: LONDON (AP)A sixmonth $720,000 advertising campaign promoting British bacon has been suspended because the de mand outran the supply.

title: A Bit of Reality by L B. Singer and Son
description: In 1962, Isaac Bashevis Singer wrote a short story called The Son, which told of his meeting with his son, whom he had not seen in 20 years.

title: PACKAGE TO YIELD CITY $400MILLION PUSHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 16  Gov ernor Rockefeller and Repub lican legislative leaders said today they had agreed on a package of new local taxes and revenuesharing measures including offtrack betting and a numberstype of state lottery that would yield New York City more than $400million.

title: Baseball Scores
EAST'S RAILWAYS HELD INEFFICIENT
description: CHICAGO, April 16  The country's Eastern railroads were taken to task here today by an international container operator for inefficiency in con tainer handling.

title: US. and Canada
Knicks Seeking Third Straight Over Bucks in Playoffs Tonight
description: MILWAUKEE, April 16  A note of sadness accompanied the otherwise confident New York Knicks today on their flight here from New York to meet the Milwaukee Bucks to morrow night in the third game of the National Basketball As sociation's Eastern Division championship playoff series.

title: WILLIAM F. KENNEY ATHLETIC SCOUT, 63
description: William F. Kenney, a scout for and sponsor of college and high school athletes, died yes terday in Polyclinic Hospital, after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 953 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Nixon's Commitment to Negroes Questioned by Black Educators
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A group of black educators who met with Commissioner of Edu cation James E. Allen Jr. ques tioned today President Nixon's commitment to higher educa tion for the nation's black youth.

title: STATE TO ACQUIRE 2 COMMUTER RUNS
description: ALBANY, April 16Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the state take over commuter service on the Harlem and Hud son divisions of the Penn Cen tral and asked the Legislature to approve a $6??million, bond financed modernization pro gram for the lines.

title: MOYERS IS SILENT ON NEWSDAY SALE
description: Bill D. Moyers, the publisher of Newsday, refused yesterday to comment on the sale of the controlling interest in the Long Island daily to the Times Mir ror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times, or on his own plans.

title: Pollution Hearing Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) Senator Philip A. Hart, Dem ocrat of Michigan, said today he would conduct a hearing on waters that had been polluted by mercury. Gov. William Mil liken of Michigan has banned sports fishing in Lake St. Clair, the St. Clair River and the De troit River because of mercury that has entered the water from industries.

title: Tiddlywinks Mark Claimed
description: THAME, England (UPI)  Four schoolboys claimed a tid dlywinks record after playing 2,007 games in 101 hours. The boys played in shifts as part of a fundraising charity drive.

title: 4TH GRADE ADOPTS INJURED FIREMAN
description: A pale young fireman in a wheelchair, who was seriously injured in December while re sponding to a false alarm, was carried down the steps of Jew ish Hospital in Brooklyn yes terday morning and given a hero's welcome by his col leagues and a fourthgrade class that seems to have adopted him.

title: Computer Is No Gentleman
description: LONDON (AP)A computer installed to record traffic cases demands the offender's date of birth. A court official in Bradford said, however, that if a woman driver did not want her age known publicly it could be held in confidence.

title: STEEL MAKERS CUT STAINLESS PRICES
description: Major producers of stainless steel disclosed yesterday that they had reduced scheduled prices last week or earlier for few product lines, mainly to meet discounting, market soft ness and official cuts by some smaller companies.

title: Head of S. C. Backs Investor Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Hamer H. Budge, the Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress to day that there is an urgent need for creation of an in surance to protect Investors from losses when brokerage firms go bankrupt.

title: U. S. and Agency Bonds
description: Thursday, April 16, 1970

title: G. O. P. Candidates Going Their Own Way
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio was sitting last week in a model kitchen in Bryan, Ohio, discussing his campaign for the Senate with a group of sup porters.

title: Carrier to Use Satellite To Assist in Navigation
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Apollo 13's main recovery ship, the helicopter carrier Iwo Jima, is being positioned to rescue the astronauts by a once secret Navy navigation system that has almost pinpoint ac curacy.

title: STRICKEN APOLLO SPEEDING TOWARD EARTH FOR PACIFIC SPLASHDOWN THIS AFTERNOON
description: HOUSTON, Friday, April 17 The Apollo 13 spaceship, dam aged but on course, sped toward the earth early today as its three astronauts braced them selves for the complicated and exacting climax to their aborted moonlanding mission.

title: Risk for Baby and Mother Seen In the Use of Anesthesia at Birth
description: Two anesthesiologists warned yesterday that excessive use of painkilling and anesthetic drugs during labor and delivery may endanger the wellbeing and perhaps even the lives of some babies.

title: Novel Dream Play, Strindberg Drama, Staged by Bergman
description: STOCKHOLM, April 16  Ingmar Bergman's staging of Strindberg's A Dream Play is the sensation of the Stock holm spring season. Composed as A Chamber Play, it is being performed at the smaller of the Dramatic Theater's two playhouses and is completely sold out for the remainder of its initial run. News of its extraordinary quality has spread quickly. It will soon be seen elsewhere in Europe.

title: U.S. Judge Gives State Court 2 Choices on Kopechne Text
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP) A Federal judge issued guide Hiles today designed to help a Massachusetts court decide how to release the transcript of the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne, killed in Senator Edward M. Ken nedy's car accident last July.

title: NEW MINERAL PLAN ANNOUNCED IN PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, April 16 (Reu ters)  The Peruvian Govern anent decreed today that would take over the sale and refining of copper and all oth er minerals in the country in 18 months.

title: BLUES TOP STARS, GAIN WEST FINAL
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (AP)The St. Louis Blues, powered by Red Berenson and Ab McDonald, moved into the semifinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs with a 42 victory to night over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Pakistani Newsmen Strike
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 16 Journalists in the principal cities of Pakistan went on strike today for the first time in this nation's 22year history. Their charter of demands newspapers have suspended publication.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AGAIN MOVE DOWN
description: Declines outnumbered ad vances by almost fourtoone yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the list con tinued to weaken in quiet trad ing.

title: Samuels Calls Goldberg Machine Man
description: UTICA, April 16A As their campaign trails crossed time and again, Howard J. Samuels carried the fight today to Arthur J. Goldberg, the man ehviews as his opposition for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Roundup: Orioles Beaten, But Manager Gains a Split
description: Forced to change the tone of his philosophical discus sions with umpires, Earl Weaver might have discov ered a revolutionary approach to managerumpire relations last night.

title: House Panel Votes A 3d Site for ABM
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The House Armed Services Committee voted today to authorize funds requested by the Administration to add a third site to the Safeguard anti ballistic missile system and to go ahead with preliminary work on five more sites.

title: Young Singer Bids the Bronx Goodby
description: I'M nadda girl from the Bronx any more, said the girl from the Bronx. The clogshod feet swung back and forth against the fringed sofa; a cockerspaniel hairdo, tied with braided wool, framed intense brown eyes.

title: WILMOT MITCHELL, LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: Wilmot Brookings Mitchell 2d, a partner in the law firm of Hall, McNicol, Marett & milton, 41 East 42d Street, died Wednesday of cancer at Memo rial Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 116 East 63d Street.

title: Tito Names First Envoy To Red China in 12 Years
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16 (AP)President Tito today named a new Yugoslav Ambassador to Communist China, the first in 12 years, marking an improvement in re lations between the two coun tries.

title: CITY ANNOUNCES EARTH DAY PLAN
description: The city announced yester day that it had asked munici pal agencies not to use cars except in emergencies during the nationwide antipollution demonstrations on Earth Day, next Wednesday.

title: HOUSE PANEL ENDS OBSCENITY HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A House judiciary subcommittee completed public hearings on antiobscenity legislation today with little indication of the scope of new laws, if any, that it would recommend.

title: N.B.A. Players Sue to Block Merger
description: In an attempt to block the proposed merger of the Na tional Basketball Association with the American Basketball Association, the players of the N.B.A. filed an antitrust suit yesterday in Federal Court here, challenging both the merg er and the reserveclause sys tem that ties a player to one team within a league.

title: SOVIET STRESSES BREZHNEV'S ROLE
description: MOSCOW, April 16Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet patty leader, flew to Lenin's birth place today and made his third nationally televised speech in four days. He asserted that, although the road might be hard, Communism would even tually triumph around the world.

title: WelltoDo Tenants Facing Squeeze
description: Welltodo New Yorkers in 5,000 apartment houses may wake up next Tuesday to find themselves without some of the people whose services are es sential to their comfort: men who run their elevators, carry their garbage downstairs, sweep their hallways, fix their leaky faucets, guard their buildings and whistle for their cabs. They are among the 25, 000 men of Local 32B of the Build ing Service Em ployes Union, which has threat ened a strike for midnight Monday unless landlords agree to an improved contract to re place the one that expires then.

title: F.A.A. HEAD FIRM ABOUT DISMISSALS
description: WASHINGTON, April. 16 The head of the Federal Avia tion Administration repeated to day the Government's determin ation to discharge the leaders of the recent slowdonw by Fed eral air traffic controllers but said that they might be given a chance to resign first.

title: NICO CHARISSE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 16 (AP)Nico Charisse, the ballet master who trained such film stars as Ava Gardner, Ann Miller, Shirley MacLaine and Cyd Charisse, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Portugal to Try 10 Charged With Link to African Rebels
description: LISBON, April 16  The Portuguese Government an nounced today that it would try 10 leftwing political acti vists, including a candidate for pariament in last October's election, on charges of having ]inks with the antiPortuguese guerrilla movement in Africa.

title: A Trucker's Grind: Me, the Rig and the Road
description: RICHMOND, April 156:47 P.M.Hokay, hokay, the Monster of the Pavement is on its way, roars Barker Keith as he swings the wheel of his barnred International Harvester tandem tractor out into the heavy traffic of Kings Highway in Bridgeport, Conn. Grinding into third gear as it passes the McDon ald's hamburger stand, the tractor grunts for a moment like a water buffalo in quicksand, straining against the weight of the 45foot trailer strung out behind. Then, turning down the ramp of the Connecticut Turnpike, the 190horsepower diesel en gine takes hold, 18 mammoth tires grab the asphalt, and Associated Transport's Bridge porttoRichmond runstill moving despite a sporadic trucking strikehits the road.

title: Minneapolis Teacher Strike Continues With No Talks
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 15 The weeklong strike of most Minneapolis teachers continued today, with negotiations broken off between the school board and the city's Federation of Teachers.

title: Express Unit Weighs Merger With International Utilities
description: The Pacific Intermountain Express Company, one of the nation's largest common car riers, has agreed to hold merger discussions with the Internar tional Utilities Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

title: LAWRENCE G. WASHBURN
description: ESSEX, Conn., April 16 Lawrence G. Washburn, Washburn, a former vice presi dent of the Sucrest Corpora tion in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Simons Island, Ga. He was 77 years old. Mr. and Mrs. Wash burn were on the way to their home at 62 North Maine Street here, after spending the win ter on Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Market Place
description: CHARLIE EDDY had that Clyde Beatty look about him yesterday as he reflected on the stock market as a me nagerie containing many de pressed values.

title: U.S. OUTPUT DOWN IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The nation's total output de clined in the first quarter of this year but monthly figures for March indicated that the slowdown in the economy may be ending, Government reports showed today.

title: CITY'S INTEREST ON BONDS DROPS
3 Drug Companies Win Appeal Of '67 U.S. Antitrust Suit Here
description: The 1967 antitrust conviction of three drug companies on charges of controlling the pro duction and distribution of $1.7 million worth of antibiotics was reversed yesterday in a 21 de cision by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HAVERFORD BALKS AT PROTEST CURB
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 Haverford College announced today that it would not give the state the names of Penn sylvania students receiving state aid who are involved in campus disorders.

title: ... a Descent to Politics
description: President Nixon's nomination of Judge Blackmun to the Supreme Court offers a promising opportunity to end the unseemly political bickering over the Court appointment and to restore public confidence the independent judiciary and the Presidency. House Republican Leader Gerald R. Ford's attack on Justice William O. Douglas points in just the opposite direction.

title: Shift at A. H. Robins
description: RICHMOND, Va., April 16 (AP)  E. Claiborne Robins, president of the A. H. Robins Company for 34 years, will be come the pharmaceutical con cern's chairman and chief ex ecutive officer June 1 and will be succeeded as president by William L. Zimmer 3d, it was announced today. Mr. Zimmer is now executive vice president and chief operating officer for the company.

title: IMPASSE CONTINUES IN TRUCKING TALKS
description: The deadlock between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking in dustry continued yesterday in major cities, but some dissident drivers ended small walkouts and strikerelated layoffs eased in some areas.

title: ROBERT. M'CORKLE
description: Robert L. McCorckle, who re tired a year ago as display administrator for Bamberger's department store in Newark and its New Jersey branches, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 67 years old and lived at 160 East 65th Street.

title: Chinese Trade Fair Is Opened in Canton
description: HONG KONG, April 15 (Reuters)China opened its annual spring trade fair Wednesday with businessmen from five continents attending.

title: Births
description: ALTMANMr. and Mrs. Robert Altman (nee Arline Benowitz) announce the birth of their son, Adam Francis, brother of Craig, on April 16th.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THE CONFINES of an indoor arena serve as a gigantic sounding board to the roars of the crowd, magnify ing them out of all true proportions. Al though there's nothing tangible about this thunder from the seats, it canand does produce tangible results. It is a match less stimulant to the hometown team. Hysterical screams of encouragement make adrenalin flow a little faster and make the players reach within themselves for that little extra something to decide the issue.

title: FLOYD A. M'CLURE5, LEADING BOTANIST
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Dr. Floyd A. McClure, a botanist at the Smithsonian Institution who was considered one of the world's leading authorities on bamboo, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Be thesda, Md. He was 72 years old.

title: City Files Own Suit To Get Car Makers To Cut Emissions
description: Turned down in an effort to intervene in the settlement of a Federal lawsuit charging automobile makers with con spiracy to suppress develop ment of pollution controls, the city filed its own suit yester day.

title: Casals Makes It a Night to remember
description: PABLO CASALS wasn't around very long Wed nesday at the benefit concert and gala in his honor, but he seemed to be having a good time.

title: Promotion at Reader's Digest
description: Hobart D. Lewis has been named chief executive officer of the Readers Digest Associa tion, Inc., it was announced yesterday by DeWitt wallace, chairman of the board of direc tors. Mr. Lewis assumes the post in addition to his duties as president and editor in chief

title: Bay Shore Restaurant Burns
description: BAY SHORE, L.I., April 16 (UPI)The posh Gateway South Restaurant here was destroyed today in an early morning blaze that is under investigation by fire officials. There were no in juries and no immediate esti mated damage.

title: 43Carat Diamond, Once an Idol's Eye, Sold for $500,000
description: A 43.38carat diamond was auctioned yesterday for $500, 000.

title: OKONITE PURCHASE DEFENDED BY LING
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) James J. Ling defended today both his acquisition of the Okonite Company from the Kenne Cott Copper Corporation in 1965, and his dealings with an insider of Kennecott whom he later made chief executive of Okonite.

title: BLACK MUN FACING INQUIRY ON ETHICS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Judge Harry A. Blackmun, President Nixon's latest Su preme Court nominee, is ex pected to be questioned closely on ethical matters by the Sen ate Judiciary Committee as a result of the disclosure that he has participated in three cases nvolving companies in which he owned stock.

title: SOVIET SAID TO JAIL A JEWISH PETITIONER
description: LONDON, April 16A So viet Jewish woman, who had tried repeatedly to obtain per mission to join her father in Israel, was reported today to have been sentenced to two and a half years in prison on charges of having slandered the Soviet Union and insulted the authorities.

title: Building from Which Oswald Fired Brings $650,000
description: DALLAS, April 16  The building from which Lee Har vey Oswald shot and killed President John F. Kennedy was sold tonight at public auction for $650,000.

title: Migrant Food Plan Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Special rood and food stamp programs for families of mi grant workers were advocated today by the director of Michi gan State University's Rural Manpower Center. Dr. Daniel Sturt, the director, testified be fore a Senate labor subcom mittee.

title: Kheel Says That Port Authority Hoards Profits:
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the law yer and labor mediator, re newed yesterday his attack on ithe Port of New York Author ity, saying it has taken a cop out on mass transportation.

title: Appetizer Recipe For the Weekend
description: IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Saigon Offers to Repatriate Vietnamese in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 17 (AP)South Viet nam has offered to repatriate all Vietnamese nationals living in Cambodia, Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam said today.

title: COFFEEHOUSE TRIAL BEGINS IN CAROLINA
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 16  The operators of one of the first antiwar G.I. coffeehouses went on trial today on charges of operating a public nuisance. State Circuit Judge E. Harry Agnew ruled that the common law violation could carry a sen tence up to 10 years in prison.

title: NIXON SETS GOAL OF BROAD ACCORD ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Administration and Congres sional sources disclosed today that. President Nixon had de cided that the United States should press for a comprehen sive limitation on strategic weapons.

title: Mrs. Christine G. Cottrell Bride of Dr. A. John Elliot
description: AVON, Conn., April 16 Mrs. Christine Geer Cottrell was married this afternoon to Dr. A. John Elliot, an ortho pedic surgeon do Westerly, R. I., in the Avon Congrega tional Church by the Rev. Theodore C. Schoonmaker.

title: The Profit Scene: Some Down, Some Up
FORM FOR PICKETING AT WHITE HOUSE HIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The American Civil Liberties Union complained to the Federal Government today that the new application for permission to picket near the White House was almost impossible to fill out.

title: Photo Processor Charges Kodak in Antitrust Action
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 (AP)  Fotomat Corporation, filed a $321.5million action against the Eastman Kodak Company in the Federal District Court here yesterday, charging conspiracy to violate antitrust laws.

title: Advertising: Candidates and TV Spending
description: There seemed to be a con siderable amount of disagree ment yesterday among adver tising men who have fought the political fight on the merits of the legislation that would limit broadcast adver tising by candidates for Fed eral office. The Senate passed the bill Tuesday.

title: William J. Baxter, Headed Economic Research Agency
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 16William J. Baxter, an economist and former pres ident of the Baxter International Economic Research Bureau, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 2 High Ridge Road, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Suffolk Judge Named
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 16 (UPI) State Supreme Court Justice John P. Cohalan Jr. will become Administrative Judge of the Suffolk County District Court next July 1. This was announced today at a news conference by Justice Marcus G. Christ.

title: U.N. DEVELOPMENT APPROVED BY CITY
description: The controversial plan for a $350million project across First Avenue from the United Nations, including glass wrapped plazas and four tow ers as tall as the United Na tions headquarters building, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Unrest Simmers at 7 Colleges
description: A rash of troubles, of vary ing degree and for assorted issues, affected seven colleges in the city yesterday, but the disruptions and attempted dis locations involved little vio lence.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ANGLERS caught more than 40 tons of muskelunge in Chautauqua and Cattar augus counties in 1969, the State Conservation Depart ment reports.

title: Aborted Mission Ends Duties for a Lieutenant
description: ABOARD U.S.S. IWO JIMA, at Sea, April 16 (AP)Lieut. (j.g.) James Coolbaugh sailed from Pearl Harbor April 4 with only one quick job to do on a threeweek cruise. And now he's out of that.

title: Cubs to Install Screen To Curb Bleacher Fans
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) The Chicago Cubs, acting to curb rowdyism at Wrigley Field, announced plans today to install a 42inch screen shelf bordering the bleachers and to stop the sale of stand ing room in the bleachers.

title: U.S. Data Widely Disseminated
description: DETROIT, April 15  A spokesman for the General Mo tors Corporation said today that by bidding to build the prototype 4,000pound safety car for the Government, the American manufacturers were committing themselves to the widest possible distribution of the results of their safety en gineering.

title: A Turn Toward Excellence...
description: In nominating Judge Harry A. Blackmun to the Supreme Court, President Nixon appears finally have met the exacting standards of excellence that the Senate has rightly demanded for one of the nation's most responsible and respected lifetime offices.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNIT ASSAILS U.F.T. LIES
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that charges by an official of the United Federatoin of Teachers against parents at Goerge Washington High School were Lies.

title: Mitchell, With 7UnderPar 65, Leads by Stroke at New Orleans
President's Welfare Plan Passes House, 243 to 155
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 President Nixon's plan for a radical revision of the nation's welfare system was approved by the House today, 243 to 155. It was a major legislative vic tory for the Administration.

title: Cambodian Orders Inquiry Into Killings
description: NEAK, Luang, Cambodia, April 16  A ranking security official in Pnompenh said he was shocked by news that hun dreds of bodies had been seen floating in the Mekong River and that he had ordered an immediate investigation. He said that no responsible official had ordered a mass execution.

title: ExPriest and Nun in Prison For Burning Draft Records
description: BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Mel ville, a former priest and nun, surrendered today to a United States marshal to begin serv ing prison terms for participat ing in the burning of draft board records in suburban Catonsville.

title: WAR DEATHS RISE TO 141 FOR WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 16  The United States combat death toll rose again last week to 141, the highest since last September, the Unit ed States command announced today.

title: NEW AIRPORT DEVICE HALTS MAN WITH GUN
description: When a bearded man stepped through Gate 34 at La Guardia Airport Wednesday night to board a Miamibound Eastern Airlines plane, a red light flashed on an electronic device called a Friskem.

title: Helen Keller Award Made
description: John F. Wilson, director and chief executive officer of the British Royal Commonwealth Society for the Blind, received the Helen. Keller International Award yesterday for outstand ing service to blind persons. The award, presented for the third time since it was estab lished in 1960, was made by Katharine Cornell, the actress, at a luncheon of the Helen Keller World Crusade for the Blind, 22 West 17th Street.

title: L.I.R.R., Engineers in Pact
description: The Long Island Rail Road And the Brotherhood of Loco motive Engineers announced jointly yesterday the reaching of a settlement on a new work contract. The 15month agree ment covered the 350 engineers on the line and was made re troactive to last Oct. 1 It is effective to next Jan. 1.

title: Taxi Problems Still Plague City's Airports
description: Fifty travelers waited un happily at the taxi stand of the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy Inter national Airport at 9 P.M. the other night.

title: NO GAIN REPORTED IN PRESS PARLEYS
description: Negotiators for the printers and newspapers in the city were reported still far apart yesterday on the wage issue as contract talks continued.

title: Use of Confessional Is Dropping
description: Like the Latin mass and fish on Friday, the regular visit to the confession box may be on its way to ob solescence in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Caroline Renton Engaged to Wed In the Summer
description: Sir David and Lady Renton of London and Huntingdon, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Renton, to Peter DoddsParker, a student at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.
