He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas DoddsParker of Lon don and Cheltenham, England. Both Sir David and Mr. DoddsParker are members of Parliament. They were elected in 1945 and have been min isters in previous Conserva tive Governments.

title: French Mothers to Get Equal Say in Raising Children
description: PARIS, April 16  The French National Assembly voted today to give mothers as much say as fathers over the upbringing of children.

title: Pentagon Doubles Arms Aid to Athens Despite Restriction
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Despite United States restric tions on arms shipments to the Greek junta, the Defense De partment is reported to have secretly supplied this year near ly twice as much military aid to Greece as authorized by Congress.

title: Soviet Embassy Is Lavish
description: LIMA, Peru (AP)The Soviet Government has bought a ma jestic estate at suburban Or rantia Del Mar for $400,000 to use as its Lima embassy, a Russian official announced.

title: As the World Watches
description: If all goes well in these last hours of Apollo 13's antastic flight, the most perilous journey human beings have ever undertaken will end safely in the Pacific today. The space ship crippled in midcourse, then desperately struggling to reach a safe harbor before disaster strikes, is a familiar theme in science fictionbut now it has become reality.

title: Note to Readers
description: The weekly table of Fed eral Reserve statistics and the condition of major corn mercial banks in New York and Chicago is omitted from this issue because of com posingroom delays caused by union meetings.

title: STOCK PRICES CUT IN BROAD RETREAT
description: The gloom gathered a little deeper on Wall Street yester day as stock prices took an other beating in a broadbased retreat that took its toll of bluechip and glamour issues and a lot of stocks in be tween.

title: ORR GETS 2 GOALS TO PACE VICTORY
description: As they have for every Na tional Hockey League season in the last 30 years the Rangers were once again denied last night a chance of attaining hockey's ultimate prize: the Stanley Cup.

title: Excerpts From the President's Message to Congress Proposing Postal Reform and Increases in Pay
description: WASHINGTON, April 16.  Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress on postal reform and pay increases for postal employes:

title: NEW TRIAL IS WON BY MRS. CRIMMINS
description: ALBANY, April 16The Court of Appeals today ruled that Mrs. Alice Crimmins, a Queens housewife convicted of killing her 4yearold daughter, was entitled to a new trial because three jurors visited the scene of the alleged crime.

title: Keel Laying Postponed Over Job Plan Dispute
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 16 (AP)  The world's largest private shipyard, its proposed minority employment program turned down by the Labor De partment, has, postponed indee finitely Saturday's scheduled keellaying ceremonies for the $510million nuclear powered aircraft carrier Dwight D. Ei senhower.

title: N.B.C.TV Drops Report On Newark After Protests
description: The National Broadcasting Company, announced yesterday that segment of the Huntley Brinkley news program con cerning Newark, in which John Chancellor called the city dead, would not be shown next Monday evening.

title: News Summary and Index
description: With the splashdown of their damaged spacecraft less than a day away, the three Apollo 13 astronauts prepared yesterday for the complicated operations they must per form to separate the lunar landing craft from the command module and ride the crippled craft back to the earth. The weather outlook was favorable, and officials were cautiously optimistic about a safe reentry. [Page 1, Columns 18.]

title: Massachusetts House Votes Voluntary Prayer in Schools
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)The Massachusetts House passed bill today to allow voluntary prayers in public schools. The roll call vote that sent it to the Senate was 20717.

title: Last Leg of Apollo Crew's Return Simulated on the Ground by Fellow Astronauts
description: When the Apollo 13 crewmen return to earth today, they will follow involved and unorthodox procedures that have been put to the most meticulous tests possible by a succession of astronauts in on  the  ground simulators.

title: Philadelphia Bank to Use Loans to Combat Pollution
description: The First Pennsylvania Bank ing and Trust Company an nounced yesterday that it would lend money at a preferred in terest rate as an inducement to get something going on the problem of environmental pollution.

title: Met Revives Chenier After 4Season Absence
description: The Metropolitan Opera had planned to include Giordano's Andrea Chenier in its current season but had to abandon it when its schedule was trun cated by last fall's labor dis pute. However, in order to keep it in the repertory of the company's spring tour, which begins next Monday, it put on one performance last night, and it will be brought back for the Met's twoweek gala at Lincoln Center in June.

title: PERSICO VERDICT IS UPHELD HERE
description: The conviction Iast year of Carmine (the Snake) Persico on his fifth trial on charges of hi jacking a truckful of linen was upheld by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here yester day.

title: RIP COLLINS DIES; EXFIRST BASEMAN
description: NEW HAVEN, April 16 (AP) James Anthony (Rip) Collins star first baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals during the 1930's, died here yesterday. His age was 65. He is survived by his widow, Joanne, three sons, a daughter and a brother.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, April 16, 1970

title: Executive Changes
description: Dr. Chester J. Cavallito has been named executive vice president of Ayerst Laboratories, a division the American Home Products Corporation, effective July 1. He is now a professor of medicinal chemistry at the University of North Carolina School of Pharmacy.

title: DEATH OF GIRL, 15, LINKED TO HEROIN
description: A 15yearold girlwho only a month ago apologetically told her aunt that she had starting, smoking cigaretteshas died of hepatitis complications that a medical examiner says were apparently caused by her tak ing heroin with an unclean needle.

title: SIX AIRMEN KILLED AS 2 JETS COLLIDE
description: WELDON, N. C., April 16 (UPI)A Navy jet collided in flight today with an Air Force jet, killing six airmen and scat tering flaming wreckage into residential area. No one on the eround was injured.

title: Even an Oscar Can't Help Cheer Up Maggie Smith
description: LONDON, April 16At the Old Vic one night last week, Maggie Smith was playing Mrs. Sullen, the unsatisfied wife in Farquhar's The Beaux' Stratagem.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Faculty Power Brokers

title: BOSTON'S 4 IN 7TH SUBDUE YANKEES
description: BOSTON, April 16  And sure enough, things got worse.

title: GOLDBERG THEME: TIME FOR CHANGE
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 16 Arthur J. Goldberg charged today that the Rockefeller administration was suffering from hardening of the arteries.

title: Death Toll 72 in Landslide That Hit Sanitarium in French Alps
description: PLATEAU D'ASSY, France, April 16Seventytwo persons were declared dead today after thousands of tons of mud crashed onto the boys' wing of a children's tuberculosis sani tarium here in the heart of the French Alps.

title: LINDSAY REVAMPS MODEL CITIES PLAN
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday re organized the Model Cities pro gram here to provide the tools and leverage needed to allow Model Cities to move ahead at full speed with complete com munity participation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The protest note, delivered to the Foreign Ministry, held the Jordanian Government re sponsible for the damage and demanded prompt and full compensation.

title: Sunbeam Is Shifting Appliance Accounts
description: Millions of dollars worth of appliance advertising as signments are being shifted around Chicago by the Sun beam Appliance Company J. Walter Thompson's office there is getting a pile of per sonal care products that will be moved in from Perrin & Associates and Foote, Cone & Belding FC&B in turn will be getting several assignments that will also be shifted out of Perrin.

title: CHURCHPUPIL AID GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBBANY, April 16  The State Senate today voted final legislative approval of a pro posed constitutional amend ment that would end the ban against state aid to parochial schools but permit court chal lenges by taxpayers.

title: CITY U. FACULTY BODY WIDENS AFFILIATION
description: The Legislative Conference of City University, the collective bargaining agent for 5,500 ten ured faculty members, yester day announced its affiliation with the National Education Association and the New York Teachers Association.

title: Tatoi Takes Aqueduct Dash
description: Tatoi, a newcomer to Aque duct, found the Big A strip to his liking yesterday. The 3year old colt owned by Orme Wilson Jr. won the feature event on the card, a sevenfurlong sprint, against four rivals. The feat was not easy, though, for the margin was a mere nose over the Birchfield Farm's Sail stone. This pair waged a thrill ing duel in the stretch, with Sailstone just falling short, after an awkward start.

title: U.S.Soviet Talks on Nuclear Arms Resume
description: VIENNA, April 16  Nego tiators for the Soviet Union and the United States opened the second round of the stra tegic arms limitation talks at a formal ceremony here today and immediately decided to get down to business at two work ing sessions tomorrow and Monday.

title: Funds Asked for Asian Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) David M. Kennedy, the Sec retary of the Treasury, told Congress today that it was time for the United States to join with other nations in pro viding easyterm loans to Asian nations. Mr. Kennedy, who testified before a House bank ing subcommittee, is seeking a $25million contribution this year for the Asian Develop ment Bank.

title: Hagberg, Oakland Back, Killed in Highway Crash
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (AP)Roger Hagberg, 31 yearold reserve fulllback and tight end for the Oakland Raiders, was killed last night when his car crashed into a highway guard rail and hurtled across the road, throwing him into the path of another car.

title: MRS. MARTIN HUBERTH
description: Mrs. Wilhelmine Hotze Hu berth, widow of Martin F. Hu berth, former board chairman of the Hearst Corporation, died Tuesday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: 3 Networks Will Televise Recovery of Apollo Today
description: The three national television networks plan to broadcast live the Apollo 13 splashdown, ex pected at about 1 P.M. today.

title: ROGERS REASSURES EUROPE ON TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that any cuts made by Presi dent Nixon in United States troop strength in Europe would be relatively small and would not weaken the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: NAVY WIFE BACKS ANTIWAR LEAFLET
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The wife of a Navy submarine commander testified at a court martial hearing today that she had distrubuted an antiwar newsletter because she felt the war in Vietnam was a terrible mistake for the United States.

title: Italy Grants Pilot Asylum
description: TRIESTE, Italy, April 16 (Reuters)  Sandor Zaboki, a Hungarian pilot who flew a MIG15 to Italy this month, has been granted political asylum, Italian officials announced to day.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Strategy of Meaning
description: PARISThe second session of Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) which just start ed in Vienna is unlikely to pro duce dramatic results. The talks come at an unfortunate moment since nobody could have foreseen when their date was fixed that the Soviet Gov ernment would then be en gaged in internal political con tortions.

title: FRED A. KALIL
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., April 16Fred A. Kalil, a re tired textile manufacturer, died Monday at Point Pleasant Hos pital after a short illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Spring Lake Gardens.

title: End of a Priest, Czech Entry, Defrocks the Sexton
Election in Ulster Is Won by Paisley, Protestant Militant
description: LONDON, April 16  The Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protestant militant, won a byelection today to fill a seat in Northern Ireland's Parliament.

title: THREEYEAR EXILE IS ENDED BY BOSCH
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 16  Juan Bosch, leader of the Domini can leftist opposition, returned from three years of exile to day and received a tumultuous welcome despite police efforts to restrain his supporters.

title: HOUSE PANEL CALLS 6 IN SONGMY INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)A special House panel investigating the alleged Song my massacre subpoened today six Army officers and enlisted men, including Capt. Ernest L. Medina, saying the Army had refused to let them testify vol untarily.

title: Professor at Barnard Named Dean of Faculty
description: The chairman of the Bar nard College French Depart ment, Dr. LeRoy C. Breunig, has been named dean of the Barnard faculty. The appoint ment was approved Wednes day night at a meeting of the college's board of trustees.

title: Rhodes Files Suit Against Life, Seeking $6.3Million for Libel
description: Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio filed a $6.3million libel suit against Time Inc. in Fed eral District Court here yester day, disputing an article, The Governor and the Mobster, that was published in Life mag azine last May 2.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: In Memoriam
description: KANTORMeyer G. In loving memory of our dearest husband and father.

title: Coast Boatbuilder Charts Course Against Inflation
description: EXPERTS say the sport of offshore racing is hurt ing because a horsepower race makes it too expensive for all but a few wealthy boatowners. We hope we can suggest a solution to the problem of inflationary costs in offshore powerboat rac ing with better design and a return to smaller engines. So spoke Ernest Kanzler, the 36  year  old president of the Autocoast Com pany of Costa Mesa, Calif., last week before the start of the Long Beach (Calif.) to Ensenada, Mexico, ocean race.

title: CALIFORNIA EDISON POSTS RISE IN NET
description: The Southern California Edi son Company's firstquarter revenues and earnings ran ahead of 1969 levels but costs in virtually all aspects of operation continued to reflect the adverse impact of infla tion, T. M. McDaniel, presi dent, told stockholders at yes Iterday's annual meeting in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Discloses It Has Received a Specific Request From Cambodia for Arms and Supplies but Not Troops
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The United States has received a specific request from Cam bodia for arms and military supplies, but not American troops, to fight North Viet namese and Vietcong invaders, State Department officials said today.

title: Intellectual Who Stirs the Peasants
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 16Juan Bosch, a man of letters as well as a political leader, is a student of the Bible, and his essays include what amounts to an apology for Judas Is carint.

title: Tax Relief for the Cities
description: The tentative agreement Mayor Lindsay has won in Albany for a state revenuesharing program that will provide more than a quarterbillion dollars in extra aid to New York and other hardpressed cities represents the longest step this state has taken in many years toward a sounder balance of fiscal responsibility.

title: MORRIS ZELKOWITZ OF ARCHITECTS' FIRM
description: PARAMUS, N. J., April 16 Morris Zelkowitz, an associate partner with the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, 400 Park Avenue, New York, died today of a heart attack in Hackensack Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived here at 210 Harwood Place.

title: JOHN O'HARA BURIED IN PRINCETON RITES
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 16 John O'Hara, the novelist, was buried, here today after funeral service in the Princeton University Chapel. Mr. O'Hara had lived here since 1953.

title: Haack Offers Plan for Broker Solvency
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Robert W. Haack, the president of the New York Stock Ex change, proposed today a sys tem of insurance against bro kerage firm failures that would involve the Federal Govern ment only as a lender of last resort in the case of wide spread bankruptcies.

title: Nixon Economic Aides Seeking More Effective European Links
description: PARIS, April 17The Nixon Administration's top eco nomic officers, disenchanted with some of the ways in which Atlantic monetary cooperation now functions, are discreetly campaigning to upgrade the effectiveness of certain piv otal activities in Paris.

title: City Plans to Tighten Rules on Fuel Oil
description: Strict new regulations are being drafted by the city to reduce further the sulphur in fuel oil because officials say a publichealth danger exists despite restrictions that have cut more than half the sulphur from fuel burned here.

title: Alvin Ailey Troupe in Dance for Six By Joyce Trisler
description: Like a wary old professional, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater came off the ropes of a debilitating injury to Dudley Williams with a change of pro gram last night that was light on its feet and still full of punch. Mr. Williams is unfor tubately lost to the company for the remainder of the season with a painfully pulled liga ment. Last night at the Brook lyn Academy of Music, Mario Delamo substituted for him in Joyce Trisler's plotless Dance for Six.

title: Rookie, ExKnick Lend Some Punch To Bucks' Offense
description: MILWAKEE, April 17It was no surprise to anyone in the Milwaukee Arena to see Lew Alcindor play one of the greatest games of his short professional career tonight in leading the Bucks to what the Milwaukee players considered a must victory over the New York Knicks.

title: Israeli Jets Raid Targets In 2 Areas of Suez Canal
description: TEL AVIV, April 17 CAP) Israeli Jets attacked Egyptian targets along the central and southern sectors of the Suez Canal for two and a half hours today and returned safely to base; the military command an nounced.

title: Minor Landslides Strike in Alps Where 72 Perished
description: PLATEAU D'ASSY, France April 17  Two minor land slides last night forced rescuers to step up efforts to recover the bodies of the 72 victims of the avalanche that destroyed the boys' wing of a children's tuberculosis sanitarium here. The bodies of 28 boys and eight members of the sanita rium staff have been recovered so far.

title: Linus Pauling Is Awarded Lenin Peace Prize by Soviet
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 17 (UPI)Dr. Linus Pauling, the Nobel prizewinning chemist, has received the Soviet Union's Lenin Peace Prize for his ac tivity in defense of peace.

title: 2 Savings and Loan Units In California Weigh Merger
description: The Citizens Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Palo AltoSalinas Savings and Loan Association said yesterday that they would begin negotia tions to merge into a California statechartered capital stockor ganization with assets of more than $800million.

title: WORLD REJOICES AT SAFE RETURN
description: For a few minutes yesterday, all over the world, people of every color and station and political belief seemed as one in their joy over the successful splashdown of Apollo 13.

title: A Cadet Named Lovell Smiles As Flight Ends
description: DELAFIELD, Wis., April 17 (AP Cadet James A. Lovell 3d broke into a wide smile today as the command cap sule carrying the three Apollo 13 astronauts, includ ing his father, landed safely in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Standing IndustryLabor Units Urged on Longshore Leaders
description: CHICAGO, April 17  America's longshore industry was advised here today to take a leaf from European water front labormanagement prac tices and adopt permanent managementlabor councils.

title: Phone Workers Walk Out In Dispute Over Security
description: Nearly 16,000 telephone in stallers and repairmen walked off their jobs in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yester day afternoon in a dispute with the New York Telephone Com pany over security during work assignments in high crime areas of the city.

title: PepsiCo Begins Its Move to the Suburbs
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., April 13  When a family moves from a city apartment to a country home, it has to ac quire a whole new set of skills that go with owning a home.

title: Alan L. Douglas Jr. to Wed Miss Short
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 11Capt. Norman Stanford Short, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Short have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Grayson Short, to Seaman 3d Class Alan Lucas Douglas Jr., U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs Douglas.

title: Bar Committee to Decide Today On Whether to Rate Blackmun
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The American Bar Association's committee that rates prospec tive judicial nominees will de cide tomorrow whether to pass on the qualifications of Judge Harry A. Blackmun to sit on the Supreme Court.

title: Liberties Union Praises Police PeaceDay Role
description: The New York Civil Liber ties Union reported yester day that it had not encoun tered a single incident of abuse by the police during the Moratorium Day antiwar demonstrations Wednesday.

title: GOLDBERG SPURNS OFFERS TO DEBATE
description: BUFFALO, April 17Howard J. Samuels and three Buffalo television stations tried unsuc cessfully today to get Arthur J. Goldberg to agree to a de bate in the candidates' cam paigns for the Democratic gu bernatorial nomi&nation.

title: Aids for the City's Budget Listed
description: The revenue package to help balance next year's city budget that was worked out by state and city officials divided into four main categories. They are:

title: Robert E. Brown Is the Fiance Of Miss Helen J. D. Henderson
description: PHILADELPHIA. April 17 The engagement of Miss Helen Jane Dickens Hender son to Robert Edward Brown, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Purvis S. Henderson, who under the professional name of Dr. Helen O. Dickens, is an associate dean at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.

title: KAISER INCREASES ALUMINUM PANELS
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announc ed yesterday that prices of fab ricated panels for mobile homes and recreational vehicles have been raised by about 2.5 per cent with orders placed April 14 and on all shipments made after May 14.

title: U.S. Aide Assailed in Sweden
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 17 (UPI)Michael Weyle, the cultural attach of the United States Embassy in Bonn, fled through the back door of a building at the University of Goteborg last night after radi cal students opposed to the Vietnam War forced cancella tion of his speech. Universityli officials later made an official apology to Mr. Weyl.

title: American Motors Set to Close Unit
description: DETROIT, April 17 (UPI) The American Motors Corpora tion announced today tentative plans to close down jeep pro duction facilities at Toledo next week because of a parts shortage caused by the truck strike.

title: Topics: A Matter of Accountability
description: George Meredith once defined the sentimentalist as he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done'that is to say, he who gets intoxicated with the sensations of danger with out exposing himself to the risks. In this sense, there is certainly a horde of sentimen talists at large in this country.

title: Aquarius Praised for Vital Role
description: HOUSTON, April 17 Fare well, Aquarius, and we thank you.

title: Study Finds Smoking Can Imperil Fetus
description: A British study of 17,000 births has shown that children born to mothers who smoked during or more cigarettes a day during pregnancy read less well and were less well ad justed socially at 7 years of age than children born to non smoking mothers.

title: TEAMSTER DEADLOCK IN NATION CONTINUES
description: The deadlock between truck ers and teamsters continued yesterday while estimates of nationwide layoffs caused by the shipping stoppages passed 100,000.

title: Sea Recovery Swift After Perfect Entry
description: ABOARD U.S.S. IWO JIMA, at Sea, April 17  The three Apollo 13 astronauts splashed down gently today in the Pacific, ending a fourday fight for survival.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES CONTINUE TO FALL
description: Stock prices continued to de cline yesterday although a mild afternoon recovery, trimmed earlier losses.

title: Antiques: Hector Guimard's Designs
description: THE Hector Gulmard exhibi tion at the Museum of Modern Art will remind col lectors of the variations in the quality of art nouveau ob jects by showing them the best.

title: Apartment Owners on Strike
description: New York City, which has undergone almost every known type of labormanagement disruption, is about to suffer one of its weirdest and least justifiable upsets: a strike called by apartment house owners and managing agents of cooperatives in the face of a per fectly sound union formula for a thirtyday postpone ment that would safeguard the landlord's legitimate interest in a fairer rent control law.

title: Strategic Arms Talks in Vienna Open Working Phase
description: VIENNA, April 17 United States and Soviet disarmament negotiators met for 75 minutes today in the first working ses sion of the second round of strategic arms limitation talks.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SEES FISCAL STABILITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Under Secretary of the Treasury Charls E. Walker said today that the country was well on the road to wage price stability with strongly encouraging signs of having avoided the opposite danger of high unemployment and reces sion.

title: JOHN F. BUDD, 70, TRADE PUBLISHER
description: John F. Budd, a maritime pub lisher and a specialist in inter national trade, died Thursday of cancer in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 247 Stratford Road, Brooklyn.

title: Seale's Trial for Conspiracy Put Off to June by Hoffman
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) Judge Julius J. Hoffman of Federal District Court granted today a Government request to continue until June the riot conspiracy charges against Bobby G. Seale, Black Panther party chairman.

title: Soviet Sea Maneuvers Begin
description: MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) Largescale Soviet naval and air maneuvers have started in the North Atlantic, the Medi terranean and the Sea of Japan.

title: New President Is Named By ParvinDohrmann Co.
description: Directors of the ParvinDohr marm Company accepted the resignation yesterday of Wil liam C. Scott as president and chief operating officer and elected Earl F. Thompson to succeed him.

title: AUSTRALIA LEADS IN ZONE CUP FINAL
description: TOKYO, April 17 (AP)Aus tralia's Davis Cup tennis team met surprisingly stubborn re sistance today from Japan be fore winning the first two matches of their Asian Zone Section A final.

title: Celanese Expands Capacity
description: The Celanese Chemical Com pany, a unit of the Celanese Corporation, announced yester day it planned to double to 400 million pounds the annual capacity of its formaldehyde making, facility at Bishop, Tex.

title: 9 MAJOR AIRLINES HALT WAR ON FOG
description: ATLANTA, April 17 (UN)  Nine major airlines have called off their $100,000 war on fog at the Atlanta airport because of a lack of fog  and because when the fog appeared, it was so thick the antifogging plane could not get off the ground.

title: Miss Osborn Is Bride Here
description: Miss Susannah Shaw Osborn end Peter George Eschauzier, a flight officer with American Airlines, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal church. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins per formed the ceremony.

title: Cleon Jones's Brother Hurt
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 18 (AP) Tommy Lee Jones, 29year old brother of Cleon Jones, of the New York Mets, was injured seriously today in an automobile accident. The car in which he was a passenger hit a rut, ran off a road and hit telephone pole. The driver was also in serious condition.

title: RUTH B. MANSER
description: SUMMIT, N. J., April 17 Ruth B. Manser of Woodland Avenue, who retired in 1957 as an associate professor of edu cation at New York University, died yesterday, at a nursing home in Whippany. She was 78 years old.

title: Nixon to Give Medal To Crew in Hawaii
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  President Nixon dropped all other duties today to follow the Apollo 13 astronauts during their final moments of descent. He applauded when they splashed down and lit up a triumphant cigar when they boarded the aircraft carrier Iwo Jima.

title: Home WonAfter a Death
description: The family of 15yearold Jimmy Santos got a better apartment yesterday, but it took a group of angry neigh bors and a funeral to accomp lish it.

title: Rumor Government Backed
description: ROME, April 17 (AP)The Italian Parliament gave final approval today to Premier Mariano Rumor's new Govern ment with a 348to235 vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies.

title: Milwaukee Railroad Studies Plan for a Holding Company
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad will con sider forming a holding com pany to diversify outside the transportation industry.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Israeli Jets Strike Along Canal
description: TEL AVIV, April 16 (Reuters) Israeli jets carried out a 70 minute raid tonight on Egyptian military targets along the Suez Canal front, a military spokes man reported. All planes re turned safely, the spokesman said.

title: MAGNAVOX PROFIT DROPS IN QUARTER
description: The Magnavox Company's firstquarter net profit fell to less than half of its earnings in the same period last year. Profits for the quarter were $5,340,000, or 33 cents a share, compared with $11,151,000, or 67 cents a share, in the same period of 1969, a drop of 52.1 per cent. Sales were down 20.4 per cent to $117,150,000 from $147,265,000 the year before.

title: HINT BY RUSSIANS ON GENEVA PARLEY STIRS U.S. INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The White House said today that the United States was in terested in exploring with the Soviet Union the possibility of convening an international con ference to resolve the conflicts in Indochina.

title: Vorster's Rift With Extreme Rightists Widens as South African Election Nears
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 17One of the most intensely fought election cam paigns in 22 years is drawing to a close with new manifesta tions of bitterness between the gbverning Nationalist party and an extreme rightwing splin ter group.

title: Roundup: Cards Topple Pirates With a New Deck
description: After St. Louis won pen nants in 1967 and 1968, the cry around the National. League was Break Up the Cardinals.

title: Fieldston Students Help Move Books Into New Library
description: It was moving day yester day at the 92yearold Field stori School in Riverdale, the Bronx, as 400 students pitched in to fill the bookshelves of their new milliondollar library, the first of its kind in the New York City area.

title: Adams Betters ShotPut Mark In QueensIona School Relays
description: The weather was clear, the track fast, but the only meet record that was set was in a field event as the twoday 16th annual Queens  Iona Relays opened yesterday with a school boy program at Downing Sta dium, Randalls Island.

title: Defense Rests in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)  Defense lawyers for George L. Brady, charged with conspiracy to steal $400,000 from the Boston Common Garage, rested their case today in an effort to have the indictment dismissed on the ground that an unauth orized person heard testimony in the case. Mr. Brady is the former chairman of the Massa chusetts Parking Authority, which built and operates the underground garage.

title: President Will Address Nation on War Monday
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)President Nixon will deliver his televisionand radio report on Vietnam Monday evening from his home in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Miss Goolagong in Final
description: LONDON, April 17 (UPI)  Evonne Goolagong, an 18year old Australian, reached the final of the Cumberland hard court tennis championship to day by beating Marilyn Asch ner, Holliswood, Queens, 36, 119, 62.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE picture that lurks somewhere in our minds of the 18thcentury New Englander as a man of assertive indi viduality, a sort of domesticated Leather stocking or farming type Daniel Boone, does not square with the facts. So says the author of this provoking and disquiet ing monograph. Not only did provincial New Englanders not value pluralism of any kind or any minority opinions strongly held, but they also feared alien ideas and did not understand them. Sure of the truth as revealed by Scripture, they con sidered toleration an absurdity. And since they derived their behavior from their doctrine, any deviation from either belief or behavior could literally undermine society.

title: Cash and Country Music Take White House Stage
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Johnny Cash came from the country to the capital tonight to perform at the White House.

title: DRAFT NUMBERS SET FOR CALLUP IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Selective Service System has told its local boards not to draft anyone with a lottery number higher than 145 in May, a headquarters spokesman says.

title: Massachusetts House Votes Voluntary Prayer in Schools
description: BOSTON, April 16 (AP)The Massachusetts House passed a bill Thursday to allow voluntary prayers in public schools. The roll call vote that sent it to the Senate was 20717.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Boston vs Chicago

title: CALIFORNIAN GETS 67 FOR 133 TOTAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 17 (AP)George Archer, the lanky golfer from Gilroy, Calif, who hasn't won in more than a year, bolted into the lead to day after two rounds of the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open with a sparkling fiveun derpar 67. His total for 36 holes was 133, giving him a twostroke lead over Howie Johnson of Palm Springs. Calif.

title: A Casualty of Campaign Costs
description: The gubernatorial candidacy of Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson has been wrecked by that familiar destroyer of aspirations to high political office: shortage of campaign funds.

title: Israel Said to Bar U.N. Unit
description: JERUSALEM, April 17  Is rael was reported today to have rejected a suggestion by Mr. Sisco that a United Na tions force be placed on the Lebanese border.

title: 5 OF 12 NEW ISSUES ADVANCE IN WEEK
description: The newissue market gave a good try this week to end up in the plus column but didn't quite make it.

title: Alexander Bernardik, 80, A Lawyer for 55 Years
description: NEWARK, April 17  Alex ander Bernardik, who had practiced law in New York for 55 years, died at the Newark Beth Isarel Medical Center yesterday of cancer. He was 80 years old.

title: Search for Japanese Zero Goes on in Pacific Islands
description: SAIPAN, April 17 (AP) While the world awaited the Apollo 13 splashdown in the South Pacific today, a search was under way for another fly ing machine that made history kin the Pacific.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: THORBEEDS for sale, 1 yr old, 3 yr old. 3 yr oldall ready for training Sound In every respect. Also a brood mare. Call for Information (201) MA 30401

title: ANTICRIME PLAN GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 17The Sen ate Joday passed a bill to estab lish a statewide task force on organized crime, to be headed by a deputy attorney general, with powers to hold hearings, prosecute cases and grant im munity.

title: Safe Return
description: The most dramatic space flight in history ended yesterday with the safe return of Apollo 13's crew. For threeandahalf days all three astronauts had lived at the brink of death in a crippled vehicle whose reserves were so near exhaustion that it had margin neither for human error nor for further malfunctioning of its equipment.

title: Display of Lunar Rocks To Open Today in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 17 (UPI) Some of the lunar rocks and dust brought back to earth by Apollo 11, together with an Apollo 12 space helmet, will go on display tomorrow in the New YorkState Museum in the State Education Building.

title: STANS VIEW AIDS TEXTILE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The possibility of legislated import quotas on textiles moved a step closer today.

title: Pollution Hearing Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 CAP) Senator Philip A. Hart, Dem ocrat of Michigan, said Thurs day he would conduct a hearing on waters that had been polluted by mercury. Gov. William Mil liken of Michigan has banned sports fishing in Lake St. Clair, the St. Clair River and the De troit River because of mercury that has entered the water from industries.

title: Agnew Criticizes Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)Vice President Agnew criticized Congress today for failing to act on President Nix on's proposed overhaul of the postal system.

title: WOYDA CAPTURES FOIL CROWN HERE
description: Witold Woyda, the diminu tive Polish star, culminated a day of billliant campaigning last night by defeating Roland Losert of Austria in the final foil match of the Martini & Rossi international fencing tournament at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Mrs. Herbert Scheftel, 51, Dies; Led Greenwich House Benefits
description: Mrs. Herbert Scheftel, whose husband is a realestate in vestor and television executive, executive, died at the ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center last night after a short illness. Mrs Schef tel, the former Sally O'Leary, was 51 years old and lived at 812 Park Avenue.

title: Benefit for Negro Troupe
description: The Negro Ensemble Compa ny will hold its first annual benefit show at the Winter Garden on May 17. Robert Hooks and Barbra Streisand are to be cohosts for the show, at which Lena Horne, Nancy Wilson, Leon Bibb, Chico Ham ilton, Roy Ayers, The Magnifi cent Men and Roseland Cash will perform. Godfrey Cam bridge and Shirley MacLaine will be masters of ceremonies.

title: Apollo 13: Moment of Exaltation
description: Dutifully and inevitably, the aerospace technicians looked to the myths and ep ics of the ancients or the signs of the zodiac to find names for their rockets and missiles. The results of their literary researches were hardly inspired: names like Mercury, Apollo, Odyssey, Aquarius, Saturn suggested to a jaded televi sion age only what was ob vious  that man's first step into space should evoke a sense of won der and exaltation. Such feel ings welled at the appropri ate moments of dramatic climax, but they were quickly dispelled by forces of the age that conspire against wonder.

title: Apollo Set Fuel Record
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) The aborted Apollo 13 mission set one record it did not try for: the spacecraft came home carrying more unused fuel than any previous moonship. The spacecraft had 58,728 pounds of propellant, most of which was to have been burned dur ing the lunar orbit phase of the mission.

title: U.S. COPPER MEN WARY OVER PERU
description: Executives of United States copper companies argued yes terday that Peru had endan geredand might well have losta badly needed $400mil lion infusion of foreign capital with its takeover of the re fining and sale of Peruvian cop per.

title: Holography Goes Underwater
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Dennis Gabor, who is known as the father of holo graphy, or threedimensional lensless photography, was granted a patent this week for an underwa ter version called sonography. In the marine form, sound is used in stead of light. A transmitter sends acoustic waves against objects to be scanned. The reflections are caught by a ring of hydro phones for reproduction as a picture.

title: UNION CHIEF URGES USE OF SPACE GAINS
description: Edward Swayducf president of. Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America, said yesterday that the dividends from this country's moon shots had produced unprecedented technological windfalls reach ing into every corner of our society and industry.

title: Vietnam: An Opening for Diplomacy?
description: LONDON, April 17On Feb. ?? 1949, the American repre sentative at the United Nations, Philip C. Jessup, met the Soviet delegate, Yakov A. Malik, in a corridor of the U.N. building. Dr. Jessup used the accidental encounter to ask a carefully prepared question about the Berlin blockade. After consult ing Moscow, Mr. Malik gave a reply that in due course led to the end of the blockade.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO EASE
description: Prices continued to ease yes terday for the twelfth consecu tive session on th American tive session on the American Stock Exchange in slightly.

title: Community Group Gives Cop Who Cares Award
description: Patrolman John. J. Fleming was declared the winner last night of the first annual Cop Who Cares Award presented by the 24th Precinct Community Council, an organization of neighborhood residents who are seeking to increase respect and understanding between the citizens and the police.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Recently, The Times reported on a plan for electoral reform that will be offered in the Sen ate as an alternate to the di rect popular proposal for elect ing the President. Unfortunate ly, the EagletonDole or Fed eral System Plan not only in troduces an almost absurd com plexity of mechanism into our election process, but also has a basic flaw that makes it com pletely unacceptable.

title: BEAN OIL FUTURES DRIFT DOWNWARD
description: After a record trading vol ume of 19,779 contracts on Thursday, soybean oil futures attracted somewhat less atten tion yesterday. Prices drifted lower for the day although some deliveries made new life ofcontract highs.

title: OUTPUT IN SOVIET UP IN 1ST QUARTER
description: MOSCOW, April 17The So viet Union today reported a significant improvement in its economy for the first three months of 1970.

title: Albert E. Van Court, 78, Dies; A Leading Judge at Dog Shows
description: Albert Eugene Van Court, an investment counselor who was nationally known in the field of purebred dogs, died of heart attack in his apartment at 44 East 63d Street yester day. He had observed his 78th birthday last week.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice.

title: A SAILOR DERIDES CAREER OFFICERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The Five Navy officers serving at the courtmartial of Seaman Roger Lee Priest listened to tape recording today hi which the sailor remarked that career military officers were prosti tuting themselves.

title: TRANSNATION CORP. REMOVES A DIRECTOR
description: Philip J. Levin, chairman and president of the Transnation Development Corporation, an nounced yesterday that Mrs. Marjorie L. Everett has been removed as a director. A spokesman said the action had been taken a week ago, but the announcement had been delay ed because of illness and a mix up in the company's of fice.

title: Towing Fee Is Asked by Grumman
description: An invoice arrived yeser day at the Houston office of North American Rockwell, the company that makes the Apollo command and service modules. It was from the Grumman Aerospace Corpo ration, builder of the lunar module, the moon landing craft that turned unexpect edly into a lifeboat on the Apollo 13 flight.

title: THE LEADING SCORES
Bridge
description: THE recent death of Albert Rose, the English expert, deprived the world of inter national bridge of one of its most engaging personalities.

title: Visa Guilt by Marriage?
description: At a time when increasing numbers of nations are inviting Americans to visit their lands without visas and without scrutiny of their teachings and writings the State Department is using its visa power to deny entry to the United States on political grounds. A few weeks ago Dr. Ernest E. Mandel, a Marxist economist from Belgium, was prevented from speaking here after a number of university scholars had invited him.

title: Vestate Is Postponed
description: The American Opera Society has announced the postpone ment of Spontini's La Vestale that had been scheduled for Wednesday as the society's final presentation of its current season at Carnegie Hall.

title: Newark G.I. Dies in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Army Spe cialist 4 Ralph M. Jenerson of Newark had been killed in ac tion in Vietnam.

title: Sharon Rockefeller's Fashion Mission
description: HERE were two big attractions in the ballroom of 1 Beekman Place the other day: Colorful patchwork fashions, and Mrs. John D. (Jay) Rockefeller 4th. Both are from West Virginia.

title: Police on Coast Wear Pig Pins
description: LONG BEACH., Calif., April 11Sticks and stonesand tear gas  frequently follow name calling these days when policemen are involved.

title: ALCINDOR EXCELS, SCORES 33 POINTS
description: MILWAUKEE, April 17On the strength of a magnificent allround performance by Lew Alcindor, who scored 33 points, grabbed 31 rebounds and ex celed on defense, the Milwau kee Bucks made an early lead stand up and defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 10196, tonight.

title: N.B.C.TV, in a Reversal, To Do Report on Newark
description: NEWARK, April 17 (AP) The onagain, offagain, tele vision report by the National Broadcasting Company on New ark appears to be on again.

title: BROWN NINE TOPS COLUMBIA, 6 TO 3
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 17 Fred Armenti, a senior right hander, and Rich Schainker pitched Brown to a 63 victory over Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game to day.

title: Newark Subway Fare to Rise Tomorrow
description: The Newark City Subway will raise its fare from 25 cents to 30 cents tomorrow.

title: Dr. Frank F. Jani, Physician Of '34 Jersey Quadruplets
description: FORT LEE, N.J., April 17 (AP)  Dr. Frank F. Jani, an obstetrician who became na tionally known in 1934 when he delivered the Kasper quad ruplets in Passaic, died of can cer at his home here yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: N.B.A. Players Get a Writ Blocking Talks on Merger
description: National Basketball Associa tion player representatives suc ceeded yesterday in halting merger negotiations between the N.B.A. and the American Basketball Association. They obtained a temporary restrain ing order in Federal District Court staying the merger dis cussions.

title: Aid Offered in Buying Island
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Nature Conservancy said today that it had agreed to assist North Carolina in buying Bald Head Island. The conserv ancy is a privately supported group dedicated to acquiring natural areas for preservation as refuges and parklands.

title: American to Open Lounge At Kennedy for 747 Flights
description: American Airlines will for mally open a passenger lounge for Boeing 747 passengers at Kennedy International Airport tomorrow as it starts its 747 flights between New York and San Francisco.

title: U.S. Assails Slayings in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The White House condemned today the slayings of Viet namese civilians in Cambodia as abhorrent.

title: Executive Changes
description: Laverne L. Hammer has been elected president CollierMacmillan International. He succeeds Leo P. Mabel, who has been named vice president In charge of international publishing sales for Crowell Collier & Macmillan, Inc., the parent organization.

title: Warriors Sign Ogden
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP)Ralph Ogden, a 6foot5 inch forward at Santa Clara, signed a contract today with the San Francisco Warriors of the. National Basketball Asso ciation.

title: Radio Conversation From Separation to Splashdown.
description: Following are excerpts from conversations between the Apollo 13 astronauts and flight controllers in Houston, as transcribed yesterday by The New York Times. In the first exchange, the damaged service module is jettisoned. The astronauts are in Aquarius, the lunar module.

title: Applause, Cigars and Champagne Toasts Greet Capsule's Landing
description: HOUSTON, April 17  The sign on the marquee of the hotel at the front gate of the Manned Spacecraft Center was quickly changed early this afternoon from:

title: Akiko Kobayashi Is Married Here
description: Miss Akiko Kobayashi of Tokyo and Dr. John Z. Bowers of New York, president of the Josiah Macy Jr.. Founda tion here, were married yes terday morning in a civil ceremony in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

title: White House Spurs Private African Aid
description: David D. Newsom, Assist ant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said yester day that the Administration was seeking new ways of engouraging American private investment in the develop ing African countries.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Richard Neutra, Architect, Dies; Helped Shape Modern Outlook
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (AP) Richard Neutra, acclaimed as one of the world's most influ ential modern architects, died last night apparently of a heart attack at Wuppertal, Germany, his family said today. His age was 78. He was on a tour of Neutra architectural projects in Europe.

title: 2 GUILTY IN SLAYING OF POLICEMAN HERE
description: Two Brooklyn men were con victed of murder last night in the 1968 shooting of a police man outside an East Side dis cothque.

title: Market Place
description: LET'S assumefor the minute, anywaythat you're a relatively sophisti cated investor and that you expect a fairly strong bull market to develop in the months ahead.

title: A Correction
description: In an obituary of Joseph T. Foley, president and owner of the Home Oil Company in Passaic, N. J., in yesterday's New York Times, the name of a daughter, Miss Mary Eliza beth Foley of New York, was inadvertently omitted from the list of survivors. Mr. Foley died Wednesday at the age of 63.

title: Dacca Hardly a Garden Spot, but Pakistanis Flock There Anyhow
description: DACCA, Pakistan It is a striking thing about this Moslem city, the capital of East Pakistan, that few wo men are to be seen on the streets.

title: Music: Creation Bows
description: LAST night in Alice Tully Hail the Juilliard School presented the premiere of Vincent Persichetti's The Creation, which it had com missioned for its opening year at Lincoln Center. It was performed by students under the composer's direc tion in one of the regular free concerts the school gives in Tully Hall. Although not much fanfare attended its first presentation, the work proved to be unusually fine, much of it possessing great eloauence and beauty.

title: THREERUN TRIPLE BY CATER DECIDES
description: BALTIMORE, April 17The Yankees have been insisting that their early problems would go away, that the breaks would even themselves out in the long run.

title: 3 MARKS CLIPPED AT KANSAS RELAYS
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 17 (UPI)  Relay teams from Bowling Green and Kansas and Karl Salb a shotputter set Kansas Relays records today as the 45th annual track carni val continued under cloudless skies.

title: Convicts' Cell Is No Castle
description: DENVER (UPI)A convict's cell is not his castle, the Colo rado Supreme Court ruled; no warrant is required to search it from the feathers.

title: RIOT POLICE ALERT IN SANTA BARBARA
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 17Santa Barbara Coun ty deputy sheriffs, reinforced by riot control squads from police agencies in neighboring coun ties, stood prepared today to quell expected new youth dem onstrations in the community of Isla Vista, bordering the Uni versity of California's Santa Barbara campus.

title: Official of Glaziers Union Draws a Fine of $20,000
description: Sidney Glasser, business manager of a Glaziers Union local, was fined $20,000 in Federal Court here yesterday, following his conviction on racket charges last month.

title: Jordan Asks Recall Of U.S. Ambassador
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 17 King Hussein asked today for the recall of the United States Ambassador, Harrison M. Symmes. The request was in protest against the decision of Joseph J. Sisco, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Af fairs, not to go to Jordan on his current visit to the area.

title: Canada Insists on Protecting Environment in the Far North
description: INUVIK, Northwest Territo ries, CanadaFor 10 days in March, seismicsurvey work in the vicinity of Old Crow, in the northern Yukon, was halted be cause a federal forest manage ment officer felt that the work was causing undue damage to the environment.

title: Patricia Nixon Named to Head Fete for Finch
description: Miss Patricia Nixon, who was graduated from Finch College in 1968, will be the honorary chairman of the college's 70th Birthday Ball next Saturday at 8 P.M. in Potomac, Md.

title: Rockwell Seeks Own Stock
description: The North American Rock well Corporation announced yesterday that it was making a cash tender offer for 500,000 shares of its common stock at $19 a share. The offer expires May 11.

title: Richard McCarthy to Reenter Democratic Race for Senator
description: Representative Richard D. McCarthy, who withdrew two weeks ago as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator, plans to become a candidate again tomorrow.

title: Football Coaches to Meet
description: The National Football League announced yesterday plans to conduct the first joint meet ing of the 26 head coaches in the league on May 24 and 25.

title: Philadelphia Bank to Use Loans to Combat Pollution
description: The First Pennsylvania Bank ing and Trust Company an nounced yesterday that it would lend money at a preferred in terest rate as an Inducement to get something going on the problem of environmental pollution.

title: Killing of 100 Vietnamese By Cambodians Reported
description: TAKEO, Cambodia, April 17 About 100 Vietnamese civil ians, including perhaps 30 children, were shot to death by Cambodian soldiers last night in a grade school where they were under detention, sur vivors said today at the scene of the slayings.

title: WOODY IS STOPPED BY FOREMAN IN 3D
description: The fans were unhappy, and James J. Woody, the beaten fighter, was most unhappy when Referee Johnny Colan stopped his heavyweight fight with unbeaten George Foreman at 37 seconds of the third round last night in the Felt Forum.

title: Student, 18, Seized As Culprit in Fire At Borough College
description: An 18yearold youth, said to have been fooling around with a cigarette lighter that ignited his girl friend's plastic handbag was arrested yester day on a charge of arson, fol lowng a threealarm fire at Kingsborough Community Col lege.

title: Lorca Play in Village
description: The Greenwich Mews Span ish Theater will present Fede rico Garcia Lorca's Dona Ro sita, the Spinster, at the Vil lage South Theater, 15 Vandam Street, on April 22 for an in definite run. Gilberto Zaldivar is head of the Spanishlanguage theater. Rene Buch is directing the play and John Braden has designed the scenery.

title: Graham Urges Renewal
description: PARIS, April 16 (Reuters) The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, said today that the Apollo 13 flight might be used to bring a spiritual renewal that the world so desperately needs at this critical time. At tending a religious conference here, Mr. Graham said he found himself praying almost day and night for the astronauts' safe return.

title: Yonkers to Offer $20 Tickets On Exacta and Double Betting
description: YONKERS, April 17  Start ing with next Wednesday night's program, fans at Yon kers Raceway will be able to purchase $20 daily double and exacta tickets. The experiment, approved today by the New York State Racing Commission, will be made to alleviate the congestion that has been in conveniencing bettors at the $10 windows.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Mortgages. President Nixon appointed five members of the board of directors of the Fed eral National Mortgage Asso ciation. They are: Paul A. Vol cker, 42 years old, of Mont clair, N.J.; Sherman Unger, 42, of Cincinnati; Lloyd E. Clark, 40, of Memphis; Julian H. Zim merman, 52, of Austin, Tex., and Charlek P. Landt, 50 of Raleigh, N.C.

title: Tokens Used as Coins
description: LONDON (Reuters)Govern mentissue plastic tokens de signed to teach schoolchildren about decimal coinage in Brit tin are being fed into automatic washing machines, a member of Parliament complained.

title: BOSCH CONSULTS WITH PARTY AIDES
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 17  Juan Bosch, the former President who leads the opposition Domi nican Revlutionary party, spent today in conference with his party leaders after his tumultu ous return here yesterday.

title: They Adapted as Haunting TV Drama
description: A HAUNTINGLY effective and heartrending adap tation of the novel They, by Marya Marines, essayist, critic and writer, was shown last night on the National Educational Television Play house over Channel 13. The drama, on which Miss Man nes and Harding LeMay col laborated, was an ode to the values of those beyond 50 years of age and their ap preciation that freedom and discipline must go together, that in their time too they wanted truth, peace and beauty.

title: Republican Underdog Seeks to Set Record in Ohio
description: CANTON, Ohio Ask most of the political professionals in Ohio whether United States Representative Donald E. Luk ens has a chance, and they will list the reasons why he ought to losenot enough money, too young, too much of a loner. But then they will tell you that he may win, anyway.

title: Surgery Puts Maloney Out at Least 8 Weeks
description: CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP)  Jim Maloney, Cincinnati Reds' pitcher, underwent Surgery today for a ruptured Achilles tendon in his left ankle, an injury suffered in last night's game against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: ORTHODOX CHURCH IN AMERICAS SET
description: A new, independent Ortho dox Church in America has been formally established by the Holy Synod of the Moscow Patriarchate.

title: OPERA COMPANIES LOOK TO 197071
description: New York's 196970 opera season ends officially this week end with Bellini's Norma at the Metropolitan Opera tonight and the New York City Opera's performance of Massenet's Manon tomorrow night. Although the Metropolitan will be back for a twoweek post script to make up in part for the drastic curtailment of the regular season that resulted from labor difficulties, both companies are already deeply involved in preparations for the 197071 season and have an nounced the highlights of their plans.

title: College Turmoil Continues Here
description: Dsputes at several colleges in the city continued yester day over a variety of issues. Although classes were sus pended at one school and at tendance was reduced some what at others, there were no disorders.

title: Unified Criminal Code
description: After eightynine years, the State Legislature has aroused itself and approved a major recodification of criminal procedures in New York. It is not exactly a model code; too many conflicting views had to be reconciled. But it makes important changes in the archaic language and in the confusing sections of the old law. The opportunity now exists to improve the administration of justice at all levels from the arrest to the appeal stage.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at BaltimorePeterson (11) vs. McNally (20).

title: Peter Veres Is Dead at 74; Headed Hungarian Writers
description: BUDAPEST, April 17 (UPI) Pete Veres, former head of the Hungarian Writers Association and exdefense minister, died yesterday at the age of 74, ac cording to the M.T.I. news agency.

title: TV: Millions of Viewers End Vigil for Apollo 13
description: THE ordeal of Apollo 13 ended for millions of people yesterday afternoon With superlative color pic tires of the spaceship drift ing leisurely from a height of 10,000 feet to the calm waters of the South Pacific. The closeups of the capsule taken from a color camera in In a helicopter, fed to the carrier U.S.S. Iwo Jima and relayed by satellite to the United States brought the week of tension and anxieties to a beautiful picturebook ending.

title: Chairman Is Selected At I.B.M. World Trade
description: The election of Gilbert H. Jones as chairman of the board of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation was an nounced yesterday. He also has been elected chairman of the company's executive com mittee.

title: Mexican Cult of Maria Sabina Is a Poetic Premiere at Carnegie
description: If the real Maria Sabina of Mexico is as extraordinary a performer as Maria Soledad Romero, the Puerto Rican actress who portrayed her in the premiere of Maria Sabina at Carnegie Hall last night, it is not surprising that she has been the object of so much popular and scholarly attention over the last several years.

title: Cambodia's U.N. Envoy Shocked at Atrocity Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17Cambodia's new chief delegate here said today that he did not want to believe Cam bodian soldiers had slain hun dreds of innocent Vietnamese civilians.

title: Korean Heart Patient Dies
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (Reuters) A 12yearold South Korean boy who had been brought here for an operation to correct a congenittal hear defect died to day, the Texas Children's Hos pital announced.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The, three Apollo 13 astronauts splashed down gently yesterday within five miles of the recovery carrier Iwo Jima in the Pacific Ocean. They were weary but unharmed after three days of perils in space that began when an explosion knocked out many of the systems on their command module and their scheduled moon landing was canceled. [Page 1, Columns 18.]

title: Yonkers Drivers
NIXON APPOINTS FIVE TO FANNY MAY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)  President Nixon ap pointed today five members of the board of directors of the reorganized Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May).

title: BOMBING SUSPECT SENT TO HOSPITAL
description: An 18yearold Bronx youth charged with having set off bombs in Federal office build ings here last fall was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for a psychiatric examination after the Government said his acts might have been affected by his use of drugs.

title: Kerry Melville Gains Final On 2Set Upset of Mrs. King
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 17 (AP)Kerry Melville of Australia upset topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., 62, 75, today in a semifinal match of the Monaco open tennis tourney.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, Apr. 19

title: Stage: Birthday for Boys in the Band
description: THE BOYS IN THE BAND has just en tered its third year at The ater Four on West 55th Street, and the damndest thing has happened to it. It has become a period piece.

title: Reserve Fears a Budget Deficit Could Stoke Inflationary Fires
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is fearful that a Federal budget deficit may provide too much inflationary stimulus for the economy in the months ahead, it was learned yesterday. The 6 per cent pay increase for postal workers and most other Fed eral employes, including serv icemen, that won Congres sional approval this week, in creases the danger, a Wall Street source familiar with central bank policy indicated.

title: NETS WIN, 122118, FOR PLAYOFF LEAD
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17 (AP)  The New York Nets, with Levern Tart scoring 46 points, held off a Kentucky rally tonight and defeated the Colonels, 122118, in overtime.

title: Bay Shore Restaurant Burns
description: BAY SHORE, April 16 (UPI)The posh Gateway South Restaurant here was destroyed today in an early morning blaze that is under investigation by fire officials. There were no in juries and no immediate esti mated damage.

title: Berrigan Fugitive, Attends Festival Honoring Him
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 17 The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, the pacifist Jesuit who is now a fugitive, surprised 10,000 young people here tonight by walking into a festival held in walking honor.

title: HENRY C. OSBORNE JR.
description: CLEVELAND, April 17  Henry C. Osborn Jr., former president of the Glascote Prod ucts Company of Euclid, Ohio, and son of the founder of the Addressograph and Multigraph Corporation, died today after a long illness at his home at 2319 Ardleigh Drive, Cleveland Heights. He was 59 years old.

title: Mediator Called by Acting Principal to Settle Dispute Over Parents' Table at George Washington High
description: The acting principal of trou bleplagued George Washington High School has called in a mediator to help resolve the dispute over a parents' griev ance table that has triggered recent student outbreaks.

title: Lakers Turn Back Hawks by 115114 In Overtime Game
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. April 17 (UPI)Wilt Chamberlain, much maligned as a foulshooter, sank two free throws with 17 seconds to play in overtime to night to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 115114 victory over the Atlanta Hawks and a 30 lead in their Western Division playoff series.

title: HARRELSON BELTS HOME RUN, TRIPLE
description: The New York Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies yester day, 60, and crossed two fron tierssomebody finally pitched a complete game and somebody finally hit a home run.

title: When FirstGrade Child Is Troubled...
description: IT was lunchtime when the little boy wandered into the office of the school guid ance counselor. He greeted her solemnly and then made straight for a shelf of toys.

title: Ridge Sues Chargers, Lays Injury to Drugs
description: SAN DIEGO, April 17 (AP) Houston Ridge, defensive end for the San Diego Chargers, sued the team and professional football today for $1.25million because of a hip injury.

title: Silent Screen Is 52 Favorite in $118,000 Wood at Aqueduct Today
description: The Wood Memorial, the New York racing fans' preview of the Triple Crown, will have its 46th running today, at Aqueduct.

title: Graham's 71 for 142 Total Leads Yomiuri Golf by One
description: TOKYO, April 17 (UPI) Daly Graham of Australia posted a windblown one underpar 71 today to wrest the lead from Bruce Fleisher of Port St. Lucie, Fla., at the halfway mark of the Yomiuri international open golf tourna ment.

title: Judge Orders Documents in Kopechne Case Impounded
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)The Kopechne papers were ordered impounded indefinitely in a rul ing issued today by Judge Wil fred J. Paquet in Suffolk Su perior Court.

title: Aides to Mayor and Governor Disagree on Politics of City Revenue Plan
description: The question of the Mayor's political support of the Gov ernor hovered over the negotia tions, a key mayoral aide said yesterday of the intensive dis cussions in Albany this week that resulted in a $469million revenue package for the city.

title: Cambodia Says Vietcong Double Area They Control
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 17 (Reuters)  A mili tary spokesman said today that the Vietcong had more than doubled their area of control in Cambodia in the last two weeks.

title: CHURCHPUPIL AID VOTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 17  The State Legislature approved state aid of $28million for non public schools today, with pro ponents hailing it as a major, but small step, toward saving the troubled private system.

title: ERNEST PITTIAN OF INTERCHEMICAL
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 17  Ernest W. Pittman, presi dent in the nineteenthirties and forties of Interchemical Corpo ration (now Inmont Corpora tion) died Wednesday at his home at Terbell Lane. He was 80 years old and also lived in Georgetown, Washington.

title: City Council Sends to Albany Endorsement of Tax Measures
description: After more than 12 hours of private negotiations and public wrangling, the City Council passed homerule messages early today approving a portion of the revenue package worked out by Mayor Lindsay and Gov ernor Rockefeller.

title: Apollo Nuclear Device Falls Off New Zealand
description: HOUSTON, April 17Snap 27, a nuclear generator aboard the lunar module jet tisoned by the Apollo 13 crew before reentry today, apparently fell into 2,700 fathoms of water in the Pacific Ocean northeast of New Zealand.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
30Day Jail Terms Given 45 Teachers For Buffalo SitIn
description: BUFFALO, April 17 (UPI) Fortyfive members of the face ulty at the State University of Buffalo were found guilty of criminal contempt today for oc cupying the office of the uni versity's president and all were sentenced to 30day jail terms.

title: MARIE COLLIER SINGS IN MET CAVALLERIA
description: Marie Collier ventured her first Santuzza in the Metropol itan's new Cavalleria Rusti cana production last night. Ii was an uneven performance, full of energy and good inten tions, but hardly a very fin ished piece of work.

title: Election of Protestant Militant Dims Hope for Peace in Ulster
description: LONDON, April 17  The prospects for peace in troubled Northern Ireland appeared to have been further dimmed to day after the election of the controversial Rev. Ian Paisley to Ulster's provincial parli ament.

title: BURNS FORFEITS PAY TO BACK GOLDBERG
description: State Democratic Chairman John J. Burns, who is backing Arthur J. Goldberg for Gover nor, has removed himself from the state committee's payroll to remove any question about the legality of my full support of . . . candidates designated by the New York State Demo cratic Committee.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ...the most beautiful film I saw In Cannes in 1969... a film full of force, violence, and poetry.Luchino Visconti

title: Control Data Sets Up New Executive Office
description: The Control Data Corpora tion announced yesterday the creation of a corporate office to share top management re sponsibility in the company.

title: Nixon Says Thank You To Kosygin
description: As four Soviet ships moved into the South Pacific to fulfill an offer by their Government to help in the recovery of the Apollo 13 astronauts, President Nixon sent a message, to Prem ier Kosygin expressing his deep gratitude for the offer but that the ships were not needed.

title: NEWSMEN HONOR MERRIMAN SMITH
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)  Hundreds of Washing ton newsmen paid memorial tribute today to Merriman Smith, chief White House cor respondent for United Press In ternational, who died last Mon day at the age of 57.

title: Quota Based on 196768
description: A key provision of the Mills measure would set import quo tas for textiles and shoes for 1970 based on an average of the 196768 totals.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Confident on City Aid
description: ALBANY, April 17Repub lican legislative leaders said to day that they had enough votes to pass a $400million package of tax and revenue measures for New York City that is de signed to help close a budget gap estimated by Mayor Lind say at $630million.

title: Highest Hopes 31 Choice
description: NEWBURY, England, April 17 (Reuters)  Highest Hopes an English filly, was installed as the 3 to 1 favorite today for the 1,000 Guineas Classic at Newmarket April 30 after win rung the Fred Darling stakes here over seven furlongs and 600 yards.

title: KRISTOFF ADVANCES IN A.A.U. WRESTLING
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 17 (AP)Larry Kristoff, a former Southern Illinois wrestling star, scored a pin in only 22 seconds today and maintained an un blemished black mark record in tile National Amateur Ath letic Union freestyle champion ships.

title: Off Central Park, Apartment in Oriental Mood
description: ACROSS the street is Cen tral Park clothed in its seasonal garb. On weekends, if the weather's right, the strollers are an animated film strip, and colorful bal loons bob in the chestnut scented air.

title: Jones's Brother Injured
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 17 (AP) The brother of Cleon Jones, Mets' star, was injured seri ously today in an automobile wreck. Tommy Lee Jones of Plateau and Roy Weaver of Saraland, the driver, were in jured when their car ran off road north of here and hit telephone pole.

title: NASA TO REVIEW SPACE ACCIDENT
description: HOUSTON, April 17The National Aeronautics and Space Administration began today an official investigation of the ac cident that forced the Apollo 13 crew to abandon their sched uled moon landing and, return to earth.

title: Kheel, Reporting No Progress, Ends Press Talks Until Monday
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, announced last night that he was recessing until Monday the talks between the printers and publishers of the city's four major newspapers because we have been making no progress whatever.

title: Francis Sees Injury to Ratelle As a Turning Point in Playoffs
description: The circus clowns were putting on makeup a few feet away yesterday and the Rangers' dressing room was deserted. The uniforms hung on a metal rod in the middle of the room. The skates lay on benches, under the name plates.

title: Apartment Strike Called Certainty
description: Landlords and apartment house employes broke off negotiations yesterday after the owners rejected a union proposal that would have postponed a strike in 5,000 buildings for 30 days.

title: JAKARTA REALIGNS CURRENCY RATES
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 17  President Suharto an nounced today sweeping changes in Indonesia's foreign exchange rates. Speaking be fore members of Parliament, he said that the new system of a general foreign exchange rate would hopefully simplify the complicated bureaucratic prob lems previously experienced un der Indonesia's multiple rate system for foreign trade.

title: U.S. Says Arms for Athens Are Consistent With Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The State Department said to day that United States deliv erles of military equipment to Greece had been generally consistent with our military assistanceprogram policy of suspended shipment of major end items.

title: 4 WOMEN CARD 69'S, SHARE RALEIGH LEAD
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 17 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, Sandra Haynie, Judy Kimball and Gloria Ehret fired threeunder par 69's today to tie for the firstround lead in the $16,500 fifth annual Raleigh women's invitation tournament.

title: Demand Granted by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The United States agreed today to recall its Ambassador from Jordan, as requested by the Jordanian Government, but the State Department expressed hope that this incident would not impair the close and cor dial relations with the Arab country.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Miss Marschalk Wed To Michael J. Viener
description: The Chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting yesterday afternoon for the wedding of Miss Karen Wynne Marschalk and Michael James Viener. The Rev. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony and a reception was given at the New York Junior League.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, April 18, 1970

title: Jets Release Billy Joe
description: Billy Joe, the popular running back who missed virtually all of last season with the New York Jets following knee sur gery, has been released by the American Conference team after having cleared National Foot ball League waivers. Also re leased by the Jets was Bob Anderson, a placekicker from Iowa who had been signed to a 1970 contract.

title: Manson Trial Postponed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (Reuters)The murder trial of Charles Manson and five of his followers, accused of killing Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons last August, was postponed today until June 15. The trial had been sched uled to begin Monday, but pros ecution and defense lawyers agreed to the delay. Superior Court Judge Charles Older will hear the case.

title: Astronauts Land Gently on Target, Unharmed by Their FourDay Ordeal in Spate
description: HOUSTON, April 17Long before dawn, Eugene F. Kranz, a tall blond man with a crewcut and a voice that resembles Maxwell Smarts, as television's spoofing spy, jumped in his car and made a short journey from his home through the misty Texas night to Mission Control at the Manned Space craft Center here.

title: Fair Play
description: MILWAUKEE, April 17Professional basketball play ers fight three instruments used by management control their lives and restrict competitionthe col lege draft, the reserve clause and forced trades. This week, the owners seemed ready to take up a fourth instrument, the merger of the rival leagues, the older, established, tele vised National Basketball Association and the new, aggres sive, possibly richer American Basketball Association.

title: Killings in Cambodia Stirring Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 The mass killings of Vietnamese in Cambodia in recent days have stirred deep anger among the people here and have confronted the Gov ernment with a difficult political problem.

title: Art: Room That Piet Didn't Build
description: CERTAIN painters inspire dreams of Utopian deliv erance. Their vision seems immune to the common frail ties of human emotion. Their forms transcend the untidy, workaday conditions of ordi nary experience, offering us instead an imaginary uni verse of perfect order. There are times when one would gladly abandon the world as we know it to dwell forever in the sublime fiction of such Utopias even though the emotional temperature they register is not exactly trop ical.

title: 4 N.Y.U. Peformers Listed In '70 ScholarAthlete Book
description: Four scholarathletes from New York University have been selected for the 1970 edition of Outstanding Athletes of Amer ica, which will be published July 1. They are Jim Signorile, basketball; Herb Austin, soccer; and Mike Jacques and Albert Peia wrestling.

title: Age of Inks in Solvents May Be Evaporating
description: Just as wood blocks yielded to metal type for printing, solvent inks may be replaced by solventfree products if a handful of ink companies have their way.

title: News of the Rialto
description: WOLE SOYINKA, Ni geria's internation ally acclaimed play wright, jailed by Nigeria during most of the Biafran war for proBiafran activity, may be visiting the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center this summer. A member of the Yoruba tribe; Soyinka would come with his theater coinpany to the center's Waterford, Conn., headquarters as a special project of the sixth annual Playwrights Confer ence, July 6Aug. 7.

title: Membership Issue Stirs Institutions
description: Some of America's giant financial institutions are be coming embroiled in a new debate whose outcome could be vitally significant for Wall Street and the nation's 26 million investors.

title: YOUTHS CONTINUE TREK TO CORNELL
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 18 Squadrons of young men and women, some of them packing bedrolls and knapsacks, con tinued to converge today on the Cornell University campus for a weekend of political discus sion and rock music that began last night.

title: All Out for Ecology
description: ON Wednesday, the nation will be doing its thing. Earth Day it will be called, a national, student generated teach  in to tell the U.S.A. that it's going down the drain, environmentally.

title: Theater in Providence
description: WHEN the resi dent professional theaters were get ting started, the idea  the hope, at least was that a director and a group of actors would join to gether in some regional city and work together long enough to develop a distinc tive style of their own, meanwhile sinking roots in the community and tapping local sources of creativity.
