But for the most part, this just hasn't happened. Some admirable productions have been created in resident the aters, but they tend to stand as isolated events, not as mo ments in a continuing devel opment.

title: Sinking Craft Is Repaired, Wins Race
description: A funny thing happened to Bill Wishnick, the offshore pow erboat racer, as his bright red Bertram thundered merrily on her way from Long Beach, Calif., to Ensenada, Mexico, in last week's first major ocean race of 1970.

title: Stricter U.S. Tests Asked to Curb Auto Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 18An effort has begun in Congress to improve the way the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare tests the air pollution control devices in cars to deter mine if they meet Federal standards.

title: The Openings
description: HOW MUCH, HOW MUCH? Tomorrow, Provincetown Playhouse, 7. A comedy by Peter Keveson.

title: NETTING OF BIRDS FOUGHT IN EUROPE
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 16 Mounting concern about Europe's environmental prob lems has brought an upsurge of opposition to an old Continental custom, the killing and eating of small wild birds.

title: CANADA EXPRESSES NEW NATIONALISM
description: OTTAWA, April 17The re cent introduction of legisla tion to apply Canadian pollu tion regulations to shipping in Arctic waters within 100 miles of Canadian soil was a step by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau away from the inter nationalism of his predecessor, Lester B. Pearson.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayBennett College, Route 44, Millbrook, N. Y. First year, amateurowner and regular work ing hunters; open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: The Destroyers
description: The demonstrators who during the April 15 antiwar rallies drowned out the concerned outcry for peace with their demands for Revolution Now showed once again their incompatibility with the broadly based movement against the war in Vietnam. Their goal is evidently to undermine any drive for a better society. The rational, democratic search for reform threatens the romantic anarchism of those whose dream of a Utopia arising out of revolutionary holacaust.

title: Rock and the Classics Can the Two Worlds Meet?
description: TO THE EDITOR: I TAKE great exception to Albert Goldman's near sighted views as express ed in his comments on The SwitchedOn Sympho ny. Why must we be con tinually bogged down in lengthy print dissertations on the roots of rock versus the roots of the classics? Why must those in control of the music media contin ually emphasize the harriers separating rock audiences from those that fail to fill Philharmonic Hall? Why don't some of these learned gentlemen attempt to nar row the gap instead of wi dening the breach?

title: Sisco Reaches Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 18  Mr. Sisco arrived here tonight for a meeting of United States Ambassadors in the Middle East and South Asia after an eventful week that included visits to two Arab countries and Israel.

title: Personality:
description: In about two months, C. Gordon Murphy, a 45year old native of Philadelphia and a product of the Harvard Business School, will step into a new job. Beyond all doubt, it will be one of the best jobs anyone ever got by answering a want ad.

title: U.S. and Hungary Pleased by Improving Relations
description: BUDAPEST, April 14  A perceptible improvement in dip lomatic and commercial rela tions between the United States and Hungary is prompting of ficials in Washington and Bu dapest to view the future with optimism.

title: PHILS GET SINGLE
description: Nolan Ryan pitched a one hitter and struck out 15 batters yesterday as the New York Mets shut out the Philadelphia Phillies for the second straight time, 70.

title: Extremists Use Sisco Mission to Inflame Arabs
description: CAIROThe travels, and tra vails, of Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco in the Mid dle East last week illustrate the increasing complexity of the ArabIsraeli conflict and the ob stacles presented by the Pales tinian refugees to a compromise settlement.

title: Robert Coviello and Mary Goss Are Wed
description: ESSEX, Conn., April 18 Miss Mary Louise Goss and Robert Francis Coviello were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Kenneth Thomas:

title: Senate's Rejection of High Court Nominees Seized On as Major Issue by G.O.P. Candidates in South
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 18 President Nixon's nomination of two Southerners for the Su preme Court and their rejection by the Senate have given Re publicans a major issue in state elections in the South this year.

title: Police Patrol Isla Vista Area After Studen tIs Killed
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 18 (UPI)Sheriff's of ficers maintained a light patrol in the Isla Vista area near the University, of California's Santa Barbara campus today after night of violence that took the life of a 22yearold student.

title: Librarians And the Young
description: To the Editor: Gee whiz! When are youall going to stop taking pot shots at librarians?

title: Harvard Lightweights Win Biglin Bowl 6th Year in Row
description: BOSTON, April 18The Har vard varsity lightweights scored their 14th straight col legiate victory today by win ning the Biglin Bowl in com petition with Dartmouth and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology over the 2,000 meter Charles River course.

title: God is dead, and religion dying
description: To judge from The Encoun ter Malachi Martin is an intel lectual arsonist, for he has pro vided in this book enough in cendiary concepts to set off a number of blazing controver sies. There will, I am sure, be readers who will have even more reservations than I about crucial aspects of the book.

title: PETTY IS WINNER IN 250MILE RACE
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N. C., April IS (AP)Richard Petty streaked from far back in the pack today and won the nation ally televised Gwyn Staley Me morial 250mile stock car race.

title: Felix Vallotton: A Few Fireworks In a amp Sky
description: THE name of Felix Vallotton (1865 1925), the Swiss artist whose work is currently the subject of a retro spective exhibition at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 67th Street, is not one that for most of us instantly evokes a particular style or point of view. We may be familiar with certain of the artist's, woodcuts  those graphic images in the purest blacks and whites that combine an elegant contour, an often witty social ob servation, and a sometimes grim political insight. We may have a vague memory of certain paintings in the manner of of Bonnard and Vuillard. But we certainly have no very clear grasp of what the artist's work as a whole consisted of, or even the exact history of its development.

title: Miss Katherine M. Ferguson Married to F. Michael Bushey
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 18  Miss Katherine Mary Ferguson and F. Mich ael Bushey were married this afternoon in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Ecology Day in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 18 (UPI) The City of Boston will observe Ecology Action Day, April 22, by creating a freedom from pollution trail from Kenmore Square to City Hall Plaza, Mayor Kevin H. White an nounced. The trail's streets will be closed to traffic from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Mayor White said. He urged motorists who normally drive to Boston to leave their cars at home in favor of public transportation That day to help cut down on the choking air pollution.

title: Few Cheers For Bad Seed Tests For the Young
description: What could be more appeal ing to politicians than an easy cure of delinquency and crime? This may be why, hoping against hope, President Nixon's advis ers forwarded to the experts at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare a docu ment suggesting that a mass testing of all 6 to 8yearold children might lead to the dis covery and cure of criminal ten dencies in their psyches.

title: Cost of Vandalism in Schools Goes Up 20% to $3.2Million
description: Vandalism cost the city's public schools $3,266,025 last year in broken glass, unlawful entries and firesand perhaps triple that amount if there were figures available on stolen equipment and defaced and broken furniture and walls.

title: Card of Thanks
description: ISELINSKYMrs. Judith Bellnsky and fam ily sincerely thank their friends, relatives and business associates for their kind expressions of sympathy In their recent bereavement.

title: Signs That Brezhnev May Be More Equal Than Others
description: MOSCOW  Shortly after Nik ita S. Khrushchev's fall from power in October, 1964, Secre tary of State Dean Rusk held a background briefing in Washing ton to discuss the new Soviet leadership. With one of his top Soviet experts at his side, Mr. Rusk predicted that the new collective power structure headed by party leader Leonid I. Brezhnev and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin would not long endure.

title: Music
description: IT may be that Amyas Ames, the new chairman of the board of Lincoln Centeras of May 11will be an activist leader. He is replacing John D. Rockefeller 3d, who saw Lincoln Cen ter to its physical completion, from the first plans in 1955 to the opening of the Juilliard School last October. Rockefel ler is, it can be truly said, leaving be hind him a massively concrete testi monial to a vision, and also to $155 million worth of real estate, buildings and brains. But Rockefeller's energies as president and then board chairman o Lincoln Center were spent in getting the cultural center completed. Ames in herits the physical plant and now has the problem of what to do with it.

title: Nixon Is Urged to Compromise on Troop Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Some high Administration of ficials have been urging Presi dent Nixon to adopt a formula for a troop reduction in Viet nam that would serve as a compromise between the de sire of civilian officials to move faster, and the warnings of military advisers that to do so could court serious dangers.

title: The Nation CONTINUED
description: WASHINGTON  Valdez (population now 1,200), a deepwater port on Prince William Sound, will be the southern terminus of the 800 mile 48inch, $1billion pipe line that the Trans Alaska Pipeline System (TAPS) will construct to move the oil from the incredibly rich new field at Prudhoe Bay on the Arctic North Slope.

title: Packers Sign McCoy, Notre Dame's Tackle
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., April 18 (AP)The allAmerica de fensive tackle, Mike McCoy of Notre Dame, signed a con tract with the Green Bay Packers today.

title: ENGLAND IS HELD TO TIE BY WALES
description: LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) England's defending champi on World Cup team ventured into Wales today for the start of the British soccer champion ship and emerged with its repu tation somewhat tarnished after being held to a 11 tie.

title: Boulder Brook Show Signals Start of Spring Equine Campaign
description: THE Boulder Brook show in Scarsdale, N. Y., which an nually signals the start of the spring equine season in the metropolitan area, is sched uled for next Saturday and Sunday.

title: Easy riders
Anne McKey Married to William Batchelder
description: WONALANCET, N. H., April 18Miss Anne J. Me Key and William H. Batchel der, a partner in Jean Rosen thal Associates, New York theatrical consulting firm, were married at noon today in the Wonalancet Chapel. The Rev. Francis G. Cleve land performed the nonde nominational ceremony.

title: Beverley Byrd Is Wed to Lieutenant
description: WINCHESTER, Va., April 18  Miss Beverley Bigelow Byrd, whose father is Sen ator Harry Flood Byrd Jr. of Virginia and whose late grandfather was also a Sen ator from Virginia, was mar ried here this afternoon to Lieut. George Partridge Greenhalgh 3d of the Army.

title: C.A.B. Awards New Routes To United and Delta Lines
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics board chose United Air Lines and Delta Air Lines to provide new service between key North Carolina cities and New York, Chicago and Florida.

title: Mary K. Drury and Jay Michael Dewey Will Marry
description: PHELPS, N. Y., April 18 Mrs. Maynard Kane Drury, formerly of Locust Valley, L. I., has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Katharine Drury, to Jay Michael Dewey, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Wilson Dewey of Big Horn, Wyo.

title: Arfons, at 276 M.P.H., Sets DragRacing Mark
description: ROCKINGHAM, N. C., April 18 (AP)  Art Arfons posted a world dragracing speed record today as he turned the quartermile Rockingham International Dragway at 276.07 miles an hour.

title: CONNECTICUT MISHAP SPILLS OIL IN RIVER
description: GROTON, Conn. April 18 (UPI)About 200 gallons of oil and kerosene spilled into the Thames River yesterday after a barge tore loose a 250 foot section of pier at the Hess Oil and Chemical Company here.

title: Pint of View
description: Executive Director, Citizens Housing and Pianning Council NEW YORK CITY's distinctiveness from all other American cities has been defined in many ways. One of the newest might be that it is probably the only city in the nation in which public apology is demanded from one who advocates residential construc tion by fully taxpaying private industry.

title: New Tank Car Sought For Hazardous Cargo
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) The railroad industry has started a reasearch program aimed at developing a stronger tank car for carrying hazardous materials.

title: Cambodian Town Encircled
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 18 (UPI)Cambodian itary officials reported today that Vietcong forces had encir cled the provincial capital of Takeo and moved to within 22 miles of Pnompenh.

title: Korean Heart Patient Dies
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (Reuters) A 12yearold South Korean boy who had been brought here for an operation to correct a congenittal hear defect died to day, the Texas Children's Hos pital announced.

title: Foreign Policy Ideas Topic Of Dartmouth Conference
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 18 More than 200 students from nearly 50 colleges and universi ties attended the Orvil E. Dry foos Conference on Interna tional Affairs at Dartmouth University this week. Its theme was The Role of Ideas in American Foreign Policy.

title: Marriage Set By Janet Fates
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 18The engage ment of Miss Janet MacLaren Fates, a sophomore at Yale College, to Steven Mitchell Lucas, a Yale senior, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Fates, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Col. John Dalton Lucas, U.S.A., retired and Mrs. Lucas of Columbus, Ohio.

title: $109,245 Tax Claim Settled
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Elwood F. Kirkman, an At lantic City banker, has settled a $109,245 Federal income tax claim for $53,426, records in the United States Tax Court here show. The outofcourt set tlement, approved by Chief Judge William Dernan in an order filed Feb. 25, concluded a tax claim filed against Mr. Kir man on March 8, 1966.

title: Texas Town Takes A Bead on Future
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex.  This subtropi cal city at the mouth of the Rio Grande is saddling up for a tourist boom. Its numerous present attrac tions  old forts, a citywide network of canals, fishing, treasurehunting, a 60stop sightseeing tour, 36 motels (rates around $10 double), 4 hotels, 10 trailer courts and its acrosstheriver proximity to the teem ing old Mexican city of Matamoroswill be overshadowed if plans for the next few years materialize.

title: Villanova Wins Five Titles at QueensIona Relays Meet
description: Villanova returned to the QueensIona Relays yesterday and regained its annual collec tion of championship medals.

title: ARGO PORT FIRST IN $25,000 TROT
description: YONKERS, April 18  Argo Port eased to a halflength vic tory in the $25,000 Hoot Mon Trot at Yonkers Raceway to night for his fourth consecu tive triumph and sixth in seven outings this season.

title: Bronx Discusses Alternate Sites For Its Fixture
description: WE will definitely con tinue the show, said Arthur JJ Haggerty, president of the Bronx County Kennel Club, whose annual event last month was transformed over night from indoors to out doors and left a major problem. Where could the show move if the Kingsbridge Armory was not available in an emergency on its scheduled date? That had happen ed twice, once on March 28, the other time in 1966. On both occasions the trouble had derived from the National Guard preempting the build ing. It could happen again.

title: As Colombia Votes, Rural Town Hopes Violence Won't Return
description: EL LIBANO, Colombia, April 16El Lbano will vote Sunday for a new Colombian President and Congress, for a new state assembly and municipal coun cil  and then hold its breath, hoping that the overwhelming violence of its recent political past is gone for good.

title: Oil Industry Combats Environmental Pollution
description: The oil industry wears a very justified black eye for the part it has played in the pollution of the nation's wa terways and the world's seas.The industry, however, is fighting hard to prevent its other eye from getting smeared and is working to clear the blots its image al ready carries because of its contamination of the water environment.

title: CENSUS IN SOVIET FIFTH SINCE 1917
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Soviet census, whose first results were announced today in Moscow, was the fifth offi cial population count in Russia since the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917.

title: Text of President's Welcome and Lovell's Response at Honolulu
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's remarks welcoming the Apollo astro nauts and Capt. James A. Lovell Jr.'s response at the Honolulu airport yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Soviet Population Is Put At 241.7 Million in Census
description: MOSCOW, April 18The So viet Union's population, on the basis of preliminary 1970 cen sus figures issued today, stood at 241,748,000 last Jan. 15, with the most significant in creases in all urban areas and in the Asian and Caucasian re gions.

title: Mary Patricia O'Brien Is Wed To R. J. Roth, a School Director
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J. April 18  Miss Mary Patricia O'Brien and Richard John Roth were married here this afternoon at St. Mary's Ro man Catholic Abby by Msgr. Richard Scully, a cousin of the bride. A reception was given at the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station.

title: REFORMS PLANNED IN CITY VOTE LAW
description: A series of reforms on voter registration has been agreed on between the city government and Community Action for Le gal Services, Inc., to settle com plaints of interference with wouldbe registrants' rights.

title: Peking Reports Oil Gains
description: HONG KONG, April 18 (Reu ters)Communist China report ed today big increases in oil production and said that the country was now completely self sufficient in oil.

title: STUDENTS ASSIST NEEDY FRIENDS
description: Everyday in his total blind ness, the 21yearold youth would sit at home in solitude and silence awaiting his moth er's return from work.

title: U.A.W. CONVENTION TO OUTLINE GOALS
description: DETROIT, April 18Walter P. Reuther and his United Auto Workers convene in Atlantic City tomorrow for a week of meetings to set the bargaining goals for negotiations with the automobile industry that may be the most significant labor confrontation of the year.

title: Corcoran Gallery Turns Into Ballroom for a Night
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 At the Corcoran Gallery of Art ball, a man on the atrium balcony looked down at the mass of people below and said, There's my wife, haven't seen her in three hours. He put on his glasses, picked up four rolls from a table and accurately hit her four times. None of the other 1,698 guests noticed.

title: Country Music Becomes Concerned
description: NASHVILLE, April 16 Country music, the South's most influential art form, is experimenting with social com ment more widely and seem ingly with more impact than at any time in the past.

title: Article 4  No Title
MISSISSIPPI BLACKS SUE FOR INTEGRATION
description: OXFORD, Miss., April 18 Eight black students expelled from the University of Missis sippi have filed a class suit in Federal Court here on behalf of all Negro college students in the state, seeking an order to integrate totally Mississippi's college system.

title: M.I.T. Building Dedicated
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 (AP)  The $8million Camille Edouard Dreyfus Chemistry Building was dedicated yester day at the Massachusetts Insti ute of Technology.

title: Patriarch Alexis Is Dead at 92; Led Russian Orthodox Church
description: MOSCOW, April 18Patri arch Alexis, head of the Rus sian Orthodox Church since 1945 and a supporter of the policies of the Soviet Govern ment, died here yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: Moscow's Hint on Indochina
description: The real situation appears to be that only a new Geneva con ference could bring about a new solution and relax tensions in the Indochina peninsula.

title: Education
description: I will sometimes initiate and often support radical change, but I will never support...the sei zure of a power position by a selfconstituted group that gains or sustains that power by force or oppression.

title: Home Improvement
description: AT this time of year the homeowner who takes a careful look at the various masonry sur faces around the outside of his house should not be surprised if he finds that his concrete walks, patios, or foundation walls have begun to crack or chip  or if he finds that brick or cement block walls have developed cracks in mortar joints so that some of the bricks or blocks have actually begun to work loose.

title: Chimps Smoke Marijuana
description: ATLANTA, April 18 (UPI) Peck is being coaxed to smoke pot. Peck is a 140pound chim panzee, one of three at the Yerkes Primate Research Cen ter at Emory University that have been practicing with ciga rettes in hopes they can be trained to smoke marijuana. Dr. Warren A. Pieper says the work, being done under a grant from the Justice Department, is to determine if marijuana af fects simple chores the chimps have already learned.

title: Bar Group's Consumer Stand Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The American Bar Association has drawn strong protests from two members of Congress for the publication of a report opposing legislation to facili tate consumer class action suits in Federal courts.

title: Jim Turner to Speak Here
description: Jim Turner, the New York Jets' placekicker, will be the principal speaker Wednesday night at the ninth annual Sons of Xavier dinner at Xavier High School, 30 West 16th St.

title: Business Index Rises in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity roset o 349.6 from 344.4 a week earlier. A year ago it was 330.9.

title: Wider Choice Is Planned In Hungarian Elections
description: BUDAPEST, April 18  Hun garian voters will have a great er choice of officially approved candidates at parliamentary and local elections, it was an nounced this week.

title: ChineseBuilt Road in Nepal Provides a Glimpse Into Tibet
description: KODARI, Nepal, April 18 (AP)A newly opened road to Tibet  a twisting, twolane highway that ends for most travelers at this border check point  is the latest thing for tourists seeking the unusual.

title: The Nation CONTINUED
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General John Mitchell is cer tainly one of the larger curi osities of the capital. He is at once its most controversial fig tire and taciturn source of in formation. Wreathed in pipe smoke and protestations of in nocence, he baffles and frus trates the newsmen who come to call; after an interview they have been known to remark that Mr. Mitchell packs less self revelation into two hours of talk than his outspoken wife Martha does in two minutes.

title: Alumni Score Harvard on Disorders
description: A survey of 1,731 Harvard University alumni by the Har vard Cub of New York City has revealed that more than half are dissatisfied with the way the university has handled recent campus disturbances and that 19 per cent have cut back on their monetary contribu tions to the University as a result.

title: TV Space Expert Honored
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., April 18 (AP)The University of Mis souri College of Engineering has accorded its highest honor, knighthood in the Guard of St. Patrick, summa cum laude, to Max H. Mesner, manager of television camera systems for the Radio Corporation of America's Space Center in Princeton, N.J. Mr. Mesner, who graduated from the University of Missouri in 1940, was cited for leadership in the develop ment of television systems for manned spacecraft and un manned satellites.

title: British Race Driver Unhurt In Grand Prix Trial Crash
description: MADRID, Spain, April 18 (Reuters)Piers Courage, a British driver, today crashed and badly damaged his To mso505 during qualifying trials for the Formula One Spanish Prix tomorrow on the Jarama circuit near here.

title: School Track Stars Get Hitch in Paddy Wagons
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 18 (AP)Fans gathered yester day for the Hendricks Relays at Cuyahoga Falls High School were surprised to find the Louisville High School track team arriving in paddy wagons.

title: Noted Athletes Memorialize Coach
description: NEWARK, April 18Bene dicts hates a Quitter.

title: Banker Scores New Accounting
description: The new accounting pro cedure for bank earnings and those of bank holding com panies, which was designed to enlighten the shareholder as to the performance of his investment, has in fact com pounded the confusion as ev

title: Oil Burns on Lake Maggiore
description: VERBANIA, Italy, April 18 (UPI)Nearly 19 tons of diesel oil spilled into Lake Maggiore from an overturned truck and caught fire this weekend. The flames destroyed a dozen small boats moored at a small ship yard. There were no injuries.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THE SUSPICION that the United States economy was not ready to lie down and play dead drew strong confirmation last week from a series of statistics on its performance in March.

title: Portrait of the artist as aging schlemiel
description: Since Seymour Krim can scarcely forgive himself for not being a great novelist or lit erary personality, the note of selfreproach in the title of his new collection of essays, re views and gossip grows louder as one reads on. His career, he insists, is a history of disaster. Though he (relentlessly) calls them by their first names, more successful writers steal his ideas (Jack Newfield) or his sociosexual thunder (Norman Mailer), snub him at parties (Nelson Algren) and neglect to answer his letters (James Jones). When he finds a good outlet, like Book Week or the Herald Tribune, it promptly folds. Even metabolism con spires against him, making him middle aged when he'd rather be young. But if he writes to a world that isn't listening, this predicament allows him the role of the man who, heroically or at least amusingly, never shuts up. One sees why he ad mires Frank Harris.

title: Marilyn Joseph, Actress, Fiancee Of Christopher Pennock, Actor
description: Miss Marilyn Joseph, an actress, and Christopher Cad walader Pennock, an actor, plan to be married in June.

title: In Human Terms the Slowdown Is Spelled: No Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Although there was some evidence in the major economic indicators last week that the downward trend in the United States economy may be nearing its end, the slowdown so far has produced an increase of about 800,000 in the number of unemployed since last November. What is more, a number of forecasts suggest that unemployment may well con tinue inching up even if the economy levels off and tfien be gins a gentle rise, as the Gov ernment hopes. Who, then, are these unem ployed? Who has been hurt by the slowdown so far?

title: Ithaca Eight Triumphs
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 18 Ithaca College defeated Buffalo State and Canisius today in a 2,000meter crew race on Lake Cayuga. Ithaca was timed in 6 minutes 59 seconds. Buffalo State was second and Canisius third.

title: GABLE IS AWARDED A.A.U. MAT HONORS
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 18 (AP)Dan Gable of Iowa State, the only defending champion to win, was voted the outstand ing wrestler tonight as the threeday National Amateur Athletic Union freestyle cham pionships at the University of Nebraska Coliseum came to a close.

title: Ballot Positions in Newark Upheld in Court Challenge
description: NEWARK, April 18An ef fort to overthrow the ballot line positions of the seven can didates for Mayor  including Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's drawing of the desirable first linewas rejected this week when Superior Court Judge Nelson K. Mintz ruled that the lotterytype drawing was cor rect and constitutional.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Cbrlsumers can be depend ed upon to buy close to their time of need, particularly when they are experiencing budgetary difficulties brought on by inflation. The weather warmed up in many parts of the country, and retailers re ported something akin to a resurgence of interest in ap parel purchasing. Improved volume has helped to soften the disappointment of their Easter figures.

title: Penn Oarsmen Dominate Childs Cup Regatta with Victories in Three Events
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 It was a parade for Penn at the annual Childs Cup regatta on the Schuylkill River today. The Red and Blue heavyweight varsity crews triumphed over Princeton and Columbia in freshman, second varsity and varsity races.

title: Nation
description: WASHINGTONOf the 75 million Federal income tax returns (joint and separate) that were filed by 115 million Americans before the midnight deadline last Wednesday, how many will some day be seen by some one other than an employe of the Internal Revenue Serv ice?

title: Television
description: THE world of television is involved in a com plitated economic wran gle. Sponsors of fall shows are taking their time in making commitments, ap parently waiting for indica tions of how they will fare financially in the year's sec ond quarter. The cost of inter connecting TV stations is be ing increased by the Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph Company, a problem that ap parently is going to be met by adding a few commercials. Talent costs continue to spi ral upward as the networks face the loss of tobacco ad vertising revenue next Jan uary.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Indepth explorations of sub culture are not often found in detective fiction. In fact, only one example comes to mind: the illuminating and evocative novels by Arthur W. Upfield about Inspector Napoleon Bo naparte and the aboriginees of Australia. Mr. Upfield's death in 1968 represented a great loss to our genre, and no one appeared on the detectival horizon to take up his mantle. Now, though it is certainly too early to suggest that Tony Hil lerman, with his first novel THE BLESSING WAY (Harper & Row, $4.95), will do so, some promising flickers come through.

title: U.S. Business:
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18Coal prices are going up. Coal dealers throughout Appalachia say that coal con sumers can expect to pay up to $3 a ton more between now and June 1, and an even greater amount after that date, when the second phase of the Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act goes into effect.

title: Coins
description: NATIONAL COIN WEEK opens today and spe cial exhibits by clubs, banks and many mu seums will provide a golden opportunity for collectors and noncollectors alike to learn more of the history behind coinage and paper currency of the world.

title: Science
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Government moved last week to curb the use of the contro versial herbicide 2,4,5T, it came as a surprise to almost everyone. Critics of the po tent weedkiller had been calling for such action for at least the last six months, but they had expected a long struggle before achieving that end.

title: PENN TRACK SQUAD SCORES 6TH VICTORY
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 18  Pennsylvania's powerful track team rolled to its sixth straight victory in a triangular meet today at Brown Stadium, scoring 101 points to Brown's 64 and Columbia's 27.

title: Guernsey Anniversary
description: Guernsey, one of the Chan nel Islands betweer1 England and France that was occupied by the Germans in World War II, will on May 9 join its sister bailiwick, Jersey, in postal observance of the 25th anniversary of their libera tion by British forces.

title: Husband of Mrs. Mitchell Aide Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The ousting of a local television editor from his job because his wife works for Mrs. John N. Mitchell was evolving into a cause clbre here today.

title: Roy W. Brown, Educator In Jersey, and His Wife Die
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 18 Roy Wanamaker Brown, retired superintendent of the Bergen field. N. J., school system, and his wife, Mrs. Edith M. Brown, died here yesterday in a hos pital wichin four hours of each other, Mr. Brown was 74 years old and his wife, who died first, was 70 years old. They died of natural causes.

title: 169 ARE SUSPENDED. BY MIAMI U. IN OHIO
description: OXFORD, Ohio, April 18 Miami University has suspended 169 students who were arrested Wednesday night after an anti war rally and the occupation of the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps building.

title: Silent Screen Loses, but Runs Well Enough for Trip to Louisville
description: J. Bowes Bond met Willie Shoemaker halfway across the paddock after the run ning of the $177,800 Wood Memorial yesterday at Aque duct.

title: CARRIER TALLIES WINNING BASKET
description: LOUISVILLE, April 18Dar rel Carrier's 15foot jump shot with four seconds remaining gave the Kentucky Colonels a 113111 victory over the New York Nets tonight and squared their semifinalround playoff series in the American Basket ball Association's Eastern Division at a game apiece.

title: The Reminders
description: There was a time when most of our rivers were clean enough for the shad to come up from the ocean and do their spawning. This was shad season, and a few places it still is, because shad aren't the most sensitive fish in the sea. But along most of the rivers, where the sewers and the poisonous factory waste have made the water untenable even for shad, there is a reminder of the days of cleaner watera shrub called shadblow.

title: Samoa Greets Astronauts With Dances and Flowers
description: PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, April 18An exotic Polynesian welcome, with flowers and lively traditional dances, greeted the three Apollo 13 astronauts as they arrived in this tiny American territory in the South Pacific this morning.

title: Ford Agreement Due in Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18 (AP)  Udruzena Metaina Industrija of Bel grade will probably conclude an agreement with the Ford Motor Company on establish ing a joint company to as semble light industrial Ford vehicles, Milan Stokic, deputy director general of UMI, said this week.

title: Chess
Texture for Rocky Sites
description: A FAVORITE spot in my garden is a large boulder covered by a carpet of henandchickens sedums in many sizes and colors. A few small sedums like the pearly dasyphyllum form contrast. Interspersed among them are small hare bells, dwarfed wild columbine, mosses and lichens. Visitors are always charmed by this miniature scene. The boulder is about three by five feet, with rough spots and shallow indentations.

title: Pittsburgh Council Debate and Political Reform Mark Flaherty's First 100 Days as Mayor
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18The City Council chamber here rang with pro and con the oth er day as the councilmen ar gued whether Mayor Peter F. Flaherty had acted responsibly in dismissing nearly 300 city employes in his first 100 days in office.

title: A New Level of Government Emerges in the Nation: Regional Councils to Attack Areawide Problems
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 While the Federal system in the United States has been undergoing severe strain in recent years, an important new level of government has sprung up almost unnoticed by the public.

title: Winning Crew Readies Coxswain for Traditional Rite, but Wrong Man Slips and Gets Wet
Streisand House Getting Set
description: TO her household staff she insists upon being called Mrs. Gould but the rest of the world is likely to keep on calling her Barbra Streisand even after she moves into her new East Side townhouse.

title: Irvington House Is Preparing 8th Bal Rouge et Noir April 30
description: Irvington House, a volun tary agency for the treat ment of children with rheu matic fever and allied dis eases, will benefit from the eighth annual Bal Rouge et Noir, to be held at the New York Hilton on April 30.

title: HARVARD TRACKMEN DEFEAT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 Royce Shaw, a senior, won the 880yard and the onemile runs today and paced Harvard's track team to a 9757 victory over Princeton.

title: DONORS OF ORGANS SEEN AS VICTIMS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18  Human rights need to be protected in the field of surgical transplants, a report from Secretary General Thant just published reminds the members of the United Na tions.

title: Paisley's Ominous Victory
description: LONDONThe Rev Ian Pais, ley, the voice of Protestant ex tremism and the most contro versial figure in the troubled politics of Northern Ireland, will now have a privileged forum to carry on his campaign to keep the country's Roman Catholics a suppressed minority. Last week, after stumping over the country roads in Northern Ireland's Bann side district, Mr. Paisley, 43, won a seat in Ulster's House of Com mons.

title: On the Stumpin Moscow
description: Admitting that his visit to Moscow could be interpreted as part of a political buildup in his campaign for Senator from New York, Theodore C. Sorensen lectured a Soviet audience lastweek in a vein that could do him no harm with voters back home. The Soviet Union, he said, should not keep in adherents of the Jewish faith who have been invited to settle in the state of Israel . . . let them go. Healso spoke on the Middle East, arms and freedom. The former aide to President Kennedy had hoped to have Amer ican newsmen cover his address to the Institute of the U.S.A., which had invited him to Moscow, but the director inititute turned down the reqnest. SoMr. Sorensen taperecorded his speech and played it back to newsmen at his hotel. The Soviet audience's reaction to his remarks, particularly on the Jewish question, was, he conceded, negative.

title: In The Nation: Trouble for Electoral Reform
description: WASHINGTON  Reform of the Electoral College, which al most everyone thinks is neces sary, is in trouble again for the same old reason: not enough of those who matter can agree on which reform ought to be ap proved.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Book

title: JASPERS' MORRIS DRIVES IN 4 RUNS
description: Rudy Wandrusch's clutch re lief pitching and the slugging of Joe Morris, a first baseman, gave Manhattan College an 87 Metropolitan Conference vic tory over Fairleigh Dickinson yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: GIANTS SINK REDS ON 7 IN 6TH, 169
description: CINCINNATI, April 18Ron Hunt walloped a grandslam homer to cap a sevenrun up rising in the sixth inning today as the San Francisco Giants crushed the Cincinnati Reds, 169.

title: HOW THE CREWS FINISHED
description: 1. New York Athletic Club, 18:51:3 2 St. John's, 18:56.5; 3, Manhat tan. 20:21.3; 4, St. John's B 22:06.5.

title: Dance: Variety Marks Brooklyn Debut of Ballet Theater Players
description: ONE of the major difficul ties of touring firstclass classic ballet is the custom ary size of the operation. Companies such as the Amer ican Ballet Theater, complete with about 70 dancers, or chestra and elaborate set tings, are necessarily un wieldy things and can really play only in the best equipped theaters and then, usually, stay a week, or even longer.

title: HOMER BY TAYLOR IS BIGGEST BLOW
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals drov out 14 hits in defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates today. 61.

title: A young approach to restoration
description: In 1968, Thomas A. and William L. Gray, brothers aged 19 and 22 respectively, bought the blue clapboard 1825 dwelling shown left and spent the next 18 months restoring and furnishing it. The house, built by a Moravian in what is now known as Old Salem, the historic restoration site in the heart of WinstonSalem, N.C., was returned to its original appearance outside. Under the regula tions of the community, all modem amenities had to be camou flaged. The airconditioning was centralized, the television antenna hidden in a walnut tree, and the mail slot concealed under hinged clapboard. The boys enlisted the muscle of fellow Duke University students in the project but the heaviest construction, plumbing and electrical work were done by professionals. Thomas, who intends to enter the restoration field when he com pletes his graduate work in art history, and his brother designed the interiors to reflect both their own informal living style and the austere character of the Moravian sect that flourished here.

title: Waterfront Panel Warns of Tighter Security Needs
description: The Waterfront Commission held two days of hearings last week on what it called the compelling need for greater and more efficient cargo protection in the Port of New York.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: SULLIVANGrace Brinkley. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated today, at 9 A.M., in the Lady's Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral, for Grace, who died April 19, 1940.

title: CANNON SETS PACE IN TRIALS ON COAST
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 18 (AP)  Two drivers were in jured today in separate smash ups during qualifying for the L. & M. Continental Grand Prix for open wheel Formula A cars at Riverside International Raceway.

title: BLACKMUN TO GET BROAD A.B.A. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The American Bar Association committee that evaluates the qualifications of Supreme Court nominees has decided to undertake a more extensive in vestigation of Judge Harry A. Blackmun than it has ever made of a Supreme Court nom inee.

title: Letters: Solving the Railroad Problem
description: To The Editor: IN his article in the Travel Section of March 29, Paul J. C. Friedlander urges the Interstate Commerce Com mission to look to Europe and Japan if it wants to learn something about passenger trains. He fails to explain why railroad travel is still holding up and still important in those countries, while close to extinction in the United States.

title: ADMISSION RISKS STUDIED AT BROWN
description: A sevenyear study of 2,100 Brown University students whose academic credentials on admission were less than first rate has found that these risk students go on to grad uate nearly as often as students who had scored higher on Col lege Board aptitude tests.

title: Synthetic Grass Is Spreading Rapidly
description: PRO football players for the most part do not like syn thetic grass based on their experiences in Houston's Astrodome and Philadelphia's Franklin Field. Their com plaint is that the surface is too hard and they are ex posed to skin burns on the forearms from sliding on the turf.

title: Calvin: Champagne, Yes, CocaCola, No
description: FIRST, let's accentuate the positive. Calvin Lockhart is a beauti ful man; no one can deny those matinee idol looks. Long curly lashes . . . skin the color of brown velvet . . .chiseled  out  of  marble features . . . a glistening Afro hairdo . . . six feet of body as trim and taut as a tennis player's. Women swooned when they saw the 35year old Bahamianborn actor in his first big screen hit, Jo anna, in which he played Genevieve Waite's nightclub owning boyfriend. He was so good, in fact, that the scripts came flowing in, and Calvin was (in the words of a Unit ed Artists press release) gob bled up by filmdom. Last year he made five films, and now all that work is about to hit the screen in what might become known to movie mavens as The Year of Calvin Lockhart.

title: Hydrofoil Tested for Commuters to Wall Street Docks
description: A new series of test runs to create interest in the use of the hydrofoil for commut ing to downtown Manhattan began last week on the East River at the foot of Wall Street.

title: PACERS CONQUER COUGARS, 123105
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 18 (AP)Freddie Lewis scored 29 points, 15 in the second quarter, and led the Indiana Pacers to a 123105 victory over the Caro lina Cougars today. It was the opening game of their American Basketball Association playoff series.

title: To Go Forward Or Not After Near Disaster?
description: Two flights to the moon, two landings, two returns to earth were carried through without a hitch. They were the grandest shows in the world, for all the machinery worked almost per fectly and everything that was supposed to happen did indeed happen. Yet now, despite this, a voice on the illfated Apollo 13 could perhaps justly say, I'm afraid this is going to be the last moon mission for a long time.

title: INFORMAL TALKS HELD ON PAPERS
description: Informal talks were held yes terday in efforts to resolve con tract disputes between the city's four major newspapers and their 13,000 unionized em ployes.

title: A Correction
description: The name of Roger W. Cloud, State Auditor of Ohio, who is a Republican candidate for Governor, was incorrectly re ported in The New York Times yesterday as Clud because of a transmission error.

title: Parley of Y.W.C.A. Asks End to Racism
description: HOUSTON, April 18The is sue of women's liberation was subordinated at the national convention of the Young Wom en's Christian Association this week when delegates voted to make the elimination of racism their prime goal.

title: Earth Day and Space Day
description: As the disabled Apollo 13 rounded the moon and flew homeward again last week, there was passionate worldwide interest in its consumables. Was there enough oxygen and water left on their crippled craft to permit Lovell, Haise and Swigert to make it back to earth? Would the available supply of lithium hydroxide suffice to clean their air of carbon dioxide and keep it breathable until splashdown? No great explanations were required to rouse such concern among ordinary citizens. It was selfevident that a small spaceship carries only finite, limited supplies of gases, fluids, food, and other life essentials, and that spacemen must return to earth before these resources are exhausted.

title: WCBSTV News Director To Leave for a New Post
description: Lee Hanna, news director of television station WCBSTV is leaving his post for a new posi tion not yet disclosed. He was unavailable for comment.

title: Brokerage House Reports $575,000 in Bonds Missing
description: Eleven bonds worth $575,000 have been missing since April 7 from the brokerage concern of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis at 25 Broad Street, the police reported yesterday.

title: Tiffany Phelps Pratt Is Bride Of Michael J. Brieze, Analyst
description: SAUGATUCK, Conn., April 18  Miss Tiffany Phelps Pratt and Michael Joseph Brienze were married here this noon in the Congrega tional Church by the Rev. Gibson I. Daniels.

title: Life History of Ruptured Oxygen Tank Studied
description: HOUSTON, April 18Teams of engineers were piecing to gether today a life history of the oxygen tank and related systems involved in the ex plosion that imperiled the lives of the Apollo 13 astronauts.

title: Miss Lynn Duryea Is Engaged To Martin Williams Kindgren
description: MONTAUK, L. I., April 18 Perry B. Duryea Jr., Speak er of the Assembly, and Mrs. Duryea have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Lynn Duryea, to Martin Williams Kindgren. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Kindgren of Tarrytown, N. Y., where his father is Chief of Police.

title: Dr. Norman Cohen Weds Miss Joseph
description: Miss Wendy Ellen Joseph and Dr. Norman Harris Co hen were married here last evening in the Astor Library of the St. RegisSheratan by Rabbi Morris Kertzer of Riv erdale. the Bronx.

title: Israeli Opinion Poll Finds 90% Support Mrs. Meir
description: TEL AVIV, April 18 (Reuters) About 90 per cent of the Is raelis support Mrs. Golda Meir as Premier, according to a pub licopinion poll released here this week.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Recent events have revealed the existence of another minor ity group, now on the receiving end of prejudice and discrimina tion. Southern whites, unlike your editorial writer of April 11, see and feel this clearly, so they don't view President Nixon's remarks on the Cars well rejection as a crudely divisive statement.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONIt is now al most a year since the Warren Court came to an end, and last week there seemed to be almost as much uncertainty as ever as to what the Supreme Court should do for an encore.

title: Down to Kew From London Town
description: LONDONSo down to Kew I went in lilac time, on a bright, soft Sunday in late April. It was just the day to pay a social call on lilacs. The sun was warm. The air was sweet with spring. And the sky was a great field of pastel blue, flecked here and there with ragged white kerchiefs of cloud.

title: New Maine College Post
description: SPRINGVALE, Me., April 18 (AP)  Ralph E. Fenton of Nor wood, Mass., has assumed a new staff post at Nasson Col legedirector of administrative management. The college said Thursday that Mr. Fenton would direct the financial af fairs of the nonacademic staff and buildings and grounds.

title: Students Riot in Italy
description: TRENT, Italy, April 18 (AP) Hundreds of students weilding crowbars and throwing cobble stones clashed with the police last night amid a cloud of tear gas in this northern Italian city. More than 15 persons, 12 of them policemen, were injured. The students were protesting the trial of two of their col leagues on charkes of violence. The court acquitted one of the students and gave the other fourmonth suspended sentence.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Rogers yesterday in structed the United States delegate to the United Nations, Charles W. Yost, to inquire whether the Soviet envoy, Yakov A. Malik was ready to give definite proposals on his suggestion that a new Geneva conference was the only way to restore peace to Indo china. Mr. Malik's remark on the possible conference stirred speculation that it may be the first sign of an impending agree ment. [Page 1, Column 34.]

title: New Avalanche Threatens In France Where 71 Died
description: PLATEAU D'ASSY, France, April 18 (Reuters)A new mass of earth slipped down the mountain here today as griev ing parents lined a churchyard at a memorial service for children killed in an avalanche Thursday.

title: Gull Deaths Laid to Spray
description: PARIS, April 18 The large scale spraying of Mediterranean beaches to kill mosquitos was blamed today for the death of a flock of seagulls on a bay near Perpignan. The gulls are belived to have eaten fish that had earlier fed on poisoned in sects.

title: RADIOTODAY'S LEADING EVENTS
description: Talk, Sports, Special Events

title: West Virginia Court Tells County to Bus Parochial Students
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 18 (AP)The State Supreme Court has ruled in a landmark case that county school sys tems in West Virginia must furnish bus transportation to parochial school students on the same basis it is provided to public school students.

title: Michele Krantz Bride of Robert Silver
description: Miss Michele Ann Krantz and Robert Allan Silver were married last evening in the Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing, Queens, by Rabbi Samuel Schafler.

title: Will Madison Avenue Lose Out to the Ginza?
description: ACOUPLE of New York dealers lens in con versation recently that there was a good chance that the biggest art market in the 1970's might shift from our shores and prairies to Japan. Since both of these dealers anticipated the shift from Paris to New York while the going was good, their prophecy may be listened to respectfully. And apparently, they are not alone. In Tokyo you will spot, now and then, skulking in the distance, a figure familiar from Madison Avenue. It is a New York dealer's represen tative casing the joint.

title: Blue Cross Urges Controls On Hospital Medicare Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Blue Cross Association says that new methods of pay ing hospitals and nursing homes should be developed for Medi care to introduce strict cost controls.

title: Prelate to Be Honored
description: LEWISTON, Me., April 18 (AP)  Archbishop Oakovos, head of the Greek Orthodox archdiocese of North and South America, will be one of five re cipients of honorary degrees at Bates College's 104th com mencement April 20. The pre late, born Demetrios Coucouzis, will be made a doctor of di vinity.

title: ZAMBEZI HIGHWAY MEETS OPPOSITION
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 18A proposal to build an international highway linking Botswana and Zambia across the Zambezi River has run into opposition from South Africa.

title: Morton Bids Republicans Perfect the Art, of Victory
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, the Republican Na tional chairman, told party leaders today, this is the year to perfect the art of victory, not of running second.

title: Holzman Is Too Pressed to Replay His Managerial Career on Milwaukee Court
description: MILWAUKEE, April 18The unpredict able, abrupt twists in the path of a sports professional's life are illustrated again by the presence here of William (Red) Holz man, coach and general manager of a New York Knickerbocker team in pursuit of a National Basketball Association champion ship.

title: In Monmouth, Homes Still Rise, Defying Lag
description: FREEHOLD, N. J.Forty five miles southwest of Times Square, on the fringe of the commuting belt in central New Jersey, devel opments of singlefamily homes are going up at a rate that is in marked contrast to the generally sluggish pace of homebuilding in the metro politan area.

title: The Philippines Maps Plans To Boost Tourism
description: MANILAAll roads lead to Osaka this year, but the Philippines wants Expo '70 visitors also to take in this island republic en route to or from the Japanese fair. In line with this objective, President Fer dinand E. Marcos has mobilized nine Government offices and as many private groups to redouble their tourismpro motion efforts.

title: The Battle Over The 10,000 Islands
description: MAPLES, Fla.We can't consign the Ten Thousand Islands to creeping death, says Joel Kuperberg, executive director of The Collier County Conservancy. And so far, thanks to his organization, the prognosis for the 70milelong chain of islands along Florida's southwestern coast is promising.

title: Brute force and blood were the precepts of rule
description: Nearly 200 years ago the philoso pher Johann Gottfried von Herder prophesied that the work of Frederick the Great, who lifted Prussia into the top league of European powers, would in course of time disintegrate. Herder advocated the dismemberment of Prussia, the unGerman warrior state and its integration into the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Amex and Counter Slumped in Week
description: It was one of the worst weeks we have had in about a year.

title: China Trade Welcomed Here
description: China trade, a source of adventure and profit for ear lier generations of American merchants, is again stirring interest among the nation's business leaders.

title: Alise Captures Two Firsts In A.A.U. Junior Gymnastics
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., April 18 Nicholas Alise of the New York Athletic Club took two firsts and three seconds tonight in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's junior gym nastic championships at the Merchant Marine Academy. Alise's firsts were in, the paral lel bar and long horse vault.

title: OKINAWANS WANT CURB ON U.S. CLUBS
description: NAHA, Okinawa, April 18 The Government of the Ryukyu Islands is demanding tighter control by the American mili tary of servicemen's and vet erans' clubs, which have been accused of unfair competition with civilian enterprises here and of exploitation of the Okinawan people.

title: NIXON, IN HAWAII, JOINS ASTRONAUTS AND HONORS THEM
description: HONOLULU, April 18Pres ident Nixon, who flew 5,000 miles from Washington, and the three astronauts of Apollo 13, who flew a quarter of a million miles from the moon, met today at Honolulu Interna tional Airport to celebrate the successful conclusion of the aborted moonlanding mission.

title: Let Plants Provide Welcome by the Door
description: Aattractive planting around the door provides a welcome. Flower color can be used in ground plant ings, in pockets built into the sides of steps, in tubs or boxes, or in strawberry jars.

title: Greek Regime Sends 40 in Exile to Remote Islands
description: ATHENS, April 18Forty per sons, many of them highrank ing retired officers detained since last year on suspicion of activity against the Greek re gime, were sent to isolated is lands and villages today as dan gerous to public order.

title: Gardens
description: Two great holidays of American origin out shine all others in their freedom from chauvinism, sectarianism and commercial exploitation.

title: ...And Gamma Rays Did Its!
description: No, not that! Not A Dream of Swal lows'! Paul Zin del coughs, winces and giggles at the mention of his 1964 Off Broadway indis cretion. I buried that play, and now you come along and resurrect it. It was so hideous that it closed after one per formance. I can still remem ber riding on the subway the next day. Everyone had his paper opened to that damned review: Swallows Hard To Swallow.

title: Penguins Call Up Four
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Penguins brought up four players from the Baltimore Clippers of the American Hockey League to day in preparation for the start tomorrow of the Stanley Cup playoff semifinals against the St. Louis Blues. They are Joe Daley, activated as a backup goalie; Rick Kessell and George Swarbrick, wings, and a de fenseman, Mike McMahon.

title: SHOLTY IS LEADER FOR DRIVING TITLE
description: CAMPBELLVILLE, Ontario, April 18 (UPI)George Sholty of Westbury, L. I., picked up 70 points in the sixth leg of the world harness racing driving championship at Mohawk Race way tonight and vaulted past Canada's Herve Filion to take the lead among the drivers.

title: Race Driver Injured
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 18 (UPI)Dale Sebring, 26years old race driver, was seriously injured today when he lost con trol of his Formula B. Legrand Ford and it burst into flames during a qualifying run for the Continental Grand Prix.

title: Tornadoes Leave 25 Dead in Texas Panhandle
description: CLARENDON, Tex., April 18 (UPI)  Tornadoes struck 200 miles of the Texas Panhandle last night and early today, kill ing at least 25 persons, injuring hundreds more and damaging millions of dollars worth of property.

title: BACALLAO GAINS IN SQUASH TENNIS
description: RYE, N. Y., April 18Two of the four seeded players were upset at the Rye Squash Barn today in the quarterfinal round of the eighth annual Rye invi tation open squash tennis tour nament while Pedro Bacallao, the defending champion who heads the draw, and Richard Squires, a former winner, ad vanced in straight games.

title: Radio Show Is Honored For Role in Auto Racing
description: The Auto Racing Frater nity of New York awarded a citation last week to Week end on Wheels, a radio pro gram devoted to all forms of motor racing in this country and abroad. The program, now entering its third year on the C. B. S. Radio Net work, is conducted by Jeff Scott, a former race driver.

title: THREE WOMEN SHARE RALEIGH GOLF LEAD
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 18 (AP) Sandra Haynie and Gloria Ehret shot 71's today to join Jo Ann Prentice in a threeway tie for first place after two rounds of the fifth annual Raleigh in vitation golf tournament.

title: Bucks Sign Two 69 Centers
description: MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association signed two 6foot9inch col lege centers todayWillie Wat son, a sixthround draft choice from Oklahoma City Univer sity and Jim Sarno of North western, an eighthround choice.

title: In Memoriam
KEY ROLE IS SEEN FOR KHMER ROUGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The Khmers Rouges, the Cam bodian equivalent of the South Vietnamese Vietcong guerrillas, may become an important po litical element in Cambodia, in the opinion of United States Government experts on Indo china.

title: Lien on Sheppard Estate
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 (UPI)  The Internal Revenue Service has filed a lien against the estate of Dr. Sam Sheppard, 46 years old, for $11,425 it con tends he owed for 1968.

title: $23,150 BEN ALl WON BY GALLANT MOMENT
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 (AP)Gallant Moment over took the pacesetter, Sheik of Bagdad, in the final quarter mile and won the $23,150 Ben All Handicap at Keeneland to day.

title: Tulane Leading Navy Crew In Kennedy Sail Regatta
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 (AP)Tulane won the third and last race today and took the firstday lead over Navy by point in the annual John F. Ken nedy memorial regatta.

title: Hard Times
description: Hard times. Roger, a 14yearold Appalachian boy, living in Chicago: See, I never heard that word depression before. They would all just say hard times to me. It still is. In a worthy sequel to Division Street: America, Studs Terkel now offers up the Great Depression in the words of more than 160 Americans, most of them survivors, a few of them young people like Roger in counter point. The effect is constant surprise. Surprise not only at the extent of the experience that most people called hard times, but the extraordinary depths of the memories Mr. Terkel evokes. With few exceptions, his most articulate spokesmen are not the wealthy and the educated but the working people who felt the Depression most personally. They are natural novelists.

title: Observer: Have a Really Swell Doomsday!
description: WASHINGTON, April 18To be a good guy nowadays you are supposed to live on the brink of hysteria. It is hard after awhile, especially on the throat. All that shouting:

title: Pop Goes the Playmate's Sister
description: TOM WESSELMANN is one of the original and most persevering pure Pop artists, by which I mean those artists who have based their work on a conjunction of fine art forms with subject matter drawn from popular culture. Though he has not lacked for success, however, Wes selmann (like Robert Indi ana) has always operated a little in the shade of the acknowledged masters of the movement  Claes Oldenburg, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and James Ro senquist. And recently his eclipse, at least in terms of critical esteem, has become nearly complete. His current show at the Janis Gallery, 15 East 57th Street, is not likely to reverse this trend, though it does offer a lot to look at and think about. Whatever his faults, Wessel mann remains a very flashy painter and something of a popularculture phenomenon in his own right.

title: Doreen Bergin, A. B. Thompson To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Ber gin of Surfers Paradise, Queensland, Australia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doreen Elizabeth Bergin, to Anthony Burden Thompson. The future bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Thompson of Stowe, Vt., is with Reynolds & Co., stockbrokers, in Sydney, Australia.

title: Pele Draws Most Votes On Warid Soccer Team
description: Eighty soccer writers from 35 countries recently com pleted vote on the greatest soccer players in the world. Pele of Brazil, at inside right, had the most votes, 76, fol lowed by the huge Russian goalkeeper, Lev Yashin, who had 69.

title: U.N. FOOD UNIT SETS $126MILLION IN AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15  an intergovern mental committee directing the World Food Program has an nounced approval of foodaid projects in 22 counties total ing $126.6million, including delivery costs.

title: Nuptials in Florida For Rita Pellegrini
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 18  Miss Rita Pel legrini, an assistant vice president of Dean Witter & Co., the the New York stock brokers was married here today to Robert J. Malm, of Stamford, Conn., president of R. J. Maim As sociates, management consul tants in New York.

title: L.I.A.C. Tops Rutgers, 149, For 8th Straight in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 18 The Long Island Athletic Club extended its undefeated streak In lacrosse to eight today by defeating Rutgers, 149, at Hofstra University.

title: Lane Is Elected Captain Of Columbia Swim Team
description: Homer Lane, a junior from New Rochelle, N.Y., has been elected captain of the 1970 71 Columbia varsity swim ming team. He succeeds Bob Schliehauf, a senior from Bayside, Queens.

title: Article 1  No Title
Long Island A.C. Walkers Favored in Jersey Event
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., April 18Steve Hayden and Gary Westerfield, Long Island Athlet ic Club teammates, are favorites in the seventh annual Borough of Seaside Heights Olympic De velopment 10mile walks on this city's boardwalk April 26.

title: Use of Coffee Rises in Japan
description: Japan, traditionally a tea drinking country before World War II, now consumes 20 million pounds of soluble coffee a year, with 80 per cent of the families there now drinking the beverage.

title: 13 RECORDS FALL IN COLUMBUS MEET
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 (AP)More than 900 athletes took advantage of spring weather today to crack 13 Ohio State University relay records.

title: Soviet Clerk Gets Berth In A.A.U. Boxing Finals
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  A Russian embassy clerk will represent the Dis trict of Columbia in the Na tional Amateur Athletic Union boxing tournament finals starting April 28 in Trenton.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: HILTON KRAMER'S el oquent commentary on the unfortunate Marc Morrel case ruling de serves the widest circulation and support. It is the cur rent political atmosphere of polarization and hysteria  exemplified by such mindless slogans as effete intellectual snobs, and by the severe Chicago trial sentences  which has exaggerated puri tanical fears for the sanctity of the American flag.

title: Miss Murphy Wed to R. S. Haenschen
description: Miss Kathryn Claire Murphy and Richard Stephen Haenschen were married here yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Chuurch of St. Vincent Ferrer. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James P. Sheridan.

title: 6 ExU. S. Officials Earn Top Pay in Defense Work
description: WASHINGTON April 18, (AP)Six former Government officials are among 16 execu tices of nonprofit research con cerns who receive salaries of $50,000 or more a year under Defense Department contracts.

title: G. I.'S IN VIETNAM STIR DUSTSTORMS
description: FIRE BASE WOOD, South Vietnam, April 11The United States Army seems to love dust. It is almost as if dust was is sued to every soldier with his rifle as an essential commodity of warfare in Vietnam.

title: GrantinAid to Andrews
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 18 (AP)Ken Andrews, a high scoring center who tallied 53 points in one game, signed a basketball grantinaid today with Memphise State Univer sity. Andrews averaged 29.7 points and 24 rebounds a game for Puxico, Mo., high school last season.

title: OTTAWA'S TALKS WITH PEKING GAIN
description: OTTAWA, April 17There have been recent signs of lim ited progress in the 14month old negotiations between Can ada and China on establishing diplomatic relations.

title: The New Plays
description: THE EFFECT OF GAMMA RAYS ON MAN  IN  THE MOON MARIGOLDS, a play by Paul Zindel, won raves from the six critics who covered it. Clives Barnes: The new play by Paul Zin del is one of the best of the season so far. The play is about a mother bringing up two daughters. The mother is an acidtongued slut who scrapes up a living by giv ing home to a human wreck whose relations are prepared to pay money for the privilege of not having to look after her. Her house is the last stop be fore the graveyard. This is the kind of truelife melo drama that fascinates Ar thur Miller, and, rather like Mr. Miller, it is extremely successful. My heart was held by it. Melvin Bern hardt's staging is unem phatic and most success fully naturalistic. Sada Thompson's mother is among the best things in the current New York theater. Pamela Payton Wright, Amy Levitt and Judith Lowry also im peccable. For Walter Kerr, see page 1.

title: Houston Channel: A Port Set to Explode
description: HOUSTON, Tex., April 18, (AP)The Houston ship chan nel winds and twists for 52 miles, pushing deep into the flat Texas coastal plain before ending five miles from down town Houston.

title: MERCURY BLAMED IN BAN ON FISHING
description: DETROIT, April 18Mercury, the white liquid metal, is trig gering a big pollution crisis in the Middle West.

title: U.S. and Saigon Reach Accord On Vietnam's Cambodian Raids
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Authoritative United States and diplomatic sources indicated today that Washington and Saigon had recently reached an understanding that would per mit South Vietnamese ground and air forces to mount limited attacks on suspected North Vietnamese and Vietcong sanc tuaries in Cambodia.

title: Car Pool Test Cuts Coast Bridge Traffic
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (AP)A oneday car pool experiment reduced morning traffic on the Golden Gate Bridge by nearly 1,000 cars and air pollution by 2.36 tons, officials say.

title: Miss Stravropoulos to Wed
Penitentiary Closed
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 UPI) The 140yearold East ern State Penitentiary, which once held such inmates as Wil lie Sutton, has closed down with the transfer of the last 28 prisoners. This surely is an outmoded prison, said the warden, Dr. Joseph F. Mazur kiewicz, as he stood in empty central hub from which the seven cell blocks, containing 1,000 cells, radiate like spokes of a wheel.

title: LOSERT CAPTURES EPEE FINAL HERE
description: Beaten in Friday's final in the event, Roland Losert, the lean son of an Austrian fencing master, produced the necessary finishing touches last night to capture Martini & Rossi Epe honors with surprising ease.

title: DOBERMAN IS BEST IN FIELD OF 2,524
description: RESTON, Va., April 18Ch. Fanfare's Ringmaster a Dober man owned by Theresa Laz zaro and Patricia Laurans, from Wassaic, N. Y., led an entry of 2,524 at the Old Dominion Kennel Club of Northern Vir ginia fixture today.

title: A Correction
description: In the map on The Emerg ing Republican Majority in this section last week, the electoral votes for Delaware and Maryland were inadver tently reversed. The correct figures are: Delaware 3, Maryland 10. The Timcs re grets the error.

title: Loyola Crew Turns Back California in Race on Coast
description: OAKLAND, April 18 (UPI) Loyola of Los Angeles handed the University of California its third straight setback in crew racing today by beating the Golden Bear No. 1 shell over 2.000 meters by threequarters or a length.

title: New York, N.Y.
description: John Lindsay went to Nelson Rockefeller last week seeking financial aid for New York City, and came away with the biggest single money package any New York Governor has ever given any New York City Mayor. Electionyear politics may have been a factor.

title: Czech Troupe Opens World Stage Season At London Theater
description: LONDON, April 18London's eighth worldtheater season has led off with as dazzling and courageous a young company as has appeared at the Ald wych. This is the Cinoherni Klub, currently the liveliest of Prague's studio theaters, and in view of the tightening re strictions on Western travel and the risks the company have recently taken with work stud iously ignored by the Czecho slovak press, we are lucky to be seeing them.

title: Agnew Criticizes Defeatists Who Belittle Space Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Vice President Agnew said last night that there were de featists who want to put the space program down in the deepest slum because of the Apollo 13 troubles. But he said that this would be a tragic mistake.

title: POLLUTION UNIT GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 18Gover nor Rockefeller's program cre ating a new superagency to coordinate the state's anti pollution efforts passed the Legislature today.

They are Art Perkins, a fullback who played with Edmonton in the Canadian League. Terry Wil liams of Grambling, a running back, and Lloyd Pate, a run ning back from the University of Cincinnati.

description: Land has been sighted on the planet Mercury for the first time.

description: Two Cabinet members and Presidential counselor are due here this week as more than 1,500 newspaper and wire news service executives hold annual Press Week meetings.

description: BALTIMORE, April 18Hey Good Lookin', charging from far back to win in the final stride, and Corn Caster, pulling away in the final onesixteenth, won the two divisions of the 38th running of the Riggs Han dicap today before a crowd of 17.747 at Pimlico Race Course.
