title: One Monastery, 16 Bars and a Flair for Art
description: ENGELBERG, SwitzerlandYou know what Engelberg means? the rotund desk clerk asked as I signed the hotel register. Angel mountain, he smiled, and we have a monastery to prove it.

title: Stockholder Sues A.T.&T. Over Phone Company Here
description: A stockholder filed suit yes terday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan charging that the 25 directors and top officers of the American Telephone and Telepgraph Company were re sponsible for gross misman agement, misconduct, negli gence and waste in the opera tion of the New York Telephone Company, a wholly owned sub sidiary.

title: The Mood Is Ugly, The Target Is Douglas
description: WASHINGTON  For years the billboards and bumper stick ers along the highways of the South used to read Impeach Earl Warren. Last week, Ger ald R. Ford, the Republican leader of the House, set off new cry of indignation against the Supreme Court: Impeach William O. Douglas.

title: Cleveland Construction Banned In Move to Curb Water Pollution
description: CLEVELAND, April 18The Ohio Water Pollution Control Board adopted a gettough poli cy this week and imposed a ban on all new construction in Cleveland and 33 of its sub urbs until the city moves ahead with sewer plans to curb water pollution.

title: The Northeast Is Floating On a Sea of Maple Syrup
description: JEFFERSON, N. Y.Maple syrup might never have been discovered if an Iroquois Indian chief named Woksis had controlled his temper. In a fit of anger, so legend relates, the chief slammed his tomahawk into a tree near where his wife was cooking, and a clear liquid ran down the handle of the tomahawk into the cooking pot below.

title: Oscars Tears and Toupees
description: OLD HOLLYWOOD has been in the process of disintegration for al most as long as the Broadway theater, but I never thought I'd live to see the night when mortality would provide the theme for a gala Academy Awards telecast. This is not to say that the 42d annual Oscar cere mony was a dead show or that it was about death, only that it was shot through with intimations, all uncon scious, of the imminent departure of just about everythingHollywood, con ventional movies, conventional stars, us.

title: To Raise $1.5Billion, A.T&T. Planned on Vast Scale
description: John Scanlon loaded his pipe with Walnut tobacco and started to explain how you go about raising a bil lion and a half dollars.

title: Three adventurers shook the empire with a lie
description: A tyrant is seldom survived by the system of government he has built up. It is in that belief that the de voted tyrannicide plants his bomb or loads his gun. During July, 1944, a group of German generals decided that only Hitler's death could save the Reich from total ruin; and, more than 130 years earlier, on Oct. 23. 1812, a small party of enthusiastic Frenchmen set out to overthrow Na poleon. The Emperor himself they could not hope to killat least, so long as he remained in Russia, where his armies had just evacuated Mos cow and were retreating slowly west wards. But the conspirators assumed that a report of the Emperor's death alleged to have taken place beneath the walls of Moscow, might be al most equally effective.

title: Spotlight:
description: The trail of the bear grows longer and longer, and Wall Street wonders when it will end.

title: PASSOVER WEEK BEGINS TOMORROW
description: Why is this night different from all others? The question will be asked by the young est child in Jewish households, the world over at sundown to morrow, as it has been for thousands of years to start the weeklong celebration of Pass over.

title: Daniel Hertz Jr. And Mrs. Hurd Marry in Jersey
description: RUMSON, N. J., April 18 Mrs. Richard M. Hurd 3d and Daniel Leeroy Hertz Jr. were married here this afternoon at Rivermarsh, the home of the bride's mother and step father, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred N. Beadleston, by the Rev. Charles Hankins. Mr. Beadle ston is assistant majority leader and Senator of Mon mouth County, Fifth Senate District.

title: Ruling Party in Singapore Wins 2 Special Elections
description: SINGAPORE, April 18 (Reu ters)  The People's Action party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew won two special elections today to retain its monopoly in this island repub lic's Parliament. But voters gave surprisingly strong support to opposition candidates of a party formed only last month.

title: A long journey to a funeral
description: Obsession is a literary con vention, whatever it may be in life. This unusual first novel is the story of a young Mexican determined to give his Indian wife decent burial. For two years they have lived a solitary existence in a northern corner of the Sierra Madre Occidental, a locale best known to us through B. Traven's writing. They are there less through choice than because the young man became a pariah of his town in Sonora by marrying the Yaqui girl.

title: Hints for the Handyman
description: ALUMINUM lawn and patio furniture theo retically needs no painting or other main tenance. However, pieces will look better if the metal is washed down with a deter gent, using a pad of very fine steel woolor one of the abrasive nylon pads sold for use on potsto scour off pit marks and embedded dirt. There are also many excel lent aluminum cleaners that can be purchased. Regardless of which is used, after the metal is clean, a coat of paste wax rubbed on and then buffed will help preserve the bright appearance and will make it easier to keep the metal clean.

title: Princeton Lightweight Crew Beats Cornell for Platt Cup
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 Princeton's lightweight var sity crew won the Platt Cup to day with a fourlength victory over Cornell on Lake Carnegie here.

title: SICILIANS SEEKING GOVERNMENT HELP
description: PARTANNA, Sicily, April 15 Living in a landscape of harsh beauty, the survivors of western Sicily's 1968 earth quake are adopting increasingly desperate tactics to call atten tion to their plight.

title: LEON GETS 2 HITS TO MACE VICTORS
description: CLEVLAND April 18 (UPI) Eddie. Leon drove in one run with a single in the fourth inning and hit a tworun dou ble during a fiverun fifth inning today to lead the Cleve land Indians to a 94 victory over the Washington Senators.

title: Bridge
description: SUICIDAL tendencies are some times observed in bridge experts who have been caught in noman's land and have some explaining to do to their teammates. Noman's land is the area between game and slam, and it includes four contracts: four notrump, five hearts, five spades and five notrump. Such contracts, if reached voluntarily, have nothing to recommend them, for they are in greater jeopardy than the game con tracts that score equally. So a part nership that reaches for a slam, draws in its horns at the last mo ment, and then goes down, is on the road to harakiri.

title: Betsy Blaisdell Wed in Tampa
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 18 Miss Betsy Ann Blaisdell was married here this afternoon to Andrew John McGinley, son of Francis W. McGinley, a member of the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, and Mrs. McGinley of Glens Falls N.Y.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A new city with a popula tion of about 430,000 is being planned for a large slice of the 93,000acre Irvine Ranch in southern California's Orange County.

description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 18 (AP)  Brown moved into strong contention in the East ern Intercollegiate Baseball League race by defeating Princeton, 97 and 84, in a doubleheader today.

description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 6The Rumanian leader ship under Nicolae Ceausescu, the President and party chief, weighs unspoken words as care fully as spoken ones.

Falconi a Gfoot5inch 187 pounder, was a first team selec tion on two AllNew York City squads last season.

description: PHOMPENH, CambodiaWhat with bulletriddled bodies of hun dreds of Vietnamese, many bound to each other and with their hands tied, floating down the Mekong River and an atmos phere of racial fervor demanded by the Government and gladly given by the people, the leaders of Cambodia find themselves in a paradoxical situation:

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 18  Harvard's varsity heavy weight crew made its usually impressive season debut today by beating Brown and Rutgers easily in the annual Walter J. Stein Cup regatta on the Rari tan River.

title: Roughing It In Venezuela's La Gran Sabana
description: CANAIMA, VenezuelaWant to prospect for dia monds? Pan for gold? Gather orchids? Hunt tapirs? Hike and canoe to the base of the world's highest waterfall? Visit a jungle Indian village? Or follow more familiar pursuits, such as birdwatching, sunning on sandy beaches, fishing, swimming or waterskiing?

title: Samizdat? Da, Tovarich
description: THE Russian word samizdat has recent ly become celebrated both in the Soviet Union and outside. It means We publish ourselves and refers to the lively under ground publications that have sprung up in the UeS.S.R., through which Soviet dissi dents distribute works of lit erature, politics and religion that are proscribed by the State.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: For many years, I have given serious consideration to the creation of monopo lies by inventors and dis coverers or their assignees who refuses to license the use of their inventions, and dis coveries fear of creating a host of competitors.

description: April 25  Suburban Sports Car Club rally; start at Acme parking lot, junction of Passaic and Bloomfield Avenues, West Caldwell, N. J. Registration: 7:15 P.M., first car off 8:01. Informa tion: Joe DeLuca, phone (201) 3728135.

title: Tiger Cats Sign Collegian
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, April 18 (AP)The Hamilton Tiger Cats of the Canadian Football League signed a guard, Ed Chalnpka, from the University of North Carolina today. Cha lopka, from Hamilton, is 6 feet and 225 pounds.

title: DOMENICO GNOLI, 37, A REALIST PAINTER
description: Domenico Gnoli, a painter of the realist school, known for his portrayal of details of dress and domestic objects, died Fri day of cancer at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 37 years old and lived in Majorca, Spain.

description: To sit quietly, in a comfor table chair on a porch and breathe in the sweet smells of summer in the country.

title: COLON'S MILE LEG HELPS POWER WIN
description: If you try to reach Tony Colon by phone this week, don't be surprised if the line is busy. The Power Memorial senior, still undecided on what college he will attend, should receive a flood of offers after his brilliant performances in the schoolboy section of the Queens Iona Relays yesterday and Friday.

title: A Correction
description: The parimutuel handle, for Friday's racing program at Aqueduct was $3,345,461. It was reported incorrectly in yesterday's New York Time's as $3,345,361. The original figure and the correction were sup plied to The Times and other newspapers by The Morning Telegraph.

title: Mrs. Nixon at 4H Ceremony
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will help break ground for an ex pansion of the National 4H Club center here on Monday, offi cials of the National Founda tion announced Thursday.

title: CAIRO REPORTS RAID ON ISRAELI TARGETS
description: CAIRO, April 18 (Reuters) A military spokesman here an nounced tonight that Egyptian fighterbombers had raided Israeli missile sites, artillery positions and camps along the Suez Canal from the Gulf of Suez to the Mediterranean coast.

title: Bahamas Prepare for Out Island Sail
description: Starting Thursday, a conta gious carnival atmosphere will invade the otherwise serene set tlement of George Town, Exu nia, Bahamas, when the 17th sailing of the Out Island Ra gatta will be held.

title: Miss Kathleen Sue Menz Is Bride
description: COLEBROOK, Conn., April 18Miss Kathleen Sue Menz was married at noon today to Basil Magor Cox. The bride is a writer for Howard Smith, commentator and in terviewer with A.B.C.FM, who also is assistant pub lisher and a columnist of The Village Voice. Mr. Cox is executive producer of tele vision commercials with Jen kinsCovington in New York.

title: Zambia Plans Stock Exchange
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 18 (AP)Socialoriented Zambia is expected to open its first stock exchange this year. More than 20 companies, most of them mining con cerns, have indicated they want to be listed.

title: Orioles Halt Yankee Rally And End Loss Streak, 54
description: BALTIMORE, April 18Just as the Yankees broke a threegame losing streak last night, so the Orioles did it this afternoon.

title: Fight Tickets Go on Sale
description: Tickets for the international 10round welterweight bout be tween Marcel Cerdan of Paris and Donato Paduano of Mon treal in Madison Square Garden on May 11 will go on sale tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock at the box office. Prices are $20, $15, $10, $8 and $5 for all seats, which are reserved. Mail orders will be accepted for the fight, which will not be televised in the New York area.

title: Brian Richards Walker to Wed Miss Jill Kingdon, Researcher
description: RUMSON, N. J., April 18 Mr. and Mrs. John G. Kingdon have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Ji ??Lincoln Kingdon, to Brian Richards Walker, son of Mrs. Vincent de Paul Dow ney of Carmel and the late H. Campbell Walker.

title: JURY IS CHECKING DEALS IN YONKERS
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 18 A special Westchester County grand jury is meeting here to determine whether any crim inal indictments will be re turned as a result of last win ter's hearings by the State Com mission of Investigation on mu nicipal corruption in Yonkers.

title: REAGAN REMARK A CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 Positions in the preprimary campaigning in California's governorship race have solidi fied to the point that Gov. Ronald Reagan's luncheon speech rhetoric has become a leading issue.

title: World's Youth to Have Its Way at U.N. Conference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18It will be a serious conference and not one of hip pies smoking marijuana, prom ises Franois L. Pouliot, a 29 yearold FrenchCanadian who is a key planner for the United Nations World Youth Assembly.

title: David Towle Fiance of Miss Baird
description: Miss Margaret Moran Baird, Baird, who became the young est registered representative of the New York Stock Ex change when she was ad mitted last year at the age of 21, plans to be maried in June to David Richard Towle, secretarytreasurer of D. H. Thomas & Co., economic ad visers here.

title: Roots of CambodianVietnamese Enmity Old and Deep
description: HONG KONG, April 18 The recent massacres of Viet namese civilians by Cam bodians is a new dark chapter in a history of bitterness and feuding between the two peo ples whose ancient, tangled roots go deep.

title: Staten Island in Cricket Draw
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., April 18 The Staten Island Cricket Club played a draw today against Harverford College. Staten Is land scored 76 runs for 8 wickets and Haverford scored 76.

title: Miss McCarthy Is Wed in Jersey To S. E. Reilly
description: FAIR HAVEN, N. J., April 18Miss Peggy McCarthy and Stephen E. Reilly were married here this afternoon in the Roman Church of the Nativity by the Rev. Harry J. Sievers, a cousin of the bride. He was as sisted by the Rev. Joseph McEvoy.

title: Professor Named Chairman Of Environment Study Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  David M. Gates, director of the Missouri Botanical Garden and professor of biology at Wash ington University, St. Louis, has been named chairman of the Environmental Studies Board of the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering.

title: T. V. NEWS
description: Through the blind eye, groomed and deodorized, expression in place for the cameras, the newsreader nightly conjures youth's protest against itself, the violence of peace marches.

title: Brooklyn Halts Pratt
description: Brooklyn College defeated Pratt Institute, 96, ina Knicker bocker conference baseball game at the losers' field.

title: Lakers on Verge Of 4Game Sweep Of Western Series
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18  The Los Angeles Lakers all but wrapped up the Western Di vision title last night in the Na tional Basketball Association playoffs, defeating the Atlanta Hawks, 115114, in a ragged overtime game.

title: Girl to the Abramses
description: A daughter was born on April 6 to Dr. and Mrs. Her bert Abrams of New York at University Hospital. Mrs, Abrams is the former Miss Beverly Fraser. The child, whose father is a pathologist, has been named Rory Ilyssa. Dr. Abrams is with Kings County Hospital and owner of the ShermanAbrams Lab oratory in Brooklyn.

title: REGENTS REJECT NADER'S Gilt PLAN
description: The regents of the University of Michigan, the University of Texas and the University ewe California have rejected pro posals that they order their in stitutions' shares of General Motors Corporation stock voted in afvor of a consumeroriented group.

title: Recordings
description: SYMPHONY orchestra re cordings have been ar riving in profusion over the past months, and taken all together, they bring up a number of ques tions in relation to recorded sound. Particularly with large groups of instruments, re cording engineers have a range of choices to make. The extremes are:

title: Mosconi Billiard Exhibition
description: Willie Mosconi will play two 150point billiard exhibitions on Wednesday at Albemarle Rec reation, 975 Flatbush Ave., at Albemarle Road, Brooklyn. Mosconi will face Harry Mur ray in the afternoon and Gus Chiariello at night.

title: Apartments Getting Ready For a Strike
description: HUNDREDS of thousands of apartment dwellers in the city face a serious disruption in living conditions this week with the expected start of a strike by 20,000 building services workers midnight tomorrow.

title: JAZZ PAYS A VISIT TO FILLMORE EAST
description: You would scarcely have recognized Fillmore East this weekend. There was no rock in the celebrated rockhouse. In stead, the programs on Friday and Saturday nights were fo cused on jazzthe Dizzy Gil lespie Quintet as well as Ray Charles and his 18piece or chestra with the Raelets.

title: English Quadruplets Well
description: SHEFFIELD, England, April IS (UPI)  Quadruplets  born to Mrs. Derek Shipley, 31 years old, were reported in satis factory condition this weekend doing well in incubators in Jessop Hospital's intensive care unit. Mrs. Shipley a teacher who had taken fertility pills gave birth Wednesday to the three boys and a girl.

title: Gypsy Moths Are Coming
description: DURING the summer of 1969, the gypsy moth defoliated an esti mated 260,000 acres of trees in northeastern woodlands  more than triple the defoliated acreage of 1968. At present, approximately 50 miltion acres are generally infested. Areas include eastern Pennsylvania, most of New Jersey, eastern New York, all of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Is land, and most of Maine, New Hamp shire and Vermont. In addition, the area extends into several counties in the southern part of Quebec, Canada.

title: Washing ton: Repeal the Bill of Rights?
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 You can put it down as a fair ly reliable rule that periods of war or fierce domestic contro versy tend to threaten or re strict the constitutional lib erties of the American people. And with the war in Vietnam and a crime wave at home, we are clearly going through an other such time.

title: ATTRIBUTION TAKES TWOMILE CLARK CUP
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 18 (AP)Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Attribution let Ringling, his stablemate, set the early pace, then closed with a rush today for a halflength victory in the Clark Cup.

title: Goldberg Changes His Attitude And Offers to Debate Both Rivals
description: Arthur J. Goldberg declared yesterday that he was prepared to debate his opponents for the, Democratic gubernatorial nomi nation at any time, but he specified that all the candidates must be included.

title: Students' Suit on Free Speech Splits Westchester Community
description: ARDSLEY, N.Y., April 18A Federal suit brought by four high school students against the Ardsley School Board and District Superintendent has generated bitterness in this Westchester County community of over 4,700 people.

title: City Compromises on Two Tax Bills
description: ALBANY, April 18The city has agreed to compromises on two of the tax measures in cluded in a $400million pack age designed to help close its budget gap and was negotia ting today against state de mands for a bigger share in the take from a proposed off tracking betting bill.

title: ASSEMBLY FAVORS A BIGGER COUNCIL TO AID MINORITIES
description: ALBANY, April 18The As sembly passed a bill today aimed at increasing the number of black and Puerto Rican mem bers of the New York City Council in the 1973 elections.

title: Poor Jennie seems to have had a marvelous lite
description: Paradise, declared the proph et Mohammed, lies at the feet of the mothers. But for her two sons, Winston and John, Paradise certainly did not lie at the feet of Lady Randolph Churchill. When Winston was 6 she wrote her mother that he was a most difficult child to manage. Indeed, it was not until after her first husband (she had three), Winston's father, Lord Randolph Churchill, had died by inches in public of syphilis, that Jen nie, ne Jerome, became interested in her offspring. Winston attributed his very life not to his mother, but to his beloved nurse, Mrs. Everest. He wrote: If there be any . . who re joice that I live, to that dear and excellent woman, their gratitude is due.

title: Miss Gretchen Bachrach To Wed E.W. Hutton Jr.
description: WEST NEWTON, Mass., April 18  Historic King's Chapel, Unitarian, in Boston, will be the scene on June 20 for the wedding ceremony of Miss Gretchen Burdic Bach rach, to Ernest Watson Hut ton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hutton of Waynesboro, Va. A reception will be given in the Women's City Club in Boston.

title: Europe's Rail Stations Blend Esthetics With Practicality
description: Unlike railroad stations in the United States, which are esteemed only so long as they turn a profit, rail terminals in Europe seem some how to stand above transportation economics. They are more than just places to catch a train or meet a friend. Many are, in fact, architectural gems, in styles ranging from monumental to modem, from labyrinthine to flowing free form. European rail stations are equipped with facilities to meet virtually all the traveler's needs restaurants, information booths; shops, newsstands and baggage rooms. Among tourists who passed through these European rail sta tions last year were more than 60,000 American users of Eurailpass, an increase of 46 per cent over 1968. Here are some of the old and new stations that travelers can see while touring the Continent.

title: SORENSEN LOOKS TO GAINS ON ARMS
description: Theodore C. Sorensen is back from a visit to Moscow with the conviction that Soviet of ficials are better informed about the United States than they were under Nikita S. Khru shchev and less hostile than at the height of the war in Viet nam in 1967.

title: Sing Your Own Blues
description: THE Berkeley Blues Festival began as a near disaster, ended in triumph, and in between was a fascinating and often moving presentation of what B. B. King likes to call American music. On the first night, Thursday, April 2, the overflow crowd, packed hot and squirming on the chairless floor of the university's Pauley ballroom, mightily booed student festival director Joe Garrett as he introduced country guitarist JohnJohnson.

title: Odyssey of A Liberal
description: Thorny and indomitable, Freda Utley now is 72 years old, full of reproaches and re sentments, possessed of acerbic wit, passionately didactic and remarkably readable. Life has not gone well for her, what with ambitions blighted and talents run to waste; even this book is set in lamentably small type and blemished by misprints. Yet it ought to be read widely, for Londonborn Freda Utley has had some part in many of the grand and grim events of our time, and has known half the people worth knowing.

title: Bear Watching in the
description: GATLINBURG, Tenn.  Snow was falling up North early this spring as two black bears ambled out of deep woods and into sunny clearings in 512,000acre Great Smoky Mountains National Park. One sniffed at a bearproof garbage can at Elkmont Campground and the other moseyed around Cades Cove Campground. They did no harm, and soon were chased away.

title: DIRECT ELECTION FACES OPPOSITION
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The proposal for direct popular election of the President is in serious trouble in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Earth Day? An Old Story in Naples
description: NAPLES, Fla.A column of quail quicksteps across a street, and traffic comes to a screeching halt....A boy dressed in an al ligator costume ambles through town, bearing a sign that proclaims: Save My Skin. ... Two weeks before the rest of the country pays its Earth Day tribute to ecology, a high school art class spends the day cleaning up the beaches.

title: Dinner Will Benefit Hospital in Nigeria
description: A coordinating committee composed of friends of Fa ther Thomas Rooney of Ma kurdi and the Nigerian Med ical FundChemke Mercy Hospital, will give a dinner at 7:30 P. M. Wednesday in the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of a new hospital be ing built in Nigeria. Mrs. Rob ert F. Kennedy, Ed Sullivan, Walter Cronkite, Morton Downey and the Rev. Jesse Jackson will serve as dinner hosts.

title: The Economics Of Pollution
description: NOW that environment has be come a national concern, it might be well to clean up some of the economic rubbish asso ciated with the subject. There are, alas, a few iron laws that cannot be escaped in the effort to reduce the pollution of our air and water, in disposing of solid waste and the like. The laws do not necessarily prevent a clean environment, but there is no hope of obtaining one unless they are understood.

title: Time for Seagulls to Leave and Humans to Take Over at Huguenot Y.C.
description: The rites of spring for some boatmen are not always wet, loose or lively. For those who belong to the Huhuenot Yacht Club in New Rochelle N. Y., for instance, the time for fitting out, going into commission and spring cleanup consists, among other things, of sprucing up after a group of seagulls.

title: Havelock Ellis and Eleanor Roosevelt helped
description: It is refreshing to find a biography of Margaret Sanger that does not seek to canonize her, and even de lights in her numerous foibles and vanities without detracting from her greatness. Indeed, David Kennedy's Birth Control in America shows how these characteristics contributed toas well as hinderedthe prog ress of the birthcontrol movement in the United States. Really, the move ment is the subject of this wise book. Margaret Sanger appears only as the central character.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.In the last few years chemists have discovered that all crude oils and the products refined from them reveal, when subjected to gas chromatography, a dis tinctive fingerprint.

title: How to Live on This Planet Called Earth
description: As the quality of American life and the debasement of our environment become topics of national concern (though not yet of any significant ac tion), the flood of books on the sub ject approaches disasterstatus in it self. All those trees dying! All those festering pulp mills! All those eyes becoming dull and dim in poring over seas of ink, sandy Saharas of words.

title: Peter R. Stuyvesant Dies; Last of Governor's Line
description: POSTON, April 18 (AP)  Peter R. Stuyvesant of Alla muchy Township, N. J., the last direct male descendant of the famous Dutch Governor of New York, died yesterday at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He was 34 years old.

title: Bucknell Tops Post, 74
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 18 Louis Kissling scored three goals today to lead undefeated Bucknell University to a 71 lacrosse victory over C. W. Post College at Hickox Field.

title: Champagne Heralds Spring and Summer Of SALT
description: VIENNA  At two minutes to noon last Thursday, a black limousine glided to a halt at the. massive Belvedere Pal ace and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir S. Semyonov climbed out and walked quick ly up the marble steps.

title: Taiwan Official U.S.Bound
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan April 18 (AP)Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo left today for talks with President Nixon and Sec retary of State William P. Rogers in Washington. Mr. Chi ang, who is the son of Presi dent Chiang Kaishek, is ex pected to emphasize United States diplomatic and econom is assistance, rather than mili tary aid.

title: Right On! With Lawyer William Kunstler
description: ...there is a disquieting proba bility that the legal subsystem itself is nothing more than the new tyrants' most reliable weapon to ward off any seemingly potent threat to the continuation of yes terday into tomorrow period If the injunction and the conviction can achieve the same results as the rope and the sword comma judges are comma after all comma far more comfortable companions than executioners period And in the last analysis comma due process of law is exactly what the high and mighty say it is period.

title: Astros' Clout Beats Padres
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (AP) Doug Rader belted his fourth home run of the season leading off the bottom of the ninth inn ing tonight to give the Houston Astros a 43 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Mission to the Middle East
description: The arrival of Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco in Israel the other day on his continuing tour of the Middle Eastern capitals was greeted by two developments that underscore the urgency and diffi culty of Mr. Sisco's peaceseeking mission.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To the Editor: The old order changeth. But the new quite often leaves something to be desired. The new artificial AstroTurf on baseball fields has diminished and possibly destroyed one of the few dramatic happenings in baseball.

title: Dance
description: THERE can be few activ ities known to man more rewarding or more frustrating than the building of a dance com pany. Of course it is tough to build any artistic organiza tion, partly because your suc cess cannot be measured in terms of profit and loss, so that even while your product could be improving, its eco nomic viability might be de clining, and partly because you have to prove yourself in a largely uncaring world.

title: Miss Adams, James Bouras Are Wed Here
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katharine Whittington Adams to James Charles Bouras. The cere mony, performed by the Rev. Frederick Hill, was followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

title: Miss Diana Worth Is Married To Archibald McG. Foster Jr.
description: RALEIGH, N.C., April 18 Miss Diana Worth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Clarkson Worth, was married here this afternoon to Archi bald McGhee Foster Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Foster of New York, where his father is chairman of the board of Ted Bates & Co., the ad vertising agency.

title: Jocelyn Engle, Joseph Di Palma Marry in Jersey
description: BAYONNE, N. J., April 18 Miss Joycelyn Ann Engle and Joseph A. Di Palma were married here this afternoon. The Rev. William Buckley performed the ceremony in St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church.

title: HENRY H. JORDAN, PHYSICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Henry H. Jordan, an orth opedic surgeon who was a pio neer in the orthopedic treat ment of hemophiliacs died of a heart attack yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 203 East 72d Street.

title: Article 3  No Title
The Bad Old Days In the Woolly West
description: NELSON, Nev.  The old caretaker at abandoned Techatticup mine is usually happy to see people, within limits of course. His phil osophy is perhaps best expressed by a handlettered sign in front of his house. It says, in big bold letters:

title: The Nation CONTINUED
description: WASHINGTONOn the wall of the Capitol meeting room of the House Rules Committee, a group rarely given to whimsy or charm, there hangs the fol lowing legend in old English characters: Due to the lack of experienced trumpeters, the end of the world is postponed for three weeks. Despite this warn ing, it was with something of a flourish that the end of an era in American Government, the days of the welfare dole, was proclaimed last week in the cavernous and resonant cham ber of the House of Representa tives.

title: Wrestling Loses Its Grip in Allentown
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 18 About an hour before today's afternoon session of what was advertised as the First Invita tional Professional Collegiate Wrestling Championships, An dy Fitch, one of the promoters, walked out of his room in the Allentown Motor Inn.

title: Mary Price Bride Of David Hornby
description: Miss Mary Carroll Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Price of New York, was married here yesterday morning in St. Vincent Fer rer's Roman Catholic Church to David Hornby. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hornby of HoHoKus, N. J.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Warships Step Up Activity in Pacific
description: HONOLULU, April 18 (AP) There has been a sharp in crease in the number of Soviet naval vessels in the Pacific in conjuction with the Soviet Uni on's worldwide naval exercise Okean, the United States Pa cific Fleet Command says.

title: EXECUTIONS CURB CRIMES IN CANTON
description: HONG KONG, April 18  The introduction of harsh penalties for criminal or political offenses throughout China has apparently brought a drop in crime in at least one area, with travelers from Canton reporting that the streets are safer now than two months ago.

title: 3d Daughter to Kampels
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 18 A daughter, their third, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Kampel of East Northport on April 10 at St. John's Smith town Hospital. Mrs. Kampel is the former Susan H. Young of Brooklyn. The child has been named Allison Michelle.

title: COURT POLL LEANS TO CONSERVATIVES
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 President Nixon's recent nom ination of Judge Harry A. Black mun to the Supreme Court comes at a time when the Unit ed States public, by a 5 to 3 margin, favors the appointment of persons who are conservative rather than liberal in their po litical views, the Gallup Poll said today.

title: TEMPESTA EXCELS IN ROUGH CONTEST
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., April 1SNay's undefeated lacrosse team hammered out a 63 vic tory today over Maryland be fore 12,400 fans at Byrd Sta dium.

title: Maida Solomon Engaged to Wed History Teacher
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18Peter H. Solomon, presi dent of the Joseph M. Her man Shoe Company of Millis, and Mrs. Solomon, assistant dean of Harvard College, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maida Elizabeth Solomon, to Chris topher St. John, a descendant of Salmon P. Chase, who was Chief Justice of the United States.

title: P.S.C. Turns Down Appeal on Fares By Penn Central
description: ALBANY, April 18 (UPI) The state Public Service Com mission has turned down a petition by the Penn Central for a rehearing on its earlier ruling that fares might not be increased for New York State riders on the New Haven Divi sion.

title: Many Youths Face a Jobless Summer
description: Several hundred thousand youths across the country face the prospect of a job less summer this year as the nation's economic slowdown causes hundreds of com panies to reduce or eliminate summer hiring.

title: Yale Wins Pair, 31, 41
description: NEW HAVEN, April 18  Jay Bryan and Jim McNerney pitched complete game victories today as Yale defeated Colum bia in a doubleheader, 31 and 41.

title: Der Chef Wraps Up His 17th Ring
description: SALZBURG, Austria THE whole responsibil ity is on me, says Herbert von Karajan draping a leg over the side of a low, modern chair in his woodpaneled of fice. And I know precisely what I'm up against. Normal ly you can complainthere were not enough rehearsals, or the orchestra wasn't good. But here in Salzburg I cannot say this. I have no excuse because nothing comes out except as I conceive it. For me, this is a mirror for my artistic existence. In this mir ror I can see how far I have progressed or not.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: J. Anthony Lukas concludes his excellent article on the recent trial of the Chicago Eight (The Second Confron tation in Chicago, Mardi 29) with the observation that in stitutionsin this case the courts  are perhaps best tested under extraordinary pressure. Against this stand ard, Mr. Lukas finds the court system locking.

title: Boston U. Heavyweight Crew Wins First Victory Since '67
description: BOSTON, April 18The Bos ton University heavyweight crew scored its first victory since the 1967 season today by defeating Northeastern and Massachusetts Institute of Tech nology over the 2,000meter Charles River course.

title: Three Came Back as The World Held Its Breath
description: HOUSTON  There have been epic voyages of survival in the past, such as the 3,618mile life boat voyage of Captain Bligh, of mutiny on the Bounty fame, in 1789, or the Incredible journey of Sir Ernest Shackleton across the stormtorn Antarctic Ocean in 1916. But the world did not learn of these feats until years after the event. Last week's saga of Apollo 13 was fought out with most of mankind hanging on each move.

title: MRS. KELLETT WINS FROSTBITE LAURELS
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 18 Mrs. Pam Kellett, represent ing Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, won the first Long Island Sound Women's Frostbite championship sailed on Oyster Bay harbor today.

title: SLUM BUSINESSES HARDHIT BY CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Crime against urban slum stores is so serious that it is undermining the chances for success of Black Capitalism in the ghetto, an official of the Small Business Administration said today.

title: Try Corporate Souls
description: After last Wednesday's an nual meeting of the Amer ican Telephone & Telegraph Company, H. I. Romnes, chairman, must know well what Thomas Paine meant when he wrote:

title: The evil and Cecil Williamson
description: BOCASTLE, EnglandHe was not the halfexpected somber Faus tian figure in flowing robes, nor did he materialize at the quay side in a puff of green smoke. Instead, he arrived by station wagon, was wear ing a tweed jacket and looked every inch a seaside businessman and ab surdly unlike a wizard.

title: U Mass Tops Vermont, 43
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 18 (AP)Paul Sulzicki doubled home the tiebreaking run in the eighth inning today as the University of Massachusetts defeated Vermont, 43, for its second Yankee Conference baseball victory over the Cata mounts in two days.

title: How Tracks Differ
description: The main track at Belmont Park is 1 miles round, but it has a shorter stretch run than either Aqueduct or Saratoga, each 1 miles round. The dis tance from the home turn to the wire at Belmont Park is 1,097 feet. It's 1,155 at Aque duct and 1,156 at Saratoga.

title: U.S. General Hurtin Vietnam
description: DANANG, Sout, Vietnam. April 18 (AP)The commander of the United States First Ma rine Division, Maj. Gen. Edwin R. Wheneler, suffered a broken leg today in a helicopter crash about 15 miles southwest of here, military spokesmen re ?? ??.

title: BOIARDO SAID TO END TIES WITH COMPANY
description: NEWARK, April 18 (AP) The Valentine Electric Com pany said today that Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo, a reputed Mafia figure, and Joseph Bian cone, both under Federal in dictment with Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and 10 other de fendants, have severed their connections with the company.

title: The Men Who Wield the Baton
description: CONDUCTORS. They are in the news these days for many reasons, some of them unfortunate. William Steinberg's illness this year meant some re shuffling of schedules for the two orchestras of which he is music director. With the Boston Symphony it provided unusual opportunities for its young assistant conductor, Michael Tilson Thomas, and with the Pittsburgh Sympho ny the spotlight was put on its associate conductor, Hen ry Mazer.

title: Liberalized Abortion Vetoed in Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, April 18 (AP)  Gov. Keith Miller, de claring his decision a matter of the Tight to life, has vetoed legislation that would have given Alaska an abortion law almost without restrictions.

title: Delays in Issuing Passports Linked to political Infighting
description: WASHINGTON  When you are doing business with the Fed eral Government, it is some times not easy to tell whether you are actually making progress or merely treading water. For a while dur ing the hearing here on a bill to reorganize the Passport Office of the Department of State to provide more efficient and convenient passport serv ice to citizens of the United States of .America, it seemed as if prompt and decisive action would be forthcoming.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, April 19, 1970

title: Young and Old Labor to Make Parts of City Gleam in Earth Day Prelude
description: Armed with brooms, dust pans and litter bags, hun dreds of children and adults invaded Central Park, the Botanical Garden in the Bronx and East 86th Street yesterday in an assault on trash and its progenitors: public neglect and apathy. It was a beautiful spring day with plenty of sunshine, tem peratures in the mid60's and buds sprouting on bushes and trees, and for many it was a perfect day to begin a personal fight against pollu tion and blight. The cam paign, a prelude to the ob servance of Earth Day here and across the nation next Wednesday, mustered the forces of city officials and equipment, Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, youth organiza tions, adult volunteers and even some passersby. Else where in the city, there were workshops, symposi ums, speeches and proclama tions, all keyed to the prob lems of pollution and the rescue of the deteriorating environment. At a workshop for teenagers at the South Street Seaport Museum, 13 yearold Edward Simmons summed up the day's prevail ing feeling this way: Last year I read the papers and figured I didn't have very long to live. But now I'm beginning to think maybe I won't die so soon, be cause more people are seeing what's wrongand something's got to happen.

title: Miss Heldman is Selected For Federation Cup Team
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 18 (UPI)  Three players were named today to the United States Federation Cup tennis team.

title: UKRAINIANS MEET ELIZABETH TODAY
description: The New York Ukrainians and Elizabeth of New Jersey, two of the strongest soccer teams in the Eastern, will clash in the eastern final of the Unit ed States Challenge Cup today at Metropolitan Oval in Mas peth, Queens. The contest is scheduled for 2.30 o'clock.

title: There Is No Raymond Aron Cult
description: TO find Raymond Aron, you must walk through the courtyard of a once elegant mansion, lov ingly built by a merchant prince some centuries ago, on the Left Bank of the Seine near the Sorbonne. You climb a wide marble staircase, a gal lery of statues along a gray wall to your left, then wander along a high ceilinged corridor, dimly lit by a few unshaded bulbs. You reach a door, on which is tacked a piece of white paper with the words Sociologie Europeene printed on it in pen. You knock and are invited to enter. In side sits a small man wrapped in sweaters, with the profile of Fearless Fosdick, surrounded by books, warm ing his feet before an electric heater. This is Raymond Aron, whom some consider the most pertinent social analyst in France today.

title: Rogers Says U, So Presses Malik for Views on Parley
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers said yesterday that the United States was attempt ing to find out whether the Soviet Union was ready to make any specific proposals concerning a new Geneva con ference on Indochina.

title: Manson Associate Guilty Of Murdering Musician
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18 (UPI) Robert Kenneth Beausoleil, a former member of the Man son family, was found guilty today of firstdegree murder in the tortureslaying of a musi cian, Gary Hinman.

title: Article 2  No Title
Photography
description: MOST photographic prints are no bigger than book size or, at biggest, picture mag azine size. The print repro duced on this page, an un titled work by John Spence Weir currently on exhibit at the Witkin Gallery, measures 5 by 13 inches. There is no reason why photographs should be so smallno tech nical reason, that is. In last year's Harlem on My Mind at the Metropolitan Museum, photographs were blown up to mural size, often to great effect. Huge enlargements occur when pictures are pro jected, as in this season's America in Crisis at the Riverside Museum or in any movie theater, and the back lighted color transparency in the Kodak advertisement at Grand Central Station is 18 feet high by 60 feet long, or roughly 50 times the size of Weir's print.

title: Cecil could runbut he couldn't hide
description: By John Edgar Wideman. 185 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & World. $5.95.

title: Scoring Blunders Put Fans Off Track On Race Telecast
description: FOR some time now the motorracing industry has been drooling in anticipation of all that luscious television money. A bit of loot already is being disbursed, but man, wait till it really starts to flow, like pro football! Pro moters, sanctioning bodies, drivers, sponsors and press agents consider television only in the context of money. No one wants to be caught in the heretical thought of giving some consideration to the motorracing fan, one of the most abused paying custom ers in sports. It seems un kind to spoil the fun, but to day is the time for the fan to insist on quality now rather than later, when the racingTV alliance will be un Oakeable.

title: 3 Americans Leave Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, April 18 (Reu ters)  Three Americans left Hanoi yesterday after having met Premier Pham Van Dong and other North Vietnamese officials, the Vietnam press agency said in a broadcast monitored here today. They were Noam Chomsky, professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Prof Douglas Dowd of Cornell, an economist, and Richard Fernandez, chair man of the Committtee for Clergymen and Laymen Con cerned About Vietnam.

title: MATSON CAPTURES KANSAS SHOTPUT
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (AP)Randy Matson and John Carlos stood off challenges to day but the decathlon star, Russ Hodge, was less fortunate and quit with one event to go as the 45th Kansas Relays con cluded in the rain.

title: A WELFARE BILL PASSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 18A bill that would strip welfare depart ments of the right to withhold rents from landlords of dan gerous, hazardous apartments received final legislative ap proval today in the Senate.

title: Joyous Families Fly With Nixon to 3 Astronauts
description: HONOLULU, April 18 (UPI) A brilliant rainbow arched today as America's three as tronauts from Apollo 13 em braced their loved ones.

title: Julia Fulper Bride Of W. MC. Hardt 3d
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 18Miss Julia Pearce Fulper was married at noon today to William McCulley Hardt 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardt 2nd of Rosement, Pa. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the Princeton Chapel, per formed the ceremony there.

title: Australia Curbs Exports of Meat
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)The Australian Meat Board has tightened export requirements for sales abroad to promote a market diversi fication among countries other than the United States, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Midwest Democrats Healing wounds After the Divisions of 1968
description: CHICAGO, April 18They haven't really buried the hatchet. But everybody needs everybody else this time, and a chance to win is enough to produce some unity, or at least to paper over the cracks.

title: Woman Driver No Drag on Racing Strip
description: You can take Della Woods's word for it, the men simply don't like women drag racers.

title: Delaware Chief Third In Prep for the Derby
description: In a furious finish, which saw three horses together the manner of a Roman chariot race, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Personality was first across the line in the $117,800 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday. The famous 1mile stakes attracted a field of 14 contestants, and the 55,004 players established Silent Screen of the Elberon Farm the favorite.

title: Hawks and Bruins Start Series Today
description: Peace and quietNational Hockey Leaguestylereturns to the sport today as the fourofseven game series to decide the East and West division champions be gins at Chicago and St. Louis.

title: Crepes without Suzette
description: Time was when you said the word crepe to the average American, it evoked one image: crepes Suzette. No longer. Crepes with a savory filling such as crab and curry or a mixture of sea food and hollandaise are fairly common, and varia tions seem endless. We give here one that blends mushrooms, chicken, spinach and cheese.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Blood

title: Architecture
description: ARE in retro spect takes on curious connotations. The in surgent becomes deja vu. De Stijl, the Dutch move ment that announced itself as a radical renewal of art in 1917, is now an indelible part of the world it set out to change. It is common cur rency. And like all such cur rency, shiny and rare when it was new, it managed to get debased to Mondrian knock offs in the 1940's in ad agency formulas and linoleum pat terns at the most popular and visible levels.

title: Army Posts 92 Triumph Over Hofstra in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 18 Ed Hirsch and Marty Knorr combined for seven goals to night, leading the Army la crosse team to 92 victory over Hofstra.

title: Francis Gary Powers Tells His Story
description: NOT long after the installation in the U2 of the granger, a device designed to throw off radar, the intelligence officer in troduced us to another new piece of equipment. We couldn't figure it out. It looked like a goodluck charm, an ordinary silver dollar with a metal loop so it could be fastened to a key chain or a chain around the neck.

title: AIDES TRY TO END FORDHAM STRIKE
description: Student demonstrations for academic reforms have reached a critical stage at traditionally tranquil Fordham University.

title: Woodstock: A Desperate Fear or the Future?
description: So I walk inside and there is this cro codile of black and white schoolkids across one row (Persons Under 17 Not Admitted, says the notice out sidewhy? because of all those naked boobs and beavers?) and three hips from Show magazine in front and a handful of nubile gigglers up the back (Let's go into the Men's Room!) plus a scattering of popcorn munchers, heads, squares and cools and we are all sitting there at 10 o'clock on a Tuesday morning for God's sake to see if Woodstock really was like that or not.

title: The Nation CONTINUED
description: Ever since mass demonstra tions against the war in Viet nam were first started, there, has been a deepening cleavage over strategy and ideology within the peace movement between its lib eral center and its increasingly radical left.

title: Everything's Coming Up Marigold ...
description: WHENEVER I think of Paul Zindel's The Effect of Gamma Rays on ManintheMoon Marigolds, am going to think of three things, not one of them the title (the title, by the way, makes perfect sense and you will re member it readily once you have seen the olay). The first is the sound, the sheer weighted sound, of a load of old news papers being dumped from a balcony land ing. Sada Thompson, slatternly mother of two and savior of none, is at her housecleaning again, which means that she is Picking up the accumulated refuse of her life and hurling it to another, though no better, spot The bundle comes down like dead heart; the force of the drop is shatter ing. And familiar. You seem to have heard it before.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TodayBaltimore County K.C. allbreed and obedience, Timo nium Race Track, Timonium, Md.; 2,154 dogs; 8 A.M.

title: Yale's Lightweight Crews Score Sweep on Housatonic
description: DERBY, Conn., April 18 The Yale lightweight crews swept the river against Penn and Columbia today, winning all three events in the annual Dodge Cup Regatta on the Housatonic.

title: Martin's Reaches Accord With Blacks to End Boycott
description: Operation Breadbasket, the economic arm of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence, reached an agreement yesterday with Martin's depart ment store in Brooklyn that it said would result in an in crease of blacks in the store's work force to 20 per cent in all categories.

title: Mobutu Leaves for Geneva
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, April 18 (Agence France  Presse)  Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, Presi dent of this former Belgian colony, left Here today for Gen eva where he is to have a 10 day medical checkup.

title: MRS. MURRAY SMOLAR
description: Mrs. Sylvia Radlich Smolar, a teacher in charge of the careerguidance program at the Edward W. Stitt Junior High School 64, 401 West 164th Street, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived at Tomkins Cove. N. Y.

title: Martha Enos Is Bride Of Jan H. van Nierop
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 18Miss Martha Plimpton Enos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Trask Enos 3d, was married here this after noon to Jan Hendrik van Nierop, assistant to the presi dent of R. S. Stokvis & Sons, an importing firm in New York.

title: COAL LOSS SLIGHT UNDER NEW LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Despite forecasts by the coal industry that crippling produc tion losses could result from tough Federal enforcement of new mine safety regulations, Government figures just re leased disclosed a decline of less than 2 per cent in mined tonnage so far this month.

title: Thou shalt make thee no graven images did not apply
description: The painstaking effort lavished on each page of medieval manuscripts by scribes and illuminators came to an end with the invention of printing. But the loss in individual craftsman ship has been largely offset by the advantage of the mass reproduction and distribution of beautiful books made possible by modern technology.

title: On a Pacific Island, They Wait For the G.I. Who Became a God
description: TANNA, New Hebrides, April 11The west Pacfic is dotted with crude wooden crosses painted red in honor of the G. I. who became a god in the influ ential cargo cult known as the John Frum Movement.

title: ALCINDOR MISSES BUCKS' WORKOUT
description: MILWAUKEE, April 18The long, lean shadow of Lew Al cindor hung over the New York Knicks as they prepared to face the Milwaukee Bucks tomorrow afternoon in the fourth game of the National Basketball Associ ation's Eastern Division cham pionship playoff series.

title: A splendid ending
description: Leonard Woolf finished his book, the fifth volume of his autobiography, just before his death last August at the age of 88. It makes a splendid ending to one of the most remark able literary achievements of our time. Woolf observes at one point that reviewers of earlier volumes had politely accused him of garrulous senility. Well, if that is really so, there is no sign of anything like it in this book, which is marked, as all the others have been, by honesty and passion, passion for justice, pas sion for civilization, passion for truth.

title: Stamps
description: THE United Nations, cele brating its 25th anni versary this year, will commemorate the event on June 26 with three spe cific stamps and a souvenir sheet for the occasion. Two additional stamps will be is sued later this year to over come an oversight in the title given the anniversary postal paper.

title: JapanChina Talks on Trade Reach Accord in Principle
description: TOKYO, April 18 (Reuters) Japan and China are reported to have reached agreement in principle in their negotiations in Peking for the renewal of a semiofficial trade pact.

title: MAYOR ASSAILS CURB ON IMPORTS OF MEAT
description: Because meat prices are be ing kept artificially high by government import quotas, Mayor. Lindsay said yesterday, hamburger will soon cost as much as porterhouse steak and hot dogs will be a luxury.

title: Blind Runner Starts Tomorrow In His First Boston Marathon
description: By dawn's eerie light, the lonely runner in a sweatsuit glided along the path circling the lake at Kissena Park in Queens. He was a medium sized, deepchested man with a thin face and powerful legs. He breathed easily and his stride was smooth as the miles rolled by, each one reg istered in his practiced mind.

title: Muskie Tells Conservationists Economic Growth Must Go On
description: Senator Edmund S. Muskie, a leading sponsor of environ mental legislation, disagreed yesterday with conservationists who would stop the nation's economic growth to protect its environment.

title: More Black Marks for The Junta In Greece
description: LONDON  The Greek regime scored a few points last week by finally releasing its most famous political prisoner, Mikis Theo dorakis, Greece's leading contem porary composer, of Zorba the Greek fame. But the gesture, welcome as it was, did little to improve the colonels' image.

title: Barbara Diaz, George Noonan Wed in Suburbs
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 18  Miss Barbara Diaz and George Flynn Noo nan were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. David S. Hoag. The Rev. Peter Renaldi assisted.

title: New York A. C Eight Outrows 3 Rivals for Hughes Cup
description: The New York Athletic Club's eightoared crew, with four na tional champions and a cagey, 107pound schoolboy coxswain, won the Hughes Cup regatta oh Long Island Sound yesterday morning for the fifth succes sive year.

title: A Leisurely Odyssey Along Turkey's Coast
description: MARMARIS, TurkeyAwaiting us at the quay was the Hurriyet (Freedom in Turkish), the squat, 16ton calque that was to be the home of our group of eight adults and two babies for the next 12 gays. We were off on a boating excur eon along the southwestern coast of Turkey, with the accent on sunning, swimming and the pursuit of archeolog ical ruins.

title: Timothy C. Birch Fiance Of Alexandra B. Russell
description: Miss Alexandra Brenda Russell of this city, a grand daughter of the Duke of Marlborough, plans to be wed to Timothy Campbell Birch of Boyce, Va., who is stationed in Washington with the Army.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEW areas of teasing speculation have been opened of recent years by the compulsive urge of electronic gadgeteers to Push computer buttons and having whirring wheels identify such items as the greatest race horse and the greatest heavyweight boxing champion. Now the space cadets of the National Broadcasting Company are about to send cards through the machine and let the computer select the eight greatest baseball teams for a recreated tournament designed to produce the best.

title: Horovitz Picks Up Speed
description: ISRAEL Horovitz is racing right ahead with his screenwriting career. The young author of The Indian Wants the Bronx and other offbeat plays will soon be represented on screen with his adaptation of James Simon Kunen's The Strawberry Statement. And now he re ports that he has just completed the script for Speed, based on Speed Is of the Essence, Gail Sheehy's New York Maga zine article about the tragic effects of am phetamines on young people. The film will be produced for MGM by Robert Chartoff and Irwin Winkler, starting here in July. Al Pacino is just about set to play the lead ing role and Stuart Hagmann, who directed The Strawberry Statement, will probably climb aboard, too.

title: Automobile Output Lags in India
description: NEW DELHIThe cheap est of the three cars made in India costs more than $2,300 no mean figure in a coun try with a per capita income of less than $80 a year.

title: Rockefeller Names Drug Aide
description: ALBANY, April 18Governor Rockefeller announced the res ignation today of Lawrence W. Pierce as chairman of the State Narcotics Control Commission, and the nomination of Milton L. Luger to succeed him.

title: Parents of Dead Baby Boy Are Charged With Homicide
description: The parents of a 7month old boy who allegedly starved to death in a Bronx basement apartment were arrested yester day and charged with criminal negligence homicide.

title: Walsh Asks Single U.S. Housing Subsidy
description: The city's top housing offi cial has suggested that all Fed eral housing programs be scrap ped and replaced with a single subsidy from Washington that would enable rents to be deter mined solely by a family's ability to pay.

title: Richmond Papers Appoint
description: RICHMOND, April 18 (AP) Dr. Tennant Bryan, publisher, has announced the appoint ments of editorial page editors of Richmond's two daily news papers. J. Edward Grinsley, member of  the staff of The TimesDispatch for 17 years, was named editor of the edi torial page of the morning newspaper. Ross MacKenzie is the new, editor of the editorial page of The News Leader, the afternoon paper.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: 34 MIDWEST TRAINS ORDERED CONTINUED
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the Penn Central (yesterday) to keep in service 34 passenger trains through the Midwest un til Oct. 1, adding six weeks to a delay ordered earlier by the Interstate Commerce Commis sion.

title: HIRO IS COWINNER IN GREEN VALLEY
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 18 (AP)Oristano breezed to a 10 length victory today in the first division of the $25,000 Green Villey Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: 3,000 Teachers Seek Jobs in OpenAdmission Program
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion has received more than 3,000 job applications from col lege teachers in all parts of the United States who wish to participate in the City Uni versity's openadmission pro gram that will be inauguratted next autumn.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: SISCO, IN BEIRUT, GUARDED CLOSELY
description: BETRUT, Lebanon, April 18 Joseph J. Sisco, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, spent four hours here today amid some of the tightest security measures ever taken by this country for a visiting dignitary.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S BEATS TRINITY'S OARSMEN
description: HARTFORD, Conn., April 18 St. Joseph's College heavy weight crew handed Trinity College its first rowing defeat today on the Connecticut River in a threeway race in which Williams finished last.

title: Growing up in Manawaka
description: Some authors, such as Co lette, write of their childhood because it was the vivid and de lectable period in their lives. Others, like Dickens, do so to free themselves from its mem ory. Still others, like Thomas Mann, hope to find in this way a clue to a puzzle. But these are specialists, and few. There is a whole corpus of huthdrum childhood chronicles which owes its being to the writer's lack of other material. Either he is too young to have ac quired any or he has used up if only for the time being what there was: whatever the cause, the results are apt to be pretty small beer.

title: Godfrey and Graham in Tie For Lead in Tokyo at 217
description: TOKYO April 18 (UPI) Walter Godfrey of New Zea land, playing through cold and rainy weather, shot a par 72 today for a 217 total to climb from sixth place into a first place tie with David Graham of Australia after three rounds of the Yomiuri international open golf tournament. Graham had a 75 today.

title: Report on Men's Wear
description: THE fashion alliance, in this first summer of the 1970's, is a somewhat surprisingbut certainly not uneasyone. For it brings to gether, with happy results, the welldressed ele gance of the thirties and the individuality of today's wearyourownthing philosophy. In the revival category the crisp look of linen, the cool look of white. A return to New Dealsized lapels and pocket flaps, biswing backs and half belts. Panama hats. Wider, flared trousers, and wide, geometricprint ties. And in the now division? Easygoing casual nonsuits that match slacks with shirt or tunic top. Zippy jumpsuits. Practical and easystretch knitted clothing. Bannersize scarves and seethrough shirts. Linking the two groupsthe classic blazer, shaped and updated, with its sensible offshoot, the blazer suit. And enough red, white and blue in leisure wear to start even the silent majority cheering.

title: SECURITY A WORRY AT U.S. JAIL HERE
description: The 40yearold Federal House of Detention is over crowded and understaffed, like most jails in the city. But re cently its own officials have been worried about something else  its ability to keep pris oners under lock and key.

title: BROOKLYN REPORT ASSAILS SCHOOLS
description: A study charging white student failure in Brooklyn academic high schools is being circulated by the Institute for Community Studies of Queens Collegeand contested by city school officials.

title: MANHATTAN WINS DOGWOOD RELAY
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18 A late spurt by the anchor man, Tom Donohue, running the mile, enabled Manhattan Col lege to win the distance medley relay today at the fourth an nual Dogwood Relays. The Jas pers were blocked in 9 minutes 45.6 seconds as Western Michi gan finished second and Ten nessee third.

title: PENN TURNS BACK ARMY, 20 AND 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 Penn won bath games of an Eastern Intercollegiate League doubleheader with Army to day. The Quakers took the opener, 20, and the second contest by 54.

title: DECKED LOVE WINS JUMPER CROWN
description: SIMSBURY, Conn., April 18 Decked Love, who toiled as a hunter and equitation mount until four weeks ago, captured the amateur  owner jumper championship today at the Simsbury spring horse show.

title: Mayor Wins Revival Of Parley to Avert Apartment Strike
description: In an effort to avert a strike by elevator operators and other employes threat ened for midnight tomorrow in 5,000 New York apart, ment houses, Mayor Lindsay yesterday persuaded land lords and their employes to resume their suspended con tract talks.

title: Toward an Income Floor
description: The House of Representatives has taken an impor tant step in passing President Nixon's welfare reform program in the improved version worked out by the Ways and Means Committee. Though still in need of further improvement in the Senate, the House version represents a major gain over the existing degrading welfare system.

title: Blacks Snubbed in Business
description: His secretary doesn't pass on the office scuttlebutt be cause their relationship is more reserved than most. As a middle manager in a billiondollar corporation, he has access to the executive dining room but he can't envision himself at the big table with the chairman and the senior officers. He cer tainly never meets them at their clubs.

title: Things to Live For Like the Beatles
description: There is not a single community in this country that provides an acceptable standard of services for its mentally ill children.Joint Commission on Mental Health of Children, June 30, 1969.

title: BASEBALL LEADS ATTENDANCE GAIN
description: Major league baseball, with four new teams, made the greatest attendance gain in 1969a year in which more than 240,000,000 Americans paid to see major organized sports events.

title: Tenants Gather To Get the Word
description: WHEN the President of our Board of Directors told us to be attentative, I knew things were serious. Usually the President of our Tenants Corporation is the personification of punctili ousness and calm.

title: M.T.A. Aide Named
description: ALBANY, April 18 (AP)  Governor Rockefeller yesterday named Lawrence R. Bailey, a lawyer who lives in Queens and practices law in Harlem, to the Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority. He succeeds Walter N. Rye, who resigned, for a term expiring June 30, 1971. Mr. Bailey is a graduate of the Howard University Law School and is a former presi dent of the Harlem Lawyers Association.

title: Carmichael Scores 2 Upsets Gains Carolina Tennis Final
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April IS (UPI)  Bob Carmichael of France upset two favorites today to gain the final against Cliff Richey in the $18,000 Carolina international tennis tournament.

title: Y. R. A. Entries Are Slow in Arriving
description: With the Long Island Sound distance yacht racing season opening the weekend after next, there was a hint of urgency in the vaices of two officials who telephoned last week.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: For Young Readers
description: A teenager's own guide to 11 of Europe's most  visited cities could be a fine companion whether trav eling aloneand possibly unsure of what to seeor even with parents who have definite ideas about what should be seen. Stan Raiff suggests wouldbe travelers sit down at least eight weeks ahead of time (presuma bly with his book) and read up on the history of the places they'll be visit ing, sights of particular interest, food, dates of festivals and where to find just the right addition to a toy train, stamp or coin collection.

title: Ceausescu Challenges Doctrine
description: VIENNA, April 18 (AP) Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rum anian Communist party chief, has countered the Soviet doctrine of limited sover eignty for Communist states and implied that the Krem lin's leaders had strayed from Lenin's teachings.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MILWAUKEE, April 19The trip had begun with its own special set of omens and signs. Dave DeBuss there, whose wife had just suffered a miscarriage, was not on Thursday afternoon's chartered flight, but press corps of 23 was aboard. When the stewardess wel comed the World Champion New York Knicks, Bill Brad ley said, How many newspapers are going to have that tomorrow morning?, and it was not easy to judge whether he considered the turnout extravagant or somehow felt that the premature championship would become an albatross if displayed too conspicuously.

title: 3 PLAY OFF TODAY FOR FIRST IN GOLF
Recession or No?
description: The nation's total output, corrected for price increases, declined by 0.4 per cent in the first quarter. Since it had already declined by 0.1 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1969, the United States is currently hi its fifth postwar recessionprovided that a reces sion can be defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in real gross national product. in baseball it makes considerable difference whether a long drive down the left field line is defined as fair or foul. In economics it makes little difference whether the current state of inflationary stagnation is or not defined as a recession. Obviously, to paraphrase William Shakespeare, a rise by any other name would smell as sweet.

title: Rescue Ship in Mozarnbiquel
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mo zambique, April 19 (Reuters) Survivors of the tanker Silver Mean, which sank after a fire off the Natal coast last night, landed here todaytwo hours after the tankers carpenter died from burns aboard their rescue ship. The South African freight er Nederberg sailed into harbor here with 26 survivors of the allChinese crew of the Liber ian registered tanker.

title: PHILIP O. ROBERTS
description: BRIELLE, N.J., April 19  Philip O. Roberts, a retired vice president of the Savings Banks Trust Company in Now York, died yesterday at Point Pleasant Hospital. His age was 70. Mr. Roberts graduated from Rutgers University in 1923.

title: SOVIET SAID TO ABORT 8 OF 10 MOON SHOTS
description: Eight of the last 10 unman ned Soviet rockets fired to ward the moon have been aborted, according to a report in the curren issue of News week magazine.

title: Castro Reports a Landing Of Exile Force From U.S.
description: MIAMI, April 19Premier Fidel Castro announced today that a group of mercenaries landed in eastern Cuba on Fri day and that Government troops were still fighting the invaders.

title: America Is Hard to Find Weekend Ends at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y. April 19 It started with a freedom Seder on Friday and it ended this evening with a rock mass, but through most of the America Is Hard to Find Weekend here at Cor nell, the rallying force was neither religion nor politics. It, was rhythm.

title: Rocco Bruzzese, 40, Dead, Rocky Lee's Restaurateur
description: Rocco Bruzzese, the Rocky of the Rocky Lee ChuCho Bianco Italian restaurant at 987 Second Avenue, at 52d Street, died last Tuesday of cancer at the White Plains Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 26 Cay uga Road in Scarsdale.

title: SANTA FE BEGINS HUSKY OIL TALKS
description: Santa Fe Industries, Inc. (the corporate parent of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway) and Husky Oil, Ltd., have agreed to study the feasi bility of affiliating the inter ests of the two companies, they announced over the weekend.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A Store That's a Haven if You're Pregnant, Tall or Plumpish
description: TO Clare McMahon, a sec retary who is almost 5 feet11inches tall, the store means slacks that are long enough. For Gail Shapiro, another secretary, it means shoes size 12.

title: CAMBODIAN TOWN NEAR THE CAPITAL REPORTED SEIZED
description: KHAU KHOR, Cambodia, April 19  A Vietnamese Coin munist unit seized without a fight the town of Saang, 20 miles south of Pnompenh, to day, a field commander nearby reported.

title: COLLEGE BASEBALL
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: ALBANY SUPPORTS YOUTH DRUG FIGHT
description: ALBANY, Monday, April 20 The Legislature voted final ap proval last night of $65million worth of programs designed to fight the increasing problem of drug addiction among youths.

title: U.S. ROLE IN LAOS DETAILED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The United States, it was dis closed today, secretly stationed air observers in northern Laos in 1966 to help guide the bomb ing of Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese forces by Royal Laotian and American planes.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: SENATE TO STUDY INTEGRATION ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19A Special Senate committee begins tomorrow months of hearings that are likely to fuel a sustained challenge to the school desegregation policies recently outlined by the Presi dent.

title: I.S. 201 EXPERIMENT TO SCRUTINIZE TEXTS
description: An experiment in teaching black studies that will give pupils a chance to compare some of the standard history textbooks with what they have learned will be introduced tomorrow in the social studies program at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem.

title: Nixon's Speech on TV Will Start at 9 Tonight
description: All three major networks said last night that they would televise President Nix on's address to the nation live at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Allen H. Karlebach Weds Jo Ann Mirto
description: Miss Jo Ann Theresa Mir to, daughter of Assemblyman and Mrs. Peter Gasper Mirto of Brooklyn and Stony Brook, L. I., was married in Brooklyn yesterday to Lieut. Allen Henry Karlebach, U.S. A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Karlebach of Bergen field, N. J. Msgr. Raphael Testagrossa performed the ceremony in St. Joseph Pa tron Roman Catholic Church.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES 4 TAX MEASURES TO HELP THE CITY
description: ALBANY, Monday, April 20 The Assembly, in less than a halfhour debate, passed four new tax bills that are part of a 1$400million revenue package designed to cover twothirds of New York City's prospective $630million budget gap.

title: Uncle Sam Learns About Living With Labor
description: Uncle Sam's relations with his 2.7 million civil servants will never be the same. The landmark settlement negotiated by the Nixon Administration and the A.F.L.C.I.O. after the nation's first postal strike marks the end of a sleepytime era in which the leaders of most Federal unions were closer to Congress than to their own rank and file.

title: Chess:
description: THE veteran grandmaster Arthur Bisguier of Harts dale, N. Y., scoring 4, won the recent Third Annual GoldwaterMarshall Invitation Tournament.

title: BOMB FOUND AT JAIL, DYNAMITE AT A BANK
description: The police found a pipe bomb in a corrections officer's car early yesterday outside the House of Detention in Queens, where 10 Black Panthers are being held on bombplot charges.

title: Canadian Bill Raises FreeSpeech Issue
description: OTTAWA, April 19A bill to prohibit expression of racial hatred and advocacy of geno cide will be taken up by the Canadian Senate's Legal and Constitutional Affairs Commit tee this week. The Opposition is expected to try to defeat it.

title: Personal Finance: Steps in Purchasing a New Auto
description: Rules of the road for auto drivers come from all sources such as the Government, auto clubs, the car makers and Ralph Nader, but practical approaches to buying a car still remain more of a game than anything else.

title: WILLIAM S. BRADLEY
description: HOUSTON, April 19 CAP) William S. Bradley, Assistant Secretary of. Commerce in the Truman Administration, died yesterday in the Veterans Ad ministration Hospital here. He was 71 years old. Mr. Bradley retired to Houston 10 years ago. He had been a banker in Center ville.

title: Secretary Hardin, Braced Against Criticism Awaits Committee Report on New Farm Bill This Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin, a tall man with an amiable smile, will learn this week how many friends he has on the House Agricul ture Committee.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at Washington (n)  Bahnsen (01) vs. Cox (20).

title: BACALLAO CAPTURES SQUASH TENNIS FINAL
description: RYE N. Y., April 19Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club, who headed the draw, won the Rye invitation open squash ten nis championship today for the third straight year.

title: Jersey Racing to Begin At Garden State Today
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 19 (AP)New Jersey's 1970 thoroughbred racing season opens today at Garden State Park with the start of a 36 day spring meeting.

title: Marital Censorship
description: Even if this were not the year of women's liberation, there would be a ludicrous quality to the controversy that led to the ouster of William Woestendiek as editor of a news feature program on Washington's educational television station. The station says it feared a conflict of interest was created by the decision of Mr. Woestendiek's wife to go to work as press secretary for Mrs. Martha Mitchell, the out spoken wife of the Attorney General. Establishing such a guiltbymarriage standard is as silly as it outrageous. Someone ought to educate the educa tional TV officials responsible in common sense.

title: Pollution Perils a French Church
