description: STRASBOURG, France, April 16Air pollution and vibrations caused by supersonic planes have helped to bring a dra matic acceleration in damage to the stonework of Stras bourg Cathedral and its famous spire, French authorities have found.Bertrand Monnet, the chief Government architect for the AlsaceLorraine area, reported the damage in a paper read re cently before a gathering of architects in an auditorium be side the cathedral.

title: SPURT BY BLUES TOPS PENGUINS, 31
description: ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 19 (UN)  Gary Sabourin, Phil Goyette and Red Berenson scored for St. Louis in the sec ond period tonight, giving the Blues a 31 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in the first game of their Stanley Cup West Division semifial playoffs.

title: Lucidity Reigns as Hungerford Plays Beethoven Piano Sonatas
description: Beethoven's 32 piano sona tas make up a whole world, and Bruce Hungerford girdled it in five leaps yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The Australian pianist, in a recital that had been postponed because of his illness last month, played Beethoven program that began with the Sonata No. 1 in Minor (Op. 2, No. 1) and ended with No. 32 in C minor (Op. 111). He filled out the day with Sonatas No. 13 in E flat (Op. 27, No. 1), No. 4 in C Sharp minor (Op. 27, No. 2), and No. 17 in D minor (Op. 31, No. 2).

title: RUSSELL'S SHOTS PROVIDE THE CURE
description: MILWAUKEE, April 19  Doctor Cazzie Russell explained is operating procedure today after giving the Knicks the in jection they needed to overcome the Bucks in what might be re garded as the critical game of the National Basketball Associ ation Eastern Division cham pionship series.

title: Apollo 13 Pictures Show Extensive Damage
description: HOUSTON, April 19  The Apollo 13 astronauts were wel comed home tonight with a message from President Nixon reiterating his strong, firm support of the nation's manned space program despite the aborted moon mission.

title: Miss Beudert Plans Wedding to Student
description: COLD SPRING HARBBOR, L. I., April 19  The engage ment of Miss Michele Frances Beudert, a senior at St. Louis University, to Millard Francis Aldridge, a law student at the University of Michigan and a 1969 graduate of St. Louis, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Beudert, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Aldridge of Des Moines, Iowa.

title: Colombians Vote on 57th St. and Turn It Into a Fiesta
description: Carrying drums, fiddles, sandwiches and babies, thou sands of Colombians from all Over the metropolitan area converged on East 57th Street yesterday to sing and dance and cast votes in their nation's presidential election.

title: U.S GROWTH PUT AT 4.3% A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The real growth of the United States economy should amount to 4.3 per cent a year in the present decade, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated to day.

title: Sir Richard Atcherley Dead; Former Air Marsha Was 66
description: LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) Sir Richard Llewellyn Roger Atcherley, former Air Marshal, died after a heart attack last night. He was 66 years old and was enroute to a flight to the United States, where he was to greet the Apollo 13 astronauts.

title: Stewart Captures Spanish Grand Prix
description: MADRID, April 19 (UPI)  Jackie Stewart of Scotland, the world champion, drove his new Formula One Mach 701 to an easy victory today in the Span ish Grand Prix. The event was marred by injury to Jacky Ickx of Belgium, who suffered burns after a twocax crash early in the race.

title: Canada's Arctic Claims
description: The United States has rejected with unseemly sharpness Canada's bid to extend her control over the Northwest Passage in order to prevent pollution her Arctic territories. That rejection is sure to exacer bate relations with Canada while failing to advance the cause of more enlightened international regula tion of the seas.

title: TV Stations Will Be Restricted To 3 Hours of Network Shows
description: Individual television stations across the country will be pho hibited from accepting more than three hours at night of network programing under a policy adopted by the Federal Communications Commission. The plan will be formally an nounced in a few weeks. It is scheduled to become effective in September. 1971.

title: Bruins Conquer Hawks, 63
description: CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) Boston's high  scoring center, Phil Esposito, beat his younger brother, Tony, the Chicago Black Hawks' goalie, for three goals today to Iead the Bruins to a 63 victory in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal play off series. Tony was the winner of the Vezina Trophy during the regular National Hockey League season for his record 15 shut outs.

title: AGENCY ANALYZES BANK TRUST FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Common trust funds adminis tered by banks have realized investment results that are similar to, but not quite as good as, those obtained by mutual funds with similar in vestment objectives, according to a study made in the Govern ment agency that regulates na tional banks.

title: Filion Wins Driving Crown As a 7Track Series Ends
description: MONTREAL, April 19 (Cana dian Press)Hery Filion of Canada clinched the first iworld's harnessracing driving championship today at Blue Bonnets Raceway.

title: Chicken and Potatoes Done Indian Style
description: NEW DELHIIn the homes of New Delhi, Mrs. Chand Balbir Singh was explaining, cooking goes on for 12 hours a day, seven days a week. And Mrs. Singh is something of an exception in her community. Although she has two maids and one cook, she does most of the cooking for her family.

title: Net Revenues Drop 61% for Big Board
description: Net revenues of the New York Stock Exchange plummet ed 61 per cent to $803,300 from $2,059,000 in the first quarter of this year, Robert W. Haack, president, reported over the weekend.

title: Computer Helps Children to Add
description: Carlton Harrison  along with 2,400 other randomly chosen pupils here  an swered his telephone the other day and got ready for one of a series of automated arithmetic drills that have improved by 20 per cent some pupils' ability to add, subtract, multiply and di vide.

title: AUSTRALIA TAKES DAVIS CUP SERIES
description: TOKYO, April 19 (AP)Aus tralia clinched the Eastern Zone, Section A, Davis Cup final to day by taking a doubles match from Japan for an insurmount able 30 lead in the threeof fivematch series.

title: Article Reports Some Risk In Smallpox Vaccination
description: CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) One person in each million vaccinated for the first time against smallpox dies of the in jection, the Journal of the American Medical Association said in its current edition.

title: Cambodian Events Worry Key U. S. Aides in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19The tumultuous sit uation in Cambodiawhich just a month ago seemed to hold such promise for United States interests in Indochina is fast beginning to sour, in the opinion of senior United States officials here.

title: A New President Is Elected By New York Susquehanna
description: William T. Frazier has been named president of the New York Susquehanna Railroad Company to succeed Irving Maidman, who remains as chairman, it was announced over the weekend.

title: Jones, Driving Mustang, Wins on Coast
description: MONTERREY, Calif., April 19  Parnelli Jones of Tor rance, Calif., driving a yearold Ford Mustang and handicapped by an injured left eye, won the first TransAmerican champion ship race of the season today at Laguna Seca Raceway.

title: JORDANIAN GENERALS GET DEFENSE POSTS
description: BEIRUE, Lebanon, April 19 Two Jordanian Army officers known to be on good terms with Palestinian guerillas were appointed to key posts in Cabinet and military changes announced in Amman tonight.

title: Vietnam Moratorium Committee Is Disbanding
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 After nearly a year of trying to mobilize Americans against the war in Vietnam, the Viet nam Moratorium Committee announced today that it was disbanding.

title: Yellow Submarine Is Symbol of Youth Churches
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19Young Protestants and Roman Catho lics seeking to create radically new types of local churches are developing a growing national cohesiveness around a new re ligious symbolthe yellow sub marine made famous by the Beatles.

title: Blackmun Expects to Disagree With Burger on Some Issues
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., April 19Judge Harry A. Blackmun said today that if he became a member of the Supreme Court, he would not expect to agree on all issues with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, his longtime friend and legal as sociate.

title: Man and His Environment: Some Basic Facts About a Growing National Problem
description: Around 5000 B.C., scientists have estimated, there were fewer people on the face of the globe than there are now in New York City.

title: Lena Horne's Father Dies
description: Edwin F. Horne, father of Lena Horne, the singer, died Saturday in Los Angeles at the age of 78. Mr. Horne was for merly a hotel and restaurant owner. Surviving, besides Miss Horne, who is the wife of Len nie Hayton, composer, arranger and conductor, are two sons, Dr. Frank S. Horne of the New York City Housing and Develop ment Administration, and John B. Home; two grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren.

title: Fibreboard Case Dismissed
description: The Fibreboard Corporation, a maker of gypsum wallboard products, said in San Francisco yesterday that pricefixing charges against it have been dismissed by a jurgment entered by Federal District Judge Al fonso J. Zirpoli.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Salvation Army Planning 3 Facilities in Brooklyn
description: The Salvation Army will spend $2.5million in the next three years for new facilities in Brooklyn, the organization announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: AIR REDUCTION COMPANY

title: Synagogue Here Finds Its Lost Cornerstone
description: Central Synagogue, which claims the distinction of being the nation's second oldest synagogue in con tinuous use, found a corner stone yesterday that it had lost in the last century.

title: Shipments of Steel Take Erratic Turn
description: PITTSBURGH, April 19Spe cial influences are making for erratic steel shipments.

title: Major Bills in Congress
UPRISING LOOMS IN LATINAID BANK
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 19  The administration of the $6 billion InterAmerican Develop ment Bank is bracing for a major revolt of its member countries when its governors open their 10th annual meeting tomorrow across the River Plate at Punta del Este, Ura guay.

title: PRINTERS' LEADER HOPEFUL OF PACT
description: The head of the New York printers' union said yesterday that the workers and the city's four major newspapers were still very, very far apart in their contract dispute but that a peaceful settlement could be achieved.

title: Inquiry Begins in Death of Baby by Starvation
description: The Department of Social Services has begun an investi gation into the death from starvation on Friday of a 7 monthold boy whose parents were receiving public assist ance.

title: Economist Named a Times Editor
description: The appointment of Leon ard S. Silk to the editorial board of The New York Times was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page. Mr. Silk has been d senior fellow of the Brookings Institution in Washington for the last year.

title: Berlin Gets Lenin Monument
description: BERLIN, April 19 (AP)The East German Communist party leader, Walter Ulbricht, un veiled today a red granite mon ument to Lenin on East Berlin square named for the Commu nist revolutionary. The monu ment, 62 feet high, was erected to mark the 100th anniversary of Lenin's birthday Wednesday.

title: JusticeSterile or Speedy?
description: The courts of New Yorkespecially the criminal courtsare so logjammed that an unwitting form preventive detention results for tens of thousands of accused persons awaiting trial. On the civil side, trials and appeals take so long that going to court has become almost a last resort.

title: DEMOCRATS HOPE TO RETAIN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  After a year of what some times approached political panic, Democratic political leaders now believe that they can retain control of the Sen ate in next Fall's election.

title: Simpler Way Sought to Bypass Digestive Tract
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Doctors at the University of Washington School of Medicine at Seattle are developing a do ityourself method of delivering, food directly to the blood stream, bypassing the entire di gestive tract.

title: COAST TEAM GAINS A 133114 TRIUMPH
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers went on a scoring spree in 31/2 min utes of the fourth quarter to night to defeat the Atlanta National 133114, and sweep the Inational Basketball Associa tion's Western Division final series four games to none.

title: BOMBERS VICTORS ON 11HIT ATTACK
description: BALTIMORE, April 19  Scratching and slapping base hits into all the nooks and cran nies of Memorial Stadium, using three relief pitchers because they were low on starters, the Yankees salvaged a split of their doubleheader with the Orioles today.

title: A. Correction
description: It was reported erroneously in The New York Times yester day that in testing the air pol lution devices in cars the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare issued certificates of compliance even if the test showed that the cars were be low Federal standards. The cer tificates are issued only if the average emissions from the four prototypte cars submitted for testing do not exceed the limits set by the National Air Pollution Control Administra tion of H.E.W.

title: General Rojas, ExDictator, Claims Victory in Colombia's Presidential Race
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19 Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, a for mer military dictator now head ing a populist movement, claimed victory tonight in the election for president.

title: Growing Gas Needs of U.S. Help Stir Drilling Frenzy
description: INUVIK, Northwest Terri tories, CanadaThe search for oil in the Canadian Arctic has become so frenzied that this bustling town of 3,000 persons will set up a bypass route to keep next summer's expected torrent of truck traffic from blanketing the main street in dust.

title: Delta Queen, Link to Twain Era, Doomed
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 19 The stars were as bright as lanterns but there was no moon.

title: PACERS TURN BACK COUGARS BY 10398
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 (UPI)The Indiana Pacers out lasted the Carolina Cougars, 10398, today and took a two game lead in their American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoffs.

title: SANDRA HAYNIE WINS ON 212 AT RALEIGH
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 19 (AP)Sandra Haynie finished with an even par 72 today and won the fifth annual Releigh women's invitational golf tour ney by three strokes.

title: 3 Democrats in Race For Governor Urged To Meet in Debate
description: The pressures for an early debate among the three Demo cratic candidates for Governor mounted yesterday with the an nouncement by the New Demo cratic Coalition that it would meet next Sunday to consider endorsing one of them.

title: WILLIAM F. BANKS
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., April 19  William Foster Banks, retired president of the Motor Carrier Association of New York, died today of a heart ailment in St. Francis Hospital, Port Jervis, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Chicago Driver Talks Snag As Industry Vows No Parley
description: The attempt by Federal mediators to end a strike and lockout by Chicago, area truck drivers and their cinployers hit a snag yesterday when repre sentatives of the trucking in dustry vowed to boycott a scheduled meeting today United Press International reported.

title: Olivares Outpoints Castillo
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 19 (UPI)Ruben Olivares of Mex ico, who retained his bantam weight championship with a over Shucho Castillo, also of Mexico, last night, wants to make his third title defense af ter a short rest.

title: Mets Rout Phils, 102, After 32 Loss Before 49,898; Yanks, Orioles Split
M'CARTHY REENTERS RACE FOR SENATE
description: BUFFALO, April 19 (UPI) Representative Richard D. Mc Carthy formally reentered the race for the Democratic party's nomination for the United States Senate tonight.

title: Entertainment
description: Events

title: FRENCH RADICAL STIRS CONFLICTS
description: PARIS, April 19Greek and French politics have become inextricably mixed in the per son and activities of Jean Jacques Servan  Schreiber, the journalist turned politician.

title: Roundup: Simpson, Griffin Join Parade of OneHitters
description: A couple of pitchers threw onehitters, a couple of play ers threw punches and the California Angels and Kansas City Royals battled for 13 innings until a passed ball settled the issue yesterday.

title: Theater: A Place for Polly Arrives
BUILDERS WARNED ON ASBESTOS RULES
description: The City's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday that contractors at many construction sites were not obeying the new regula tions requiring the contain ment of asbestos dust and that it would order work halted on projects that did not comply.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:Not surprisingly, in rejecting the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell the Senate split according to generally predictable party and sectional groupings. Another split, less apparent, but perhaps more significant, also occurred.

title: First Money Offer Is Made To Avert Apartment Strike
description: Apartment house owners made a new contract offer yesterday to their service em ployes, in an effort to avert a strike threatened for mid night tonight in 5,000 buildings.

title: Earth Day Plans Focus on City
description: Months of planning by do zens of organizations and hun dreds of people will culminate Wednesday in Earth Day, the largest demonstration ever or ganized to protest the degra dation of the environment.

title: Economists to Help Fix Aim of Financial Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 19A group of more than 20 econo mists, most of them academics but some from business, has been asked to help decide ex actly what should be studied by the new Commission on Fi nancial Institutions.

title: Tough, Affable Chinese Nationalist
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 19 Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo, who arrives in Washington tomorrow for talks on Tuesday with Presi dent Nixon and State Depart ment officials, has a reputa tion for being tough, im perious and hard to know.

title: Volpe Backs General Aviation Use of Floyd Bennett
description: Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe and city trans portation officials have come out in favor of using Floyd Ben nett Field for general aviation flying other than that done by commercial airlines and the military.

title: IRVING JARCHO
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 19Irving Jarcho, Presi dent of Jarcho Brothers, Inc., a large plumbing contracting firm and a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 39 Roxen Road. He was 62 years old.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: Miss Susan R. Pearl Is Married To Richard Grausman in Akron
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 19 Miss Susan R. Pearl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl D. Pearl, was married at her parents' home here today to Richard I. Grausman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roland I. Grausman of New York. Rabbi Morton Ap plebaum performed the cere mony.

title: Books of The Times
description: COINCIDENTALLY, the Eagle that landed on the moon last summer was not the first pioneer flying craft to bear that name. It must have been coinci dence, for had the men of NASA remem bered Eagle's ancestor, they would surely have chosen another name.

title: TV: A Party of Sorts
description: HUGH HEFNER, who be came a millionaire with his Playboy Magazine and chain of bunny clubs, ap pears on television as some thing of an aging antifemi nist. In his Saturday night hour over WORTV it is not just that he interminably chews a pipe stem, which means those slippers for the weary cannot be too far behind, but his notions of pre senting sexy ecology are worn and unimaginative.

title: Knicks Set Back Bucks, 117105
description: AIILWAUKEE, April 19The New York Knickerbockers sur vived a furious thirdperiod as sault by the Milwaukee Bucks to gain a 117105 victory and a 31 lead in their National Basketball Association Eastern playoff, series today.

title: Interfaith Mission Asserts Soviet Jews Are Troubled
description: Members of an interfaith mis sion that just returned from three weeks in the Soviet Union asserted yesterday that Jews in the Soviet Union were tense and badly worried over recent developments.

title: PRESIDENT LANDS IN SAN CLEMENTE
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 19 President Nixon returned to the mainland tonight after a whirlwind trip to Honolulu where he honored the Apollo 13 astronauts. He will address the nation tomorrow night on Viet nam.

title: EGYPTIAN FIGHTER REPORTED DOWNED
description: JERUSALEM, April 19Is raeli Army authorities reported today that an Egyptian jet was downed and two others were hit by Hawk missiles in an at tack yesterday against Israeli positions on the Suez Canal.

title: SAIGON UNIT ENDS CAMBODIAN FORAY
description: CHAUDOC, South Vietnam, April 11Hundreds of South Vietnamese troops supported by armored vehicles and artil lery fire returned here last night from an extensive two day operation in Cambodia, ac cording to witnesses and knowledgable military sources.

title: WASHINGTON HIGH REMAINS CLOSEt
description: George Washington High School will remain closed again today to preclude a renewed outbreak of violence, the Board of Education, announced last night.

title: 4 Choices for Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay, a Republican reelected last year as a Liberal supported mainly by Democrats, is baying the time of his politi cal life practicing the politics of keeping all options open, in the words of those who know him best. As a politician almost without party, Mr. Lindsay's biggest option at the moment is that he is free to support either a Republican or a Democrat for Gov ernor this year. Despite a history of personal, and sometimes bit ter, differences with Governor Rockefeller, he could support Mr. Rockefeller, who has just helped New York City win a $469  million package of new revenues, the biggest a Mayor has ever won.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Scien tific and Technical Subcom mittee10:30 A. M. and 3 P. M.

title: Seiichi Ueno, 87, Coowner Of Major Japanese Paper
description: OSAKA, Japan, April 19 (AP) Seiichi Ueno, coowner of Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest national newspapers, died at his home in Ashiya near here tonight of a heart ailment. He was, 87 years old.

title: Paris: Simplifying Life's Ambiguities
description: PARIS  The Things of LifeLes Choses de la Viemay not be the mas terpiece that French critics say it is, but the press agent of the movie directed by Claude Sautey certainly de serves to be hailed as a genius. Getting truck drivers to block the roads on the weekend before Easter, thereby causing mon strous traffic jams on the super highways; persuading the French Gov ernment to impose a speed limit on the roads despite the pressure of the automobile lobby; persuading the City Council of Paris to turn down the prefect's proposal to set up parking meters; inducing the Seine to overflow its banks, thus forcing the city to close the riverside drives, which in turn made driving in Paris literally impossible; finally, contriving to make an army of mothers march down the roads to protest the imprisonment of their hus bands, thereby provoking new bottlenecks, all this in order to underscore the time liness of a film in which life's ambiguities are abruptly sim plified by the unequivocal bluntness of a car crash who could do better?

title: As Centennial Nears in Moscow, Thousands Wait to See Lenin's Body While Others Fight for Profits
description: MOSCOW, April 19Tens of thousands of Soviet citizens waited for hours to see the embalmed body of Lenin, others darted into shops in search of vodka, still others fought for wholesale flowers they would sell at high prices.

title: Leslie R. Cohen, J. W. Tuttleton Are Wed Here
description: Miss Leslie Ruth Cohen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel S. Cohen of River dale, the Bronx, was married yesterday afternoon to James W. Tuttleton, son of Mrs. Clarence M. Tuttleton of Tampa, Fla., and the late Rev. Mr. Tuttleton, a minister of the Church of Christ in Providence, R. I.

title: Heroin Traffickers Here Tell How $219Million Trade Works
description: Supplying heroin to 100,000 users in New York is one of the biggest of the city's big businesses.

title: Rigoli of Italy Captures Saber Laurels After Fenceoff
description: In one of the biggest sur prises since the international Martini & Rossi fencing jam boree was introduced at the New York Athletic Club 10 years ago, Rolando Rigoli, an agile competitor from Italy, won the saber championship last night.

title: MOST COOPERATE IN CENSUSTAKING
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Mrs. Marion Henley of Chicago got a phone call the other day from a woman who saw her on a local television show. The caller said: I heard you talk ing about whatever that thing was you were talking about. I called to tell you I didn't re ceive whatever it was you were talking about.

title: French Ship Sabotaged
description: DUNKIRK, France, April 19 (Reuters)Fiftyyearold Man uel Victoria, an Algerianborn electrician, was charged today with sabotaging a refrigerator ship being built here for the Soviet Union, the police said. A series of fires aboard the vessel is still under investiga tion they added.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series)

title: Bridge:
description: IF experts are asked to nom irate the world's best play er  excluding themselves from consideration  they will suggest a number of names.

title: Ceausescu Indicates Rumania Would Not Give Soviet Union Military Support Against Red China
description: MOSCOW, April 19Nicolae Ceausescu, President of Ru mania and head of that na tion's Communist party, today indicated that while his coun try sought continued good re lations with the Soviet Union it would not lend it military support in case of war with Communist China.

title: Measures Urged to Halt Electrocutions in Rail Yard
description: John Rodriguez, 13 years old, was admitted to Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx for severe electrical burns last week. Dr. Lewis M. Fraad, chief of the pediatrics depart ment, said the boy had been fried to a crisp. He died the next day.

title: THEODORE YUDAIN, STAMFORD EDITOR
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 19Theodore Yudain, editor of The Stamford Advocate, died at Greenwich Hospital to day after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 22 Valleywood Road, Cos Cob.

title: Sales Lag and Inflation Add to Retailers' Woes
description: The president of one of New York's best known de partment stores leaned back for a moment in his office and observed, From my personal standpoint, I have felt no added pressure, except what I have exerted myself. Then, his phone started ringing, the calls became incessant and he could no longer continue his conversation.

title: Nets Win by 10799 And Lead Colonels In Playoffs, 2 to 1
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 19It was the Nets' first home playoff game ever. The floor was freshly polished, the commissioner was in the stands, and it was Sunday afternoon, their favorite time of the week.

title: Newark Striving for a New Image
description: As Its first move toward kidnapping some businesses away from New York, the Greater Newark Chamber Commerce is launching a bit of an image campaign. Modest but meaningful.

title: Advertising: Old Crow Account Assigned
description: The National Distillers Product Company is assign ing its Old Crow bourbon to Ogilvy & Mather. And so ends a search that started on Feb. 2 when the distiller first announced it would be shift ing the $4million account out of Lennen & Newell.

title: HENRI MASS'S DEAD; FRENCH ESSAYIST, 84
description: PARIS, April 19  Henri Massis, a defender of the cause of the intellebtual Catholic and nationalist right in France and a member of the Acadmie Franaise, died here on Friday. He was 84 years old.

title: The Poetry and Politics of Space
description: LONDON, April 19The British Broadcasting Corpora tion's news readers, as they call them on radio here, are notorious for their wellbred absence of emotion. Not a vowel, not a thought usually strays from the tone of even blandness. And so it made an impression, the other night, when a B.B.C. announcer giv ing the news of Apollo 13's re turn suddenly stopped and said:

title: Biafra's Reconstruction Succeeds Slowly
description: OWERRI, Nigeria, April 8 The conquered nation that was Biafra is struggling to its feet with some success.

title: Nuns Form Assembly to Bring Pressure for New Church Role
description: CLEVELAND, April 19Most of them came here in their black habitsthe veils set little farther back on their heads now, the hemline a few inches below the knee  but many wore neat suits or dresses in bright pink, green or yellow.

title: Man Who Cast Key Vote On Abortion Is Rebuffed
description: AUBURN, N. Y., April 19 (AP)Assemblyman George M. Michaels, who last week cast what proved to be the swaying vote for approval of the abortion reform bill in the Legislature, was denied today the endorsement by his party for reelection.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, April 20, 1970.

title: Newspaper Publishers Group, Opening Meeting Here Today, Sees U.S. Threat of Antitrust Suits
description: A potential threat of anti trust actions hangs over hun dreds of newspaper publishers, an American Newspaper Pub lishers Association committee said yesterday, on the eve of the association's 84th annual convention here.

title: Southern Group Seeks to Unite Factions and Strengthen Region
description: MEMPHIS, April 19A new Southern Strategy, one devised by the natives instead of by Washington political theorists, took shape this weekend by the banks of the Mississippi.

title: ALBERT S. BAKER
description: Albert S. Baker, a retired accountant and a founder of the Emergency Medical Aid to Cuba Committee, who was active in civil rights move ments, died Saturday of cancer in University Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 70 LaSalle Street.

title: Port Engineers to Meet
description: The Society of Marine Port Engineers, New York, N. Y., Inc., will hold its last general meeting of the current season Wednesday at the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street. Thomas J. McTaggart, port en gineer of the Humble Oil and Refining Company's marine de partment, will be the speaker. The meeting starts at 5:30 P. M.

title: 72d Slide Victim in France
description: SALLANCHES, France, April 19 (AP)The body of the 72d and last known victim of the avalanche that struck a chil dren's sanitorium last Thursday was recovered this afternoon on the Plateau D'Assy.

title: Calisthenics While Lolling in the Bath
description: A WOMAN who's bored just staring at the tiles when she's taking a bath, might try bathtub gym. The cosmetics companies, shifting their in terest temporarily from faces to bodies, seem to think that cleanliness is not the endall of bathing. Instead of just letting you loll there soak ing in their sy baritic products, they urge that you whittle down your waistline or build op your bosom while you're at it. Along with its Seaqua bath array, Elizabeth Arden pro vides a regimen of prebath and inbath exercises worked out by its Maine Chance beauty spas. The idea is that while you're basking in the citrusscented waters embel lished with Sea Emollient or Foaming Sea Bath, you tone up your arms and bosom mus cles by pressing a rubber bath ball between the palms of your hands.

title: Palisades Interstate Park Loses Trees in Forest Fire
description: ROCKLAND LAKE, N. Y., April 19A forest fire burning between the south end of Rock land Lake State Park and Hook Mountain has destroyed 1,000 acres of trees.

title: Cautious Ridding Is Likely For New Bond Offerings
description: Bond underwriters, fearful for several reasons that prices of fixedincome securities will register further declines, can be expected to bid cautiously for new offerings this week.

title: Applause and Bacall Win Tonys
description: Applause and Lauren Ba call, its star, walked off with top honors as best musical and best actress in a musical last night at the 24th annual pre entations of the Antoinette Perry Awards at the Mark Heflinger Theater.

title: Pollution Control Cost Cited
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 AP) Pollution control will soon require expenditures of $25bil lion to $30billion a year, Sen ator Gaylord A. Nelson, Demo crat of Wisconsin, said today. And pollution is much more important than space, weapons systems, or the money we're wasting in Vietnam, the Sen ator said on the CBSTV pro gram Face the Nation.

title: Legislative Crescendo
description: The wild and furious windup of this session of the New York State Legislature has been much like others in recent years, which, in turn, have resembled Tchai kovsky's Symphony No. 4: plenty of timpani and cymbal crashes and the blast of brass, amid frantic, rushing movement. While this can be good music, it cannot be good lawmaking. It emphasizes the need for fundamental state legislative reforms.

title: 75 Homeless in Bronx Fire; Man Charged With Arson
description: A threealarm fire, alleged to have been deliberately set, heavily damaged a row of six attached threestory frame apartment buildings in the Bronx last night, making 75 persons homeless and slightly injuring two firemen.

title: A Gadfly in South African Politics, Woman Serves as Multiracial Party's Sole Member of Parliament
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 19There is a 5 foot3inchtall woman here who has been termed the flea in the ear of the Government of Prime Minister John Vorster.

title: JEWS TO CELEBRATE START OF PASSOVER
description: Passover, which commemo rates the liberation of the an cient Israelites from bondage in Egypt, begins at sundown to day with the traditional Seder the ceremonial feast.

title: ADM. PENFENTENYO OF FRENCH NAVY, 87
description: PARIS, April 19Rear Adm. Herv Alphonse Marie de Pen fentenyo de Kervereguin died today in Versailles. He was 87 years old.

title: MARATHON GIVING GALS RUN AROUND
description: BOSTON April 19Most of the world's top distance run ners and some of the world's sturdiest women suffragists will take to the pavement to, morrow at high noon in they 74th annual Boston Athletic As sociation marathon. The suffra gettes will be running unoffici aly.

title: Housing Patrolman Says Beard Cost Him His Job
description: A suspended New York City housing patrolman who has re fused to shave off his beard re ceived his dismissal notice in the mail on Friday, his wife said yesterday.

title: Foe of Separatism
description: HE is a black man and a social scientist and, be cause he is both, there is for Dr. Kenneth Bancroft Clark no cool world of detachment lying somewhere between what should be and what is. Instead, there is involvement with his people and much frustration and battling. Yesterday in Wash ington, before a Senate hearing on school desegrega tion, Dr. Clark was fighting once again for an end to racial separation in the schools, but now he was opposing not only the white supremacists but also the black separatists.

title: TV OFFICIAL DENIES HE OUSTED EDITOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Max M. Kampelman, the chair man of the Board of WETA TV, denied today that he had exerted pressure to oust an editor at the station because his wife hadbecome press sec retary for Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The director of the 84year old University Settlement House on the Lower East Side has resigned following the institu tion's rejection of his advice that it should not present an award to Governor Rockefeller.

title: U.S. Drops Plan to Order the Removal of Flammable Carpets in Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Social Security Administra tion has scrapped a plan to require the immediate removal of flammable carpeting from nursing homes certified as ex tended care facilities under the Medicare program.

title: ALVARY GASCOIGNE, BRITISH ENVOY, 76
description: LONDON, April 20Sir Al vary Gascoigne, British Ambas sador to the Soviet Union at Stalin's death, died here Satur day. He was 76 years old.

title: J. RICHARD RINGGOLD
description: J. Richard Ringgold, vice president for sales of the Amer ican Flange & Manufacturing Company, Inc., died at Doctors Hospital yesterday of cancer. He was 57 years old and lived at Feeks Lane, Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Japanese Asks End Of Trade Barriers
description: Moriatsu Minato, a leading Japanese economist, said yesterday that Japan should try to reduce current trade frictions with the United States and speed removal of her own harriers to imports and foreign investment.

title: CREDIT MARKETS RETREATING AGAIN
description: Bond prices retreated again yesterday as gloom spread in Wall Street about the pros pects of successfully handling a large volume of new issues without help from some dra matic outside development to spur demand for fixedincome securities.

title: 3 HURT, 25 ARRESTED IN JERSEY RAMPAGE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 20 More than 200 youths roamed this resort city today, broke windows in four stores, dam aged a police car and roughed up two policemen.

title: TON MARVEL, WRITER AND A WINE EXPERT
description: WESTPORT, Conn., April 20 Tom Marvel, an author, jour nalist and authority on wines, died of a heart attack last Mon day while on assignment in Fresno, Calif. He was 68 years old and lived on North Avenue.

title: BRANCHBANK BILL IS DEAD IN ALBANY
description: Statewide branch banking  which would have allowed the giant New York City banks to spread their branch operations from Montauk to the Niagara Frontierdied a quiet death in Albany yesterday.

title: Scotland Yard's Thomas Butler, Train Robbers' Captor, Is Dead
description: LONDON, April 20Thomas Butler, one of Scotland Yard's top detectives, who carried out a relentless fiveyear quest to put the perpetrators of Brit ain's great train robbery be hind bars, died today of lung cancer at Westminster Hospi tal. He was 57 years old.

title: CHRYSLER POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, April 20  The Chrysler Corporation reported today a loss of $29.4million in the first three months of 1970, making it the corporation's worst first quarter in its his tory.

title: Expos Acquire Gosger
description: MONTREAL, April 20 (AP) The Montreal Expos purchased today Jim Gosger, an outfielder from the San Francisco Giants Gosger will report to Buffalo the Expos' International League farm club

title: Barber Takes New Orleans Playoff at 2d Hole
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 20 (UPI)Miller Barber watched Bob Charles and Howie John son miss 40 and 17 foot birdie putts, then calmly sank a 12 footer for a birdie on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff today and took down first prize in the Greater New Orleans open.

title: CATER AND WOODS GET 3RUN HOMERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 It is happening just as Ralph Houk said it would. The Yankees are hitting baseballs. Sometimes they even hit them over the fence. Sometimes they win games, too.

title: Summary of Actions in Various Fields Taken by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: 5 Survivors of Avalanche File Manslaughter Charge
description: PLATEAU D'ASSY, France, April 20 (Reuters)Five nurses rescued from the sanitarium where 71 people, mostly young boys, died in an avalanche here last week lodged formal com plaints today of manslaughter through negligence.

title: LISTING MARKET NEARS EVEN KEEL
Previous Dealings Recalled
description: Charles E. Sorensen, an ear ly Ford executive, said in a book published in 1956 that he believed no other American industrial firm ever did so much business with Communist Rus sia as Ford Motor Company.

description: One of the nation's leading housing economists warned yes terday that premature credit ease could backfire and pro duce less money for housing rather than more.

title: U.S. Sees No Conflict
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  State department officials said today they did not know the details on the Soviet proposal but that, broadly speaking from what they did know, they did not think the proposal would conflict with United States policy on trade with Soviet Union.

title: Knicks Couldn't Wait to Beat Bucks, Can't Wait to Oppose Lakers
description: The Lew Alcindor era in Na tional Basketball Association competition Was postponed in definitely last night when the knicks eliminated his Milwau kee Bucks from the champion ship playoff series. But no body, including the Knicks, thinks that the 7foot2inch center will now disappear into the woodwork.

title: Geritol Sued Over Tired Blood
description: The Federal Government filed a $1million suit yester day against the companies, that make and advertise Geritol charging that they violated Fed eral Trade Commission orders to stop deceptive advertising.

title: EDITOR SAYS NIXON FAILS AS A UNIFIER
description: A United Press International senior editor asserted yester day that the great failure of the Nixon Administration has been in this area of furthering national sense of community.

title: Vietcong Turn Down France's Proposal On Indochina Talks
description: PARIS, April 20The Viet cong today turned down the French proposal for a new, in ternational conference on Indo china.

title: SUBVERSIVES UNIT LOSES MAIN ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Subversive Activities Con trol Board was left with virtu ally no function to perform today after the Supreme Court refused to review a lower court ruling that barred the board from declaring individuals to be members of the Communist party.

title: NEW YORK VICTOR IN EAST FINAL, 41
description: Perfection was the only ap propriate word for the way the New York Knickerbockers play ed basketball last night. They crushed the Milwaukee Bucks, 13296, with so dazzling a dis play of shooting, passing, mov ing, sniping and team cohesion that their style overshadowed the significance of a historic victor.

title: ASYLUM IS SOUGHT BY LATVIAN HERE
description: A 25yearold Latvian wait ress who apparently took an overdose of slrugs to escape from a Soviet ship sailing 100 miles off New York applied for political asylum in the United States yesterday.

title: City Bans Cars in 4 Parks Tomorrow
description: Four large city parks will be closed to automobile traffic to morrow from sunrise to sunset, the city announced yesterday as planners put the final touches on preparations for they first Earth Day.

title: 91 and 182Day Bill Rates Rise At Treasury's Weekly Auction

title: Janus Chorale Gives Premiere Of a Cantata to Whitman's Text
description: Walt Whitman's poetry is so Whitman's kaleidoscopic theme, expansively wordrich and im ageladen that most composers drawn to his work find that the shorter poems provide am ple material for musical treat vent. Not so Robert L. San ders, who has taken the entire text of Whitman's massive Song of Myself and out of it has fashioned a threehour can tata for narrator, soprano, chorus, brass instruments and percussion. The work was in troduced Sunday night by the Janus Chorale conducted by Robert Hickok  appropriately enough in Brooklyn College's Whitman Auditorium.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 20  Walter P. Reuther, the pres ident of the United Auto Work ers, warned today we have got to stop violence in America before it destroys our society.

description: LONDON (UPI)A High Court judge has ordered Roger Brook shaw, a $26.40aweek plumber, to pay $12,900 to a fellow ama teur soccer player he kicked during a game. Mr. Brookshaw, 29 years old, said he figured it would take him 40 years to pay it off.

title: Deadline on Reds' Stadium
description: Baseball Commissioner Bow ie Kuhn set a deadline yester day of May 30 for the Cincin nati Reds to advise him whether their new riverfront stadium would be ready for this year's AllStar Game, scheduled for July 14. There has been speculation that the stadium would not be com pleted in time for the inter league classic, thus necessi tating moving the game to the backup city, Atlanta.

title: 'Thanos and Despina,' Mock-Folk Film Epic, opens
description: EVERY now and then, just when I think I've reached the point of no return in cinematic sophistication, I see a film such as "Thanos and Despina" and am magically returned to that state of dumb innocence in which I looked at movies as a child. Watching it in the company of a (probably) bored parent, I wouldn't have hesitated to ask such questions as "Why'd the goat explode?" or "What's that lady doing crawling on the ground  is she sick or something?"The goat explodes and the lady (who's not sick, just mad with passion) crawls on the ground because "Thanos and Despina" is a mock-folk epic about passions so primitive and basic that perhaps only music can define them.The scene is contemporary Greece and the people picturesque, peasants oppressed by church, state, drought and superstition, to say nothing of other peasants. It opens with the belly of that starving goat erupting into the eye of the camera and it ends with a young man and a young woman, fleeing authority, jumping off a cliff. Because it's Easter, someone says "Greece is resurrected." Greece is resurrected, indeed.The film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema Village as part of the Grove Press International Film Festival, is the second movie to be directed by Nico Papatakis, a Jack-of-all-trades of Greek-Ethiopian parentage who lives in Paris and calls himself a spokesman for the avant-garde. (His first film; "Les Abysses, which I did not see, wa presented here in 1964.)Papatakis apparently means for "Thanos and Despina" to be taken as political allegory (the villian of the piece is a young man named Yankos). Allegory, however, is rather like quicksilver: it needs some kind of vessel to give it shape. There are times when "Thanos and Despina" seems on the point of becoming a lunatic "Romeo and Juliet," but because it never makes sense as coherent drama, it has even less meaning as allegory.The photography is quite lovely with its brilliantly contrasting, grainy tones of blacks and whites. There is, however, something patronizing about this loveliness, as there is about the entire film. It's as if somebody said: "Oh, let's go down and look at the peasants tonight. They are real."

title: Easy New Way Found To Give Up Smoking
description: NEW YORK N. Y.Even before publication of the U.S. Surgeon General's report on the danger of cigarette smoking, a team of scientists were hard at work seeking ways to make smoking safer. Their efforts led to a major breakthrough which com pletely eliminated the hazards of tobacco's toxic component, nico tine. After 10 years of research, laboratory test ing and clinical trials, these scientists had pro duced a new smoke made without a trace of tobacco. What's more it has been described as one of the major re search successes of this decade.

Without pumping the rhe torical bladder as though it were a bagpipe, without advertising him self as the ulti mate in revolu tionary pep pills, without quoting Chairman Mao or Timothy Leary, Mr. Gardner pro duced a disturbing and important book. It deals with conditions as they exist in military

title: The Old Political Game
description: ALBANY, April 20It is fact as old as elective politics that the voices of individual voters and pressure groups are never heard so clearly as they are in an election year. The 1970 session of the New York State Legislature reconfirmed that fact and proved that if there is a new politics functioning in this state, it is strangely like the old. The session took some surpris ing twists and turns, and the gen eral conclusion here is that no one could have predicted, when it convened in January, the character of legislation it would enact, But, looking back on the session, many observers here can see that the upcoming elec tion, in which both the Gov ernor's job and continued Re publican control of the Legisla ture are at issue, determined the final vote on many major issues.

title: Political Issues Excluded
description: At a City Hall news confer ence, Mayor Lindsay said re peatedly that his discussions with Governor Rockefeller, which led to Albany's massive money package for the city had not touched on political issues affecting this year's statewide elections.

title: Leaseway Transportation
description: Stockholders of the Lease way Transportation Corpbra tion were told yesterday at the annual meeting in Cleveland that firstquarter earnings probably will be lower than the 25 cents a share earned in the corresponding 1969 period. William J. O'Neill, chairman, said, however, that prospects Ifor the second half year are encouraging despite current problems. The company has been hurt recently by the phas ing out of the investment tax credit and by the sharp cutback in auto output which reduced Leaseway's carhauling opera tions.

title: Councilman Urges Inquiry Into Student Protests
description: Students strikes, demonstra tions and canceled classes cut attendance at several colleges and universities here yesterday as a City Councilman called for an investigation of recent campus disruptions in the city.

title: Yale Strike Urged To Back Panthers
description: NEW HAVEN, April 20The Yale College Student Senate, the undergraduate student gov ernment of Yale University, urged students tonight to stage a campus strike Wednesday in support of the Black Panthers who are facing trial here.

title: SUMMER TRIO SHOWS INTERPRETIVE FLAIR
description: The Sumner Trio was formed only two months ago, a fact rare ly discernible from the group's wellbalanced, highly proficient performances Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Its mem bers are Kay Fitzmayer Livolsi, violin; Herbert Feldman, viola, and Robert von Gutfeld, cello all busy freelance musicians in the New York area  and their easy expertise was evident throughout the evening.

title: American Cyanamid Co.
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 20 The quality of the environment vied with the state of business for attention at the annual meeting of the American Cy anamid Company here today.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The newest nudes around could be our belts of naked leather, much softer and suppler than the dressed up kind. Both in a mattefinish white with silvery metal buckles, either an anchor motif, or a capital G. By Givenchy in one size to fit 26 to 35, 15.00 each Belts, Street Floor Lord & Taylor. Call WI 73300 And at all Lord & Taylor stores

title: Shoe Import Curbs Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)Some 300 shoe industry employes from New England and New York appeared before an ad hoc Congressional tex tile committee today to support

title: Space Data Studied in Inquiry Into Apollo Explosion
description: HOUSTON, April 20The in vestigation of the oxygen tank explosion that imperiled the lives of the Apollo 13 astronauts was focused today on the analy sis of data radioed from the spacecraft Immediately before and during the accident a week ago.

title: Paris Unveils a Grand Matisse Exhibition
description: PARIS, April 20  Henri Matisse posthumously made a lot of people happy here to day: those invited to the pre view of a grand exhibition of his work. The show will open to the public on Wednesday.

title: Postal Reform Coming
description: If Benjamin Franklin were to come back to the postal service he set up nearly two centuries ago, he would find many of its practices for delivering the mail little changed. The reorganization plan recom mended by President Nixon, on which the House Post Office Committee begins hearings today, promises bring the system into the automation age.

title: Sihanouk Kin in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, April 20 (Reu ters)Prince Norodom Yuve neath, son of the deposed Cam bodian Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has been allowed to extend his stay in Hong Kong until May 15, a Government spokesman said to day. The prince arrived in the colony for a short vacation with his wife and 4yearold son on March 16, two days be fore his father was overthrown in a bloodless coup.

title: Giants's Schedule
description: Sept 19, Chicago, at Yankee Sta dium, 8 P.M. 27, at Dallas.

title: Hanoi Calls for the Infliction of Heavier Combat Losses on U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Hanoi has called on Commu nist forces to kill American sol diers in South Vietnam at a rate far beyond the 100a week level, which the United States ruling clique has con sidered bearable.

title: Market Rebuffs Britain's Bid For Full Role in Political Talks
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 20  Foreign Ministers of the Euro pean Economic Community to day rejected a British proposal for full, early participation in talks on political union.

title: Card Party to Aid Nurses
description: The Student Nurses Schol arship Fund of the depart ment of nursing at Columbia University will benefit from a card party at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow. Mrs. Cyrus R. Vance is honorary chaignan for the event, which will be held at Maxwell Hall, the nurses' and student nurses' residence, at 179 Fort Wash ington Avenue.

title: Salary and Pension, Too, Are Allowed Garelik
description: ALBANY, April 20The State Senate passed a bill to day that would permit San for D. Garelik to collect his $25,000 annual police retire ment pension in addition to his $45,000 salary as Presi dent of New York's City Council.

title: Brown Indictment Challenged in Court as Invalid
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., April 20Another attempt to try H. Rap Brown for arson and riot opened here today with his lawyers attacking the validity of the indictment.

title: Israeli Jets Strike Target In Central Suez Canal Area
description: TEL AVIV, April 20 (Reuters)  Israeli jets struck targets today in the central section of the Suez Canal.

title: Tommy Michaels Tends Stable While His Ailing Brother Rests
description: YONKERS, April 20Train ing horses at Yonkers Race way this morning was out of the question. Because of the heavy rain no standardbreds were permitted on the track, so that Cesare Gennari and his ground crew could have the surface in racing condition for tonight's harness card. most Horsemen were disap pointed by the enforced idle ness, but a few welcomed the respite from the continual grind of conditioning trotters and pacers. In the latter group was Tommy Michaels, the older brother of Jimmy Michaels, who is recuperating from a fiveweek hospital siege.

title: Observer: And Now, the Way It Happens in Real Life
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  We were just a few thousand miles east of the moon when we heard a loud bang and de duced that we had a blowout to deal with. Red lights twin kled their cozy little danger signals. Gauges spun alarm ingly. Looking through the portholes, we could see gears, ratchets and radiator hoses being ejected at a startling rate.

title: F.T.C. BEGINS STUDY OF CEREAL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the breakfast food industry to see whether control of the market by a few large companies leads to higher prices, commission sources said today.

title: 5 Former SS Men Get Life For Murder of Thousands
description: BONN, April 20A court in Cologne today sentenced five former members of the Nazi SS (elite guard) to life imprison ment after finding them guilty of having murdered thousands of inmates at Sachsenhausen concentration camp near Berlin.

title: Article 7  No Title
Broad New Group Seeks Independence for Taiwan
description: A worldwide organization with headquarters in New York has been formed with the aim of overthrowing the Chinese Nationalist Government in Tai wan and replacing it with one chosen by the 14 million peo ple on the island.

title: Art Show in Brooklyn
description: The Junior Committee of ColonySouth Brooklyn Houses is sponsoring the 16th annual Brooklyn Heights Art Show, which will he held at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, 75 Hicks Street, Friday through Sunday. A preview and reception is scheduled for 8 to 10 P.M. Friday. The show will be open from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. The donation is $2 a person Friday and $1 thereafter. Proceeds will go to the set tlement house that has served the community for more than 60 years.

title: Short Interest Is Up For April 15 Period
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in the month ended April 15. marking the first monthly in crease in this widely watched technical indicator since Dec ember.

title: Seabed Draft to Bar Atom Arms Revised
description: GENEVA, April 20  The United States and the Soviet Union, attempting to meet ob jections of coastal nations, have completed a revised draft of their joint proposal to prohibit the installation of nuclear weapons on the ocean floor.

title: Gleaming New Iowa Hospital, Built to Attract Doctors, Has 90 Beds and a Staff of One
description: DYERSVILLE Iowa  No Quiet, Please signs are needed at the Dyersville Community Hospital. No doctors scurry down its pol ished corridors to the metal lic summons of public ad dress speakers. No interns and nurses wait offstage amid the sterilized steel and porcelain of the emergency room, ready to play out the next drama of life and death. The Dyersville hospital, built a year ago ingly raised by a rural com munity that has not lost the oldtime can do spirit, is a medical oddity on the verge of bankruptcy.

title: Nation Set to Observe Earth Day
description: Thousands of colleges, schools and communities across the country were getting ready yes terday for an unprecedented event: tomorrow's Earth Day an Interlude of national con templation of problems and man's deteriorating environ ment.

title: Hector Garcia Godoy Dies at 49, Month Before Dominican Vote
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 20Hector Garcia Godoy Caceres, a presfi idential candidate who offered a moderate opposition alterna tive to the reelection of Pres ident Joaquin Balaguer, died of a heart attack today in the midst of the campaign period here.

title: For the Princess, A Stylish Business
description: A pram is parked in the hallway, next to the paintings from ParkeBernet stacked against the wall. A collection of cigarette boxes, some by Faberge, and family snapshots give the sitting room a homey look. But be yond, dresses are hung over chair backs, order books are scattered around, a telephone rests on the dining room table. It's not quite a typical Park Avenue apartment.

title: In The Nation: The (Not Quite) Open Society
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Much more now is known about the secret war in Laos because of the official testimony forced by the Symington subcommit tee last fall and published Mon day after a lengthy struggle with the State Department over security clearance. The testi mony also was eloquent as to how even the Senate was mis led for years about the extent of the Laotian involvement.

title: M'GOVERN AND PERCY DEPLORE U.S. HUNGER
description: CHICAGO, April 20Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, charged today that hunger in the United States is as bad or worse as in some of the most backward naitons in the world.

title: Four Marines Die in Crash
description: MERIDIAN, Miss., April 20 (AP)Four Marine Corps crew men were killed and another critically injured near here to day when a search and rescue helicopter attached to the Me ridian Naval Air Station crashed and burned, the authorities said. A spokesman for the base said Capt. Wayne T. Henderson, 27 years old, and Corpsman 2d Cl. Lorenzo Overstreet, 21, both of Meridian, and Lieut. Alfred C. McGlothlin, 28, of Marion died in the crash. A fourth Ma rine killed was not immediately identified.

title: Reprieve for the Tundra
description: A significant victory for the future of the American earth was won last week when a Federal District Court judge enjoined Secretary of the Interior Hickel from issuing a rightofway permit for a road parallel to the projected Alaska oil pipeline. Construction on both the road and the 800mile pipeline will thus be further delayed, forcing both the Federal Government and overeager oil firms to take a harder look at the potentially disastrous effects of these projects on the fragile ecology of the Alaskan tundra.

title: SOCIALISTS FORMING CABINET IN AUSTRIA
description: VIENNA, April 20  The Chancellor  designate, Bruno Kreisky, announced the nearly complete formation of a minor ity Socialist cabinet tonight after his negotiations with the conservative People's party for a coalition government had ended in failure earlier today.

title: I Don't Advocate Big Families for Everyone, Says Mother of 13
description: MRS. JOSEPH CLAIR of Northvale, N. J., is preg nant again. Nobody in her family was very surprised, even though it will be the 14th blessed event in the Clair household.

title: 3Year Celebration Begun
description: ELY, England (AP)Com memorative celebrations start ing this year in this communi ty's ancient cathedral to mark the 1,000th anniversary of its establishment as a Benedictine settlement in 970 will culmi nate in 1973 with ceremonies marking the foundation of this historic bastion of English Christianity by St. Etherreda in 673.

title: FREDERICK L. CASE
description: MADISON, N.J., April 20 Frederick L. Case of 11 Overhill Drive, a member of the editorial staff of The Newark Evening News since 1933. died today in New York University Medical Cetner. His age was 64.

title: Cambodians Battle Reds 15 Miles From Pnornpenh
description: SAANG, Cambodia, April 20 The war between Cambodia and Vietnamese Communist forces reached within 15 miles of Pnompenh today with a bat tle for this district capital of a few thousand people. The marketplace marked the front line.

title: High Court Denies Kirk Appeal to Take School Busing Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) The Supreme Court denied today a motion by Florida Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida to transfer a Florida school busing case from the Federal courts directly to the high court.

title: Offtrack Betting Operation Is Regarded as Major Gamble for the City, Too
description: Offtrack Betting Operation Is Regarded as Major Gamble for the City, Too

title: Book Casts New Light on Mysterious Death of Donald Crowhurst
description: Two British journalists have unraveled much of the mystery of the apparent suicide of Donald Crowhurst, the 36year old electronics engineer who set sail from the English resort town of Teignmouth in Octo ber of 1963 to emulate Sir Francis Chichester in a voy age alone around the world.

title: American Home Products
description: American Home Products Corporation had net earnings of $35,583,000, or 67 cents a share, up from $32,416,000, or 61 cents a share, a year before. Sales increased 9 per cent to $359,008,000 from $329,119, 000.

title: FORD SAYS SOVIET ASKS AID ON PLANT
description: MOSCOW, April 20Henry Ford 2d said today that the Soviet Union had asked the Ford Motor Company to help build a large truck manufactur ing complex.

title: FOSTER TITLE BOUT DELAYED BY INJURY
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Bob Foster's defense of his world lightheavyweight cham pionship against Mark Tessman in Baltimore May 4 has been postponed because of Foster's hand injury.

title: POTATO FUTURES ATTRACT BUYERS
description: The May contract in potato futures attracted many buyers yesterday, and the prices closed higher on the New York Mer cantile Exchange. These pota toes are the last of the 196970 season in storage and the futures market was influenced by higher prices attained in the cash markets.

title: O'REILLY IS NEXT, 42 SECONDS BACK
description: BOSTON, April 20In the vernacular of the mod genera tion, Ron Hill of England was literally as well as figuratively out of sight today in the 74th annual Boston Athletic Associa tion Marathon.

title: Packagers Show New Products
description: Automobiles packaged in plastic. Twelvefoot bags holding nothing but air. A $700 machine for the home or filling station that crushes tin cans or glass bottles.

title: LINDSAY ASSUMES MORGENTHAU TASK
description: Mayor Lindsay took over the chairmanship of the untended city Narcotics Control Commis sion yesterday, replacing Rob ert M. Morgenthau, who is on leave to campaign for Gov ernor.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: Steel production rose L6 per cent last week, compared to output in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel In stitute reported yesterday.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
EXM.P. PUT ON TRIAL UNDER SECRETS ACT
description: LONDON April 20William Owen, a Labor party member of Parliament until two weeks ago, admitted that he had given Czechoslovak diplomats inform ation and received money in return, a British court was told today.

title: Ottinger Puts FishKill Of Con Ed Up to A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Representative Richard L. Ot tinger petitioned the Atomic Energy Commission today to force the Consolidated Edison Company to protect fish in the Hudson River at the util ity's Indian Point nuclear power plant near Buchanan, N. Y.

title: George Washington High To Remain Closed Today
description: Board of Education officials reported last night that, the George Washington High School in Washington Heights would remain closed today, because of the fear of additional student disorders.

title: CUBICULO STAGES MIXED DANCE FARE
description: The Cubiculo presented Rosa lind Pierson and Robert Chris topher along with the Ballet Concepts Company last night in a mixed modern dance and ballet program, most of which was choreographed by Miss Pierson.

title: It Was A Good Day for Ducks in the Rain at Aqueduct
description: A follower of form at Aque duct yesterday could hardly have been blamed for observing that it was a great day fo ducks. The rain was pelting the Queens County landscap and puddles at the Big A were fetlock deep in many cases.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: PRICES OF STOCKS SLUMP IN LONDON
description: Prices slumped on the Lon don stock market yesterday amid generally depressed con ditions that sent the main in dexes to new lows for the year. Trading was sluggish.

title: Taiwan Group Stages Protest At White House Against Chiang
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 About 60 members of the Tai wanese independence move ment, marching behind a ban ner reading We Represent the Silenced Majority, rallied in front of the White House today to protest the visit of Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo of Nationalist China.

title: Funds for Reserve Gain
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill au thorizing about $500,000 for development, operation and maintenance of the Ice Age National Scientific Reserve in. Wisconsin.

title: HARNESS TRACKS TO RESUME SERIES
description: MONTREAL, April 20  The Harness Tracks of America an nounced today that the organ ization plans another series of races next year to pick the driving champion of the year Race track sites will be an nounced later.

title: Exile Group Says Its Members Landed in Cuba
description: MIAMI, April 20A Cuban exile organization declared to day that its members landed in eastern Cuba on Friday.

title: Australia Expected to Pull A Battalion Out of Vietnam
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 20 Prime Minister John Gorton is expected to announce this week that Australia will withdraw one of her three infantry battalions now in Vietnam.

title: Spanish Institute Planning Fetes
description: The Spanish Institute, which has been camping out in its new quarters for al most a year, will get around to the formal opening next week with special concerts and exhibitions and a banquet at the St. RegisSheraton Roof on Thursday.

title: Stage: The Pertinence of How Much, How Much?
description: YOU will have noticed, I am confident, that an enormous quantity of the plays written todayor, to be generous, yesterday  happen to be about nothing. The excuse is meant to be that they offer the mindless oblivion that some entre preneurs hopefully term en tertainment. They quite for get that such nothingness can always be obtained for nothing on television, a me dium that at the very least affords superbly artistic com mercials.

title: A RUSSIAN IN AMMAN IS QUOTED ON ISRAEL
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 20 (Reuters)The Soviet press at tach here was quoted as hav ing said at a news conference today that his country sup ported the overthrow of the State of Israel. He denied hav ing said so.

title: 2D SESSION HELD AT ARMS PARLEY
description: VIENNA, April 20 American and Soviet negotiators contin ued their closeddown search here today for an agreement to limit strategic arms.

title: HARRY W. GOLDING, TEXTILE EXECUTIVE
description: Harry W. Golding, president of the Golding Bros. Division of W. R. Grace & Co., died Sunday in a Boston hospital after a short illness. He was 73 years old and had moved recently from 160 Central Park West to Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Bakers on Strike in Paris
description: PARIS, April 20 (Reuters) Large areas of Paris went with out fresh bread today as bakers continued a 36hour strike that began yesterday afternoon to protest the Government's re fusal to approve a price rise.

title: 1970 N.F.L. Schedule
description: Friday, Sept. 18St. Louis at Los Angeles (n).

title: French Ship Sabotaged
description: DUNKIRK, France, April 19 (Reuters)Fiftyyearold Man uel Victoria, an Algerianborn electrician was charged Sunday with sabotaging a refrigerator ship being built here for the Soviet Union, the police said. A series of fires aboard the vessel is still under investiga tion they added.

title: Taking Case to People
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, said that Mr. Carswell was taking his case to the people.

title: TV: Nixon's Vietnam Talk Assayed by Networks
description: TELEVISION'S commercial and noncommercial net works offered instant com mentaries after President Nixon's speech last night. The main reaction appeared to be uncertainty over exact ly what strategy the Presi dent was pursuing in his campaign of Vietnamization.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, April 21, 1970

title: Lottery Offers a Twist To Shaggy Dog Stories
description: A sixyearold English spaniel named Penny was awarded a share of one of the three $100,000 grand prizes given yesterday in the New York State lottery.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon, in a televised report on the Vietnam conflict, announced plans for the withdrawal of 150,000 more American troops over the next year. Mr. Nixon said that the training and equipping of the South Vietnamese Army had substantially ex ceeded expectations. [Page 1, Cols. 68.]

title: Orr Named Player of Year
description: MONTREAL, April 20 (UPI) Bobby Orr, star defenseman of the Boston Bruins, was named player of the year in the Na tional Hockey League by Hockey News today. William M. Jennings, president of the New York Rangers, was named executive of the year and Red Kelly of the Pittsburgh Pen guins was chosen top coach.

title: CARSWELL RESIGNS AS JUDGE TO SEEK U. S. SENATE SEAT
description: Will Oppose Rep. Cramer of Florida in G.O.P. Race for Post Holland Is Leaving MIAMI, April 20G. Harrold Carswell announced today that he had resigned from the Unit ed States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to run for the United States Senate.

title: CAHILL PROPOSES ANTICRIME LAWS
description: TRENTON, April 20Gov. William T. Cahill proposed to the New Jersey Legislature to day a package of anticrime measures that would give the State Attorney General direct control over County Prosecu tors and impose new regulations against loansharking and busi bess monopolies by organized crime.

title: Israeli Soldiers at Suez Join in Seder in Tanks to Mark Passover
description: JERUSALEM, April 20Is raeli soldiers on duty in tanks along the Suez Canal were able to join this year in the tradi tional seder meal opening thel Passover holiday.

title: Drug Company to Build Waste Processing Plant
description: Eli Lilly & Co., which is building a plant in Clinton, Ind., will include a separate waste processing plant that it says will eliminate 90 per cent of normal nroduction wastes.

title: Scientists Find Ancient South Pole in the Sahara
description: A team of earth scientists, dressed in summer shorts and sun hats, searched for the South Pole recently and found itin the middle of the Sahara.

title: Chemical Profits Grow; American Brands Gains
description: Only one of eight diversified chemical producers made less money in the first quarter this year than in the initial three months of 1969, according to their reports issued yesterday.

title: LOUIS P. ANZIANO
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 21Louis P. Anziano presi dent of the Anziano Building Company, died of a heart at tack Saturday at a hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 67 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla., and at 10 Carteret Place.

title: Praise for Knicks From Buck Coach Knows No Limits
description: Carl Braun, who has played, coached and watched National Basketball Associa tion games for more than 20 years, summed up what he saw on Monday night at Madison Square Garden in one terse sentence.

title: MISS STACY SCORES ON PINEHURST LINKS
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP)Holly Stacy, the medal ist, and Barbara McIntire, last year's winner, were among the favorites today who advanced as play began in the North and  South women's amateur golf tournament.

title: L.I.R.R. Is No More; Now It's Simply L.I.R.
description: The Long Island Railroad, already changed into the finest commuter rail line in the country, according to Governor Rockefeller, made another change this week: It ceased being the Long Is land Rail Road.

title: BLACKPOWER MOB RIOTS IN TRINIDAD
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 21  Policemen opened fire today on rioting mobs that went on a looting rampage in this Caribbean capital in defi ance of a stateofemergency proclamation issued to cope with black  power demonstra tions.

title: Rep. O'Neal Declines to Run
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Representative Maston O'Neal, Democrat of Georgia, said today that he would not seek reelection because of ill ness. Mr. O'Neal cited a heart condition that developed re cently. He now is in his sixth year as a House member.

title: North American Sets Pay Cuts for Employes
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21  The pay of 45 per cent of the salaried employes of the North American Rockwell Corporation's Los Angeles Division may be cut because of declining Government business.

title: AMEX IS STUDYING COAST OPERATION
description: The American Stock Ex change is studying the feasibil ity of establishing a West Coast branch operation to facilitate serving investors in the West ern states.

title: Ford Theater Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) A House Interior subcommit tee approved today a bill to establish the Ford Theater a National Historic Site. The bill would designate as a historic site the Washington theater where President Lincoln was shot, the adjoining Lincoln Mu seum and the Peterson House, across the street, where Lincoln died.

title: Salvation Army Sets Spring Fete Friday
description: The 46th annual spring festival sponsored by the Woman's Auxiliary of the Salvation Army Foster Home Service will be held at the Flatbush Tompkins Congrega tional Church, Dorchester Road and 19th Street, on Fri day, from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Mrs. H. Norman Runsdorf and Mrs. Robert B. B. Moor man are cochairmen for the benefit, which will in clude a Chinese auction, a luncheon and booths selling handmade gifts and home made cakes, cookies, jams and jellies.

title: CITY GETS FUNDS FOR CLEAN WATER
description: Governor Rockefeller gave New York City an Earth Day present today when he an nounced that the state has ap proved $60million for cleaning up the water in the Upper East River, the Harlem River and Jamaica Bay.

title: Watch Fob, 741, Beats Favored Process Shot in Bed o' Roses at Aqueduct
description: Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown. Especially when the track comes up muddy.

title: C. WADSWORTH JOHNSON
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 21  Dr. C. Wadsworth Johnson, chief physician of the Mount Vernon Fire Department since about 1923, died at the Wartburg Nursing Home today of cancer. He was 87 years old and lived at 252 South Fifth Avenue.

title: I.O.S. NET CASH FLOW SLOWS FOR QUARTER
description: GENEVA, April 21Investors Overseas Services Management, Ltd., reported yesterday that the net cash flow produced by sales of its mutual funds had slowed in the first quarter of the year.

title: BINGHAM TO SHUN HIGHWAY HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Representative Jonathan B. Bingham said today that it was impossible to get fair consid eration of a balanced trans portation program in the House of Representatives and announced that he would boy cott the new House hearings on the Federal highway pro gram.

title: June Nuptials For Baroness Set for Vienna
description: Mrs. Anthony Adama Zylstra of Paris and Baron Herbert von Waldsttten of Vienna have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Baroness Elizabeth Maya von Waldsttten, to Christo pher Morgan Wynkoop, son, of Mr. and Mrs. Burson Wyn koop of Red Bank, N. J. The couple plan to be married, in Vienna on June 20.

title: Robert Laurent, Sculptor, Dies; Pioneer of an Abstract Trend
description: CAPE NEDDICK, Me., April 21Robert Laurent, a sculp tor, who figured in the de velopment of an American sculptural art that balanced nature and abstraction, died at his home here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Strike Forces Goodyears To Disband Basketball Team
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 21Be cause of the strike called last night by 23,000 members of the United Rubber Workers Union, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that it was reluctantly discontinu ing the Akron Goodyears bas ketball team in an effort to reduce anticipated financial losses.

title: Pelting Says Soviet Has Betrayed Lenin
description: HONG KONG, April 21  Communist China, today deliv ered a major attack on the Soviet Union to mark the cen tenary of the birth of the man to whom both countries owe allegiance.

title: For Men, SeeThrough Shirts, Slacks
description: OF ALL the boutiques that Bloomingdale's, has had and it has had plentyprobably the most successful has been micmac of St. Tropez, which took up residence on the third floor a couple of years ago. One reason is that the designer for it, Tan Giudicelli (half Italian, half Vietnamese), has, always had a knack for turning out clothes that are up to the minute, or even ahead of itbut that are not too far out.
