With their smart look just this side of sportiness, they have appealed both to dashing young wo men and to notsoyoung and notsodashing.

title: Saigon Vows to Investigate Alleged Torture of Students
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21 (UPI)A delegation of stu dents today called on the South Vietnamese Premier, Tran Thien Khiem, who promised an inves tigation to determine whether 21 other students were tortured while awaiting trial on charges of proCommunist activity.

title: 33 Are Killed in Crash Of Airliner in Philippines
description: MANILA, April 21 (Reu ters)All 33 persons aboard a twinengined passenger plane were killed when it crashed today about 75 miles north of Manila.

title: Ithaca Five Elects Chafin
description: ITHACA, N.Y., April 21 (AP) The Ithaca College basketball team elected Brian Chafin to day as its basketball captain for next season. The sophomore guard averaged 12.5 points a game this season, after he be came eligible for varsity play in January.

title: U.S. PLAYERS GAIN IN ITALIAN TENNIS
description: ROME April 21 (AP)  Top seeded Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman gave the United States a pair of opening victories in the Italian open tennis championships today.

title: Corrosion! on Way Out Of TV Razor Blade Ad
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The announcer who peers over a mansized razor blade with nicks in its edge and sneeringly proclaims Cor rosion is facing a forced change in his television mes sage.

title: Lindsay Declines Comment On the BlackPanther Case
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that he considered it inap propriate for him to comment on the high bail set in the case of 13 black panthers awaiting trial on bomb conspiracy charges in New York City.

title: Wunderman, Ricotta Gets BookoftheMonth
description: Wunderman, Ricotta & Klinevery big in direct re sponse advertisinghas just been named the agency for the PeakoftheMonth Club. The ad budget is expected to be approximately $4million.

title: Broadcasters Give Earth Day Special Attention
description: Television and radio will ob serve Earth Day today with special broadcasts devoted to various aspects of pollution and their effects on the ecological balance of the country.

title: THIEU SAYS SAIGON REQUIRES MORE AID
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21 (Reuters)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that South Vietnam needed more aid from its allies to assume full responsibility for its defense.

title: The America (Now the Australis) Returns
description: The onetime pride of the American merchant marine returned to port yesterday after a sixyear absence, fly ing a Greek house flag.

title: VICTOR O. JONES, 64, BOSTON COLUMNIST
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP)  Victor O. Jones, former execu tive editor of The Boston Globe, died today in Massachusetts General Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: 5 Young Pianists Chosen for Finals Of WQXR Contest
description: Five pianists from high schools in New York and the metro politan area will compete for more than $2,000 in cash schol arship awards in the finals of the WQXR Young Artists Com petition on Saturday, May 2.

title: Jolts Name Boxing Coach
description: The New York Jolts, off to a winning home start in the In ternational Boxing League, an nounced yesterday the appoint ment of Bobby Lewis as head coach. Lewis, an outstanding coach in national Amateur Ath letic Union circles and in the Golden Gloves, will lead his team against Miami tonight in the first of four dates at Sun nyside Garden.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS STILL A STANDOFF
description: The typographical union in creased its economic pressure on The New York Times yes terday by lengthening the daily chapel, or (union), meetings that stop composing room op erations.

title: EARTH DAY GOALS BACKED BY NICKEL
description: Earth Day activities got off to an early start across the country yesterday, with Federal officials, industrialists, house wives and students contribut ing to a kaleidoscope of envi ronmentally oriented activities.

title: 94 Degrees Given by Bates
description: LEWISTON, Me., April 20 (UPI)  Bates College today awarded 94 bachelor's degrees, including 11 with honors, and five honorary degrees at its 104th commencement. Honor ary degrees went to Archbishop Iavokos, head of the Greek Or thodox Archdiocese of North and South America; John Ciardi, poet and critic; Dr. Ruth M. Adams, president of Wellesley College! King V. Cheek, presi dent of Shaw University in Raleigh, N. C., and Eli Goldston, Boston industrialist.

title: Half Out, Half In
description: There is a bittersweet message in President Nixon's announcement that United States forces in Vietnam will be reduced by 150,000 during the coming year, the same withdrawal rate as in recent months. By next spring almost half the American troops will be out. But about half will still be there, 284,000 of them, more than two years after Mr. Nixon's assump tion of office with a pledge and an undisclosed plan to end the war.

title: Some Troubled by Environment Drive
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 Some 10,000 people are expected to swarm into a local park here tomorrow for an Earth Week rally, but the 2,000 members of the Young Great Society won't be among them.

title: Westchester Jury Urges State To Investigate RoadWork Bids
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 21 A special Westchester County grand jury has called for a major inquiry by the State Department of Transportation into what it terms the con tinued erosion of competition in bidding for highway con tracts in the county.

title: Egyptians Attack in Sinai and Lose MIG
description: CAIRO, April 21Egyptian fighterbombers struck again today at Israeli military posi tions in the Sinai Peninsula, un derlining indications here of a new sense of confidence and readiness for battle on the part of the Egyptian Air Force.

title: Isabel T. Barringer, 59, Headed Decorating Firm
description: Mrs. Isabel Thacher Barring er, an interior decorator, died at New York Hospital Saturday after a short illness. She was 59 years old and lived in Man hattan.

title: Foreign Affairs: From Lenin to Brezhnev
description: PARISThere is something almost religious about today's international tributes to Lenin sponsored by the Soviet Com munist leadership. Special pil grimages to Moscow have been arranged by party functionaries from all around the world.

title: F.D.A. Warns 80,000 Pizzas May Be Tainted
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The Food and Drug Administra tion issued tonight an urgent warning that as many as 80,000 frozen pizzas may be contami nated with lethal germs that cause botulism.

title: Barge Canal Open Friday
description: The New York State Barge Canal System is scheduled to be opened Friday to commer cial and pleasure boat traffic. The 524mile system includes the 348mile Erie, the 60mile Champlain, the 24mile Oswego and the 92mile CayugaSeneca Canal.

title: Court Bars a Grievance Table In Washington Heights School
description: Parents were temporarly en joined yesterday from setting up a grievance table at George Washington High School in Washington Heights.

title: Nixon Signs Food Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) President Nixon signed to day a bill designed to make more surplus dairy products di rectly available for food aid programs.

title: Advertising: Newspapermen Criticize TV
description: The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, found ed in 1913 to generate more national advertising dollars for the nation's papers, is in the midst of a major effort to hold onto newspaper's big gest source of revenue  re tail advertising.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WHEN the Knicks were riding high on the rollercoaster of their 18 game winning streak early in the season, a wellphrased critique was offered by Bill Bradley, the Princeton alumnus and Rhodes scholar who serves as the team's intellectual.

title: ACE AUSSIE PACER STARTS SATURDAY
description: YONKERS, April 21Lucky Creed, the Australian represen tative in the $50,000 Interna tional Pace on May 8 at Yon kers Raceway, will make his first start in the United States, when he enters a qualifying race Saturday morning in prep aration for the rich pace next month.

title: 4 Women Join Board Of New York Y.M.C.A.
description: For the first time in its 118thyear history, the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York will have women on its board of directors.

title: BOSCH SAYS AIM IS TO END CRISIS
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 21 Juan Bosch, former president and pivotal figure in the civil war here in 1965, said in a nation ally broadcast speech today that he had returned here to help solve the political crisis with the least harm to the Dominican people.

title: St. John's Trackmen Beat Fairleigh Dickinson, 8361
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 21 Don Rowe ran a mile in 4 min utes 10.6 seconds today as St. John's defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, 8361. Rowe beat Fairleigh's mile ace, Bob Bailey, who ran 4:14.9.

title: CITY RUSHES PLAN FOR AUTUMN START OF OFFTRACK BETS
description: A top level task force was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to hurry into shape the details of the city's new off track betting plan.

title: 3 PEABODY WINNERS WARN OF PRESSURES
description: The 30th annual George Foster Peabody Awards for distinguished and meritorious public service in radio and television were presented yes terday at a luncheon at the Pierre Hotel.

title: 4 Witnesses for AntiWar Sailor Ruled Irrelevant
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The defense rested its case to day in the courtmartial of Seaman Roger Lee Priest after some of the testimony of sev eral witnessesincluding law professors, a folk singer and the defendant's fatherhad been ruled irrelevant.

title: Panthers' Apologies Free Two Jailed for New Haven Contempt
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21A Superior Court judge freed David Hilliard and Emory Doug las from jail today after the two national Black Panther party leaders stood before the bench and apologized for an in cident a week ago that led to their being sentenced to six months for contempt of court.

title: Cerro Resuming Delivery Of Copper Mined in Peru
description: The Cerro Corporation an nounced here yesterday that it had lifted its suspension of scheduled copper deliveries from its Peruvian mines, follow ing the settlement of a strike by 14,000 mining and metallur gical workers.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Sihanouk Said to Abandon GovernmentinExile Plan
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 21 (Reuters)The Cam bodian news agency reported today that Prince Norodom Sihanouk had told his former Premier and confidant, Penn Nouth, that he had given up the idea of forming a govern ment in exile.

title: Dutchmen Bypass Doctors
description: THE HAGUE (UPI)  The Dutch spend 200 million guil ders ($56million) a year on medicines not prescr??be?? by their doctors, according to pharmaceutical industry statis tics.

title: Tension Eases on Coast Campus as Riot Victim Is Buried, but the Polarization Persists
description: ISLA VISTA, Calif., April 21 Kevin Moran was buried to day as this college community started to unwind from five days of tension and to probe the circumstances surrounding his death.

title: A SCHOOL MONOPOLY IS FEARED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  President Nixon said today that it would not be good for either the country or its schools if either public or pri vate school systems had a monopoly over the education of the nation's children.

title: Orders of Durables Declined in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 New orders for durable goods, which turned upward in Feb ruary, resumed their decline in March, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: Gimeno and Holmberg Win
description: DALLAS, April 21 (AP) Andres Gimeno and Ron Holm berg defeated the topseeded doubles team, John Newcombe and Tony Roche, 86, 64 to day in the opening round of the Dallas tennis classic. Fred Stolle defeated Warren Jacques, 63, 63, in the opening singles match.

title: Crew of Apollo 13 Willing to Attempt Noon Trip Again
CHRYSLER CHIEF REPORTS ON GAINS
description: DETROIT, April 21 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation, which yesterday reported a $29.4million loss for the first quarter; now is operating prof itably, Lynn Townsend, chair man, told a news conference after the annual meeting here today.

title: Soviet, in Geneva, Seeks Revival Of 1959 FullDisarmament Plan
description: GENEVA, April 21The So viet Union disclosed today that it would seek to revive the dis cussion of its 10yearold pro posal for general and com plete disarmament at the sum mer session of the Geneva Dis armament Conference.

title: Earth Day Sponsors to Stay Together
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The national organization that is sponsoring Earth Day plans to stay together after nation wide environmental demonstra tions scheduled for this week. It will adopt a new name and begin emphasizing direct poli tical action.

title: Radioactive Gas in Nevada
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (Reuters)A small amount of radioactive gas escaped today from an underground nuclear test in Nevada, about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced. A spokesman for the agency said the barely detect able radioactivity dissipated within an hour and presented no danger.

title: Jailed Greeks Mourn an Anniversary
description: ATHENS, April 21  Greek political prisoners marked the militarybacked Government's third anniversary in power to day by staging a hunger strike, maintaining silence and wear ing black armbands for 24 hours.

title: Frank G. Schlosser Dies; Hoboken Lawyer 45 Years
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., April 21 Frank G. Schlosser, a lawyer here for 45 years, died Sunday in Newton Memorial Hospital in Newton, where he had lived for several years. He was 68 years old.

title: CAMBODIA CALLS FOR MILITARY AID IN NOTE TO NIXON
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 21Premier Lon Nol sent an urgent appeal to President Nixon yesterday to help Cam bodia in her critical situation, high Cambodian sources dis closed today.

title: G.M. IS CRITICIZED ON BOARD PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The Campaign to make G.M. Responsible charged to day that the General Motors Corporation had spent more than $500,000 to defeat pro posals to put representatives of consumers and conservation interests on its board of direc tors and to make other changes in its operations.

title: Memorial Services
description: BARUCHAIMEE. A memorial service for Aimee Baruch will be held on Sunday, April 26 at 2 P.M., N.Y. Society For Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St.

title: Expos Release Ken Johnson
description: MONTREAL, April 21 (UPI) The Montreal Expos released unconditionally Ken Johnson, a pitcher, and recalled Don Hahn, an outfielder, from the Buffalo Bisons today.

title: Nixon Plan Surprises Many at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Most senior Pentagon leaders, military and civilian, learned of plans to withdraw 150,000 more United States troops from Vietnam over the next 12 months only when President Nixon announced the decision on television last night, ac cording to Defense Department sources.

title: BLACKS SEEK AID FROM METHODISTS
description: ST. LOUIS, April 21The 11 million member United Metho dist Church wasasked today to give blacks not less than $10 million a year for higher edu cation and not less than $5.5 million to undergird the con cept of selfdetermination.

title: Nixon's Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The first reactions here to Pres ident Nixon's latest report on Vietnam focused on his obvious effort to balance the political pressure for more troop with drawals against the military's request for a show of strength on the battlefield in the next few months. The President found his compro mise in the kind of annual timetable that he had re fused to proclaim last autumn. He committed himself to the mini mum withdrawal rate of 12,000 men a month over the coming year. But he left his generals free to argue for slowdowns and speedups as the course of battle changes, provided only that they scale down to $284, 000 men by next spring.

title: 3M Profits and Sales Register Record in the First Quarter; Other Companies Issue Earnings Figures
U.A.W. Asks Bill of Rights To Protect Environment
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 21 (UPI)The United Auto Work ers called today for an environ mental bill of rights for Ameri cans and said that pollution control would be made an issue in the union's contract talks this year with the nation's auto makers.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON BECOME STEADIER
description: The London stock market showed a steadier tone yester day following the slump on Monday.

title: Mystery Man Is Honored
description: TUCSON, Ariz. (AP)An ob lisk has stood in a prominent spot aat Davis, Monthan Air Force Base near here, honoring Stanley L. Perry, since 1954. But no one has been able to come up with an explanation as to who Perry was or why he is so honored.

title: Dodger 73 Lead Rained Out
description: MONTREAL, April 21 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers Montreal Expos baseball game was postponed today because of rain. The Dodgers were holding a 73 lead in the third inning when the game was called.

title: Cardinal Says DecisionMaking Must Remain With the Bishops
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 John Cardinal Dearden, presi dent of the National Confer ence of Catholic Bishops, de clared today that despite the trend toward democratic proce dures within the Roman Cath olic Church, decisionmaking power must ultimately remain with bishons.

title: Australia Defeats Japan; Sweeps Davis Cup Series
description: TOKYO, April 21 (AP)Aus tralia won the two remaining singles matches today to sweep its Eastern Zone Section A Davis Cup final against Japan, 50, Australia now will meet India.

title: Senate Hearings Are Set On BankHolding Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (Reuters)Senator John Spark man said today the Senate Banking Committee would open hearings May 12 on a bill to regulate onebank holding com panies.

title: Medieval Furnace Found
description: HATTULA, Finland (UPI)A medieval brick furnace, believed to be the oldest in Finland, has been discovered in this com munity in southern Finland.

title: Cramer of Florida Will Stay in Republican Senate Race, Opposing Carswell
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Representative William C. Cramer said today that G. Harold Carswell's entry into the Florida Republican Sen ate primary had not changed his own intention of remain in in the race.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 22, 1970

title: SAMUEL G. MAY
description: Samuel G. May, vice presi dent of Samuel H. Moss, Inc., manufacturers of rubber stamps, died of a heart attack Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 420 East 51st Street.

title: Williams Opens Reelection Campaign in Jersey
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 21 Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a Democrat, appealed for a return to office today on the ground that the nation needs a Democratic Congress that will not rubberstamp token withdrawals while the war spills over into Laos and Cambodia.

title: Detroit Nurses Return to Job
description: DETROIT, April 21 (AP) Nurses at Detroit General and Herman Keifer hospitals re turned to their jobs today under threat of a Wayne County Cir cuit Court injunction that the city sought yesterday, contend ing the nurses' walkout was illegal.

title: Phelps Dodge Is Pessimistic on Peruvian Copper
description: George B. Munroe, president of the Phelps Dodge Corpora tion, told the company's an nual meeting here yesterday that the financing for a major Peruvian copper development has not been obtained and may prove difficult or even im possible.

title: Two College Heads Discuss Unrest
description: Yale University's president declared last night that the malaise, the disenchantment with life and its prospects, is greater now than a year ago among most American students on college and uni versity campuses.

title: F.T.C. CHALLENGES DRUG ADVERTISING
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The Federal Trade Commission is reaching for a new weapon against questionable advertis ing in accusing a drug manufac turer of illegally representing a sunburn remedy as a pain relieving anesthetic.

title: RUBBER WORKERS STRIKE GOODYEAR
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 21  A classified ad in The Akron Bea con Journal gave a clueto the hard times ahead: For sale, Buick Riviera, Goodrich worker who may have to strike.

title: CELLER WILL HEAD PANEL ON DOUGLAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Promising neither a whitewash nor a witchhunt, the House Judiciary Committee created today a subcommittee to study impeachment charges against Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

title: N.Y.U. Students Back Workers By Forcing Cafeterias to Close
description: Three cafeterias that had re mained open on New York University's Washington Square campus after last week's wild cat walkout by cafeteria work ers were closed last night after students disrupted their oper at ions, apparently to support the walkout.

title: Amusements Listed for Children in City
description: Films

title: Norwegian Official to Retire
description: OSLO, Norway, April 21  Foreign Minister John Lying, who will he 65 years old in August, today announced his retirement effective in the mid dle of May.

title: Austrian Cabinet Sworn In
description: VIENNA, April 21 (AP)The first allSocialist Government in postwar Austria was sworn in today by President Franz Jonas. The President had charged the Socialist leader, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, with form ing a minority cabinet after the failure of coalition talks with the conservative People's party, which had ruled Austria for four years.

title: 3,800 Discharged by Navy On Drug Charges Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)More than 3,800 Navy men have been discharged in the last year for illegally using or pushing drugs, but the prob lem is not centered in Vietnam as many persons believe.

title: Koch III With Hepatitis
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, April 21 (UPI)Thomas Koch, the No. 1 Brazilian tennis player, has been stricken with hepatitis and will be unable to compete in the Davis Cup Zone semifinals against Colombia, officials said today. The matches are scheduled for May 1 through May 3.

title: Guatemalan Guerrillas Killed
description: GUATEMALA, April 21Two members of the long inactive, MR13 guerrilla faction were killed in a clash with the police today in a fashionable residen tial area of this capital.

title: Marcel Marceau Mimes His Way Through Script of Just 26 Words
description: The alphabet begins with A for Awakening and drops off with Z as in zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz zzzz. From bright start to snoozy end, the newest al phabet book for children26 words of a sort for the 26 letters of traditiondiffers from all other alphabet books because Marcel Marceau, the French mime, acts out the words.

title: BRODY HELD IN WEST AT PSYCHIATRIC UNIT
description: BURLINGGAME, Calif., April 21 (AP)  Michael James Brody Jr., who offered last January to give away millions of dollars, is being held tem porarily at Belmont Hills Neu ropsychiatric Center, sheriff' deputy said today.

title: Term Given in Welfare Theft
description: Don W. Tuzo, who was con victed last month of fencing $12,000 in stolen welfare chechs was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to a nineyear prison term. Judge Marvin E. Frankel ordered him to begin his sen tence immediately instead of releasing him on bail. Assistant United States Attorney James T. B. Tripp, who tried the case, said that Tuzo, 30 years old, of 147 West 142d Street, had cashed hundreds of welfare checks, that were taken from hallway mail boxes.

title: Old Burial Ground Found
description: VERONA, Italy (AP) Arch eologists have found a 3,300 yearold burial ground they say marked the turning point from burial to cremation in the Bronze Age.

title: Couple Die in Plane Crash
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., April 21 Anthony G. Rubino, executive vice president of. Michael Con tracting Company, Inc., in Flushing, Queens, and his wife, Mary, were killed Sunday when their private plane crashed at Ramapo Airport, Clarkston, N.Y. Mr. Rubino, 51 years old, and his wife, 48, lived at 25 Phipps Lane. Mr. Rubino joined the Michael Constructing Company in 1951 and had been executive vice president for 10 years. Sur vivors include their daughter, Marie, and son, Anthony Jr.

title: Chiang's Son Cautions U.S. on Peking
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Deputy Premier Chiang Ching kuo of Nationalist China was reported today to have warned Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers that the Nixon Administration's gestures to improve relations with Commu nist China were not in the in terests of peace in Asia.

title: Murder Conviction Stands
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 20 (UPI)The Mississippi Supreme Court agreed today that an al leged Ku Klux Klansman must serve a life prison term for kill ing a Negro leader. The court let stand a guilty verdict re turned by a jury against Charles Wilson of Laurel in the 1966 death of Vernon Dahmer.

title: Strike Ends At Fordham; Poll Waited
description: After a dramatic series of orderly discussions, Fordham University students ended their weeklong strike yester day in the hope that a stu dentfaculty Council would be established to give them a significant voice in policy decisions on the Bronx cam pus.

title: UTILITY REPORTS RECORD EARNINGS
description: The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday new highs in earnings for March, the first quarter and the 12 months ended March 31.

title: Industrialist Robbed in Home
description: FLOSSMOOR, Ill., April 21 (AP)Harry O. Bercher, 60 yearold board chairman of the International Harvester Com pany, was hound and gagged by robbers who looted his home in this southern suburb of Chi cago yesterday.

title: Cosmic Outlaw...
description: A Marine company camped on a South Pacific island hilltop during World War II was startled by sounds of wailing and the mournful beating of drums using day and night from a tribal village in a valley below. After a few days, the valley fell silent. A passing patrol discovered that the village had been burned and abandoned because of an attack of crop pestilence and human disease. The survivors had moved on to build new homes in an unspoiled portion of the vast, thinly populated jungle.

title: Auto Clubs See Threat To Port Authority Tolls
description: The organized motorists of New York State and New Jersey wrote the Governors of both states yesterday op posing attempts to involve the Port of New York Au thority in mass transit.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: For Electoral College

title: Busy Advocate of Gains for Negroes
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Prof. James Samuel Cole man is so busy these days that the little things in life sometimes slip by unnoticed.

title: Dean Named President Of N.Y. Savings Banks
description: The Savings Banks Asso ciation of New York State announced yesterday that Ira O. Scott Jr., dean of the Arthur T. Roth Graduate School of Business Adminis tration at Long Island Uni versity, had been named ex ecutive president of the trade group. Dean Scott, whose appointment is effective June 8, will succeed Austin S. Murphy, who resigned last January 1 to become presi dent of the East River Sav ings Bank.

title: U.S. JUDGE WEIGHS BROWN TRIAL BID
description: BALTIMORE, April 21  A Federal judge took temporary charge of trial proceedings against H. Rap Brow today after counsel for the missing black militant said that their client was afraid to come to Maryland because the state was unable to assure him safety and was about to stage his trial to a predominantly white county.

title: War Victim Gets Citizenship
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) Andre L. Knoppert, born in the Netherlands, became an American citizen today, but he will never vote or exercise his other rights of citizenship. Lance Corporal Knoppert, a marine, died in 1969 at the age of 21 when he stepped on an enemy land mine near the vil lage of Danang in Vietnam. Citizenship came posthumously under legislation introduced by Senator Frank E. Moss of Utah.

title: Church Dignitaries Attend Rites for Patriarch Alexis
description: MOSCOW, April 21 (Reuters)  Patriarch Alexis of Moscow and All Russia, head of the Russian Orthodox Church in the Soviet Union for 25 years, was buried near here today after a fivehour funeral service.

title: 4Year Term for Governor Gains in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 21 The New Hampshire House of Representatives today ap proved fouryear terms for the state's Governors, thus vir tually assuring that the pro posed constitutional amend ment will be voted on by the people.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, April 22, 1970

title: Accardo Is Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Anthony J. Accardo, a re puted Mafia chieftain in Chi cago, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of unlawful possession of fire arms. If convicted, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment and a $10,000 fine on each of two counts.

title: GUSTAVE G. KEIN JR.
description: UNION, N. J., April 21 Gustave G. Kein Jr., attorney for Union Township since 1946 and a Republican leader here for many years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 504 Twin Oaks Road.

title: Loss in Operations Is Listed by MGM
description: MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., reported yesterday an operat ing loss for the first 28 weeks of its current fiscal year but a consolidated profit after in cluding an extraordinary gain of $6,531,000.

title: EXIMBANK REVISES INSURING PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The ExportImport Bank and the privately sponsored For eign Credit Insurance Associa tion announced today major changes and expansion of the program of export insurance, with the aim of nearly tripling the volume of insurance issued in the next year.

title: Lawn Statue Is Potpourri
description: SARASOTA, Fla. (AP)The peculiar statue in front of the Teo Zacchini home here to hold up the mail box is de signed from broken and dis carded machine pieces welded together.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
Plan Hailed in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21President Nixon's decision to phase the next stage of Unit ed States troop withdrawals over a 12month period won a warm reception among senior American officers here today.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: Change in Priorities Urged
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., April 20 (AP) Before environmental pollution can be effectively fought, America must reorder its priorities by cutting military spending and foreign aid, Sen ator Joseph D. Tydings, Demo crat of Maryland, told a Uni versity of Missouri audience today.

title: Florida Bids for Convention
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) A campaign to hold the Re publican National Convention in Miami Beach again in 1972 was started today by Represen tative William C. Cramer, Re publican of Florida. He said that the success of the 1968 convention plus the fact that President Nixon had a home in nearby Key Biscayne weighed heavily in Miami Beach's favor.

title: SILVER FUTURES DIP IN A BUSY DAY
description: Silver futures prices slipped yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange although the high obtained at the Gov ernment's weekly auction of the metal in Washington was slightly above that of the week before.

title: In London, Too, Lenin Is Remembered
description: LONDON, April 21  The whitehaired men with canes moved slowly into the stone house on Clerkenwell Green this afternoon and crowded the library.

title: 7 CONCERNS CITED OVER POLLUTION
description: Criminal informations against seven corporations, including the Long Island Lighting Com pany and Mobil Oil for alleged violation of Federal antipollu tion laws were filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: New Play by Neil Simon Shifts Into Serious Vein
description: Neil Simon, Broadway's prime provider of humor, is turning serious. He has writ ten a new play, It Only Hurts When I Laugh, which is essentially tragic in con tent.

title: L. K. Shapiro, Co.Founder Of Harness Racing on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) L. K. Shapiro, one of the founders of Western Harness Racing, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Carpenters Back Governor
description: BUFFALO, April 211 (AP) The 80,000  member State Council of Carpenters, A.F.L. C.I.O., has endorsed Governor Rockefeller for reelection, it was announced today. Herman F. Bodewes, a member of the council's executive committee, said that 350 delegates chose to back the Governor, a Repub lican, at the council's annual convention last week at Kiame sha Lake. Edward J. Bjork, council president, lauded Mr. Rockefeller's state building program.

title: Mobuto Restricts Election
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, April 20 (Agence FrancePresse)  A decree signed here today, by President Joseph D. Mobutu stipulated only the ruling Peo pie's Revolutionary Movement could enter a candidate in the presidential election scheduled for next November.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series).

title: Musicians' Strike Cancels City Ballet
description: After nearly eight months of fruitless labor talks, mem bers of the New York City Ballet's orchestra went on strike yesterday, causing cancellation of last night's opening of the company's spring season at the New York State Theater.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Plan to Treat Addicts Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)  Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat Of Queens, asked Secretary of De fense Melvin R. Laird today to study the feasibility of using surplus military ships as treat ment centers for drug addicts. Mr. Addabbo said that the idea had been proposed by the In stitute for the Advancement of Criminal Justice, headed by Queens District Attorney Thom as J. Mackell.

title: Daley in Office 15 Years
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) Mayor Richard J. Daley, 67 years old, who has served as chief executive of Chicago longer than any other man, be gan his 16th year in office today.

title: Tax Office Studies Contents of N.E.T. Programs
description: An agent of the Internal Revenue Service has been spend ing hours in the screening room of National Educational Television at 10 Columbus Circle to determine whether any of the group's noncommer cial TV programs in 1969 ad vocated legislation that might involve taxexempt problems.

title: HIGH COURT RULES ON MERGER COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that corporations and their stockholders May not write off as business expenses some of the costs of reorganiza tion, including some incurred in corporate merger proceedings.

title: Brezhnev, Honoring Lenin, Urges Reform and Unity
description: MOSCOW, April 21Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, marking the 100th anniversary of Lenin's birth tomorrow, called anew today for renovation of the Soviet economy and for unity in the Communist world.

title: Summary of Measures Passed and Killed by Albany Legislature During '70 Session
description: ALBANY, April 21Follow ing are the major actions taken by the Legislature during the regular 1970 session that ended last night:

title: PENN STATE SITIN ENDS IN 4 ARRESTS
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 21 (UPI)  About 50 student ended a brief sitin at the main administration build ing of Pennsylvania State University today after state troopers were called to the campus for the second time in a week.

title: Fordham, Manhattan Tie As Darkness Halts Contest
description: Fordham and Manhattan played to a 11 tie yesterday in a baseball game at Jack Coffey Field. The game was called after nine innings be cause of darkness.

title: Symphony Ball to Benefit Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: Governor and Mrs. Rocke feller will serve as honorary sponsors of the 16th an niversary Symphony Ball of the Brooklyn Philharmonia on Saturday, May 2, in the Grand Ballroom of Del monico's Hotel.

title: PAL Names Head of Drive
description: Mortimor S. Gordon, presi dent and director of Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., has been named chairman of the Police Athletic League's 1970 fundraising campaign. The league, which has provided rec reational services to the city's deprived areas, for more than 50 years, is seeking to raise $1.1 million, with $750,000 from pri vate donations and the balance from governmental agencies.

title: New Yorker Chooses Different Ad Agency
description: The New Yorker, which has been suffering advertis ing page losses, is going to a different agencyLord, Gel ler. Federico and Partners.

title: Baggage Delivered to Hotel On Pan Am San Juan Flights
description: A new service for air travel ers to San Juan, P.R., that guarantees baggage delivery direct to hotels has been an nounced by Pan American World Airways.

title: Mediator for School Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (UPI) Striking teachers agreed with the school board today to call in a Federal mediator, but the union vowed to continue the walkout until a contract was signed. Donald Baer, executive director of the United Teachers of Los Angeles, said that the Board of Education's decision to call in a mediator had been taken because our strike was so effective.

title: Roundup: Cubs' Homers Beat Gibson
description: It was a normal Bob Gib son game, said Billy Wil liams, the Chicago Cubs' outfielder from Whistler, Ala. He was throwing good in the first inning and all the way to the seventh. Then he made a couple of bad pitches and walked Don Kessinger, Glenn Beckert hit one and he grooved one to me.

title: Murder of Stepson
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 (UPI) Ronald Fouquet was found guilty of first degree murder today in the death of his 5year old stepson. The boy was said by his mother to have died after Fouquet jumped up and down on him as the boy lay on the floor. A jury will decide if the death penalty demanded by the state should be imposed.

title: F.A.A. MEETS SNAG ON PENALTY DRIVE
description: The Government has run into legal stumbling blocks in its efforts to suspend or dismiss air traffic controllers who re cently refused to work, claim ing illness.

title: Market Place
description: YES, Virginia, there is a bullmarket Santa Claus. Practically every broker in Wall Street will show red at the first sight of an uptick. But what about the bears? Have they given up? Do they see a land of milk and honey in the months ahead for those who are looking for higher stock prices?

title: Hanoi Party Chief Sees AntiU. S. Front
description: MOSCOW, April 21  Le Duan, First Secretary of the North Vietnamese Communist party, said here today that the people of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia would unify their ef forts against American im perialists.

title: Holland's Aide Is Selected
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Merrill Winslett, administra tive assistant to Senator Spes sard L. Holland, Democrat of Florida, has been selected as secretaryoftheyear on Capitol Hill. The award is given annu ally by the Capitol Hill weekly newspaper, Roll Call.

title: Boland Asks Faster Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Representative Edward P. Bo land of Massachusetts, a senior Democrat on the House Appro priations Committee, introduced a resolution today calling on the Administration to acceler ate troop withdrawals so that no American combat forces would remain in Vietnam a year from now. The Boland resolu tion, introduced before President Nixon's speech on Vietnam, would also express the sense of Congress that United States military activities in countries bordering Vietnam should be restricted to those necessary to shield American troops in Vietnam against enemy infil tration.

title: Student Is Beaten
description: STORRS, Conn., April 21 (UPI)  An investigation into the alleged beating of a Uni versity of Connecticut dormi tory president by black stu dents over a comment made about Mr. Seale was under way today.

title: MAYE GETS 4 HITS AS SENATORS WIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Lee Maye, the singer, has a re cording of Fools Rush In waiting to be released. But most of the rushing tonight was done by a 35yearold out fielder named Lee Maye.

title: PRIESTS CALL OFF A PROTEST MEETING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 The National Federation o Priests' Councils announced Monday that it had called off a meeting scheduled for May 3 to discuss the situation of 19 Washington priests disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle in 1968 in a dispute over the papal encyclical banning artifical con traception.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1970

title: Times Square Getting 2 Film Houses
description: Two new theaters will join the growing number of firstrun film showcases in the Times Square area in the fall. Con struction has begun on twin, sidebyside houses, one seating 299 people, the other 269, on Seventh Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets.

title: In Memoriam
description: TRETTTheodora R., Happy Birthday Teddy dear in Heaven. You are always in our thoughts.

title: Governor Orders Study on Bridge Over L.I. Sound
description: Governor Rockefeller or dered a state agency yesterday to stop preliminary work on the proposed bridge over Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay while a compre hensive study was made of transportation needs over the Sound.

title: MIG Downed, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM, April 21Is rael today reported downing the 55th Egyptian MIG since the 1967 war during the second raid since the weekend against Israeli positions in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: JERSEY STANDARD STEADY ON PROFIT
description: Firstquarter net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was reported yes terday at $325million, or $1.50 a share on 223.6 million shares, matching the yearearlier rec ord of $325million, or $1.51 a share, on 215 million shares.

title: Never Underestimate the Power of Menat Women's Colleges
description: STEVEN AXELROD, a col lege sophomore who looks as calculating as a choirboy, insists he had no intention of fomenting revolution in Sara toga Springs, N. Y. But the orange juice incident he precipitated taught the girls of Skidmore College a lesson in political action. It also in dicated to doubting parents, trustees and administrators what the effect of coeduca tion on a traditionally female college is likely to be.

title: Fugitives Arrested
description: The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, a Roman Catholic priest in the antiwar movement, was ar rested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yester day in the rectory of a church on West 90th Street.

title: Two Guatemalan Guerrillas Die in Fight Near Embassy
description: GUATEMALA, April 21 (AP) Two men identified as guer rillas were killed today in a battle with security forces near the Brazilian Embassy. It was not known whether the guer rillas were planning to kidnap a member of the embassy staff.

title: Schoolboy Star Honored
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Tom McMillen, one of the most soughtafter highschool basketball players in the coun try, received the National ScholarAthlete Award today at a meeting of the National Con ference of State High School Coaches Associations.

title: Czech Tradition Lures Expo Crowd
description: OSAKA, Japan To say that things are quiet at Expo '70 as the big fair enters its second month would not be entirely accurate, since the noise and the crowds are as great as ever. But Expo has settled down to routine oper ation for its increasing mil lions of visitors and the settl ing provides an opportunity for a less distracted look at the place.

title: ALIOTO LIBEL TRIAL MISSING A WITNESS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 The man who wasn't there tes tified for about two hours as the first witness today in May or Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5mil lion libel action against Look Magazine.

title: A.N.P.A. Head Urges Curb on Labor
description: The head of the nation's newspaper publishers called yesterday for new Federal and state legislation to correct what he described as an im balance in favor of labor that was rapidly becoming a threat to the wellbeing of the na tion.

title: Japan Banks Lift Rates
description: TOKYO, April 21 (Reuters) The directors of the National Bankers Association said they would raise the rates of inter est charged by Japanese com mercial banks on discounts and shortterm loans for exporters, effective May 15.

title: Strike Rally at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21  A black assistant professor of philosophy called upon an assembly of 4,500 people to night to close down Yale University in the morning to support the 14 Black Panthers who are awaiting trial here on charges of murder and kid napping.

title: Aussie Cup Yacht Troubled by Rigging
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 21 With only six weeks before Gretel II, Australia's potential challenger for the America's cup, leaves Sydney for New R. I., her designer, Alan Payne, is still searching for a sail and rigging combination that will allow her to give her best per formance.

title: I.B.M. Challenges Xerox in Copier Field
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the computer industry giant, an nounced yesterday its long anticipated entry into the office copier field. The Xerox Corporation, the behemoth of the copying industry, imme diately filed a patentinfringe ment suit against I.B.M.

title: Army Rifle Supplier Lags Despite Premium Contract
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) A supplier of M16 rifles re mains far behind schedule two years after the army cited ability to meet an accelerated delivery timetable as justifica tion for paying the supplier premium prices for the rapid firing weapons.

title: The Elephant's Jawbone
description: Personal freedom, President Nixon observed in his Economic, Report last winter, will be in creased when there is more economy in Government and less Government in the economy. domina tion like any other Government dom Analysis ination, is danger ous to a free society, no matter how benevolent its aims. With this passage, the Preident un derlined what is perhaps his deepest disagreement in eco nomic philosophy with his predecessor.

title: Productive Session
description: The highly partisan, terribly hectic, electionyear session of the New York State Legislature which just ended turned out, nonetheless, to be a distinctly pro ductive one. Governor Rockefeller's leadership proved firm and, especially at the end, progressive.

title: CORPORATE BONDS PICK UP SPARKLE
description: The quick sale of a large new offering yesterday helped the sagging corporate bond market regain its equilibrium. However, the market for tax exempts continued to skid as investors showed considerably less enthusiasm for three siza ble new issues.

title: Alleged Mafia Triggerman Shot To Death on a Street in Brooklyn
description: Gaspare Magaddino, an al leged Mafia triggerman sought by the local and international police in connection with mur ders and bombings here and in Sicily, was found slain on a Brooklyn sidewalk early yester day.

title: Eastland Doubts Passage Of a New Electoral Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Senator James O. East land, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that he did not think the Senate would approve any constitutional amendment reforming the Presidential election system this year.

title: Prices Drop as Volume Grows On American Stock Exchange
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yes terday in light trading after selling pressure erased an early advance.

title: ... in an Urban Wasteland?
description: Probably the most potent and certainly the most poignant of the nation's Earth Day observances today will be those in New York City, a megalopolis where this technological era has reached the heights of triumph and tragedy.

title: City Will Study Imposing East River Bridge Tolls
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a preliminary study of the feasibility of charging tolls on the city's four East River bridges into Manhattan.

title: Thai Troops Reported Sent To Border With Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 21 (UPI) Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today tha Thai ttropps had been sent to the border with Cambodia as a security precaution.

title: JERSEY GENERAL IS FACING INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, April 21The state is investigating the pos sible misuse of funds by the retiring chief of staff of the New Jersey Department of Defense, according to State Senator James H. Wallwork.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 21, 1970

title: Royals Trade Robertson to Bucks for Robinson and Paulk, Rookie in Army
description: MILWAUKEE, April 21 (UPI) Oscar Robertson of the Cin cinnati Royals was traded to day to the Milwaukee Bucks, where he'll join another basket ball superstar  Lew Alcindor in the lineup.

title: Sports Car Racing Encourages Women to Participate Actively
description: MONTEREY, Calif., April 20 One of the distinguish ing characteristics of sports car racing is thatvive la diffrencelwomen are en couraged to participate. At USAC and NASCAR races women are not even per mitted in the pits. But in sportscar racing birds may drive and some are mechan ics. Many women join pit crews to keep score. Most of them are ama teurs lending a hand, but the top teams need professionals. Judy Stropus of Plandome, L. I., is one of the latter. Here at Laguna Seca Raceway yes terday she began her fourth year as a professional timer and scorer. The tall, person able brunette is working this season for Roger Penske's SunocoJavelin team in the 13 race TransAmerican Cham pionship of the Sports Car Club of America.

title: NIXON DRAFT PLAN EXPECTED TO CURB JOB DEFERMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 President Nixon is expected to announce tomorrow or Thursday the elimination of most, if not all, future occupa tional deferments from the military draft.

title: Carlyle B. Bodman Affianced To James Calvin Hughes Jr.
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., April 21The engagement of Miss Carlyle Berdan Bodman to James Calvin Hughes Jr. has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Luther Bodman Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Hughes of WinstonSalem.

title: Albany Bill on Garelik Hazy to Council Sponsor
description: A cosponsor of a City Council homerule message in volving Sanford D. Garelik's pension said yesterday that he had been unaware that the bill later passed in Albany, gave Mr. Garelik a $24,000 annual police pension in addition to his $40,000 salary as Council President.

title: BIG BOARD STOCKS CONTINUE TO SLIP
description: I.B.M. and Xerox, two of Wall Street's favorite growth stocks, tilted lances yester dayand both of them lost ground.

title: 15 MEDALS OF HONOR GIVEN TO SURVIVORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) In a White House ceremony today, Vice President Agnew presented the Medal of Honor to wives and parents of 13 Ma rines and two sailors who were killed while winning the na tion's highest decoration in Vietnam.

title: Bridge
description: FEW players are on record as having successfully de fended a major regional team championship. This rare feat was performed at the Florida Regionals last week by Hal Fein of Eastchester, N. Y., Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Has tingsonHudson, N. Y., and Dan Morse of Houston. They headed a field of 132 teams in the Swiss team champion ship, played in Miami Beach. William August of Spring field, Mass., who did not compete last year, was the fourth player.

title: Earth Day Traffic Effect
description: Following are the effects of the observance of Earth Day on major facilities here today:

title: Korean Violinist to Play For Israel Philharmonic
description: A 21yearold Korean violin ist, Miss Kyungwha Chung, who is a graduate of the Juil hard School here, has been asked to replace an ailing Nathan Milstein, 66, for 12 concerts with the Israel Phil harmonic.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Chicago

title: PACIFIC TO SEEK DREW CHEMICAL
description: The Pacific Vegetable Oil Corporation announced yester day that it planned to make a cash offer for the assets of the Drew Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Slick Corpo ration. Drew Chemical had slaes of more than $70million in the last fiscal year.

title: INTEGRATION HELD KEY AID TO PUPILS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 A noted sociologist testified to day that racially integrated schooling aided ghetto pupils while costly compensatory edu cation programs in ghetto schools did not.

title: ANNUAL MEETING OF TIMES IS QUIET
description: The New York Times Com pany held a quiet annual meet ing yesterday with only three of the approximately 250 stockholders present at Town Hall asking questions of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher, and other executives.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: The President and the Generals
description: In announcing the with drawal of another 150,000 American troops from Vietnam within the next twelve months, President Nixon said this far reaching decision was made after consultation with our commanders in the field and it has the approval of the Government of South Vietnam.

title: L.I.U.'s SevenRun Second Turns Back Hofstra, 87
description: A threerun homer by Ruben Ramirez sparked a sevenrun secondinning yesterday as Long Island University topped Hofstra University, 87, in a Metropolitan Conference game at the winner's field in Brook lyn.

title: Browns Sign Columbia Star
description: CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) The Cleveland Browns signed Bill Wazevich, who gained all Ivy League honors at Columbia as a wide receiver, today. In three seasons at Columbia, Wa zevich caught 102 passes for 1,333 yards.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Dance: Royal Troupe
TRADE BLOC AGREES ON FREE WINE TRADE
description: LUXEMBOURG, Wednesday, April 21, (UPI)Common Mar ket ministers agreed this morn ing on free trade in wine, thus clearing the way for starting talks on British membership next summer.

title: Rams Trade Lundy; Meador Retires
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP)Two aging defensive stars left the Los Angeles Rams today.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP] The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: NEGROES BOYCOTT SYRACUSE DRILLS
description: SYRACUSE, April 21The 10 black athletes on the Syracuse University football team con tinued a boycott of spring prac tice today as Coach Ben Schwartzwalder directed the first workout since Saturday.

title: Two States Ask Court to Delay Nerve Gas Shipment
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 21 The Governors of Oregon and Washington sought an injunc tion today in United States Dis trict Court to delay the pro posed shipment of nerve gas from Okinawa to the Umatilla Army Depot in eastern Oregon.

title: Ancient Cemetery Found
description: VERONA, Italy (AP)Ar chaeologists have found a 3,300yearold burial ground that they say marked the turn ing point from burial to crema tion in the Bronze Age.

title: Mitchell's Press Aide Quitting; Parting Described as Amicable
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Attorney General John N. Mitchell is looking for a new press secretary.

title: Hickel Pledges Federal Efforts To Clean Up Lakes and Rivers
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Secretary of the Interior Wal ter J. nickel said today that the Nixon Administration was committed to a policy of pro hibiting further deterioration of the country's water supplies.

title: Padres Get Together and Overcome Mets After Overcoming a Bit of Loose Work Afield,
description: The Mets, who spent the win ter dividing the loot, continued their generosity well into the spring yesterday when they treated the San Diego Padres to a baseball game before 7,712 frozen fans in Shea Stadium.

title: Fanny May Results for the Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Threemonth and sixmonth mortgage purchase commitment prices rose again at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association disclosed yesterday.

title: Fight at Forum Postponed Because of Knicks Playoffs
description: The lightheavyweight fight between Ray Anderson and Charlie (Devil) Green scheduled for Friday night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum was postponed yesterday until next Tuesday night because of the New York Knickerbockers basketball playoffs with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: GOLDBERG AGREES TO THREE DEBATES
description: Arthur J. Goldberg agreed last night to an hourlong tele vised debate tomorrow night with his two opponents for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Howard J. Samuels and Robert M. Morgenthau.

title: Big Board Is Facing Antitrust Pressure
description: The Justice Department has stepped up its pressure to bring the New York Stock Exchange under the purview of the Fed eral antitrust laws.

title: New Zealand Plans No Cut In Its Vietnam Force Now
description: WELLINGTON, New Zea and, April 21 (AP) New Zea and will not emulate the Unit ed States and reduce its mili tary force in Vietnam now, Prime Minister Keith J. Holy pake said today.

title: Prospering Taiwan Is Beset by Internal Discontent and External Uncertainty
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 21 Nationalist China, whose very right to exist is questioned by much of the world community, manages to live on, even to prosper, despite the tortuous uncertainties of its internation al position and nagging dis content within its body politic.

title: Books of The Times
description: ONE approaches this paperback teachin much as if it were Sunday afternoon with a dogoading maiden aunt. Who can deny her, yet who can take her seri ously? After all, no one on the face of this increasingly scorched earthnot even Con Edison or General Motorswould deny that there are too many people using up too much too quickly, and that we all must do something quickly, But what's to do? As Charles Galton Darwin pointed out on the centennial of the publication of his grandfather's great book: those of us who voluntarily limit the size of our families are hi the long run simply weeding our selves out in favor those who produce large families. As for consuming less power: if I throw out my water pick and go back to dental floss (as one piece in this book recommends), will you? Will Mao Tsetung?

title: COLOMBIA IMPOSES A STATE OF SIEGE
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 President Carlos Lleras Res trepo decreed a state of siege and martial law tonight in Co lombia.

title: MUTUAL FUND BILL IS MADE STRICTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The House Commerce subcom mittee that is considering leg slation covering the mutual fund industry swung back sharply today toward the more, restrictive measure passed by the Senate last year.

title: Executive Changes
description: Walter F. Lineberger Jr. has been elected the new post of chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Society Corporation, Cleve landbased multibank holding company.

title: Phone Craftsmen Return To Jobs After 5Day Strike
description: A fiveday walkout in a dis pute over the safety of per sonnel ended yesterday when 16,000 telephone craftsman re turned to their jobs in the plant department of the new York Telephone Company.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engaaemants may be tele phoned to Oxford 53311 until 11 P.M. In suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark (801) Market 33900; White Plains (914) White Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) Ivanhoe 36660; Commack (516) 5455400; Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: A Century of Lenin
description: Lenin played too vital a role in shaping the twen tieth century for today's centennial of his birth to be of interest only to his ideological admirers.

title: ALL AHEAD VICTOR IN JERSEY SPRINT
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 21 (UPI)All Ahead held off the favored Imbibe in the early go ing and drew away from the field in the stretch today to win the $12,000 allowance purse at Garden State. The 4yearold filly was a badly beaten eighth in her last start.

title: Esposito Gets Hickok Award
description: Tony Esposito, the ace goalie of the Chicago Black Hawks, was named winner yesterday of the March award in the S. Rae Hickok pro athlete of the year poll. Esposito had 25 first place votes and 105 points to beat Lew Alcindor of the Mil waukee Bucks, with 15 first places and 87 points, and Bobby Orr of the Boston Bruins, with 13 first places, and 69 points.

title: BRUINS SCORE, 41, LEAD SERIES, 20
description: CHICAGO, April 21 (UPI)  Phil Esposito stole the puck and beat his brother Tony for an unassisted goal tonight to wrap up the scoring for the Boston Bruins in a 41 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks. The victory gave the Bruins a 20 edge in their fourofseven Stanley Cup semifinal hockey playoff series.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 12 Heroin Deaths Reported in City In Last Five Days
description: The City Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday that 12 persons had died from acute reactions to heroin or from direct complications from heroin addiction from Friday to yester day. One was a teenager.

title: LOSS IS RECORDED BY PENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Company's financial position worsened in the first quarter of this year.

title: MUTUAL FUND BILL SET BY HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The House Commerce subcom mittee reached agreement today on legislation Increasing the Government's authority to reg ulate the charges imposed on investors by mutual funds. But the agreement was only tenta tive and subject to reversal at the subcommittee's next meet ing on Tuesday.

title: A Young American in Paris Who Cooks to His Heart's Content
description: PARISIf you see a young man swinging a knap sack full of pots and pans and cutlery along the banks of the Seine, it may well be an American named William Rice en route to a cooking session in the home of a friend or friends.

title: G.M. IS CRITICIZED ON BOARD PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The Campaign to make G.M. Responsible charged Tues day that the General Motors Corporation had spent more than $500,000 to defeat pro posals to put representatives of consumers and conservation interests on its board of direc tors and to make other changes in its operations.

title: Today's WellDressed Bishop Dispenses With Frills at the Expense of the Salesman Who Serves Him
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 It costs a lot less to become a monsignor or a Bishop these days, said Kevin Quinn. The trend is definitely toward sim plicity.

title: Attendance at Yale Is Cut 50% to 75% by Pickets Supporting Black Panthers
description: NEW HAVEN, April 22  Picket lines were set up around most undergraduate classroom buildings at Yale University this morning as students be gan a strike in support of Black Panthers who are await ing trial here on charges of murder and kidnapping.

title: Naito Holds Austin to Draw
description: TOKYO, April 22 (AP)Cas sius Naito, Japan's middle weight boxing champion, bat tled Charlie Austin of Phoenix, Ariz., to a draw in a 10round bout tonight. Naito, a son of United States Army Negro sergeant killed in the Korean War, weighed 161 pounds and Austin 160.

title: Miami Airport Sets Mark
description: MIAMI (UPI)Miami's Inter national Airport served 10,562, 1768 passengers in 1969, passing the 10 million mark for the first time.

title: Beame Assails Idea Of Imposing Tolls On 4 More Bridges
description: The Lindsay administration's study of possible tolls on East River bridges drew a protest from Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday, who said such charges would be an undue burden upon the motor ist.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
Living Costs Up 0.7% in the City Area
description: Living costs for New York area consumers rose 0.7 per cent in March, the regional director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, Herbert Bienstock, announced yesterday.

title: VICTOR WAY, 59, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 22  Victor Olgyay, an architec tural pioneer at integrating buildings into their environ ments, died at his home here today after a brief illness. He, was 59 years old and an asso ciate professor of architecture and urban planning at Prince ton University.

title: Court Dismisses Libel Suit Against 2 Newspapermen
description: A libel suit brought by two lawenforcement officers against two newspaper editors of the now defunct New York JournalAmerican over articles in the newspaper concerning an alleged shakedown has been dismissed.

title: POLLS SHOW GAIN FOR LABOR PARTY
description: LONDON, April 22  A dra matic turn in the publicopin ion polls today gave Prime Minister Wilson and the La bor party hope of victory at an early general election.

title: The Day the City Caught Its Breath
description: There was a rare interlude during Earth Day yesterday when it was perfectly possi ble for a man to sit spang in the center of Fifth Avenue and not be hit by a hack.

title: Earth's Day, Like Mother's, Pulls Capital Together
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Conservatives were for it. Lib erals were for it. Democrats, Republicans and independents were for it. So were the ins, the outs, the Executive and legislative branches of Govern ment.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: As a recent candidate for the Senatorial nomination of my party, I can persuasively testify that the high cost of political campaigns has become a prob lem of immense proportion.

title: State Bill Widens Rights of Newsmen
description: In the lastminute push for adjournment, the Legislature gave final approval this week to a bill exempting newsmen from contempt proceedings for failing to disclose any news or the source of any such news.

title: Public Found to Take Hard View On Bombings, Hijackings, Riots
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 22 The United States public is in no mood, according to the Gallup Poll, to be lenient with persons who commit three types of crimes that are prod ucts of modernday America: terror bombings, hijacking and inciting riots.

title: France Relaxing the Austerity That Began With Devaluation
description: PARIS, April 22Eight months after the devaluation the franc, the French Government announced today it has repaid all its shortterm debts to central banks and is beginning to relax its austerity program.

title: Savings Banks Post Filled
description: The Savings Banks Associa tion of New York State has an nounced that Ira O. Scott Jr., dean of the Arthur T. Roth Graduate School of Business Administration at Long Island University, has been named ex ecutive vice president of the trade group. Dean Scott, whose appointment is effective June 8, will succeed Austin S. Murphy, who resigned last Jan. 1 to be come president of the East River Savings Bank.

title: Union Carbide Faces Student Disruption
description: A group of about 20 stu dents made an unsuccessful at tempt to disrupt the annual meeting of the Union Carbide Corporation here yesterday in the Hunter College Auditorium.

title: Seaver Strikes Out 19, Including Record 10 in a Row, as Mets Beat Padres, 21
description: Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets to a 21 victory over the San Diego Padres yesterday and pitched himself into the baseball records by striking out 19 batters10 in a row.

title: South African Voting Is Heavy As Whites Elect a Parliament
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 22 (Reuters)White South Africans voted heavily today in a general election that could force the Government of Premier John Vorster further to the right.

title: Dope Is Church Play
description: Dope, a oneact play by Maryat Lee, will be presented by the Art Players of the Ad diction Research and Treatment; Corporation at St. Luke's Lu theran Church. 259 Washing ton Avenue, Brooklyn, tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30. Mark Walters has staged the play.

title: Air Taxi Crash Laid to Beacon Loss
description: The story of a strange odys sey through the sky, in which almost everything seemed to go wrong, was unfolded yesterday at a National Transportation Safety Board hearing near Ken nedy International Airport.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 22, 1970

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Wringing Wet Dry Season
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica Eight large birds, the pilot said they were parrots, rose from the jungle beneath us, and we altered course to avoid coming close to them.

title: Stratagems In Suburbs
description: Like the city dwellers, more and more residents of the suburbs are turning to ingenious stratagems and new devices to protect their furs, jewelry, silverware and tele vision sets from theft.

title: Music: Houston Visitors
description: ST. JOHN'S UNIVERSITY has been celebrating its centenary with a series of concerts, among other things. Last night in Philharmonic Hall, St. John's presented the sixth and last of its series, sponsoring the Houston Sym phony Orchestra under Hans Schwieger. Soloist on the program was the young Ko rean violinist Young Uck Kim, playing the Bruch G. minor Concerto. Mr. Schwie ger, in addition, conducted the Death and Transfigura tion of Strauss and the New York premiere of the Shos takovich 12th Symphony.

title: British Set Hereford Mark
description: LONDON  Hereford cattle, which provide about half of the beef eaten in England and Wales, have achieved an export record, with more than 00 pedigreed animals shipped abroad to 10 countries in 15 months ending with Jan. 1.

title: Culver Plans to Open An Academy for Girls
description: CULVER, Ind., April 22 (AP)Culver Military Acad emy announced today that it will end a 77year policy by becoming coeducational in September, 1971.

title: Mohawk to Suspend Run
description: Mohawk Airlines announced yesterday that it would tempo rarily suspend all flight opera tions at Westchester County Airport from May 4 through June 23. The suspension will coincide with the county's plans to resurface the airport's main runway.

title: 6 Children and Father Die In Fire in Camden Home
description: CAMDEN, N. J., April 22  Six children and their father died today in an early morning fire that swept through their twostory brick house at 45 South 28th Street here.

title: Pierre Dux, Actor, Is Named to Head Comedie Francaise
description: PARIS, April 22Pierre Dux, a veteran actor who headed the police force of the authorita rian junta in the movie Z, was named today to head France's most prestigious the atrical institution, the Comdie Franaise.

title: GOVERNOR NAMES 4 M.T.A. MEMBERS
description: ALBANY, April 22  Gover nor Rockefeller forwarded to the State Senate for confirma tion oday the names of four new members of the Metropol itan Transportation Authority.

title: In The Nation: An Old Question in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 22 When Puerto Ricans voted in 1967 by 60 to 39 per cent for commonwealth status rather than American statehood, with only one per cent choosing in dependence, the issue seemed Pretty well settled. Now it has been reopened with a bang by President Nixon's appointment, at the urging of Gov. Luis Ferre, of a committee to study the possibility of giving Puerto Ricans the vote in Presidential elections.

title: Rubber Strike Continues
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 22 (AP) A strike against the Good year Tire & Rubber Company, the nation's largest rubber pro ducer, continued through its second day today with no signs of progress toward a settle ment. The strike has idled about 23,000 workers at 15 Goodyear plants in 12 states.

title: MAFIOSO'S ACREAGE IS SEIZED IN JERSEY
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., April 22  The Internal Revenue Serv ice in Newark seized 17.62 acres of land this morning from Ruggerio (Richie the Boot) Boi ardo, the 80yearold reputed Mafia chieftain.

title: Naskra and Corn Off The Cob Head Blue Grass Stakes Field Today
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22  The Blue Grass Stakes, generally accepted as a cri terion for the Kentucky Derby over the last several years, will offer an even greater influence on the 3yearold championship field tomorrow, when it has its 46th running.

title: BACKERS OF ROJAS THREATEN REVOLT
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 22 As the Colombian Army en forced calm in the country to day, leaders of the movement trying to return Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, the former dicta tor, to power, insisted that they were ready to provoke civil war in the general's cause.

title: TV: The Campaign for an Unspoiled Environment
description: EARTH DAY dominated much of television yes terday and covered almost every aspect of mankind's health and environmentpol lution from automobile ex haust, litter on the highways and streets, smog, venereal disease, the fouling of rivers with industrial waste and the ruination of homes and pas turelands by avaricious strip coal miners.

title: Knickerbocker Hospital Dance to Honor Physician
description: When some 500 of New York's political, social and community leaders get to gether for a $100aperson dinner dance, there is usually an excuse; and if there's one thing next Tuesday's party at the Plaza doesn't lack it's excuses.

title: PARKER K. JAMES, 60, DISPLAYS EXECUTIVE
description: Parker Kent James, president of Standard Outdoor Advertis ing, Inc., a subsidiary of John Donnelly & Sons, died Tues day of a heart attack in his office at 270 Park Avenue. He was 60 years old and lived at 3337 70th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Aide to Hruska Is Robbed
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) An aide to Senator Roman L. Hruska, Republican of Nebras ka, and the aide's mother were robbed Monday night by a man who threatened them with knife, according to the police. The aide was identified as David Wherry, 26 years old, grandson of the late Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican of Nebraska.

title: Screen: Haunting Indecisions of 'Brotherly Love'
description: "MUMMY," says Sir Charles Henry Arbuthnot Pinkerton Ferguson (Peter O'Toole), "left me the most extraordinary amount of phenobarbital." She also left him so emotionally dependent on his sister Hilary (Susannah York) that Hilary can't bring herself to leave the family dairy farm to take up residence with her decent, dull husband.Hilary is not only afraid Pink will attempt suicide again, but she herself quite enjoys the lifetheir manic squabbles and their sharing of afternoon booze, topped off, perhaps, by a nice hot tub with a toy duck in the bathwater. It's apparent that the duck was not the only thing Pink and Hilary shared in their childhood.The name of James Kennaway's original novel was "Household Ghosts." When Kennaway adapted it as a play, it was called "Country Dance," which was the title it bore when production began on the film version. During the filming, it was known briefly as "The Same Skin," and yesterday the cinematic ghost of the novel opened at the Paris Theater as "Brotherly Love."I mention all this because the movie and its two principal characters are haunted by the same sort of indecision that seems to have marked the search for a title. The screenplay, written by Kennaway just before he died in 1968, is a series of scenes, which, although big, are never exactly obligatory. It does seem, in fact, that the movie's real obligatory scenes must have taken place years before, when Pink and Hilary stopped being lovers. The film merely records the events leading to their final inevitable separation.The course of these events is often tumultuous but never terribly affecting. O'Toole looks so thin and haggard that the enormous energy of his performance comes as a genuine surprise. It also comes to seem completely mechanical. This, however, may partly be the result of Kennaway's foundness for literary dialogue, heavy with dim similes ("Country dances, like country manners, are very old and very true"). The screenplay is also heavy with exposition, a lot of which is given to Miss York, who is an actress of intelligence and humor. Happily she is also endowed with an elastic lower lip that can be stretched around a line such as: "Oh God! Mummy did us enough harm when she was alive. Why did she have to go and die suddenly like that?"The film was directed by J. Lee Thompson with what is usually referred to as taste. The scenes of rural Scotland are set very prettily. Individual confrontations have a theatrical tension that seems to elude the movie as a whole. Somehow, it is typical of the film that we never see the outside of the house where Hilary and Pink live, although we are in it almost constantly. At the same time, the camera explores their faces and never once suggests what's really going on behind the facades of skin."Brotherly love" is so tasteful in this regardas if it didn't want to shockthat it seems downright platonic, which, under the circumstances, is a bit of a bore.

title: A LINK IS SOUGHT IN SLAYINGS HERE
description: Detectives pressed their in vestigations yesterday into two gangland shootings that were discovered within a 16hour period here on Tuesday.

title: Suit on Army Political Data Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 A Federal district judge dis missed a suit today that would have kept the Army from col lecting, storing and circulating information on the political ac tivities of civilians.

title: Pacific Far East Holders File Second Damage Suit
description: A second damage suit on be half of minority stockholders of Pacific Far East Lines, Inc., has been filed in the Federal District Court in San Francisco, charging that last year's ac quisition of 51 per cent of Pacific Far East by Consolid ated Freightways, Inc., was il legal. A similar action was be gun last June.

title: Inca Outlines Its Efforts on the Environment
description: TORONTO, April 22Report ing to its shareholders on Earth Day, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., an nounced increased firstquarter earnings today and outlined ef forts to reduce air pollution from its principal complex of mines and mills, at Sudbury, Ont.

title: Long Island Trains Delayed
description: Midmorning trains to and from Babylon on the Long Is land Railroad's Montauk branch were delayed for 20 minutes and more when one train broke down and took 15 minutes to start up again. A spokesman explained that traffic in both of track improvement work directions was affected because being done at Wantagh that forced all traffic to move on one track.

title: Russ Meyer's Film Cherry, Harry & Raquel Opens
description: IN Russ Meyer's Cherry, Harry & Raquel, a rugged band of Southwestern pot smugglers and their girls come to no good end and have a terrific time getting there. At the last, when all the men have killed one another and their ladies are making lesbian love, the voice of the epilogue asks: What then does life hold forth in store for these creatures of eroti cism? I think I'm quoting accurately (there is always so much to hear as well as see in a Russ Meyer movie), but despite the natural urge to make a few suggestions, the question must be taken as wholly rhetorical.
