title: Knick Games Here Set For Closed TV at Forum
description: A closedcircuit television showing of tomorrow's and Monday's New York Knicker bockerLos Angeles Laker playoff games has been ar ranged for the Felt Forum, the 4,000seat amphitheater that is part of the Madison Square Garden complex. The games will be shown live on a theatersize screen.

title: They Don't Always Look It, but They Really Are Lamps
description: VLADIMIR KAGAN has been busy bending fluorescent tubing into some extraordi nary lighting fixtures in prep aration for the opening yes terday of his new furnishings showroom at 232 East 59th Street. One 4footlong ceiling structure, for instance, is a tripletubular design shaped like an exclama tion point. It can be duplicated with fewer or more tubes, in larger or smaller sizes, bent in circles, horseshoes or other curved shapes and comes in many colors. Designs are made to order and are in stalled directly on the ceiling or on panels hung from the ceiling. Prices are from $500 into four figures.

title: BRAZILIAN CHORUS STRESSES COLORS
description: The Conjunto Brasileiro Ro berto de Regina staged what could have been just a vaude ville act, but with this group, it turned into a strong concert last night at Town Hall.

title: Garbage Strike in Atlanta Ends With 4.3% Pay Rise
description: ATLANTA, April 22 (UPI) Atlanta's 37dayold garbage strike was settled today when striking workers accepted the city's offer of a onestep 4.3 per cent pay rise.

title: July Nuptials Set By Miss Imberman
description: The engagement of Miss Ingrid Imberman, a junior majoring in English at New York University, to Kenneth Einstein, a student at New York Medical College here, has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Dr. and Mrs. Mark Imberman of New York and Shrub Oak, N. Y.

title: SILVER PRICES UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Evidently influenced by high er prices obtained at the Gov ernment's silver auction on Tuesday, futures contracts traded on the New York Com modity Exchange rose yester day in heavy trading, after dropping the day before.

title: PORK BELLIES
description: On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, futures prices of pork bellies rose in fairly ac tive trading on active demand. The busiest contract, May, with 5,515 sales, rose to 44.37 cents a pound compared with 43.35 cents a pound on Tuesday.

title: Art Exhibition Will benefit Horace Mann School Fund
description: The Art Department of Hor ace Mann School, 231 West 246th Street, the Bronx, will open an exhibition of paintings and sculptures on Sunday. The display, which is for the bene fund, will run through May 16. fit of the school's endowment.

title: Advertising: An Iron Womb on a Basic Bus
description: It just may be that Mutual Transit Sales might have struck on the secret formula needed to bolster sagging transit advertising sales.

title: School Strike: First Resort
description: When the United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education arrived at early agreement on new threeyear contract last June, Albert Shanker, the union's president, hailed the pact as assurance peace and stability for the school system. Now, less than ten months later, Mr. Shanker is back at his favorite sport of threatening to shut down the schools if he does not get what he wants for a newly enrolled group of union members.

title: 1967 Loans Urged By U.S., Ling Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)  Treasury Department officials encouraged American businessmen to circumvent the Federal Reserve Board's tight money policy in 1967 by bor rowing Eurodollars abroad, Congress was told today.

title: Candaules Coming May 20
description: Daniel C. Gerould's Can daules, Commissioner, de scribed as an antiwar, radical theater drama, will be present ed at the MercerHansberry Theater on May 20 by the Peo ple's Company. Roy Levine, who directed MacBird, wits design and stage the produc tion. The author, chairman of the World Literature Depart ment of San Francisco College has based his play on a Greek myth dealing with a mythica king of Lydia, who is obsessed with his wife's beauty.

title: Bruins Take Home 20 Lead
description: A strong defense, bolstered by Bobby Orr, and a sharp shooting offense, paced by Phil Esposito, have given the Boston Bruins an unexpected 20 lead over Chicago in their East Division final of the Stanley Clip playoffs.

title: Police Report BreakIns Declined Here in 1969
description: A locksmith in the Bronx tells a story about a woman with seven locks on her door who had an eighth one in stalled because her apart ment was broken into so often.

title: Activity Ranges From Oratory to Legislation
description: Earth Day, the first mass consideration of the globe's en vironmental problems, pre empted the attention and en ergies of millions of Americans, young and old, across the coun try yesterday.

title: Association of Bar Plans Symposium On Viability of Law
description: Announcing a symposium to be held next Thursday and Friday and called Is Law Dead? the head of the As sociation of the Bar of the City of New York said yesterday that it isn't.

title: U.S. PRESSES BRAZIL ON TORTURE ISSUES
description: The United States has repeat edly expressed its concern to the Brazilian Government over the alleged torture of political prisoners in Brazil, the State Department said today.

title: Courthouse in Rome Unsafe
description: ROME, April 22 (AP)  The superintendent of public works condemned Rome's courthouse today as unsafe and ordered it evacuated. The order was trans mitted to the Ministry of Justcie after months of con troversy over cracks that ap peared all over the ornate trav ertine marble building on the wset bank of the Tiber River.

title: American Farmers Are Reaping Little Profit From the EverIncreasing Prices of Food
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  No one agrees more than the Amer ican farmer that the cost of food is outrageous.

title: Score Mine Law Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)Representative John H. Dent, Democrat of Pennsyl vania, said today that a House labor subcommittee would in vestigate what he termed highhanded and capricious enforcement of the new coal mine safety law. Mr. Dent, who is chairman of the subcommit tee, contended that the Bureau of Mines, which administers the new law, had set a different schedule of civil penalties by Congress and had failed to al low flexibility in enforcing standards.

title: GRAINSSOYBEANS
description: Profit taking and speculative liquidation late in the session turned early advances of 1 cent and more in wheat corn and soybeans into losses on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 7 Journalists Given Medals of Freedom At the White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 President Nixon tonight award ed to seven journalists, includ ing Arthur Krock of The New York Times, the Medal of Free dom, the nation's highest civil ian award.

title: ARTHUR E. GERE
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., April 22Arthur E. Gere, a grain broker in New York City for years until he retired in 1940, died yesterday in Overlook Hos pital, Summit, after a brief ill ness. He was 90 years old and lived at 252 Old Tote Road.

title: Editor in Policy Dispute Loses JoblessAid Appeal
description: ALBANY, April 21 (AP)An appellate court has ruled that newspaper  editor cannot col lect unemployment compensa tion because he quit his job in a disagreement with his pub lisher over an editorial.

title: Mediator for School Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (UPI) Striking teachers agreed with the school board Tuesday to call in a Federal mediator, but the union vowed to continue the walkout until a contract was signed. Donald Baer, executive director of the United Teachers of Los Angeles, said that the Board of Education's decision to call in a mediator had been taken because our strike was so effective.

title: 2 Lenins: The Man and the Icon
description: There are two Lenins.

title: Moorish Palace in Majorca Restored for Franco's Use
description: PALMA, Majorca (Reuters).  A 700yearold palace, once the fortress of Moorish kings who ruled this Mediterranean island, has been restored as a museum and residence for Gen eralissimo Franco.

title: 31 TEE OFF TODAY IN $160,000 GOLF
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 22  Thirtyone profes sional golfers, whose total win nings in 1969 exceeded $2.4 million, are here for a special tournament. It is the Tourna ment of Champions, an event limited to those who have won one or more events on the cir cuit during the last 12 months.

title: All Astronauts Are Facing Tests for German Measles
description: HOUSTON, April 22 (AP) Astronauts on future space mis sions will not have to worry about an exposure to German measles, Dr. Charles A. Berry, chief of medical operations at the Manned Spacecraft Center here said yesterday.

title: Perot on Annapolis Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) H. Ross Perot, the Texas mil lionaire who has been active in efforts to aid prisoners of war in North Vietnam, was ap pointed by President Nixon to day as a member of the board of visitors of the United States Naval Academy.

title: Alcoholism Bureau Shifted
description: ALBANY, April 22  The state's Bureau of Alcoholism, formerly in the Division of Mental Health of the State Department of Mental Hygiene, has been elevated to the status of a separate division. The new division, which will remain in the Department of Mental Hy giene, will be headed by John R. Butler, who served as bureau director. Mr. Butler has been named as assistant commis sioner at an annual salary of $26,335.

title: Canadian Commons Votes Bill to Curb Pollution in Arctic
description: OTTAWA, April 22  The Canadian House of Commons voted 198 to 0 this afternoon to extend pollution controls over Arctic waters 100 miles to sea. The action contradicts United States claims that the waters are part of the interna tional high seas.

title: Beard Ban Reversed By Housing Authority
description: The New York City Housing Authority decided yesterday that its patrolmen could wear beards.

title: Observer: Permissiveness
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Logans have a permissive child. They are the envy of all parents in the neighborhood.

title: Radioactive Gas in Nevada
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (Reuters)A small amount of radioactive gas escaped Tuesday from an underground nuclear test in Nevada, about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced. A spokesman for the agency said the barely detect able radioactivity dissipated within an hour and presented no danger.

title: Arab Grenade Injures 3 Women Tourists
description: TEL AVIV, April 22 (AP)A terrorist hand grenade wound ed three American tourists and a dozen other persons today in the main square of Nablus in Israelioccupied Jordan, the Is raeli military command re ported.

title: Nixon Picks Coast Executive To Head Financial Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) President Nixon announced today that Reed O. Hunt, a San Francisco industrialist, will be chairman of the Presidential Commission on Financial Struc ture and Regulation.

title: Bearded Collies Grow in Favor Here
description: PROGRESS report: Two year ago The Times carried a story about how Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Levy of Mansfield Center, Conn., pur chased a bearded collie in England under the impres sion that they were getting an Old English sheepdog. Instead of being annoyed about the mis take, they were delighted with the dog they got and decided they wanted to organ ize a club for the old Scottish breed in this country. They became breeders in a small way.

title: U.A.R. Enters GATT
description: GENEVA, April 22The Gen eral Agreement on Tariffs and Trade announced today the signing of an accord making the United Arab Republic its 77th member nation. Fourteen more countries are provisional members of the organization.

title: Bay State Picks a Drink
description: BOSTON, April 22 (UPI)On a 210to9 rollcall vote, the Massachusetts House passed today legislation designating cranberry juice as the official state beverage.

title: PERU ADVOCATES NEW ORIENTATION
description: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 22Peru's revolutionary military regime today urged Latin America to adopt a new political orientation that would abandon capitalism and at the same time prevent Communism from spreading through the re gion. Instead, Peru advocated greater state control over de velopment plans and the re striction and channeling of for eign investment and aid to achieve national goals.

title: C. A. Fogarty Fiance Of Mary Rockefeller
description: RYE, N. Y., April 22Miss Mary Gillett Rockefeller and Clayton A. Fogarty will be married here in August.

title: Colonels Subdue Nets by 128101 and Even Series at 22
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD L.I, April 22The New York Nets should have taken a lesson to night from the Whiz Kids, group of basketball tricksters who staged a halftime show at the Island Garden.

title: Punishing Politics
description: The Cayuga County Democratic Committeemen can and did refuse renomination to Assemblyman George M. Michaelswho cast the deciding vote in favor of the abortion reform billjust as he predicted they would. He voted his conscience; they voted their politics of punishment.

title: Failure to Expand Council By Legislature Deplored
description: The Chairman of the City Council's State Legislature Committee said yesterday that the legislature's failure to pass a bill providing for an expan sion of the City Council had left him surprised and dis heartened.

title: Pierre Ball to Benefit Boys' Club
description: The Boys' Club of New York will hold its spring dance on Wednesday at the Pierre. Mrs. Carroll L. Wain wright is chairman of the event. Mrs. Charles. B. Gros venor, Mrs. Hiram D. Black and Mrs. Howland P. Rogers are vice chairmen. Best & Co. and Helena Rubinstein, Inc., are sponsors.

title: Amex Will Process Its OddLot Orders
description: Many of the orders of small investors will be switched di rectly from brokerage houses to the floor of the American Stock Exchange via computer starting early next month, the Amex announced yesterday.

title: Dance at Plaza To Aid School
description: The fourth annual spring dinner dance for the benefit of the development fund of the Marymount School of New York will be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Saturday. About 350 guests are expected to attend the invitational event.

title: Collection of Lenin's Writings on U.S. Published Here
description: Shortly after the Bolshevik seizure of power in 1917, Lenin, in an open letter to American workers, acclaimed the revolutionary tradition of the United States and urged worker to help the Soviet cause.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Paisley Rebuked for Speech
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 (Reuters)The Rev. Ian Paisley, a militant opponent of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority, was ruled out of order in his first speech as a member of Northern Ire land's Parliament today. A per sonal attack by Mr. Paisley on the Minister of Commerce, Roy Bradford, drew a rebuke from the Deputy Speaker, Walter Scott, who told him to try and relate your remarks to the busi before the house.

title: DR. HARRY TIRSCH
description: Dr. Harry Tirsch, a specialist in internal medicine here for 40 years, died Monday in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: GORTON ANNOUNCES VIETNAM TROOP CUT
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 22 (AP)  The Government has decided to withdraw one of the three Australian battal ions serving in South Vietnam, along with some support troops, Prime Minister John Gorton announced in Parlia ment today.

title: Proceedings in the U.N.
description: April 23, 1970

title: MISS STACY GAINS GOLF SEMIFINALS
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP)Hollis Stacy of Savannah, Ga., won two matches today and gained the semifinals of the Women's North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: Protest Keeps Gen. Taylor From Giving Speech on War
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., April 22 (AP)  Booing and brawling antiwar activists to night forced Gen. Maxwell Tay lor, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to termi nate a speech on the Vietnam conflict after only a few words at Monmouth College here.

title: Fat Girl, 13, Is Placed In a Government Home
description: HAYWARDS HEATH, Eng land (UPI)  A juvenile court has taken a 13year old girl away from her mother and put her into a Government Nome because she was too fat.

title: Chiang's Son Sees Laird
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)  Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo of Nationalist China conferred with Secretary of De fense Melvin R. Laid and other Pentagon officials today on Asian security arrangements in the nineteenseventies.

title: Mood Is Joyful as City Gives Its Support
description: Huge, lighthearted throngs ambled down autoless streets, here yesterday as the city heeded Earth. Day's call for a regeneration of a polluted en vironment by celebrating an exuberant rite of spring.

title: WAGE ISSUE SNAGS NEWSPAPER TALKS
description: Meetings between negotia tors for the city's four major newspapers and the typograph ical union continued yesterday, but no progress toward a con tract settlement was reported.

title: U.S. CONCERN SUED WITH 2 IN JAPAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Justice Department, in the first action of its kind in 20 years, filed an antitrust suit today charging the Westing house Electric Corporation and two major Japanese companies with illegally conspiring not to sell certain products in each other's countries.

title: BorgWarner German Unit
description: The BorgWarner Corpora tion announced yesterday it had formed a company in West Germany to be known as ZF BorgWarner, G.m.b.H., to pro duce automatic transmissions for European automotive man ufacturers. The German part ner in the $40million venture is Zahnradfabrik Friedrichsha fen, A.G.

title: Angry Coordinator of Earth Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Denis Allen Hayes, the national coordinator of Earth Day, remembers the world he grew up in as pristinely beautifula world of dense forests, rushing streams and lonely foothills rolling away into the Cascades range of Washington state.

title: Roundup: Porky Fattens With Tigers' Dumbo Out
description: While Dumbo's away, Porky will play.

title: Mayor Says U.S. Bill Would Impede Drug Control
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that the passage of an an tinarcotics bill backed by the Nixon Administration would severely impede our efforts to control the illegal use of drugs.

title: Carpenters Back Governor
description: BUFFALO, April 21 (AP) The 80,000  member State Council of Carpenters, A.F.L. C.I.O., has endorsed Governor Rockefeller for reelection, it was announced Tuesday. Her man F. Bodewes, a member of the council's executive com mittee, said that 350 delegates chose to back the Governor, a Republican, at the council's an nual convention last week at Kiamesha Lake. Edward J. Bjork, council president, lauded Mr. Rockefeller's state building program.

title: Samuels Will Drop TV Ads If Goldberg Debates Weekly
description: Howard J. Samuels offered yesterday to cancel $250,000 worth of television advertising if Arthur J. Goldberg, the or ganization designee, agreed to debate once a week until the June 23 primary with his two opponents for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Methodist Welfare Aid Found Almost Totally White
description: ST. LOUIS, April 22Health and welfare agencies supported by the United Methodist Church serve an almost allwhite, mid dleclass clientele, according to a report distributed here today to delegates attending the church's fiveday general con ference.

title: House Panel Votes Plan For Clean Air Standard
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 A House subcommittee unani mously approved today a bill designed to reduce air pollution by providing national quality standards and strict enforce ment procedures for the foulers of the atmosphere.

title: SovietNigeria Cultural Pact
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 22 (Agence France  Presse)  Nigeria and the Soviet Union signed a cultural agreement to day. The Information Commis sioner, Chief Anthony Enahoro, who signed for Nigeria, said the agreement would further promote friendship between the two countries.

title: BOTULISM DANGER BRINGS NEW BAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The Department of Agriculture ordered three food manufactur ing plants in the Minneapolis area today to halt distribution of products containing mush rooms suspected of being in fected with deadly botulism toxin.

title: Theater: A Minimusical
description: FOUR people in an empty park, six musicians in a green bandstand. The new musical Park, which opened last night at the John Gold en Theater, takes simplicity in Broadway musicals to new lengths. Given its world premiere by Baltimore's Resi dent Theater, it makes an unpretentious yet somewhat thin New York evening.

title: Perot's Stock Falls $445Million in Day
description: H. Ross Perot, the executive who has been workking private ly for the return of American war prisoners from North Viet nam, suffered a sharp paper loss yesterday in the overthe counter market.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Even for Its Inventor, Miniskirt Is Dead
description: LONDON, April 22 (AP) Mary Quant, the British designer who introduced the miniskirt in the middle 1960's and as recently as Jan. 11, 1968, insisted that the miniskirt has built itself into a fashion classic that will never be replaced, officially abandoned the style today.

title: Soviet Shifts Information Aides; Zamyatin Is Made Head of Tass
description: MOSCOW, April 22Soviet officials today disclosed major personnel changes in the news and information field.

title: 80% in Faculty Member Survey Consider Protesters a Threat
description: A survey of 60,447 univer sity and college faculty mem bers has disclosed that while most profess liberal views on national and international af fairs they are becoming more conservative on academic is sues.

title: PAUL SCHMIDT, 71, HITLER AIDE, DIES
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 23 (Reuters)  Paul Schmidt, Hitler's chief inter preter who was also press spokesman for the Foreign Of fice of the Third Reich, died yesterday at the age of 71, it was reported here today.

title: Chess:
description: DURING the recent 10 board quadruple round chess match between the So viet Union and players front the rest of the world, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a seventime United States champion, was paired on Board 6 with a former world champion, Vasily Smysloy.

title: April 1120 Sales Declined At 3 of Big 4 Car Makers
description: Newcar sales in the United States in the April 1120 period fell 10.5 per cent, the major automobile makers reported yesterday.

title: Marquez Rides 3 Winners As Gulfstream Meet Ends
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 22 (AP)  Carlos Marquez won three races and the riding title today, while Arnold Winick cap tured another training cham pionship as Gulfstream Park closed its 43day meeting with the highest mutuel handle in the track's history.

title: The Good Earth
description: Earth Day is over and the country's most elegant pedestrian mallFifth Avenueis again just another noisy, congested, exhaustpoisoned traffic artery, like all the other streets in this noisy, congested, exhaust poisoned pollution capital of the world.

title: U.S. Plane Flies In Arms As Trinidad Fights Mutiny
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The United States flew a planeload of weapons, including mortars and machine guns, to Trinidad today at the urgent request of the black Government there, which is seeking to put down a mutiny inspired by blackpower elements.

title: Moynihan, at A.N.P.A., Supports Welfare Plan
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to President Nixon, declared yesterday that the na tional welfare reform approved by the House reflects what we are now able to do in funds likely to be available over the next five years.

title: Wedding Sept. 11 For Miss Thompson
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 22  Miss Margaret Susan Thompson and Louie Samuel Echols 3d, plan to be married Sept. 11 in New York.

title: CRASH IN PHILIPPINES LINKED TO EXPLOSION
description: MANILA, April 22 (AP)In vestigators concluded today that there was an explosion in the lavatory of a Philippine airliner before it crashed yes terday in rugged country north of Manila, killing all 36 per sons aboard.

title: Role of White House and G.O. P. In Carswell Senate Bid Debated
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Claims that G. Harrold Carswell had advance approval from the White House and the Republi can National Committee for his Senate bid from Florida were advanced and denied here to day.

title: 7 U.S. AIRCRAFT LOST IN VIETNAM AND LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 (AP)  The United States Command announced to day the loss of four American planes over southeastern Laos and three helicopters in South Vietnam. It was one of the highest aircraft tolls reported at one time in the war.

title: City's School Ship Will Be Retired Soon
description: The John W. Brown, the former World War II Lib erty ship that has served as a floating classroom for thou sands of maritimeminded city high school students for more than at years, is leaded for retirement.

title: 75 N.Y.U. STUDENTS PROTEST AT CLUE
description: A group of 75 students swept through the kitchen of New York University's Washington Square Faculty Club yesterday as a protest in support of strik ing library and cafeteria work ers continued.

title: CAPS WIN, 131114, AND TIE ROCKETS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Rick Barry and Mike Barrett scored 30 points apiece tonight as the Washington Caps de feated the Denver Rockets, 136114, to even their fourof sevengame Western Division playoff series in the American Basketball Association at two games each.

title: Jordan, in U.N., Accuses Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22Jordan accused Is rael today of military activity to seize wells in Jordanian ter ritory near the Dead Sea and to pump their water to Israeli factories extracting chemicals from the Dead Sea.

title: A SCHOOL MONOPOLY IS FEARED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  President Nixon said Tuesday that it would not be good for either the country or its schools if either public or private school systems had a monopoly over the education of the nation's children.

title: Expos Trade Farm Hand
description: MONTREAL, April 22 (AP) The Montreal Expos traded a 22 yearold infielder, Garry Jestadt, of their International League Buffalo Bisons farm club today for an infielderoutfielder, Jim my Qualls, of the Tacoma Cubs in the Pacific Coast League, owned by the Chicago Cubs.

title: G.E. Stockholders Hear From Protesters
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 22 Some 250 stockholders of the General Electric Company as sembled here today for their annual meeting amid implied threats of bombings and dis ruptive activities of the young militants.

title: SCHOOL WORKERS VOTE TO STRIKE
description: Representatives of pararo fessional school employes belonging to the United Federa tion of Teachers voted over whelmingly yesterday to rec ommend a strike if the Board of Education did not make a meaningful contract offer.

title: Ship Fire Burns Bananas
description: NEWARK, April 22 (AP)  Fire broke out today aboard Grace Line freighter loaded with bananas at Pier 6 in Port Newark, fire officials said. Damage to the ship, the Santa Magadelenca, was described as extremely light with most of the damage being confined to the bananas. There were no injuries.

title: SENATORS DEFEAT YANKS IN 18TH, 21
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, April 23The Yankees and the Senators almost completed baseball game in two hours last night but that would have been ridiculous. Instead they played four hours and 40 minutes, 18 innings in all, before the home team scored a 21 victory.

title: Lenin Centennial Ended With a Speech by Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, April 22  The 100th anniversary of Lenin's birth was officially commem orated today with pomp, speeches and a pledge by Prem ier Aleksei N. Kosygin that the Soviet Union would guard the peace and aid the struggle against imperialism.

title: PRICES CLIMB 0,4% BUT RATE OF RISE APPEARS TO SLOW
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Consumer prices rose strongly again in March but there were signs that the pace of infla tion was slowing, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CAMBODIAN CRISIS GROWS AS TROOPS SEEM TO FALTER
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 22An atmosphere of heighten ing national emergency is ver taking Cambodia.

title: 4 Companies Announce Elections of Presidents
description: Four companies announced yesterday the election of new presidents.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON LONDON BOARD
2 Draft Protesters Ordered Returned to Baltimore Jail
description: The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, a Roman Catholic priest, and David Eberhardt, both arrested by the Federal Bureau of In vestigation as fugitives, were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy re turned to Baltimore to face nineyear prison sentences.

title: City Ballet and Musicians Talk; Ailey May Disband His Troupe
description: Representatives of the New York City Ballet's orchestra met with management yesterday in a hastily called meeting as the musicians' strike against the company went into its second day.

title: STOCK PRICES FALL IN BROAD RETREAT
description: The stock market continued its sharp plunge yesterday with the bears outpointing the bulls for the 15th consecutive ses sion.

title: In the Schools, Pollution Is a Dirty Word
description: Earthlings concerned about their Mother Earth heard the bad news, yesterday, and were heartened by wishes for speedy recovery.

title: MIRY CAPABILITY DEFINED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 President Nixon has assured a leading critic of multiplewar head nuclear weapons that the Administration is not develop ing the capability of striking at shielded Soviet mssiles.

title: Station Committee Upholds Dismissal Of TV News Editor
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The executive committee of sta tion WETATV approved today the dismissal of William Woe stendiek, the news editor who was ousted last week after his wife took a job as press secre tary to the wife of Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: Publishers Rate Environment as the Big Story in U.S.
description: The public temper on the major issues of the timefrom the war in Vietnam to racial integrationhas cooled in the last year, a geographical sam pling of newspaper editors and publishers meeting here indi cated yesterday.

title: BELMONTE SCORES AQUEDUCT TRIPLE
description: Eddie Belmonte, the Puerto Rican who has been running away with the jockeys' stand ings race at Aqueduct, contin ues to outdistance the field.

title: MINIBIKES PRESENT MAXIMUM HEADACHE
description: LOS ANGELES (AP).  Mini bikes are causing maxihead aches in many places, and no painrelievers are in sight.

title: California Faculty Unit Urges Closer Control of Weapon Research
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 A faculty study committee is sued a report today approving the University of California's continued participation in nu clear weapons research, but only if closer administrative controls are imposed.

title: Seaver Sets a Record
description: Tom Seaver set one major league strikeout record and tied another yesterday in pitching the New York Mets to a 21 victory over the San Diego Padres at Shea Sta dium. He struck out the last 10 batters, surpassing by two the modern record for con secutive strikeouts. His game total of 19 tied the rec ord. Details on Page 48.

title: Sources Say Housing Unit Seeks to Find News Leak
description: Sources within the city's Housing and Development Ad ministration said yesterday that the agency had begun an investigation designed to en trap those who have been leak ing confidential studiessuch as the Rand reportto the press.

title: New Apeal Made at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22  Cambodia made an urgent appeal to all coun tries which love peace and jus tice today to help the new Government to fight invading Vietcong and North Vietnam ese forces.

title: Ballet Recalls Era Of Covent Garden
description: To thousands of middle aged and elderly Londoners, an event in Covent Garden in 1946 may still symbolize the end of the austerity of World War II. For on Feb. 20 of that year the royal family headed an invitation audi ence that filled the 2,200 seats of the old building for the first performance of its new tenant, the Sadler's Wells Ballet, now the Royal Ballet, which opened its twelfth tour here Tuesday night.

title: U.S.L.T.A. Fined $2,500 by World Unit
description: LONDON, April 22 (UPI) The United States Lawn Tennis Association was fined $2,500 today by the International Lawn Tennis Federation for rule violations at recent tourna ments in Boston and Philadel phia.

title: Credit Markets: Yields Rise Amid Recovery Signs
description: The bond market took a turn ?? the worse yesterday, de spite some surface indications that it might be beginning to recover. Specialists said that a dramatic change in psychology had apparently become wide spread in the last week or so, indicating that more declines lay ahead.

title: U.S. Officials Leave Iran As Regional Parley Ends
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 22 Two highranking State Depart ment officials left here today following a twoday conference with the United States Ambas sadors in the Middle East and South Asia. The officials were Under Secretary Elliot L. Richardson and Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

title: Dolfay, With 2,013, Takes Division Lead in Bowling
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 22 (UPI)Ed Dolfay, a profession al from Seattle, took the classic division allevents lead in the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a pinfall of 2,013.

title: RAILROAD POLICEMEN INDICTED IN BEATING
description: Three Long Island Railroad policemenone of them a cap tain with 19 years on the po lice force  were charged in Criminal Court yesterday with the beating last winter of a commuter who died a few hours after the alleged incident.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AT midnight, a blonde he had picked up outside The Jockey Club whispered Beautiful Dreamer in the seventh at Belmont instead of tipping him, so when Herman R. Burrows turned in his cab at 10 A.M., he went directly to his neighborhood betting parlor, a square, stone, banklike building that bore the inscription Municipal Wagering Center No. 93. The oak doors were locked and a small sign hung from a knob: Temporarily Closed for Inventory. Burrows sat down on the top step to wait.

title: Knicks Confront BigMan Jinx in Final
description: After 17 years, the New York Knickerbockers have another shot at the National Basketball Association championship, and some things are remarkably familiar. The opposing team is, again, the Lakers  although now it represents Los Angeles instead of Minneapolis. And the central problem again is to cope with the physically most domi nant player in the gameWilt Chamberlain now, George Mikan then.

title: AntiEarth Day Wires Cost Official $1,600
description: ATLANTA, April 22 (AP) Comptroller General James L. Bentley, who sent out $1,600 worth of telegrams at the taxpayers' expense charging that Earth Day might be a Communist plot because it fell on Lenin's birthday, says he has changed his mind and will pay for the wires him self.

title: GRIEVANCE TABLE IS WON AT SCHOOL
description: The Board of Eductaion an flounced last night that, in the interest of restoring a positive educational climate to embat tled George Washington High School, a studentgrievance ta ble staffed by parents would be set up in the school.

title: Market Place:
description: NOW that Wall Street has had time to eval uate the gargantuan Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph financing, the ifs, ands and buts are flying.

title: Witness Tells Court That Seale Ordered Black Panther Killed
description: NEW HAVEN, April 22  The main prosecution witness in the forthcoming murder trial of Bobby G. Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party, testified at a bail hear ing today that the Panther lead er ordered the slaying last May.

title: Stanley Benham, a Bobsledder, World Championin '4950, Dies
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 22 (UPI)Stanley Benham, the bobsled ace who represented the United States in more inter national competitions than any other American, died today at hospital in Miami, after suffer ing a heart attack. He was .57 years old.

title: Coeds Throw Pills at Rally
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 22 (AP)  Participants in an Earth Day rally at Indiana Uni versity were pelted today with birth control pills thrown by coeds dressed as witches. The girls danced in a circle and chanted, Free our bodies, free our minds. The demonstra tion was conducted by about 20 members of the campus Wo men's Liberation Movement.

title: Bergen Sheriff Plans to Run For Senate as Independent
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April 22 (AP)  Bergen County Sheriff Joseph Job says he will be an independent candidate for the United States Senate although his family and close friends tried to discourage his decision.

title: CAMBODIA TO GET RIFLES FROM U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The Nixon Administration has agreed to supply several thou sand rifles to the beleaguered Government of Cambodia, Ad ministration officials disclosed today. The weapons would be automatic rifles of Soviet de sign captured from Communist forces in South Vietnam.

title: D. D. B. Places First in Art Directors Club Medals
description: The Art Directors Club honored its own again yes terday in the Imperial Ball room of the Americana Hotel where some 1,100 creative types watched 20 medals being awarded to someone else.

title: Trouble in Trinidad
description: The travel brochures write glowingly of Trinidad Tobago as a tropical paradise, two islands with ex quisite beaches, lovely palm trees and the throbbing rhythms of steel bands accompanying masters of calypso song. Potential investors are wooed with literature stressing the racial amity in the hetero geneous population, the political stability under Prime Minister Eric Williams's strong but moderate govern ment, and the abundant labor supply.

title: Zilly Joins Eagles' Staff
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UPI)  Jack Zilly, head coach at the University of Rhode Is land for seven years, has joined the coaching staff of the Phila delphia Eagles, the Nationale Football League team an nounced today. Zilly will coach the eagles' running backs and also work with the specialty teams.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 23, 1970

title: Soviet Fleet Maneuvering in Atlantic
description: LONDON, April 22  Six heavy cruisers and a helicop ter cruiser led a Soviet fleet to day in a large exercise across an area of the North Atlantic traditionally associated with naval control of the coast of Western Europe.

title: President Urges A Reorganization Of Disaster Relief
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)  President Nixon pro posed today a reorganization of the Federal Government's dis aster relief operations, includ ing loans to help local govern ments make up property tax losses.

title: Earth Bond Issued
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UPI)The First Pennsylvania Bank issued today a new type of bondan Earth Bondun der which the bank will match the amount of deposit with funds to be lent to businesses and government only for anti pollution projects. In all other respects, the bank said, the Earth Bond is similar to regular 5% per cent savings certifi cates compounded daily and guaranteed for 20 years.

title: Too Little of a Good Thing
description: From the standpoint of a Penn Central Railroad passenger, a worm'seye view if ever there was one, it begins to seem that the vaunted Metroliner is going into a decline in record time even for the railroad industry.

title: Government Drops Charge Against Two in Spook Case
description: BOSTON, April 22 (AP) The Government dropped today draft conspiracy, charges against the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, chaplain of Yale University and Mitchell Good man of Temple, Me.

title: Equity Corp. Unit Elects
description: The Equity Corporation, closedend investment con pany, announced here yestr day that Michael D. Dingmn, president, had been elected to the additional post of presidnt of Pacific Industries, Inc., the of Equity's affiliates. At he same time, William A. Mez, corporation counsel of Equy, has been named treasurer of the investment company, se ceeding Paul J. Steil, who his resigned.

title: Brown Trial Delayed Again; 3Judge Panel to Hear Plea on Shift in Jurisdiction
description: BALTIMORE, April 22The arson and riot trial of H. Rap Brown, the black power mili tant, was postponed today at least until Monday. A three judge panel will hear then a defense plea to have the case moved from state to Federal jurisdiction.

title: M.T.A. Silent on Defeat Of Rail Link to Kennedy
description: The Metropolitan Trans portation Authority fended off questions yesterday about a bill killed in Albany this week that would have fi nanced construction of a spur on the Long Island Rail road to Kennedy Interna tional Airport.

title: Bury the Ghost
description: The Supreme Court has now removed the last excuse for pretending that there is any life left in the Sub versive Activities Control Board. For twenty years this ugly vestige of the spirit of hate and suspicion en gendered by the late Senators Patrick A. McCarran and Joseph R. McCarthy has done nothing to justify its existence. It would have died quietly two years ago the late Senator Everett McK. Dirksen had not done some armtwisting at the White House to get it some synthetic cases.

title: MAX RICH, COMPOSER OF SMILE, DARN YA
description: Max Rich, composer of Smile, Darn Ya, Smile, died yesterday at University Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Personal Finance
description: Two bills awaiting Gov ernor Rockefeller's signature and a third measure just in troduced by the State In surance Department are ex pected to have a wide impact for consumers.

title: Books of The Times
description: YOU can't be a tourist in the novels of Janet Frame. The act of apprehen sion makes you an accomplice. The landscape is static, a world of art, frozen images, memories like cameras pointed at each other, dreams like cooled lava that once upon a time erupted from a volcanic imagination. The only weather in such world is psychic shifts of con sciousness, brain storms, eclipses. Man is the cli mate. Color and motion exist only in the mind. Even the rain is a suc cession of avenues of burning fluid mirrors. The snow swallows, its big/white mouth turning over and munch ing the sugared people/limbs go down into cool columns of pres sure,/the sky is spinning out the flakes like webs/they drift like lantern spiders across the sky/ catching the air/hammering silver fang nails into its nothingness. Nothingness To perceive is to lose your purchase on the manageable, to give up your citizen ship in the nation of the real.

title: 20 Protest Pope's Visit
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, April 22 (Reuters)About 20 anarchists held a hunger strike today in a poor suburb of Cagliari the capital of Sardinia, to protest Pope Paul's visit here Friday. The protesters said the Pope lives among treasures in the Vatican while the people live in old houses. So far the anar chists, who came from Milan, have been joined in their pro test by only three local resi dents, the police said.

title: Phone Craftsmen Return To Jobs After 5Day Strike
description: A fiveday walkout in a dis pute over the safety of pier sonnal ended Tuesday when 16,000 telephone craftsman re turned to their jobs in the plant department of the new York Telephone Company.

title: Reynolds Tobacco Sets Sales and Profit Marks
Mets' Ace Responds to Award in Manner Befitting Pitcher of the Year
Bridge:
Peter Chiesi, CoFounder OfIda deFrance Restaurant
description: Peter Chiesi, a founder with his brother, Alexander, of the Ida deFrance Restaurant, 1540 Second Avenue, near 81st Street, and chef there since 1968, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home, 397 East 52d Street. His age was 53.

title: LEVINTOWNSEND IN MERGER TALKS
description: The Standard Prudential Cor poration announced yesterday it is holding conversations re garding the possible acquisition of the LevinTownsend Com puter Corporation, a financially ailing computerleasing com pany.

title: Lawyer for Manson Named
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) A judge appointed Richard A. Walton today to defend Charles Manson on murder conspiracy charges in the slay ing last July 27 of a musician, Gary Hinman. Manson, 35 years old, and Susan Atkins, 21, de fendants in the killings last Au gust of the actress Sharon Tate and six others, appeared in Superior Court for arraignment in the Hinman case.

title: 6 Die in Plano Crash
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 22 (AP) A private plane crashed be tween two houses while trying to land at Austin's municipal airport tonight and six persons were killed, the police reported.

title: Kennedy Discerns Crisis, Asks More in School Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massa chusetts, said today that the nation's schools faced a finan cial crisis and urged that Fed eral aid for education be in creased.

title: Assaults on Teachers Here Show a Marked Increase for SixMonth Period
description: Attacks on teachers by stu dents and others have increased substantially during the current school year, accord ing to figures compiled by the Board of Education.

title: Richey and Spear Advance To Semifinals at River Oaks
description: HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) TOPSEEDED Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and unseed ed Nikola Spear of Yugoslavia advanced to the semifinals of the $25,000 River Oaks invita tion tennis tournament today.

title: GARY PLAYER'S 68 LEADS BY STROKE
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 23  Gary Player of South Africa led the field with a 68 as foreign golfers domi nated the opening round of the $150,000 Tournament of Cham nions today.

title: Pot Roast for the Weekend
description: IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Pizza Company in Jersey Not Involved in U.S. Action
description: A spokesman for the Roman Products Corporation of South Hackensack, N. J., said yester day that his company uses no mushrooms whatsoever in any of its frozen pizza products and was not to be confused with the Roman Inn Pizza Com pany of Eau Claire, Wis.

title: JOINT PANEL BACKS 3D NUCLEAR CARRIER
description: WASHINGTON, April 23A Congressional joint subcommit tee recommended today that the House and Senate give the Navy money to start building its third nuclear aircraft carrier.

title: Forum Fight Rescheduled
description: Because of the closedcircuit telecast of the KnicksLakers playoff game in Felt Forum to night, the scheduled 10round fight between Charlie (Devil) Green and Ray Anderson has been rescheduled for Tuesday night in the Forum.

title: Bruins Sink Hawks, 52, for 30 Lead; Penguins Top Blues
description: BOSTON, April 23 (UPI) John Bucyk scored two power play goals tonight while lead ing the Boston Bruins to a 52 victory and a 30 Stanley Cup playoff series lead over the Chi cago Black Hawks.

title: JAVITS PROPOSES MORE AID TO POOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Calling the Nixon Administra tion's welfare reform bill only a beginning, Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today raising Federal benefits to the poor and requiring the states to con tribute, too.

title: Jersey's Statute On Passenger Tax At Airport Upset
description: NEWARK, April 23 (AP) A judge ruled today that a state statute enacted Dec. 1 authorizing a passenger head tax at Newark Airport was un constitutional.

title: Toward a More Equitable Draft
description: President Nixon has taken substantial new steps toward making the draft more equitable with his order ending some deferments and with his request to Con gress to put an end to others.

title: Hanne A. Kristensen to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kris tensen of Jyderup, Denmark, have announced here the en gagement of their daughter, Miss. Hanne Agnete Kristen sen, a stewardess with Amer ican Airlines, to John Doug las Maxwell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Maxwell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell of Glen Head, L.I.

title: Fiduciary Trust Elects
description: Henry H. Moulton, executive vice president and director of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, has been elected chairman of the executive com mittee. He succeeds Edward P. Stuhr, who is retiring next month as a director. Also an nounced was the election of Lawrence S. Huntington, exec utive vice president of Fidu ciary's investment department, to the board.

title: Harrington Places a Condition On Quitting Race for Governor
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Har rington said yesterday that he would not withdraw as the Liberal party's candidate for Governor in favor of Arthur J. Goldberg unless the party re ceived evidence that the Demo cratic designee was really in dependent from the oldline Democratic machine.

title: Use of Movie Houses Urged For Offtrack Betting Here
description: A plan to convert movie houses into offtrack betting parlors was proposed to Gov ernor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Priorities After Vietnam
description: President fixon's announced plan to withdraw 150,000 more troops from Vietnam inevitably raises hopes that the United States is now decisively shifting its national priorities and will soon have the resources needed to tackle domestic social problems that have long been starved for funds by the war.

title: EARTH DAY THEME CONTINUES IN U.S.
description: The Earth Day theme of en vironmental concern contin bed to resound yesterday on campuses, in legislative halls, and among conservation groups across the country.

title: British Study Finds Birth Pills Safer With Estrogen Cut
description: LONDON April 23 (AP)  A report of four doctors con ducting research for the British Government says new, low dosage oral contraceptives should reduce deaths among women using the pill by one half and cut the thrombosis rate by 25 per cent.

title: ExGov. Brown Tells Alioto Trial of Role Played by the Press
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23  Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown injected some of his philosophy of political public relations today into the trial of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5 million libel complaint against Look magazine.

title: The Women of Andorra Receive Right to Vote
description: ANDORRA, April 23 (AP) The men who govern this tiny principality decreed to day that women had the right to vote.

title: The Draft Before, Now and in Future
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Following is the White House analysis of The Impact of Draft Reform on Individual Registrants:

title: Antitrust Suit Filed On LevinTownsend And I.B.M. by Levin
description: The recently ousted presi dent of the LevinTownsend Computer Corporation filed $750  million antitrust suit against that company and the International Business Ma chines Corporation in Federal Court here yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
Malaysia Reports Blasts
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 23 (Reuters)Blasts of booby traps tied to Communist flags injured at least eight per sons in widely scattered areas of Malaysia and Singapore to day. The Malaysian Government ascribed the explosions to the banned Communist party, which refuses to accept the separation of Malaysia and Singapore.

title: Suns Obtain Bulls' Haskins
description: PHOENIX, April 23 (UPI) The Phoenix Suns traded Jim Fox, a center, and their secondround 1971 draft choice to clay to the Chicago Bulls for Clem Haskins, a guard and one of the National Basketball As sociation's top playmakers.

title: Jets Raid U.A.R. Targets
description: TEL AVIV, April 23 (Reu ters)  Israeli jets raided Egyptian military targets for more than three hours today in intermittent attacks across the Suez Canal, a military spokes man said here. He said that all planes had returned safely to base.

title: U.S. Reserves Declined in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 United States international monetary reserve assets de clined $320million in March, largely because of a reduc tion in foreign currency hold ings, the Treasury reported today.

title: LONDON ENSEMBLE MAKES LOCAL BOW
description: The London Philharmonic Orchestra, making its New York debut, gave the first of three concerts in Carnegie Hall last night as part of the hall's Internaitonal Festival of Visit ing Orchestras. A comparative ly young ensemble, founded in 1932 by the late Sir Thomas. Beecham, it has bernard Hai tink as its current conductor, who also heads the Concertge bouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.

title: Building Evacuated in Rome
description: ROME, April 23 (Reuters) The Palace of Justice on the banks of the Tiber was evacu ated today after being officially declared a public danger. Tons of furnishings and legal archives were carried away. The govern ment ordered the evacuation because large blocks of granite had been breaking off the build ing, which was completed 59 years ago.

title: Copter Kills Finnish General
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 23 (UPI)  Lieut. Gen. Kauko Poeyhoenen of Finland walked into a whirling helicopter rotor yesterday and was killed as he was leaving a meeting in Nor way of Nordic defense officials.

title: Murdering Justice
description: Those students and faculty members at Yale who are trying to stop a murder trial by calling a strike dgainst the university have plunged campus activism into new depths of irrationality.

title: Ex Maryland Representative Starts Serving Prison Term
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., April 23 (AP)Thomas F. Johnson, for mer Democratic Representative from Maryland, reported today to a deputy United States marshal, who took horn to the Federal penitentiary to start serving a sixmonth sentence.

title: REUTHER REELECTED AS U.A.W. PRESIDENT
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 23 (AP)Walter P. Reu ther was reelected president of the United Auto Workers today, swamping his first opponent in 21 years and setting the stage for handpicking his successor four years from now.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Exemption Would Keep The Delta Queen Afloat
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Bills were introduced in both the Senate and the House to day to exempt the last Miss issippi River steamboat that carries overnight passengers from Federal fire regulations.

title: Changes in Military Pay
Theater: Inquest Opens
description: Two questionsquite dis tinct, if interrelatedare raised by Donald Freed's play Inquest, which opened last night at the Music Box. The first is whether this play, a courtroom drama about unavailing innocence, the ob scenity of capital punishment and the savagery of the electric chair, is an effective piece of theater. To my mind it is. It is one of the most gripping courtroom dramas of my experience, from the first polite legal exchanges to the final electric flashes of society's revenge.

title: Mrs. Olin Downes Dies; Edited Husband's Work
description: Mrs. Irene Miles Downes, widow of Olin Downes, The New York Times's music critic for more than 30 years, died of cancer Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 81 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.

title: Gross, Senate Candidate, Puts Net Worth at $802,191
description: TRENTON, April 23Nelson G. Gross, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, reported, today that his and his wife's net worth was $802,191.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 23, 1970

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Brokers in Detroit Vote Against Union
description: DETROIT, April 23The first attempt in the nation by stock salesmen to organize brokerage firms failed here today.

title: NIXON ABOLISHES DRAFT DEFERMENT FOR FATHERHOOD
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon abolished to day, by Executive order, occu pational draft deferments and deferments for fathers.

title: Black Power Flourishing in Caribbean
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 23A potent, studious, often raucous and sometimes violent blackpower movement has come to the Englishspeak ing Caribbean, and nowhere more visibly than here.

title: TALKS CONTINUE AT PAPERS HERE
description: Pressure on The New York Times mounted yesterday as meetings continued between ne gotiators for the typographical union and the city's four major newspapers.

title: EXSCIENCE AIDES URGE MORE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Four former chief Presidential science advisers joined today in sharp criticism of present Government policy in support ing science.

title: Judge Delays Calley Trial In Songmy Case to Aug. 24
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., April 23 (AP)A military judge to day set a new trial date of Aug. 24 for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is charged with murdering 102 Vietnamese civil ians at Songmy in 1968.

title: U.S.CHINA TRADE IS URGED IN STUDY
description: Normalization of United States relations with Commu nist China could bring a grad ual, though modest, growth of trade, according to a study made public here yesterday.

title: Where Is the Bottom?
description: The stock market has ab sorbed a merciless pounding so far this spring and pessimism is rampant on Wall Street. Secu rities prices keep falling day after day, with little regard for news developments or the lack of them.

title: SHERIFF TESTIFIES AT SEALE HEARING
description: NEW HAVEN, April 23  The 73yearold Sheriff of New Haven County was questioned for four and a half hours to day on the selection of the grand jury that returned a mur der indictment against Bobby G. Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party.

title: THOMAS F. GOREAU, STUDIED CORAL REEF
description: Dr, Thomas F. Goreau, an au thority on coral reef ecology, die Wednesday at St. Vin cent's Hospital of complications following surgery for cancer. He was 46 years old and lived in Discovery Bay, Jamaica, where he was resident director of a marine laboratory, sponsored jointly by the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L. I., And the University of the West Indies.

title: N.Y.U. Routs Coast Guard On Collins's 3Hitter, 120
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., April 23Ellsworth Jones, a first baseman, had three hits and batted in four runs today to lead New York University to 120 rout of the Coast Guard Academy.

title: Earth Day Cases Continued
description: BOSTON, April 23 (AP)Ten persons who were arrested dur ing an Earth Day antipollution demonstration at Logan Air port yesterday had pleas of not guilty entered for them today in East Boston District Court. Judge James J. Mellen contin ued the cases to April 30 and released them in $5,000 bond.

title: BANK SEES DEFICIT IN U. S. PAYMENTS
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company estimated yesterday that the United States balance of payments was in heavy de ficit during the first quarter, representing a sharp deteriora tion from the large surplus posted in the final three months of 1969.

title: Teamster Picketing Halts Some PiggyBack Trucks
description: The Penn Central said yes terday that a representation dispute between two unions over railroad police at its piggyback freight yards had had some effect on vans being trucked in.

title: Menotti's First Play Presented in Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 23For 20 years Gian Carlo Menotti has been harboring the idea of The Leper. At first he planned this work on the theme of minorities as an opera, but two years ago he decided to write it as a play because it was be coming too intellectual and philosophical.

title: SOVIET MISSILE SUB ON ATLANTIC POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The Defense Department said today that a Soviet missile carrying submarine was pa trolling in the Atlantic.

title: Pola Negri's Memoirs: Best Roles Were Played in Real Life
description: IN the nineteensixties, mov ie actresses were semi hippies, like Mia Farrow. In the fifties and forties, they were girlsnextdoor, smiling wholesomely out of the faces of June Allyson and Doris Day. But in the movies' golden era, the thirties and twenties, they were Stars. And in the firmament that in cluded great vamps such as Theda Bara, Nita Naldi and Gloria Swanson, there was no starrier star than Pola Negri.

title: BROOKLYN DIOCESE WARNED ON FUNDS
description: Unless the laity of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn increase their contributions to the parishes and the schools there may be no parochial elementary schools in Brooklyn and Queens within five years, according to the Center for Urban Redevelopment in Edu cation.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Up From the Ashes

title: FRANCO'S FOES MEET WITH BONN OFFICIAL
description: MADRID, April 24Four Spanish opposition figures to day expressed to Foreign Min ister Walter Scheel of West Germany their concern that Spain could become a part of Europe without first achieving moderate liberal reforms.

title: 25 Trackrnen at Yale Quit Penn Relays
description: Twentyfive members of the Yale track team have with drawn from the Penn Relays today and tomorrow at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. Among the group are five blacks, in cluding Kwaku OheneFrem pong, a high hurdler and the team captain, and Don Martin, a sprinter.

title: Mayor Says Hours Of Criminal Judges Are Being Studied
description: Mayor Lindsay said last night that the presiding justices of the two Appellate Divisions of the State Supreme Court were investigating reports that some Criminal Court judges in the city were working on a parttime basis.

title: Investigators Seek Reason For Philippine Plane Blast
description: MANILA, April 23 (Reuter) An explosion that ripped off the tail section of a Philippine Air Lines plane in midair, kill ing all 36 persons aboard, could have been the work of a passenger intent on suicide, civil aviation investigators said here today.

title: CITY OPENS STUDY OF POLICING POLICE
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of a special fiveman committee to review the city's procedures for investigating police corruption.

title: KENNEDY URGES RELEASE OF DATA
description: BOSTON, April 23Senator Edward M. Kennedy asked the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court today to order released for public examination the original transcript and report of the Mary Jo Kopechne in quest.

title: TRAINING CENTER ORDERED EVICTED
description: An eviction order was signed yesterday against the Univer sity of the Streets, the Lower East Side training school and daycare center, for failure to pay $5,000 in back rent.

title: ARMS RECEIVED, CAMBODIANS SAY; ORIGIN IS IN DOUBT
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 23Informed Cambodian sources reported today that their country had received shipment of weapons for its underequipped army, which has been striving to check ad vances by Vietnamese Commu nist troops.

title: New Ailey Work Introduced By His Dancers in Brooklyn
House Adds to Space Fund Despite Strong Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Despite unexpected strength from opponents of the space program, the House supported today a proposal to give the space agency more money than President Nixon requested.

title: Hanoi's Chief at Talks to Leave; Vietcong Aide May Also Depart
description: PARIS, April 23Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief negotia tor at the peace talks here, is expected to return to Hanoi in a few days, and the Vietcong delegation hinted today that its leader, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, might also leave Paris.

title: Howe Sound Fishing Curbed
description: VANCOUVER, April 23 (AP)  The Canadian Government has ordered a section of Brit ish Columbia's Howe Sound closed to sport fishing because traces of mercury have been discovered in the water. Fisher ies Minister, Jack Davis, said the mercury had been found in effluent from the plant of F.M.C. Chemicals Ltd.

title: Berlin Rolls a 2,004 Total To Lead A.B.C. All Events
description: KNOXSVILLE, Tenn., April 23 (UPI)  Mike Berlin of Muscatine, Iowa, shot a 647 in doubles and a 669 in singles today to take first place in the regular division all events in the American Bowling Congress tournament at 2004.

title: Eastern Drops Plan to Cancel NewarkWashington Air Shuttle
description: Bowing to heavy pressure from New Jersey Congressmen, Eastern Airlines announced yes terday that it had cancelled plans to end NewarktoWash ington flights on its air shuttle service.

title: $39Million Deficit One of Biggest Recorded by an Airline
description: In one of the largest quar terly losses ever reported by an airline, Trans World Air lines announced yesterday that it had a loss of $39,770,000 in the first quarter of 1970, com pared with a loss of $14,911, 000 in the same period last year.

title: Aquatic Park for Ohio
description: SAN DIEGO, April 23 (UPI) A twoton killer whale, an elephant seal, 8 dolphins, 12 sea lions, 4 harbor seals, 10 flamingos, 5 swans, 19 pen guins, 2,000 carp and a host of other marine animals leave Sunday by jet freighter for their new land  locked home. Sea World of Ohio, Sea World of San Diego will open the aquatic park in Aurora, Ohio, on May 29.

title: New Travelers Corp. Listing
description: The Travelers Corporation, the Hartford Insurance concern, listed its stock on the Pacific Coast Exchange yesterday. It is already on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Chicago

title: Ibos Live in Enugu Offices, Awaiting Old Employers
description: ENUGU, Nigeria, April 8  Lawrence Chibiko, a 29year old Ibo with a fierce pride but no money, is camping out in a bulletscarred office building here, waiting to get his old job back.

title: Brazil Tops U.S. in Opener Of World Title Roller Hockey
description: SAN JAUN, Argentina, April 23 (AP)   Italy defeated Japan, 103, and Brzil downed the United States, 73, today, completing the first round of the 29th world roller skate hockey championship.

title: Cambodia to Admit Saigon Unit For Repatriation of Vietnamese
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (UPI)  Cambodia agreed today to admit a South Vietnamese Red Cross delega tion this weekend to start the repatriation of 600,000 Viet namese.

description: Indochina Formula

description: There were some obvious and notsoobvious results of the city's first Earth Day.

description: FICTION

title: Young Ben Barnes, Top Texas VoteGetter, Broadens His Political Horizon
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 21  A young Texas politician named Ben Barnes will make speeches during the next six months in Alaska, Illinois, Ohio, Colorado, New York and half a dozen other states.

title: Poodle Goes to Girls' School
description: DETROIT (AP)Taffy, goes to school witch the girls at Bloomfield Country Day School. She is the French poodle be longing to Miss Marjorie Sallie, the headmaster.

title: GENEVA ARMS TALKS TO RECESS THURSDAY
description: GENEVA, April 23  The United States and the Soviet Union today submitted to the Geneva Disarmament Confer ence a revised draft treaty for the banning of nuclear weap ons on the ocean floor under which countries not possessing those weapons would be ac corded special treatment.

title: Gains by Rojas Are Shaking the Colombian Elite
description: BOGOTA, April 22On a cold afternoon 11 years ago, the Colombian Senate censured a retired lieutenant general as un fit because of his misconduct in the presidency of the re public.

title: Juilliard Chooses Stravinsky Opener
description: THE Juilliard Theater was inaugurated last night with a performance of Igor Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress, and now Lincoln Center stands complete. This little theater, seating about 1,000, but possessed of every stage facility known to cur rent technology, is a little jewelthe handsomest and most tasteful of all of the Lincoln Center auditoriums.

title: Parents at Washington High Reject Table Plan
description: A parent group that has been demanding a grievance table for students at George Wash ington High School, yesterday rejected a plan for such a table announced on Wednesday by the Board of Education.

title: Quake Injures 6 in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 23 (Reuters)A new earthquake shook western Turkey today, injuring 6 persons, destroying 200 houses and toppling the minarets of 5 mosques. The in jured were taken to a hospital in Demirci, 40 miles west of Gediz, where an earthquake three weeks ago killed 1,087 persons and leveled the town.

title: Mrs. Ruth S. Tatar Is Remarried Here
description: The marriage of Mrs. Ruth Starr Tatar, a lawyer with the office of the Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, to Bennet H. Korn, a communications consultant and former president of Met romedia's television division, took place here yesterday.

title: Environmental Watchdog for State
description: AS New York State's first Commissioner of Envi ronmental Conservation, Hen ry L. Diamond is in the envi able position of being a public official riding a cresting wave of public enthusiasm for his specialty.

title: General Dynamics Loses Plea For Rise in F111 Progress Pay
description: The Air Force yesterday re jected a request from the Gen eral Dynamics Corporation for about $40million more in pro gress payments for F111 planes completed since an accident grounded the fleet in Decem ber.

title: MARTHA JOWYK WINS IN FIGURE SKATING
description: Long Island Figure Skating Club members took the top four places of the 6to 9yearold division of the special juvenile girls' event of the Middle At lantic States championship yes terday at Sky Rink, 33d Street land 10th Avenue.

title: London Dockers End Curb
description: LONDON, April 23 (AP) yesterday to lift their 18 month ban on handling giant new containers, ending a dis pute that had threatened to cut off London as a container port. The decision came after an agreement had been reached on pay and working conditions.

title: Upstate G.I. Dies in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Army Spec ialist 4 Richard H. Ward of Philadelphia, N.Y., had been killed in action in Vietnam.

title: Bridge:
description: ONLY one partnership from the New York area will be among the American rep resentatives in the World Pair Championship in Stockholm in June.

title: Panther Organizer Convicted of Slaying Man Unknown to Him
description: An organizer of the New York branch of the Black Pan ther party was convicted yes terday of having shot to death a stranger on an East Bronx street last year in a case of mistaken identity.

title: Wagner College Dean Held 7 Hours by 30 Students Demanding Increased Black Studies
description: Thirty black students at Wag ner College on Staten Island held the dean of the college captive in his office for more than seven and a half hours yesterday to press their de mands for an increased black andPuertoRicanstudies pro gram.

title: 4Day Music Festival Starts Ran in Harlem
description: A fourday music festival sponsored by the Harlem Jazz Music Center began last night and will continue through the weekend as one of the musical events mark ing April Is Jazz month.

title: Soviet Names 10 for Forum Here
description: MOSCOW, April 23  The Soviet Union today made pub lic the names of its 10man delegation that will take part in a public discussion with American public figures next week in New York.

title: GOVERNOR SCORED BY 3 CANDIDATES
description: The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor, in their debate last night, attacked Governor Rock efeller far more vigorously than they criticized each other.

title: British Budget
description: There were tunes of glory in Great Britain last week when the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Roy Jenkins, stood in the well of the House of Commons, bearing his budget in the same battered red dispatch case once carried by Gladstone.

title: Wallace on Attack As Race Intensifies
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 23George C. Wallace, who ran for President knowing he would not win, entered this state's Democratic gubernatori al primary believing he could not lose. Now, 10 days before the election, there are indications that he has changed his mind.

title: 'Early Works,' Yugoslav Romanticism
description: "SO MY FILM is about the impossibility of changing the world by romantic means . . . ," but it is a romantic film nonetheless, an evocation of lucid idealism and of a dim reality that turns everything to confusion and defeat, but that does not lose its hold upon the imagination. "Early Works" is the first feature of Zelimir Zilnik, Yugoslav, not yet 30, revolutionary, and with the sense to know from what, as well as for what, he speaks.At one point he even has somebody cry "Down with Romantics!," but the scene belies the sentiment: a broad calm river, a drifting raft, the early mista little like the great farewell to the River Po in Bernardo Bertolucci's "Before the Revolution," another young man's movie about the futilityand beautyof romantic means. And once he holds his camera, for maybe 10 whole secconds on his sleeping heroine's profile, an enraptured, reticent and wholly romantic homage to her breathtaking and challenging beauty.Her name is Yugoslavia, and together with three males shouting slogans and even conversing in aphorisms ("additional dialogue by Marx and Engels"), she sets out to persuade the peasants that the world must change. The four comrades fail, and as their revolutionary play grows more serious, it also becomes a self-destructive testing of intent, ending in a real killing and immolation for which all the practice, the "political theater" of Molotov cocktails and torture games, has been a preparation.In style, "Early Works" resembles middle-period Jean-Luc Godard, looking a bit like "Band of Outsiders," and sounding a bit like "La Chinoise." In its borrowings, and in its many (sometimes academic) technical excesses, it is clearly a young man's movie. But Zilnik has managed to fuse his insights and his imitations into a form of personal expression that is often deeply moving and is always under conscious and complex control. The film builds upon a series of rhetorical positions  but for each, there is a point of view that transforms didacticism into drama.None of the performers seems especially distinguished, except for Milja-Vujanovic (Yugoslavia), but when she is on the screen it is really difficut to look at anybody else. In a sense the film is a tribute to her beauty, her toughness, her navet, her pathos. She is, of course, a heroine of a picaresque romance that is disguised as diatribe, and emerges finally as tragedy.I liked "Early Works" when it played last fall in the Museum of Modern Art's Yugoslav series. Seeing it again, at its commercial opening at the Bleecker Street Evergreen Cinema, I like it even more.

title: City Workers Strike in Italy
description: ROME, April 23 (Reuters) Traffic became chaotic and garbage rotted in the streets of major Italian cities today as 600,000 municipal employes continued a 48hour strike for more pay and administrative reforms. Motorists took advan tage of the absence of traffic policemen to disobey parking restrictions, clogging the streets of Rome, and residents threw their garbage into the streets.

title: WHITE SOX SCORE OVER TWINS, 7 TO 5
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 23 (AP)  Bobby Knoop's iomer and a tworun throwing error by the Minnesota relief pitcher, Ron Perranoski, Drought the Chicago White Sox 75 victory today, ending a Twins' winning streak at four games.

title: Dame Adeline Genee Dies at 92; A Leading British Ballet Figure
description: LONDON, April 23Dame Adeline Gene a celebrated dancer who helped to found modern Birtish ballet, died to day at Esher, Surrey, at the age of 92.

title: 2 Children Badly Beaten; Bronx Stepfather Seized
description: A 26yearold grocery clerk from the Bronx was arrested last night after he allegedly beat his two stepchildrena 6 yearold girl and her 4yearold brotherso severely that they were hospitalized in serious condition with welts and bruises.

title: Brandt Note Emphasizes Desire for Ties With Poles
description: BONN, April 23Chancellor Willy Brandt has written to the Polish Communist leader, Wladslaw Gomulka, to under line the West German Gov ernment's earnestness in seek ing normal relations with Po land, it was disclosed today.

title: OFFICIALS OF SEEK DISPUTE AID TOTAL
description: A group of directors of the City University's SEEK pro gram yesterday challenged an Assemblyman's report that an $18million package had been negotiated in Albany for the program's 197071 fiscal year.

title: Campaign Littering Scored
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday scored the practice of plaster ing campaign stickers and post ers to buildings, lampposts, mailboxes and other public fix tures. The Mayor appealed to all candidates to help us pre serve the good looks of our city by prohibiting their cam paign organizations from en gaging in the illegal practice.

title: Perot on Annapolis Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) H. Ross Perot, the Texas mil lionaire who has been active in efforts to aid prisoners of war in North Vietnam, was ap pointed by President Nixon Wednesday as a member of the board of visitors of the United States Naval Academy.

title: U.A.R. Planes Attack Foe
description: CAIRO, April 23  Egyptian fighterbombers carried out midnight raid last night against Israeli military positions about 60 miles east of the Suez Canal, Cairo's military spokesman re ported today.

title: Bishops, Ending Parley, Pledge $50Million to Combat Poverty
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church ended a threeday meeting today by narrowly defeating a motion to open portions of future sessions to the press and other observ ers.

title: Luncheon Aiding Eight Charities Planned for May 5
description: The 40th annual luncheon in aid of the eight charitable organizations that benefit from sales at the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the WaldorfAstoria on May 5.

title: ZERO AND ROSSMOOR END MERGER TALKS
description: The negotiations for the Zero Manufacturing Company to acquire the Rossmoor Corpora tion, a privately held company in Laguna Hills, Calif., have been terminated, both com panies announced yesterday.

title: China Scores Soviet Policy In 4th Attack in a Week
description: PEKING, April 23  Com munist China strongly attacked Moscow's economic policies today with an article declaring that the Soviet economy had been brought to the brink of ruin by Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid. I. Brezhney.

title: Methodists Send 9Church Merger Plan to Members for Study
description: ST. LOUIS, April 23The 11 millionmember United Meth odist Church became today the first Protestant denomination to transmit formally to its con stituency a plan of union that would merge nine churches into a single denomination of some 25million members.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Card of Chanks
description: COOPERJack L. The family of Mr. Jack L. Cooper wishes to express their gratitude for the thoughtfulness and kidness in our hour of sorrow.
