title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW WEAKNESS
description: Hesitancy on the part of dealers because of the immi nence of the Government's re port on stocks caused grain and soybean butures to turn gener ally weak yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Huey Newton Denied Parole
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., April 23 (AP)Huey P. New ton, cofounder of the Black Panther party, has been denied parole for the second time, the California Adult Authority re ports. Newton, 28 years old, is serving a 2to15year sentence at the Los Padres Men's Colony here on a manslaughter convic tion involving the 1967 shoot ing of an Oakland policeman, John Frey. The parole board heard his case last week and the rejection was announced yesterday.

title: 3 in House Accuse Interior Agency of Mine Laxity
description: WASHINGTON, April 23A bitter controversy between members of the House and Secretary of the Interior Wal ter J. Hickel intensified today over the Interior Department's alleged inconsistency and in action in enforcing new Fed eral safety standards for coal miners.

title: Washington: President Nixon's Fair Solution
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  In his latest report on the war in Vietnam, President Nixon said: A fair political solution should reflect the existing re lationship of political forces within South Vietnam. We rec ognize the complexity of shap ing machinery that would fairly apportion political power in South Vietnam. We're flexible. We have offered nothing on a take it or leave it basis.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment stbre sales at $667million, up 3 per cent from the year earlier $649million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $6,840,000,000, up 3 per cent from $6,657,000,000.

title: Leary's Bail Plea Rejected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP)The California Supreme Court denied without comment yesterday Timothy Leary's peti tion that he be freed on bail pending appeal of his convic tion for possession of mari juana. The former Harvard Uni versity lecturer has been con fined since February at the California Institute for Men at Chino on a sentence of one to two years.

title: Dust Commander, $72.80, Captures Blue Grass With Rally in Mud
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 Dust Commander kicked mud into the eyes of eight rivals in the $32,975 Blue Grass Stakes today at Keeneland.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS POPULAR ELECTION OF THE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The plan to replace the Elec toral College with direct popu lar election of the President won the grudging approval of the Senate Judiciary Committee today and moved toward final floor vote.

title: Seaman Is Cleared Of Urging Sedition; Guilty on 2 Counts
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) A Navy court found Seaman Roger Lee Priest not guilty of the most serious accusations against him tonight but found him guilty on two counts of promoting disloyalty and dis affection among servicemen.

title: ARMS DELEGATES OUTLINE POSITIONS
description: VIENNA, April 23The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union continued to outline their posi tions on the limitation of stra tegic arms today as their chief delegates met for an hour and 40 minutes at the Soviet Embassy.

title: HOLLIS STACY, 16, GAINS GOLF FINAL
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP)  Hollis Stacy's putting carried her to a 2and1 vic tory over Connie Day today, and into the final of the North and South amateur golf tour nament against Mrs. Paul Dye, winner by the same score over the defending champion Barba ra McIntire.

title: Big Board to Be Open May 29 but Closed July 3
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to keep the exchange open on Friday, May 29, the day before Memorial Day, but to close on Friday, July 3, the day before Independence Day.

title: 46Foot Boat Built as Hobby
description: TAMPA, Fla. (AP)Ed Rich ards has completed Bolero, a 46foot yacht, 12 years after the plans for the boat were delivered.

title: Environment Chairman
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 23 (AP)Lieut. Gov. Joseph Gar rahy has been chosen chairman of the session on environmental control problems of urban in dustrial areas at the national Lieutenant Governors Confer ence in Atlanta.

title: Advertising: A Shift on Media Ownership
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23The mem bers of the American Associa tion of Advertising Agencies have voted overwhelmingly to allow advertising agencies to own media as well as sup plier companies.

title: Nationalists' Margin Cut in South Africa
description: DURBAN, South Africa, April 23  Tile Nationalist party of Premier John Vorster has been returned to power with a re duced but still overwhelming majority in Parliament.

title: TRUCK TONNAGE OFF 139.5% FROM '69 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 18, still affected by work stoppages throughout the country was considerably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Freight traffic on United States railroads during the same period registered an increase.

title: Tisserant Will Visit U.S.
description: ROME, April 23 (Reuters) Eugene Cardinal Tisserant of France, Dean of the College of Cardinals, will leave here Sat urday for a visit to the United States and Canada that will end May 26, the Vatican an nounced today. His itinerary of several American cities will in clude Chicago.

title: French Launch Challenger For America's Cup Races
description: LA TRINITESURMER, France, April 23 (Reuters)  The France, the French chal lenger in the America's Cup yscht races this summer, was launched in the calm sea at this Brittany port today.

title: Paper Manufacturers List Mixed Results for the First Quarter
description: The slowdown in the nation's economy in the first quarter of 1970 did not have much im pact on the paper industry but some downtrends are begin ning to appear, William R. Adams, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, said yes terday at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Hanoi Charges U.S. Planes Raided the North on Sunday
description: TOKYO, April 23 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that the United States carried out fresh air raids on a num ber of populated areas in North Vietnam on Sunday.

title: Smith Stands Out In Trot Directory As Winning Driver
Addonizio Loses Fight on Grand Jury's Censure
description: TRENTON, April 23Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark lost his bid today to have all references to him removed from a grand jury presentment that censured the city for its toler ance of widespread gambling.

title: Trinidad Presses Mutiny Talks As Dissidents Are Rounded Up
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 23The Government of Trinidad and Tobago pressed its negotiations today with a hold out faction of blackpower ad vocates in the armed forces who mutinied on Tuesday. At the same time, the police con tinued to round up antiGov ernment activists.

title: Market Place
description: OUTSPOKEN Howard Butch er 3rd was as bullish as a cowcatcher on Penn Central stock in January when the stock was selling at 29just a couple of points below its 19691970 low.

title: Foreign Affairs: Bringing the Boys Back Horne
description: PARIS The great American troop withdrawal from foreign parts appears irreversible, un less wholly unexpected crises come, and affects both East and West. Over a hundred thousand soldiers have already left Viet nam and President Nixon prom ises to take away another 150, 000 within a year.

title: BondMarket Prices Are Down Again
description: The bond market took it on the chin again yesterday, al though there were few declines as severe as were recorded on Wednesday.

title: NIXON AIDES SPLIT ON CAMBODIA ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon is struggling with a decision on further mil itary aid to Cambodia in terms that at least some of his ad visers portray as fateful.

title: Second Judgment
description: Shifting rapidly to a target of opportunity following his nomination and rejection for the Supreme Court, Judge G. Harrold Carswell has resigned from the United States Court of Appeals to run for the Senate. He has of course, every right to leave the bench, he wishes, and seek a seat alongside the majority Senators who snurned him for the hieh court.

title: 2 Films by Marco Ferrari To Be Shown at Museum
description: Dillinger Is Dead (Dil linger e Morto), an Italian film drama, will have its first local showing at 8 P.M. tomor row at a special screening at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Miss Howland Plans Nuptials
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 23 John Patridge Howland, president of West PointPep perell, Inc., the textile con cern, and Mrs. Howland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Briggs Howland, to Peter Norris Pund, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. R. Pund.

title: Street Phones Working Once Again
description: Suddenly and surprisingly, more street phones are start ing to work.

title: Campus Woes Make Martin Dubious on Track Future
description: NEW HAVEN, April 23Don Martin, one of 25 Yale athletes who withdrew from the Penn Relays, said today, The rest of the track season is in doubt for me.

title: STEELPLANT MERGER ANNOUNCED BY BONN
description: BONN, April 23West Ger many's merger carousel took another spin today as the Gov ernment announced the amal gamation of the Salzgitter steel works and Ilseder Hte, another steel plant, into the country's thirdlargest steel concern.

title: W.H.O. Report Deplores Lag In Environment Safeguards
description: GENEVA, April 23Dr. Mar colino G. Candau of Brazil, Director General of the World Health Organization, today de plored man's failure to match his progress in medioine with an improvement in the quality of his environment.

title: N.B.A. IS REALIGNED INTO FOUR DIVISIONS
description: The hoard of governors of the National Basketball Asso ciation realigned yesterday the league's 17 teams for next sea son at the Hotel Roosevelt. The league owners had previously realigned the association's two divisions into four sections at a meeting in Chicago on March 16.

title: MRS. E. C. HAMMOND OF CHURCH AGENCIES
description: Mrs. Marian Thomas Ham mond, wife of Dr. E. Cuyler Hammond, vice president for epidemiology and statistics of the American Cancer Society, died yesterday at her home. She was 47 years old and lived at 164 East 72d Street.

title: Cynthia Alley, W. H. Andrews Plan to Marry
description: Miss Cynthia Alley plans to be married in July to Woodbury H. Andrews, a cum laude graduate of Princeton University, of which his fi ancee's ancestor, Jonathan Dickinson, was the first pres ident. The university was known then as the College of New Jersey.

title: Yankees Overcome Senators, 116, on 15 Hits as Cumberland Wins in Relief
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The management of the Sena tors had every excuse for call ing off tonight's game this aft ernoon, when it was raining like mad.

title: GOVERNOR IS SAID TO BACK BADILLO
description: Governor Rockefeller is back ing Herman Badillo, former Bor ough President of the Bronx and a Democrat, as the Repub lican nominee for United States Representative from the 21st District, political sources said yesterday.

title: KNICKS START BID FOR TITLE TONIGHT
description: Basketball's world series, the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, begins tonight at Madison Square Garden with the New York Knickerbockers facing the Los Angeles Lakers in the first contest of a fouroutofseven game series.

title: Money Market Becomes Tighter, But Reserve Policy Is Steady
description: The New York money market was sharply tighter this week, banking data published yester day showed. But even so, it appeared that the Federal Re serve System had not modified its basic policy of encouraging modest monetary expansion despite increasing concern within the central bank over the position of the Federal budget.

title: Argentine General Strike Brings Nation Almost to Halt
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 23  A general strike call supported by all six warring factions of Argentina's organized labor movement brought industry throughout the country nearly to a halt today.

title: Met and City Opera Take Stock of Past Season
description: During its curtailed 85th season, which ended Satur day, the Metropolitan Opera played to an estimated 90 to 92 per cent of capacity. Its neighbor at Lincoln Center, the New York City Opera, which closed its 51st season on Sunday, played to an estimated total of 95 to 97 per cent of capacity. Al though these are not final figures, officials of both com panies feel certain that they are close to the correct.

title: '70 City Auto Forecast: 90,000 Will Be Stolen
description: One of every 20 cars in New York City will be stolen this year, according to offi cials who have tried without much success to curb the ris ing number of automobile thefts.

title: 4 Concerns List Drops
description: Three major aerospace com panies reported sharp declines yesterday in firstquarter prof its. A fourth, meanwhile, re ported a strong drop in profits for the second quarter.

title: Drawing a Crowd With Sewing Demonstrations
description: THE doors at B. Altman & Co. had barely swung open yesterday when the women came swarming up to the fifth floor. Teenagers. Moms. Greatgreatgrandmothers. They were all there for what was billed as a SewIn. There was no sewing on their part, however. The Sew In, which continues in the store's fabrics department through Saturday, is mainly a series of sewing demon strations by experts from fabric, pattern, and sewing machine companies.

title: Enemy Downs 12 U.S. Aircraft in 2 Days
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (AP)Enemy gunners in Laos and South Vietnam shot down 12 American air craft t in a twoday period this week, the United States com mand said today.

title: GREYHOUND ASKING I.C.C. TO LIFT CURBS
description: The Greyhound Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had petitioned the Interstate Com merce Commission to recon sider a restrictive order issued against the company early this month.

title: Roland Wank, Chief Architect Of T.V.A. in Early Years, Dies
description: Roland A. Wank, head archi tect of the Tennessee Valley Authority from 1933 to 1944, who designed towns, public housing projects and many im portant buildings, died Wednes day of cancer in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 35 Highview Ave nue. New Rochelle. N. Y. Mr. Wank was a partner in Wank Adams Slavin &

title: WILLIAM T. EYJUE, WISCONSIN EDITOR
description: MADISON, Wis., April 23 William T. Evjue, founder, pub lisher and editor of The Capital Times, died here early today. He was 87 years old.

title: THEODORAKIS WORK FOUND ON NAPKINS
description: ATHENS, April 23  An unfinished manuscript on Byzantine music, written on paper napkins by the Greek composer, Mikis Theodorakis, was found this week at the prison camp where he had spent six months before his unexpected release 10 days a co.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN his first novel, Lie Down in Me, Andrew Jolly tells the story of a young Mexican cabrero who has rebelled against his family, community, and church by marrying a Yaqui Indian girl and living with her in the mountains. At the start of the story the girl dies of a mysterious tumor, and in the course of what follows the cabrero suffers miserably to give her a proper burial. He doesn't quite succeed, but in the process of trying he achieves a heroism that has meaning far beyond the mere fact of his efforts

title: Average Buyer Paid 8.51% in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The cost of buying a home continued its steady push up ward in March despite some recent pauses in other interest rate increases and a promising improvement in available loan money, the Government report ed today.

title: Wellington Fund Elects Chairman
description: The election of John C. Bogle as chairman of the boards of the Wellington Fund and the Windsor Pund, mutual funds with combined assets of more than $1.7 billion, was announced yester day in Philadelphia.

title: Bill Rates Register an Advance At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Treasure bill rates advanced at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Subway Plans Test of Energy Storing
description: A system that stores the energy of a moving subway train as it helps bring the train to a halt, then uses the stored energy to help the train start up agan may be tested on the city's subway system as a way of reducing electric bills.

title: Hickel to Approve Alaska Oil Pipeline With Safeguards
description: COLLEGE, Alaska, April 23 The Secretary of the Interi or, Walter J. Hickel, said last night that he would issue rightofway permit for con struction of an 800mile oil pipeline across Alaska.

title: COUNTER STOCKS AND AMEX DOWN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthe counter market took another pounding yesterday in compar atively quiet trading.

title: Red Reality Beats Crack Ruler by Head at Aqueduct
description: Thtee eligibles for the $50, 000 added Carter Handicap which will be contested at Aqueduct a week from tomor row, and a naneligible for that fixture, who had won five of his six 1970 starts, were among the six principals yesterday in the Big A's featured Sailor Handicap.

title: STOCKS AND BONDS DECLINE IN LONDON
Executive Changes
description: Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been elected a director of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation.

title: PROFITS DOWN 7% IN FIRST QUARTER
Soviet Orbits Cosmos 334
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched its Cosmos 334 satellite into orbit around the earth today, the So viet press agency Tass said. The satellite was reported in an orbit ranging from 160 to 305 miles above earth. Tass said the satellite was making one trip around the globe every 99.1 minutes at an inclination of 71 degrees to the Equator.

title: VON BRAUN BRIEFS PUBLISHER GROUP
description: American space plans for a grand tour of outer planets call for two space craft to be spun off the gravitational field of Jupiter as a booster, Dr. Wernher von Braun told the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday.

title: Building Unions Endorse Rockefeller
description: Governor Rockefeller won the support yesterday of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York in his hid for a fourth term.

title: Battle for Saang: A Soldier Hugs the Earth in Fear
description: SAANG, Cambodia, April 23 (AP)  Pvt. Kong Deth hugged his AK47 rifle and pressed close to the sun baked earth. He was afraid.

title: DOW LOSES 12.02, FALLS TO 750.99
description: The stock market plunged through the 760 support level in the opening halfhour yes terday and kept moving down ward to close at 750.59. Despite an abortive attempt to rally at the noon hour, the market continued in the vein of the last two weeks by sink ing a whopping 12.02 points, as measured by the DowJones in dustrial average.

title: Yale Faculty Rejects Proposal to Cancel All Classes to Support Panthers
description: NEW HAVEN, April 23The undergraduate faculty of Yale University tonight rejected a proposal by black professors to cancel all classes next week in sympathy with a student strike supporting the Black Panthers who are aawaiting trial here, a university spokesman said.

title: U.S SEEKS TO BAR AN ACQUISITION
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Justice Department an nounced today its intention to file suit to block the planned acquisition of the American Credit Corporation by the Wachovia Corporation.

title: Paisley Rebuked for Speech
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 (Reuters)The Rev. Ian Paisley, a militant opponent of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority, was ruled out of order in his first speech as a member of Northern Ire land's Parliament today. A per sonal attack by Mr. Paisley on the Minister of Commerce, Roy Bradford, drew a rebuke from the Deputy Speaker, Walter Scott, who told him to try and relate your remarks to the busi.

title: Sohio Prospects Bright
description: For followers of oil industry fortunes, the news was mixed yesterday.

title: Israelis Arrest Briton, 72, As a Spy for Egyptians
description: TEL AVIV, April 23 (Reu ters)A 72yearold Briton has been arrested here on suspicion of saving spied for the United Arab Republic, it was disclosed today.

title: Vietcong Mission Elevated
description: CAIRO, April 23 (Reuters) The United Arab Republic has agreed to raise the diplo matic representation here of the Vietcongsponsored pro visional revolutionary govern ment in South Vietnam to am bassadorial level, it was an nounced today.

title: West Virginia Crash Kills 5
description: JESSE, W. Va, April 23 (UPI)Five youths were killed today when their automobile went off a road near this south ern West Virginia community and struck a tree. The victims were identified as Alan Shrews bury, 18 years old, the driver, Philip Greer, 17, Arthur Jude, 18, Douglas Hall, 16, and Steve Tilley, 15, all of Glen Fork, W. Va.

title: Everest Team in Third Camp
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 23 (Reuters)The Japanese Alpine Club's expedition to Mount Ev erest established its third camp at 22,730 feet last Friday, ac cording to a report received here today by the Nepalese Foreign Ministry.

title: Glastron Offers Cruises as Incentive
description: MONEY, believe it or not, doesn't make it any more at least not as a sales incentive. The old green stuff that used to turn on boat dealers and their salesmen now leaves them with a yawn and a so what else is new? The reason is sim ple: Like too much of a good thing, money's been overdone. How do you give incentive to successful deal ers and sales men who aren't looking for extra dollars? That's the problem the Glastron Boat Company of Austin, Tex., had back in 1967.

title: Knick Fans Sweep Up Playoff Tickets in Fast Break
description: In the sort of mob scene that establishes an event's status, angers fans and warms the heart of any promoter's accountant, the New York Knickerbockers sold out their remaining playoff tickets yes terday before the hour that had been officially set for the beginning of the sale.

title: Poor Families Taking over Condemned Buildings
description: The family trudged like refugees yesterday through the chill rain up Columbus Avenue, the man with a vac uum cleaner over his shoulder, the gaunt woman cradling a yearold daughter wrapped in faded scarves, a small boy, walking along by her side.

title: New Post for Educator
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 23 (AP)  Dr. S. Thomas Greenburg, president of Incarnate Word College since 1960, has submitted his resignation to become director of the Institute of Catholic Higher Education. His resignation, announced yester day, is effective Jan. 1, 1971.

title: Diversified Concern Sets New High in Earnings and Volume
2 ISRAELIS KILLED ON VISIT TO GOLAN
description: JERUSALEM, April 23 Two Israeli civilians touring the occupied Golan heights were killed today and five others were wounded when infiltrators from Syria am bushed their cars on a main road less than a mile from the 1967 ceasefire line.

title: Mrs. Greitzer Expands Discrimination Drive
description: Councilman Carol Greitzer extended her campaign against sex discrimination yesterday by introducing a bill that would forbid the city from doing business with companies that discriminate against women in hiring and promotion practices.

title: Priest Seeks U.S Senate Nomination in Rhode Island
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 For what is believed to be the first time in American political history, a Roman Catholic priest is running for the United States Senate.

title: Chavez Supporters Schedule A March on Capitol in May
description: DELANO, Calif., April 24A spokesman for the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee announced today that supporters of Cesar Cha vez, the farm union organizer, had scheduled a threeday march on the nation's capitol for May 1 through 3.

title: MRS. FELIX JANKE
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 24 Mrs. Cecelia Schenck Janke, a former trustee of Rutgers University died today in Muhl enherg Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 203 West Ninth Street. Mrs. Janke was the widow of Felix Janke, an insurance agent.

title: Brooklyn Man Shot by Policeman After Shooting 2d Patrolman
description: A 29yearold Brooklyn man was killed by a policeman early this morning after he al legedly wounded another po liceman with the latter's own gun.

title: Senate Aide Calls Guarantees In F  111 Contract Ineffective
description: WASHINGTON, April 24A Senator investigator contended today that contract guaran tees' on performance of the F111 attack plane were unen forceable and that defens offi cials never had any intention of making the manufacturer comply strictly with require ments.

title: Aetna Life and Casualty Lifts Earnings in Quarter
description: Aetna Life and Casualty reported yesterday that net earnings in the first quarter rose to $19.7million, or 74 cent a share, from the yearearlier $9.4million, or 35 cents a share Olcott D. Smith, chairman, cau tioned that three months was too short a period to indicate a trend, but he noted that casual ty and property coverage con tributed about $6million to earnings in contrast to a loss of $2.5million a year before.

title: City Ballet Performances For Weekend Are Canceled
description: Weekend performances by the New York City Ballet have been canceled as a result of the fivedayold strike by the company's orchestra.

title: Taiwan Silent on Shooting
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan Saturday, April 25 (UPI)  The Govern ment of Nationalist China with held immediate comment on attempted assassination of Dep uty premier Chiang ChingKuo in New York City. Neither newspapers nor radio and tele vision broadcasters mentioned the attempt.

title: MISS STACY BEATS MRS. DYE, 6 AND 4
description: PINEHURST, N.C., April 24 (AP)  Hollis Stacy won the first two holes and went on to defeat Mrs. Paul Dye, 6 and 4, in the final of the North and South women's amateur tour nament.

title: Grote Goes to Hospital
description: Jerry Grote, who had been complaining of chills for sev eral days, was examined in the clubhouse before the game by Dr. Robert Woods, the Dodgers' physician. He was found to have a temperature of 103 de grees and was sent to St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica where Bill Singer of the Dodg ers has been under treatment for hepatitis.

title: Cambodians Fear a Big Drive by Foe
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24High military sources re ported today that there was a greatly increasing number of local attacks by the enemy throughout the frontier regions occupied by the Vietnamese Communists. They expressed concern that the enemy might be preparing an offensive de signed to divide Cambodia in two. Enemy raids were reported in the last 24 hours in all sectors east of an axis running from the southern town of Kompot through Takeo, Prey and Chup to the northernmost prov ince of Ratanakiri, which is mountainous, and sparsely pop ulated and has long been a cen ter of heavy Vietnamese Com munist infiltration.

title: Sisco Returns Home
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Mr. Sisco returned from his tour of the Israeli and Arab capitals tonight, expressing his concern that neither side was yet willing to make the con cessions necessary for peace.

title: Leander Wins at Sandown
description: SANDOWN, England, April 24 (Reuters)Leander, the fa vorite, owned by Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N.J., was an impressive winner of the Tudor Stakes for 3year olds today. Leander, ridden by Lester Piggott, won the 1,775 first prize by beating Mrs. G. Harriss's SolArge by four lengths. Wabash, also owned by Engelhard, finished third in the 27horse field.

title: JOHN J. SULLIVAN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 24John J. Sullivan, a senior partner in the law firm of Hirschberg, Pettengill & Strong, died after a heart attack last night at Greenwich Hospital. He lived at 31 Anderson Road, Milbrook, and was 51 years old.

title: ACTIVITY IS SLOW IN NEW OFFERINGS
description: The newissue market did practically no business at all this week as 14 companies postponed their public offer ings because of depressed mar ket conditions.

title: BECKETT IS FOCUS OF SHOW IN PARIS
description: PARIS, April 24Beginning to End, an anthology of the works of Samuel Beckett, edited and performed as a oneman show by the Irish character comedian Jack McGowran, had its world premiere at the Theatre Edouard VII last night.

title: Israeli Jets Attack in Egypt, Jordan and Syria
description: JERUSALEM, April 24Is raeli jets attacked Egyptian, Jordanian and Syrian targets today in one of the most wide ranging aerial assaults since the sixday war of June, 1967.

title: 2 SHARE LEAD AT 138 IN TALLAHASSEE GOLF
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 24 (UPI)Jack McGowan and Bobby Greenwood, a tour rookie, shared of the 36hole lead in the Tallahassee open golf tournament today with sixunderpar 138's.

title: Article 5  No Title
Coast Guard Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) President Nixon nominated Rear Adm. Thomas R. Sargeant 3d today to be assistant com mandant of the Coast Guard, succeeding the retiring Vice Adm. Paul E. Trimble. The 55 yearold Admiral Sargeant, the announcement said, will be pro moted to vice admiral when he takes over his new post.

title: Dance: Ashton Variations
description: THE saddest aspect of the I present Royal Ballet sea son at the Metropolitan Opera Houseindeed, perhaps, the only sad aspectis that it marks the last time we will see Sir Frederick Ashton at the head of the company.

title: RECRUITING OFFICE DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: An explosion rocked an Army and Air Force recruiting office on the second floor of a Harlem office building late yesterday afternoon, but four sergeants and a woman enlistee escaped injury.

title: Air Pollution Charged
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) Daniel P. Bartoli, 52 years old, was charged with polluting the air after he was arrested in his North Side apartment as he threw hundreds of pieces of paper from his window. The pieces of paper were records of horse bets, the police said. Mr. Bartoli was charged Thursday with being the keeper of bets and violating the city's air pol lution ordinance.

title: Sports of The Times
description: HORSE RACING was the first organized sport in the New World, the first to be tainted by the fix, the first to be decried from the pulpit. It was stratified early: Laborers could not run their horses against those gentlemen and the first jockeys, like the first professional boxers, fightingcock handlers and competitive oarsmen, were black slaves. When the thoroughbred track became fashionable late in the 19th century, politicians used variously as a place to meet the public, as an issue reform campaigns and as a vested interest willing to pay for legislative protection.

title: STRIKE EXPLAINED BY YALE STUDENTS
description: NEW HAVEN, April 24 About 200 Yale students, fresh ly shorn and attired in clean jeans, ventured into parts of this city today to explain their concern over the impending murder trial of Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party.

title: Satellite's Orbit Refined
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Technicians refined the orbit of the newest communications satellite today. It was launched Wednesday from Cape Kennedy, Fla.

title: Graebner Topples Fairlie; Santana Turns Back Buding
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (UPI) Clark Graebner of New York and Manuel Santana of Spain moved into the semifinals of the $25,000 River Oaks tennis tournament today.

title: Queens to Get New College
description: ALBANY, April 24  The state Board of Regents today gave formal approval to crea tion of a ninth community col lege in New York City. The twoyear college will he in Long Island City, Queens and is scheduled to open in 1971.

title: Barbara Jo Oppenheim To Marry Here June 12
description: Miss Barbara Jo Oppenheim and Geoffrey Case Berresford, teachers at the Collegiate School, will be married here June 12.

title: The Incumbent Politician's Dream
description: LONDON, April 24Late in 1956, after the Conservative Government's disaster at Suez, an American correspondent newly arrived in Britain was talking with Aneurin Bevan, the great leftwing Labor poli tician. How would Labor do in an election today, he asked.

title: Open Politics in U.A.W
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 In the southwest corner of the cavernous Convention Hall here, the fat man and his friends poli ticked furiously but in vain all week against the candidate of the Reuther caucus. But the significance of the fight of Robert (Buddy) Battle 3d for the leadership in Region 1A of of the United Automobile Work ers, on the west side of Detroit, was in the race itself. It was not the only serious fight at the union's convention here this week.

title: Moscow Assails Washington
description: MOSCOW, April 24  The Soviet Union broke its month long silence on events in Cam bodia tonight with a bitter at tack on the United States and a warning that attempts to widen imperialist aggression in South Asia may have most serious consequences.

title: Ancient Trees Cut By Misled Logger
description: MILWAUKEE, April 24 As Wisconsin observed Arbor Day today, Milwaukee County dis covered that one of its choicest woods had been demolished by a misled logger.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series)

title: Article 1  No Title
RICHARD KNOTT, 77; INVESTMENT BANKER
description: GEORGETOWN, Conn., April 24Richard Gillmore Knott, a consultant of Goldmann Sachs & Co., investment bankers, and the publisher and editor of The Louisville (Ky.) Post and Her ald from 1919 to 1929, died to day of a heart ailment at his home here. His age was 77.

title: Penn Central Picketing Ends
description: The Penn Central said yes terday that all operations were proceeding normally at its piggyhack freight yards in the metropolitan area. The railroad had obtained Federal Court order to bar picketing by Local 84 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in connection with a dispute with the rival Brotherhood of Rail way and Airline Clerks over representation of railroad po lice at the yards. Some drivers had been turning away from the yard, though there was no strike.

title: America's Cup Candidate Launched
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 24One roundhouse swing with a bottle of champagne by Mrs. Robert W. McCullough of River side, Conn., and her words, I christen thee Valiant, launched a new America's Cup defense candidate today.

title: Daylight Time to Start In 47 States Tomorrow
description: People who go to bed to night without setting their alarm clocks ahead one hour may be late getting to church or the golf course tomorrow.

title: Wife and Son Visit Hess In Prison for First Time
description: BERLIN, April 24 (AP)  Rudolf Hess today received the first visit from members of his family inside West Berlin's Spandau Prison, where he has been held since 1946.

title: Margaret Bryant to Be Bride Of Arnold Amstutz on June 27
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., April 24  Miss Margaret Louise Bry ant of New York and Arnold Everett Amstutz of Cam bridge, founder and board chairman of Decision Tech nology, plan to be married June 27 at St. Peter's Epis copal Church in Weston.

title: Protesters Begin Sentences
description: WORCESTER, Mass., April 24 (AP)An Assumption College professor and four Clark Uni versity students began serving jail sentences today on trespas sing charges arising from an April 10 sitin at the Worcester Selective Service office. The five are Prof. Michael True of Worcester; serving 20 days; and Victor H. Reinstein, of Winth rop; Glen Rabut and David M. Vogelstein of New York City, and Joshua Miller of Tuckahoe, N. Y., all serving 10 days.

title: Sisco Finds Situation in Mideast Has Not Improved
description: ROME, April 24President Nixon's leading adviser on the Middle East said here today, at the end of a stormy trip through the area, that the chances for peace between Arabs and Israelis had not im proved.

title: Lenin Centenary Program Accorded Mixed Reviews by the Soviet Public
description: MOSCOW, April 24Leonid I. Brezhnev ended his three hour speech on Lenin the other day with the slogan, Lenin lived, Lenin lives and Lenin will live!

title: Rally Leaders Hope for Order
description: NEW HAVEN, April 24 (AP) Organizers of a May 1 rally in support of the Panthers were said today they would do their best to keen order.

title: The Coup de Grace for the Mini?
description: THE big guns of Paris readymade fashion, like Sonia Rykiel and Jean Cacharel, stayed home. The leading American merchants and manufacturers had already been in Paris last week buying or snooping and cribbing tax deductible ideas at the influential prtporter showings.

title: Books of The Times
description: IF you can get by the first 75 pages of Ved Mehta's documentary, you will find yourself in a firstclass book. It is unusually informative and full of pertinent details that Mr. Mehta has expertly manip ulated and arranged to fill out and color the larger picture. It is surprising how, by the end of the book, the Indian continent has managed to assume a knowl edgeable shape and how the prob lems begin to make sense in terms of the peo ple and the land. By quiet and reit erative references to the variety of beliefs, sects and languages, Mr. Mehta conjures up the complexities and the distinc tions that divide this great Asian nation. The solu tioneven to a simple problem  involves sensitive and deeply rooted lines of force. A reader may end up puzzled as to the right answers (like many Indians), but he'll have a good idea of the right questions.

title: FIGHTING REPORTED NEAR ALLIED CAMP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24 (AP)New fighting was reported today near the beleaguered allied camp at Dakseang near the Laotian border.

title: Article 3  No Title
STOCK PRICES RISE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed slightly firmer yesterday following two days of sharp losses.

title: RULES PANEL STAYS STUDY ON DOUGLAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Representative William M. Colmer, chairman of the House Rules Committee sidetracked today for 60 days a bipartisan resolution calling for a study of impeachment proceedings against Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

title: There's a Real Thirst Problem in Arid Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 4 About the most exciting thing to do at night now is to go down to Al Istiqlal Street and look at the thermometer, barometer and hygrometer in the meteorological case, a sunburned American oil driller remarked as he sipped a PepsiCola in the bar of the Tripoli Palace Hotel and wished it was Scotch and water.

title: Japanese Cherry Trees Planted Along Henry Hudson Parkway
description: The first of 344 Japanese cherry trees, their pale pink petals just beginning to appear on slim green branches, were planted along the river edge of the Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday as a gift from the Albert and Mary Lasker Foun dation.

title: SCHOLARS UPSET BY FUND CUTBACK
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Scholars at major American universities fear that the study of some foreign languages and of the history and culture of critical areas will be perma nently damaged if Congress approves the Nixon Administra tion's cuts in the education budget.

title: Europeans Weigh Currency Reform
description: PARIS, April 24It was the end of a cold spring day in Paris as the monetary authori ties of the richest nations dashed from the spacious gal leries of the Chateau de la Muette into their warmedup official cars.

title: Mrs. Jones in Tennis Final
description: SUTTON, England, April 24 (UPI)  Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, the Wimbledon cham pion, and Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia battled their way into the women's final of the Sutton tennis tournament to day with victories over team mates. Mrs. Jones defeated Joyce Williams of Britain, 61, 63, and Mrs. Court stopped Pat Edwards of Australia, 61, 63. They will meet tomorrow for the title.

title: U.S. SUES TO HALT BID BY WACHOVIA
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Justice Department formally filed suit today to prevent the merger of the American Credit Corporation into the Wachovia Corporation.

title: Topics: Science Or Stunts On the Moon?
description: The neardisaster of Apollo 13 has shown that lunar land ings are risky as well as ex pensive. Still I think it can be argued that carefully planned scientific exploration of the moon justifies the outlay. Unfortunately, this is not happening.

title: AGNEW SEES RISE IN CRIME SLOWED
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Vice President Agnew said to night that the rate of increase in street crime had been re duced sharply since the Nixon Administration took office, and he gave the credit to Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: PictureFrame Sketch by Mrs. Onassis Withdrawn From Sale
description: A sketch of a picture frame by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, drawn when she was the wife of President John F. Kennedy, was withdrawn from an auc tion sale Thursday night by order of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

title: Focus of Turmoil in Colombia
description: WHEN Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was the dictator of Colombia 15 years ago, the people told a joke about a visit he made to a strug gling rancher.

title: Demands at Ohio State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 A march on the administra tion building at Ohio State University today by some 400 dissidents was described as peaceful by a school official.

title: POLICE HEAD IS OUT IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 24The city manager of New Rochelle has dismissed Police Commissioner Edward F. Carey, effective midnight tonight.

title: HARRY ARCHER
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 24 Harry Archer, a partner in the law firm of Archer, Leonard & Archer, died yesterday at the United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 64 years old and lived at 20 Old Mamaroneck Road.

title: MRS. GOETZWITTELS
description: Mrs. Poldi GoetzWittels, a former editor of the Western Publishing Company, Inc., in New York, died of a heart at tack at her borne at 155 East 93d Street on Thursday. She was 72 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: THE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES Of FOOD CITY SUPERMARKETS Express their deep and heartfelt sympathy over the loss of MA JACK SLOAN FOUNDER & GUIDING SPIRIT Of FOOD CITY SUPERMARKETS April 23, 1970

title: Abbie Hoffman Barred From White House Tea
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader who was a defendant in the Chicago Seven trial was turned away from the White House today when he tried to attend a tea given by Tricia Nixon.

title: Methodists Vote $4Million for Aid to Minorities
description: ST. LOUIS, April 24  The United Methodist Church com mitted itself today to give $2 million in 1971 and $2million more in 1972 to its Commission on Religion and Race to be used in the service of minori ty peoples.

title: Man's Estranged Wife Flips His Wig at Court
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Vincent DiCola nearly lost a full head of hair after a hearing in di vorce court.

title: Market Averages
description: Friday, April 24, 1970

title: ...and Damaging to Taiwan
description: The despicable attempt at assassination of Chiang Chingkuo was a criminal pervertion of a cause which, an its merits, deserves a wider hearing in the United States.

title: Legislative Oversight
description: While the session of the New York State Legislature which just ended was one of the most productive in recent years, it nonetheless left some important unfin ished business. Four major areas were neglected: labor law, the courts, reapportionment and legislative procedural reform.

title: Sources Say Leary Refused Any Help To U.S. Panel Here
description: The only major study known to have attempted to estimate just how much cor ruption there is among po licemen was conducted by the President's Commission on Law Enforcement and Ad ministration of Justice in the slums of Boston, Chicago and Washington.

title: Nixon Driven to Camp David As Fog Grounds Helicopter
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)President Nixon traveled by limousine today to Camp David, his mountain retreat in Maryland he camp was sub merged in clouds and fog and the customary helicopter trip I was ruled out.

title: SEIZURE OF SAILOR AT TRIAL ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, April 24At torneys for Seaman Roger Lee Priest protested today that the sailor should not have been taken into custody despite his conviction by a military court late last night.

title: Twas Brillig at Tickle Tree Where Furniture Is Wonderland of Whimsey
description: Shop Talk

title: In Memoriam
description: BARUCHAlmee. A memorial service, for Aimee Baruch will be held on Sunday, April 26 at 2 P.M., N. Y. Society For Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St.

title: Biz 4 Meet on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24Representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union met again today to continue drafting a memorandum on the progress of the talks among their ambassadors on a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Police Find a Pipe Bomb In Loiterer's Coat Pocket
description: A routine search of a man suspected of loitering in a Har lem apartment house lobby turned up a bomb made from length of lead pipe, according to the police at the West 126th Street station.

title: Campaign for the Supreme Soviet Opens
description: MOSCOW, April 24  The Soviet Union today formally opened its election campaign for the Supreme Soviet with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, President Nikolai V. Podgorny and Leonid L. Brezhnev, gen eral secretary of the Soviet Communist party, heading the list of those nominated for automatic election to the So viet version of a national leg islature.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
Swissair Spurring Financing of Jets
description: Walter Berchtold is not ex actly what one pictures as the president and managing director of an international airline, but then Swissair, which he heads, is not ex actly a typical airline.

title: Carolina Bars Vote to Teens
description: COLUMBBIA, S.C., April 24 (UPI)The South Carolina sen ate has turned down, by a 16 to 12 vote, an amendment that would have lowered the voting lage to 18. A group of teenaged spectators groaned audibly when the vote was recorded.

title: The Disruption at G. W. High
description: In its efforts to pacify strifetorn George Washington High School, the Board of Education is aiming primar ily and properly at safeguarding the right of students to an uninterrupted education. That right has too long been ignored as small groups of parents and students have locked themselves in conflict with the adminis tration and some of the teachers. In the course of this battle, all education at George Washington has been virtually suspended for weeks. In their latest rejection of the board's compromise, the dissident parents ap peared once again to place issues of power above the interests of education.

title: 2 Buildings Seized in Hawall
description: HONOLULU April 24 (AP) Student demonstrators seized a second R.O.T.C. building on the University of Hawaii campus late today.

title: WHEAT AND CORN UP WITH SOYBEANS
description: Interest shifted on the Chi cago Board of Trade yesterday from soybean oil and soybean meal to those three basics wheat, corn, and soybeans.

title: MARYLAND SECOND, 30 YARDS BEHIND
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24  Villanova began the 76th annual Penn Relays today the way it opened the preceding four meets, by running to a com fortable victory in the distance medley relay at Franklin Field.

title: Teamsters to Vote on National Contrac
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 24  The International Brother hood of Teamsters will submit its controversial contract to its members within a week, Frank Fitzsimmons, the union's gener al vice president, said here to day.

title: Newspaper Talks Near Critical Stage
description: The city's newspaper dispute appeared yesterday to be ap proaching a critical phase.

title: Refugee Tells of Flight From Cambodia
description: HATIEN, South Vietnam, April 19Le Tan Son, a Viet namese refugee from Cambodia, decided it was time to flee when, he said, he saw two Vietnamese monks and a nun stabbed to death on a Pnom penh street.

title: WHEELING STEEL REPORTS DECLINE
description: PITTSBURGH, April 24 The severe impact of inflation on the steel industry was em phasized here today by Allison R. Maxwell Jr., chairman of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Cor poration, at the annual meet ing of stockholders.

title: Ace Aussie Pacer's Qualifier Put Off
description: YONKERS, April 24  A swollen front left leg, apparent ly the result of having bumped against his stall at Stanley Dancer's Egyptian Acres Farm, at New Egypt, N. J., will keep Lucky Creed of Australia out of the qualifying mile he was scheduled to pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow morning.

title: Knicks Conquer Lakers, 124112, in First Game of N.B.A. Final at Garden
description: After having taken a 20 point lead in the first 17 min utes and a 15point lead midway through the third quarter, the New York Knick erbockers had to come from behind in the final period to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 124112, before another hysteri cal gathering of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Lovell Reports Astronauts Felt Death Was Near
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. told Congress today that the Apollo 13 astronauts had felt close to death but that they had still wanted to get their crippled spacecraft as near to earth as possible, even if they perished.

title: Israel Plans To Seal Off Hebron Site
description: JERUSALEM, April 24  Is raeli defense officials have an nounced that for military pur poses they intend to close off a 750acre site in the town of Hebron, in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan. This type of action has previ ously been used to prepare for Jewish settlement in occupied Arab areas.

title: Stephen Klein, Ellen L. Klein Planning Bridal
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Mr. and Mrs. John S. Hayes of Washington and Ponte Verdra, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hayes's daughter, Miss Ellen Laurie Klein, to Stephen David Klein. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Klein Jr. of Chicago.

title: Reuther Says U.A.W. Seeks Rises of Over 8 Per Cent
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 (AP)Wage demands of the United Auto Workers on the auto industry this year will be well in excess of 8 per cent year, Walter P. Reuther said today.

title: 22 SEIZED FLEEING STANFORD PROTEST
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 24 Twentytwo persons were ar rested at 1 A.M. today by a 50man sheriff's squad as they tried to flee from a Stanford University building captured by protesters yesterday.

title: South African Nationalists Show a Loss of Five Seats
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 24 (AP)Final fig ures from Wednesday's general election showed today that the ruling Nationalist party lost nine seats in Parliament to its major opposition, the United party, but regained four seats held by the ultrarightist Recon stituted Nationalists, who had bolted the Government party.

title: Better Hospital Utilization Urged to Halt Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)Hospitals can fight rising prices by improving the utiliza tion of hospital facilities and adopting programs of preven tive or prospective medicine, Senate subcommittee was told today.

title: Beard Cards 64 and Takes a ThreeStroke Lead With a 134 in Champions Golf
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 24Frank Beard equaled one record and narrowly missed another as he scored a 64 today in the second round of the $150,000 Tournament of Champions. Golfdom's leading moneywinner in 1969 with earnings of $175,223.93, the Louisville, Ky., slugger had nine birdies in a round that tied for the lowest tally put to gether in this 18yearold event for the game's elite.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Plans for 42d Street

title: Fauchon's in Paris, Gourmets' Heaven
description: PARISThey used to say that when a good Ameri can dies, his soul goes to Paris and they still say that when a good gourmet dies his soul goes to the Place Madeleine, specifically to the corner that quarters the house of Fauchon.

title: Roundup: It's Out of Park For Howard of Senators
description: Frank Howard made it out of Robert F. Kennedy Sta dium twice last nightonce with his bat and once with his temper.

title: M.T.A. Says It Lacks the Funds For ManhattanKennedy Spur
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority, disclosed yesterday that his agency had no funds available to build its planned highspeed rail link to Kennedy International Airport from Manhattan and Queens.

title: SLUMP CONTINUES IN STOCK MARKET
description: The 747 flew over Wall Street yesterday, but unfortunately for the bulls it was the Dow Jones industrial average and not the big jetliner.

title: Cambodia Says Saigon Sent Supply of Arms
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24The Cambodian military acknowledged today that the shipment of arms re ceived yesterday consisted of Sovietdesigned and Chinese manufactured AK47 auto matic rifles and ammunition that had been captured from Communist forces in South Vietnam.

title: System Lets Handicapped Communicate by Moving Parts of Body
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 A patented system per mits communication by a handicapped person who is unable to write or to operate a conventional typewriter keyboard but who can move parts of his body, such as the arms, feet or tongue. Elec tric typewriters or other machines can be controlled from a remote, portable board with a mini mum number of switches. Patent 3,507,376 was granted this week to Haig Kafafian, president of Cybernetics Re search Institute, Inc., Wash ington. He says his Cyber com methods have been used in homes for childrenby the blind, deaf and mute, amputees and sufferers from cerebral palsy and other de bilitating conditions.

title: MET DETAILS PLANS FOR SERIES IN JUNE
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced details of the added fourweek season of nonsub scription performances that will begin June 1. The series will make up for some of the per formances lost during the labor, dispute that shortened the reg ular 196970 season by 15, weeks.

title: Art: Holograms in Their Infancy
description: I WISH I could wax more enthusiastic, as they say, about the esthetic potential of holography  which, as every preschooler seems to know, is the making of three dimensional photographs by laser beam. But while N Dimensional Space, a show of holograms by artists at the Finch College Museum of Art/Contemporary Wing, is earnest and enlightening, it doesn't go far toward con vincing me.

title: GOODELL WOULD BAR G.I.'s IN CAMBODIA
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 Senator Charles E. Goodell said yesterday that he planned to introduce legislation to prevent President Nixon from using any military personnel in Cam bodia.

title: METREVELI TRIMS HOAD AT ROME NET
description: ROME, April 24 (AP)  Two American women, Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman, seeded No. 1 and No. 2, respec tively, in the women's singles of the Italian international ten nis championships, earned berths in the semifinals today, but in men's competi tion topseeded Lew Hoad of Australia was ousted by Alex ander Metreveli of the Soviet Union.

title: Bonwit's and Harrods Trading Credit Cards
description: Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenuebased specialty store chain, and Harrods, London's prestige department store, have agreed to reciprocal credit arrangements for each other's customers, starting May 15. The plan is the first one between major stores in different countries.

title: Disruptions Force Closing of Hunter
description: Classes were suspended at Hunter College yesterday after noon following student disrup tions in which more than 60 helmeted policemen were called in to clear the building at Lex ington Avenue and 69th Street.

title: What Caribbean Black Power Means
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 24The men whose ideas shape the philosophy of the blackpower movement in the Englishspeaking regions of the Caribbean represent a wide range of radical thought but they are all together on one point: that white power must become a thing of the past in their countries.

title: MODERATOR RESIGNS IN TV NEWS DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Max M. Kampelman has with drawn as moderator of Wash ington Week in Review, a tele vision feature appearing on educational stations around the country.

title: Market Place:
description: THOSE letters from irate small investors continue to turn up in the mail.

title: Bomb for White House Found and Deactivated
description: SEATTLE, April 24 (AP) A bomb mailed in Seattle to the White House was de tected and deactivated in Washington, officials said to night. Another bomb, mailed to Selective Service head quarters, was also inter they said.

title: Music: But Is It Opera?
description: ELEPHANT STEPS is an opera, or something, by Stanley Silverman, and it was given last night at Hunter College, and I can't explain this work of the ontological hysteric theater because I don't know what the hell was going on. But I know one thing. Nobody was bored.

title: PARIS TRASH GROWS DESPITE ARMY HELP
description: PARIS, April 24  The French Army assigned 750 soldiers to the Paris garbage detail at dawn today, replacing 3,800 striking sanitation men. By nightfall, the city streets were filthier than when they had started.

title: School to Gain At Street Fair On West Side
description: The Parents Association of the West Side Montessori School will sponsor a street fair on 99th Street be tween Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway next Saturday. Proceeds of sales and admis sions to entertainments for children will benefit the scholarship fund of the school at 225 West 99th Street.

title: F.D.A. Advises Doctors to Give Birth Pills Lowest in Estrogen
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration advised physi cians today to prescribe oral contraceptives with the lowest content of estrogen, a hormone.

title: A Riot Gas Study, Laid to U.S., Heightens British Controversy
description: LONDON, April 24  British controversy over the use of tear gas in Northern Ireland was heightened today by the release of a document report edly prepared by a United States Army research team detailing the damaging effects of the widely used riotcontrol agent known as CS.

title: Paris to Spurn Request
description: PARIS, April 24  France will turn down a request from the Cambodian Government for arms to fight North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces, according to informed diplomatic sources here.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Chicago

title: 2 Religion Editors Honored
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Colman McCarthy and Dan L. Thrapp, religion editors of The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times, respec tively, were named winners today of the 1970 Faith and Freedom Award in Journalism. The awards, sponsored by Reli gious Heritage of America, Inc., will be given to the two editors at a breakfast here June 18.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Herb Shriner and Wife Killed in Crash in Florida
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., April 24 (UPI)Herb Shriner, the homespun humorist who starred on television in the 1950's, was killed with his wife in a car wreck that apparently was caused by a mechanical failure, the police said today.

title: S.D.S. Woman Arrested Here on Weapons Charge
description: Dianna Donghi, a member of the Weatherman fection of Stu dents for a Democratic Society, was arrested in Foley Square yesterday on a charge of un lawful use of dangerous weap ons.

title: 500 Stranded on Tour Boat
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) About 500 persons, most of them high school pupils, were stranded for more than eight hours last night and early today when a Potomac River excur sion boat grounded on a mud hank during a heavy fog. No in juries or panie were reported.

title: Beckett's Beaux Jours Stars Madeleine Renaud
description: A GREAT actress in a great performance this is Madeleine Renaud in Samuel Beckett's Oh, Les Beaux Jours. The French production, directed by Roger Blin and featuring Olivier Hussenot as Willie, opened last night at the BarbizonPlaza Theater as Le Treteau de Paris's third program, to run through May 3.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Kenyon Review, Citing Losses, Halts Publication
description: Thirtyone years after its founding, The Kenyon Review, the literary quarterly that gave early exposure to such writers as Boris Pasternak and Robert Penn Warren, has suspended publication and will not resume unless a sponsor is found.

title: Benson Inge, 61, Writer And Public Relations Aide
description: Benson Inge, a writer critic and public relations man, died of a heart attack Thursday in his home at 17 West 71st Street. He was 61 years old.

title: MILTON N. GRASS, 78, HOSIERY HISTORIAN
description: Milton N. Grass, a historian of the hosiery industry, who re tired in 1962 as president of Stylecraft Sales Corporation here, hosiery wholesalers, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Stamford, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived at Skyview Lane in New Canaan Conn.

title: COURT RESTRAINS BUREAU OF MINES
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The United States Bureau of Mines was under a Federal Court order today restraining its inspectors from enforcing some controversial sections of new coal mine safety regula tions that have stirred confu sion and anger in the coal fields.

title: ALCOA CONSIDERS PLANT IN RYUKUS
description: Officials of the Aluminum Company of America said yesterday in Pittsburgh that Alcoa might build a smelter in the Ryukyu Islands and had told the Government of the Ryukyus thatif the project went aheada Japanese con cern might be invited to parti cipate as a joint owner of the smelter.

title: Crime Against New York...
description: The shocking attempt on the life of Chiang Ching kuo, Deputy Premier of the Republic of China, as he entered the Plaza Hotel yesterday is a source of shame and embarrassment to the people of this city and merits the strongest possible condemnation. Fortunately, the shot was deflected by an alert police officer and Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's son and possible heir was unharmed.

title: PACERS TRIUMPH TO SWEEP SERIES
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 24 (AP)The Indiana Pacers broke a 104104 tie with six straight foul shots tonight and downed the Carolina Cougars, 110106, to complete a fourgame sweep of their American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff.

title: Ulcers as a Childhood Disease Reported Common
description: A survey of medical records over 16 years has indicated that ulcers may be becoming an increasingly common child hood disease, particularly among teenaged boys in the upper socioeconomic groups, a Buffalo researcher has reported.

title: Westinghouse Expands Investment in Venezuela
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day the acquisition of better than a 50 per cent interest in Emprases Incorporadas C.A. of Maracaibo, Venezuela, a re frigerator maker.

title: Space Aide to College Post
description: RICHMOND, April. 24 (AP) Christopher C. Kraft, a top figure in the nation's manned space program, was named by Gov. Linwood Holton today to the board of visitors of Virginia Polytechnic Institute. Mr. Kraft a 1944 Virginia Tech graduate, is deputy director of the Nation al Aeronautics and Space Ad ministration's Manned Space craft Center in Houston.

title: Harassing Educational TV
description: Fear that the Internal Revenue Service is being converted into an agency of political repression can only be increased by the disclosure that tax agents have been exhaustively scrutinizing programs pro duced by National Educational Television.

title: POPE PAUL HAILED ON SARDINIAN TRIP; POLICE ATTACKED
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, April 24  Pope Paul VI made a triumphal visit to this craggy Mediterranean island today. He was the first reigning pontiff to set foot on its impoverished shores.

title: Penn State Strike Urged
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 24 (UPI)Angered by a trustee's crackdown on disrup tive campus elements, two stu dent leaders of Pennsylvania State University proposed today a protest strike by all of the University's more than 48,000 students.

title: Coffee Prices Rise At Maxwell House
description: The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corpora tion announced yesterday it would increase wholesale prices of its ground and freezedried coffee effective Monday.

title: Waiting in Movie Lines Achieves Status Rating
description: Cheri Eisenberg, a high school sophomore from Woodmere, L.I., was sitting crosslegged, tranquilly hold ing a longstemmed yellow lily. She was sitting on the sidewak, easing herself into a mood of euphoria suitable to the movie Woodstock, which she would see after a wait in line of an hour and a half.

title: It's Arts and Letters' Day to Remember
Hightstown School Melee
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., April 24  Three teenaged boys were injured today during a wild melee involving about 80 Negro and white students at Hightstown Regional High School. Chains, baseball bats, and lengths of pipe were used as weapons.

title: ALLEGED MAFIA MAN GETS 10YEAR TERM
description: Nicola Melillo, an alleged Ma fia figure, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and was fined $12,000 yesterday after pleading guilty to perjury and conspiracy charges in Federal Court.

title: BREWSTER DOUBTS FAIR BLACK TRIALS
description: NEW HAVEN, April 24 Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, declared last night that he was skeptical of the ability of black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the United States.

title: NEW GLASS GALLERY TO OPEN IN TOLEDO
description: A new gallery for the exhi bition of glass, ancient and modern, will be opened today at the Toledo Museum of Art, which from its beginning in 1901 has had important spon sorship by glass magnates.

title: HAITIAN WARSHIPS FIRE ON CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Ships of Haiti's coast guard sporadically shelled her capi tal, PortauPrince, this after noon in apparent rebellion against the regime of President Fran?ois Duvalier, American and Haitian sources reported.

title: ARTHUR J. VOUTE
description: Arthur J. Vont, a former vice president of the Emigrant Savings Bank, died at St. Vin cent's Hospital Thursday after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 5420 Nether land Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 25, 1970

title: HELEN FOLLETT, 85, WRITER ON TRAVEL
description: Mrs. Helen Thomas Follett, a writer of travel books, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived at 404 West 116th Street.

title: Northwestern Mutual Gains
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Mil waukee reported yesterday that sales rose to a new high of $442.7million in the first quar ter from $439.7million a year before.

title: Kalman Feher, Contestant In Major Tennis Matches
description: Kalman Feher, a tennis coach at the Vanderbilt International Racquet Club here and former member of the Hungarian Da vis Cup team, died of a heart attack Thursday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Jamica, Queens.

title: Huntley's Resort Meets Protest
description: BOZEDAAN, Mont.  As it does in cities large and small across the nation, Chet Hunt ley's teleyision image arrives in Bozeman in the evenings.

title: J. Cameron Day Dies at 59; A Trade Periodical Editor
description: FORT LEE, N. J., April 24 J. Cameron Day, a trade pe ridical editor, died today in Englewood Hospital, after hav ing been struck by an auto mobile here last night. He was 59 years old and lived at 233 McElroy Avenue.

title: PROF. EUGENE J. KEEFE
description: Prof. Eugene J. Keefe, a faculty member of the Fordham University School of Law for 42 years, died Wednesday in Physi cian Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens, after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Jackson Heights.

title: Fights in Penns Grove
description: PENNS GROVE, N.J., April 24 (AP)  Fighting broke out between black and white stu dents at Penns Grove Regional High School today, forcing the closing of the 900student school. Several youths suffered minor injuries.

title: Anarchy Has a Tradition in Ital
description: ROME, April 24The small group of Sardinian anarch ists involved in a stonethrow ing melee with policemen guarding Pope Paul VI today are the modern represen tatives of an intellectual and political tradition that goes back to 1876 in Italy.

title: JULIAN C. ALDRICH, N.Y.U. TEACHER, 69
description: GLASSBORO, N.J., April 24  Dr. Julian Carter Aldrich, an emeritus professor of edu cation of New York University and an author, died here Wed nesday of a stroke. He was 69 years old and lived in Man sion Park Apartments 70.

title: Prejudging a Pipeline
description: Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel, the Federal official who has the broadest responsibilities for pre serving the American environment, introduced an ominously sour note into the Earth Day observance (which otherwise the Nixon Administration largely ignored), when he announced his intention to grant a permit for the controversial 800mile oil pipeline across Alaska.

title: Bronx River Parkway Modified to Cut Accident Rate
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 24  The scenic Bronx River Parkwaythe world's oldest and Westchester County's most daagerous parkwayis getting some safety improve ments in a county effort to lower the high accident rate.

title: Entrance to the Plaza Hotel Is the Scene of Assassination Attempt
description: A Taiwanese fired a pistol at Chiang Kaishek's son and heir apparent, Chiang Chingkuo, in a revolving door at the Plaza Hotel here yesterday, but missed when a detective grabbed his wrist just before the gun went off.

title: Disadvantaged Youngsters To See Yanks Play Today
description: The New York Yankees will entertain 5,000 disadvantaged youngsters, 140 college sports editors and numerous women at the Stadium this afternoon, when they meet the Oakland Athletics in the first Ladies Day game of the season.

title: Boulder Brook Horse Show Begins 2Day Event Today
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 24 With about 1,100 entries on hand, the Boulder Brook horse show traditional opener of the spring season  is sched uled for tomorrow and Sunday.

title: CLEVELAND HIGH SHUT AFTER FIRE
description: Classes at Grover Cleveland High School were dismissed shortly before noon yesterday after a small fire flared in the crowded cafeteria and hundreds of unruly youths headed toward the school from another neigh borhood.

title: Nixon Gets Bumper ticker
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) President Nixon got an I'm proud to be an American bumper sticker Friday from the Cheektowaga, N. Y., Rotary Club, which plans to distribute the stickers. He did not say whether it might show up on the Presidential limousine.

title: PLEDGES BOLSTER MORTGAGE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Commercial banks, life in surance companies and trustees of pension funds have pledged to increase by $2billion their investments in residential mort gages this year, the White House announced today.

title: Delay in Kopechne Inquest Data Is Linked to Liability of Clerk
description: BOSTON, April 24 (AP)  State Attorney General Robert H. Quinn called today for the full and speedy disclosure and publication of the report and transcripts of the report and transcripts of evidence of the Mary Do Kopechne inquest.

title: METS AND DODGERS IN SCORELESS DUEL
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 The New York Mets made their first appearance on the West Coast as the defending cham pions tonight with Jerry Koos man pitching against Alan Foster of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Stars Down Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, April 24 (AP)Los Angeles outscored Dallas by 14 points during the first 4 min utes of the second half tonight and defeated the Chaparrals, 146139, to give the Stars a 32 lead in their fourofsevengame American Basketball Associa tion Western Division playoffs.

title: Gambia, Africa's Smallest State, Becomes a Republic
description: BATHURST, Gambia, April 24 (Agence FrancePresse) Gambia, Africa's smallest country, became a republic within the British Common wealth just before midnight last night.

title: Antiques: New Show at Metropolitan
description: The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 19thCentury America, can help collectors expand their knowledge of the distinctive urban art and design of the period.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS CAMBODIANS FIGHT FOREIGN INVASION
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The United States and the So viet Union publicly disagreed today over the character of the current fighting in Cambodia, although the two Governments were reported to be maintains ing private contacts on the pos sibility of a broad Indochina peace conference.

title: 6 TO START TODAY IN STEPPING STONE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 A sevenfurlong race called the Stepping Stone Purse will be the main attraction at Churchill Downs tomorrow. The reason for the eminence of a race of only $6,500 value is that it will include in its lineup two of the leading candidates for the Ken tucky Derby a week from to morrow.

title: 15th Peacock Ball Set for Next Saturday
description: The Lila Motley Cancer Foundation's 15th annual Pea cock Ball will take place next Saturday at the Plaza. The foundation, which will re ceive the proceeds of the ball, supports the Lila Motley Radiation Therapy Pavilion at the New York University Medical Center.

title: Graft Paid to Police Here Said to Run Into Millions
description: Narcotics dealers, gamblers and businessmen make illicit payments of millions of dollars a year to the policemen of New York, according to policemen, lawenforcement experts and New Yorkers who make such payments themselves.

title: 2,000 Attend G.O.P. Dinner
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 24 Vice President Agnew made his first venture into the South to night since the Senate rejected the nomination on April 8 of Judge G. Harrold Carswell of Florida to the Supreme Court.

title: Bridge:
description: THE average bridge player is well above average in inteligence, and the average bridge expert is even higher on the I.Q. scale. If there were any way to determine the standings in this depart ment the highest rank would perhaps go to 36yearold Dr. Chun Shen of West Lafayette, Ind., who has an international reputation in three distinct activities re quiring high Intelligence.

title: Soviet Ousts Forestry Aide
description: MOSCOW, April 24 (UPI) The Chairman of the Soviet Forestry Committee was dis missed from his job and retired on pension, an announcement in Pravda said today. Vasily I. Rubtsov who is 57 years old, was ousted, after his com mittee was accused by the Gov ernment newspaper Izvestia in February of mismanaging the nation's forestry industries.

title: Emerson, Roche Triumph
description: DALLAS, April 24 (UPI)  Roy Emerson of Australia reached the semifinals of The Dallas Morning News profes sional tennis tournament today with a 64, 64 victory over Cliff Drysdale of South Africa. Tony Roche of Australia de feated Fred Stolle of Australia, 75, 64. Roche is playing for the first time singe a shoulder injury two months ago.

title: Bonn and Warsaw Agree To Fourth Round of Talks
description: WARSAW, April 24 (Reuters) Polish and West German delegations completed tonight their third round of talks on improving relations and agreed to meet again early in June in Bonn.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DIP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthe counter market continued to weaken yesterday although the number of declines and the price drops were not so large as in the previous two sessions.

title: Foreign Ships Ordered O??
description: PORT OF SPAIN, April 24 (Reuters)Prime Minister Eric Williams ordered all foreign naval vessels today to leave Trinidad's territorial waters.

title: TRINIDAD REPORTS CONTROL RESTORED
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 24The acting police commissioner for Trinidad and Tobago declared today that the blackpower disorders that shook this tropical island for the last three days were now under control.

title: Report on Hunger in U.S. To Be Released Monday
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) A new report on hunger in America will be released Mon day, timed to coincide with Congressional consideration of welfare reform, and the food stamp and school lunch pro grams.

title: RCA Sells 7055 Computer
description: The RCA Corporation an nounced yesterday that the Carte Blanche credit card com pany had ordered a largescale Spectra 70/55 computer sys tem, valued at $1.6million. The system will handle the company's Increased account ing and billing load.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: TEXAS AGGIES SET 880 RELAY RECORD
description: DES MOINES, Iowa April 24 (AP)  Texas A.&M., anchored by Curtis Mills, broke the world 8880yard relay record while American records tumb bled in the 440yard hurdles and twomile relay as the 61st Drake Relays opened today.

title: Mayor Asks Aid From All In Inquiry on Corruption
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that reports of police corruption in this morning's issue of The New York Times are extremely serious and go to the heart of the effectiveness of law enforcement in our city.

title: BANK CONSULTANT WARY OF CONGRESS
description: A leading consultant to the banking industry warned yes terday that Congress might well enact legislation this year that would severely restrict the scope of banking operations.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Water. The President signed an executive order that broad ened the jurisdiction of the New England River Basins Commis sion to cover Long Island and Long Island Sound. Also he re quested that a representative from the Atomic Energy Com mission be added to the agency.

title: Police Use Own Words To Speak of Corruption
description: Slang, one theory holds, is sometimes created so that those who understand it can discuss subjects they want to keep secret. Whether this is true for the police is not known, but there are many police slang words that deal with corruption. For example:

title: Peking Bars Geneva Talks And Sees Soviet Betrayal
description: HONG KONG, April 25 (Reu ters)Communist China op posed today any reconvening of the Geneva conference and ac cused the Soviet Union of be traying the peoples of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: Card of Thanks
description: COOPERJack L. The family of Mr. Jack J. Cooper wishes to express their gratitude for the thoughtfulness and kidness in our hour of sorrow.

title: Staten Island Youth Seized in Slaying Of 3 in One Family
