description: Organized pressure on behalf of Nationalist China, which once exerted a powerful in fluence on American politics and the direction of United States policy, apears mori band, a victim of old age and lack of interest.

title: Rhodesian Team Starts 5Week European Trip
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 25A 17man field hockey team has slipped quietly out of Rhodesia for a fiveweek tour in which it will play a series of secret games against European teams whose names will not be an nounced until after the con tests are over.

title: An IBM Machine? Not Casals
description: IT is not every day that one has the chance of watch ing 100 cellists simultaneously in action. Not even every other day. So the morning of April 15 saw us in Carnegie Hall, where Pablo Casals was sched uled to rehearse his centenary of cellists in his own Sardana. We got there early to have a talk with Arthur Aaron. He is the personnel manager of the American Symphony Orchestra, and as such was in charge of the proceedings.

title: In Tokyo Cabs Don't Stop for Everyone
description: TOKYO, April 25Every night in Ginza, Asakusa, Shinjuku and all the other neonlit entertainment dis tricts of Tokyo, as the mid night approaches, the bar lined alleys off the main streets overflow with taxi cabs looking for choice fares among the tipsy menfolk and the miniskirted or kimono clad hostesses.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Banker's View on War

title: Dr. Henry Betts, Miss Paul Wed At U. of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 25In the Bond Chapel at the Universi ty of Chicago this afternoon, Miss Monika Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arno Rich ard Paul of East Berlin, was married to Dr. Henry Brogn ard Betts, who is vice presi dentmedical director of the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago and chairman of the department of rehabilitation medicine at the Northwestern University Medical School.

title: New York's new law and the divorce lawyer
description: IT is 9:25 in the morning as attor ney Milton Hutner strides up the steps of the State Supreme Court Building on Grand Concourse in the Bronx. On the elevator up to the seventh floor, he opens his battered attach case and pulls out a manila file marked Kleinman.

title: Racing the Racers on the Susquehanna
description: BAINBRIDGE, N.Y.Pitting brawn, brains and muscle against 70 miles of the Susquehanna River in a canoe is not a sport for the fainthearted. Even watching such an endurance race requires a certain amount of grit, true or otherwise.

title: In The Nation: Polarization in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 25 The Popular Democratic party was in power here for so long that its rule came almost to be taken for granted. Now, in the bitter words of its last Gov ernor, Roberto Sanchez Vilella, whose alienation from the party contributed to its downfall in 1968, all the Popular Demo crats want is a Restoration.

title: Italian Plane Crash Kills 18
description: UDINE, Italy, April 25 (AP) An Italian Air Force C119 transport crashed soon after takeoff near this north Italian city today, killing at least 18 of the 21 men aboard.

title: Soviet Ousts Forestry Aide
description: MOSCOW, April 24 (UPI) The Chairman of the Soviet Forestry Committee was dis missed from his job and retired on pension, an announcements in Pravda said Friday. Vasily I. Rubtsov who is 57 years old, was ousted, after his com mittee was accused by the Gov ernment newspaper Izvestia in February of mismanaging the nation's forestry industries.

title: CANTABS TRIUMPH 8TH YEAR IN ROW
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 Harvard made three changes within its varsity heavyweight shell, including a shift at stroke, and still continued to look very powerful today as it easily won the Compton Cup race from Princeton and Massa chusetts Institute of Technol ogy.

title: Man Held in Check Thefts
description: The arrest of a Metropolitan Transit Authority bus driver on charges of stealing and cashing more than $42,000 in welfare checks was announced yester day by the city's commission er of investigations, Robert K. Ruskin. The bus driver, Robert Spencer, 46 years old, of 127 East 123d Street, was charged with stealing 567 checks. He was arraigned before Criminal Court Judge John T. Brickley, who ordered him held in lieu of $15,000 bail on charges of grand larceny and possession of forged checks.

title: BAGHDAD PRESSES GULFAREA ISSUE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 The Baathist regime in Iraq has begun to marshal its forces in preparation for Britain's with drawal next year from the Per sian Gulf area, and has appar ently set itself on a collision course with Iran and Saudi Arabia.

title: Great Expectations, A Quarter Of a Century Later
description: THE American soldier coming home 25 years ago from Ger many, the South Pacific or even a garrison in Alabama was as relieved to be done with war, as delighted to take up the old routine of his life as his father in World War I had been a quarter of a century before him. Discharge was as joyful, celebrations as riotous. But there was a fateful difference in expectations. For one who does not think the perspectives of history altogether irrelevant, that contrast is not without significance in this 25th year since the end of World War II.

title: BEARD IS CLINGING TO 2STROKE LEAD
Hoping for Adventure and Finding It
description: TOLEDO, SpainMy two daughters and I had saved Spain for the last, hoping for adventure. We wound down the Pyrenees Mountains on a curving secondary road, and before we knew it we had passed the Spanish Cus toms House. A sternlooking member of the Guardia Civil stood with an upraised hand, shouting. Another clapped his hand to the pistol at his side.

title: Cambodians Overturn Seaport's Name, Too
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 25 (AP)  Sihanouk ville, the Cambodian seaport Prince Norodom Sihanouk built and named for him self, has been renamed by the leaders who deposed him as Cambodia's chief of state last month.

title: A Talk With Margaret Mead
description: At 8 o'clock one Saturday morning, over breakfast in a Manhattan restaurant, I taped a wideranging con versation with Margaret Mead. She had already been up for three hours and was on her way to a civilliberties conference at a midtown hotel. A week later, I spoke with her again in her apartment. Here, and on the fol lowing pages, are excerpts from her comments.D.D.

title: Dance: Ashton Variations
description: THE saddest aspect of the present Royal Ballet sea son at the Metropolitan Opera Houseindeed, perhaps, the only sad aspectis that it marks the last time we will see Sir Frederick Ashton at the head of the company.

title: Democrats in West Eye 9 Governorships
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 Democratic organizations in the 13 states west of the Rocky Mountains are making a strong attempt this year to reverse the trend that has cut their power sharply in the last decade.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Sees Risk of Extremist TakeOver
description: NEW DELHI, April 25 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi says that if her fight to bring democratic socialism to In dia does not succeed, the coun try will fall into the hands of extremists, probably Com munist extremists.

title: From Country Joe to Mothers of Invention
description: C J. FISH: Country Joe and The Fish (Van guard VSD  6555). Country Joe and The Fish were one of the pre miere San Francisco rock groups, participants in the be ins, dances and festivals that were seminal events in the growth of the youthful coun terculture of the sixties. Leader Joe McDonald's musi cal sensibilities resonate most strongly to the traditional, Guthriestyled folk songs, but he also seems fascinated by romantic love ballads. In their earliest days (as in their ap pearance in the Monterey Pop Festival film) The Fish were more focused toward San Francisco musical psyche delia, or if you will, acid rock. The quintet's music be came gentler in succeeding years, as Country Joe's lyrics became paradoxically more aggressively antiEstablish ment.

title: Jazzmobile Concert Marks April Is Jazz Month Here
description: A twohour jazz concert by teenagers of the Harlem com munity was presented yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of I. S. 201, on 127th Street be tween Maditon and Park Ave nues, in recognition of April Is Jazz Month in the city. The program was organized by Jazzimobile, the independent, nonprofit organization that six years ago began offering free jazz performances in mobile units. Yesterday's program, sponsored by the CocaCola Bottling Company of New York, was the first concert perform ance by young people, follow ing a series of seminar work shops initiated last November.

title: JUDGE SAYS YALE PERILS FAIR TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, April 25A State Superior Court judge ac cused the president of Yale University and demonstrators today of having created the atmosphere that they now say could prevent a fair trial for the Black Panthers here.

title: PACIFICATION POLICY IS SHREWD, FOE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 American specialists on Vietna mese affairs view a recent speech by a high Vietcong of ficial as strongly suggestive of Communist concern over the rural pacification and Vietnam ization effort.

title: Foreign Affairs: A Lurch Toward Disaster
description: PARISThe Middle East has recently seen both unabashed growth of Soviet military in fluence in Egypt and a concur rent takeover bid by China to gain control of the Palestine Arab Guerrillas. One immediate consequence has been intrusion into a tense region of new rivalries between the Com munist great powers which heighten the risk of war.

title: Democrats Criticize New BallotPlacement Law
description: The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor and other leading Democrats yesterday bitterly criticized the bill signed by Governor Rockefeller giving in cumbents here first place on the June 23 primary ballot.

title: High Court Elections Urged
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) Supreme Court Justices should face voters for approval or re jection at periodic intervals, Chief Judge Donald H. Hunter of the Indiana Supreme Court said Wednesday. Judge Hunter, speaking at the DePaul Univer sity Law School, proposed a constitutional amendment that would permit the President to appoint Justices from among nominees submitted by an in dependent, bipartisan commis sion.

title: City Wants Air Rights To Hop, Skip and Jump
description: THE city may be on the verge of the age of the sensational air grab, but it's all on the up and up, according to those who envi sion a booming business in air rights.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThere was so much news here about the war in Indochina last week it was hard to tell what was going on.

title: Soviet Swimmers Win
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 25 (AP)The Soviet Union de feated Britain, 200104, in a twoday international swim ming meet that ended today. An unexpected British victory was scored by 18yearold Alan Widdowson, who defeated Vik tor Sharygin in the 100meter butterfly in 1:00.1.

title: Reportorial Awards Given To Two Science Newsmen
description: Two science reporters were cited by the Albert Deutsch Memorial Foundation and the American Orthopsychiatric As sociation yesterday for disting uished reporting.

title: Mrs. Ralph Hill Dies at 72; Director of Walden School
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Goldsmith Hill, a psychologist and former director of the Walden School, died Thursday at her winter residence in Naples, Fla., appar ently of a heart attack. She was 72 years old, and also had a home in Killingworth, Conn.

title: Bridge
description: DECEPTIVE plays provide some of the most entertaining moments in the game, provided you are not the victim. But the chance of bring ing off a coup in this area depends largely on the quality of the oppo sition. The bridge version of the Barnum maxim says that you can fool all the beginners nearly all the time, but all the experts rather rarely.

title: The Program
description: DAPHNIS AND CHLOE, Choreography, Frederick Ashton; music, Maurice Ravel; scenery and costumes, John Craxton; conductor, John Lanchbery.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: French Salvation Army Faces Mutiny in Its Drive Against Public Display of Sex
description: PARIS, April 25The cam paign of the Salvation Army against eroticism has not visibly reduced the public dis play of sex, but it has pro duced a small mutiny in the evangelical organization's staff.

title: Office Space Demand Still Weakens in City
description: THE demand for office space in Manhattan is continuing to slack en in the wake of the general slowdown in the economy, widen ing the choices available for the space seeker.

title: Une de Mai Captures $56,000 Trot at Milan
description: MILAN, Italy, April 25 (AP) The French trotting mare, Une de Mai, won the $56,000 Grand Prix or the Milan Fair today at the San Sire track. It was her 12th victory in Italy and increased her earn ings to $248,000.

title: Religion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Whenever a priest has chosen to drop out or resign his ministerial role in the Roman Catholic church, his action has caused both church officials and congregation to ask Why? But what was once an occasional event swathed in of ficial secrecy has in recent years become an increasing, wellpub licized and muchdiscussed prob lem involving thousands of dropouts.

title: Hockney: How His Style Changes
description: LONDON DAVID HOCKNEY's art elicits affection. We can admire it like many another man's, and be amused or impressed by it according to our in clinations and the object be fore us, but this tribute of affection it exacts is some thing quite particular. You could put it down to the air of innocence, the childlike surprise it shares with the man himself. But then how do we allow for his equally evident, massive cunning?

title: GAMBLING DEFEAT IN POLL IS HAILED
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 25 Mayor Jay Dermer of Miami Beach said today that he hoped the defeat of a gambling pro posal in a citywide referendum on Thursday had buried the casino gambling issue in this resort city for all time.

title: Headliners
description: Norman Mailer's graphic account of his experiences during the October, 1967, antiwar demonstrations at the Pentagon won him a Pu litzer Prize and a National Book Award when it was published as the book, Armies of the Night. Last week, the episode won him a distinction of a different kind. During the demonstra tions, after he had crossed through a line of United States marshals, Mr. Mailer was charged with disorderly conduct. On being brought to trial he was convicted and sentenced to 30 days in jail, 25 of them suspended, plus a $50 fine. Mr. Mailer, and several others convicted with him, appealed. Last week, the United States Supremo Court refused hearings to the appellants. That means, after deducting two days because he had already been held overnight, that Mr. Mailer faces three days in jail.

title: A TACTICAL SHIFT IN MIDEAST SEEN
description: JERUSALEM, April 25The air war between Israel and the United Arab Republic appears to have undergone a major change in recent weeks, with both sides apparently in fluenced in large measure by political rather than strategic factors.

title: U.S. Bankers Survey a Multinational Horizon
description: The new frontier of American banking in the last few years has been the inter national market.

title: And Now Whisky in Plastic
description: Whiskies and soft drinks in plastic bottles, cocktail mixes and just plain liquor in cans, and milk in plastic containers.

title: SILVER KING WINS NONBETTING TROT
description: Phalen had Silver King three comfortable lengths ahead of Jack Minbar, driven by Del In sko. Timrick, with John Schroe der in the sulky, finished third, beaten by a length for the place among the 11 starters in the race for New York Statebred 4yearolds. The best previous clocking for the roan son of Cedar Crest FlashSadie Mite, was 2:09 over the fiveeights mile Green Mountain track at Pownal, Vt., in 1969.

title: StillLife Foxes And Swans Cavort On Maryland Farm
description: JACKSONVILLE, Md.The fox has just crossed the road at Pleasant Valley Farm, and the first of six hounds is close behind. A mounted huntsman is about to clear a gate in the groomed hedges, but nothing moves. The fox, the hounds and the huntsman, it develops, are groomed hedges.

title: Robert Katz to Wed Magda Stark, Student
description: Miss Magda Stark, a sen ior at Finch College, and Robert S. Katz, an account executive with Batten Bar ton Durstine & Osborn, plan to be married on June 14. title: POPE AND VATICAN CRITICAL OF PRESS
description: ROME, April 25Pope Paul VI and the vatican newspaper both struck out at the Italian press today for its reporting of a stonethrowing incident in volving the police and anarch ists during the Pontiff's visit to the island of Sardine yesterday.

title: Cheaper Lottery Tickets and More Drawings Are Not Expected to Cut Into Numbers Play
description: For the average Harlemite, playing numbers is like bingo is to the Catholic Church, said Assemblyman Charles B. Ran. gel. It's moral and a way of life.

title: QUAKERS PROPOSE PLAN FOR MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The American Friends Service Committee has called on Israel, as the militarily dominant pow er in the Middle East, to take the first step toward peace by pledging withdrawal from Arab territories occupied in 1967 and a program of major aid to Pal estinian refugees.

title: Recordings
description: WHAT is music, any way? An art, says the textbook. Mere ly a high craft, says Stravinsky. An entertain ment, says your Aunt Maud. A branch of physical science, says Xenakis. A weapon of moral philosophy, said Bee thoven. Composers and lis teners continue to debate the possibilities, in spite of cen turies of polemics and the oretical ponderings that should lead us to suspect that no answer will ever prove permanently satisfying.

title: Soviet Navy in Maneuvers
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (Reuters) Soviet aircraft, ships and submarines carried out a rocket strike during the navy's current worldwide maneuvers, the Gov ernment newspaper Izvestia said today.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 25 (AP)Look it up in the dic tionary, 12yearold Keith Hoover was told. He did, but he did not agree with it and he was right.

description: CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) A mercurybased fungicide, be lieved responsible for serious injury to three New Mexico children, is free to be sold on the market again.

title: Best Seller List

description: Theodore W. Kheel held sepa rate private talks yesterday with representatives of the printers and the publishers of the city's four major news papers as he tried to ease the stalemate in their contract ne gotiations.

description: HOMEOWNERS who would like to keep re pair bills at a mini mum, and do every thing possible to extend the life of their home and its equipment, will be interested in a new eightpage booklet recently published.

description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)The Nixon Administra tion has agreed to release $18 million for more Farmers Home Administration grants to help small rural communi ties build water and sewer Sys tems.

description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 25Miss Laura Powers Maxwell and Quartermaster 3C A. The ceremony was performed in the presence of the families and a few close friends.

title: CARLOS CAPTURES SPRINT IN 0:09.2
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 John Carlos, who has been run ning pass patterns in his spare time, ran 100 yards in a straight line today and showed why he is the world's greatest sprinter.

description: BUFFALO, April 25 (AP) Students from Brown and Rut gers Universites took firstplace honors today in the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Northeastern Re gional aerospace research com petitions.

description: Following the rainfall of a normal season, the city reser voir system is virtually full, with all reservoirs spilling over except two.

title: Moore, a Very English Romantic
description: IN nature, every form is the realization of an organic imperative. In a work of art, however, every form is the realiza tionor an attempt at the realization of an esthetic imperative. This holds true even for those works of art that simulate the organic forms which nature produces in such prodigal abundance. An artist may feel a special affinity for the organic forms of nature, but he can only act upon the demands of that affinity through a series of esthetic decisions.

title: A New World at Their Fingertips
description: THERE is nothing at all uncommon about it. They can be seen almost anytime at the Passport Office and at travel agencies, talking in familiar terms about faroff places and distant shores. Once, magical names like Darjeeling or Singapore or Rio were, to the blind, merely so many musical and exotic sounds.

title: Etherington Is Rated a Threat in Connecticut Senate Race
description: NEW HAVEN, April 25  When Edwin D. Etherington re signed as president of Wesleyan University two months ago to enter the United States Senate race in Connecticut, he had neither a strategy, a staff nor a campaign headquarters.

title: YOUNG PHYSICISTS FIND FEWER JOBS
description: Young physicists just earn ing their Ph.D. degrees are finding it more and more diffi cult to land jobs, according to a new study by the American Institute of Physics.

title: Tass Reports Launching
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (AP) Tass reported today briefly and without comment the Chinese launching of an earth satellite.

title: John A. Knox Johnston Weds Miss Shirley Laffey in Jersey
description: PEAPACK, N. J., April 25 Miss Shirley Collette Laf fey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Wellman Laffey of Far Hills and Harbour Island, the Bahamas, and John Anthony Knox Johnston of Had dington, Scotland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Knox John ston of Palma de Mallorca, Spain, were married here this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The owners' asking price in the proposed conversion of the luxurious Excelsior apartment house on the East Side into a cooperative has been reduced by about 25 per cent.

title: Murderer Who Escaped In Connecticut Still Sought
description: SOMERS, Conn., April 25 Connecticut police and author ities in adjoining states inten sified their search today for Benjamin Reid, a convicted murderer who escaped from the state prison here yesterday.

title: Dr. Mattison Retiring July 1 As Public Health Unit Aide
description: Dr. Berwyn F. Mattison, who directed an extensive reorgani zation of the American Public Health Association during his 12year tenure as executive di rector, has announced he will retire July 1.

title: Wallace Backer Enters Race For South Carolina Governor
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 25 A. W. (Red) Bethea, a Presi dential elector for George Wal lace in 1968, entered the South Carolina Governor's race this week as a third party candi date.

title: The Nation
description: It is an axiom of systems re searchwhich a scientist wryly defined as common sense that the first task in solving a problem is defining the problem. In that respect the nation pre sumably made substantial prog ress toward environmental qual ity in last Wednesday's farflung Earth Day absorption with the globe's ecological woes.

title: Mr. Laird Pushes the Arms Race
description: Secretary Laird's missile rattling last year brought him two successive Presidential admonitions in the form of copies of Mr. Nixon's inaugural address with underlining beneath the words, We cannot learn from one another until we stop shouting at one another.... It would be interesting to know if a third copy was sent to the Defense Secretary after his release of scare pictures of Soviet MIRV multiple warheads and other intelligence data and his latest scare speech in New York.

title: Bullitt Letter Excerpts
description: Following are excerpts from newly released letters from William C. Bullitt to President Franklin D. Roosevelt:

title: This Thing Don't Lead To Heaven
description: This Thing Don't Lead to Heaven covers a day at the old folks home in Cumseh, Ga., just a regular old Sunday in the Senior Club, as one char acter remarks. The action begins with the arrival in town of Carlita Rojas Mundez, a Cuban refugee on her way to Atlanta, where she is to be a cook. She speaks only Spanish, is thought to be a Negro, practices voodoo magic on a variety of dolls made of bones and hanks of hair. (One of the dolls represents the driver of the Greyhound bus who has left her stranded in Cumseh.)

title: Letters:
description: Public Ownership of Exchange Firms

title: Ad Executive, 59, Found Injured Along Railroad
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 25A 59yearold advertising man, badly injured in an ap parent fall from a commuter train on the Penn Central's New Haven division late Fri day night, lay on the railroad's right of way overnight until he was seen from a morning train. He had suffered multiple frac tures.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Elliott of Jets Agrees To '70 Contract Terms
description: John Elliott, New York Jets' defensive tackle, has agreed to contract terms, the coach and general manager, Weeb Ewbank, announced yesterday.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Oliva opened the Minnesota half of the ninth with a single and reached second on Al Ka line's error. Then Killebrew sliced a hit between first and second, scoring Oliva and end ing Detroit's eightgame win ning streak.

title: For the Forgotten, a Play
description: WAY way Off Off Broadway a re hearsal was going on. Rain poured through a hole in the roof pre cisely at stage center, so the young actors, wearing uni form gray shirts and pants, did their improvisations hud dled at stage right. Every few minutes their dialogue was drowned out by the roar of jets taking off from LaGuardia Airport, which is so near that a strong arm could skim a stone at it across the narrow channel of the East River.

title: City Rent Law Blocks Owners From Retroactive Increases
description: Landlords have been blocked from collecting retroactive rent increases from certain tenants in 375,000 apartments covered by the city's Rent Stabilization Law.

title: COMMUNIST CHINA ORBITS SATELLITE; SPACE GAINS SEEN
description: HONG KONG, April 25 Communist China announced today that it launched its first space satellite yesterday.

title: Bernstein Paces Post Nine To 52 Victory Over Queens
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I. April 25 Pete Bernstein hurled a seven hitter today for his fifth victory of the season and slammed two hits to drive in three runs as he led C.W. Post College to a 52 Knickerbocker Conference victory over Queens College at Hickox Field.

title: In Zeckendorf's Mind, Ideas Are Spinning
description: THE big news is that William Zeck endorf Sr. is still dreaming. Which means that, despite his loss of 24,000 bottles of fine wines and $40mil lion in the collapse of his real estate em pire, a couple of years ago, his mind is spinning with buildings, highspeed trains, jetports, Stolports, container ports and architects' renderings of ma jestic projectsall in living color.

title: China Realigns Area Along Border
description: HONG KONG, April 25 An internal territorial rtans fer of potential strategic sig nificance has been detected in Manchuria by specialists on Communist China.

title: Youth Arraigned in Deaths Of 3 by Stabbing on S.I.
description: Albert Pedersen, 17yearold suspect in the fatal stabbing of a young married mother and her husband's elderly parents, was held yesterday in the Brooklyn Criminal Court for hearing May 5 on three homi cide charges.

title: Kerr on Boy Friend and Dear Jane
description: THERE are two new entertainments worth talking about, if not necessarily worth see ing, for the girls in them. In the latest revival of The Boy Friend, a wench named Sandy Duncan, hitherto of Canterbury Tales and now flattened out into a dizzy, el bowflapping, 1920ish surf board, comes on as a mem ber of the fourgirl chorus and almost instantly wipes the stage clean of any other presence. Bent backward, her redheaded bob bobbing to the ratchety clockwork of the beat, dancing cheek to belt buckle with the whiteshoed boy who brought her, she is the girl John Held Jr. had in mind holding.

title: Decision Nears in Dispute Over Plan to Develop Carolina Island.
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 25 The controversy that had raged for years over the future of Bald Head Island is heading for a decisionperhaps in court.

title: A Massachusetts Last
description: BOSTON, April 25 (AP)A 50yearold Greenfield woman was sworn in yesterday as lawyer, probably the last un der an old Massachusetts law allowing residents admission to the bar after an apprenticeship with a law firm. On the last day the law was in effect in 1967, Mrs. Marguerite Dolan applied for admission to the apprenticeship program. She served it with the head of the Franklin County Bar Associa tion.

title: Miss Urich Bride Of W. H. Hatch 3d
description: MADISON, N. J., April 25 Miss Roberta Anne Urich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Malcolm Urich of Chatham, was married here this afternoon in Grace Epis copal Church to William Hen ry Hatch 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hatch of Weston, Mass. The Rev. William L. Neiman performed the ceremony.

title: The Commitment
description: By the last week in April there is no more room for doubt. The commitment is complete. It's spring, no matter what happens today or what the weather turns out to be day after tomorrow. The sun climbs the sky farther and farther toward the north each day. Day light approaches the fourteenhour mark, which it will surpass before this week is out. (And we mark the longer light today by setting our clocks ahead for daylight saving time.) Birds sing. Buds open. Flowers bloomnot roses yet, and not all the violets, but hepatica and anemones and bloodroot and all the early ones.

title: The $50 Divorce
description: The new state law ended divorcement discrimination against the poor, who pre viously could rot afford a trip to Mexico or Reno. At the Legal Aid Society's civil branch on Park Place in lower Manhattan, the number of divorce cases handled last year shot up to 1,200 from about 200 a year under the old law.

title: Medicine
description: Psychosomatic shivers ran down the spines of pizza fans last week when the Food and Drug Administration issued a warning that as many as 80,000 frozen pizzas made by the Ro man Inn Pizza Company in Eau Claire, Wis., may be contami nated with the deadliest poison known to manthe toxin pro duced by the bacterium, Clos tridium botulinum.

title: Cars Said to Give Clue to Driver's Age'Well, Sort of
description: If you really want to know a woman's age, check with her automobile. It's a new technique that gives you an instant answer according to a connoisseur of cars and women.

title: Merchant's View:
description: Retailers are bearing up well under the strains and stresses in the economy, and many are convinced that the best tactic for the present is a holding action. They will be thankful for small gains in the months ahead  if such are attainable, and will wait out the Government moves to get a reversal in the rate of inflation and high interest rates.

title: Cambodian Troops Repel the Vietcong In Fight for Town
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sun day, April 26  Cambodian troops repulsed a threeday Communist attack at Ang Tasom and won their first ma jor test against the Vietcong, military spokesmen said today.

title: HICKEY COLT GOOD FOR A $10 PAYOFF
description: BALTIMORE, April 25Rob in's Bug, a son of Martin's Rul lah, surprised a crowd of 16,372 at Pimlico today when he scored a fivelength victory in the $36,750 Survivor Stakes for Marylandbred 3yearolds.

description: To the Editor:

title: OFFDUTY POLICEMAN KILLS BROOKLYN MAN
description: A 23yearold Brooklyn man was shot and killed early yes terday by an offduty police man who said that the man had wounded another police man.

title: 28 Stutz Is Auction's $15,000Star
description: Automobile collectors and dealers, attracted by a colorful assortment of cars dating from 1898, spent nearly $150,000 yesterday at an auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries here.

title: Blacks Are Ready to Travel, But
description: THE travel industry has been in tegrated by law for as many years as the common carriers and hotels catering to the general public have been required to accept on equal terms the custom of all wellcomported guests able to pay their bills. In modern times, the travel industry has been in volved almost completely with the white middleincome and uppermiddleincome classes of America because that is where its marketthe largest concen tration of customers interested in and able to afford foreign and domestic travelresides.

title: 2,000 CELEBRATE HISTADRUT SEDER
description: An updated Haggada was read last nightnot to answer the traditional Passover ques tions of how the ancient Israel ites fled from Egyptabut to tell what Histadrut, Israel's la bor movement, means in the social and economic life of the Jewish state

title: Article 4  No Title
description: When a husband and wife in a dealer's showroom look at a washing machine or power lawn mower, hesitate and then walk out without buying, a dozen considerations probably have affected their decision, and only one of these is price.

title: 200 Arrested in Costa Rica After PoliceStudent Clash
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 25 (Reuters)About 200 dem onstrators were under arrest today after 45,000 students battled with the police for four hours in an attempt to storm the national legislature.

title: Rise in Traffic Losses Reported for February
description: The Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday that the economic loss from traffic accidents in this na tion last February amounted to $1,113,581,000, an in crease of more than $17mil lion over February, 1969.

title: Camera Doings
description: APERMANENT new Gal lery and Photo Infor mation Center has been opened by the Eastman Kodak Company at 1133 Avenue of the Ameri cas (at 43d Street). The open ing show features a collection of 70 new photographs of New York, with a range of scenes that varies from aerial shots of Shea Stadium to in door pictures of the Rock ettes.

title: Heroes of the Confederacy
description: ON May 9, about 15 miles east of Atlanta, Ga., thousands of persons are expected to share in ceremonies dedicating the world's largest mansculp tured work (above) showing heroic figures of Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jack son. West Pointers, all they forsook Service under the Stars and Stripes to serve under the Stars and Bars of the Confederate States of America in an internecine struggle that threatened to sever this nation. Later this year, a stamp will be issued to commemorate the carving on Stone Mountain, a freak 8,000feetlong granite out cropping that juts out about 800 feet over the Georgia plains.

title: BETTING FORECAST CALLED INFLATED
description: Estimates that offtrack bet ting will bring the city $50 million in the next fiscal year are overinflated  to twice the likely figure, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yes terday.

title: Training Is Stiff for London Cabbies
description: LONDON, April 25  Each morning at 7, Allan Rosen climbs into his taxicab in sub urban Middlesex and starts driving toward Piccadilly. By 9 P.M., the 30yearold driver has picked up his last fare in downtown London.

title: Colleges Urged to Develop Better Links to Students
description: WASHINGTON, April 25A private study group said today that colleges and universities should develop better lines of communication among students, faculty members, administra tors and trustees to ease campus unrest.

title: Alvin Schall Weds Sharon LeBlanc
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 25 In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Sharon Frances LeBlanc, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moreland Paul LeBlanc Jr. of Darien, was married to Alvin Anthony Schall, son of Mrs. Edward Alden Rogers of Greenwich and Edgar town, Mass., and the late Gordon W. Schall.

title: R. P. McKinney And Lynn Pitts Wed in Suburbs
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 25In the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Lynn Carol Pitts was married to Ronald Paul Mc Kinney, who is sales manager in the Washington office of Francis I. du Pont & Co., stockbrokers. The Rev. Rich ard Sconnell performed the ceremony.

title: NIXON MAYDIVERT MODEL CITIES AID FOR SCHOOLS' USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Nixon Administration is seriously considering diverting money from the Model Cities program to provide funds that the President promised for school desegregation and for improving the quality of edu cation in black schools.

title: G.I.'s in 1945 didn't expect a rosy political future. A good thing, too..
description: order, because It has not been man's growing humanity that has given him this desperately needed stay but rather a common fear of extinction. Nor is this an argument for a con tinuing competition in ultimate weap ons, since what the two leading pow ers already have is ultimate enough to do the ultimate job. And finally, the precarious balance need only fail once and we are through.

title: Most of 32 Blocks In Houston Bought By a Gas Company
description: HOUSTON, April 25  The purchase of a major portion of 32 city blocks in downtown Houston was announced today by the Texas Eastern Trans mission Corporation.

description: TodayHunt Cap Farms, Main Street, Three Bridges, N. J. Maiden, novice, limit and junior working hunters; ponies, equita tion. 9 A.M.

title: KEY ROLE FOR IRAN SEEN IN GULF AREA
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 25 The view of the Shah of Iran and his Foreign Minister that their country should be the re gional leader in the defense of the Persian Gulf after the British withdraw in 1971 has received the support of two ranking officials of the United States State Department.

title: America's Cup Candidate To Be Launched in Florida
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 25 (AP)The second of two new America's Cup racers will be launched at St. Petersburg next Saturday.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: FIRE DEPARTMENT BATTLES DRINKING
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery acknowledged yes terday that in the last year there had been a slight increase of drunkenness by firemen while on duty.

title: One Man Dies, 2d Wounded In a Brooklyn Gun Battle
description: One man was killed and an other was critically injured in a gun battle yesterday morning in a Brooklyn restaurant.

title: JOHN, SOUTHPAW, LOSES 5TH IN ROW
description: CLEVELAND, April 25 (UPI) Tony Horton drove in two runs with a single and a home run and Ray Fosse hit his first homer of the season today to pace the Cleveland Indians to a 65 victory over the Chicago White Sox. Tommy John, a lefthander, suffered his fifth straight loss.

title: Oberammergau's Passion, Onstage and Off
description: OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany For a rustic, unruffled village of wood carvers, innkeepers and pious, occasional players, this is the year of passionon the stage, and beyond it. From May 18 to Sept. 30, more than a halfmillion people from around the world will stream into the forested lower slopes of the Bavarian aips to view the Oberammergau Passion Play. Every 10 years for more than three centuriesthere have been only a few interruptionsthe daylong reen actment of the sufferings of Jesus has been performed here in spite of buffet ing winds of criticism and ridicule.

title: Party Will Open Museum's Mexican Hall
description: Two hundred guests will attend a dinner party May 14 to celebrate the opening of the Hall of Mexico and Central America at the America Museum of Natural History.

title: REDS IN MALAYSIA INCREASE TERRORISM
description: SINGAPORE, April 25 The Communist underground here and in neighborhood Malaysia is stepping up propaganda and terrorist acts, apparently in preparation for the 40th anni versary of the Malayan Com munist party.

title: Meet the Mets
description: Horatio Alger, Don Quixote, Robert the Bruce's persistent spider and young David surrounded by Goliaths all seem to be part of the mystique of the New York Metsa team that did more last year to transport the nation into waves of ecstasy than the moonshot.

title: 8 FEDERAL INMATES PERMITTED TO SUE
description: Atlanta, April 25 (AP)A Federal district judge has authorized eight inmates of the Federal prison here to file a $240million lawsuit against tow corporations and officials of the prison.

title: Tuxedo Park Rider Is Heading for German Tour
description: JOHN W. (JACK) WINNETT Jr., an investor from Tuxedo Park, N. Y., will leave for a twomonth tour of Ger man horse shows on Satur day. He'll compete in dress age events ana has no idea how he will come out in this rather exotic division of the equestrian world. For two years now, while the jumpers and hunters have been competing in major shows, Winnett has been training every morning in his indoor and outdoor rings be hind his home. Occasionally he had an instructor, Fritz Stecken of Germany or Maj. Hector Carmona of Chile. But mostly he worked alone.

title: Photography
description: THE photographer's at titude towards nature is essentially differ ent from that of the painter. For the photographer life is an immediate reality which he penetrates and re produces. His passion is find ing, ordering, retaining. His object is that which is visible, palpable, measurable, and di visible. His means is a con scious crosssection in the course of a yetundefined time and a yetunknown space. What he does is re the present.

title: Personality:
description: John Kenneth Jamieson looks as if he was born to the corporate purple.

title: The Legal Season
description: The legal season is about to get under way, and before it ends, no one knows where or when, the structure of mass spectator professional sports may be radically changed.

title: 4 ARE CONVICTED IN HIJACKING CASE
description: The Government got its first convictions yesterday in its at tack on a truck hijacking ring in the metropolitan area al legedly dominated by the Mafia.

title: Scheduled Airlines Find Profits in Charters
description: The scheduled airlines, which have been complaining bitterly for some time about supplemental carriers' grow ing revenues from charter flights, now seem to be doing quite well in the same field.

title: Slowdown Reported In Texas
description: AUSTIN, Texas, April 25 An economic decline that be gan in late 1969 in Texas is continuing, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Texas.

title: A Family Hike in the Smokies
description: CHEROKEE, N. C.Where is the best place to start family hiking on the Appalachian Trail? The question came from the father of two boys of grammarschool age as we sat at a picnic table in a crowded campertrailer park near Sylva, 10 miles from the Cherokee entrance to Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

title: NEVER BOW NEXT
description: A & L rebounded for a stun ning gain on the equine stock market at Aqueduct yesterday, which is another way of saying that last season's Horse of the Year won the $84,650 Grey Lag Handicap.

title: Washington: The Politics of Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The main thing in all the talk about clean air and clean water these days is that the American people finally have a personal and political issue they can do something about  if they're really serious.

title: Japanese Socialist Party Fails to End LeftRight Split at Special Convention
description: TOKYO, April 25  The So cialist partyJapan's major op position group, which suffered a crushing defeat in last December's general election failed to solve its identity crisis at a special party con vention here this week.

title: VictoryBut Not For the Heart
description: LONDON

title: AGGIES' QUARTETS CAPTURE 3 TITLES
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 (AP)Texas A. and M., led by the speedy Mills brothers and Rockie Woods, dominated the 61st Drake Relays, which roared to a finish today with seven meet marks broken for a twoday total of 14, plus a world record in the 880yard relay.

title: Engagements
description: BRANDTALEXANDERMr. and Mrs. Simon Alexander happily announce the engage ment of their daughter Barbara Jane to Mr. Warren J. Brandt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Brandt.

title: NEWARK CANDIDATES CHARGE CORRUPTION
description: Five of the seven candidates for Mayor of Newark assailed the incumbent, Hugh J. Addo nizio, during a televised debate yesterday and agreed that mu nicipal corruption was the main issue in the campaign.

title: Nation's Oldest Society of Scholars Ruffled by Fight Over Cash for Science
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 In the shrine to American sci ence, under the benign gaze of Benjamin Franklin by Charles Willson Peale, several promi nent scientists gathered here tesday, to raise a collective voice against Federal budget, cutbacks for research. They did not succeed: Voices were raised, but not in harmony.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: Far from being inadequate, the pro grams of the Department of Correc tion are exemplary. They reflect an enlightened recognition of all that is desirable to effect the rehabilitation of the deviant. There is no emphasis on punishment. There is an intelli gent effort to effect rehabilitation consistent with necessary custody. JOHN V. LINDSAY, at the Adolescent Remand Shelter, Rikers Island, Feb. 28, 1969.

title: CHINA AGAIN FILLING AMBASSADOR POSTS
description: HONG KONG, April 25Com munist China has sent four am bassadors abroad within a pe riod of a month, resuming the reorganization of diplomatic representatives that it began last May and suspended in July.

title: Larceny by Bonnie
description: WHEN Bonnie Franklin, five foot three, eyes of green, hair like a ripe persimmon, struts her wideopen smile and whippy hip huggers across the Palace stage as a chorus gypsy in Applause, you nearly lose sight of the fact that the unquestioned star of the new hit musical is Lauren Bacall. (Larceny is the word for it, wrote Walter Kerr after observing Miss Franklin at work.) And when, wearing a slithery leathery black jumpsuit, she throws her self into a quick reprise of the title song by way of launching an interview in her West 57th Street hotel room...well, you nearly.

title: NEW SENATE FIGHT LOOMS ON DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 A new Senate battle over the defense budget appears likely as two Senators clashed today with the Senate and House Armed Services Committees over construction of a third nuclearpowered aircraft car rier.

title: 99.9 Million Cars in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)There was one motor vehicle in this country in 1969 for every 2.5 Americans, according to the Commerce Department. It said Tuesday that the United States had 99.9 million cars, trucks and buses out of the world's total of 216.3 million. By contrast, the African nation of Rwanda had one car for every 1,600 persons.

title: Picking Contenders in the Run for the Roses Is a Thornier Task Than Usual
description: Churchill Downs had hoped to stimulate wagering on this year's Kentucky Derby by adding an exotic 123 gimmick called the French Tierce.

title: Daisy Urged as U.S. Flower
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) A bill to name the Shasta Daisy as the national flower was introduced Thursday by Representative Don Clausen, Republican of California.

title: Egyptian Commando Victory In Canal Raid Is Reported
description: CAIRO, Sunday, April 26 (Reuters)A military spokes man here said that about 200 Egyptian soldiers crossed the Suez Canal today and wiped out an Israeli fortified position in a raid.

title: Observer: Pounding the Mother Tongue
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Things are not going well for the English language. Just re cently politicization has crept in and nobody seems disposed to take up a club and give it a bonecrushing whomp on each of its six illiterate syllables.

title: Person Joins Colts
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)  Ara Person, who played high school and college foot ball in Baltimore, signed a con tract today with the Baltimore Colts. Person, a 220pound tight end, caught 30 passes for 545 yards and eight touch downs last season at Morgan State College.

title: BRADSHAW SIGNS WITH STEELERS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) Terry Bradshaw, pro football's No. 1 draft choice for 1970, signed his contract today with the Pittsburgh Steelers for what was officially termed only as a multipleyear agreement. No cash terms were disclosed.

title: My Dear Cousin
description: Peggy Hoffmann has gone rummaging through American history and unearthed a tragic love story that should make thousands of women happily teary  and, to their surprise, a bit more educated than those who confine themselves to ladies novels have any right to expect. Judging by her choice of title, Mrs. Hoffmann seems content to shoot for the ladies market alone. She un derrates her novelized history: this vivid, downtoearth book merits a wide readership.

title: Justice Douglas and Wife Lead Hike to Make the C.&0. Canal a Park
description: GLEN ECHO, Md., April 25 (AP)  Justice William O. Douglas hiked 15.8 miles to day along the towpath of the historic Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, accompanied by his 26yearold wife, Cathy, and hundreds of other con servationists.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Fed eral Government's most expen sive anachronism, the Subver sive Activities Control Board, suffered another setback last week in its 20year search for something to do.

description: To the Editor:

title: Security Is Tightened
description: PNOMPENH, April 25The Cambodian Government, faced with broad inroads by Vietna mese Communist forces and in creasingly worried about the security of Pnompenh, is tight ening measures against the capital's Vietnamese residents.

title: Connecticut Track Squad Beats Columbia, 10153
description: The University of Connecti cut track team, led by Peter Lacaillade, defeated Columbia, 10153, yesterday at Baker Field.

title: G.M. LIKELY FOCUS OF AUTO WORKERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 The union man from Canada shouted into the microphone that it was time to strike against the General Motors Corporation.

title: RESTLESS RETREAT SECOND IN SPRINT
description: CHERRY HILL, N. 1, April 25 (AP)Hickory Tree Stable's Hagley drove to a onelength victory in the $28,900 Delaware Valley Handicap at Garden State Park today for his initial victory of the year.

title: Demand and Prices For Metals Stay Up
description: Demand and Prices For Metals Stay Up

title: Tax Law for Pueblo Crew
description: WASHINGTON, Apri125 (AP) The White House announced yesterday that President Nixon had approved a bill to give members of the U.S.S. Pueblo crew special tax exemptions for the time they were impris oned by the North Koreans in 1968.

title: DRIVE FOR FUNDS OPENS IN DIOCESE
description: Special masses at the 412 parish churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will open the annual fund raising drive of Catholic Chari ties today. This year's goal has been set at $7.3million, a mil lion dollars more than last year.

title: Talk, Or Inflammatory Misinformation?
description: TO THE EDITOR:DICK CAVETT'S contri bution to civilized talk on the late night shows has been widely noted. Recently Stokely Carmichael was Cavett's guest and I as sume that, to the extent word got around, there were many people watching who would be susceptible to Carmichael's arguments. He proved to be a beguiling figure. His man ner was almost bland. What he said was not, however, nor could it have been ex pected that it would be.

title: U.S. Not Surprised by Launching of Chinese Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Communist China's launching of its first satellite was greet ed by United States space and defense officials today as a longanticipated event that confirms China's growing tech nological capability.

title: TaxExempt Parsonage Pays Taxes for Services
description: PORTAGE, Mich., April 25 (AP)A minister says his congregation has voted to pay taxes on its taxexempt parsonage because it enjoys the same services from the city and school system as do the other residents.

title: Theodorakis's Wile Can't Leave
description: ATHENS, April 25  Greek security authorities today told Myrto Theodorakis, wife of composer Mikis Theodorakis, that she was still barred from leaving the country but would ?? when the ??

title: A Correction
description: The Times incorrectly stated last Sunday that Theodore Sor ensen had been permitted to see Federal income tax returns when he was special counsel to Presi dent Kennedy. The returns were actually made available to Car mine Bellino, whose title at the time was special consultant to President Kennedy.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fishing the Backwaters
description: PARISMINA, Costa Rica Primitive man, knowing nothing of the climatic forces that breed weather changes would if he encountered an unusual number of foul days while hunting or fishing, begin to wonder if he had offended the gods.

title: Paul Jablow Weds Miss Moraghan
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., April 25Miss Martha J. Mora han, reporter for The Ral eigh (N.C.) Times, and Paul John Jablow, the State Capi tol reporter for The Char lotte Observer, were married here this afternoon in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John B. Kanak.

title: WALTER C. CARROLL
description: Walter C. Carroll, a former president of the American As sociation of Sheet and Tin Plate Manufacturers, who served on the War Production Board in World War II, died Friday in a nursing home in Springfield, Mas. He was 93 years old and lived in Wilbra ham, Mass.

title: Car Crash Kills 2 From City
description: POCOMOKE CITY, Md., April 25 (UPI)Two New York men were killed today when their automobile ran off U.S. Route 13, just south of here and slammed into a utility pole. They were identified as Clifford Robinson, 26 years old, the driver, of 175 Lot Street, Brook lyn, and Jerry Johnson, 29, of 765 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive, Manhattan, a New York Ciy policeman.

title: Some field notes on an anthropological phenomenon
description: EVERYBODY talks about Mar garet Mead but nobody does anything about her, a fellow ethnologist complained, only some what facetiously, a short time ago. Florida's Governor Claude R. Kirk, for example, called her this dirty old lady (when she came to the defense of marijuana smokers at a Senate committee hearing on drug abuse). To Mrs. John Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General, she is a spook who just wants to get her name in the papers. Others call her over exposed or an international busy body. Unlike most of her colleagues, who bury themselves in the tribal customs of primitive man, Mead is visible, a willing plunger into modern social controversy who projects her self as a global prophetess on almost every subject that concerns the hu man condition. To a society troubled by its own shifting folkways, and hungry for guidance in coping with them, she is a poor man's anthro pologist, a mediator between high erudition and the middlebrow mind.

title: Copts and Ethiopians Clash in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 26 (AP) Coptic and Ethiopian Chris tians hurled abuse at one an other over the heads of Is raeli policemen today during Orthodox Easter observances at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, traditionally known as the tomb of Jesus.

title: PepsiCola Appoints 2
description: James B. Somerall has been named chairman and chief ex ecutive officer of the Pepsi Cola Company and Victor A. Bonomo has been chosen to succeed Mr. Somerall as presi dent of that division of Pepsi Co, Inc.

title: Eastern Applies for Flights From New York to Ponce
description: Eastern Airlines has applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority for the first non stop service from New York to Ponce, which is Puerto Rico's second largest city. At present commuter airlines link San Juanl International Airport near the capital with Ponce on the island's southwestern coast.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers, 31, for Seaver's 4th Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 The New York Mets benched three regulars today in their first shakeup of 1970. And, with Tom Seaver pitching a sixhitter, they defeated the Los Los Angeles Dodgers, 31, with a spray offense that included two home runs and five stolen bases.

title: TV: Lindsay Is Host of an Unusual Museum Tour
description: THE versatile Mayor Lind say, who can read a script with a professional actor's sense of timing, and the imaginative Aline Saarinen, the art critic, joined forces last night for a truly inven tive television program from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The hour was not the conventional museum tour, but almost an entertainment variety program containing elements of fun, enlightenment and uninterrupted pleas ure. In television terms it was a breakthrough in the treat ment of art.

title: NETS WINI127112, TO LEAD PLAYOFFS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 The New York Nets battled their way back into the lead to day in their semifinal round, playoff series in the American Basketball Association's East ern Division by defeating the Kentucky Colonels, 127112

title: Teiko Maehashi Makes Her Debut With Paganini Opus
description: Is there an undeground fac tory in Japan manufacturing violin virtuosos? Yesterday's soloist with the American Symphony Orchestra at Car negie Hall was yet another of those phenomenally good Jap anese violinists, this time named Teiko Maehashi.

title: Chiang's Son in California
description: EL TORO MARINE AIR STA TION, Calif., April 26 (AP) Deputy Premier Chiang Ching kub of Nationalist China ar rived in southern California this afternoon from Denver. He leaves tomorrow for Ha waii. Upon arrival he traveled by car to San Onofre to view to Southern California Edison Company's nuclear generating plan.

title: Actor, 19, Who Played Addict Dies of a Narcotics Overdose
description: Manuel Vasquez, a 19year old East Harlem youth who played the lead role in the Soul and Latin Theater's presenta tion of Dope, died in Metro politan Hospital Saturday night in circumstances strangely like those in the play.

title: 80% Success Claimed for Sex Therapy
description: BOSTON, April 25Two ex perts on human sexuality who have developed an intensive twoweek course of therapy for male impotence, female frigidity and other forms of sexual in adequacy say that their treat ment has been effective in eight out of ten cases.

title: SOVIET EVALUATES CHINA SPACE FEAT
description: MOSCOW, April 26The So viet Union reported today the launching of Communist China's first earth satellite with the barest publicity possible and no public comment.

title: 3 Derby Hopefuls in Strong Workouts
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 The workouts of the Elberon Farm's Silent Screen and Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Personality and High Echelon impressed ob servers at Churchill Downs this morning.

title: CANADIAN WRECK BEING PUMPED OUT
description: TORONTO, Aril 26In what may be the first pollutionpre vention action of its kind, more than a million gallons of heavy industrial fuel oil and sea water have been pumped out of the wreckage of the tanker Arrow on the floor of Chedabucto Ba?, Nova Scotia

title: Cambodian Quandary
description: The fundamental decision that confronts President Nixon in Cambodia is not whether to send further arms aid at this time but whether to pursue a mili tary mirage.

title: SERVICE DECLINES ON LONDON BUSES
description: LONDON, April 26Woman with shopping bag (handing fare to conductor on bus on Fulham Road): I should say it's about time. I've waited 25 minutes, mind you!

title: Russians to Increase Alumina Output
description: The Soviet Union's position as the world's second largest aluminum producer has been significantly strengthened with the inauguration of an unusual raw material source in Siberia.

title: Professors Start a Journal for Participatory Social Reform
description: A group of professors, in cluding Dr. Kenneth Keniston, the Yale psychologist, and Ami tai Etzioni, the Columbia Uni versity sociologist, have started a new journal, Social Policy, ex pressing a trend in social thought that has been described as participatory reform.

title: MORE RED FORCES SAID TO BE SENT TO CAMBODIA TOWN
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26  The Cambodian Govern ment today reported having captured Angtassom, a town 40 miles south of here, but report ers trying to reach it said that Vietcong forces still occupied the roads.

title: CHARLES KANTER
description: Charles Kanter, a Newark lawyer, died Saturday in Adelphi Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness.

title: RECITAL OFFERED BY PETER SERKIN
description: Since Peter Serkin is only 22 years old, he has plenty of time to develop into a mature musical artist, if that is what he would like to become. The recital he gave at Hunter Col lege Assembly Hall on Satur day night showed that his ex traordinary pianistic gifts and skills are intact and that he is indeed a thoughtful and imagi native musician. But it fell so far short of providing a satis fying artistic experience that it made at least one listener won der what the young man is try ing to accomplish.

title: Nasser Names EditorAdviser Chief of Information Services
description: CAIRO, April 26In a move to enliven the United Arab Re public's information services, President Gamal Abdel Nasser issued a decree today appoint ing Mohammed Hassenein Hey kal, leading editor and critic of secrecy and bureaucratic subterfuge to the post of Min ister of National Guidance.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Missing Vietnamese Mourned in Cambodian Village
description: CHRUI CHANGWAR, Cam bodia, April 26  Fourteen women attended mass this morning in this village of Vietnamese Roman Catholics across the Tonle Sap River from Phnompenh. Four bare foot boys sat among them, and another assisted the priest, a Frenchman. A French Benedictine monk was the only other person in view in the small Carmelite chapel.

title: Police Corruption Fosters Distrust in the Ranks Here
description: Corruption in the New York Police Department, which re portedly involves millions of dollars a year in graft, has cre ated an atmosphere of suspi cion, distrust and fear for many New York policemen, police sources report.

title: U.S. Envoy Arrives in Ceylon
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 26 The United States Ambassa dor to Ceylon, Dr. Robert StrauszHupe, arrived here yes terday. After presenting his credentials to the Governor General he will go to the Mal dive Islands, to which he is also accredited as ambassador, for a similar ceremony. He succeeds Andrew Corry.

title: BRAVES SCORE, 20, ON NIEKRO 2HITTER
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) Phil Niekro fired a twohitter and Tommie Aaron collected four safeties today as the At lanta Braves defeated the Pitts burgh Pirates, 20. Aaron drove in two runs on a homer and double.

title: Rock Festival in Illinois, Like Many Others Now, Meets Bitter Community Hostility
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., April 26Mrs. Liberty Throgmor ton says she likes kids.

title: Spring Brings Out A Hardy Perennial On a Brooklyn Lot
description: In the lambent air, on a neglected lane squeezed be tween the Belt Parkway and Gravesend Bay, Antonio Tur co labored patiently yester day to reclaim a corner of the city for spring.

title: TransAmerica Race Off
description: DALLAS, April 26 (AP)The, TransAmerican sports sedan championship race was post poned today by officials at the Dallas International Motor Speedway because an 8inch rainfall yesterday made track conditions dangerous.

title: U.S. Aide Gets U.N. Post
description: GENEVA, April 26Prince Sadruddi Aga Khan, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, announced today the appointment of Charles H. Mace, a 53  year  old United States Foreign Service officer, as his deputy. The High Com missioner said he was most happy that Washington had made Mr. Mace, who is now serving in Bonn, available be cause of his extensive experi ence with refugees and migra tion problems.

title: Status of Major Legislation Introduced in Congress
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: APRIL 27, 1970

title: STARS CLINCH SERIES BY 124123 VICTORY
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 26 (UPI)  Sevenfoot Craig Raymond tapped in the go ahead basket with 43 seconds left and blocked a shot 35 sec onds later as the Los Angeles Stars edged the Dallas Chapar rals, 124123 tonight to win their American Basketball As sociation playoff series, 42.

title: lakovos Leads Rite As Orthodox Here Celebrate Easter
description: On the stroke of midnight yesterday, Archbishop Iakoves, head of the Greek Archdiocese of North and South America, led a procession of priests, acolytes and churchgoers out of the Cathedral of the Holy Trin ity to the street, where he pro claimed, Christos Anesti [Christ is Risen]!

title: Sorensen Reports Trouble in Raising Funds to Campaign
description: Theodore Sorensen, the choice of the New York Democratic State Committee for the party's Senate nomination, said yes terday he was having trouble raising campaign funds.

title: Goodell Goes West Seeking Money for His Campaign
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 Senator Charles E. Goodell, whose $42,500 salary is the most money he has ever, earned in a year, glanced toward the Picasso oil over the fireplace in Samuel Shulman's living room last night and said: Well, I have to get about $3million in the next six months.

title: PRIMARY IN TEXAS PITS OLD AND NEW
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 25Almost every day, a stocky, 38yearold MexicanAmerican named Erasmo Andrade climbs into his 1964 Dodge and sets out for one of the small, dusty farm towns of south Texas Cotulla, perhaps, or Zapata or Beeville.

title: Gypsy Rose Lee Is Dead at 56; Made Strip Tease an Art Form
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 26, (UPI)Gypsy Rose Lee, who made the strip tease an art form, died tonight. She was 56 years old.

title: LOUIS KLOSK
description: Louis Kiosk, a builder and real estate operator, died Satur day night in University Hos pital. He was 85 years old and lived at 75 Central Park West.

title: SOVIET IS ASSAILED IN EXODUS MARCH
description: To the background of reli gious and secular chants, 20, 000 people, most of them young, staged an Exodus March and rally yesterday to protest discrimination against Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: TREASURY CHARTS REFUNDING PLANS
description: The Treasury, against the background of a demoralized bond market, is expected to an nounce on Wednesday its de cision on how to refund $4,863, 000,000 of publicly held notes coming due May 15.

title: Buford's Homer Wins, 109
description: KANSAS CITY, April 26 (AP) Don Buford's threerun homer with two out in the eighth in ning gave Baltimore a 109 vic tory today, the Orioles' 14th straight triumph over the Kan sas City Royals.

title: Malik Holds Talks Today
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Malik plans to talk tomorrow with representatives of the five nation Association of South east Asian Nations, which is sponsoring a conference on Cambodia. The Indonesians hope the conference will be held next month in Jakarta.

title: Go: It's Round, Square, Intellectual and Goes Thunk
description: A series of soft thunks, much as if stone was hitting lightly against wood, was heard yesterday in an up stairs room on West 72nd Street. It was the character istic sound of a game that is both the oldest in the world and the newest as a worldwide activitya game that is one of the simplest to learn, and the hardest to play well.

title: Chess:
THREE BILLS SIGNED ON HOME TAKEOVERS
description: ALBANY, April 26 (AP) Governor Rockefeller's office announced today that the Gov ernor had signed three bills whose overall effect will be to help New Yorkers whose prop erty is condemned for public projects.

title: Janice Mathews Engaged to Wed W. R. Stromsem
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., April 26James K. Mathews, Bishop of the United Metho dist Church for New England, and Mrs. Mathews have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janice Virginia Mathews, to Ens. William Rolf Stromsem, U. S. C.G.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Stromsem of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: KNICKS' REED SET TO FACE LAKERS
description: Championship fever of epi demic proportions will be in the air tonight at Madison Square Garden as the Knicks, only three victories away from the club's first National Basketball Association crown, face the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Romain Gary, Who Says He Wants Peace and Quiet, Stirs Storm With Hollywood Memoir
description: PARIS, April 26For a man who by his own account wants nothing more than a little peace and quiet, the writer Romain Gary manages to stir up a fair amount of conflict. He has done so twice so far this spring, and summer is still two months away.

title: Sisco Praised in Lebanon For Views on Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, April 26Joseph J. Sisco, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian af fairs, drew praise today for re marks about the Palestinians.

title: Egypt Reports Ambushes
description: CAIRO, April 26Two de tachments of Egyptian com mandos crossed the Suez Canal this afternoon and ambushed Israeli patrols, Cairo's military sookesman reported.

title: Rochester Bishop Chosen
description: ROCHESTER, April 26 (UPI)  The Right Rev. Robert Rae Spears Jr. was selected last night as the fifth Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Roch ester. Bishop Spears, who is Suffragan Bishop of Western Missouri, was chosen from 13 nominees for the post. He was born in Rochester and has a reputation as an activist. He will succeed Bishop George W. Barrett here

title: Nixon and Advisers Weigh Decision on Cambodian Aid Request
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 President Nixon and his top political and military advisers continued today to weigh United States policy in the rapidly deteriorating Cambo dian situation as Administra tion officials acknowledged that this might be a critical week in the crisis.

title: India Carries on British Sport, Hunting Vanishing Boar
description: ASAFABAD, India, April 12 A jackal howled out in the darkness as the slight Indian cavalry colonel, his face oddly lit by a flicker ing kerosene lamp, rose to address his civilian guests.

title: ALLY IN COALITION UPSET BY BRANDT
description: BONN, April 26Chancellor Willy Brandt's zeal in trying to improve ties with Eastern Europe caused him trouble this weekend in a quarter where it was least expectedhis rela tions with his coalition part Iner, Walter Scheel.

title: Beleaguered Empire
description: PARIS, April 26As the stock market bombards the spectacular financial structure of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the question being posed in the chic cocktail lounges of Europe is whether this is the begin ning of the end for Bernard Cornfeld. Bernie Cornfeld, as he is known by those who don't even know him (some call him the sun king), founded his empire in Paris in 1956 selling shares of American mutual funds in Europe, chiefly to G.I.'s.

title: Week's Votes In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: The New Temptation: Cambodia
description: LONDONHow familiar it all seems as the generals and the jingoes begin their pressure for American intervention in Cambodia. The situation, we read, gives us a great chance to win the Vietnam warif only we expand it. We must send arms and encourage the South Vietnamese Army to cross the border. The oppor tunity to clean out the Commu nist sanctuary is almost too rood to be true. Etcetera.

title: HAITIAN GUNBOATS REACH A U.S. BASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)  The three Haitian Coast Guard ships that shelled Port auPrince arrived at the United States naval base at Guanta namo, Cuba, yesterday and the men aboard asked for American asylum.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Peru Seizes Art Treasures Being Shipped to Germany
description: LIMA, Peru, April 26 (AP) Art objects from Peru's colon ial times and relics from the Inca era have been uncovered by customs officials in a ship ment marked household good that was bound for West Germany.

title: LANDLORDS ISSUE WAGECUT THREAT
description: Twelve hundred owners of rentcontrolled apartment build ings threatened yesterday to slash superintendents' wages up to 50 per cent and possibly dismiss other employes if Mayor Lindsay does not recom mend rent increases by June 1.

title: UKRAINIANS BEATEN IN SOCCER HERE, 32
description: The GermanHungarians de feated the New York Ukrain ians, 32, in a GermanAmer ican Soccer League game yes terday at Metropolitan Oval, Queens, and took a 2point lead in the South Group stand ing.

title: College of Optometry Expected to Open Here in '71
description: The hope of starting a college of optometry here in the fall of 1971 as part of the State Uni versity was voiced yesterday by Dr. Alden N. Haffner, executive director of the Optometric Cen ter of New York.

description: To Regulate Imports

title: Housing Looks to 7th Avenue
description: Can Seventh Avenue teach the housing industry some new tricks?

title: Tightening Asked In AirTaxi Rules As Result of Crash
description: An investigation into the crash of a Pilgrim Airplanes plane in Long Island Sound Feb. 10 with the loss of five persons may result in recom mendations for tighter safety regulations on airtaxis, a member of the National Trans portation Safety Board said last week.

title: MARCH ORDERS UP IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: New orders for machine tools  an important indicator of how businessmen view the futurewere almost unchanged in March from those of the preceding month.

title: Volleyball Title to U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26, (UPI)  The University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, won the Volleyball championship yester clay by defeating Long Beach State 157, 154, 158 in the final of the National Collegiate tournament at Pauley Pavillon.

title: HARLEM GUNMAN SLAYS 2 IN BAR

description: The Friends of the Whit ney, whose membership is about 750, will bring other friends to a party the evening of May 4 at the Whitney Museum. Their purpose is to inspire them to become mem bers of the museum at $250 a year each.

title: CONTINUING CLIMB IN JOBLESS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A monetarist model of the United States economy predict ed that unemployment will creep upward throughout 1970 and 1971 even if the money supply is allowed to grow at a rate of 3 per cent a year.

title: The Threat to LibertyII
description: Less than a generation ago, the tapped wire, the bugged room, the secret informer evoked contempt and ridicule in the minds of most Americans. These were the marks of police states in a jaded Old World. It could not happen here.
