Brezhnev in the Spotlight
description: Does Moscow's postKhrushchev collective leader ship still survive? That question is very much on the world agenda in the wake of the astonishing dis play of personal power by Leonid I. Brezhnev these last two weeks. Not since the distant days when Nikita S. Khrushchev took the center of the Soviet stage has one Kremlin leader so dominated Soviet press, television and radio.

title: Coast Guard Blames 2 Skippers In Fatal Collision Near Ambrose
description: The Coast Guard will prefer charges against both masters involved in last summer's col lision between the fishing boat Amberjack III and the tanker Tullahoma.

title: 100 Alaskans Descend on Washington This Week to Lobby for Oil Pipeline Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Upwards of 100 Alaskan busi nessmen, bankers, politicians, lawyers and publishers, headed by Gov. Keith Miller are de scending on the capital this wek for two days of intensive lobbying on the transAlaska pipeline.

title: Francisco Cunha Leal, 81, Portugal's Premier,192122
description: LISBON, April 26 (AP) Francisco Cunha Leal, Premier and Finance Minister of Por tugal in 1921 and 1922 who later became an outspoken op ponent of the regime of An tonio de Oliveira Salazar, died here today at the age of 81.

title: Screen: 'Sympathy for the Devil' ('1+1')
description: AN English-language movie by Jean-Luc Godard, opened theatrically yesterday at the Murray Hill. If you go on Monday, Wednesday, Friday or Sunday, you will see Godard's film, which is properly known as "1 + 1." On other days, you will see a film popularly advertised as "Sympathy for the Devil," which exactly resembles "1 + 1" except that in the latter part of the last reel a complete version of the song "Sympathy for the Devil," which the Rolling Stones have been rehearsing and recording in cuts throughout the film, is played on the soundtrack. Several monochromatic stills of the film's last shot are added to fill out the song's time. The changes and additions are the work of the producer, Iain Quarrier.Why anyone, given the choice, would prefer a producer's version of a movie to a director's escapes me. The movie to see at the Murray Hill is "1 + 1." Not only does the use of the song impose a sense of emotional fulfillment (and, I think, the wrong sense of fulfillment) upon a conclusion that does not ask for it, but also the use of the song's title for the movie suggests a meaning that is less interesting in context than, say, the proposition "1 + 1 equals 2."For "1 + 1" is a heavily didactic, even instructional, film, like much recent Godard, and it builds upon repetition, or, if you will, addition. The Rolling Stones' repeated assays upon "Sympathy for the Devil" in their recording studio, the rote repetitions of passages and slogans passed back and forth among black-power revolutionaries in their river-side automobile junkyard, the mere adding up of questions and answers in the interview sequences, juxtaposing words to make new combinations (such as "So-Viet Cong") and finding new words in old combinations (such as SDS in "Sight and Sound"; LOVE in "All About Eve")all suggest a concern with ways of putting things together, to the film seems determined to be the prospective text of some ultimate, infinitely complex collectivism.Whatever its intentions, "1 + 1" contemplates rather than advocates revolution. It collects evidence and examines texts  including a by now famous pornographic political novel read on the sound track ("'You're my kind of girl, Pepita', said Pope Paul as he lay down on the grass . . .," etc.)records interviews ("The Occident is fighting communism because the Occident is Faustian?" "Yes."), and observes the forces preparing the apocalypse.In "1 + 1" the camera comes alive on its cranes and tracks. As if lost in a precise meditation it moves deliberately among the persons and places of the Stones' recording studio or from wreck to wreck in the fantastic black power junk heap.The chief delight of the film lies in this precision and in these scenes. At the end, when it martyrs its one named character, Eve Democracy (Anne Wiazemski), it spreads her body across a mighty camera crane on a seashore. The crane lifts her in a great sweeping movement, red and black flags flying in the wind, across the sky. And at this moment, and not until this moment, it seems possible that the meaning of Godard's film depends not only upon a cause but also upon the camera's eye; not only in sympathy, but in objectivity as well.

title: A Second Career: Children's Books
description: CATHERINE BURNS, the blond, babyfaced actress who won raves as the teen aged rape victim in the movie, Last Summer, is now writing children's books.

title: Wisniewski and Harvey Win Metropolitan A.A.U. Runs
description: George Wisniewski of the United Athletic Association won the 5,000meter Metropol itan Amateur Athletic Associa tion development run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: White Sox Win, 20
description: CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) Joe Horlen held Cleveland to three hits in seven innings and drove home a run with a single today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 20 victory over the Indians.

title: Advertising: Agency Involvement Is Urged
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26  After three days of creativity, costs and cocktails; crisis, competition and cocktails; commercials, chaos and cock tails, some of the nation's leading advertising men who had placed some of its lead ing bankers, turned the state ly Green Brier Hotel over to some of its most skilled surgeons. So life goes on.

title: F.C.C. Phone Study Finds Service Here Worst in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Federal Communications Commission, making its first national survey of telephone service, has compiled volumi nous new evidence that the New York City phone system is the worst in the country and getting worse.

title: Airlines Aide Is Shifted
description: Scandinavian Airlines an nounced yesterday that Tore H. Nilert, president of its American subsidiary company since 1946, would rejoin the organization's main headquarters in Stock holm.

title: WISCONSIN'S G.O.P. SEES A LOVELL BID
description: MILWAUKEE, April 26 Speculation that Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. would run for the United States Senate in Wis consin mounted this weekend after the astronaut said that he was still thinking about the race.

title: Brewers Triumph, 53
description: BOSTON, April 26 (AP) Gene Brabender allowed the Red Sox just two hits until the ninth inning today and then Bobby Locker came out of the bull pen to retire the last batter as the Milwaukee Brew ers topped Boston, 53.

title: S.E.C. Challenges Rules on Solvency
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are arguing over how to measure whether a brokerage firm is insolvent and ought to be put out of busi ness.

title: SALES EXPAND 11% AT RETAIL CHAINS
description: An early Easter helped to bolster chain store sales last month.

title: Scientists Find Cutbacks Reaching a Critical Point
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Scientists concerned over the vitality of the nation's research effort believe a critical point is fast approaching. It is the point at which further economies, postponements in buying equip ment, and other efforts to stretch scarce research dollars will no longer suffice.

title: Craftsmen of Sexuality
description: ONCE every four or five years, Dr. William H. Masters locks up his office and hides. That's the day on which he publishes one of his studies on human sexual behavior, for which he has observed sexual intercourse in the laboratory.

title: Theater: Company Offers a Guide to New York's Marital jungle
Soviet Lifter Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, April 26 (AP)  Vasily Alexeyev, a Soviet weight lifter, set a world record of 476.1 pounds in the super heavy weight press class today at Vilnius, Lithuania. The pre vious record of 473.9 pounds was set a week ago by Serge Reding of Belgium.

title: PENGUINS WIN, 21, TO SQUARE SERIES
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) Michele Briere, for the second West final playoff game in a row, scored one goal and as sisted on another tonight as the Pittsburgh Penguins evened their Stanley Cup series against the St. Louis Blues with a 21 victory.

title: 2 Japanese Pros Card 65's To Lead in Nagoya Tourney
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 26. (UPI) Hiroshi Ishii and Yosh imasa FujiiJapanese Pros, fired fiveunderpar 65's today for a stroke lead in the open ing round of the 11th Chunichi Crowns tournament.

title: The Other Side of the Ledger
description: Although New York City and probably every other urban area across the country can use all the money available, there are two sides to a municipal ledger, not just one. You can close budgetary gaps by in creasing taxes and increasing revenues. You can also close them by cutting expenditures and making absolutely certain that programs run efficiently and without any waste or un necessary personnel.

title: HEPATITIS FEARED IN GROTE CHECKUP
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 The New York Mets had a new worry today  hepatitis, the liver ailment that already had appeared among the St. Louis Cardinals and Los An geles Dodgers players.

title: KENNEY CONNECTS, DRIVES IN 3 RUNS
description: After giving away baseball caps in their first promotional day of the season, the New York Yankees stuck a feather in their own caps yesterday by defeating the Oakland Ath letics, 83, and climbing out of last place in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Giants Rout Expos As McCovey, Dietz Hit Grand Slams
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)Willie McCovey and Dick Dietz hammered out grandslam homers and McCovey and Bobby Bonds also hit solo shots as the San Francisco Giants crushed the Montreal Expos, 111, today.

title: ROJAS IS SECOND IN COLOMBIA TALLY
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 26 The official vote count for Colombia's national election ended today, awarding the presidency to Misael Pastrana Borrero, candidate of the gov erning coalition. But the week of violence and tension since the balloting last Sunday has posed the question of how he can govern so long as the for mer dictator Gustavo Rojas Pinilla insists the victory should be his.

title: RUSSIANS OBSERVE EASTER AT GRAVES
description: MOSCOW, April 26Tens of thousands of Russians observed Easter today by strolling through cemeteries, where they ate picnic lunches, chatted as they placed the traditional hard  boiled eggs and cakes on graves, and enjoyed the warmth of Moscow's sunniest day of the spring.

title: Stamping Out Freedom
description: General Maxwell D. Taylor knows as much about America's involvement in Vietnam as anyone in the world. He was President Kennedy's Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Johnson's Ambassador to South Vietnam, still serves as President Nixon's Chairman of the Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board.

title: Alomar's Double Decides
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Sandy Alomar's eighthinning double drove in Aurelio Rod riguez with an unearned run that decided the game today as the California Angels de feated the Washington Sena tors, 32.

title: Equal Political Air Time
description: The Senate has made a valiant try at easing the high cost of political broadcasting. It has succeeded by halfthe most important half: repealing the equal time section of the Federal Communications Act.

title: Senators Get Reichardt
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) The California Angels traded Rick Reichardt, high bonus out fielder and Aurelio Rodriguez, an infielder, to the Washington Senators today for Ken Mc Mullen, a third baseman.

title: L. I. Charities to Gain
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 26  The Cornelia Junior Assembly Ninth Annual Din ner Dance, to be held at the Garden City Casino on Fri day, will benefit the Charities of the Bishop's Call. The 43 ninthgrade and 10thgrade girls who have been invited, with their escorts, attend the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here or the Cathe dral School of St. Mary. Eligibility to attend depends on completion of the required hours of church and com munity service.

title: Wendy Norris To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Wendy King Norris to Cpl. Richard Hooker Wilmer 4th, who is serving with the Ma rine Corps at Quantico, Va., was announced yesterday at a cocktail party given by her grandmother, Mrs. John Wal lace Kearns, at her home here.

title: OUTLOOK IN STEEL HELD REASSURING
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26Re ports on the steel market were reassuring last week.

title: SAMUELS BACKED BY NEW COALITION
description: The New Democratic Coali tion, an organization of liberals and reformers, voted yesterday to endorse Howard J. Samuels for Governor.

title: CITY PUTS FREEZE ON JOBS OF POLICE AND GARBAGE MEN
description: The Lindsay administration has quietly imposed a job freeze on the uniformed police and sanitation forces to offset unexpected additional expenses in the current budget.

title: Asian Talks Rejected
description: HONG KONG, April 26 North Vietnam and Communist China have made it clear that they oppose a conference of Asian nations on Cambodia as proposed by Adam Malik, In donesia's Foreign Minister.

title: Passengers Arrive From Haiti
description: MIAMI, April 26The Haitian airport, closed since coast guardsmen mutinied and shelled PortauPrince on Friday, re opened today. Three planes left the capital.

title: Ruby Drives to Victory in Trenton 200
description: TRENTON, N.J., April 26 Lloyd Ruby of Wichita Falls, Tex., a 42yearold driver who still has a lot of racing left in him, won the Trenton 200 to day, beating out Mario Andretti by five seconds. Al Unser of Albuquerque, N. M., finished third.

title: GRAEBNER DEFEATS RICHEY IN NET FINAL
description: HOUSTON, April 26 (AP) Clark Graebner won the 36th River Oaks invitation tennis tournament today by beating Cliff Richey in the final, 26, 63, 57, 63, 62.

title: Trinidad Appoints Panel To Investigate Rebellion
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 26 (Reuters)The Gov ernment announced today that a threeman committee would inquire into a mutiny of troops that broke out last week after a state of emergency was de clared to curb black power anti  Government demonstra tions.

title: Israel Warns Jordan on Voiding Truce
description: JERUSALEM, April 26The Israeli Government, through the Unitd Nations, has warned Jordan of the severe implica tions of a new Jordanian dec laration that the ceasefire no longer exists between the two countries.

title: Beard's 71 for 273 Provides 7Shot Victory in Tournament of Champions
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 26Although his 31st birthday doesn't come until Fri day, Frank Beard thought his victory in golf's Tournament of Champions today and the win ner's check of $30,000 were early and suitable anniversary gifts.

title: A School Redolent of Shallots and Wine
description: PARISIt Is not nearly so well known as the Sor bonne, for example, or the Alliance Francaise, but one of the most interesting schools in Paris is in the 17th arrondissement.

title: Top Colleges Fear Costs Will Bar the Middle Class
description: Admissions officers of the Ivy. League and Seven Sisters col leges are expressing fear that rising costs are driving away middle  income students and turning their campuses into places for the poor, supported by scholarships, and the rich.

title: J. & L. Cuts Back
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (UPI) The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation said this weekend it was cutting hack production because the strike by haulers had tied up deliveries. The company said 3,000 men were being laid off as a result of the dispute.

title: O'Brien Puts Kennedy on List Of Presidential Possibilities
description: Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, said yesterday that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Mass achusetts must be rated among the party's potential Presi dential contenders in 1972 despite his disclaimer of can didacy, the Associated Press renorted.

title: 10,000 Celebrate Hair's Birthday in Park
description: A warm Sunday afternoon, azure skies and the rocking rhythms from Hair, the loverock musical that usher ed in the Age of Aquarius, combined yesterday to at tract 10,000 people to Central Park's Mall for the show's second anniversary party.

title: ANITA LOUISE, 53, MOVIE STAR, DIES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI)Anita Louise, whose career as a movie actress be gan at the age of 5 and spanned more than 70 pictures, died last night of a stroke. She was 53 years old.

title: International Law Society Elects Professor as Head
description: The American Society of In ternational Law elected Harold D. Lasswell of the Yale Law School yesterday to succeed Oscar Schachter of New York as president.

title: MORGENTHAU URGES CLAY'S TITLE RETURN
description: The State Athletic Commis sion should restore the world heavyweight boxing champion ship to Cassius Clay, Robert M. Morgenthau, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, said yesterday.

title: Joseph Wells, Golf Champion And China Concern Head
description: NEWELL, W. Va., April 26 Joseph M. Wells, board chair man of the Homer Laughlin China Company, and a former United States senior golf cham pion, died Friday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: KODAK 3MONTH NET RISES 8% TO RECORD
description: The Eastman Kodak Com pany realized an 8 per cent in crease in firstquarter earnings on a sales gain of 5 per cent with both setting record levels for the period, according to the report released today.

title: CHANGES FORECAST IN DEFENSE SPENDING
description: NonVietnam defense spend ing is likely to increase sharply over the next five years, off setting a significant part of the decline in Vietnam expendi tures, according to an analysis of the Federal Budget released yesterday by the National In dustrial Conference Board.

title: Governor Scored on Bill Calling For Criminal Justice Agency
description: Two Democratic candidates for statewide office charged yesterday that Governor Rocke feller's socalled supercop bill was a political smoke screen and an electionyear gimmick.

title: HENNING RALLIES TO CAPTURE GOLF
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 261 (AP)  Harold Henning blazed to a birdieeaglebirdie finish today to edge young Rives Mc Bee by one stroke in the $50,000 Tallahassee open golf tourna ment. It was the South African pro's first victory since the 1966 Texas open.

title: DENIED PARTY AID, MICHAELS TO RUN
description: AUBURN, N. Y., April 26 Assemblyman George M. Mi chaels, the Democrat of this city who was denied party endorsement for reelection because of his decisive last minute vote for the abortion reform bill in the Legislature, announced tonight that he would seek renomination in the June 23 primary election.

title: Penn Relays Irked at Athletes Who Run Out Rather Than Run
description: The bus bringing the Atoms Track Club from Brooklyn to the Penn Relays last Satur day broke down miles out side of Philadelphia.

title: Bruins Top Hawks, 54, on McKenzie's Late Goal and Sweep East Final, 40
description: BOSTON, April 26  With less than 1 minute 41 seconds remaining, Johnny McKenzie, who once roped calves in rodeos and who played for the New York Rangers briefly four seasons ago, scored the goal that provided the Boston Bruins with a 54 victory today for a sweep of their Stanley Cup series with the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: DR. ALEXANDER, LED ORTHODOX SEMINARY
description: JORDANVILLE, N. Y., April 26 AP)Dr. Nicholas Alexander, dean of the Holy Trinity Ortho dox Seminary here, an engineer and former officer in the Im perial Russian Navy, died yes terday at the age of 84.

title: Rosamond Hoyt Heroy Fiancee Of Lieut. Thomas H. Miller
description: HUNTINGTON, LI., April 26The engagement of Miss Rosamond Hoyt Heroy to Lieut. Thomas Hayes Miller, U.S.N., who is with the Bu reau of Naval Personnel in Washington and is a White House social aide, has been annouced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Ward Heroy of Lloyd Harbor. Lieutenant Miller is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Har ry Maxwell Miller of Eliza bethtown, Ky.

title: Abortion Law Seen Burdening State
description: The possibility that pregnant women from all over the coun try might inundate New York hospitals with requests for abortions has created an im mense organizational and fi nancial problem, two specialists in community medicine said here yesterday.

title: CLARA THOMAS, 79, MURALIST, IS DEAD
description: MOUNT DESERT ISLAND, Me., April 26Mrs. Clara Fargo Thomas, a painter and muralist, died today of cancer at her home, Fortune Rock. She was 79 years old.

title: AMON CAPTURES SILVERSTONE RACE
description: SILVERSTONE, England, April 26 (AP)Chris Amon of New Zealand ended seven years of frustration today by captur ing his first Formula One auto race, the Silverstone Interna tional Trophy for Grand Prix cars.

title: Hollywood's Fairest
description: Miss Louise, who in the nine teenthirties was named the most beautiful actress in Holly wood, was a natural blonde with golden hair, blue eyes and a creamy complexion. She was long considered one of the best dressed women in the movie colony.

title: Merrill Lynch Plans Overhaul Of Economic Research Division
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest brokerage house, is planning to overhaul com pletely its economic research department.

title: Antonio Ayuso, Publisher, Dies; Built San Juan's El Imparcial
description: Antonio Ayuso Valdivieso, owner of El Imparcial, a news paper in San Juan, P. R., died Saturday of a stroke at Down town Beekman Hospital. He was 71 years old and had come to New York for medical treat ment. Surviving are his widow, the former Iris Mieres; a son, Antonio Ayuso Mieres; a sister and three grandchildren. A fu neral mass will be offered at 10 A.M. tomorrow at Our Sa viour Roman Catholic Curch, 59 Park Avenue.

title: TWINS AND TIANT DOWN TIGERS, 60
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 26 (AP)Luis Tiant, triggering a fourrun Minnesota sixth in ning today with a double and stolen base, stopped Detroit, 60, with a threehitter.

title: MRS. KING VICTOR IN ITALIAN FINAL
description: ROME, April 26 (AP)  Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., using a brilliant assort ment of drop shots and passing drives, defeated Julie Heldman of New York, 61, 63, today for the women's singles title of the Italian international tennis championships.

title: In Memoriam
description: ELLENBOGEN Franklin Jr. In cherished memory of our beloved son and brother who went away seventeen years ago. KATZ Ida. In loving memory. Still missing you Henry.

title: 4 G.I.'s Are Reported Killed In Vietcong Attack on Basel
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday. April 27 (Reuters) United States military spokes men said today that Vietcong broke through the perimeter of an American artillery base 46 miles northwest of Saigon last night and killed four Americans and wounded 12 in a halfhour battle.

title: MARY LOU WILLIAMS PLAYS JAZZ PIANO
description: Mary Lou Williams, a jazz pianist whose long and highly active career has encompassed ragtime, vaudeville, blues, big band swing (with Andy Kirk's band and as arranger for Ben ny Goodman), bebop, the jazz avantgarde and, in re cent years, religion expressed through jazz, gave a con cert last night at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, that touched on many aspects of her musical experience.

title: PUBLIC REPORTING CORRUPTION DATA
description: Mayor Lindsays appeal to the public for confidential in formation on police corruption here has begun to elicit use ful and specific information, the city's Department of In vestigation reported yesterday.

title: ExAide to Dean Accused of Setting Penn Campus Fires
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26A former associate dean of stu dents at the University of Penn sylvania has been arrested and charged with setting fires at the university early yesterday.

title: Summer Job Prerequisites: Talent, Luck and Audacity
description: To get an interesting, high paying summer job, a metro politan area student often needs knowhow, luck, con nections or the ability to tell a believable lie.

title: Sihanouk and 3 Top Reds Hold Parley on Indochina
description: HONG KONG, Monday, April 27 (Reuters)  The deposed Chief of State of Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, met leaders of North Vietnam, the Vietcong and the Pathet Lao Friday and Saturday, the North Vietnam press agency said today.

title: New York Donations
description: In New York State after Co lumbia, New York University was second with $23.8million, Cornell University third with $21.3  million, Yeshiva Univer sity fourth with $16.1  million and the University of Rochester fifth with $13.4million.

title: MoneyLabor Pinch Felt By 2 British Shipyards,
description: LONDON, April 26Two major British shipyards are facing acute financial and la bor problems. They are the Upper Clyde Shipbuilders, Ltd., of Clydebank, Scotland, and Harland & Wolff of Belfast, Northern Ireland. Their com mon problem is one of soaring labor costs.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series).

title: Fashion Mannequin Designs Swimsuits
description: TAKE heart, you women who look upon the prospect of shopping for a bathing suit with the same degree of glee as a visit to the dentist or the supermarket on Satur day afternoon. June West doesn't like it either. And not because she has any figure problems that need disguising.

title: 17,000 Youngsters at the Stadium Don Their Gift Baseball Caps for the Yankees
description: Contrary to what it may have looked like on television yesterday, Horace Clarke and Bobby Murcer of the Yankees were not taking their signals from the stands in the eighth inning of the game against Oakland.

title: William Nichol, Who Commuted 685,000 Miles, Is Dead at 97
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., April 26William B. Nichol, a former special agent in the traffic section of the Eastern Railroad Association, died at the Dobbs Ferry Hos pital today after a short ill ness. He was 97 years old and lived at 765 Broadway here.

title: Fund Managers in Boston Trim Sails and Ride Out the Storm
description: BOSTON, April 26One day last week while the stock market was being mauled, a money manager in Boston could afford briefly to smile. My Quotron is on the blink, he explained, so I can't tell how badly my portfolio is doing.

title: 3 Charities to Gain At Baseball Games
description: Fans of the Yankees and Mets will have an opportuni ty this spring to cheer their favorite team while contribut ing to their favorite charity.

title: Bridge:
description: MANY sad stories at the bridge table concern de fensive might  have  beens. An expert rises to the occa sion with a brilliant maneu ver, but his incompetent partner fails to cooperate and the contract is made after all.

title: RUSSIAN REPORTS ECOLOGY THREAT
description: MOSCOW, (AP) April 26  Two Soviet farmers accidentally, killed more than 50 cranes, 200 rare great bustards, 11 gray geese and 50 foxes by careless use of chemical pesticides, a Moscow conservationist re ported today.

title: CUBS VICTORS, 63, FOR 10TH IN A ROW
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (UPI) Ron Santo, who had driven in only four runs this season, snapped out of his slump with his fourth career grandslam homer today to pace the Chi cago Cubs to a 63 victory over the Houston Astros. It was the Cubs' 10th consecutive triumph, their longest streak since 1953.

title: State's Mentally Ill Children Neglected, Civic Group Charges
description: An influential civic group de clared yesterday that children in the state's mental hospitals were not receiving adequate treatment or required school ing.

title: Yuriko and Her Dance Troupe Offer Premieres at 92d St. Y
description: VURIKO'S customary cho reographic voice is quiet understatement, but occasion ally she allows herself a more vigorous approach. On Satur day evening at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, she en closed the middle section of her program with two reper tory works that showed her in a spritely and charming mood.

title: 200 Young Basques Clash With Police In Guernica Protest
description: GUERNICA, Spain, April 26 (Reuters)  Policemen wielding nightsticks today dispersed 200 to 300 young Basques trying to stage a demonstration here against the Government, on the 33d anniversary of the destruc tion of this historic Basque town during the Spanish Civil War.

title: Printers Union and Publishers Resume Contract Talks Today
description: Another effort to resolve the New York newspaper contract dispute will be made at 10:30 A.M. today when union printers and publishers of the city's four major papers resume negotia tions after a weekend recess.

title: MEANINGFUL OFFER SOUGHT BY SHANKER
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, declared yesterday that the Board of Education must make a substantial be ginning wage offer and es tablish an intensive schedule of negotiations to ease the possibility of a strike next month by professional school employes belonging to the union.

title: JAY LeFEVRE DIES; EXREPRESENT ATIVE
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., April 26 Jay LaFevre of New Paltz, a former Republican Representa tive, died at the Kingston Hos pital today. He was 76 years old.

title: CAMERATA CONCERT STRESSES VITALITY
description: Abraham Kaplan's Camerata Singers and Camerata Sym phony Orchestra gave a con cert at Philharmonic Hall that was notable for vitality. Or chestra and chorus pitched in with a will, and there was a sense of full involvement.

title: Cards Defeat Reds, 41
description: ST. LOUIS, April 26 (UPI) Bob Gibson pitched a fivehitter and struck out 15 batters in his first complete game of the sea son today as the St. Louis Cardinals downed the Cincinnati Reds. 41.

title: Eastern Air Prepares Some Ads for Summer
description: Through TV and radio, magazines and newspapers, Eastern Airlines will be pro moting A Summer to Re member in Bermuda, Puerto Rico or Florida. The ads will even suggest you take the Wings of Man.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN The Nashville Sound, a Southern reporter named Paul Hemphill has pro duced a firstrate book on the Country & Western music scene. This is news that may strike you as being about as useful as the fact that Jean Shepherd can tap out the William Tell Overture on his front teeth. But the fact remains that ever since the dust bowlers went West, ever since Northern boys started coming back from Fort Benning and the other Southern Army camps, and ever since the word got out among Southern farmers that there was gold in the factories of the North, country music has been infiltrating the masscult.

title: Lindsay Urges P.B.A. to Forgo Job Action in Contract Dispute

title: Lorrayne and MacLeary Head Cast Changes in Sleeping Beauty

title: Holding Up the City
description: The city's uniformed patrolmen are threatening to hold up the city at midnight tonight with a socalled job action overwhelmingly voted by members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. This uncon scionable pressure tactic on the part of supposed guardians of the law stems from an admittedly com plicated contract dispute; it is particularly inexcusable now because it comes at a time when a court action has already been filed. Furthermore, the P.B.A. will be ignoring procedures of the city's Office of Collec tive Bargaining, which has settled previous disputes involving the police, and if it goes through with the projected action will also be defying an injunction barring such a move.

title: Amex Prices Slide To TwoYear Low
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell to their lowest level in more than two years yesterday as the list continued to decline in slow trading.

title: 'Zigzag' Fantasy Opens at the Coronet
description: "ZIGZAG" finally does a tailspin. A great deal of ability and perspiration has gone into this suspense melodrama about a supposedly dying man, who cooks up a fantastic swindle scheme to benefit his family, snaps to after an operation and tries to wiggle out of the mess. And a mess it truly is, for this cunning chap, believing he is doomed by a brain tumor, has deliberately gotten himself tried and convicted for a dormant, unsolved murder case.What now to save his skin? Having hornswoggled a keen insurance company, the Los Angeles police force, his own suspicious lawyer and a jury, he now nips out of a prison hospital into town and in a few hours, and more or less intuitively, unearths the real murderer.Anybody who believes this intricate story, painstakingly developed by John T. Kelley's scenario, will believe anything. As the deceptive hero, a man who pulls off a miracle comparable to Jonah's, George Kennedy performs with dogged, admirable sincerity. Better still, however, are Anne Jackson as his confounded wife, and Eli Wallach as his exasperated lawyer, and with good reason.For not only is the incredibly farfetched plot cluttered with trivial details and zigzagging flashbacks, it also rushes forward breathlessly behind what amounts to a directorial smokescreen. Richard A. Colla, a sharp new talent, has elected to flip an already baffling plot at the viewer teasingly, in flying bits and pieces, with a twitching camera that goes hysterical at the climax, along with the sound track. The color, by the way, is excellent.Steve Ihnat, William Marshall and others do well on the sidelines. But even if you can keep apace of "Zigzag," you won't believe it.

Although it is an intelligent, wellmade film, it is also  surprisingly  somewhat banal. It achieves its goals so early that there isn't much for the mind and the eye to do but to consider the incriminating repetitive details of lives made bitter, empty and hypocritical under Stalinist Communism.

title: Nixon Wound Up by Apollo Trip
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Exhausted by over 5,000 miles of travel in less than 24 hours, the members of the press pool accompanying President Nixon on the return leg of his recent whirlwind trip to Honolulu fell asleep somewhere across the Pacific. Without warning, a dark, familiar shape ap peared and drew back the curtain of the separating the White Home press section of the airplane from the larger quarters reserved for the Presidential party. The man from The Associated Press, who had one eye open, quickly nudged his colleagues from the National Broadcast ing Company, The New York Times and United Press In ternational. Too late. By the time they had roused them selves, President Nixon had smiled, closed the curtain and disappeared.

title: 'Hi, Mom!' a Brian De Palma Satire
description: AMONG contemporary-urban-scene-movies (sub-genre, invasion-of-privacy) Brian De Palma's "Hi, Mom!" stands out for its wit, its ironic good humor, its multilevel sophistications, its technical ingenuity, its nervousness, and its very special ability to bring the sensibility of the suburbs to the sins of the inner city. With no recognizable landmark further north than Cooper Square, it nevertheless feels like Bronxville or the quieter stretches of the upper East Side.Not that it aspires to quietness or that it even for a second eschews relevancy. One major portion (for me, the best portion) depicts an all-black play production, "Be Black, Baby," in which the cast, in white face, mingles with, steals from, and finally beats and rapes the white liberal audience. And the hero, a young Vietnam veteran, moves from filthy picture-taking to middle-class apartment house bombing, partly in an effort to achieve total involvementwhich, in the terms of this film, seems necessarily to include a final solution.But the eager hero (Robert De Niro) and the over-eager heroine (Jennifer Salt, the major interest of the flashbacks in "Midnight Cowboy," revealed as a fine comedienne here) are so clean-cut; the second leads, white and black, so epitomize attractive youth; and the supporting cast, as in many Brian De Palma movies, could so handsomely model a panoramic painting of the Rape of the Seven Sister Colleges; that an air of tasteful respectability pervades even the outrageous violence. As if they were making bombs on West 11th Street."Hi, Mom!" turns approximately every other current social misery to a comedy that is sometimes quite elabborately successful and sometimes only well intentioned. As in De Palma's previous "Greetings," the humor, at its best, is understated but highly structuredso that you have to work a bit for your laughs. But "Hi, Mom!" is much sharper, crueler, funnier. Although it scatters some shots (often in a kind of fast-motion photography that seems an addiction of De Palma's) it pulls enough together to suggest some major insights, as it investigates the militarization and despoliation of Washington Square South.But it is the minor insights that most happily remain: the white black-power activist (Gerrit Graham) who for a second demurs before painting his body entirely black; the pornographic-movie impresario (Allen Garfield) who wants to make "the first children's exploitation filmnothing dirty, nothing smutty;" or the mere idea of the TV show that chronicles the opening night of "Be Black, Baby!" A production of National Intellectual Television, it is called "N.I.T. Journal," which, (to my mind, comes under the category of what oft was thought, but ne'er so well expressed.

title: POLICEMAN BEATEN BY 3 IN BROOKLYN
description: An offduty patrolman was beaten and slashed with knives and a machete by three men in Brooklyn early yesterday but managed to wound two sus pects.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARTHA BYRD HOYLE has written a military history of World War  so concise, so lucid and so unemo tional that the war itself assumes a pecu liar shape in the mind: as though we were perceiving it whole for the first time, a blossoming and withering of neon flowers, a kind of cancer eating its way to the brain of the earth along energy lines and mineral veins that have been lit with a cold elec tric light. Forty million lives and 40 trillion dollars later...why? Mrs. Hoyle seems less interested in why than in how, for the most part eschewing per sonalities and ideologies. Some dislocations result. The extermination of the Jews, for instance, gets only two paragraphs, as does the decision to drop the atomic bomb. The firebombing of Dresden gets only a sentence. Resistance activities in occupied France, the Balkans and else where are barely hinted at. And the ex tramilitary behavior of the Red Army on its way to Berlin goes unmentioned.

title: U.S. RIDERS FACE EUROPEAN SLATE
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., April 27 The United States Equestrian Team will compete in six major European horse shows starting with Wiesbaden, Germany, May 16 through 18, Bert de Ne methy, the coach, announced today.

title: Negro Fund Aide Named
description: Ely R. Callaway Jr., president! of Burlington Industries, has been named national corporate chairman of the 1970 drive of the United Negro College Fund. He will direct the fund's appeal for $4.5 million from the na tion's leading corporations.

title: COMMERCIAL PAPER AT RECORD IN MARCH
description: The commercial paper market surged to a record for the third consecutive month dur ing March, the Federal Re serve Bank of New York re ported yesterday. But the fig ures showed that the rate of climb was markedly lower than has been characteristic recently.

title: Phone Bill Is for $2,544
description: AVELLINO, Italy (UPI)Vit torio Petretat asked the tele phone company to recheck his bill, which was for the equiva lent of $2,544 for 99,000 direct dialing longdistance calls the company said he made in three months. Mr. Petreta said he had made only a handful of calls.

title: Market Place:
description: THE little guy who has suf fered as much as any body in the current bear market is perhaps more dis enchanted than ever before with Wall Street.

title: Note Links Explosion at Louisiana Capitol to Police Killing of 3 Negroes
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 27 (UPI)An anonymous note wrapped around an ar row and dropped in a news paper's mail slot today said that Louisiana's Capitol was dynamited last night in re taliation for the killing of three Negroes by the police.

title: FLORABEL MUIR, 80, OF THE DAILY NEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27 (UPI) Florabel Muir, a reporter and columnist for The New York Daily News, who covered both Hollywood celebrities and New York gangsters during her career, died of a heart attack today. She was 80 vears old.

title: Briton, 98, Says Burglars Brightened Her Boring Life
description: LONDON (UPI)When bur glars invaded the home of Miss Jennie Arnold, 98 years old, she said she did not mind a bit.

title: School Named for Disney
description: TRAPANI, Sicily (AP)An elementary school just erected in this town in western Sicily has been named Scoula Walt Disney, after the cartoonist.

title: Taillights Urged for Horses
description: MELTON, England (UPI)  The Melton and Belvoir Road Safety Council has asked hunts men to fit red reflectors to the tails of their horses as motor ists complained they could not see returning huntsmen clearly as dusk.

title: Soviet Announces Program to Combat Pollution and Conserve the Nation's Water Supply
description: MOSCOW, April 27  The Soviet Union announced a com prehensive legislative program today to conserve water and curb increasing pollution.

title: Infirmary Plans Benefit May 6 At Wildenstein's
description: All five floors of Wilden stein's art gallery will be open the night of May 6 as the New York Infirmary sponsors a benefit there.

title: Sondheim Scores With Company
description: Several years ago George Furth wrote a straight play, or rather eleven miniplays, about marriage, and Kim Stanley was going to play all the wives. Astoundingly al tered, the Furth work is now the new Harold Prince Stephen Sondheim hit musi cal, Company, starring Dean Jones  as the best friend in all those marriages.

title: Schary Assumes City Post
description: Dore Schary, the playwright and honorary chairman of the Anti Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, was sworn in yes terday as, the city's new Com missioner of Cultural Affais. The post pays $35,000 a year. The swearingin ceremony, with Mayor Lindsay officiating, took place at the museum of the city of New York 104th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL FORESEES GAINS
description: John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corpora tion, said at the annual meet ing yesterday that the company expected profits during the re mainder of the year to be con siderably better than in the first quarter, when earnings fell from 53 cents to 27 cents a share.

title: PRESS CLUB GIVEN EVICTION PETITION
description: The Correspondents Fund, which holds title to the 11story building at 54 West 40th Street that houses the Overseas Press Club, served an exiction peti tion on both the club and 35 of its tenants yesterday.

title: In The Nation:
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 27 As Governor of Puerto Rico, Luis Ferre is pledged to develop the Commonwealth; as a prom inent citizen, he has never stopped calling for Estadidad Jibara. Since Jibaro is a fa miliar word for a native Puerto Rican, particularly a country man, this translates loosely into what some deride as hillbilly statehood but what Mr. Ferre explains as our kind of state hoodour own thing. That is obviously what statehood for Puerto Rico would have to be.

title: Vanier Wins College Golf
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 26 (UPI)Gary Vanier, a sopho more from Stanford, shot a oneoverpar 72 in the final round to win the individual championship in the United States invitation college golf tournament yesterday as Stan ford won the team title with a 54hole aggregate of 872 strokes.

title: Morocco Shears Visitors
description: TANGIER, Morocco (AP)A British tourist huff arriving at the Moroccan border found that the police had decreed no more longhaired males could enter the country. The bus waited while the driver and two passengers were shorn.

title: TV STATIONS END TONY CURTIS ADS
description: Tony Curtis's conviction for marijuana possession in Lon don yesterday has prompted immediate cancellation of his antismoking spots for the American Cancer Society by national and local television.

title: DOUGLAS ABSTAINS FROM 3 RULINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Justice William O. Douglas dis qualified himself today from participating in rulings on ob scenity appeals involving the film I Am Curious (Yellow) and a libel suit against Look magazine.

title: Monkey Riding Dog's Back Is EyePopping to Texans
description: POST, Tex. (UPI)A working cowboy who rides into town and ties his horse in front of an airconditioned diner raises little interest in this West Texas community.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 28, 1970

title: Married Fiance Is Sued
description: MILAN, Italy (AP)  When Antonio Nicita learned that his eldest daughter's fianc of five years was married he sued for $4,385, saying that would just cover the cost of the food Ful vio Oreste had eaten with the family and for his other daugh ter's labor as Mr. Oreste's sten ographer. The court denied the claim, but ordered Mr. Oreste to pay $128 in court costs.

title: Mike Sorrentino Retires as Jockey at 40
description: Operating on the theory that if life really begins at 40 that perhaps it ought to start with a new format, Mike Sorrentino, the jockey from Baldwin Harbor, L. I., has quietly announced his retirement.

title: Observer:
description: WASHINGTON, April 27In this radio commercial being used in the termite belt this spring two termites are over heard discussing the dumbness of the man whose floor they are eating. While they gorge on white pine boards and ori ental rug, they speculate wheth er it will ever occur to the poor boob to call the extermi nator for whom they are shill ing, and to make it harder for him they eat his telephone di rectory.

title: Portugal Increases Rates
description: LISBON, Portugal, April 27 (Reuters)The Bank of Portu gal increased its bank rate from 3 to 3.5 per cent today, and in terest rates of commercial banks and credit houses were also raised by a half of one per cent.

title: BLUES TO RETURN PLANTE TO GOAL
description: ST. LOUIS, April 27 (UPI) Jacques Plante will be back in the St. Louis goat tomorrow night when the Blues play the Pittsburgh Penguins in the fifth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff.

title: LateHitting Angel
description: Jay Johnstone of the Cali fornia Angeles, hitting only .205 last June 28, spurted to finish with a .270 average.

title: Petitions and Parades:
description: AS far as the fashion estab lishment is concerned, there is no hemline hassle. The mini, a definition that includes anything above the knee, is out; the midi, an equally elastic definition that descends from the knee to the ankle, is in.

title: Bronx Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Lance Cpl. James M. McDonough of the Bronx was identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: LACROSSE RACES DRAWING TIGHTER
description: The lastminute victory, the heroic substitute, the drive that falteredthese were the ingredients that contributed to the tightening of division la crosse races last week.

title: Doctor Finds Virus in Mothers May Cause Nervous Disorders
description: A doctor reported yesterday finding that some disorders of the nervous system, thought to be congenital, may be caused by viral infections in the mother during pregnancy.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Rockwell Picture Stoleit From Physician's Office
description: Thieves broke into the office of Dr. George Roberts, a physi cian, at 79 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, during the weekend, and stole a painting by Norman Rockwell, done for a Saturday Evening Post cover in the nine teentwenties.

title: Key Decision by London Awaited on Plane Funds
description: LONDON, April 27The Brit ish Government faces difficult financial decisions on two proj ects crucial to the future of the British aircraft industry  the British Aircraft Corporation's proposed widebody airliner, the B.A.C. 311, and the advanced jet engine of RollsRoyce, Ltd.

title: Jakarta to Repay Debts Over a 30Year Period
description: PARIS, April 27 Afternearly four years of negotiations, Indonesia and Western creditor countries have agreed upon a formula for repayment of her debts over the next 30 years.

title: U.S. Grants Asylum To Latvian Woman Taken Off Trawler
description: The United States Govern ment granted political asylum yesterday to a 25yearold Lat vian waitress who took an overdose of barbiturates 18 days ago to get off a Soviet trawler sailing 100 miles off New York.

title: SENATORS' RALLY TOPS BREWERS, 65
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  Ed Brinkman's two run single tied the game and John O'Donoghue's throwing error let in the deciding run in the 10th inning tonight as the Washington Senators rallied for, a 65 victory over the Mil waukee Brewers.

title: Paduano Fears Appetite, Not Cerdan
description: Donato Paduano of Montreal, will fight Marcel Cerdan Jr. in Madison Square Garden on May 11, says the only worry he has in meeting the unde feated Frenchman is eating too much.

title: Berkeley Team Reports Synthesis of 105th Element
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A team of physicists at the Uni versity of California in Berkeley reported today the synthesis of a new element and proposed that it be named hahnium in honor of Otto Hahn, the late German physicist.

title: YALE'S SIX CREWS FACING DILEMMA
description: Yale's heavyweight crews are scheduled to row in the Carnegie Cup regatta at Prince ton on Saturday while the light weight oarsmen play host to Princeton and Harvard in the Goldthwaite Cup at Derby, Conn. However, the six Eli crews will be deciding boat by boat to go through with these races or to withdraw as a means of displaying sympathy for the Black Panther demon stration this weekend on The Green in New Haven adjacent to the university.

title: Senate Passes Bill Raising Veterans' Disability Pay
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Senate passed a bill to day that would increase dis ability compensation payments to two million veterans and their dependents by about $230 million a year.

title: U.N. Assembly Leader Is Married in Monrovia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 27Miss Angie Brooks of Liberia, president of the 24th General Assembly, was married today to Isaac Ran dolph, an educator. She kept a longstanding promise to let her friends at United Nations know right away.

title: GERMAN REDS ASK FOR EXTRA WORK
description: BERLIN, April 27  Faced with serious economic troubles and a farming crisis, East Ger many called on all ablebodied men and women throughout the country over the weekend to put in extra work in day and night shifts.

title: PIANOFLUTE TEAM FROM CANADA BOWS
description: Claude Savard pianist, and Suzanne Shulman, flutist, two young performers from Canada, made their New York debuts last night in a concert pre sented by Carnegie HallJeunes ses Musicales at Carnegie Re cital Hall.

title: Chinese Food, Gallic Flair
description: PARISAlthough Paris has scores of fine restaurants (and please don't labor the point that the finest French restaurants are in the prov inces), a few of the most interesting are not necessar ily French.

title: Caymans' Tax Base Limited
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. (AP)A United Nations Secre tariat paper noted that Britain's Cayman Islands got most of their government revenue from import duties and postage stamp sales, and there are no income, capital gains, property, sales, corporate, estate, excise or inheritance taxes.

title: N.Y. Phone Declines
description: Profits of the New York Tele phone Company for the first quarter of 1970 fell to $41, 484,000, or 34 cents a share, from $49,362,000, equal to 47 cents a share, in the like period last year, the Bell Sys tem affiliate announced yester day.

title: CASE DISMISSED IN POLICE ATTACK
description: A complaint filed two years ago on behalf of two members of the Black Panther party who were among those beaten in the Brooklyn Criminal Courts Building by a group of whites that included offduty and out ofuniform policemen has been dismissed as unsubstantiated.

title: Government Program to Aid Home Financing Progresses
description: MIAMI, April 27 (UPI) Three Government sales of mortgagebacked securities last week brought to $25.5million the total sales volume under the new program to aid resi dential financing, an official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: Three Derailments Delay Commuters On Penn Central
description: Penn Central services were delayed yesterday by three de railments.

title: M.P.'s Ask Inquiry Into the '65 Murder Of a Salazar Foe
description: LONDON, April 27On an April morning in 1965, a young Spanish shepherd found two bodies partly covered with earth and stones in a eucalyp tus grove near a village beside the Portuguese border.

title: Food Stamps for Wine? No!
description: RALEIGH, N. C. (AP)Gro ccers who sell beer or wine in exchange for Federal food stamps will have their beer and wine licenses revoked or sus pended, the North Carolina Board of Alcoholic Control ruled.

title: Average Tokyo Wage Noted
description: TOKYO (AP)The average monthly net income of a Tokyo worker's family in 1968 was 107,000 yen ($297), the metro politan government announced.

title: Study Links Malnutrition and Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 A Senate committee was told today that a Government sur vey just completed in Texas and Louisiana found wide spread malnutrition, attributed in part to poverty.

title: RED SOX WIN, 43, ON SMITH'S CLOUT
description: BOSTON, April 27 (AP) Reggie Smith completed a per fect day at bat today by lead ing off the eighth inning with a home run, lifting the Boston Red Sox to a 43 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Screen: Korty's riverrun Treks Back to the Soil
description: JOHN KORTY'S riverrun is an ode to the simple life as it is lived by Sarah and Dan, two Berkeley drop outs who have elected to re turn to the soil on an im mensely photogenic sheep ranch two hours outside San Francisco.

title: CITY OPENS STUDY OF POLICE GRAFT
description: Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin yesterday rejected a call for a state investigation of charges of police corruption after presiding at the first meeting of a special committee appointed by Mayor Lindsay to investigate the allegations.

title: French America's Cup Challenger Holds First Trial
description: LA TRINITE SUR MER, France, April 27 (Reuters) France's first challenger for the America's Cup, The France, underwent first sea trials today.

title: National Biscuit Company
description: Strong marketing programs developed for the remainder of 1970 should make it a satis factory year, Lee S. Bickmore, chairman of the National Bis cuit Company, told stockhold ers at their annual meeting yes terday in the Commodore Hotel. He said that the company had the best first quarter in its history, having bounced back from a costly strike that shut 13 of our major bakeries last fall. The company he said, has entered the research and development of basic protein materials for a world market.

title: URBAN LEAGUE CITES EIGHT JOURNALISTS
description: Earl Caldwell, a reporter for The New York Times, and Don Hogan Charles, a Times pho tographer, are among the eight journalists named to receive the 1970 Russwurm Awards, presented each year by the New York Urban League.

title: Absence at Relays Clarified
description: Dulaney High of Timonium, Md., which won the unseeded section of the schoolboy two mile relay at the Penn Relays Saturday, did not apply for the championship race, a spokes man for the meet's seeding committee said yesterday. It was reported to the press Sat urday that the team's applica tion had been turned down be cause its previous times for the event were not fast enough.

title: Indiana Standard Off
A Jockey's Dream Day
description: An apprentice jockey, Rudy Tur??, ?? six winners on Dec. 2, 1969 at Aqueduct Race Track, the first time since 1964 that this had been accom plished.

title: Morgenthau Resigns as Third Deputy Mayor and Lindsay Abolishes Position
description: Robert M. Morgenthau re signed his $42,500ayear post as a Deputy Mayor yesterday and Mayor Lindsay, parceling out the duties elsewhere, quick ly abolished the post.

title: Saigon Aide Gets Cambodian Pledge on Vietnamese
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 27South Vietnam officially called on the Cambodians to day to preserve the lives and property of the Vietnamese mi nority and was told that Cam bodia would take steps to stop all acts that are contrary to the principles of justice and human ity.

title: U.S. Embassyi n Cambodia Gets New Communications
description: PNONPENH, April 27 (AP) A United States air Force C130 arrived today and un loaded ases that American of ficials said contained commu nications equipment for the United states Embassy.

title: The Hudson, a Public Interest
description: Governor Rockefeller's misbegotten scheme for building a sixlane expressway along the Hudson River north of Tarrytown has received another rebuff in a ruling of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that has implications for conserva tion far beyond the shores of the Hudson.

title: Practice Bomb Hits Home
description: ARCACHON, France (UPI) A practice bomb fell from a French Air Force plane on a training flight and crashed through three rooms of an empty house here.

title: Cricket Tour a Racial Issue in Britain
description: LONDON, April 27  The hottest issue in Britain today is not the upcoming election or the war in Southeast Asia or pollution. It is cricket.

title: 19 Youths Arrested With 40 Bombs Here
description: The police raided a base ment club at 517 West 134th Street last night and seized more than 40 homemade bombs. Nineteen teenagers, who, the police said, were mak ing the bombs in production line fashion for use in a gang war, were taken into custody.

title: Ballet: New Staging of Cinderella in Washington
description: WASHINGTONThe new production of Prokofiev's Cinderella, seen here over the weekend at the Lisner Auditorium, is very possibly the most ambitious project to date of Washington's Na tional Ballet. The company already has Giselle, La Sylphide and Copplia. in its repertory, but this was the first time it had dared pro duce a completely new choreographic version of a fullevening ballet.

title: ARTHUR SHIELDS, ACTOR, DIES AT 74
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 27 (AP)Arthur Shields, the actor and younger brother of the late Barry Fitzgerald, died today of emphysema at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: Dove Has Nets Winging in Playoffs
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 27Sonny Dove pushed his 6foot8inch frame around in the New York Nets' work out today at the Island Garden. He dominated the offensive and defensive boards and his jump shot was working well from both corners and from the key.

title: A Circuit Riding Rabbi in Bible Belt Helps Jews to Retain Identity
description: WHITEVILLE, N. C.The burgundy Oldsmobile bumps along the back highways of the Carolinas, trailing a cloud of dust and passing paintflecked roadside signs nailed to the trees along the tobacco fields.

title: Fiberboard Box Use Rises
description: Percapita corrugated fiber board box consumption in the United States amounts to al most 100 average size boxes for every man, woman and child in the country, a 35 per cent increase in the last de cade, according to the Fiber Box Association, United Press International reports.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.) Wisniewski and Harvey Win Metropolitan A.A.U. Runs
description: George Wisniewski of the United Athletic Association won the 5,000meter Metropol itan Amateur Athletic Associa tion development run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Gypsy Rose Lee Memorial Service Tomorrow
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27 Gypsy Rose Lee, the strip tease artist, actress and author, died of cancer last night at U.C.L.A. Medical Center. She was 56 years old.

title: Grote's Ailment Called Noncontagious and He Is to Rejoin Mets Thursday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 Hepatitis shots were ruled out at least temporarilyfor the New York Mets today after the team received encouraging word on the condition of Jerry Grote.

title: PRICES IN LONDON RESUME DECLINE
description: Prices on the London stock market resumed a downward trend yesterday as renewed selling reversed initial gains. Key market indexes closed at lows for the year.

title: EASTERN TENNIS DEEP IN TOURNEYS
description: Prize money? Forget it. Conflicts with professionals? Nonexistent. Expense payments? Unheard of.

title: Auto Use Rises in Austria
description: VIENNA (AP)Austria had 155,480 newly licensed auto mobiles in 1969, an increase of 4.3 per cent compared with the previous year, the Statistical Office reported.

title: Price of Progress in Colombia
description: Colombia's dilemma after the surprisingly powerful Presidential bid of General Rojas Pinilla last week is a familiar one for developing countries. President Lleras Restrepo's administration, which has laid the necessary foundations for sound economic develop ment and social reform, has been a model in the Alli ance for Progress.

title: Theater: Women's Lib
description: ARISTOPHANES' Ecclesia zusae probably was the world's first play about women's liberation. First per formed in Athens in 392 B.C., it reopened last night under the title The Republic at the Free Store Theater, the scene of the great Che bust.

title: Israel Players Demonstrate To Meet Rhodesia in Tennis
description: TEL AVIV, April 27 (Reu ters)  Israelitennis players called on the Lawn Tennis As sociation today to go through with the Davis Cup match against Rhodesia.

title: In Memoriam
description: APRILGloria Anna. In loving memory of my beloved daughter Gloria, who departed this world April 28, 1931. May God grant her beloved soul Eternal Peace. Amen.

title: Eisenhowers Lead 1,500 to Hail Dr. Peale's Mental Health Work
description: Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, minister of the Marble Col legiate Church, author and lec turer, was honored last night by more than 1,500 persons for his efforts in the field of men tal health.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THERE have been so many dazzling moments for the Knicks throughout this season that their bemused fol lowers can see only to the end of the current rainbow. Hopefully, it will he the first basketball championship ever won by the New Yorkers in their long and not always glorious history. They can supply a fitting climax to a spectacular year by polishing off the Los Angeles Lakers in the final playoff series now in progress.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Chicago

title: Mayor Asks Doctor to Head Hospitals
description: After an intensive search, Mayor Lindsay has asked Dr. Peter Rogatz to head the quasi independent corporation that will assume control of the city's 18 public hospitals on July 1.

title: Washington:
description: April 27

title: Nastase Wins Italian Tennis Title by Defeating Kodes in 4 Sets
description: ROME, April 27 (UPI)  Ilie Nastase of Rumania became the first East European to win the Italian tennis championship to day when he beat Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia in the final, 63, 116, 63, 86.

title: MOYNIHAN SCOLDS CHAMBER ON BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Presidential adviser, scolded the United States Chamber of Commerce today for its shrill opposition to the Nixon Ad ministration's welfare reform legislation.

title: Student Fiance Of Miss Krech
description: WESTBURY, N.Y., April 27 The engagement of Miss Barbara H. Krech to Ronald C. Smeder, son of Rear Adm. Orvan R. Smeder, U.S.C.G., Assistant Chief of Staff for Ocean Sciences at Coast Guard Headquarters in Wash ington, and Mrs. Smeder of Chevy Chase, Md., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William G. Krech.

title: The Daughter of Colette Emerges From Obscurity Briefly
description: COLETTE, the French writer who created such de lectable girls as Claudine and Gigi and Mitsou, and who was responsible for the casting of the then unknown Audrey Hepburn in the role of Gigi for the stage (the movie came much later), also produced a girl of her own.

title: 11 Students, 2 Teachers Seized in Hunter Protests
description: Thirteen persons, including two faculty members, were arrested at Hunter College yesterday during a day of hitand run disturbances by bands of dissident students. The arrests followed the announcement earlier by Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the col lege, that seven students had been suspended for the rest of the spring term and that she would no longer tolerate violence, force and bully tactics.

title: The Long Arm of Chamberlain Helps Defeat Knicks
Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Striking Teachers Reach An Accord in Minneapolis
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 27 (AP) A tentative agreement was reached today on a contract that would end a 19day strike by more than 2,000 public school teachers.

title: Union Oil Co.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27 The annual stockholders meet ing of the Union Oil Company here today was marked more by what did not happen than what did.

title: Life Terms Asked For 2 Convicts In Police Slaying
description: A State Supreme Court jury here recommended life sen tences yesterday afternoon for two men whom they had ear lier found guilty of murdering a policeman. The jury had been given the choice of recommend ing life imprisonment or the death penalty.

title: Strikes Rise in Israel
description: TEL AVIV (AP)Israel had 114 strikes in 1969, up 13 per cent over 1968, the Govern ment reported.

title: Economic Passivity
description: There is no limit to the number of theories about what ails the stock marketdespair over persistent inflation, falling profits, rising unemployment; the skid of the Federal budget into deficit, and the likeli hood that this might force the Federal Reserve to tighten money again; the weakness of the security industry itself; the worsening of the United States balance of payments; the danger of a widening war in Southeast Asia; waning confidence in the Adminis tration's ability to manage the economy.

title: 4 Democrats Ask Details On Finances of Blackmun
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)Four Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee have asked for more detailed disclosure of the financial af fairs of Judge Harry A. Black mun, President Nixon's latest Supreme Court nominee.

title: NEW GROUP SCANS CORPORATEACTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The formation of a study group to make detailed inquiries into corporations' performance in such areas as defense produc tion and the environment was announced today.

title: MONTICELLO PLANS BETTING CHANGES
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 27  Monticello Raceway will open its 13th season of harness racing Thursday night with win, place, show, daily double and perfecta betting in various de nominations. An innovation will be the same availability of $3 doubles and perfectas, which will replace the more conven tional $2 tickets.

title: Larry Rockefeller Fitted in Perfect on 121st St.
description: Michelle Jackson side stepped an overflowing gar bage can and raced down the block after the lean, blond young man. Hey, Larry, hey, Larry! she called. Hey, Larry!

title: Rates of Treasury Bills Climb At Weekly Government Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Treasury bill rates advanced sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: Cuba Says 13 in Invading Party Are Dead or Captured
description: MIAMI, April 27Cuba an nounced today that all mem bers of an exile guerrilla group that landed in Eastern Cuba on April 17 had been either killed or captured.

title: Sailor Dischar ged Over Protest Leaflet
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)A Navy court rep primanded and ordered a bad conduct discharge today for Seaman Apprentice Roger Lee Priest, who has been convicted of promoting disloyalty and disaffection through his anti war newsletter, Om.

title: TERROR IN STREETS IRKS SOVIET WOMEN
description: MOSCOW (UPI)The coun try girls who went to Fergana to work in the silk weaving mill found the advantages of their high wages outweighed by ter ror on the streets, a Soviet newspaper reportd.

title: WHEAT FUTURES HAVE MIXED DAY
description: Reports that grain output in Europe may not come up to early estimates sparked buying of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Austin Uses Arc Lights
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (AP)An of ficial state marker commemo rating the city's 27 artificial moonlight towerscarbon arc street lightshas been dedi cated here.

title: YIELDS AT PEAKS IN BOND MARKETS
New Parquet Floor Made
description: Floor parquets made of wood impregnated with liquid plastic solidified through a nuclearen ergy process are being produced by the American Novawood Cor poration of Lynchburg, Va., the magazine Architectural Record reports. The floors are highly re sistant to moisture and require only light buffing to maintain.

title: Plane Maker's Profit Down for Quarter
description: SEATTLE, April 27  A crowd of antiwar demonstra tors attempted today to dis rupt the annual meeting of the Boeing Company here.

title: Keating Named Director Of C.B.S. Radio Station
description: Michael Keating, WCBSTV's onair editorial spokesman, has been named director of news for the Columbia Broadcasting Systemowned station, it was announced yesterday by Alan P. Sloan, its vice president and general manager.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series).

title: Planners Discuss April in Paris Ball
description: Women on the committee for the 19th annual April in Paris Ball, which will be held at the WaldorfAstoria on Oct. 30, attended a lunch eon at the hotel yesterday. It was given by Mrs. John R. McLean, general chairman of the ball, and her cochair men, Mrs. Theodore Gary and Mrs. Henri Claudel, wife of the French Consul General here.

title: 6 KILLED IN CRASH OF U.S. PLANE IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (AP)  The United States command reported to day the loss of an AC130 gun ship over southern Laos. Six crewmen were killed, four are missing and one was rescued, spokesmen here said.

title: U.S. Concern's Method of Burning Oil Spills Praised
description: Favorable results have been reported from Stockholm for a method, developed by the Cabot Corporation of Boston, of burning oil spills at sea.

title: Sales and Marketing Director Appointed by New York Times
description: Paul D. Townsend, a well known marketing man, will be joining The New York Times as director of sales and mar keting. He will be in charge of the newspaper's advertising and circulatica sales, and its promotion.

title: Militia Backs Duvalier in Colorful Rally
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 27President Frangois Duvalier's armed militiamen staged a colorful demonstration of support for their chief to day, celebrating the end of a mutiny in this country's small coast guard.

title: Stonitsch's Penn Relays Feat Focuses Attention on C. W. Post
description: It began when a desk clerk handed Roy Chernock the keys to his hotel room, and the nurn hers read 711. Since Chernock spends most of his time dis secting statistics as a track coach, he knew it would not be any ordinary weekend in Philadelphia.

title: Cat on Utility Pole Rescued After Much BuckPassing
description: A neighborhood in Fresno, Calif., held its breath as a cat sat on the crossarm of a utility pole, The Fresno Bee reports.

title: Jersey Boy Named Winner Of Safety Poster Contest
description: Nineyearold Tito Ayala, of Nutley, N. J., has been named a grand award winner in the American Automobile Associa tion's 26th national school traf fic safety poster contest.

title: SENATE APPROVES HUDSON RIVER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill extending the Interior Depart ment's power to review fed erally licensed construction projects affecting the Hudson River.

title: S.E.C. to Review Rule by N.A.S.D. On Nonmembers
description: WASHINGTTON, April 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would hold public hear ings shortly to determine whether the National Associa tion of Securities Dealers is exceeding its authority in re fusing to let its members join with nonmembers in distribu tions of securities.

title: Coffeehouse Owners Guilty in Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 27 TThree operators of the U.F.O Coffee Housse, one of the firs antiwar coffee houses that ca tered to G.I.'s, were found guil ty here today of operating and maintaining a public nuisance.

title: WATERFRONT UNIT IS HELD NEGLIGENT
description: An executive of a company that supplies private port se curity guards charged yester day that the bistate Waterfront Commission and its investigator had systematically and rou tinely undermined the osition of the port guard in New York.

title: 3 Reporters Subpoenaed for Draft Trial in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 27Three reporters were subpoenaed here today to appear as wit nesses for the prosecution in the Federal trial of 15 persons charged with destroying Selec tive Service records in Chicago last May.

title: Kienast Quintuplets, Calm in Spite of Chaotic Atmosphere, Taken to Their Jersey Home
description: LIBERTY CORNER, N. J., April 27Five healthy and remarkably composed quin tuplets, wrapped in blankets and strapped into car seats, came home today by ambu lance under police escort with their parents, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kienast.

title: 8 Russian Satellites Reportedly Orbited With Single Rocket
description: MOSCOW, April 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union announced today that it sucessfully placed eight unmanned satellites into orbit around the earth with a single rocket booster on Satur day, and that all were re ported functioning normally.

title: TIMES OFFICER SEES SUBPOENAS THREAT
description: Harding F. Bancroft, execu tive vice president of The New York Times, said yesterday he believed that any incursion against freedom of the press would lead to ever larger in cursions until eventually the concept of freedom of the press is irrevocably damaged or lost.

title: John Bertles to Wed Miss Manger
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 27  Mr. and Mrs. Julius Manger Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Bell Manger, to John Harrison Bertles, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bertles of Green wich and Tuckerstown, Ber muda.

title: Patriots Get L.S.U.'s Ray
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP) Eddie Ray, a running back and punting specialist from Louisi ana State, was signed today by the Boston Patriots. He was the club's fourthround choice in the pro football draft.

title: News Summary and Index
description: According to Israeli diplomats in Wash ington, their Government is convinced So viet pilots are now participating in the defense of central Egypt against raids by the Israeli Air Force. Israel reported that two of her planes were pursued by eight MIG's on April 18, piloted by Russians. United States officials, it was reported yes terday, are studying their own intelligence reports on this possible development which they believe could have a serious effect on the balance of forces. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Dominican Group Urges Ouster of 15 for Violence
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, April 28The re moval of 15 military and police commanders accused of using violence in support of President Joaquin Balaguer's reelection campaign was recommended today by a nonpartisan electoral conrol commission.

title: Johnson TV Interview Abridged at His Request
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Columbia Broadcasting System said today that its forthcoming television inter view with former President Johnson had had material cut out, at Mr. Johnson's request, on the ground of national security.

title: Gulf Oil Corporation
description: PITTSBURGH, April 28 (UPI) Demonstrators staged a noisy protest at the Gulf Oil Corpora tion annual meeting today and then joined a march of 200 per sons on various downtown cor porate headquarters.

title: Reaume Sets Back Updegraff by 1 Up In Pinehurst Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 28 (AP)Frank Reaume, a 22 yearold substitute school teach er, from Ypsilanti, Mich., eased Dr. Ed Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., out of the North and South amateur golf tournament today, with a 1up secondround victory.

title: Ray Joins Patriots
description: BOSTON, April 28 (UPI) The Boston Patriots today signed Eddie Ray, their fourth round draft choice. Ray is a 230pound fullback from Louisi ana State.

title: CAPITAL PARLEY ON STOCKS IS SET
description: A group of top Wall Street officials will meet with several Cabinet members and leading economic officials of the Ad ministration in Washington this morning to discuss the current problems of Wall Street.

title: Saw Mill Parkway Area Shut
description: YONKERS, April 28 (AP) A portion of the Saw Mill River Parkway was shut down today after pavement sagged when a column supporting an under ground water chamber col lapsed. Traffic in both direc tions was detoured. The trouble developed in that area of the parkway that passes over the Saw Mill River on its way to the Yonkers filter plant.

title: GEN. ASENSIO, AIDE OF FRANCO IN WAR
description: MADRID, Spain, April 28 (Reuters)  Lieut. Gen. Carlos Asensio Cabanillas, one of the Spanish Army officers involved with Generalissimo Francisco Franco from the start of the Spanish Civil War, died here last night at the age of 73.

title: Jersey Court Voids State's Busing Aid To Private Pupils
description: TRENTON, April 28  A controversial New Jersey law authorizing the busing of parochial and private school students at public expense was declared unconstitutional today by State Superior Court Judge Joseph A. Stamler.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange took another beating yesterday in steppedup volume.

title: Hunter President Struggles to Maintain Humor
description: At 1:28 P.M. yesterday, all the telephones in the office of the president of Hunter College began to ring.

title: Leary Assails Articles in Times On Police Corruption as Unfair
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday character ized as unfair and McCar thyism all over a series of ar ticles printed in The New York Times dealing with police cor ruption in the city that report edly involves millions of dollars a year in graft.

title: ROCHE IS BEATEN AT BOURNEMOUTH
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UPI)Tony Roche, the world's secondrainking player, was knocked out of the men's singles in the British hard court (clay) championship to day. The Australian said that a persistent shoulder injury could sideline him for a year.
