title: Monserrat Hopeful on SchoolAide Negotiations
description: Joseph Monserrat, the presi dent of the Board of Educa tion, said last night that he was hopeful that a strike by paraprofessional school em ployes, threatened for next month, could be averted.

title: Dimon Gains Leadership Of G.O.P. in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 28 (AP) The Republican State Com mittee elected John E. Dimon, the Burlington County leader, as state party chairman to day to succeed Nelson G. Gross, who resigned to run for the United States Senate.

title: Frederick Bradlee, 77, Dies; Harvard AllAmerica Back
description: BEVERLY, Mass, April 28 Frederick J. Bradlee, former financial consultant to the Bos ton Museum of Fine Arts, died today of an aortal aneurism. He was 77 years old.

title: SIRHAN AWAITING APPEAL OUTCOME
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 One year after he was sentenced to die for the murder of Sena tor Robert F. Kennedy, Sirhan Bishara Sirhan sits on death row in San Quentin, waiting for the long legal maneuverings that will decide his fate.

title: Earl Weds Mrs. Enid Boulting
description: PARIS, April 28The ninth Earl of Hardwicke was mar ried quietly here yesterday to Mrs. Enid Boulting, the for mer wife of the British movie producer, Roy Boulting.

title: Quarterly Earnings Of Texaco Up 2.7%
description: Texaco, Inc., held an old fashioned annual meeting yes terday where the only people with long hairs were women and the protesters were stock holders who wanted to know why the dividend had not been raised.

title: M'CRACKEN SEES INFLATION EASING AS ECONOMY RISES
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The chairman of President Nix on's Council of Economic Ad visers disclosed today a new analysis indicating a modera tion of inflation this year even if, as he expects, the economy rises for the remainder of the year.

title: Beatle Thinks Group Will Regain Harmony
description: George Harrison of the Beatles said yesterday that as far as he is concerned there is every prospect that the singing group would get together again eventually.

title: GREEN REGISTERS KNOCKOUT IN FIRST
description: Charlie (Devil) Green, who serves as a bouncer in an East Village nightclub, is a quick man with his fistsin or out of the ring. Last night in the Felt Forum before 1,500 fans, Green fired two righthand punches at Ray Anderson and the 10round fight ended in the first round.

title: Wall Street Drop Is Chief Influence Abroad, but Depressants Vary
description: PARIS, April 28  Europe's stock markets tumbled today in response to the fall in Wall Street, higher shortterm inter est rates, rumors that mutual funds were dumping their as sets and general pessimism over immediate economic pros pects.

title: L. I. School Strike Voted
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I., April 28 Teachers here authorized a strike at a meeting today in Jonas Salk Junior High School. No date has been set for the strike, which was authorized after a breakdown in contract negotiations covering Nassau County's largest school dis trict.

title: Eskimos Sign 2 U.S. Stars
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, April 28 (AP)The Edmonton Es kimos of the Canadian Football League today signed Roger Larson, a split end, and Tom Elliott, a defense halfback. Lar son is a 22yearold University of South Dakota graduate. El liott, also 22, played four years at Iowa State University.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert I.. Kaufman has he?n appointed presi dent and general partner of the Mollie Parnis Bou tique division, a new branch or ParnisLivingston, Inc., of which Miss Parnis is president. ?e formerly was vice president of Jerry Silverman, Inc., a whole sale dress firm.

title: DOW FALLS AGAIN; CLOSES AT 72433
description: The stock market tried to get out of a hole yesterday but ended up in a deeper one.

title: Christian Churches Defying Rhodesia On Race Barriers
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 28Church leaders of most of Rhodesia's Christian denomina tions agreed today to defy new laws that would prevent people of one race from worshiping on land allocated to another race.

title: The Threat to LibertyIV
description: Civil liberties are held in contempt by extremists of right and left alike. Convinced of their own righteous ness, the dogmatists at both ends of the political spectrum characteristically believe in freedom for themselves but rarely for those who reject their ideo logical discipline. This narrowly restrictive view of freedom is normally accompanied by a selfindulgent approach to violence as an appropriate terror weapon against the ideological enemy.

title: RECORD EARNINGS LISTED BY ASARCO
description: E. McL. Tittmann, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company, told the (annual meeting here yesterday that increased production and prices for metals had pushed earnings in the first quarter to the highest level for any quar ter in Asarco's history.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice.

title: CARMAN J. CAGE
description: SHARON, Conn., April 28 Carman J. Cage, a retired operations supervisor for the Western Union Telegraph Com pany in New York, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: Tuesday's Baseball
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: National Guard Alerted for Panther Rally Duty
description: NEW HAVEN, April 28Na tional Guard units have been ordered to stand by here Fri day for deployment in the event of disorder at the mas sive rally being organized in support of eight Black Pan thers facing murder and kid napping trials.

title: Quarter Levels Ease
description: The three largest steel com panies in the nation reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter had dropped about 30 per cent, despite sales and other revenues that were higher in all cases than those of the 1969 period.

title: Robert L. Koerner
description: Robert L. Koerner, assistant professor of business law at Fordham University, was found dead in his home, 60 west 190th Street, the Bronx, Saturday. He had been on medical leave for the last year, and apparently died of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Mr. Hickel's Great Test
description: An Emergency Citizens' Task Force of Alaskans, headed by Governor Keith Miller, has been in Wash ington this week pressing for immediate permits to get on with the proposed oil pipeline from the North Slope. The eagerness of these citizens, especially contractors who have invested time, money and equipment, is understandable. But in no way does their plight release Secretary of the Interior Hickel from the obligation to act with extreme caution.

title: Market Summary
description: Wednesday Tuesday Tuesday, April 28, 1970 (Volume 4,627,165 shares)

title: COPTS DEMAND KEYS IN JERUSALEM RIFT
description: JERUSALEM, April 28The Coptic patriarchate lodged a complaint in the Israeli Suprem High Court today demanding that the Ethiopian Orthodox patriarchate return the keys to a passage in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

title: With Minimum of Fanfare, Frick Collection Turns
description: The Frick Collection, that sumptuous mansion of mas terpieces on Fifth Avenue, quietly turned 50 this week. And in the Frick tradition, it is modest about the occasion.

title: NASSAU IS VICTOR IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its sea son yesterday with interclub team matches over 50 courses in the district.

title: Negro Fund Aide Named
description: Ely R. Callaway Jr., president of Burlington Industries, has been named national corporate chairman of the 1970 drive of the United Negro College Fund. He will direct the fund's appeal for $4.5 million from the na tion's leading corporations.

title: Market Place:
description: TALK TO the average in vestor and he'll tell you that his broker is lousy; that the broker steers him into situations fraught with risk and then forgets to tell the customer when the situations go sour.

title: Ousted Woman Says Allstate Discriminates
description: Her hands quivering and her voice shaking, a tall, blond woman charged yesterday that she had been dismissed last November by the Allstate In surance Company because it discriminated against women employes.

title: A HEART IS GIVEN ATOM PACEMAKER
description: PARIS, April 28French sci entists announced a world pre miere today in the implanta tion in a human patient of a heart pacemaker powered by nuclear energy.

title: ELDERLY ARE TOLD WAR CUTS THEIR AID
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell told a group of older persons yesterday at a tea opening Sen ior Citizens Month that all the expenditures authorized by Congress under the Older Americans Act from its incep tion in 1965 would finance the war in Vietnam for less than two days.

title: Rationality in Labor Relations
description: In this period of labormanagement turbulence, any note of rationality on the collective bargaining front is cheering. That is especially true when it takes the form of longterm agreements reached five months before the deadline in an industry whose labor rela tions were once notorious for violence and discord.

title: Transit Authority Faces Job Action By Black Policemen
description: Charging the Transit Author ity and its police department with racial discrimination, an organization representing 900 black transit policemen yester day threatened mass sick calls by its members if the authority failed to negotiate the issue.

title: Scientist's Prize Going to Panthers
description: BOSTON, April 28 (UPI) A Harvard microbiologist who won the 1970 Eli Lilly award for being the first to isolate a pure gene said tonight that he was turning the $1,000 honorarium over to the Black Panther party.

title: Eastman Kodak, Co.
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 28  The Eastman Kodak Com pany, which has a licensing agreement with the Polaroid Corporation to make and sell color film for Polaroid cameras in five or six years, told about 700 shareholders at its annual meeting here today that Kodak was also working on a Polar oidtype film of its own inven tion.

title: Jersey Officials Accept Resignation of DeVita
description: TRENTON, April 28 (UPI) The resignation of Judge Ralph DeVita of Union County Dis trict Court, who was found guilty April 15 of obstructing justice, was accepted today by Gov. William T. Cahill and Chief Justice Joseph Wein traub.

title: Antipoverty Group In Bronx Settles 11Month Dispute
description: An 11month controversy over the management of a South Bronx antipoverty pro gram that led to a virtual halt in its activities and created racial friction throughout the area, has been settled, commu nity leaders said yesterday.

title: Bulls Stick to Home Court
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) The Chicago Bulls announced today they would play their entire 41game home schedule in the 197071 National Basket ball Association season in Chicago.

title: Pfizer Company Renamed
description: Pfizer, Inc., is the new cor porate name for Chas. Pfizer & Co., Inc., manufacturer of ethical pharmaceuticals, chem icals and numerous other prod ucts. The original name dates hack to the founding of the organization in 1849.

title: Theater: Mahagonny, BrechtWeill Lyric Opera, Here at Last
DELURY SAYS TIMES LIES IN EDITORIAL
description: John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that a New York Times editorial suggesting that the sanitation men were engaging in a work slowdown was a filthy lie filthier than the streets of New York,.

title: High Bail Is Set for Two In Attempt on Chiang's Son
description: The two Taiwanese suspects in the attempted slaying of Chiang Kaishek's son last Fri day were ordered held in high bail yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Dennis Edwards Jr.

title: POLICEMEN DELAY A WORK STOPPAGE UNTIL SATURDAY
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday post poned for 72 hours until 12:01 A.M. Saturday a threatened work stoppage by 20,000 of the city's 25,000 patrolmen.

title: Rights Panel Urges Laws to Protect MexicanAmerican
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (AP)  The United States Civil Rights Commission urged Congress yesterday to pass laws aimed at halting what it called widespread patterns of police misconduct against Mexican Americans in the Southwest.

title: BAR'S TOP RATING GIVEN BLACKMUN
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Judge Harry A. Blackmun re ceived a strong endorsement to day from the American Bar As sociation's Committee on the Federal Judiciary, on the eve of the Senate Judiciary Com mittee's hearings on his Su preme Court nomination.

title: PACER QUALIFIES WITH 2:01 45 MILE
description: NEW EGYPT, N.J., April 28  Looking overweight, Lucky Creed, a 6yearold Australian stallion, nevertheless proved he was in top shape by pacing a mile here today in 2 minutes 1 45 seconds, an incredible time for a workout.

title: Rookie Haywood Voted Most Valuable Player
description: Spencer Haywood, the Den ver rookie who led the Ameri can Basketball Association in scoring and rebounding this season, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday.

title: Roundup: Perez Hits 10th For April Homer Record
description: Although Tony Perez would have to get 15 hits in his next 15 times at bat to catch Fritz Peterson in batting, the Cincinnati third baseman holds a comfortable lead over the Yankee slugger in home runs.

title: BunkerRamo Elects New Chief Executive
description: The election of George S. Trimble Jr. as president, chief executive officer and a direc tor of the BunkerRamo Corporation, succeeding Mil ton E. Mohr, was announced MacIntyre, chairman. All other officers were re elected.

title: Mailmen in Britain Bar Stop for Chat and Tea
description: LONDON (UPI)The Post Office Corporation's new campaign to he kind in your mailman has run into a hit of troublefrom the mail men.

title: 5 U. S. Aircraft Lost in War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 (AP)  The United States command announced to day the loss of five aircraft in which 15 Americans died and six were injured, and an acidental bombing by Ameri can planes that killed 10 South Vietnamese militiamen and wounded 20 others.

title: 17th Feather Ball on Tuesday To Help Just One Break, Inc.
description: Dozens of palm trees will help transform the Pierre ballroom into a South Seas Island paradise Tuesday when about 600 persons gather for the 17th annual Feather Ball.

title: SixYear Sentences Given to 3 Owners Of G.I.Coffeehouse
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 28 Three operators of an antiwar coffeehouse that catered to sol diers were each sentenced to six years in prison today after their conviction yesterday on charges of operating a public nuisance.

title: State Bank Head Sworn In
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., for mer executive director of the New York State Council of Economic Advisers, was sworn in yesterday as Superintendent of Banks in Governor Rocke feller's Manhattan offices. Mr. Dentzer, who is 40 years old, succeeds Frank Wille, who gave up the office to become chair man of the Federal Deposit In surance Corporation.

title: Admiral's Shield, 201, Captures $16,500 Derby Trial by Length
description: LOUISVILLE, April 28Ad miral's Shield added confusion to the 3yearold picture today by winning the $16,500 Derby Trial. The onemile event, de signed as a proving ground for the Kentucky Derby, had some important entrants for that fa mous 1mile event in its lineup of 10 starters, but Ad miral's Shield was not one of them.

title: Guns Bought in Boston By Panther Supporters
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 Members of at least one of the groups planning to join the May 1 Black Panther demonstration in New Haven have been purchasing guns in Bostonarea stores in recent weeks, despite their public dis avowals of any violent intention.

title: Paris Assailed on Intervention in Chad, Sometimes Called France's Vietnam
description: PARIS, April 27Opponents of the French Government have been criticizing France's con tinuing military intervention in Chad, the central African state that they sometimes call France's Vietnam.ter of protecting the existence of Chad? And if so, who would threaten it? He went on: Is it a matter of protecting strategic interests and the uranium of Niger and of the Central Afri can Republic?

title: Financier's Mexican Divorce Obtained in '69 Set Aside
description: A Mexican divorce obtained in March, 1969, by Gerald Tsai Jr., a mutual fund financier, was set aside yesterday by Su preme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold.

title: RUSSIAN AIRMEN BELIEVED FLYING MISSIONS IN U.A.R.
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 There is growing evidence that Soviet pilots are now partici pating in the defense of central Egypt against penetration raids by the Israeli Air Force. But no direct clashes have been report ed so far.

title: Peterson Hits Homer, 2Run Single and Pitches Yanks to 75 Victory Here
description: Ron Woods is one game ahead of Roger Maris, but Fritz Peterson is still far behind Babe Ruth.

title: LIBERALS BLOCKED ON ARMS DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 House liberals who oppose various portions of the military budget suffered a setback to day when the Rules Committee turned down their request for increased time to debate the defense authorization bill.

title: Foreign Affairs: Danger of the Private Eye
description: PARISDoes television by its very presence at an event help to create an explosive at mosphere of excitement and disorder? This question, posed in the current London Encoun ter by the highly regarded Brit ish television commentator, Robin Day, undoubtedly lies at the source of many contempo rary political headaches.

title: Intrigue Over Racing Sanctions Takes a Machiavellian Turn
description: IF Machiavelli were alive today and engaged in auto racing politics, he would have to paint a rookie stripe on his bumper. He'd be dazzled by the BorgiaMedici machin ations in the routine councils of the Autmomobile competi tion Committee for the United states_ let alone something special like the present imbroglio over who will sanction the extra Grand Prix the United States will evidently get next spring. The second race will supplement the regular Grand Prix at Watkins Glen.

title: Cavaliers Enroll Johnson
description: CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) The new Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association signed John John son, their No. 1 draft choice, today. The 6foot7inch Uni versity of Iowa star posted a 31.8pointagame average in Big Ten competition during the last season.

title: METS TOP GIANTS ON A GRAND SLAM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Time has not treated the San Francisco Giants kindly. They toured Japan this spring and lost six of nine games. They paid $750,000 for synthetic grass in their park and base balls began bouncing over the fences. And Willie Mays will be 39 next week.

title: Ann P. Buck Is Engaged To James Harry Beggs
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 28 Charles Welles Buek, presi dent of the United States Trust Company of New York, and Mrs. Buek have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Pinckney Buek, to James Harry Beggs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry George Beggs. Both families are of Darien.

title: Horse Show Rider Injured
description: ROME, April 28 (AP)Capt. Raimondo D'Inzeo, a twotime world jumping champion from Italy and an Olympic gold med alist, fractured his left hand today when he fell from his horse during the International Horse dhow in the Villa Bor ghese Gardens.

title: Children's Crusade
description: While a rock concert on the Mall attracted all the attention and the publicity, something considerably more significant was taking place in jampacked Cen tral Park Sunday under the warm and brilliant sunshine of a lovely spring afternoon.

title: U.S. Rail Aid Is Set For Intercity Lines
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Nixon Aministration and key Senate Democrats have agreed on compromise legisla tion that would aid rail pas senger service in heavily trav eled intercity corridors, James A. Beggs, the Under Secretary of Transportation, disclosed to night.

title: Salazar Turns 81
description: LISBON, April 28 (UPI)Dr. Antonio Oliveira de Salazar, who was Premier of Portugal for almost 40 years before he was felled by a stroke in Sep tember, 1968, celebrated his Rlst birthday today. He is part ly paralyzed, but is able to walk and talk.

title: Trotsky Not All Evil, in Mikoyan View
description: MOSCOW, April 28  Ana stas I. Mikoyan, a leading offi cial for more than 40 years, has published some details concern ing the power struggle between Stalin and Trotsky in the first years of Soviet rule.

title: ED BEGLEY, WINNER OF AN OSCAR IN '63
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 28 (AP) Ed Begley, the character actor who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of Southern political boss in Sweet Bird of Youth, died tonight. He was 69 years old.

title: Football Giants Retire Dess, Drop Plum and Two Others
description: Darrell Dess, a guard, was retired by the New York Giants yesterday. The club said it was making room for some promis ing youngsters for next year.

title: Saigon Aide Tours Village Of the Missing in Cambodia
description: CHRUI CHANGWAR, Cam bodia, April 28The mayor of Pnompenh crossed the Tonle Sap River today to this village to show an official of the South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry how Cambodia treats members of her Vietnamese minority.

title: Nijinsky, Engelhard's Colt, Choice at Newmarket Today
description: LONDON, April 28 (Reuters)  Nijinsky, rated one of the best colts to race in Europe in the last decade, is heavily fa vored to win the onemile 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket tomor row in the first classic of the British racing season. The race has a value of $100,152, with the winner getting $67,910.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR ASKS ROAD FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Keith Miller, the Republican Governor of Alaska, announced here today that he had decided to ask the Alaskan Legislature to appropriate the money to build a 390mile gravel road from the Yukon River to Prud hoe Bay on the Arctic North Slope.

title: Transport News: General Motors Names Subcompact Vega 2300
description: DETROIT, April 28General Motors said today that its new entry into the subcompact car field would be named the Vega 2300.

title: Yasuda Posts 62 for 195 For 8Shot Lead in Japar
description: NAGOYA, April 28 (AP) Haruo Yasuda of Japan, play ing in a drizzle, shattered the course record with an eight underpar 62 today to extend his lead to eight strokes after three days of play in the $52, 777 Chunichi Crowns golf tournament.

title: TULLY HALL ADDING 2 CHAMBER SERIES
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will add two new series of concerts to its schedule in its 197071 season at Alice Tully Hall. One will be presented Sundays at 5 P.M., and the other Tuesdays at 7 P.M. Each series will comprise six concerts, as will the. Friday series at 8:30 P.M. and the Sat urday series at 9 P.M.

title: Stonitsch Helps Post Win
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 28 Ron Stonitsch, voted the out standing athlete in the Penn Relays this past weekend, won the mile and twomile runs to day to lead the C. W. Post Col lege track team to a 10648 victory over Central Connecti cut State Stonitsch ran the mile in 4 minutes 11.6 seconds and the two miles in 8:56.6.

title: Open Interest
Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all baseball games except those involving the Yankees and the Mets are omitted from this issue because of com posingroom delays caused by union meetings.

title: THEODORE K. HESS
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., April 28Theodore K. Hess, super vising accountant for the American Telephone and Tele graph Company in New York, died Sunday at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield. He was 61 years old and lived at Indian Run.

title: Article 2  No Title
Hope G. Harron To Be the Bride Of D. K. Glidden
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., April 28Miss Hope Glendon Har ron, a magna cum laude grad uate of Lawrence University, and David K. Glidden, who was graduated summa cum laude from Lawrence plan to be married this November.

title: Brazil: Terror and Torture
description: When Gen. Emilio Gerrastaz Mdici was named President of Brazil last October he said he hoped by the end of his term to leave democracy definitely in stalled in our country, along with the bases for eco nomic and social development.

title: Bridge:
description: PETER LEVENTRI'S team, including Sam Stayman, Stan Turecki, Sol Rubinow, Jacqui Mitchell and Dorothy Hayden, won its semifinal match Monday night in the New York Double Knockout Championship. They will op pose Jeff Ruben's unbeaten squad in the final and if Lev entritt wins this, a playoff will be required to decide the title.

title: NIXON ASKS MORE FOR COLLEGE FUND
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 President Nixon, responding to pressure from the academic community, has increased his request for funds for univer sity study programs in the lar guage, history and culture of countries that are outside Western Europe but neverthe less crucial to modern Ameri can diplomacy.

title: MUGGED POLICEMAN LISTED AS CRITICAL
description: A 33yearold policeman mugged early Monday morning while checking a tire on his auto in a Brooklyn service station was reported in critical condi tion yesterday in Kings County Hospital.

title: Mrs. Albert Lasker Named Head of Palsy Foundation
description: Mrs. Albert D. Lasker has been elected president of the United Cerebral Palsy Research and Education Foundation, the organization's executive com mittee announced yesterday.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Pittsburgh vs. St. Louis

title: 3 Are Arrested in the College for Trespass
description: Three persons, only one of them a student at the school, were arrested at Hunter Col lege yesterday as school ad ministrators continued a hard line taken on Monday by Hunter's president, Mrs. Jac queline G. Wexler.

title: A Racial Outbreak In Detroit Suburbs Results in Curfews
description: DETROIT, April 28  Cur fews were ordered in two De troit suburbs after racial vio lence erupted last night and edged into Detroit today.

title: Appeal on School Prayers
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)The state Board of Education voted unanimously today to appeal a recent Superior Court decision that allows pupils in Leyden public schools to pray before classes, providing teachers do not participate.

title: Study Finds Auto Victims Regain Only Half of Loss
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Department of Transporta tion said today that a survey showed that victims of serious traffic crashes and their de pendents recovered in 1967 only an average or one fifth of their losses from automobile insurance companies.

title: Bethlehem Also Off
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 28 (AP)The Bethlehem Steel Cor poration reported today that firstquarter earnings fell to $21.8million from $33million in the first quater of 1969.

title: Associated Press
TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: California at New York 3 (P.M.) Messersmith (2.2) vs. Cumber land (10).

title: 2 Experts Hold New Missile Systems Would Hinder Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Two specialists In missile strategy argued today that the projected deployment of new missile systems would seriously reduce changes of an agree ment with the Soviet Union to curb the arms race.

title: European Football
description: EUROPEAN FAIRS CUP FINAL

title: Republican Gambian Cabinet
description: BATHURST, Gambia, April 28 (Agence FrancePresse)Sir Daudl Kalraha Jawara, Gam bia's first President, announced a new Republican governrnent today but there were few changers from the outgoing ??.

title: SPECIAL WIRE RATE FOR PRESS ENDED
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)The Federal Communi cations Commission today terminated special rates on telegraph and telephotograph lines leased by news organiza tions. The order ending seven years of proceedings, is ef fective in 50 days.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series).

title: Italians, Austrians and Yugoslays in the Trieste Area Are Some of the Friendliest Neighbors in Europe
description: TRIESTE, Italy, April 27 The Italians. Austrians and Yugoslays who live within a 250mile arc west, north and east of this Adriatic seaport are among the friendliest neighbors in Europe.

title: TESTS FOR APOLLO 14 POSTPONED A MONTH
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. Apr. 28 (AP)  Altitude chamber tests of the two spacecrafts for the Apollo 14 moon mission have been delayed about a month pending an investigation of the flight of Apollo 13.

title: China Trains Rural Medics
description: HONG KONG (UPI)  The medical corps of the Chinese Communist Army has trained 274,000 peasantmedical work ers in China's rural areas during the last two years, ac cording to the Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, April 28. 1970

title: South Africa Seeks Leaders
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia (AP) Quality leadership is in short supply in southern Africa, says Dr. Mario Milani, president of the South African Jaycees. There is a critical need for levelheaded mature and toler ant leaders, Dr. Milani said during a visiting here.

title: Goodell, at Tombs, Asks U.S. Aid
description: United States Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republi can of Jamestown who is seeking reelection, called for doubling the $61million budg et of the city's Department of Corrections yesterday aft er witnessing overcrowding at the Tombs prison.

title: BOND RATES RISE FOR NEW ISSUES
description: Interest rates on several types of fixedincome securi ties  Federal agency notes, taxexempt notes and bonds and corporate bonds  moved upward yesterday as the credit markets sought to get their bearings.

title: 2 Alleged Leaders In Mafia Indicted
description: Two men described as among the highestranking Mafia lead ers on the East Coast were in dicted by a grand jury here yesterday.

title: Individuals Seem Hopeful Despite the Beating Taken by Stocks
description: At 3 P.M. yesterday, as the stock market plunged to its lowest level in nearly six and a half years, a retired Bronx plumber named Silvio Volpe sat in a brokerage board room and gave his assesment:

title: SALZBURG QUARTET ESSAYS BEETHOVEN
description: The Salzburg String Quartet, which performed a Beethoven Bicentennial Program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a group of four conscientious musicians whose ideas dove tail and whose talents are rather closely matched. The program ranged over the full spectrum, from Op. 18, No. 4, through Op. 59, No. 1, and clos ing with Op. 130, which is enough of a proving ground for any quartet. None of the works could he said to have received firstclass treatment, however.

title: 2 Presidential Yachts Taken Out of Service
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)The Patricia and the Julie, Presidential yachts named after President Nix on's two daughters, were de commissioned today while Tricia, Mr. Nixon's elder daughter, watched.

title: You Don't Like Midiskirts? There Are Always Gaucho Pants
description: WOMEN who want to buy just plain clothes next fall will probably be able to find some, but that's not what designers are counting on. The forwardthinkers want to sell a fashion ex periencea life style, not just the cut of a sleeve or a longer skirt.

title: WILLIAM L. FREEBORN
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., April 28 William Livingston Freeborn, former president of Freeborn & Co., insurance brokers in New York City, died yesterday at Northern Dutchess Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Tivoli, N. Y.

title: Food Products Recalled Twice a Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 About twice each week, food manufacturers in the United States order products off the market for safety reasons, sometimes because of deadly contamination, Government re ports indicate.

title: RICHARD REMSEN, 80, LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 28Richard Remsen, a retired partner in the New York City law firm of Remsen Millham Bowdish & Spellman, died today at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 80 years old and lived at 64 Second Street.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: In line with prices received at the Government's auction in Washington, silver futures prices on the Commodity Ex change here, dropped yester day.

title: Vatican Eases Rule In Mixed Marriage; Stand Lauded Here
description: Revised norms for mixed marriages issued by the Roman Catholic Church yesterday elim inate the requirement that the nonCatholic partner promise orally to raise offspring in the Catholic faith.

title: Soviet Physicist Favors Talks on Space Cooperation
description: A leading Soviet scientist said here yesterday that the time was fovorable for the Soviet Union and the United States to negotiate an agreement for cooperation in space explora tion.

title: Peking Hails Conference of Indochinese Leftists
description: HONG KONG, April 28 Communist China today hailed the weekend meeting between Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Head of State, and top Communist of ficials from North and South Vietnam and Laos, and express ed support for a joint declara tion adopted by the delegates.

title: Schary Assumes City Post
description: Dore Schary, the playwright and honorary chairman of the Anti Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, was sworn in yes terday as, the city's new Com missioner of Cultural Affairs. The post pays $35,000 a year. The swearingin ceremony, with Mayor Lindsay officiating, took place at the museum of the city of New York 104th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Books of The Times
description: WELL, this lost weekend in Los An geles the Dodgers scored three runs in three games and still took two from the Mets. Cleon Jones, Tommie Agee and Joe Foy were benched. Nolan Ryan has given up three hits in 18 in nings, and his record is 11. Jerry Koos man has yet to win. Only Prince Valiant, the rightarmed Eagle Scout, looks like last year: the Torn Seaver Dollwind it up and it strikes you out; available from most dream factories with the Nancy Sea ver Doll, by California out of Kansas, or ange juice and wheat germ, selfwinding tamo'shanter.

title: Article 3  No Title
Five Charged in Slaying
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (UPI)  Five Negro youths were charged with murder to day in the shooting of a white Temple University graduate student, David Fineman.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: N.&W. INCOME DROPS AS REVENUES GO UP
description: The Norfolk & Western Rail way reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in the first quarter had dropped sharp ly to $9.5million, or 88 cents a share, from $22million, or $2.03 a share, in the similar period last year.

title: MUTUAL FUND BILL LOSES FEE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  The House Commerce subcom mittee gave final approval to day to the mutual fund bill and, in the process, took out virtually every provision it had inserted earlier that would have given the Government any au thority to restrict the charges that fund managers impose on investors.

title: Jockeys' Chatter at Big A Is Watch My Dad George
description: My horse is supposed to be able to run all day, said Mike Venezia, flipping a card onto the table during a betweenrace interlude yes terday in the jockey room at Aqueduct.

title: Washington: And Now the Middle East Again
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 When President Nixon refused Israel's request for more Phan tom fighter bombers recently, he did so in the hope that the Soviet Union would also limit its military aid to the Arab states and thus help bring sta bility to the Middle East. That, however, is not the way things are going.

title: Leader of Quebec Separatists
description: MONTREAL, April 28In January, 1968, three months after he had quit the Liberal party and before he had founded the separatist Quebec party, Rene Levesque contemplated a modest time table for political success.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT DOWNING 2 JETS
description: TEL AVIV, April 28Two Sukhoi7 fighterbombers were reported shot down today by Israeli interceptors when the Egyptian Air Force launched synchronized low  flying at tacks on Israeli forces in the occupied Sinai Peninsula.

title: Sports of The Times
description: TAKE your pick, said Red Holzman, his voice flat and his face an unemo tional mask. It could have been good defense by them or bad shooting by us.

title: Leftists Parade in Tokyo In Protest on Ties with U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 28 Radical students with helmets and bamboo poles took to the streets here tonight in an annual rite known as Okinawa Day. But the level of violence was much lower than last year, when the students briefly oc cupied a major railroad station as well as an important down town intersection.

title: U.S. Building in Turkey Hit
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 28 (UPI)A gang of leftist youths partially destroyed a United States aid mission warehouse with gasoline bombs and ex plosives today after driving off the watchman with gunfire. The police said the attackers were extreme leftist students at the Americanfounded Mid dle East Technical University. Damage was estinmted at $20,000.

title: EXECUTIVE IS GUILTY IN SECURITIES CASE
description: Jerome Deutsch, executive vice president of the Realty Equities Corporation, has been convicted of a violation of the kickback provision of the In vestment Company Act of 1940.

title: ILMARI KIANTO DIES; FINNISH WRITER, 96
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 28 (UPI)  Ilmari Kianto, writer, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 96 years old, and lived in Suomussalmi, in northeastern Finland.

title: Pollution Research at G.M.
description: DETROIT, April 28  The General Motors Corporation said today that it would spend $112.8million this year on con trolling automotive emissions. Last year General Motors said it had spent $651million. This is the first time General Motors has specified its out lays to combat auto pollution.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS 18YEAROLD VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Democratic leaders in Congress continued to press today for lowering the voting age to 18 as part of a broad voting rights bill, despite opposition from President Nixon.

title: Banker's Widow Dies at 100
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 28Mrs. Augusta Koos, who celebrated her 100th birthday last October, died at her home in nearby Loch Arbour Sunday. She was the widow of Charles Koos Sr., former president of the Clinton Trust Company, Newark, and former head of the Koos Furniture Company, Rahway.

title: Slain G.I. Insurance Claim
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP)The mother of a soldier killed in Vietnam filed suit today in Federal Court against the United States Government for $10,000. The suit, filed for Mrs. Mary C. Dagget of New Bedford, alleges that the Gov ernment failed to pay the premiums on a policy taken out by Pfc. Joseph R. Paulette, 22 years old, who was killed in action April 9, 1968.

title: Colonels Defeat Nets, 116113, and Send Semifinal Series Into Seventh Game
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 28The 3point basket, at which the Kentucky Colo nels excel, sent the American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal series into a seventh game tonight.

title: Federal Injunction Is Denied On Kopechne Data Release
description: BOSTON, April 28 (AP) Judge Bailey Aldrich refused today to issue a Federal injunc tion to prevent the Massachu setts Superior Court from mak ing public the transcript of the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.

title: Avco Giving TV Time To People With Views
description: A big (and therefore, one would think, impersonal, con glomerate is going to offer its TV commercial time to people who want to get something off their chests.

title: Lawyer Is Retained by Douglas To Help in Impeachment Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas notified a House investigation panel today that he had retained Simon H. Rif kind, a New York lawyer and former Federal judge, to repre sent him on possible impeach ment charges.

title: Gradually, They Learn Poise
description: SOME lived in hospitals where, even if anyone cared, no one had the time to help them with their ap pearance. Others simply felt they weren't worth bother ing about. One was so sure she was ugly that, when asked to look in a mirror, she burst into tears.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Daylight Saving Time

title: RAP BROWN TRIAL RESET FOR MONDAY
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., April 28Judge James Macgill today ordered the trial of H. Rap Brown resumed here at 10 A.M. next Monday, and aides in the Howard County Circuit Court said the black militant leader must be present then or forfeit $10,000 bail bond.

title: Con Edison Profits Fell in First Quarter
Artists in South Vietnam Are Still Able to Wield a Critical Brush
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28In South Vietnam, where the Government for bids antiwar demonstrations, limits freedom of speech and censors books before publi cation, artists have unusual freedom in protesting against the war and the influence of foreigners in their country.

title: N.C.A.A. Penalties Given to Villanova And Massachusetts
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 28 (AP)Villanova and the University of Massachu setts were penalized today by the National Collegiate Athle tic Association for rules infrac tions.

title: AMERICAN DANCE OPENS 3WEEK RUN
description: The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, usually found in Tulsa, Okla., Baalbek, Lebanon or Paris, is now on 55th Street, where it opened the City Cen ter's American Dance Season last night.

title: Advertising: Magazine Men Hear Favorites
description: For its Magazine Advertis ing Workshop yesterday, the Magazine Publishers Associa tion quite naturally invited representatives of some of their favorite companies.

title: FOREIGN MARKETS DECLINE SHARPLY
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: John E. Donnelly Jr. Is Dead; Designed Facades of Buildings
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 28 John Emmet Donnelly Jr., an architectural sculptor, died yes terday at Princeton Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at Fair Acres in Freehold.

title: Book Left by Hemingway Will Be Published in Fall
description: A 200,000word novel by Ernest Hemingway, consid ered by scholars to be the most significant of his un published manuscripts, will be issued this fall by Charles Scribner's Sans.

title: U.S. CHARGES INSULT TO ENVOY BY SWEDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The State Department said today that antiAmerican dem onstrations in Stockholm yes terday were insulting and uncalled for and a spokesman indicated that some diplomatic action might be taken.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Blues Turn Back Penguin Sextet, 50, To Lead Series, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, April 28 (UPI) Frank St. Marseille scored three goals and Jacques Plante shut out the Pittsburgh Penguins to night as the St. Louis Blues scored a 50 victory in the Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Laird Says '70 Draft Calls May Be 100,000 Under Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that draft calls this year may be reduced to as low as 150,000 men about 100,000 under original plansbecause of troop with drawals from Vietnam. This is the lowest estimate yet made.

title: Rise in U.S. Stake In I.M.F. Is Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)The House Banking Com mittee approved today legisla tion for an increase of almost $2billion in contributions by the United States to the capital of international financial insti tutions.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS FOR PARTY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  A Democratic party reform commission warned today in its final report that the only alternative to broader citizen participation in politics was the antipolitics of the street.

title: Rod McKuen Offers Poetry and Songs To Soldout House
description: Rod McKuen was ata Philhar monic Hall last nighthis long, Taney frame slumped over a high stool, singing in a hoarse, worn voice, croaking out his poems.

title: Egyptians Describe Raids
description: CAIRO, April 28  Egyptian fighterbombers, continuing a wave of offensive actions, struck Israeli targets today along the Suez Canal and south ward along the Gulf of Suez, Cairo's military spokesman re ported. All the planes returned safely from the raids, he said.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1970

title: REVOLVER SEIZED IN PANTHER HOME
description: A detective testified yester day that a fully loaded 38 caliber r??volver, several kinds of ammunition, two books about explosives and homemade bombs, and five bottles of liq uid, three with names of chem icals on them and two un labeled, were seized at the apartment of one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places.

title: HOMECOURT EDGE TO LAKERS TONIGHT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 Wilt Chamberlain is alive, and standing under the basket, just as he always has been. That's what the New York Knicker bockers discovered in New York last night before they and the Los Angeles Lakers flew here today, in separate char ter planes, with the National Basketball Association's final playoff series tied at 11.

title: Honeywell Meeting Adjourns After Protest
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 28 Young militants turned the an nual meeting of Honeywell, Inc., today into an unruly shout ing match that lasted only 14 minutes. At that point, James H. Binger, chairman, who had been frustrated in his attempt to conduct the meeting, de clared it adjourned.

title: Sports Fans Need a Scorecard To Keep Up With Books on Mets
description: There are so many books coming out on the New York Mets' rise to baseball's world championship in 1969 that not even the Mets have any idea of how many there are.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, April 28, 1970

title: In Memoriam
description: BIRTHLols. We miss you very much. LOIS, MILTON and the Children.

title: Chairman and Chief Officer Of Comsat Retiring May 12
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  James McCormack, chairman and chief executive of the Communications Satellite Corporation, announced today he is retiring from those offices at the annual shareholders' meeting on May 12.

title: A Correction
description: CHICAGO, April 28A story from Chicago in today's New York Times reported that even with rate increases, Common wealth Edison's dividends in 1970 would probably be 15 cents a share because of ex penditures for pollution control measures. The sentence should have said that even with rate increases, the company's earn ings would probably drop 15 cents a share because of the pollutioncontrol measures.

title: Maryland Eases Drug Law
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28 (AP)  A new drug law that sharply reduces harsh penalties for users of narcotics and dan gerous drugs, especially mari juana, was signed today by Gov. Marvin Mandel of Mary land. The new statute provides a maximum sentence of one year in jail and a $1,000 fine for use or possession of mari juana, changing it from a felony classification to a mis demeanor. It contains no mini mum sentences.

title: London Stocks Plunge
description: LONDON, April 28Prices on the London Stock Exchange dropped sharply today in gloomy reaction to the Wall Street decline. About the only bright spot was gold shares, the traditional refuge for invest ment money in times of uncer tainty.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP Knicks vs. Los Angeles

title: Writer on Alioto Is Silent on Sources
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Lance Brisson, one of the authors of the Look magazine article that linked Mayor Joseph L. Alioto with Mafia hoodlums, refused today to identify sources of information.

title: Keith Conrey to Wed Miss Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Brig. Gen. George Arthur Lincoln, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lincoln of Washington and Evergreen, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce LeFevre Lincoln, to Keith Ar thur Conrey. He is the son of Prof, and Mrs. Lawrence A. Conrey of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Printers at The Times Increase Pressure With Longer Meetings
description: The typographical union in creased its economic pressure on The New York Times yes terday by lengthening its work stopping meetings to 15 hours a day.

title: Trial Starts in the 1967 Slaying Of Policeman in Plainfield Riot
description: ELIABETH, N. J., April 28  The selection of a jury began today for the trial of Bobby Lee Williams a key figure in the Plainfield riots of July, 1967, that resulted in the mur der of a policeman.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, April 29, 1970

title: Confusionin Wall Street
description: It was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us... Charles Dickens, A Tale of Two Cities.

title: U.S. SECURITY ISSUE IN GREEN BERET CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  An Army lawyer warned today that public disclosure of evi dence in a twoyearold murder case connecting the United States Special Forces, the Green Berets, to a Cambodian sect once dedicated to the overthrow of Prince Norodom Sihanouk would threaten American security.

title: Protest Wins Striptease
description: CORNWALL, England (UPI) Dave Hawkes, owner of a local nightclub, decided to re instate striptease artists at his club because of a threatened boycott by women. He said no complaints were received from men.

title: Eastern Air Lines Gets Astronaut as Executive
description: Frank Borman, the astronaut, will leave the space program on July 1 to become a vice presi dent of Eastern Air Lines, the carrier's management announced yesterday before the annual meeting in Houston.

title: Americans Back From Cuba
description: ST. JOHN, New Brunswick, April 28 (UPI)The Luis Arcos Bergnes, a converted cattleship, docked in St. John today, carry ing 687 Americans returning after eight weeks of cutting sugar cane in Cuba. A fleet of 12 chartered buses will take the Americans to United States cities. The buses are to travel to New York, Los Angeles, Bos ton, Philadelphia and San Fran cisco.

title: PANEL WOULD PUNISH UNREST AT COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)The House Armed Serv ices Committee says it does not want any more Pentagon re search funds going to colleges and universities where lecturers are heckled and other forms of disruption take place.

title: Big Perfecta Pays $44,108
description: HAZEL PARK, Mich., April 28 (AP)A record Big Perfecta payoff of $44,108.20 for $2 was posted last night at Hazel Park Harness Raceway. Track offi cials said the previous record at their raceway was $21,050.20, paid on April 6.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 28, 1970

title: Stocks Tumble Again
description: Stock prices took another sharp drop yesterday after an early attempt at a rally from Monday's setback failed to make headway. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.82 points, to 724.33, an other new low since the mar ket collapse that followed the assassination of President Kennedy in November, 1963. Details on Page 59.

title: TOLLS INCREASED ON BERLIN ROUTES
description: BERLIN, April 28 The East German Government increased tolls on West Berlin's highway and canal access routes about 30 per cent todayon the day of a fourpower conference on improving the situation of the city.

title: A Raphael in Boston Arouses Skepticism
description: LONDON, April 28The Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum expressed skepticism today over the authenticity of the socalled Boston Raphael, a tiny por trait that has prompted debate in European art circles.

title: Antidrugs Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) President Nixon desig nated the week beginning May 24 as Drug Abuse Prevention Week and urged government and private groups today to focus attention on the dangers of experimenting with nar cotics.

title: Hanoi Names Victims
description: HONG KONG, April 28 (reu ters)  North Vietnam made public today the names of 129 Vietnamese and Chinese who were allegedly massacred in Prasault, in a Svayrieng Prov ince, April 9 by Cambodian troops on Government orders.

title: Agnew Says White House Is Neutral in Florida Race
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 28  Vice President Agnew said here today that the Nixon Ad ministration would stay out of what is shaping up as an ex plosive Republican primary bat tle for a Senate seat from Florida.

title: ROCKETS ROUT CAPS AND CAPTURE SERIES
description: DENVER, April 28 (A6)The Denver Rockets turned back the Washington Caps, 143119, to night and won the American Basketball Association's West ern Division semifinal series four games to three. The Rock ets will meet the Los Angeles Stars in the division finals.

title: Exchange Accused Of Bias in Banning Worker's Yarmulke
description: The New York Stock Ex change was faced yesterday with a complaint by an Ortho dox Jew that the exchange had refused to permit him to wear a yarmulke at work.

title: JOHN H. BUCHANAN
description: RED BANK, N. J., April 28 John H. Buchanan, retired pres ident of the Atlas Supply Com pany, a subsidiary of the Stand ard Oil Company (New Jersey), died yesterday in Riverview Hospital here. He was 73 years old and lived at 10 Ocean Boulevard, Atlantic Highlands.

title: Owners of Woolworth Building Call Landmark Law Onerous
description: Owners of the Woolworth Building, fighting a plan to designate the 60story struc ture as a landmark, attacked the city's landmark law yester day as onerous and discrimina tory.

title: Payments Deficits Large This Year, Reserve Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters)  The Federal Re serve Board said today that both the official settlements and liquiditybased United States balance  of  payments positions were registering large deficits in the early months of 1978.

title: U.S. Barring Newsmen From Cambodian Baffle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP)The United States command refused to day to permit American cor respondents to accompany American support units in the new Cambodian operation. Officers that that it was an operation directed by the South Vietnamese but that the South Vietnamese were making no press arrange ments either.

title: U.S. Eases Curb on Exports To Communist Countries
description: WASHINGTON. April 20 (AP) The United States lifted re. strictions today on 222 ite for export to almost all Corn munist countries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1970

title: President's Gamble Widen War to End It More Quickly
description: WASHINGTON, April 29As so often before in the Indochina war, an American President has chosen to expand the conflict in the hope of ending it more quickly.

title: Books of The Times
description: ONE flounders in these thousands pages. Aldous Huxley was not in the same league with Yeats and D. H. Lawrence as a letterwriter (nor as a poet, nor as novelist). On the evidence of Grover

title: Democratic Coalition Clubs Urged to Endorse Basel
description: Another Manhattan judge ship battle took shape yester day as the New Democratic Coalition backed Criminal Court Judge Amos S. Basel for the Surrogate's Court seat held by S. Samuel DiFalco, a candi date for reelection.

title: Consent Order is Accepted In Chrysler Credit Ad Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion provisionally accepted to day the first settlement of truth  in  lending charges against the Chrysler Corpora tion under the law that took effect last July 1.

title: Ability, Not Luck, Regarded in a Poll As Key to Success
MONTICELLO GETS NEW TOTE BOARD
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 29The smell of fresh paint is certain to be overcome by the smell of fresh money, when Monticello Raceway's 13th an nual openingLucky 13 is this year's slogan at the Sulli van County harness racing track begins here tomorrow night. Leon Greenberg, the president of the raceway, pre dicted today that 10,000 or more fans would turn out and Wager $500,000 or more on this earliest kickoff in the local oval's history.

title: Candidate Ambro Calls on Bigots to Stay Home
description: Jerome A. Ambro, who is seeking the Democratic nomina tion for Lieutenant Governor, said yesterday that he would reject any suppoit offered to him merely because I am white.

title: Population Explosion Recorded By Pharaoh Hounds in America
description: THE known United States population of Pharaoh hounds more than doubled last January when a litter of seven, bred by Mrs. Ruth Taft Hobbs of Bummet Brook Farm, Shrewsbury, Mass., was whelped. The litter was the first of the breed in this country. Before the popula

title: In The Nation Avoiding Mr. Nixon's Coattails
description: BOSTON, April 29One of a group of men strolling across the Boston Common in the spring sunshine at noon today was heard to declare There's no reason to get panicky but there's an awful lot to be de pressed about.

title: Mary Lambert, 1964 Debutante, Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Mary Robinson Lambert to William von Raab, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick von Raab of Roslyn, L. I., has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Lambert of New York and Old Black Point, Conn.

title: Knitwear Imports Hit Record Level
description: Imports of knitted outerwear  sweaters, shirts, dresses, playsuits and trousers  have reached record proportions and now are approaching close to half of domestic consumption.

title: Hanoi Leader Said to Go To Peking From Moscow

title: Richard Harris in 'Man Called Horse'
description: "A MAN CALLED HORSE" is Lord John Morgan (Richard Harris), an English aristocrat who is captured by Sioux Indians in the course of a hunting trip through the Dakotas in the early 19th century. Lord John not only survives his initial captivity but he goes on to prove his manhood so well that he eventually becomes a great white chief, the sort of superhero exalted by American romantics from James Fenimore Cooper to Edgar Rice Burroughs.The film, which was directed by Elliot Silverstein ("Cat Ballou," "The Happening"), places great stress on authenticity of ritual and language ("80 per cent of the dialogue," say my production notes, "is in Sioux, and in old Sioux at that!"), although a couple of odd faces turn upquite at homein the old Sioux camp.The ancient squaw, who looks like Mammy Yokum in a fright wig, is actually Dame Judith Anderson, whom publicists like to describe as one of the great actresses of the English-speaking theater. Here, however, she is restricted to speaking pure Lakotan, which sometimes sounds like Yiddish The Indian princess who wins Lord John's hand is played by Corrina Tsopei, a Miss Greece who went on to oblivion as Miss Universe of 1964.In these details, "A Man Called Horse" is conventionally absurd. However, Silverstein has elected to tell the story of Lord John's survival largely in terms of Sioux rituals relating to such things as wars, weddings, deaths, and even spiritual deliverance. I must admit that I found all this interesting, although I'm the sort of Indian buff and tourist who gets a kick out of watching contemporary Navajos do their rain dances in tennis shoes.There are no tennis shoes in "A Man Called Horse," but there is a good deal of blood, as well as an emphasis on salvation-through-mutilation.An old squaw acknowledges the death of her son by slicing off several fingers. Harris, whose performance is mostly one of endurance, shows himself worthy of an Indian bride, by allowing himself to be suspended by ropes attached animal bones that are, in turn, stuck through the skin of his chest. I would thus hesitate to recommend. "A Man Called Horse," which opened yesterday at the Astor and Loew's Orpheum Theaters, to small children, the audience for whom it was probably intended. On second thought, the children of my generation played with tomahawks, and I can't remember that we ever actually succeeded in scalping anybody.

title: Filmed 'Diary of a Schizophrenic Girl' Arrives
description: NELSO RISI'S "Diary of a Schizophrenic Girl" is based upon the autobiography of a schizophrenic patient, which was translated from the French, together with commentary by her analyst, Marguerite Sechehaye, and first published here 20 years ago. Although properly speaking a fiction film rather than a study of schizophrenia, it nevertheless involves considerable explanation of the disease and its treatment, mostly spoken by the therapist (Margarita Lozano) in insufficiently dramatized situations.They are, however, the only serious insufficiencies in a tactfully realized film, and, in context, even they are redeemed again and again by the clarity of Nelo Risi's images and the lucidity of Ghislaine D'Orsay's performance as Anna, the teenage girl who thinks herself a little rod of iron until her therapist's intensely personal treatment opens her to the demands and satisfactions of the external world.The other actors range from solidly professional (Miss Lozano) to stolidly amateur (Umbato Raho, as Anna's father), but Miss D'Orsay, in a beautiful and absolutely unsentimental projection of madness as a form of inwardness, excells every other performance I have seen in recent movies.As a director, Risi knows exactly how to leave her alone. Indeed, the camera often discovers her by withdrawing from herto present a world that is not her world but that nevertheless contains and somehow, awkwardly, sustains her. Set mostly in Lucerne, the location of Anna's clinic, and the home of her therapist, the film uses the city, its architecture, its streets, its lake, to support and differentiate its action. Often "Diary of a Schizophrenic Girl" is a joy to watch because it is visually so seemly, so decently balanced. And at its very best, as in the suicide attempt that follows a crisis in Anna's cure, it achieves a fine dramatic urgency largely granted it by the authority of so plain and forthright rhetoric.Perhaps you won't think you have too much of a good thing, some fool (not the composer of the good background music) has added a song for the opening and closing credits. Sung by Julius La Rosa, with lyrics that begin "If love can hurry home to some, why was love so slow to cometo Anna," it has nothing at all to do with the lovely small movie it frames.
